# 庄子翼

**Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries**
**Category: Masters, Section Fourteen**
*Zhuangzi Yi (Wings of Zhuangzi)*

**Abstract**

We, your ministers, respectfully note: *Zhuangzi Yi* comprises eight juan, with *Zhuangzi Quewu* (Omissions and Errors in the Zhuangzi) appended as one juan and supplementary materials as another, compiled by Jiao Hong of the Ming dynasty during the *wuzǐ* year of the Wanli era. Its structure mirrors that of his *Laozi Yi*. The preface lists twenty-two commentaries from Guo Xiang’s annotation onward, sixteen supplementary expositions from Zhi Dun onward, and eleven works on chapter divisions, phonology, and exegesis from Guo Xiang onward. Upon examination, only the works of Guo Xiang, Lü Huìqīng, Chǔ Bóxīu, Luó Miǎnxué, and Lù Xīxīng are cited extensively; the rest appear sporadically, serving merely to round out the roster of commentators.

It is further noted that Chǔ’s *Yihai* (Sea of Meanings) cites Wang Pang’s annotations on the Inner Chapters and Liu Gai’s on the Outer Chapters. The *Daoist Canon* additionally contains Wang Pang’s *Xinzhuan* (New Transmission) in fourteen juan—perhaps his earlier and later annotations differed, warranting their parallel inclusion? Here, only the congruent passages are incorporated, with the *Xinzhuàn* distinguished accordingly. Yet upon inspection, no separate "Pang annotations" exist beyond the *Xinzhuàn*. The *Yangsheng Zhu* (Maintaining Life) chapter cites one passage from Liu Gai, suggesting his commentary also covered the Inner Chapters—a perplexing inconsistency. Ming scholars, fond of parading erudition, often prove hollow upon scrutiny. Such was the intellectual climate of the Wanli era and beyond, rendering deeper inquiry futile.

Zhi Dun’s *Zhuangzi* commentary is unattested in earlier histories. His exegesis on the *Xiaoyaoyou* (Free and Easy Wandering) chapter, originally cited in Liu Xiaobiao’s commentary to *Shishuo Xinyu*, is here misattributed entirely to "Zhi Daolin’s annotations"—a sleight of hand typical of Ming scholars, unworthy of credence. Nevertheless, among Ming polymaths since Yang Shen, none surpassed Jiao Hong in breadth. Though tainted by Li Zhi’s heterodoxy—blurring Confucian and Mohist boundaries with errant arguments—he remained vigilant against Buddhist and Daoist excesses. Thus, his selections often capture Zhuangzi’s intent: while heterodox from a Confucian standpoint, they remain true to the Daoist tradition. Judged by its own standards, this work surpasses vulgar commentaries in scholarly rigor.

The appended *Zhuangzi Quewu* reproduces Chen Jingyuan’s *Nanhua Jing Jie* (Exegesis of the *Nanhua Jing*) in full, offering valuable reference material. The supplementary juan includes:
- Sima Qian’s *Biographies of Zhuangzi* and Ruan Ji
- Wang Anshi’s *On Zhuangzi*
- Su Shi’s *Record of the Zhuangzi Shrine*
- Pan You’s *Miscellaneous Writings on Parting with Wang Pang*
- Li Shibiao’s *Nine Discourses on Zhuangzi*

The *Song History: Bibliography* records Li Shibiao’s *Ten Discourses on Zhuangzi* in one juan; here, only nine survive, the reason unclear. Moreover, three of these discourses—*Jie Niu* (Dissecting the Ox), *Huzi*, and *Hao Liang* (The Hao River)—are already incorporated in the main text, yet reproduced in full at the end. Such inconsistency suggests hasty compilation without thorough revision.

Respectfully submitted in the eighth month of the forty-third year of the Qianlong reign.

**Chief Compilers:**
Minister Jì Yún
Minister Lù Xīxióng
Minister Sūn Shìyì

**Chief Collator:**
Minister Lù Fèi Chí

**Original Preface to the *Zhuangzi***

In the late Zhou, Laozi composed his book in two chapters, illuminating the meaning of Dao and virtue. His disciples included Guan Yinzi, Yang Zhu, Lie Yukou, Geng Cang, and Zhuang Zhou. Among these, only Yang Zhu left no writings. The *Liezi* emerged in the late Jin; its authenticity is suspect, likely padded with passages from the *Zhuangzi*. Thus, Sima Qian’s *Records of the Historian* omits Liezi’s biography. The *Geng Cangzi*, compiled by Wang Shiyuan of the Tang, and the *Guan Yinzi*—filled with infantile incantations and clay-idol sorcery—were absent in Laozi’s time, clearly later fabrications by Daoist adepts.

The *Zhuangzi* originally comprised fifty-three chapters; thirty-three survive today. The Outer and Miscellaneous Chapters contain dubious passages, but the Inner Chapters are unmistakably the work of Master Meng of Song. Thus, among Laozi’s disciples, only Zhuangzi’s writings endure.

Having compiled *Laozi Yi* in several juan, I turned to *Zhuangzi* commentaries, selecting the most congruent for this work, which I also title *Zhuangzi Yi*. Laozi and Zhuangzi relate as Confucius and Mencius do: Laozi and Confucius were contemporaries, as were Zhuangzi and Mencius. Confucius and Mencius never attacked Laozi or Zhuangzi. Yet scholars today clamor incessantly—why? Perhaps because Confucian teachings elaborate the "manifest" (*you*), while Lao-Zhuang texts expound the "latent" (*wu*), their divergence lying therein.

Alas! Confucius and Mencius did not neglect the *wu*; it is implicit in the *you*. They merely guided people from what was familiar—what is called "learning the lower to reach the higher." Laozi and Zhuangzi, witnessing how Confucian scholars remained confined to the *you* and few attained enlightenment, sought to transcend this limitation. Thus, they...

Having attained the *wu*, one may then employ the *you*—thus taking what was previously omitted and elaborating upon it, that it might nearly serve to supplement what Confucius and Mencius left incomplete. As for such matters as benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music—Confucius and Mencius have already expounded upon them at length. Why should I redundantly reiterate them? This, indeed, was the refined intent of Laozi and Zhuangzi, not their invention of some lofty doctrine. Otherwise, "that which is above form is called the Dao; that which is below form is called the implement"—this is the very teaching of Confucius and Mencius. Now, if one merely substitutes *Dao* and *implement* with *you* and *wu*, or inverts *above* and *below* into *subtle* and *wondrous*, the words differ, yet their meaning remains the same. To let the difference in words obscure the sameness of intent is but the self-inflicted malady of those who attack them—how could it ever harm Laozi and Zhuangzi?

Confucius, Mencius, Laozi, and Zhuangzi all lamented that scholars had strayed from their true nature, and so they composed writings to awaken them. Yet instead of returning to their nature, they clamor endlessly over distinctions of similarity and difference—such matters are beyond my comprehension.

Written on the Day of Humanity in the *wùzǐ* year of the Wanli era by Jiao Hong, styled Ruohou.

*Reading the Zhuangzi* [seven entries, recorded in *Literary Jottings*]

The *Zhuangzi* is a work that illuminates the Dao. The Confucians speak of the Dao yet do not depart from benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music; Zhuangzi, however, severs and discards them—one might suspect this is inconsistent. Yet even tiles, shards, husks, and chaff are none other than the wondrous Dao. Why then would benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music alone be excluded from its purview? Clearly, this does not accord with Master Zhuang’s intent.

Why is this so? Benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music *are* the Dao—but what the worldly Confucians call benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music are merely its traces. Clinging to these traces without understanding their origin, how can the Dao be made manifest? Thus, Zhuangzi had no choice but to cast them aside, that others might come to know the Dao.

This is like establishing images first, then transcending their constraints—only then can one realize that what one formerly grasped was of no true substance. Perhaps then one may advance and seek the Dao in earnest.

If one seeks and truly grasps it, one then realizes that images are none other than reality, and constraints are none other than principle—thus, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music need not be cast aside and abandoned. As Zhuangzi himself said: *"That which is distant yet cannot but be dwelled in is righteousness; that which is moderated yet cannot but be accumulated is ritual."* Scholars recognize one aspect but fail to see the other—how far they are from comprehending his words!

Laozi and Zhuangzi spoke extensively of the principle of emptiness and nothingness, not to abolish the teachings of the world, but because emptiness and nothingness are the very foundation upon which worldly teachings stand. Those who perceive only things cannot govern things, while those who perceive nothingness are sufficient to order being. Thus, the Dao is established in the constant alternation of non-being and being—otherwise, how could the sage’s work bring about transformation, enact change, and traverse the realms of ghosts and spirits? Yet if one demands of them a mind entangled in worldly clamor, how could they possibly succeed?

Laozi said: *"Hold to the ancient Dao to govern present being."* If what is called "present being" exists, then the ancient must have been non-being—this much is clear. To govern being, one must draw from non-being. How, then, can it be said that emptiness and nothingness abolish worldly teachings?

Thus, Shun’s *"governing through non-action"* was not a failure to govern, but governing through non-action. Yu’s *"acting without affairs"* was not a failure to act, but acting through non-affairs. Yet the benighted have come to equate pure discourse with the abandonment of affairs, as the scholars of the Jin and Song did—how far they have strayed!

Zhuangzi said: *"Water that is unmixed remains clear; when undisturbed, it is level. But if it is stagnant and blocked, it cannot become clear."* To mistake the abandonment of affairs for non-action is to stagnate and block it—how could it ever be as clear as water?

Sima Qian claimed that Zhuangzi *"slandered Confucius,"* and the world’s Confucians have largely echoed this view. Only Su Zizhan argued that *"in truth, he affirmed Confucius, though in form he did not."* Ah! Zizhan’s judgment truly grasped the marrow. Yet the world’s Confucians, ensnared by surface words, have never penetrated to its essence—how could they understand what Zizhan meant?

For what the world’s Confucians cling to are but the traces of Confucius, the dregs and husks. What Zhuangzi discussed was his essence. It is like Bian Que, who saw through walls to the five viscera and devised prescriptions. Two students learned from him: one could not see the viscera or diagnose illness, yet rigidly adhered to his teacher’s prescriptions; the other, like Bian Que, saw through walls to the viscera and composed prescriptions not necessarily derived from his teacher. Which would Bian Que have praised—the one who guarded his formulas, or the one who devised his own based on insight?

The Buddhist teachings on repaying kindness hold that those who revile the Buddha and curse the patriarchs are truly repaying their debt. If reviling and cursing are repayment, then those who take refuge and offer praise must be doubly indebted—yet who understands that reviling and cursing are the highest form of refuge and praise? Otherwise, when Qin Yi mourned Lao Dan, or when Zhuangzi wandered through the chestnut grove, were these not also acts of slander against Lao Dan and self-reproach? How could such interpretations be justified?

The *Records of the Grand Historian* states that Zhuangzi was contemporary with King Hui of Liang and King Xuan of Qi—yet in his writings, Wei Ying is none other than King Hui of Liang. It further claims that Zhuangzi debated Confucianism with Duke Ai of Lu, which would place him in the same era as Confucius. Though Sunshu Ao served as minister to King Zhuang of Chu before Confucius was born, and Yi Liao never held office in Chu, the text speaks of Confucius’s journey to Chu, where the people of Chu toasted him while Sunshu Ao stood holding the goblet and Yi Liao received the wine to offer libation. Such contradictions abound. Scholars have long questioned these discrepancies, yet Zhuangzi himself addressed them: “Nineteen out of twenty are parables; seventeen out of twenty are reiterations.” By “parables,” he meant borrowing others’ voices to lend credence to his own intent. If the intent alone is what matters, must the events themselves be true? Sima Qian observed that figures like *Weilei Xu* and *Kangsangzi* were mere fabrications, akin to the likes of *Master Nonexistent* and *Sir Vacuous*—yet to scrutinize them by dates and months is to mistake a fool’s dream for reality.

Nevertheless, Zhuangzi’s sole concern was affirming his own intent. Even if scholars were to recognize that names are not truly names and right and wrong are not truly right and wrong, they would still be following the very teaching of Master Zhuang. Su Zizhan defended Zhuangzi’s reverence for Confucius but doubted the authenticity of the *Robber Zhi* and *Fisherman* chapters, as if they alone truly slandered Confucius. Yet the *Yielding the Throne* and *Sword* chapters are shallow and far from the Dao. Reexamining the text, one finds the parable’s conclusion in the line: “When Yang Ziju journeyed west to Qin and met Laozi, those at his lodging welcomed him—his host held the mat, his wife the towel and comb, while the other guests yielded their seats and the stove-tenders withdrew from the hearth. On his return, they vied with him for seating.” Remove the *Yielding the Throne*, *Sword*, *Fisherman*, and *Robber Zhi* chapters to align with the *Liezi* passage: “When Lie Yukou journeyed to Qi, he turned back midway, saying, ‘I am astonished! I ate at ten porridge stalls, and five served me first.’ Then he understood and laughed, ‘This is surely one and the same lesson.’” Zhuangzi’s words were not yet finished, but the ignorant cut and pasted them into their own. Thus, in his *Eulogy for Prefect Xu Jun*, he wrote of “contending seats filling the hall” and “no longer five stalls serving first,” treating them as one event. Reading the parable in *Zhuangzi* alongside the two chapters in *Liezi* brings sudden clarity.

Now, the second chapter of *Liezi* begins with the story of Liezi’s porridge stalls, immediately followed by Yang Zhu’s contending seats—precisely matching Su Zizhan’s argument. Could it be that Su’s insight arose from this very passage? Generally, the marvels of Zhuangzi’s writings cannot be muddled by later generations; the differences in style and structure are discernible at a glance. Guo Xiang remarked, “Those with partial talent recklessly interpolate strange passages, such as the *Yan Yi*, *Xiu Zhi*, *Wei Yan*, and *You Fu* chapters, along with the *Wu Zixu* section—altogether, three-tenths of the text is spurious.” The *Book of Han*’s *Treatise on Arts and Letters* lists *Zhuangzi* in fifty-three chapters, corresponding to Sima Biao and Meng’s annotations. The language is often bizarre and fantastical, resembling the *Classic of Mountains and Seas* or divination manuals, leading commentators to take liberties in selection. Only the Inner Chapters remain consistent across all editions. Was this not what Su Zizhan meant by “the ignorant”?

The *Yan Yi*, *You Fu*, and other spurious chapters no longer survive. In Cui Zhuan’s edition of *Zhuangzi*, many passages differ. For instance:
*“The *Free and Easy Wandering* chapter: ‘The blind cannot appreciate the beauty of patterns; the deaf cannot appreciate the sound of bells and drums.’ Below: ‘One without feet cannot wear embroidered slippers.’*
*The *Equalizing Things* chapter: ‘Nothing is not so; nothing is impermissible.’ Below: ‘There is what is permissible in the permissible and impermissible in the impermissible; impermissible in the impermissible yet permissible in the permissible.’*
*The *Great and Venerable Teacher* chapter: ‘Riding the eastern ridge, Mount Jiwei, he joins the ranks of the stars.’ Below: ‘Born without parents, dead he ascends to the distant. After three years, his form vanishes—this speaks of the spirit beyond naming.’*
*The *Perfect Happiness* chapter: ‘Deep in sleep, suddenly awake; sweating profusely.’ Below: ‘Laughter comes before one can respond; joy before one can arrange it. Departing, transformation enters the vastness of heaven.’*
*One version reads: ‘Meeting an opponent, laughter comes before one can respond; joy before one can arrange it. Transformation departs, entering the boundless.’ Below: ‘Not yet male, drifting and sinking; drifting and sinking, not yet divining with milfoil and turtle shell. Divining with milfoil and turtle shell, entering the flowing vastness.’*
*The *In the World* chapter: ‘Knowing that Zeng and Shi are not the vanguard of Jie and Zhi.’ Below: ‘The mutual arising of being and non-being.’”*

Then how can Zeng and Shi, Jie and Zhi, not partake of both being and non-being? How could they not mutually grind against one another? Their differences, however, often persist. The transmitted *Outer Chapters* and *Miscellaneous Pieces* contain many passages revised by Guo Xiang—could this be his doing? Or was it some other meddler who falsely altered and interpolated them thus?

In *Laozi Zhigui* by Yan Junping, references to Zhuangzi abound. He writes:
A cart, though unharmed, overturns when a child drives it; though lofty, it plummets into ravines, and a thousand men cannot right it. An egg, unbroken, may yet be shattered by a single touch; once it becomes a soaring swan, beating its wings into the clouds, nets and arrows cannot reach it. A calf, while nursing, may be restrained by a single rope; when it becomes a bull, no snare can hold it. A tiger, seizing beasts and devouring oxen and horses, cannot be challenged by sword or shield.

Thus, a trickle of water, flowing long enough, becomes a river or sea; a small snake, if it does not die, transforms into a divine dragon. Accumulated goodness leads to good fortune, while minor evils, unchecked, bring ruin.

He further says:
That which makes me *me*—is it truly me? I am like the body, yet the body is not the body; the body exists because I am present. And that which makes me *me* exists because of spirit. The spirit that abides in me is made so by the Dao.

He further says:
The Dao’s generation, Heaven’s arising—all beginnings begin from non-beginning; life lives from non-life; existence exists from non-existence; perishing perishes from non-perishing.

He further says:
When blessings arise, benefits are born, achievements are completed, affairs are accomplished, resources are prepared, and uses are brought forth, men grow vastly wealthy and the world turns extravagant and transgressive. Yet wealth and goods never suffice, and the people grow ever more depraved. Blessings fill the mountains and marshes, gold and jade pile up in heaps, but the state grows ever more unstable and the people ever fewer. Profit adorns cunning, and men deceive one another, using fraud to bind one another. They block the paths of deviance and debauchery, yet the routes of treachery and villainy grow dense. They distinguish likeness and difference, right and wrong, in ever more numerous permutations—thus the state darkens and governance declines. They devise techniques and perfect skills, carving and polishing, adorning with patterns and colors, creating strange and monstrous novelties to glorify the virtuous and distinguish the noble from the base. Craft and deceit flourish, and the extraordinary grows ever more bizarre. Decrees multiply, rewards deepen, punishments grow harsh, and penalties sever. They hack at flesh and sever limbs, yet distant kin remain estranged and close kin grow discordant. Crimes lead to extermination, rewards to enfeoffment as marquises. Heaven and Earth quake in terror, yet thieves and bandits multiply.

He further says:
To eat twice as much when hungry, to drink twice as much when thirsty, to leap into water when overheated, to enter fire when cold—though one may remove the immediate cause, the body will surely die. A mass in the chest cannot be chiseled out; a disease in the throat cannot be scraped away. Mosquitoes alighting on the face cannot be shot; lice clinging to the body cannot be hacked apart.

He further says:
The rising and setting of the sun and moon share the same light; the death and life of men share the same form. The divisions of spring and autumn share the same benefit; the sage and the rustic share the same appearance. The open-minded and the narrow-minded share the same capacity; the Daoist adept and the infant share the same achievement. In all these cases, their inner natures differ while their outward manifestations are the same—none but the sage can discern this.

He further says:
Without yin, there is no yang, and the myriad things cannot be born; without yang, there is no yin, and the myriad things cannot be completed. The Way of Heaven and Earth begins with an end and ends with a beginning.

He further says:
The infant, though ignorant, is loyal and trustworthy even to enemies; yet when grown and possessed of understanding, he deceives his elder brothers and sisters-in-law. When the army prevails, he slays captives without mercy; the beast trapped in a ravine does not flee from rhinoceros or tiger. These are not changes in principle but in the nature of things.

The above passages are not found in the extant texts. According to the *Han shu: Yiwen zhi*, the *Zhuangzi* originally comprised fifty-three chapters. Guo Xiang excised its artful and miscellaneous portions, reducing it to thirty-three chapters—thus, what remains today is but four-tenths of the original. Yan’s work predates Xiang’s, and the passages he cites must have been from the lost chapters. Su Zizhan deemed the *Rangwang*, *Yu jian*, *Dao Zhi*, and *Yufu* chapters to be spurious; Luo Miandao further suspected the *Keyi* and *Shanxing* chapters as shallow and superficial, ultimately fixing the authentic text at twenty-six chapters. Broadly speaking, the refinement or crudeness of the language clearly distinguishes them. As for the passages cited by Junping, there is no doubt they were among those excised by Xiang.

Alas! Xiang was indeed a man of keen discernment. *Qinding Siku Quanshu*

*The Wings of Zhuangzi, Volume One*
*By Jiao Hong of the Ming Dynasty*
*Inner Chapters*
*Chapter One: "Free and Easy Wandering"*
[Guo’s commentary: Though small and great differ, when they roam in the realm of self-attainment, each thing employs its nature, each affair matches its capacity—all fitting their proper place. "Free and easy" is one and the same.
*Brush Notes*: "Free and easy" was anciently written as "dissolving and swaying." Huang Jifu explained: "Dissolving" is like yang moving and ice melting—though diminished, its root is never exhausted. "Swaying" is like a boat moving on water—though in motion, its interior is never harmed. Only one who embodies the Dao can wander through the world in this way.]

In the northern darkness there is a fish, and its name is *kun*. The *kun*’s greatness—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans. It transforms into a bird, and its name is *peng*. The *peng*’s back—no one knows how many thousand *li* it stretches. When it rises in fury and takes flight, its wings are like clouds hanging from the sky. This bird—when the sea surges, it will journey to the Southern Darkness. The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond.

*The Qi Xie* is a record of marvels. It says: When the *peng* journeys to the Southern Darkness, it strikes the water for three thousand *li*, whirls on the whirlwind and ascends ninety thousand *li*, departing on the sixth-month gale. Wild horses and dust motes—

The myriad creatures are blown along by the breath of life. Is the deep blue of the sky its true color? Or is it simply so distant that it has no end? From above, the *peng* gazes downward—it sees no more than this.

[The *ming* of the Southern Darkness means "boundless and without limit," as Ji Kang notes. Dongfang Shuo’s *Record of the Ten Continents* says its waters are black, hence the name *ming*. "Clouds hanging from the sky" means clouds at the edge, vast as the heavens themselves. *Qi Xie*, Sima, and Cui all refer to individuals; Emperor Jianwen speaks of a book. The "ascending wind" is called *fuyao*. The *Erya* says *fuyao* is a whirlwind. "Wild horses" are the *qi* between heaven and earth, galloping like untamed steeds. "Dust motes" are *qi* dense and swirling, like dust stirred into the air.]

Guo’s commentary: [The reality of the *kun* and *peng* is beyond my understanding. Zhuangzi’s great intent lies in wandering freely, embracing non-action, and finding contentment. Thus, he exhausts the extremes of small and great to clarify the fittingness of one’s nature. The discerning scholar should grasp its essential message and disregard its outward form. The *kun*’s transformation into the *peng* requires the boundless sea to bear its body, and ninety thousand *li* to support its wings—this is no mere love of the strange. It is simply that great things must arise in great places, and great places must give rise to such great things. A principle that is naturally so. With wings so vast, lifting is difficult; only by riding the *fuyao* can it ascend ninety thousand *li*. Once departed, it travels for half a year before reaching the Celestial Pond to rest. "Wild horses" are wandering *qi*. The *qi* of wild horses and dust motes are what the *peng* relies upon to fly. As for the deep blue of the sky—is it truly the sky’s true color, or merely its vastness without end? From above, the *peng* gazing down at the earth is like a person on the ground looking up at the sky. It turns southward, heedless of distance, driven only by what it can bear and where it must go.]

Lü’s commentary: [Wild horses and dust motes are the breath of life by which all creatures are blown along. This *qi* fills heaven and earth without gap, and humans dwell within it. From below, gazing upward, the sky appears deep blue—is this its true color, or is it simply so distant that it has no end? We cannot know. Because we cannot know, we do not take our place as "below," so how could the *peng*, from above, know what it means to be "high"?]

Oral exposition: [The *kun* and *peng*’s transformations are but a depiction of the boundless joy within. For those who see only the small, there is endless strife. But if one knows the world contains such vastness, one’s own body seems no more than a single grain in a granary. The *kun* and *peng* are metaphors for the flight of birds. The word "fury" alone makes it extraordinary. "Sea surges" means the sea moves—even today, coastal folk songs speak of the "sixth-month sea surge." When the sea stirs, great winds arise, its waters roiling from the depths, their sound heard for *li* around. Only such winds can carry the *peng* south. *Qi Xie* records strange and extraordinary things, like the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. "Three thousand *li*" and "ninety thousand *li*" merely describe its height and distance. "Departing on the sixth-month gale" means it flies for half a year before resting. The three lines about wild horses are set here to foreshadow what follows: when people look up at the sky, they see only its deep blue. Is this its true color? Or is it merely that our vision fails, and the sky has no end, so we see only a hazy expanse? When the *peng* flies to the heavens, gazing down, the distance to the earth is incalculable. The breath that blows wild horses and dust motes must appear just as hazy, like a person below looking up at the sky. These lines simply depict how high the *peng* flies.]

Personal observations: [What must transform cannot but transform; what must fly cannot but fly—all is moved by the mechanism of heaven. The transformed do not know it themselves. "Rising in fury" expresses the inevitability of movement when compelled by *qi*, swift and forceful as if enraged. It is not anger in the sense of resentment or injustice. All things that have lain hidden for long must burst forth; all that have been coiled for long must stretch. Is this weariness with the constant or delight in change? No—it is simply that when form is great and transformation fitting, it moves with the *qi* of yin and yang, waxing and waning, growth and decline, a principle inescapable. The *Qiwu Lun* speaks of the "ten thousand hollows roaring in fury"; the *Waiwu* chapter says "plants and trees grow in fury"—this is the same idea. The *Daodejing* says, "The ten thousand things arise together." Observing this, we understand the meaning of "resting in the sixth month." People see the fury but not the rest, know the arising but not the return. Thus, they turn away from the realm of carefree wandering and rush daily into the domain of striving, becoming entangled in affairs, ensnared by troubles, exhausted and adrift, not knowing where to return. Is this not lamentable? Master Guanyin said, "Though heaven and earth are vast, they can constrain the formed but cannot constrain the formless." To escape the constraints of the two *qi*, seek it in the time before the *ming* fish took shape.]

Supplementary notes: ["Departing on the sixth-month gale" and "the myriad creatures blown along by breath" both use *xi* in the sense of *qi*. Humans breathe as *xi*; creation breathes through the four seasons. "Departing on the sixth-month gale" refers to the great winds of the sixth month, which the *peng* uses to journey south. "The myriad creatures" is simply creation, with "born" replacing "made" for freshness. "Blown along by breath" echoes Laozi’s "Is not the space between heaven and earth like a bellows?" The various commentaries take "sixth month" as half a year and *xi* as rest, but this is because they have not considered the context.]

Moreover, when water accumulates, if it is not deep, it cannot bear a great boat.

When no force is applied to spill a cup of water upon the hall’s floor, a mustard seed may serve as its boat; yet place the cup there, and the water is too shallow for so large a vessel. If the accumulation of wind is not deep, it cannot bear great wings. Thus, only when one reaches ninety thousand *li* does the wind lie beneath—only then, borne upon the wind, with the blue sky at one’s back and no obstacle to bar the way, does one set out to journey south.

The cicada and the fledgling dove laugh at this, saying: “We burst forth in flight, striking the elm and sandalwood, yet sometimes fail to reach them and fall to the ground—what need is there to go ninety thousand *li* south?” One who travels to the outskirts need only pack three meals, and returns with belly still full; one who journeys a hundred *li* must pound grain the night before; one who travels a thousand *li* must gather provisions for three months. What do these two creatures know?

Small knowledge does not reach great knowledge; short years do not reach long years. How do we know this is so? The morning mushroom knows not dusk and dawn; the summer cicada knows not spring and autumn—these are short years. South of Chu there is the *fangling* tree, for which five hundred years make a spring, five hundred years an autumn. In high antiquity there was the great *chun* tree, for which eight thousand years make a spring, eight thousand years an autumn. Yet Pengzu alone is still renowned for his longevity—how sad that common folk compare themselves to him!

The *guobao* mushroom appears plump, the *dazhi* fungus grows beneath the sky’s shade—yet if exposed to sunlight, it perishes. Yang Shen notes: "The *chaojun* was originally written as *jīqūn*; in modern Yunnan, mushrooms are called *jīzōng*—this is it." The *huìgū* is the cold cicada, born in spring and dying in summer, or born in summer and dying in autumn. Pengzu, surnamed Jiān and named Kēng, was enfeoffed at Pengcheng by Yao and lived seven hundred years into the Shang dynasty.

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
The roc soars high because its wings are vast—thus it is. A small substance requires no great resource, just as a great substance cannot rely on what is small. Therefore, principle has its ultimate measure, things their fixed limits; each suffices for its task, and their success is one. Yet if one loses the master of life and pursues it beyond what is fitting—if affairs exceed one’s strength, if actions fail to match one’s nature—then even wings spanning the sky cannot escape exhaustion, nor can the swiftest flight avoid distress.

The reason the roc now plans its journey south is not that it craves height or admires distance, but that without accumulated wind, the path is blocked. Thus, for three meals, the farther one travels, the more provisions one must gather; the larger the wings, the thicker the qi must be. The "two creatures" refer to the roc and the cicada, the great contrasted with the small to show their differing inclinations.

Yet why do their inclinations differ? Not because they knowingly choose difference, but because each follows its nature unawares. This is the great meaning of *xiaoyaoyou*. The disparity in years and knowledge is so vast—compared to the sorrow of common folk, it is even more lamentable. Yet common folk never lament this, for each nature has its limit. If one knows this limit, then even the slightest excess is impossible; what in the world is there to grieve?

Things never shrink because they desire smallness, nor do they necessarily envy greatness. Thus, the distinction between small and great has its fixed measure, beyond the reach of envy or desire. Once the burden of envy and desire is severed, sorrow departs. With sorrow gone, how could one’s nature and life fail to be at peace? From this point onward, *Liezi* enumerates the varying scales of years and knowledge, each adhering to its own standard, none sufficient to overturn another. Only then does he unify them under the person free from dependence, who forgets the self and obscures these distinctions. All differences—whether of direction or kind—are equally attained, while I remain without merit or fame. Thus, the one who unites small and great is without small or great. If there were small and great, then even the great roc and the sparrow, the minister and the wind-rider, would alike be burdened by things.

The one who equalizes life and death is without life or death. If there were life and death, then even the great *chun* tree and the cicada, Pengzu and the morning mushroom, would be equally cut short. Therefore, to wander where there is no small or great is to be without limit; to be obscured in neither life nor death is to be without end. If *xiaoyaoyou* is bound to a particular realm, then even if one were set free to roam, there would still be an end—one would not yet be without action.

The newly transmitted passage states: *"Lesser knowledge does not reach greater knowledge; short years do not reach long years. Thus, the morning mushroom does not compare to the cicada, the *mingling* does not compare to the great *chun*, and the short-lived child does not compare to Pengzu. Yet when viewed through the principle of neither small nor great, neither death nor life, all are equally burdens of form—how then can there be any ‘not reaching’ or ‘not comparing’ among them?"*

Following the source:
The *tiao* and cicada: Those with black markings that sing in the fifth month are called *tiao*; those with speckled markings that sing after the seventh month are called cicadas; those with green markings are called *diaoliao* (sounding like *diao liao*). Some say they transform from dung beetles, water insects, or grubs. The *xue* mountain magpie is named for its resemblance to the turtledove in form.

The *xuejiu*: Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Monthly Commands* states: *"The singing turtledove resembles the mountain magpie but is smaller, with a short tail and dark blue-black color; it is very vocal. Now in Jiangdong it is called *guzhou* (sounding like *gu zhou*)."* The *Monthly Commands* says: *"In the second month of spring, hawks transform into turtledoves; in the second month of autumn, turtledoves transform into hawks."* The *Zuozhuan*’s *Shuangjiu* lineage—Du Yu’s commentary identifies it as the hawk. Because the two creatures transform into one another, the turtledove can be named after the hawk. These two insects, capable of transformation yet small, are thus contrasted with the *kun* and roc.

The *jun* are ground mushrooms. Large ones are called *zhong* [□], small ones *jun*. Mushrooms grow by the morning, hence "morning mushroom." The *huigū* is also a cicada. The *Tongzhi Lüe* states: *"The cold cicada is properly called *huigū*; in the ninth and tenth months, its cry is mournful and urgent."* The *Xiaoshan* says: *"The *huigū* cries, *jiujiu*; the year ends, and it cannot endure."* This refers to the small purple-green cicadas of the fourth and fifth months, as in Zhuangzi’s *"the *huizhan* does not know spring and autumn."*

*Ming* is the Southern Darkness; *ling* is the spirit turtle. The unicorn, phoenix, turtle, and dragon are called the Four Spirits. The *mingling* is the spirit turtle of the Dark Sea. The morning mushroom and the great *chun*, the *huigū* and the *mingling*—these pair one plant and one animal, making it clear that the *mingling* is not a plant.

*"Five hundred years as spring, five hundred years as autumn"*: The *Records of the Grand Historian* states that a thousand-year-old turtle measures one foot two inches; two five-hundred-year periods make up the thousand years. *"Eight thousand years as spring, eight thousand years as autumn"*: The character *chun* is split into two; eight hundred multiplied by ten yields two eight-thousand-year periods.

The *guji* and fabrications arise by chance—this is likely another case of the character *hai*’s two heads and six bodies, merely unrecognized by readers.

When Tang questioned Ji about this, Ji replied: Beyond the northern lands of bare wilderness lies the Dark Sea—the Celestial Pond. There is a fish there, spanning thousands of *li* in breadth, its length unknown; its name is Kun. There is also a bird, named Peng, whose back resembles Mount Tai and whose wings hang like clouds veiling the sky. It spirals upward on whirling winds like rams’ horns, ascending ninety thousand *li*, piercing the clouds and bearing the blue heavens on its back, then sets its course southward, bound for the Southern Dark.

The quail mocked it, saying: “Where does it think it’s going? I leap and bound upward no more than a few *ren*, then descend to soar among the mugwort and wormwood—this is the utmost of flight! Where does it think it’s going?” This is the distinction between small and great.

Thus, those whose knowledge suffices to fill an office, whose conduct matches a village’s standards, whose virtue pleases a lord, or whose ability wins a state—they regard themselves no differently. Yet even Song Rongzi would laugh at them. Though the whole world praised him, he would not be encouraged; though the whole world blamed him, he would not be disheartened. He had settled the division between inner and outer, discerned the bounds of honor and disgrace—this was all. In his relation to the world, he was not hasty. Yet even he had not yet attained the ultimate.

Liezi rode the wind and traveled, light and effortless, returning after fifteen days. In his pursuit of good fortune, he was not hasty. Yet though he avoided walking, he still depended on something.

Those who ride the constancy of Heaven and Earth, who harness the transformations of the six qi to wander through the boundless—what could they possibly depend upon? Thus it is said: the Perfect One is without self, the Spirit Man is without achievement, the Sage is without name.

Those who distinguish between inner and outer set the self within and things without; those who demarcate the realms of honor and disgrace exalt themselves and debase others—this is the furthest they can go. Those who do not frequently engage with the world are content with themselves and thus remain aloof from it. Yet this is still akin to one who has not yet crossed the ford: they merely affirm themselves but cannot yet embrace all without exception.

The demeanor of one who is serene and effortlessly refined—though they may return after fifteen days—still relies on something. Even one who rides the wind cannot circumnavigate the world in an instant; their movement, too, is natural, not something they strive after. Yet without wind, they cannot travel; thus, they must depend on something. Only those who ride nothing are without dependence.

Heaven and Earth are the collective names for the myriad things. Heaven and Earth take the myriad things as their body, and the myriad things must take spontaneity as their norm. Thus, the great Peng’s ability to soar high, the quail’s ability to fly low, the great tree’s ability to live long, and the morning mushroom’s brief span—all these are what spontaneity enables, not what effort achieves. Not acting yet able to do so is the norm. Therefore, riding the constancy of Heaven and Earth is to follow the nature of the myriad things; harnessing the transformations of the six qi is to wander the paths of change. Proceeding thus, where could there be an end? Whatever one encounters, one rides—what then could one depend upon? This is the freedom of those of utmost virtue, who merge self and other.

If there is dependence, then even the lightness and wonder of Liezi cannot travel without wind; only by obtaining what they depend upon can they be free. How much more so for the great Peng? Only those who merge with things and follow great transformation can be without dependence and ever-unobstructed—how could this be mere self-attainment? They also guide those with dependence to not lose what they rely upon; if what they rely upon is not lost, they too merge with the great unobstructedness.

Thus, I cannot equate the dependent and the independent. As for each resting in its nature, the heavenly mechanism unfolding spontaneously, receiving without knowing—I cannot distinguish between them. If even the independent are not sufficient to distinguish themselves from the dependent, how much less the vast and minute among the dependent?

There is no end, so one follows things to the utmost. When principle reaches its limit, traces vanish. Now, following without aiding becomes one with the ultimate principle—thus, there is no achievement. The Sage is merely the name for things attaining their nature; this is insufficient to name how they attain it.

Zhi Daolin:

The carefree wandering reveals the mind of the Perfected Person. Zhuangzi established his discourse on the great Dao and conveyed his meaning through the roc and the quail. The roc, with its vast path of sustenance, loses its ease beyond its own form; the quail, content in proximity, mocks what is distant, harboring self-conceit within. The Perfected Person rides the celestial norm and roams joyfully, unbounded in unfettered wandering. Things are things, yet he is not thinged by things—thus, he remains remote, beyond their grasp. Profound responses do not fail to arise swiftly, yet in their arising, he is carefree, nowhere unsuited. This is why it is called carefree wandering.

As for those with desires, when they attain what suffices, they are content in their sufficiency, delighting as if in natural spontaneity. Yet like the hungry who eat their fill or the thirsty who drink to satiety, how could they forget the steamed grains or abandon the goblet of fine wine? If it is not ultimate sufficiency, how can it be called carefree wandering?

Xu Xi:

The intent of the parable is entrusted to the *Qi Xie*, yet it remains insufficient, so it is further entrusted to Tang’s inquiry—"If you do not believe it, try verifying it with so-and-so." Song Rongzi may have achieved this, yet he has not attained carefree wandering. Even Liezi, who rode the wind, reached this point, yet still did not attain carefree wandering. Only when one is utterly without dependence can it be called wandering. Thus, the earlier words about "riding the wind" still do not qualify as carefree wandering. The roc marks the beginning of wandering—ten thousand *li* from home, one first glimpses the sky’s hue, yet by the time one arrives, even the roc is no longer worth mentioning. The unplanted tree still leans upon something; it has not yet departed from...

Is this not the realm of right and wrong? Yet one who is *lingran* (serenely detached) dwells beyond the world’s right and wrong. To govern *qi* through form is still not to depart from *qi*. Only by riding the uprightness of Heaven and Earth does one stand at the origin of the ten thousand things—above the single *qi*, where there is no yin, no yang, no wind, no rain, no darkness, no light. Though Heaven and Earth arise together with me, the ten thousand things and I alone stand independent—not by entrusting form to another.

The perfected person has no self; how much less do they have achievements or fame?

---

**New Transmission:**
The Kun-peng’s southward flight and the quail’s leaping differ in scale, hence the saying: "This is the distinction between small and great." Yet the Kun-peng and the quail each possess their own form, which is why they do not attain carefree wandering. But does carefree wandering truly depart from the original body? Rather, each obscures its limits equally—whether carefree or burdened, whether at ease or in distress, the difference lies solely in whether one is enlightened or not.

---

**Brush Jottings:**
The perfected person knows the Dao, inwardly obscuring all thoughts until they vanish without reliance—hence "no self." The spirit-person exhausts the Dao, accomplishing the ten thousand things with wondrous efficacy deeply concealed—hence "no achievement." The sage forgets the Dao, their divine transformations vast and unfathomable—hence "no name."

---

Yao offered the world to Xu You, saying: "The sun and moon have risen, yet the torch-fire still burns—is it not difficult for its light to compare? The timely rain has fallen, yet you still irrigate—is it not laborious for its moisture to compare? You stand and the world is governed, yet I still occupy the throne. I see myself as lacking—please take the world."

Xu You replied: "You govern the world, and the world is already governed. Yet I would still replace you—would I seek fame? Fame is but the guest of reality; would I seek to be a guest? The wren nests in the deep forest, yet needs only a single branch; the mole drinks from the river, yet needs only a bellyful. Return, my lord—what use is the world to me? If the kitchen chef does not prepare the food, the invocator at the sacrifice does not step beyond the wine vessels and sacrificial stands to take his place."

*(Xu You, a man of Yangcheng in Yingchuan, styled Wuzhong, withdrew to Mount Ji. *Jue* means torch-fire; *jiaoliao* is a small bird; *yan shu* is the mole.)*

---

**Guo’s Commentary:**
One who can govern the world does not govern the world. Thus Yao governed by not governing—this is not governing yet governing. Now, Xu You clearly saw that the world was already governed, so there was nothing for him to replace. The governance truly belonged to Yao, hence Xu You’s words: "You govern the world." Governance arises from non-governance, issuing from non-action. Yao’s attainment was sufficient—what need had he of Xu You? To claim that one must withdraw to the mountains and forests to be called "non-action" is the talk of Laozi and Zhuangzi, which is why it is rejected by those in power. Those in power remain fixed in the realm of action and do not return.

One who takes on burdens responds to things; one who flows with things is without opposition to them. Thus Yao was without opposition to the world, and Xu You was a peer to Hou Ji and Qi. Why say this? Because one who guards against things cannot be separated from the multitude of things. Thus, with a mindless and dark responsiveness, one follows only what is felt—adrift like an untethered boat, east or west is not of one’s own doing. Therefore, one who takes no action yet shares all with the people also goes nowhere without being the lord of the world. To be a lord in this way is like the height of Heaven—truly the virtue of a lord.

If one stands alone atop a high mountain, guarding the bias of a single household, one remains but a common thing among the vulgar, an outer minister to Yao. If such an outer minister were to replace the inner ruler, one would have the name of a lord without the responsibility of a lord.

The wren settles on a single branch; the mole drinks its fill—each speaks to the nature of things having its own limit. If one is content within that limit, then the wealth of the world becomes surplus. The two lines "retire in peace" and "equally useless" show that Yao alone possessed them, revealing that one who embraces openness has no fixed bounds, and thus the world delights in elevating him without weariness.

The cook and the ancestral priest each abide in their appointed roles; birds, beasts, and the myriad things each find sufficiency in what they receive. Emperor Yao and Xu You each rest in what they encounter—this is the utmost reality of the world. When each attains their reality, what more is there to do? Simply to be self-content. Thus, though Yao and Xu You differ like Heaven and Earth, in their freedom they are one.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
From Yao’s perspective, though Xu You practiced non-action, he was never incapable of action. Thus, Yao offered the world to him without hesitation. From Xu You’s perspective, though Yao desired action, it always arose from non-action. Thus, when the world was already well-governed, he refused to accept it. To take the world through non-doing and thereby govern it—this is the true essence of non-action. Once the world is governed, if I were still to take its place, it would be as if seizing the world to act upon it, and one would soon find it unmanageable. This would be claiming the name of non-action while missing its reality. Since the name is but the guest of reality, would I willingly pursue it?

Therefore, when one acts, the Nine Provinces and Four Seas gladly elevate him without feeling it excessive; when one does not act, a single branch or a full belly brings retirement without feeling it insufficient. This is why the world’s affairs are of no use to Yao and Xu You, and why they attain freedom. When acting, Yao ruled as Son of Heaven and possessed all under Heaven without excess; when not acting, Xu You lived as a commoner, retiring to Mount Ji without want. Taking Xu You as an analogy for Heaven’s workings—like the sun and moon, timely and correct. Taking Yao as an analogy for human endeavor—like a torch’s flicker or irrigation’s slow spread.

Yao, knowing Xu You could govern the world, dared not claim his place; Xu You, knowing Yao could govern the world, refused to replace him. Then who shall govern the world? If governed by Yao, it is action within non-action; if governed by Xu You, it is non-action within action. For the Dao in the sage appears as Yao when manifest and as Xu You when hidden—

Yan Wu asked Lian Shu, saying: "I heard Jie Yu’s words—they are vast yet without measure, boundless and never returning. I am startled and terrified by them, for they seem as the Milky Way, without end. They are so extreme, so far from human sentiment—how can this be?"

Lian Shu said: "What did he say?"

Yan Wu replied: "On the distant Mount Miaogu Ye, there dwells a spirit-person. Their skin is like ice and snow, their bearing supple as a maiden’s. They eat no grain, but drink the wind and sip the dew. They ride the clouds and qi, driving flying dragons to wander beyond the Four Seas. Their spirit is so concentrated that things suffer no blight, and the harvests ripen. Yet I deem this mad and cannot believe it."

Lian Shu said: "Indeed. The blind cannot partake in the sight of patterns, nor the deaf in the sound of bells and drums. Is it only the body that may be blind and deaf? The mind, too, may suffer this. Such words as these are timely, yet it is you who are blind and deaf. That person, that virtue—it pervades all things, uniting the world as one. Who, then, would trouble themselves with the world’s disorder? Those who take the world as their burden—nothing harms them. The greatest floods rise to the heavens, yet they do not drown; the fiercest drought melts metal and stone, scorches mountains and earth, yet they do not burn. Their dust and chaff could mold even Yao and Shun. Who would trouble themselves with things?

The people of Song carried ceremonial caps to Yue, but the Yue, with shorn hair and tattooed bodies, had no use for them. Yao governed the world’s people and brought order to all within the seas. Yet when he went to see the Four Masters on Mount Miaogu Ye, by the northern banks of the Fen River, he was suddenly lost to the world, his mind adrift in the boundless dark.

Jie Yu was a man of Chu, surnamed Lu, named Tong. *Naoyue* means supple and yielding; *shi nü* refers to the present moment—here, *nü* is the character for 'you,' meaning that wisdom, too, has its blindness and deafness, and it is you who are mad and disbelieving. Guo’s commentary, which likens this to a maiden sought by many, is mistaken. *Bi bi* describes ceaseless striving; *ji* means to reach. *Zi* means to carry goods; *zhang fu* are Yin dynasty caps. The Four Masters, as Sima and Li both note, are Wang Ni, Nie Que, Pi Yi, and Xu You.

Guo’s commentary: These are but figures of speech—the spirit-person is the sage. Though the sage may sit in the halls of power, their heart is no different from one dwelling in the mountains and forests. How could the world recognize this? They see only the yellow canopy and jade seals and think these enough to bind the sage’s heart. They see the sage traversing mountains and rivers, sharing in the people’s affairs, and think this enough to weary their spirit. How could they know that the most perfect remains unharmed?

Now, to speak of one of kingly virtue and place them on this mountain is to show that the world has no way to recognize them. Thus, they are set beyond the farthest reaches, beyond sight and hearing. The maiden does not let the outer harm the inner. Not eating grain but drinking the wind and sipping the dew shows that the spirit-person is not sustained by grain but by the wondrous qi of nature itself. Those who embody the spirit, dwell in the numinous, and fathom the profoundest principles—though they may sit quietly in their halls, their mystery is as boundless as the Four Seas. They ride the Two Modes and command the Six Qi, guiding the multitude and driving the ten thousand things. If nothing is not in accord, then floating clouds become their steed; if no form is not borne, then flying dragons become their chariot. They forget the self and attain spontaneity, moving as if dragging a withered tree, resting as if a heap of dead ashes. Thus it is said: their spirit is concentrated. When their spirit is concentrated, what is not concentrated attains its own harmony.

The world judges by what it sees—how could it ever believe this? Not knowing the subtlety of such perfect words, they deem them mad and refuse to believe. This is the blindness and deafness of wisdom. 'Such words are timely, yet it is you'—this means that Jie Yu’s words naturally seek things, but those blind and deaf in wisdom deny their truth.

The sage’s heart encompasses the utmost meeting of the Two Modes and fathoms the wondrous numbers of the ten thousand things. Thus, they embody transformation and harmonize with change, nowhere unwelcome. Pervading the ten thousand things, nothing is not so. The world, in its disorder, seeks them, but they are without intent. If they are without intent, why would they not respond to the world? Their way of uniting the natures of the ten thousand things and molding the world to achieve the governance of Yao and Shun is always to act by not acting. Who would exhaust themselves in striving, laboring the spirit and toiling the mind, taking affairs as their affair, and only then succeed?

'Nothing harms them'—this means that when one is at ease with what harms, harm cannot harm; when harm cannot harm, things do not harm them. Wherever one goes, all is fitting; life and death hold no change for them—how much less drowning or burning? Thus, the perfected do not cling to misfortune and calamity—not by avoiding them, but by following principle straight ahead, naturally meeting with good fortune.

Yao and Shun are but names for worldly affairs. To be named is not to be the name itself. Thus, Yao and Shun are not merely Yao and Shun—they must possess the reality of the spirit-person. What we call Yao and Shun are but the dust and chaff of their names. Yao’s uselessness to the world is like the Yue’s uselessness for ceremonial caps. Yet those who abandon the world are revered by the world. Though the world reveres Yao, Yao never possessed the world. Thus, he was suddenly lost to it, ever roaming his heart in the darkest depths. Though seated above the ten thousand things, he was never not free.

The Four Masters are but figures of speech to show that Yao was not confined to being Yao. Yao was truly guarded, yet his traces were those of Yao. The world sees only Yao as Yao—how could they know his mystery? Thus, they seek the Four Masters beyond the seas and judge Yao by what they see, claiming that those who flow with things lose their freedom. Yet they do not know that what seems most distant is in truth nearest, and what seems highest is in truth lowest.

If one clings to solitary loftiness as perfection and does not level with the common, they are but a hermit of the mountains and valleys—not one who is without dependence. How could they speak of the utmost and wander the infinite?

Fan Wu Yin: The mountain is an analogy for the body; *Miaoshe* speaks of its seclusion. The spirit-person is the utmost numinous within the body. If one seeks this utmost numinous within the secluded depths, then not eating grain, drinking the wind and sipping the dew, riding clouds and driving dragons to wander the Four Seas is no exaggeration. Yet to seek it outside is to go far indeed.

Guan Jian: Their skin like ice and snow—embodying pure simplicity, no dust can defile them.

Graceful as a maiden, she guards her softness to preserve her wholeness—harm cannot reach her. By not eating grain but drawing in the wind and sipping the dew, she severs worldly flavors to embrace heaven and earth’s pure chill. Riding clouds and driving dragons to wander the Four Seas, she soars through the vastness of space, merging with the primordial qi’s obscurity—this is what is meant by "arriving without traveling" and "roaming with the Creator." Her spirit congeals, preventing blight and pestilence so that the harvest ripens. This is the utmost of nurturing the spirit: not only preserving oneself but also aiding heaven and earth’s transformative nurturing and assisting the spontaneity of the myriad things. Such words reveal the effect of extending oneself to benefit others, thereby uniting with the unfathomable spirit and aligning with the boundless Dao.

Yet some, misled by names and appearances, seek this mountain beyond the furthest reaches—thus the so-called spirit-person becomes ever more distant. Moreover, the saying that "dust, grime, chaff, and husks mold Yao and Shun" seems to belittle them, but upon examining the classics and their safeguards, one finds the highest reverence. What the world calls Yao and Shun, extolling them as sages, merely praises their dust and chaff. How could the true essence of Yao and Shun be captured in mere names?

Xun Ben: *"Great divergence"*—*jing* refers to the path before the gate, and *ting* to the ground outside the hall. Though path and courtyard are not far apart, Jie Yu’s words differ so greatly from ordinary speech that they seem as distant as path and courtyard—unlike the usual proximity of path and courtyard.

Hui Zi said to Zhuangzi: "The King of Wei gave me a large calabash seed. I planted it, and it grew to hold five *dan*. When filled with water, its strength could not support itself. When split to make ladles, its hollowness left no place to contain anything. It was not that it wasn’t resoundingly large—it was simply useless, so I smashed it."

Zhuangzi replied: "You are indeed inept at putting great things to use. There was a man from Song skilled in making a salve that prevented chapping. For generations, his family made a living by washing silk floss. A traveler heard of this and offered a hundred gold pieces for the recipe. The family gathered and deliberated: 'For generations, we’ve washed silk floss and earned no more than a few pieces of gold. Now, in one morning, we can sell this skill for a hundred gold. Let’s give it to him.' The traveler acquired it and presented it to the King of Wu. When Wu and Yue were at war, the King of Wu made him a general. In winter, he engaged Yue in a naval battle and decisively defeated them. A portion of land was carved out and bestowed upon him. The ability to prevent chapping was the same, yet one man was enfeoffed while another could not escape washing silk floss—the difference lay in how it was used.

Now you have a five-*dan* calabash. Why not consider making it into a great float to drift upon the rivers and lakes? Instead, you worry that its hollowness leaves no place to contain anything—your mind is still as tangled as a clump of weeds!"

Hui Zi said to Zhuangzi: "I have a large tree—people call it a *chu*. Its massive trunk is gnarled and does not meet the inked line; its smaller branches are twisted and do not conform to compass or square. Standing by the road, no carpenter would glance at it. Now your words are grand but useless—everyone rejects them alike."

Zhuangzi replied: "Have you never seen a wildcat or a weasel? They crouch low to ambush their prey, leaping east and west, dodging high and low, only to be caught in a trap or die in a net. Then there is the yak, as vast as a drifting cloud—great indeed, yet it cannot catch mice. Now you have a large tree and fret over its uselessness. Why not plant it in the land of Nothingness, the vast wilds of boundless expanse? Wander idly by its side, roam carefree beneath it, sleep undisturbed under its branches. No axe will fell it prematurely, and nothing will harm it. If it is of no use, where is the hardship in that?"

[Annotations in the original text retained for context but not translated as per guidelines:]

Hui Shi, surnamed Hui and named Shi, served as Prime Minister of Liang. The *gourd that holds five piculs*—as Sima [Biao] notes, "holds five piculs within" and is *huoluo* (vast and hollow), meaning broad and empty. The *xu* (floss) is called *kuang*; the *zun* (goblet) resembles a wine vessel, its body floating upon rivers and lakes, allowing one to cross on one’s own—this is a matter of contemplation.

"Waiting for prey" means lying in wait for soaring creatures to feed upon them. "Nothingness" and "boundless expanse" refer to a desolate, useless land.

Guo’s commentary: "The medicine enables hands not to chap, so one constantly floats floss in water. The *peng* is not merely a vessel for direct use. This speaks of things great and small: if they lose their proper measure, the principles of benefit and harm are the same. When use is found in their proper place, all things wander freely."

Lü’s commentary: "Dao, as a term, is one. If not used well, it is insufficient even to sustain the four limbs—thus, generation after generation, washing floss brings no more than a few coins. If used well, it not only sustains the self but even when the world is drowning, one may still save it—this is like using it in naval battles or splitting the earth to establish fiefdoms. Pour into it, and it does not fill; ladle from it, and it does not empty."

The unexhausted—this too is man’s rivers and lakes. Now you possess a great vessel yet cannot float it in a vast expanse, fretting that it has no place to hold things—this is called a *peng*-bound heart. How fitting! Things take usefulness as their use: when used in small ways, they take uselessness as their use; when used in great ways, the leaping weasel and squirrel die in nets and snares, unable to be effortless, and so perish through cunning and skill—this is the analogy. The yak is vast yet cannot catch mice; to roam effortlessly, to preserve its form and life—this is the analogy. The sage’s relation to the Dao is to embody it with deep roots and firm stem, so that as a tree, it is great indeed. Those who wish to fell it would do best to return and seek their own hearts. The heart, as a thing, no one knows its abode; find its unknowable place and rest in it—this is the tree’s dwelling in the land of nothingness. Fill it, and it grows ever vaster; still it, and the ten thousand things cannot disturb it. Roam freely at its side, sleep beneath it—never for a moment is it apart. Then where is the distress in what is called great yet useless? Why do you fret over it?

Chen Xiangdao’s commentary: "Things have their proper place; affairs have their fitting application. The trouble lies in not using them well. The medicine that prevents chapped hands is one and the same: the Song people used it for small profit, the Wu people for great. The strategies of the Seven Warring States were one and the same: when Chao Cuo used them, disaster arose; when Zhufu Yan used them, chaos ceased. Is the use of the great gourd any different? The gourd is hollow within and good for holding things, round without and good for floating. Set it on the ground, and it loses its floating nature, its firmness unable to lift itself. Split it to make a ladle, and you destroy its roundness, leaving the gourd fragments with nothing to contain. But if you consider it as a flagon and float it on rivers and lakes, it lifts itself without effort, fitting everywhere without hindrance. Generally, small things are easy to use, while great things are hard to use. Yet human nature is skilled in using small things but often clumsy with great ones, finding them difficult. To handle them with skill rather than following their nature and letting principle guide—who can compare to one who sheds the burden of a *peng*-bound heart? The weasel and squirrel are small and useful, yet cannot escape disaster; the yak is large and useless, yet nothing harms it. Thus, the use of usefulness does not surpass the use of uselessness. The great catalpa is useless—yet if you plant it in a place of uselessness, the planter may wander freely, and those who wish to fell it are spared the axe’s harm. How can this compare to those who turn and twist on the path of profit and harm, battered by the俗世? They are not even worth mentioning in the same breath."

Xun Ben’s commentary: "This chapter is titled *Free and Easy Wandering*, yet the entire piece is threaded through with a single word: *transformation*. The first section speaks of the roc and the peng, the cicada and the quail, the sparrow—each transforms differently in size, so their flight varies in height. The second section speaks of Heaven’s transformations, which also differ in size, so their free and easy wandering varies in excellence. The third section speaks of how, if one can transform the useless into the useful, one may also wander freely and easily. What Heaven bestows has its fixed allotment—how can the cicada, quail, and sparrow be forced to match the roc and peng? Yet for humans, whether wise or foolish, worthy or unworthy, all may ascend the great Dao. Still, some see themselves as cicadas, quails, or sparrows. Thus, at the chapter’s end, it enlightens them: though a man may be like a hollow gourd too cumbersome to lift, or a gnarled, twisted catalpa, if he can follow its nature and use it according to circumstance, transforming with the moment—how could he lose his free and easy wandering?"

*Bishu* commentary: "The Master said, 'I am truly clumsy at using great things.' The reply: 'It is the difference in how they are used.'"

For human nature is fundamentally one—yet the use of it differs. When used with skill, one attains free and easy wandering; when used clumsily, one is bound and constrained. This is precisely what Confucius meant when he said, "By nature, men are close; by practice, they grow far apart." The land of Nothing-Whatsoever, the wilds of Boundless-Expanse—this is the use that is no-use, the true place of return. Thus the matter is concluded by way of use.

*General Observations in My Humble View*:
Those who follow the utmost principle find the Dao pervading all things; those who preserve their original nature move in harmony with the world. Once one attains the single Heavenly principle, how could one fail to wander freely and easily? The mind of the infant is originally without knowledge; as form grows, knowledge expands, and contact with things begins. Gain and loss lodge in the heart, ice and fire contend within—abandoning this, laboring for that, without respite. If one does not illumine principle with perfect clarity and let the power of Dao prevail, even those of the highest rank and greatest wealth cannot escape entanglement. Thus the essential task in learning the Dao is first to seek the joy of the sages and worthies, to embody and thoroughly investigate it. As the *Book of Changes* says, "Rejoice in Heaven and know fate"; Yan Hui found joy in his gourd bowl and bamboo cup; Mencius nurtured his vast qi until it filled Heaven and Earth; Yuan Xian sang as he walked, his voice ringing like metal and stone. All these transcended the burdens of external things, preserved their Heaven-given nature, and in action or stillness, going or staying, knew no joy but this—only thus can one speak of free and easy wandering.

The kun of the Northern Darkness transforms into the roc, riding the wind to strike the waters and migrate to the Southern Darkness. This illustrates how scholars, confined by narrow learning and petty concerns, lose sight of the profound clarity of the sea of nature and sink the pearl of fate into oblivion. Thus the text presents this great creature born in a vast place to clarify the origin of one’s own being. With long cultivation, body and spirit unite, and one emerges from yin to enter yang—its use unfathomable. Those who "take knowledge as their office, conduct as their norm, virtue as their match, or ability as their measure" will awaken to the lightness of external things and the weight of one’s own Heavenly nature. Then, nurturing the wind and soaring beyond the clouds, they merge with the boundless transformation—what worldly burden could reach them? Only when one rides Heaven and Earth, harnesses the six qi, and roams the infinite can one attain the ultimate in free and easy wandering. The utmost in spiritual sageliness is nothing but complete fusion and transformation—fame and achievement are but external things.

The chapter where Yao offers the throne to Xu You serves to confirm the preceding meaning, fostering a spirit of humility and warning later generations against coveting external pursuits. It greatly benefits the governance of the Dao. When Jian Wu hears the words of Jie Yu, the secrets of the spirit-person are revealed, illustrating that the utmost numinous power within the body must be cultivated through preservation and nurturance—it is not to be sought far away. "Dust and grime, chaff and husks, can be molded into Yao and Shun"—this speaks of the spirit-person’s virtue, which moves in accord with Heaven. Even its remnants suffice to bring about the governance of Tang and Yu, yet its true essence is beyond the ken of worldly people.

When Yao went to see the Four Masters on the distant Guye Mountain, the subtle principle could not be fathomed by conjecture—one must personally reach Guye. The Four Masters need not be described; let scholars take heed. This chapter begins with discussions of the kun and peng, the cicada and quail, the divine tree and the morning mushroom, all exploring the principle of knowing fate in terms of great and small. At its close, it presents the great gourd, preserving itself through emptiness within, and the massive catalpa, securing itself through deep roots—metaphors for fully realizing one’s nature to the utmost of fate, achieving the great completion of learning the Dao and entering the realm of the spirit. Without haste, one moves swiftly; without going, one arrives—where could one not wander freely and easily?

**Chapter Two: On the Equality of Things**

**Guo’s Commentary:** From one’s own perspective, this is right and that is wrong; one praises oneself and disparages others—none fail to do so. Yet though right and wrong differ, self and other are equal. *Jingchuan’s entire discourse argues that fundamentally there is no right or wrong, for right and wrong are all made by man.*

---

Nanguo Ziqi sat leaning against his table, gazing upward and exhaling with a sigh, as though he had lost his counterpart. Yan Cheng Ziyou stood in attendance before him and asked, “What is this? Can the body truly be made like withered wood, and the heart like dead ashes? Yet the one who now leans here is not the same as the one who leaned here before.”

Ziqi said, “Yan, is this not well asked? Now I have lost my self—do you understand? You have heard the *human pipes*, but not the *earthly pipes*; you have heard the *earthly pipes*, but not the *heavenly pipes*.”

Ziyou said, “May I ask the method?”

Ziqi said, “The great clod breathes forth *qi*—its name is wind. This only arises when there is no activity; when it acts, the myriad hollows roar and howl. Have you alone not heard its long, rushing sound? The towering peaks and forests, the lofty trees of a hundred spans—all their hollows resemble noses, mouths, ears, beams, rings, mortars, pits, or pools. Some gush, some whistle, some hiss, some inhale, some cry, some wail, some moan, some sob. The gentle breeze brings a small harmony; the whirlwind, a great harmony. When the fierce gale subsides, all hollows fall silent—have you alone not seen their quivering, swaying motion?”

Zifang said, “The *earthly pipes* are simply these myriad hollows; the *human pipes* are but the joined bamboo. May I ask about the *heavenly pipes*?”

Ziqi said, “The wind blows in ten thousand different ways, yet each finds its own cessation. Who stirs them to such fury?”

The dissolution of form is but the pairing of semblances—some say it is the body, for body and spirit form a pair, vast as the great expanse of heaven. *Wei* resembles towering mountains and hills; *jī*, *bó*, and *lú* are brackets and capitals. *Yǎo* means deep; *yǎo*, a sound of sorrowful grief.

Guo’s commentary: “Since heaven and humanity are equal, self and other alike, nothing external remains to bring joy—thus one dissolves in stillness, as if losing one’s mate. Like withered wood or dead ashes, it speaks only of desolation and the absence of feeling. Those who follow nature and forget right and wrong rely solely on their innate truth—what else could they possess? Thus, their stillness resembles a withered tree, their movement drifting dust; in their bearing of motion and rest, I cannot find unity. In their effortless attainment of the uncontrived, I cannot find a second way. I have lost my self, and my self has forgotten itself—what in the world remains to be known? Only when all within and without is forgotten can one transcend and attain all.”

*Lài* means flute. Flutes and pipes, varying in length and pitch, produce myriad sounds of differing registers, yet the measure they receive is one. Thus, no distinction of superiority or inferiority arises among them. How much more so with the winds and things: though their sounds differ, all arise from their own accord. Herein lies the *heavenly pipes*.

A clod is nothingness; the sighing of breath—how could it be a thing? Qi simply sighs of itself, clod-like. All things that come to life do so clod-like, arising of themselves—thus the greatness of the clod-like body. Hence, it is called the *Great Clod*. The roaring of the long wind is the stirring of the mighty gale. From the nose and mouth onward, the text briefly lists the forms of the myriad hollows; from the rushing and whistling onward, it briefly lists their differing sounds. As for *yú*, it speaks of the harmony of notes: though the sounds of gong and shang transform endlessly, in their calls and responses, great and small, none fail to match what they receive, each fitting its proper place. *Jì* means cessation. When the fierce wind arises, the myriad hollows are full; when it ceases, they are empty. Though emptiness and fullness differ, in each attaining its own, they are the same. *Tiáotiáo diāodiāo* describes a quivering, swaying appearance: though the sounds of things differ, the movements of their forms likewise vary. Though their movements differ, in their attainment of equality, they are one. How could *tiáotiáo* alone be right and *diāodiāo* alone be wrong?

“The wind blows in ten thousand different ways, yet each finds its own cessation”—this is the *heavenly pipes*. Are the *heavenly pipes* some separate thing? They are nothing but the myriad hollows, the joined bamboo, and all that connects with the realm of the living, coming together to form a single heaven. If there is no nothingness, it cannot give rise to being; if being has not yet arisen, it cannot give rise to life. Then who gives life to life? It arises of itself, clod-like. It is not I who give life; since I cannot give life to things, and things cannot give life to me, I am simply natural. Since it is so of itself, it is called *natural*—how could it refer to the azure sky? Yet some claim the *heavenly pipes* command things to follow them. But heaven itself cannot possess itself—how could it possess things? Thus, *heaven* is but the general name for the myriad things. If none is fit to be called heaven, who then commands things? Things each arise of themselves, without source—this is the Dao of heaven. “All attain their own, who stirs them to such fury?”—this further clarifies the *heavenly pipes*.

Lü’s commentary: “The reason one has form and mind is simply because one has a self. If there were no self, it would be no different from dead ashes or withered wood. Ziyou did not know whence his self arose, nor how it was enslaved by form and mind, leaving him no respite—how could he have come to this? Yet in that moment of stillness, he recognized the difference between past and present, his observation growing keen. For in the past, his stillness was a response to things; now, his stillness is a forgetting of things. If one knows whence the self arises, then existence and loss have never been beyond one’s grasp.

Bamboo pipes are things all know to be hollow and empty. The reason I am I is no different: when the myriad hollows roar in fury, is it not like the time when I am enslaved by my form and mind? When the hollows fall empty, is it not like the time when I have lost my self, like withered wood or dead ashes? ‘Have you alone not heard, have you alone not seen?’—it speaks of the arising and cessation of the *earthly pipes*, which you have heard and seen, while the arising and cessation of the mind, which you have never heard or seen. By investigating what you have heard and seen, you may understand what you have never heard or seen—thus the *heavenly pipes* may be known.”
