Yi Du’s note: “The wind emerges from emptiness, seeking no trace; it arises from stillness and returns to stillness, is born from nothingness and returns to nothingness. Only the differing capacities of the hollows make the sounds heard by people vary; it is the same with the endowments of the myriad things. The myriad hollows are sounded by the wind; the myriad forms are moved by transformation. If the wind cannot sound, the myriad hollows are empty; if transformation cannot move, the myriad things are still. As for that which has no sound and no hollows—it is not something the wind can enter. This is what Liezi called *dubious solitude*.”

Xin Zhuan’s note: “*Ǒu* means pairing; all things have their mates, yet only the Dao and spirit are wondrous and without mate. Without mate, they return to unity, forgetting self and other—thus the judgments of things are equalized. The stillness of today is not the stillness of yesterday—this is what the Brahmin meant when he said, ‘I am still I, yet I am not the I of yesterday.’ The *heavenly pipes*, *earthly pipes*, and *human pipes*—the reason the myriad hollows differ is that they all receive the wind to form sound. Though the myriad things differ, they all entrust themselves to qi to form their bodies. Hollows are sounded by the wind, and things are moved by transformation; though their encounters differ, they all return to unity—thus self and other cannot but be equal. Yet the wind cannot sound without hollows, and transformation cannot move without things. Who can escape the burden of form and the delusions of the mind, attaining clarity and enlightenment, so that ‘I am not possessed by me’? Then one enters the wondrous and transcends the constraints of creation.”

Xun Ben’s note: “*The Equality of Things*—the form of the wind seems to flow from the tip of the brush; only the hand of a master craftsman could achieve this. Nose, mouth, ears—these three resemble human forms. *Jī* are stacked with gaps; *quān* are round and hollow; *jiù* are concave in the center—these three resemble the forms of vessels. Water pooling in a cow’s hoofprint is called *wā*; water flowing into a depression is called *wū*—these two resemble the forms of the earth. This speaks of their forms.

Below, it speaks of their sounds: *jī* is like the sound of rushing water; *hè* like the sound of an arrow leaving the bow; *hào* like the sound of wailing; *yǎo* like the sound in the southeast corner of a deep room; *yǎo* like the sound of a bird’s pecking; *chàng yú*—the *yú* is a reed pipe, as Han Fei said: ‘The *yú* leads the five notes, hence it is called *chàng yú*.’ *Yóng* means the hollows are like the gaping mouths of fish.”

The *líng* wind is the clear, cool wind; the *piāo* wind is the fleeting, drifting wind. *Diāo-diāo* describes the wind at the treetops—*diāo-diāo* in harmony, yet *diāo-diāo* in caution. In common speech, a gentle wind is called *diāo-diāo*, and tea-pickers pluck the tender shoots, saying they are *diāo-duō*—*diāo-diāo* and ready to be plucked.

Xūxī says: “My mate is lost, yet I remain. If things perish alongside me, from where does dispute arise? It is but contention without end.” Zhuangzi sought to depict the heartlessness of disputation, and from the world he found what is most rootless: the wind. To know whence the wind arises and what it receives is to equalize all that is unequal.

How vast is heaven and earth! How vast is the wind—a mere sigh. Such are the words of the enlightened. *Wéi* from the mountain is called *fáng*; *cuī* from the mountain is called *cuī*—the secluded corners and sharp angles of mountain forests where the wind does not reach.

*Jì* means crossing in chaos, as in a fierce wind greater than the *piāo* wind. Where it passes, all hollows resound together, like a breath through emptiness. If *jì* were to cease, to what would the fierce wind belong? With so many hollows and crevices, add *diāo-diāo* and *diāo-diāo*, and even the swaying treetops would be left with nothing untouched.

In the world, there is no day without right and wrong—small winds for small matters, great winds for great matters—yet in the end, all must still to rest. This is what is meant by equalization. To recognize their source is to equalize them without waiting for their cessation.

Who stirs up anger? That which acts without acting is heaven.

The *fùmò* [secondary ink—notes that serve the primary text]:

What destroys the self is forgetting the self. Forgetting the self, one attains heaven. One who wanders with heaven knows yet has never known, speaks yet has never spoken. Thus, though the three *lài* are raised in discussion, they ultimately return to the heavenly *lài*. *Lài* are flutes and pipes—their sounds rise and fall, bright and dark, like the unevenness of things and judgments, comparable to human actions. Hence, they are called the human *lài* and the earthly *lài*, while the wooden hollows produce sound; the heavenly *lài*, however, is soundless yet capable of all sounds under heaven. This is what is meant by "as if there were a true master, yet no trace of it can be found."

The hollows of wood have two holes resembling nostrils, one hole resembling a mouth, holes slanting inward like ears, square holes like crossbeams, deep round holes like rings, shallow ones like mortars, curved ones like depressions, and wide ones like puddles. These several phrases depict the hollows so vividly they seem visible. Furthermore, the sounds of these hollows: when struck, they clatter and cease; when blown, they rush forth swiftly; when shouted into, they issue roughly; when inhaled, they enter softly; when cried out, they rise sharply; when howled, they descend turbidly; when deep, they linger; when gnawed, they bark and continue—like light singing. *Yóng* is deep harmony; the advance and retreat of wind are its advancing and retreating fronts.

The *líng* wind is a gentle breeze; the *piāo* wind is a swift gale; the *lì* wind is a fierce gust. Though the myriad blows differ, each ceases of itself. "All take from themselves"—this phrase means that though the myriad sounds differ, each arising of itself, all are self-derived and not from Heaven. Then who is it that roars and howls within the hollows? Clearly, there is a true master governing them, yet no trace of it can be found. Thus it is called the Heavenly Pipe.

The great wisdom is expansive; the petty wisdom is cramped. The grand words blaze; the small words prattle. In sleep, the spirits intermingle; in waking, the forms open. Engaging with things, they weave connections, daily contending with the heart. Some are slack, some guarded, some timid, trembling with small fears, or drifting with great ones. Their outbursts are like the release of a crossbow’s trigger—this is what it means to judge right and wrong. Their persistence is like a sworn oath—this is what it means to cling to victory. Their decline is like autumn and winter, speaking of their daily decay. Their drowning in things cannot be reversed. Their oppression is like sealing—speaking of their aging stagnation. The heart near death cannot be made to revive. Joy, anger, sorrow, and delight; thought, sighing, change, and dread; coquetry, ease, openness, and postures—pleasure issues from emptiness, mushrooms form from steam, day and night succeeding one another before us, yet none knows whence they sprout. Enough! Enough!

At dawn and dusk we attain this—is this not the source from which life arises? Without that, there is no me; without me, there is nothing to grasp. This is nearly so, yet none knows what brings it about. As if there were a true master, yet no trace of it can be found. It may act and be trusted, yet its form is unseen. It has essence but no form. The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera are all complete and present within—with whom should I be intimate? Do you all delight in them equally? Or is there partiality? Are they all servants and concubines? If so, are these servants and concubines insufficient to govern one another? Do they take turns being lord and subject? Or is there a true lord residing within? Whether one seeks and obtains its truth or not, does it matter? Its truth is one: it receives its completed form and does not forget until its end. With things, it clashes and grinds away; its course runs to the utmost like a galloping horse, yet none can halt it. Is this not lamentable? A lifetime of toil and struggle, yet no success is seen. Exhausted and worn, one does not know where to return—how can this not be sorrowful? People call this "not dying"—what benefit is there? The body transforms, the heart with it—can this not be called great sorrow?

*[Spare and expansive in appearance, yet distinct in detail; blazing and magnificent in aspect, narrow and petty in speech; carefree and broad of heart.]*

Deep-heartedness—this is profound intent. Trembling timidity—this is petty caution. The appearance of equanimity toward life and death—unmoving stillness—these are the first signs. All-encompassing completeness—this is thorough preparation.

*[Guo’s Commentary: The spacious and distinct show differences in knowledge; the blazing and petty reveal disparities in speech. The mingling of souls and the merging of forms differ in waking and dreaming; the carefree and the secretive diverge in intimacy. Trembling and carefree mark differences in fear and dread; the judging of right and wrong, the guarding of victories, and the regulation of movement and stillness—all vary. Daily, they wane and decline, and cannot be drowned again to proceed thus. Sealed in desire, submerged in longing, the old grow ever more mired. Near death, they take profit and danger lightly, calamity and misfortune as nothing—none can restore their yang, their yin congealed, their wills fulfilled. Joy and anger below—these are the divergences of nature and emotion. Music arising from emptiness, mushrooms steaming into being—these are the transformations of events. From this point upward, the boundless spontaneity of Heaven’s piping is roughly sketched; below, the naturalness of boundlessness is clarified.]*

Each thing is spontaneous, not knowing why it is so, yet so it is. Though forms may differ endlessly, their spontaneity is ever the same. Day and night succeed one another, and thus the world renews itself. Heaven and Earth, the myriad things—all change and daily renew, advancing with time. What thing initiates this? It is simply so of itself. That by which it lives speaks of its self-generation. That is spontaneity. Spontaneity gives birth to me, and I give birth to spontaneity. Thus spontaneity is none other than my own spontaneity—how distant is it? Not knowing what impels it, all things, in all their variety, are simply thus of themselves, not acting at another’s behest. Therefore, if one follows it, principle arrives of itself.

The ten thousand things, the ten thousand dispositions—though their lodgings differ, it seems as if a true master makes them so. Yet when one arises to seek the traces of this true master, in the end it cannot be found. Thus it is clear that all things are spontaneous, with nothing compelling them to be so. The traveler who trusts in what can be traveled, whose feelings accord with things, who does not distinguish forms—then the hundred bones and nine orifices are entrusted to spontaneity, and none are not thoroughly preserved. If one delights in it, there is partiality; with partiality, one cannot be thorough and preserving. If the will exceeds its proper measure, high and low encroach upon one another, and none serve as lord and subject.

The distinction of lord and subject is like Heaven’s height and Earth’s lowness—when placed in their proper stations, the true lord allows them to be thus of themselves, not through artifice. All who attain their true nature and employ their spontaneity—whether knowing or not—are naturally thus. Yet the knowing guard their knowledge to the end, while the foolish cling to their folly until death. Adversity and good fortune intersect; each trusts in their own bias and indulges their conduct, none able to turn back. This, compared to what most people lament, is also lamentable. Yet they have never taken this as lamentable, for it is the nature of their spontaneity. Each thing is so by nature—what thing is worthy of lament?

Yet a lifetime of toil and struggle, weariness and exhaustion—though alive, one is in truth the same as dead. This is the greatest sorrow, yet people have never taken it as sorrow. Thus all that is lamented is not truly lamentable.

*[Lü’s Commentary: The spacious and distinct clarify the differences between great and small measure.]*

Sleep and wakefulness intertwine, yet their weave differs—some loose, some tight, some hidden, some dense. Likes and dislikes lie within, and when things strike them, their release is like the trigger of a crossbow. Fame and principle stand without, and when things draw them, their clinging is like a sworn oath. Thus their inclinations and aversions diverge. Their decline is like autumn and winter’s advent—none can restore the yang; thus their desires vary in depth. Joy and anger, sorrow and delight, coquetry and ease, openness and poise—each emotion’s form and manifestation differ.

All these are the myriad breaths, each distinct, yet each left to itself. Like music emerging from emptiness or mushrooms forming from steam, day and night succeed one another, none knowing their origin—such is the Heavenly Pipe, the work of non-action. The differences in vessels’ size, in inclinations and aversions, in divergence and convergence—are these not like the varied shapes of caves and hollows? The distinctions in composure and agitation, joy and anger, sorrow and delight, in the forms of emotions—are these not like the diverse cries of the wind through gaping mouths? Music emerging from emptiness, mushrooms forming from steam—seeking their origin, one finds nothing. Are these not like the wind passing through hollows, now murmuring, now whistling, yet none knowing where it goes?

Viewed thus, where lies the "I" that makes me myself? Where is the form that is not like withered wood? Where is the heart that is not like dead ashes? The Heavenly Pipe is hard to know; the True Lord is hard to see. Only by losing oneself in serene oblivion and aligning the heart with it can one attain this. Morning and evening, one finds the source of life—knowing that its origin is unknowable, yet aligning the heart with it.

If one cannot grasp its signs or see its form, one cannot discern what moves it. Searching within the bodily frame for what moves it, one finds it was never there. Yet within the bodily frame, if one seeks what moves it and finds nothing, the True Lord is present—this much is knowable. All people possess the True Lord, yet none seek to know its nature, neither adding to nor diminishing it. Why? It cannot be attained by the mind’s nearness, nor can it be grasped by the mind’s distance.

*[New Tradition: Great knowledge and small knowledge, grand words and petty words—all fear the burdens of form, whether in sleep or wakefulness. With form, one is enslaved by transformation; enslaved by transformation, one experiences movement and stillness differently. This is why one remains bound. How much better to be formless, so that transformation cannot enslave! Only the spirit can partake in this.]*

*[Xu Xi: What has drowned them cannot be restored. The three "之" are empty words, indicating that their past inclinations, once drowned in intent, cannot be made to return. A ditch now full, now dry—merely saying "dry" does not convey how easily it was once filled. Joy and anger, sorrow and delight—here, sorrow and anger are depicted through "anxiety, sighing, change, and dread," while joy and delight are shown through "coquetry, ease, openness, and poise." "Openness" is the spirit’s release; "poise" is its bearing. Joy and delight are like music resonating in empty space, boundlessly unobstructed. What is pent-up is like yin qi congealing into mushrooms—all is spontaneous.]*

*[Xun’s Edition: Joy, anger, sorrow, delight, anxiety, sighing, change, dread, coquetry, ease, openness, poise—these seven emotions are here expanded into twelve variations. "Dread" (慹) combines "grasp" and "heart," signifying a heart that clings. "Coquetry" (姚) means allure; "ease" (佚), indulgence; "openness" (启), the awakening of intelligence; "poise" (态), demeanor. Xunzi’s line—"None fail to be beautiful, alluring, and adorned in their blood, qi, and bearing"—follows the same structure.]*

*[Guan’s Insight: Anxiety is premeditation of the future; sighing is lament for the past. Change is restlessness with purpose; dread is fear that inhibits action. Coquetry is self-indulgent beauty; ease is heedless abandon. Openness is the heart’s receptivity to things; poise is arrogance and haughtiness. Those who chase things and forget themselves exhibit these varied states within a single body. Calculating gains and losses, they are like scorching fire and congealing ice—body and heart both waste away daily, nearing death.]*

*[Secondary Ink: Below, the text depicts the heart’s shifting states, paralleling the earlier passage on wind and wood’s sounds. It guards against grand knowledge. "Spacious and distinct" (闲闲) aligns with Mencius’ "The wise act without contrivance." "Narrow and rigid" (间间) sets boundaries, dividing self and other—this is merely the knowledge of petty men. "Blazing brilliance" (炎炎) illuminates above; "babbling uniformity" (詹詹) aligns front and back. "Loose" (缦) is unhurried, gentle; "hidden" (窖), a concealed mechanism, treacherous. "Dense" (密) is meticulous, petty. "Anxious" (惴惴) is a heart ill at ease; "listless" (缦缦), scattered and self-doubting. Those who arbitrate right and wrong are litigious sorts, aiming for the vital point—like a crossbow’s trigger, cunning. Those who cling to victory are obstinate, like an oath’s unyielding hold—stubborn. Petty knowledge’s heart contends thus; innate truth fades daily, fading further, until the heart dies unawares. Thus it says, "Their decline is like autumn and winter," describing daily decay. "Drowned and submerged, it cannot be retrieved"—thus it says, "What has drowned them cannot be restored." Drowning and decline correspond; such scheming deepens with age. Thus it says, "Old ditches, sated and sealed"—like the *Great Learning*’s "sated and sealed." If the heart is not dead, there remains life’s vitality, like spring’s return. But this near-dead heart—can it restore the yang? It cannot. This exhaustively describes petty knowledge’s heart. Below, twelve words depict its interactions with things. Yet even so, it is not free—like music emerging from emptiness, now sounding, now ceasing; like steam forming mushrooms, now living, now dying, day and night succeeding one another. Yet none knows their origin—this is the "myriad breaths, each distinct." Who stirs them? Alas! Alas!]*

"From dawn to dusk, do we obtain this—what gives rise to life? The word *already* here is the *who* in 'Who stirs them?' Below, it is not that there is no self without that other; it now replaces this word with *that*, saying: if I am not that, then I cannot complete myself. If I reject or accept the other, then that too cannot manifest itself. Like wind departing from the hollow—it never forms sound. Such an argument about creation seems nearly apt.

Yet why does it fail to grasp its traces? It says: not knowing what causes it. If there were a true master yet it could not grasp its traces—read this as one phrase. One would only seek its traces if the true master had form. Now, the true master makes each person act spontaneously, and people likewise believe in it. Thus it says: 'It can be practiced and believed.' Only because its form is unseen are no traces to be found.

Though the true master has sentiment, it has no form; one must recognize it through the formed. Thus it speaks of the hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera—there is self-interest in them. Is there a true lord residing within? The two *yan* and three *hu* are all interrogative particles, repeatedly questioning to urge deep reflection and personal realization. To seek and grasp its sentiment is to have sentiment without form—this sentiment neither benefits nor harms its truth. This truth is the truth of the true lord and true master; this truth originally neither benefits nor harms people. Only when deluded does one become ordinary; when awakened, one becomes sagely." *Human life—*

Firm indeed is this obscurity—yet am I alone obscure while others are not? If one follows the heart already formed and takes it as teacher, who then is without a teacher? Why must there be knowledge and succession when the heart naturally grasps things? Even the foolish share in this. Before the heart is formed, is there right and wrong? This is like arriving in Yue today yet having reached it yesterday. Thus to take nonbeing as being—though even the divine Yu could not comprehend it, how then should I fare?

Speech is not like the wind’s blowing. Those who speak have something to say, yet what they say remains unsettled. Is there truly speech, or has there never been speech? Do they deem it different from the fledgling’s chirp? Is there distinction, or is there no distinction?

Where does the Dao conceal itself to produce truth and falsehood? Where does speech conceal itself to produce right and wrong? Where does the Dao go and yet not exist? Where does speech exist yet remain unutterable? Concealed in petty accomplishments, speech is concealed in flourishing splendor. Hence arise the Confucians and Mohists, each affirming what the other denies and denying what the other affirms. If one wishes to affirm what the other denies and deny what the other affirms, nothing surpasses clarity.

Nothing is not "that," nothing is not "this." From "that," one does not see; by knowing oneself, one knows. Thus it is said: "That" emerges from "this," and "this" likewise depends on "that"—"that" and "this" arise together. Yet even as they arise, they die; even as they die, they arise. Even as they affirm, they negate; even as they negate, they affirm. Therefore the sage does not proceed thus but illuminates it in Heaven—this too is dependence. "This" is also "that," and "that" is also "this."

Is that also one right and wrong, and is this also one right and wrong? Is there truly "that" and "this"? Or is there truly no "that" and "this"? Where "that" and "this" find no counterpart, this is called the *pivot of the Dao*. Only when one attains the pivot at the center of the ring can one respond to the inexhaustible. "This" too is inexhaustible, and "not-this" too is inexhaustible. Thus it is said: nothing surpasses clarity.

For all things are boundless and obscure—this is the realm where knowing is self-subsistent, where one’s own understanding stands in place of another’s. (Alternatively: where succession and change occur. The wind’s sound is the *lai*, the chirp of a fledgling breaking from its shell. The pivot is the essential point.) Guo Xiang’s commentary: Now, those who know do not know *how* they know, yet know of themselves; those who live do not know *how* they live, yet live of themselves. Though the myriad things differ, in that life does not arise from knowing, none are not the same. Thus the world is boundless and obscure. That by which the mind suffices to govern the body’s functions is called the *completed mind*. If one takes one’s completed mind as one’s teacher, then each person has their own teacher. Since each has their own teacher, one may entrust things to them, and they will naturally be fitting.

To use what is completed to replace what is not completed is not true knowing—it is merely the mind attaining itself. Thus even the foolish take their completed mind as their teacher, unwilling to employ what they deem deficient while discarding what they deem sufficient. If today one travels to Yue, how did one arrive there yesterday? Before the mind is completed, how does the clarity of right and wrong arise? Right and wrong are what the multitude cannot be without, so the perfected person accords with both. Those who are deluded by right and wrong take what is not as what is. Once the deluded mind is formed, even the sage cannot dispel it, so one entrusts it to its own nature without forcing knowledge.

Words each have their own basis, hence they differ from the wind’s sound. I deem this right, while another deems it wrong; what another deems right, I deem wrong—thus nothing is settled. That nothing is settled arises from the partiality of "that" and "this." If one claims there are words, this is not yet sufficient to settle anything; if one claims there are no words, one already relies on words. Words and the chirp of fledglings share the same end. Whether there is debate or no debate cannot truly be settled. The feelings of the world need not be the same, yet their words cannot differ, so right and wrong are in tumult, and none know what is settled.

Where is the Dao not present? Why would words conceal it, giving rise to names of truth and falsity, right and wrong? Petty accomplishments and flourishing splendor conceal themselves from the Dao, yet the Dao cannot be concealed. Thus truth and falsity, right and wrong arise in flourishing splendor and cease at what is fitting; they appear in petty accomplishments and vanish in great wholeness. The Confucians and Mohists alternately affirm and negate each other, each prizing their own views. To have right and wrong is what the Confucians and Mohists affirm; to have no right and no wrong is what they negate. If one wishes to affirm what they negate and negate what they affirm, one must clarify the absence of right and wrong. To clarify the absence of right and wrong, nothing surpasses using the Confucians and Mohists to mutually illuminate each other. Through mutual illumination, one knows that what they affirm is not right and what they negate is not wrong.

All things deem themselves right, so none are not right; all things deem others wrong, so none are not wrong. If none are not wrong, then the world has no right; if none are not right, then the world has no wrong. Without wrong and without right, this is called *mysterious sameness*. All things do not see what others see but know only what they themselves know. Knowing only what they themselves know, they deem themselves right; deeming themselves right, they deem others wrong. Thus it is said: "That" emerges from "this," and "this" likewise depends on "that"—"that" and "this" arise together.

The transformations of life and death are like the progression of the four seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer. Though the states of life and death differ, in that each is content with its lot, they are one. Now, the living deem life as life and death as death, so there is no life; the living deem death as death and the dead deem death as life, so there is no death. Without life and without death, without right and without wrong, the debates of the Confucians and Mohists are what I cannot agree with. As for each obscuring their own portion, this is what I cannot differ from. Thus the sage accords with the world’s right and wrong yet is without right and wrong. Therefore, not proceeding by the path of right and wrong, right and wrong are never inappropriate—one simply illuminates their natural Heaven and does not impose upon them.

"This" is also "that," and I too am what "that" deems "that." "That" too deems itself right, so "that" and "this," being and non-being, are not yet settled. They are counterparts. "That" and "this" stand in opposition, yet the sage accords with both, so the mindless one guards things without ever having an opposite in the world. The pivot is the essential point. Abiding in the pivot, guarding the mysterious extremity, one responds to the boundless. Right and wrong follow one another in endless recurrence, thus it is called the *ring*. The center of the ring is empty. If one takes right and wrong as the ring and attains its center, one has no right and no wrong. Without right and wrong, one can respond; since right and wrong are inexhaustible, one’s response is also inexhaustible. The world deems itself right and others wrong, so one right and one wrong proceed endlessly. Only one who traverses the empty and attains the center is vast and without attachment, riding it in wandering.

Lu Huiqing’s commentary: The Dao is nowhere absent, so words are nothing but the Dao. Why would words conceal it, giving rise to right and wrong? Since things are nothing but the Dao, words too are the Dao. Why would words conceal it, giving rise to right and wrong? Since the Dao is nowhere absent, where does it not abide? Since words are nothing but the Dao, where do they not abide? Yet there are places where they do not abide and cannot—this is because the Dao is concealed in petty accomplishments, and one does not know great wholeness; words are concealed in flourishing splendor, and one does not know their root and substance. Hence arise the right and wrong of the Confucians and Mohists.

If one wishes to affirm what the other denies and deny what the other affirms, nothing surpasses clarity. Clarity means returning to one’s mandate and knowing constancy. Now, the right and wrong of the Confucians and Mohists do not depart from knowledge and perception, yet they have never employed clarity. Thus they are insufficient to be the standard of right and wrong. If one relinquishes knowledge and turns the light of awareness back to clarity, then what things call "that" and "this" truly have no fixed substance. Without fixed substance, there is nothing that is not "that," nothing that is not "this." From the perspective of the Dao, when things are in the process of arising, where does life come from? When in the process of dying, where does death go? Knowing the oneness of life and death, then the process of arising is the very process of dying, and the process of dying is the very process of arising. Right and wrong, affirmation and negation—all are the same.

Likewise, all these are fabrications of our own minds. Exhausting the mind and plumbing the spirit, one returns to the state of "no-self," and then their essence has never differed. Thus, "this" follows from "that," and "that" follows from "this," alternating in function—nothing more.

Following the root: Speech is not the blowing of the wind. When people speak, their words are not like the *tianlai* that blows through the myriad things with no mind. Speech arises from humans, yet they cannot be without mind, so their words remain unsettled and cannot serve as a standard. Since words are unsettled, others perceive them as if they were nothing. Thus, one may ask: do words truly exist, or have they never existed? When a fledgling bird first emerges from its egg, people hear its cries—if it is a magpie, they herald good fortune; if a crow, they foretell misfortune. The crane’s call foretells rain, the cuckoo’s urges plowing; these sounds can serve as standards. But the fledgling’s cry is not yet fixed, so it cannot be a standard. Human speech, when unsettled, is no different.

Xu Xi: Speech is not the blowing of the wind; it is not like the emotionless gusts. There must be meaning in it, yet what is meant remains unsettled. I deem it "this," while another deems it "that"—thus the debates of the world begin. Yet from the perspective of the enlightened, how is this different from the fledgling’s cry in the ear? Does it truly matter?

Jingchuan: The blowing arises naturally; speech, however, is intentional. Thus, it is said that "speech is not the blowing." Clarity is great wisdom. With luminous insight, one penetrates both self and other, and there is no "this" or "that." Yet things have "this" and "that," hence it is said: "Nothing is not 'that,' nothing is not 'this.'" It is self-generated. Because there is "that," one becomes obscured and cannot see; through wisdom, one comes to know it. "This" and "that" are to be understood through the characters *bi* (彼, that) and *ci* (此, this). They pertain to existence, yet they have never truly existed. Illuminated by the light of Heaven—Heaven being the state of neither "this" nor "that"—then clarity emerges. Only when there is neither "this" nor "that" can "this" and "that" be dissolved.

A humble view: Fan Wuyin said, "Before the mind is formed, true nature is undivided, its vastness equal to the empty sky. Once the mind is formed, it departs from nature, and there is good and evil."

In the midst of worldly interactions, one cannot avoid the formation of the mind. Yet when this occurs, one should model oneself on the state before its formation—then good and evil do not arise, right and wrong leave no trace, and what is there that cannot be harmonized? For a person, halting a thought is not difficult; the challenge lies in preventing its continuation. If, from the very moment the mind forms, one models oneself on the state before its formation, thoughts will not persist, and one’s nature may be restored. Thus, when facing things, the mind arises; when things are forgotten, nature manifests. The mind is like departing fire—fire cannot take shape on its own but must cling to something. If the mind is like the empty sky, it has nothing to cling to. Moreover, when the mind clings to things and acts with goodness, it is still inferior to having no mind and no action—how much worse when it clings to things and acts with evil?

Guan Yinzi said: "What comes to me is like the flash of flint and steel. Responding with one’s nature, things drift lightly away." This is the essential method of relinquishing things, departing from the human, gathering emotions, and returning to nature. Those who "know in place of" and "take for themselves with the mind" refer precisely to those who follow their own minds, using knowledge to replace the Dao and thus forming the mind.

*Brush Strokes* states: "That does not arise on its own; because of this, there is that. This does not arise on its own; because of that, there is this." Thus it is said: "That arises from this, and this also arises from that." Both emerge from nothing into being—this is what is meant by the "incipience of arising." Yet arising is paired with perishing, and perishing with arising. Only when there is being can there be non-being; only when there is non-being can there be being. These are matched pairs of affirmation and negation—this is the way of humanity, not of Heaven. The sage does not follow this but illuminates it through Heaven, standing transcendent beyond the bounds of right and wrong, roaming alone with the Creator. How could this be compared to those in the world whose opinions run rampant?

Even the sage does not discard right and wrong in this context, for what the world deems right, he deems right; what the world deems wrong, he deems wrong—no more than this. The character *yin* (因, "because") is the key safeguard of Laozi and Zhuangzi, hence the following text repeatedly responds to it. Knowing this, then this is that, and that is this; the right and wrong of that are the right and wrong of this. Is there truly a distinction? Or is there truly no distinction? The mutual seeking of matched pairs cannot be resolved, and the pivot of the Dao lies here.

All things, whether odd or round, are paired with even or square. The ring has no beginning or end, and its center is empty, containing nothing—this resembles one who has grasped the pivot of the Dao. Thus it is said: "Attain its ring’s center to respond to the endless." For one who travels the endless paths of right and wrong, the state of neither right nor wrong remains unchanged. Without illuminating it through Heaven, this cannot be achieved—hence the saying: "Nothing is better than clarity."

Using a finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger is not as good as using a non-finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger. Using a horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse is not as good as using a non-horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse. Heaven and earth are one finger; the myriad things are one horse. Is this acceptable? Or is it unacceptable?

To speak of "that by which things are so" is not as good as to affirm their being so; to speak of "that by which things are not so" is not as good as to affirm their not being so. Things inherently have that which makes them so; things inherently have that which makes them acceptable. There is nothing that is not so, nothing that is not acceptable. Thus, whether it be a stalk or a pillar, a leper or Xi Shi, the grotesque, the strange, the deceptive, or the bizarre—all are subsumed into the One. Their division is their completion; their completion is their destruction. Yet all things, without completion or destruction, are again subsumed into the One. Only the enlightened know that all are subsumed into the One. For this reason, they do not employ it but lodge it in the ordinary. The ordinary is the function; function is the penetration; penetration is the attainment. Attaining it, one is nearly there. Following this, one rests without knowing why it is so—this is called the Dao. To exhaust one’s spirit in striving to unify without knowing their sameness is called "morning three." What is "morning three"? A monkey-keeper distributed acorns, saying, "Three in the morning and four in the evening." The monkeys were all enraged. He then said, "Then four in the morning and three in the evening." The monkeys were all pleased. The names and realities remained unchanged, yet joy and anger were employed—this too is an example. Therefore, the sage harmonizes with right and wrong and rests in the Heavenly balance. This is called "walking two paths."

The pillar is a column; *lì* is ugliness—one says it is leprosy. *Huī*, *dà*, *guǐ*, *lì*, *jué*: vast, perverse, twisted, deviant, strange, and bizarre. The *jūgōng* is one who keeps monkeys. *Xù* are acorns. "Three in the morning and four in the evening" means three *shēng* in the morning and four *shēng* in the evening.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
That one takes oneself as right and others as wrong is the common tendency of the world. Thus, if I use my finger to illustrate another’s finger, then that finger, from the perspective of my finger, is not a finger. This is using a finger to illustrate the non-finger-ness of a finger. If, however, one reverses the analogy and uses that finger to illustrate my finger, then my finger, from the perspective of that finger, is also not a finger. This is using a non-finger to illustrate the non-finger-ness of a finger. To clarify the absence of right and wrong, nothing is better than mutual illustration. Through mutual illustration, that and this are both identical in their self-affirmation and equal in their mutual negation. Equal in mutual negation, then the world has no right; identical in self-affirmation, then the world has no wrong. For if right were truly right, then the world could not also have those who deem it wrong. If wrong were truly wrong, then the world could not also have those who deem it right. Now, with right and wrong lacking any fixed ground, they become confused and chaotic. This shows that these petty distinctions merely reflect each side clinging to its own bias, converging in their duality. Looking up and down, nothing is not like this. Therefore, the perfected person knows that Heaven and Earth are one finger, and the myriad things are one horse. Thus, in vast and boundless tranquility, each abides in its place, identical in self-attainment, without right or wrong.

What is acceptable to oneself is called acceptable; what is unacceptable to oneself is called unacceptable. The Dao accomplishes all things without anything it does not accomplish; each thing is as it is, each acceptable as it is acceptable. The stalk is horizontal, the pillar vertical; *lì* is ugly, Xishi beautiful—what is meant by "equalizing" is surely not equalizing forms or conforming to the same compass and square. Thus, whether vertical or horizontal, beautiful or ugly, vast or perverse, twisted or strange, each is as it is, each acceptable as it is acceptable. Though forms differ in ten thousand ways, their natures share the same attainment. Hence it is said: "The Dao penetrates to become one."

Some things are considered dispersed from this perspective yet complete from that; what I call completion, others may call destruction—all arise from self-regard and failure to see the other. Only the penetrating one is not fixed to one side. Suddenly self-forgotten, they lodge in what is fitting for spontaneous function. In spontaneous function, nothing fails to flow smoothly and attain itself. *Jǐ* means "exhaustive"; the utmost principle is exhausted in self-attainment. The penetrating one follows and does not act, hence it is said, "Following this, one rests." How could they know that following is good and thus follow it? They do not know why they follow and simply follow of themselves. Hence it is called the Dao. The Dao is simply the One. For the penetrating one, how could unifying require exhausting the spirit? If one exhausts the spirit to unify, it is not reliable—no different from those who are not one, merely like the monkeys who affirmed themselves based on what they preferred. Therefore, the sage does not lean toward any one side but entrusts things to their natural balance, halting at "walking two paths"—entrusting the world’s right and wrong to Heaven.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Using a finger to illustrate the non-finger-ness of a finger, desiring to distinguish between small and large in names and food, how could this not arise from the same body and thus fail to be a non-finger? Using a horse to illustrate the non-horse-ness of a horse, though there may be distinctions of coat and speed, how could this depart from the same kind and thus fail to be a non-horse? Only by not following right and wrong but illuminating them through Heaven can one transcend the same body and depart from the same kind—then one is sufficient to determine the world’s true right and wrong. Though Heaven and Earth are vast, they are no different from one finger, for they are born together with me and share the same body. Though the myriad things are numerous, they are no different from one horse, for they are one with me and share the same kind. Then who determines what is acceptable or unacceptable for things?

The Dao is enacted and thereby accomplished—not accomplished through non-action. Things are named and thereby become so—not inherently so. What they are and what they accept are the very sources of what they are not and what they do not accept. Seeking the one who makes them so, one ultimately finds nothing—thus knowing their fundamental absence. This is how things are equalized. Why pursue or reject among them? Small and large, beauty and ugliness are inherently opposed, but when the Dao penetrates and unifies them, their distinctions become what accomplishes their completion and what accomplishes their destruction. The myriad things have no completion or destruction, returning to become one—only the penetrating one knows that penetrating is one. Thus, I do not act but lodge in the spontaneous function of things. Lodging in things, one penetrates; penetrating, there is nowhere one does not attain oneself. If one does not know this and exhausts the spirit to act, this is precisely what makes one not one.

**Zhao’s Commentary:**
Knowing that beyond the finger there is something that moves it, one knows the finger is not the finger. Knowing that beyond the horse there is something that gallops it, one knows the horse is not the horse. Finger and horse are things with form; non-finger and non-horse are without form. Using what has form to illustrate the formlessness of form is not as good as using what is formless to illustrate the formlessness of form. Then one knows that the movement of Heaven and Earth and the generation of the myriad things all have a separate master. One may seek it beyond Heaven and Earth and the myriad things.

Acceptable or unacceptable, so or not so, vertical or horizontal, beauty or ugliness, vastness or perversity, twistedness or strangeness, right or wrong, completion or destruction—all return to become one, then there is no right and no wrong. Though there is right, one does not use it. *Yōng* is the ordinary; the ordinary is the function without function that becomes penetration. Penetrating, one attains; attaining, one is nearly at the Dao. If at this point one not only ceases to affirm but also ceases to negate, yet still does not know why it is so, and merely seeks to leave form and abandon knowledge as "sitting in forgetfulness," what is this if not exhaustion?

**Shizhang’s Note:**
The *Gongsun Longzi* has the chapters "White Horse" and "Pointing at Things," and it says, "A white horse is not a horse." Zhuangzi likely based his argument on this. Some commentators even interpret "horse" as a counting rod in *bo* and *sai* games—how absurd!

**Bishu:**
Heaven and Earth are vast yet no different from one finger; the myriad things are numerous yet no different from one horse. How much more is man, one thing among Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things? Knowing this, the true substance is vast and empty, right and wrong are entirely extinguished, and one’s Heavenly nature is complete. Yet the sage has no right or wrong and also does not abolish right and wrong—this is called "following." What people find acceptable, one finds acceptable; what people find unacceptable, one finds unacceptable. The Dao is enacted and thereby accomplished; things are named and thereby become so. This is not that I impose "so" on what things are so, nor impose "not so" on what things are not so. In this way, things naturally have what they are and what they accept—there is nothing that is not like this. Why then impose right and wrong among them?

The blade of grass and the pillar stand in opposition, ugliness and Xi Shi stand in opposition, division and completion stand in opposition, success and ruin stand in opposition—yet the utmost in vastness, strangeness, and marvelous transformations all pass through and are unified as one. Without penetrating clarity and profound understanding of the supreme principle, one cannot achieve this. This is what Zhuangzi called "attainment." Not employing, nor being self-employed—it is lodged in the ordinary and follows along. As for man, the ordinary is what man constantly employs, hence it is called "ordinary." *Yong* means "to employ." All things, if not employed, stagnate; if employed, they flow—hence it is called "employing." *Tong* means "to flow." When the Dao reaches flow, it is attained—hence it is called "flow." *De* means "to attain." When attainment is reached, it is near perfection. Yet all of this is entirely encompassed by the single word "following."

Lest the meaning of "following" remain unclear, observe Master Cu’s poem on the taro: it does not increase or decrease of itself but follows the joy and anger of the many monkeys to increase or decrease—what is this if not "following"? Thus, the sage externally follows people and harmonizes with them through right and wrong, while internally rests in the Heavenly balance of neither right nor wrong. Not allowing the existence of right and wrong in traces to obstruct the mind’s absence of right and wrong—this is what is called "dual operation."

The knowledge of the ancients reached a certain point.

How far does it reach? To take "there has never yet been anything" as the ultimate—this is perfection, completion, beyond which nothing can be added. The next level takes "there is something" yet "there has never yet been boundaries." The next takes "there are boundaries" yet "there has never yet been right and wrong." When right and wrong become manifest, the Dao suffers loss. The Dao’s loss is the completion of attachment. Is there truly completion and loss? Or is there truly no completion and loss? Because there is completion and loss, Master Zhao plays the zither. Because there is no completion and loss, Master Zhao does not play the zither. Master Zhao’s zither-playing, Shi Kuang’s tapping his staff, and Huizi’s leaning against the wutong tree—these three were nearly at the height of wisdom, each in their prime. Thus, their deeds were recorded in later years. Yet it was only their fondness for these things that set them apart from others. Their fondness for them sought to illuminate what others could not illuminate, and so they ended in the obscurity of the "hard and white" debate. Their sons, in turn, spent their lives weaving the threads of their fathers’ arts, yet in the end achieved nothing. Can this be called achievement? Even I, too, would have achieved something. Can this not be called achievement? Then neither things nor I achieve anything.

Thus, the dazzling confusion of doubt is what the sage avoids. To reject this and instead entrust it to the ordinary—this is called "illuminating through the ordinary." (Master Zhao was an ancient master of the zither. *Zhi* means the bridge of a stringed instrument; *ce* means a staff. To raise the staff and strike the rhythm on the wutong wood of the zither. "Recorded in later years" means their deeds are written down to this day. "Hard and white" refers to the debate over the hardness of stone and the whiteness of a horse. *Lun* means the strings of a zither or se. *Gu* means confusion.)

Guo's Commentary:
To know that there was never a beginning to things is to forget heaven and earth, to leave the myriad things behind, to look without seeing within the cosmos, to be unaware of one’s own body. Thus, one remains vast and unburdened, moving with things and responding to all without obstruction.

To know that there were never boundaries is, though not having forgotten everything, still to forget the distinction between self and other.

To know that there were never right and wrong is, though not having forgotten self and other, still to forget the right and wrong of self and other. When right and wrong become manifest, the Dao is diminished; only without right and wrong is it whole.

When the Dao is diminished, emotions become partial, and love takes form. One has not yet forgotten love or relinquished self-interest, thus failing to merge with the other in profound unity.

Sounds cannot all be enumerated. Thus, though blowing pipes and plucking strings may involve many fingers, many sounds are still missed. Yet those who grasp the flute and sound the reed seek to make sounds manifest. In making sounds manifest, sounds are lost; in not making sounds manifest, sounds remain whole. Thus, to seek completion and thereby diminish it is like Master Zhao striking the zither. Not to seek completion and thus remain undiminished is like Master Zhao not striking the zither. This is near to perfection.

These three masters all sought to clarify what they themselves did not understand, exhausting knowledge, depleting thought, wearing out form, and fatiguing spirit. Some leaned on staffs and dozed, some rested against the wutong tree and closed their eyes, relying on their prime to endure—otherwise, they would have succumbed long ago.

The three masters only cherished what they themselves understood, considering themselves distinct from the crowd, wishing to make the crowd share their own preferences. This is like playing the reed pipes to an ox. Since the other ultimately does not understand, their own arts end in obscurity.

Master Zhao’s son continued his father’s legacy, yet in the end achieved nothing. Though these three masters sought to illuminate others, the others ultimately did not understand. Thus, their lives ended without achievement. If these three can be called accomplished, then my lack of accomplishment can also be called accomplishment. If things all illuminate themselves yet remain unilluminated by others, and if this lack of illumination is called failure, then all things together achieve nothing.

Therefore, the sage does not display this to dazzle that, nor abandons the self to pursue things. Instead, they follow and entrust each to its own capacity, thus achieving all things in their particularity without omission.

Now, these three masters sought to make their own preferences clearly known to others—is this not delusion? The sage is without self, thus avoiding the dazzling confusion of doubt by setting boundaries, and unifying the strange and wondrous, allowing each difference to rest in its own place. The crowd does not lose what is right for them, yet the self is not employed by things, and the use of the myriad things is fully realized.

If all things are self-using, then who is right and who is wrong? Thus, though the changes of extravagance and the strangeness of the peculiar may vary endlessly, by following and entrusting them to their own use, their uses, though myriad, are clearly self-evident.

---

Lü's Commentary:
The Dao is present in all things, thus there is nothing that is not the Dao. If nothing is not the Dao, then there is nothing outside the Dao. This is how the ancients could speak of there never having been things, for they could encounter things and embody the Dao.

To know and stop at this is perfection. Next are those who believe in things but not yet in boundaries, who cannot encounter things as the Dao but can use the Dao to penetrate things. Then there are those who believe in boundaries but not yet in right and wrong, who cannot use the Dao to penetrate things but can leave things behind to merge with the Dao. Though the knowledge of these two is not yet fully good in relation to the Dao, it remains undiminished.

It is only when right and wrong become manifest that the Dao is diminished. When the Dao is diminished, emotions arise, and love takes form.

Yet from the perspective of the enlightened, was there ever truly a beginning to things? How could there be completion or diminution? Master Zhao’s zither playing, Shi Kuang’s staff, and Hui Zi’s leaning against the wutong tree nearly grasped the meaning of completion and diminution. If this can be called accomplishment, then lack of accomplishment is also accomplishment. If this cannot be called accomplishment, then neither things nor I ultimately accomplish anything. Why exhaust the mind over completion and diminution, seeking to call it accomplishment?

---

Zhao's Commentary:
Master Zhao’s zither playing was understood only by Shi Kuang; Hui Zi’s debates were grasped only by Zhuangzi. Each of the three masters attained the subtleties, yet not playing, not listening, not debating—this is what they did not know. Thus, Zhuangzi followed them, saying that what he understood differed from theirs. They sought to clarify what was insufficiently clear, yet even with the full force of the "hard and white" and "same and different" debates, they ended in obscurity and lack of understanding. Like Master Zhao’s son, who did not know the profundity of the zither without strings, they ended without accomplishment.

If this is called accomplishment, it can also be called lack of accomplishment—neither depends on its true nature. Thus, clarity emerges from the midst of confusion and doubt, which is what the sage values.

---

Oral Explanation:
This passage indeed speaks of the beginning before heaven and earth, yet to grasp this principle, one need only look before one’s eyes. For example, before a thought arises, there is "never a beginning to things." Once a thought arises, there are things. From this thought come things and self, which is the existence of boundaries. From things and self come likes and dislikes, joy and anger, which is the existence of right and wrong.

If one cannot return to the time before a thought arises but only sees the entanglement in one’s heart, this is the diminution of the Dao and the formation of love. Yet when this thought passes, all is as it was—where is there truly completion or diminution? If one can realize this, it is all a direct and personal experience.

Now, let me say something here: is it similar to this or not? If similarity and dissimilarity are themselves considered similar, then there is no difference from that.

Though this be so, let me attempt to speak of it.

There is "having a beginning." There is "never having had a beginning." There is "never having had that which never had a beginning." There is "having existence." There is "having non-existence." There is "never having had non-existence." There is "never having had that which never had non-existence." Suddenly, there is existence and non-existence—but who can know whether existence or non-existence is truly existent or non-existent?

Now, I have already spoken, yet I do not know whether what I have called it truly has speech or truly lacks speech. In all the world, nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small. Nothing is longer-lived than a child who dies young, yet Pengzu is short-lived. Heaven and earth are born together with me, and the myriad things and I are one. Since we are already one, can there be speech? Since we have already called it one, can there be no speech? One and speech make two; two and one make three. From this point onward, even the most skilled mathematician cannot reckon it—how much less the ordinary person!

Thus, from non-existence proceeding to existence, one reaches three—how much more so from existence proceeding to existence! Proceed nowhere from this.

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
Now, to speak of having no right or wrong—do we not know whether this is similar to having speech or not? If we call it similar, then I take non-existence as right while they take non-existence as wrong—this is not similarity. Yet even this, though right and wrong differ, is not free from having right and wrong, and thus is similar to that. Therefore, it is said: similarity and dissimilarity themselves considered similar—then there is no difference from that.

If one wishes to be greatly dissimilar to that, nothing surpasses having no mind. First, discard right and wrong; then discard the discarding. Discard it again and again until there is no discarding—then there is no discarding and nothing not discarded, and right and wrong depart of themselves.

Let me attempt to speak of it: the ultimate principle is without speech, yet speech is inevitably dissimilar. To speak of "having a beginning" is to acknowledge that speech must have an end. "Never having had a beginning" means there is no end or beginning, and life and death are one. "Never having had that which never had a beginning" means that to speak of oneness is not as good as forgetting oneness and naturally becoming equal—this is to forget even that oneness.

"Having existence" means beauty and ugliness, right and wrong, are all present. "Having non-existence" means one does not yet know that there is no non-existence, and right and wrong, likes and dislikes, still linger in the heart. "Never having had non-existence" means one knows there is no non-existence, yet still cannot be without knowing. "Never having had that which never had non-existence"—suddenly, there is existence and non-existence, yet one does not know which is truly existent or non-existent. This is to forget all knowing. Only then does one suddenly realize there is nothing at all. Realizing nothingness, heaven and earth, the myriad things, self and other, right and wrong—all are suddenly and completely clear.

"I have already spoken" means that to speak of having no right or wrong is itself to have speech again. Not knowing whether what I have called it truly has speech or truly lacks it—only then is the heart utterly free of the slightest obstruction.

In terms of form and appearance, Mount Tai is greater than an autumn hair. But if each possesses its own nature and things reach their limit, then great form is not excessive, and small form is not insufficient. If each is sufficient in its nature, then an autumn hair is not merely small in its smallness, and Mount Tai is not merely great in its greatness. If sufficiency of nature is considered greatness, then nothing in the world is more sufficient than an autumn hair. If sufficiency of nature is not considered greatness, then even Mount Tai may be called small. If Mount Tai is small, then nothing in the world is great. If an autumn hair is great, then nothing in the world is small. Without small or great, without long-lived or short-lived—thus the mayfly does not envy the great *chun* tree but rejoices in its own contentment; the sparrow does not value the heavenly pond but delights in its own sufficiency. If one is sufficient in Heaven’s nature and at peace with one’s allotted portion, then even heaven and earth are not long-lived enough to surpass me, and the myriad things are not different enough to be separate from me.

The myriad things and myriad forms are self-sufficient, and thus one is already one. The principle requires no speech, but some things cannot clarify their oneness on their own and thus pursue one another with this. To speak of one in order to correct them is already to have speech. Yet to speak of one with speech is not one, so one and speech make two. One is already one, and speech makes it two—can this not be called three? To speak of one with one word still results in three—how much more so when tracing its branches and streams, where the names of ordinary things are beyond counting! Thus, those who speak of one are not different from that, while those who forget one are without speech and naturally one.

Therefore, resting in what one is capable of—this is the most correct.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary:
People cannot let go of self and other, forget right and wrong, and reach "never having had things" because they do not know the origin of the mind of self and other, right and wrong. To grasp this principle, one must observe it from its beginning. Thus, it is said: "There is having a beginning." The beginning originally had no source, but once there is this beginning, it has a source. It is also said: "Never having had a beginning"—this is to discard its source. Yet discarding it does not remove what is discarded; it merely avoids having a source. It is further said: "Never having had that which never had a beginning"—this is to discard the discarding. With no source and no discarding, the arising of my mind is suddenly understood, and one knows that what exists now all emerges from nothingness.

Only by knowing this can life and death be in my hands. If I wish nothing to arise, it does not arise. Seeking its beginning is impossible, and seeking its nothingness is also impossible—thus enlightenment comes in an instant, naturally fitting together. Therefore, it is said: suddenly, there is existence and non-existence, yet one does not know which is truly existent or non-existent.

Let scholars forget words and grasp it with the mind. Though this be so, what I have now spoken is also "never having had things"—whether it has speech or lacks speech, how can I know? Let scholars know that speech has never truly had words.

Only by knowing the origin of my mind’s arising do the tip of an autumn hair, Mount Tai, a child who dies young, Pengzu, and even heaven and earth and the myriad things—none arise apart from this. Then small and great, long and short—how can they have a constant form? With self, there is heaven and earth; without self, there are no myriad things. Thus, heaven and earth are born together with me, and the myriad things and I are one.

*Bishu*:
"Proceed nowhere from this" means that to speak of proceeding from non-existence to existence is to recognize the wind stirring the waves, turning endlessly without cease—being this, being that, ultimately without resolution. "Proceeding nowhere" means proceeding from having no destination. Proceeding to nothingness, there is no right or wrong, yet one takes others’ right and wrong as one’s own right and wrong. Therefore, it is said: "proceed from this." This phrase appears several times in the text, and commentators all err in their interpretations because they do not know that "is" is a particle and read it together with "from."

The Dao has never had boundaries, and words have never had fixed forms—yet by affirming "this," divisions arise.

Let me speak of these divisions:
There is left and right,
There are hierarchies and righteousness,
There are distinctions and debates,
There are competitions and conflicts—
These are called the Eight Virtues.
Beyond the Six Directions, the sage preserves but does not discuss;
Within the Six Directions, the sage discusses but does not deliberate.
The *Spring and Autumn* orders the world, embodying the intent of the former kings—
The sage deliberates but does not dispute.
Thus, what is divided also remains undivided;
What is debated also remains undebated.
Why is this?
The sage holds it within, while the multitude debates to display to one another.
Thus, it is said: what is debated also remains unseen.

The great Dao is not called "great,"
Great debate does not speak,
Great benevolence is not benevolent,
Great integrity is not modest,
Great courage does not harm.
When the Dao is made manifest, it is no longer the Dao;
When words are debated, they fall short;
When benevolence is constant, it does not succeed;
When integrity is pure, it is not trusted;
When courage is harmful, it does not prevail.
These five, though rounded, nearly approach squareness.

Thus, to know where to stop in what one does not know is perfection.
Who knows the debate that does not speak,
The Dao that is not the Dao?
If one can know this, it is called the Heavenly Storehouse—
Poured into but never filled,
Drawn from but never exhausted,
Yet one does not know its source.
This is called "preserving the light."

Thus, in ancient times, Yao asked Shun:
"I wish to attack Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao. Why do I remain unsettled when facing south?"
Shun replied: "Those three lords still dwell among the weeds and mugwort. Why are you unsettled?
In ancient times, ten suns appeared together, illuminating all things—
How much more so when virtue advances?"

The three states—Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao—are named thus: Zong is one, Kuai two, and Xu’ao three.

Guo’s commentary:
The Dao has never had boundaries, yet there is nowhere it is not present. It has never had fixed distinctions of "this" or "that," right or wrong. To impose divisions upon it is to deny the Dao’s boundlessness, for all things freely inhabit their own domains. "Left" and "right" refer to differing conveniences; "order" and "propriety" mean that each thing has its principle, each affair its fitting course. "Differentiation" is the division and distinction among groups. "Competition" is the pursuit of the same goal; "contention" is the dispute in debate. These eight virtues lie beyond the six directions—beyond the inherent nature of the myriad things.

Though principles exist even beyond the nature of things, they do not pertain to what lies within their inherent nature and thus never move the sage. Therefore, the sage never discusses them. To do so would be to lead things to learn what they cannot. Thus, the sage does not debate what lies beyond the eight boundaries, allowing all to find harmony in their own attainment.

To discourse without deliberation is to set forth their nature and let them rest in it. To deliberate without contention is to follow their completed traces, modeling the ultimate appropriateness without clinging to one’s own rightness, unlike the common people.

"Undivided division" and "uncontended contention" mean that each thing divides itself, each affair distinguishes itself, yet those who insist on imposing their own distinctions fail to see how things distinguish themselves. To "cherish" is to hold fast to non-contention. The sage harbors nothing. Contention arises from not seeing how things contend themselves, so one argues from what one knows to show others.

"Not naming" is to leave things to name themselves, without imposing names. "Not speaking" means things distinguish themselves. "Not benevolent" means existing without attachment, self-sustaining. "Not modest" means being utterly sufficient—things come and go, yet it is not I who acts, so there is no place for modesty or fullness.

"Not envious" means going nowhere without accord, thus able to traverse no peril without going. "Dao illuminated but not Dao" is to use this to clarify that, where both this and that are lost. "Words eloquent but insufficient" means unable to reach what distinguishes itself.

"Benevolence constant but unfulfilled" means things have no constant love; constant love cannot be all-encompassing. "Integrity pure but untrusted" means forced purity and clarity are but the greed for reputation, not true integrity. "Courage envious but unprevailing" means envious, contrary courage is detested by all under heaven, leaving no ground to stand.

These five all injure what is fitting through deliberate action. One cannot cease from this.

Seeking externals from one’s original nature is endless. Yet the external cannot be sought—pursuing it is like trying to square the circle or envying fish for birds. The nearer one draws, the farther it recedes; the more one learns, the more one’s nature is lost. Thus, when things are equalized, the burden of partial preferences vanishes.

What lies beyond knowing belongs to the realm outside one’s nature; therefore, one halts within what is known and arrives at the utmost. "Eloquence without words" and "the Dao that is not the Dao" are the boundless, all-embracing spontaneity. "Neither full nor exhausted" describes the heart-mind of the perfected person, like a mirror that reflects without storing—vast and free from the fluctuations of fullness or emptiness.

"Not knowing whence it comes" speaks of the arrival of the utmost principle, naturally and without trace. "Preserving light" means allowing it to shine of itself, so its radiance is never obscured. To desire to conquer the three states yet feel unresolved is to have not yet attained the Dao of tranquil compliance; thus, one remains uneasy even while attending court.

The question arising from wonder is posed to lodge the principle of luminous equality in the great sage. For what beings find peaceful is not base—even mugwort and artemisia are the wondrous abode of the Three Masters. Why, then, this unresolved feeling? When double brightness ascends the heavens, the six directions are all illumined, with no mugwort or artemisia left unenlightened. Though the sun and moon shine without partiality, there are still places they do not reach; virtue, however, misses nothing.

Yet now, to seize the aspirations of mugwort and artemisia and force them to follow one’s own path toward the utmost Dao—how could this be fitting? Thus, the unease lingers, a matter of spiritual discernment. If beings flow freely in their nature, each resting in what it finds peaceful, whether distant or near, hidden or deep, left to itself, all attain their utmost. Then nothing is amiss for them, and nothing is not joyful for me.

---
**Zhao’s Annotation:**
To know where to halt in what one does not know is to be beyond naming—this is the perfection of the Dao. If one can grasp this, one’s center is empty, hence called the "Celestial Storehouse," the source from which all things emerge.

"Not full, not exhausted" means without limit or end. "Not knowing whence it comes" is to cast off even that knowledge. "Preserving light" speaks of naturally concealing one’s brightness.

Following the root: *"Great integrity is not content"*—*qiàn* (嗛) here means "to hold in the mouth," implying the mind clings to something. Some cling to satisfaction and sufficiency; others cling to resentment and lack. This speaks of "not being content in integrity," for one does not take integrity as self-sufficiency.

**Supplementary Annotation:**
What *Zhuangzi* calls "the judgments of things" refers generally to the Hundred Schools and their various arts. Each school holds its own views, yet none communicate with the others—right and wrong, this and that, diverge along separate paths, their myriad concerns impossible to exhaust. It is like the wind passing through mountains and forests, where sounds differ, or like the limbs and organs of a single body, each serving its distinct function. The phrase *"blowing in ten thousand different ways"* means these differences arise naturally, not through the power of mere judgments to create division.

If one allows things to follow their nature without engaging in debate, then the judgments of things become equal. Yet there exists in heaven and earth a kind of fundamental principle—discourse on it cannot be omitted, nor can it be lumped together with the Hundred Schools and their arts. Thus, the text adds these two sections, from *"Beyond the Six Directions"* to *"preserving light,"* to clarify that the teachings of sages and saints differ from those of other schools. This distinction is perfectly clear in the author’s mind; it simply remains unarticulated.

**Brush Notes:**
The Dao has no boundaries; words have no constancy. Why, then, would the sage despise boundaries or constancy? It is because they establish divisions of right and wrong. Left and right, ethical norms, distinctions, debates, and contentions—these eight are all called *"boundaries."* The sage preserves them without discussion, discusses without debate, debates without contention, and thus transcends the realm of right and wrong—how could boundaries arise?

Yet the sage does not merely avoid discussion, debate, or contention to be free of boundaries. Even when the sage sometimes discusses or debates, this cannot be called a boundary. The sage’s mind is without discrimination; to discriminate is to fail to discriminate, to debate is to fail to debate. The difference lies in this: the sage takes *"not seeing"* as debate, while the common people take *"showing to one another"* as debate.

*"Not boasting, not speaking, not benevolent, not content, not envious"*—these ancient sayings are cited as proof. In these five, perfect virtue is complete, names and appearances unestablished—this is what is called *"round."* If the Dao is made manifest through words, if benevolence is constant, if integrity is pure, if courage is bold, if envy is present, then edges and corners are too exposed, approaching squareness. Squareness is a boundary.

Alas! The world knows that *"not knowing"* is the utmost, but not knowing while knowing is even more utmost—what is called *"debate without words"* and *"the Dao that is not spoken."* This is *"being yet nonbeing, color yet emptiness"*—is it not the *"Celestial Storehouse"* that is *"not full when drawn from, not exhausted when poured,"* whose origin cannot be known? *"Preserving light"* is the state of *"knowing yet not knowing."*

---

*Nie Que* asked *Wang Ni*, "Do you know what all things share in common?"
"How would I know?" replied *Wang Ni*.
"Do you know what you do not know?"
"How would I know?"
"Then do things have no knowledge?"
"How would I know? Still, let me try to say: How can we be sure that what I call knowing is not not-knowing? How can we be sure that what I call not-knowing is not knowing? Now, let me ask you this: If people sleep in damp places, their waists ache and they become half-paralyzed—is that so for eels? If they dwell in trees, they tremble with fear—is that so for monkeys? Of these three, who knows the proper place to dwell?"

"Ah! Of these three, who knows the proper dwelling?

Humans eat the flesh of grain-fed and pasture-raised animals; elk and deer eat grass. Centipedes delight in snakes; owls and crows relish mice. Of these four, who knows the proper flavor?

Apes and monkeys take female gibbons as mates; elk consort with deer; loaches swim with fish. Mao Qiang and Lady Li are considered beauties by humans—yet when fish see them, they dive deep; when birds see them, they fly high; when elk and deer see them, they flee in haste. Of these four, who knows the proper beauty of the world?

From my perspective, the beginnings of benevolence and righteousness, the paths of right and wrong, are tangled and confused—how could I discern their distinctions?"

Nie Que said, "If you do not know benefit and harm, does the Perfect Person likewise not know benefit and harm?"

Wang Ni replied, "The Perfect Person is divine. Though great marshes burn, they cannot be scorched; though the Milky Way freezes, they cannot be chilled; though thunder splits mountains and winds shake the sea, they cannot be startled. Such a one rides the clouds and qi, harnesses the sun and moon, and roams beyond the Four Seas. Death and life bring no change to them—how much less the beginnings of benefit and harm?"

Guo's Commentary:
What is shared is not necessarily correct, nor is what differs uniquely wrong—neither self nor other can rectify the other, so knowledge serves no purpose. If one knows what one does not know, this is already a form of knowing; with knowing, one cannot entrust things to the natural course of the many talents. Only with complete unknowing does one become vast and unobstructed, able to entrust all things.

Those who venture tentative words do so precisely because they do not know, and thus dare not speak definitively—they merely test their words. Fish swim in water, a capacity all creatures share, and thus it is called "knowing." Yet from a bird's perspective, what was called "knowing" becomes "unknowing." Therefore, he cites the examples of humans, gibbons, and monkeys to illustrate the differing conveniences of the myriad things; then he cites humans, deer, grubs, and crows to show that beauty and ugliness have no fixed standard. He further lists gibbons, *biandan*, elk, deer, *fang*, fish, and creatures with radiant fur to demonstrate that what the world favors is not the same. If one condemns what differs, one cannot know that what is shared is necessarily correct.

Benevolence and righteousness, right and wrong, are tangled and confused: what benefits one may harm another, and with the endless "other" and "self" in the world, the contest of right and wrong has no constancy. Thus, only by refraining from disputing and allowing each to be self-so can all things be harmoniously attained.

Nie Que has not yet mastered this unknowing, so he still doubts whether the Perfect Person must know these things—this is a question left unresolved. The Perfect Person is divine, without deliberate intent yet in accord with all things.

The one who is neither stifled nor chilled, neither startled nor alarmed—this is the person of complete spirit, whose form is whole and whose substance merges with things. Though traversing the utmost transformations, they have never ceased to be themselves, thus remaining unbounded, with no thorns lodged in the heart.

Those who ride the clouds and qi borrow things to journey, yet it is not the self that moves. Those who roam the sun and moon know day and night but not life and death. Those who wander beyond the four seas are without knowledge of it, yet entrust the world to its own self-so—thus they gallop through the ten thousand things without exhaustion.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
The Dao cannot be known; to know it is precisely to be without knowledge. To know the "not-knowing" is to see the body of the Dao.
