Now, the common people take bodily ease and comfort as the correct state, the taste of fodder and grain-fed animals as the correct flavor, and the sight of beautiful colors as the correct appearance—just as gibbons find their own rest, maggots and crows their own sweetness, and fish, birds, elk, and deer their own mates. Like them, each takes their own knowledge as the correct knowledge. But can the common people and the ten thousand things truly have a single correct state, correct flavor, or correct appearance?

If one knows without attaining the correct state, correct flavor, or correct appearance, then what they know is not correct—this much is clear. Thus, from my perspective, benevolence and righteousness, right and wrong, are tangled and confused. How could I know their distinctions? This is why, when asked four times, I four times did not know.

The Perfect Person is divine. Being divine, they wondrously embody the ten thousand things, yet in speaking of the ten thousand things, none are not the self—while the self, in the end, is nothing. Who could then stifle, chill, or startle them?

The Doubtful Alone:
In all under heaven, the correct state is no-state; the correct flavor is no-flavor; the correct appearance is no-appearance. Yet those who take nothingness as correctness see only nothingness. Thus, they speak only of the distinctions between having state, flavor, and appearance, never of nothingness as correctness. From my perspective, right and wrong, benevolence and righteousness, are tangled and confused—who could set them right? Therefore, not knowing their distinctions is precisely how one distinguishes them.

Narrow Views:
What all things share is called "understanding," yet these explanations remain unclear. In my humble opinion, what humans and other beings share is their nature; what differs is their emotions. Nature flows into emotion, and each thing takes itself as correct. Their partial views point to horses and blame one another, debates escalate, and resentments arise—even to the point where liver and gall become as distant as Chu and Yue, and father and son become strangers. Such calamities truly begin with the word "knowledge," which falsely generates distinctions. Thus, Wang Ni answered three times, "How could I know?" Desiring to gnaw through the gap, he instead sought what he did not know, attaining their shared, identical nature and obscuring the principle of great penetration—this was close. Yet I fear it was still not a true meeting of minds. He then spoke of the differences between humans and birds or beasts, of how their proper states, flavors, and appearances are not correct. If so, then what is called "knowing"—is it truly knowing? And what is called "not knowing"—is it truly not knowing?

Following the Root:
The milu deer eat the sweet grass *jian*; the grass grows thick. Emperor Jing of Han decreed that some ponds abound with *jian* grass. Zhao Chongguo memorialized, "Now the barbarians have abandoned their fertile lands and *jian* grass."

Master Ququezi asked Master Changwuzi, "I have heard from the Master that the sage does not engage in affairs, does not pursue profit, does not avoid harm, does not delight in seeking, does not follow the Dao, has no words yet speaks, speaks yet has no words, and roams beyond the dust and grime. The Master considered these reckless words, but I see them as the wondrous practice of the Dao. What do you think?"

Master Changwuzi said, "These are words that even the Yellow Emperor would find dazzling—how could Confucius understand them? Moreover, you are far too hasty in your calculations, seeing an egg and seeking a rooster to crow at dawn, seeing a slingshot and seeking a roasted owl. I have spoken to you recklessly; you have listened recklessly.

What is it like? The sun and moon embrace the cosmos within their lips, placing their obscurity and murkiness together to honor one another. The masses toil endlessly; the sage appears foolish and dull. They encompass ten thousand years as a single accomplishment, yet the ten thousand things are all complete. How could I know that delighting in life is not delusion? How could I know that hating death is not like a youth who has lost his way and does not know to return? Lady Li was the daughter of the border warden of Ai. When the state of Jin first obtained her, she wept until her collar was soaked. Yet once she reached the king’s palace, shared his bed, and ate fine meats, she regretted her tears. How could I know that the dead do not regret their initial longing for life?

One who dreams of drinking wine may weep at dawn; one who dreams of weeping may go hunting at dawn. When dreaming, one does not know it is a dream. Within the dream, one may even interpret the dream. Only after waking does one know it was a dream."

Once awakened, one then knows it was a dream. Moreover, only with great awakening does one know this was all a great dream. Yet the foolish believe themselves awake, priding themselves on their keen discernment: "This is a lord! That is a herdsman!" How rigid! Even you and I, Qiu, are dreaming. When I say you are dreaming, I too am dreaming. Such words are called "perverse and strange." Yet ten thousand generations hence, should a great sage arise who understands their meaning, it will be as if encountering them at dawn or dusk.

The Keeper of Changwu said to Confucius: "Menglang’s words drift without direction, like listening to fireflies—confusing and bewildering." Cui Zhu comments: "Small brightness, not great understanding." *Shiye* refers to the rooster that marks the night; the *e* is a bird as large as a turtledove, with mottled plumage and exquisitely smooth flesh. *Hun* means unsettled; *kuang* (or *kuang*) is a bed, a place of rest. *Qieqie* means meticulous; *diaogui* means utterly strange.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: Those who do not pursue affairs find affairs come of themselves, principles naturally aligning—this is not a matter of chasing after them. Those who do not seek profit or avoid harm proceed directly forward, without evasion. Those who do not delight in seeking take what comes without joy; those who do not resent take what comes without anger. Those who do not rely on the Dao yet arrive alone—this is the state of having no words for what is called "having words," or having words for what is called "having no words." All such designations are not what I call so; each claims its own. Thus, there is no "that" with words, yet there is "this" without words. All that is not true nature is dust and grime.

Things possess their natural principles and ultimate limits. Following them directly leads to dark harmony, not through words. Thus, to speak is to drift aimlessly, and to hear is to be dazzled. Even the Yellow Emperor could not prevent all beings from harboring attachments and being dazzled by words. Therefore, the sage entrusts things to the realm beyond dust and grime, merging obscurely beyond the bounds of seeing and hearing, illuminating with Heaven and not opposing calculations, letting things be as they are without deliberate elucidation.

Now, when Qūquè hears Menglang’s drifting words and takes them for the practice of the wondrous Dao, it is no different from seeing an egg and demanding the crowing of a rooster, or seeing a slingshot and seeking the roasted flesh of an *e*. Those who cannot rest in their time and follow their lot, who probe transformations and seek change, who contemplate death while alive, and cling to this to debate that—all are those who oppose calculations. Since words drift aimlessly, let us try speaking them recklessly. If one listens correctly to reckless words, it is like calculating for a great drought. Thus, take life and death as day and night, a metaphor like the sun and moon; take the myriad things as a single body, a metaphor like embracing the cosmos. Because there is that which is deemed base, hierarchy arises, and with it, confusion and disorder that no one can set right. Each claims rightness from their own side. Therefore, the Dao of effortless harmony is best left unspoken, entrusted to its own spontaneity.

*Hunran* means without ripples, the state of being driven and rushing about in the realm of right and wrong. *Yuchun* describes the ignorant, moving straight ahead without awareness. *Chun* means unadulterated. To survey ten thousand generations and compare their changes, the common people call it mixed. Thus, they toil their forms and startle their minds, abandoning this to grasp that. Only the great sage, free from attachments, moves directly forward and unites with transformation, roaming constantly in solitude amid all changes. Though the Dao passes through countless ages, myriad differences, and endless variations, its accomplishment remains one—ancient and present are the same. When things are called so, the myriad things are one in their so-ness. Nothing is not so, no time is not complete—this may be called *chun*.

*Yun* means accumulation. Accumulating "this" over ten thousand years makes ten thousand years one "this." Accumulating "so" over the myriad things makes the myriad things entirely so. Thus, one does not know where life and death, before and after, reside, nor where victory and defeat between self and other lie. Life and death are one. Yet to delight solely in life and oppose transformation—how can one know this is not delusion? To lose one’s original home in youth is called *ruofang*; *ruofang* means chasing comfort in one’s present place without knowing to return to the homeland. How can one know that life is not such a loss?

To know that death is not a return and yet to detest it—how is this different? Observe Lady Li: first she wept, then she repented—her emotions shifted thus within a single life. At such moments, one does not even know oneself; how then can one know the transformations of death and life? Thus, between waking and dreaming, if circumstances change, emotions differ, and the wishes of life and death cannot be the same. If one delights in life while alive, then one will delight in death when dead. Though life and death differ, in each attaining its wish, they are one. What then is there to cling to?

At the moment of dreaming, one does not know it is a dream; at the hour of death, one likewise does not know it is death but follows one’s will. The dreamer, even while dreaming, may interpret the dream—yet this differs not from the waking state. In whatever one encounters, there is nothing lacking. Why then, while alive, should one worry about death?

The great awakened one is the sage. The great awakened one knows that those who harbor anxieties and concerns have not yet awakened. The foolish, lost in a great dream, believe themselves awake, stealthily elevating their preferences as rulers and condemning their dislikes as servants. Joyfully clinging to the biases of their household, they may be called truly benighted. Extraordinary discourse is beyond the ken of ordinary men, hence it is called "consoling." Though it may seem strange and uncanny, they do not recognize its profound liberation. Those who encounter it at dawn or dusk, who can speak of it and shed all attachments, uniting life and death as one—such people are exceedingly rare.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The sage knows neither advantage nor harm, thus has no inclinations or aversions. Lacking nothing, he does not seek; acting without contrivance, he does not stray from the Dao. To have assertions is the very reason for having none; to have none is the very reason for having them. Only the unburdened heart can align with this. Ququezi once heard the Master speak of this, dismissing it as reckless—yet later deemed it the wondrous Dao. Both views miss the mark. The Dao is not borne by speech or silence. The *shiye* bird hatches from an egg, yet the egg is not the *shiye*; the osprey is roasted by the slingshot, yet the slingshot is not the osprey. The wondrous Dao arises from what is heard, yet what is heard is not the wondrous Dao.

Those who today hear the Dao believe themselves enlightened, yet they do not know to daily diminish their attachments until reaching non-action—all are disciples of Quque. The Dao cannot be transmitted through words. What I speak and what you hear are but delusions. To desire deluded words yet grasp them with the heart—this is to know how the sun and moon become luminous and merge with their light, to know how the cosmos becomes the cosmos and its mechanism lies within one’s grasp. When words align perfectly, this is the practice of the wondrous Dao—not merely hearing it. Those who muddy its clarity and exalt one another with flattery are surely set aside and not adopted.

The multitude toil endlessly, achieving nothing; the sage appears foolish and ignorant, vacant yet not scattered. Though ten thousand generations pass, he unites them as one, forming purity. The myriad things are entirely so, mutually accumulating through this. My body encompasses the myriad things; the myriad things are my body. Uniting ten thousand years into one pure whole, even a child who dies young may outlive Pengzu. The myriad things being entirely so, mutually accumulating through this, even a autumn hair may surpass Mount Tai.

Viewed through Lady Li’s example, how can one know the dead do not regret their former pursuit of life? Why then should life be delightful and death detestable?

**Bixu’s Commentary:**
"Uniting ten thousand years into one pure whole" means traversing past and present as a single dawn and dusk, merging all changes into undifferentiated completion. The perfected person regards life and death as a great dream, transcending them as the great awakening. The multitude take the mingling of souls as dreaming and the separation of forms as waking—confused and strange, they are deluded by life and death. Thus, the enlightened utter these ultimate words on dreams and awakening to console the uncanny bonds of death. Though life and death’s ties have no cords, they cannot be undone. If, after ten thousand generations, one encounters a great sage who unravels this knot of life and death, it is like an encounter at dawn or dusk.

**New Transmission:**
"Merging with the sun and moon" refers to a single day and night; "grasping the cosmos" means equaling far and near. The multitude have a self and objects, are enslaved by things, hence are called "toiling." The sage has no self, no objects, and becomes one with things, hence is called "foolish" and "vacant."

**Xuxi’s Commentary:**
"Flattery" is the lowest. Harmonizing with the dust and preceding the lowest—this is why flattery is exalted. To exalt flattery is to have no lower; to have no lower is to have no disgrace. Laozi said, "Honor is lowly"—this is the meaning. "Ruler or servant"—this refers to dreaming of being a lord or a servant. The whole world is dreaming, yet they stealthily choose between them—how benighted!

**Bishu’s Commentary:**
"Why" belongs to the next sentence. *Ruofang* in the *Record of Rites* (Chapter 20) means "loss." "Encountering it at dawn or dusk" means having one who knows it. Though ten thousand generations distant, it is like dawn and dusk—emphasizing its rarity. The ancients said, "A sage every thousand *li* is like shoulder to shoulder"—the meaning is similar.

Even if you and I were to debate, if you defeat me, or I defeat you—is it truly so?

"I am truly in the wrong—yet if I defeat you, or you do not defeat me, am I truly right? Or if you are truly right, yet I am truly wrong—is it possible one of us is right, or one wrong? Or could both be right, or both wrong? You and I cannot know each other—then people are fundamentally shrouded in obscurity. Whom shall we ask to set it right? If we ask one who agrees with you to set it right, since they already agree with you, how can they set it right? If we ask one who agrees with me to set it right, since they already agree with me, how can they set it right? If we ask one who differs from both you and me to set it right, since they already differ from both you and me, how can they set it right? If we ask one who agrees with both you and me to set it right, since they already agree with both you and me, how can they set it right? Thus, you, I, and others—none can know each other, yet must we await another?

What does it mean to harmonize with the Heavenly Pivot? It is to say: 'Is it so? Is it not so? If so, then so differs from not-so—yet there is no debate. If so, then so differs from not-so—yet there is no debate.' The mutual dependence of changing sounds—if they do not depend on each other, harmonize them with the Heavenly Pivot, follow them with the myriad transformations, and so exhaust the years. Forget the years, forget righteousness, rouse yourself to the boundless—thus lodge in the boundless."

Guo's Commentary:
To infer when one does not know, to debate when one does not see—debate is insufficient for self-assurance, for it stands in opposition to things. Debating in opposition all day, one remains in darkness until the end, unable to set anything right. Thus, one must leave it to self-correction. Agreement leads to affirmation, difference to negation—neither is fully trustworthy. If "so" were truly so, then the world could no longer negate it; if "not-so" were truly not-so, then there would be no grounds to affirm it. Now, one affirms what is agreed upon and negates what differs—yet with both agreement and difference present, affirmation and negation lack a foundation. Thus, affirmation and negation arise from the love of debate and rest in the Heavenly Pivot. Entrust them to the twofold course and cease in self-correction. If relying on another is insufficient to correct this, then none in the world can correct another. Thus, entrust it to self-correction, and therein lies perfection.

The Heavenly Pivot is the natural division. Affirmation and negation, so and not-so, self and other stand in opposition—hence there is no debate. With no debate, one harmonizes with the Heavenly Pivot, abiding in the natural division alone, without relying on another to correct this. The debate of affirmation and negation is but a changing sound; changing sounds in mutual dependence are all insufficient to correct one another. Thus, as if they do not depend on each other, harmonize with the natural division and follow the boundless transformation. Pursuing this path, the realm of affirmation and negation naturally dissolves, and the attainment of one’s nature and destiny is fully realized. Forgetting the years, one merges life and death; forgetting righteousness, one transcends affirmation and negation. When affirmation and negation, life and death are swept away into oneness, this is the ultimate principle. The ultimate principle flows unbounded—thus, those who lodge in it find no limit.

Lü's Commentary:
What the world calls affirmation and negation is no more than: I affirm what you negate, you affirm what I negate, or both affirm, both negate—all four arise from you and me. Yet if neither you nor I can know each other, then what is called affirmation and negation remains ultimately obscure. Humans are inherently enveloped in darkness—who then can correct it? It must be corrected by others. But are others the same as oneself? If the same as oneself, then the same as you; if different from oneself, then different from you. Are they the same as you? If the same as me and you, then different from me and you. Yet you, I, and others are no more than these four, and none can correct another—thus, you, I, and others all cannot know each other. Must we await another? It means we do not await another.

Only the sage knows this: though changing sounds depend on each other, if they do not depend on each other, then affirmation and negation find no counterpart and rest in the Heavenly Pivot. Why? Affirmation and negation have no reality—they are but sounds arising from transformation. The dependence or non-dependence of you and others arises from the deluded calculations of the discerning mind. If I harmonize with the Heavenly Pivot without dividing or debating, follow the boundless transformation, and extend it endlessly, then the myriad things do not burden the mind. To exhaust the years is to merge the ten thousand ages into a single, pure whole.

The absence of debate over "so or not-so, so or not" arises from knowing their shared essence—all things are thus. To exhaust the years is to forget the years; to be without affirmation and negation is to forget righteousness. It begins in the boundless, thus it ultimately lodges in the boundless. "Changing sounds in mutual dependence—this is how one exhausts the years." This passage should be placed above "What does it mean to harmonize with the Heavenly Pivot?"—the text’s compilation is erroneous here, as the meaning makes clear.

Yi Du’s Notes:
Whenever one says "is," it is not necessarily so; whenever one says "so," it is not necessarily so—thus their agreement and difference are also without debate. Yet "so" and "is" stand in mutual opposition, equally subject to change. There are transformations, and there are transforming transformations; there are sounds, and there are sounding sounds. Sounds arise from transformations—without transformation, sounds are not manifest; sounds manifest transformations—without sound, transformations are not revealed. This is the mutual dependence of changing sounds. Yet sounds emerge from transformations, which sounds cannot know; transformations encompass sounds, which sounds cannot comprehend. This is as if they do not depend on each other.

Dependence arises from two things; if the ten thousand transformations are merged into one, then the traces of dependence have no place to arise. Sounds are constant sounds—they do not wait for things to be heard; hearing arises from things themselves. Transformations are constant transformations—they do not wait for sounds to be seen; understanding arises from sounds themselves. This is how they depend on each other yet seem not to.

Guan Jian’s Observations:
The distinctions between life and death, waking and dreaming arise from transformation; the debates of self and other, affirmation and negation arise from sound. They seem to depend on each other, yet transformations transform on their own, unaware of how they transform; sounds sound on their own, unaware of how they sound—thus, they seem not to depend on each other. In the end, the utmost principle of things cannot escape the spontaneity of creation. This is the source and passage of the ten thousand transformations, the great equalizer of the myriad things.

Xiang Dao’s Explanation:
The Heavenly Pivot is the beginning of nature and destiny; the boundless transformation is the endless change. Harmonizing with the Heavenly Pivot and following the boundless transformation, self and things are not obscured by affirmation and negation, and each fulfills its allotted nature and destiny—this is how one exhausts the years. Forgetting the years, life and death become a single thread; forgetting righteousness, right and wrong become a single strand. Life and death, right and wrong—once swept away into oneness, this is the ultimate principle. The ultimate principle flows unbounded—thus, knowing the forgetful one does not take it as something substantial, but merely lodges in it.

Fu Mo’s Supplementary Notes:
Above, it was said that one must await a sage of future ages to resolve it—thus, another layer of discussion follows: you, I, and others—none can know each other, so why await another? That "another" is the sage, who is the knowing of the unknowing, the debating of the non-debating, the one who harmonizes with the Heavenly Pivot. The Heavenly Pivot is the vanishing of "is and is not, so and not-so"—though sounds may lodge in affirmation and negation, they are but changing sounds. Their dependence and non-dependence are the same. "Dependence" refers to the "awaiting another" above—it concludes in endlessness. A Chan master was once asked, "What is it ultimately?" He replied, "There is no ultimate here"—this is the meaning of "no bound."

Shadow asked Shade, "Previously you moved—now you are still; previously you sat—now you rise. Why are you so without constancy?"
Shade replied, "Do I depend on something to be thus? Does what I depend on also depend on something to be thus? Do I depend on the scales of a snake or the wings of a cicada? How would I know why it is so? How would I know why it is not so?"

Formerly, Zhuang Zhou dreamed he was a butterfly, fluttering happily—a butterfly indeed! He was content and unaware of being Zhou. Suddenly he awoke, and there he was, solidly Zhou. He did not know whether Zhou had dreamed he was a butterfly, or a butterfly had dreamed it was Zhou. Between Zhou and the butterfly, there must be a distinction—this is called the transformation of things.

Guo's Commentary:
"Vast darkness is the shadow beyond the shadow—it is the yin that guards the outer bounds. 'Do I depend on something to be thus?' speaks of the heavenly mechanism moving of itself. To sit and rise without dependence—who alone attains this? Who could know its cause and demand its reason?

If one demands what it depends on and traces its origin, the tracing and demanding will be endless, until finally the principle of being without dependence and transforming alone becomes clear. If one depends on the scales of a snake or the wings of a cicada, then the source of its independent conduct would not be difficult to discern. Now, the reason it is not discerned lies precisely in its not depending on this and transforming alone.

Some say that vast darkness depends on shadow, shadow on form, and form on the Creator—then I ask: does the Creator exist or not? If not, how could it create things? If it does, then it is insufficient to give rise to the multitude of forms. Thus it is clear that the multitude of forms give rise to themselves and create themselves without dependence—this is the true nature of Heaven and Earth.

Therefore, self and other are mutually entailed, form and shadow arise together, and though they may seem to merge in mystery, they do not depend on one another. Now, vast darkness arising from shadow is like saying they arise together without dependence. Thus vast darkness is not controlled by shadow, nor is shadow manipulated by form, nor is form transformed by nothingness. Whether transforming or not, being so or not—whether following others or proceeding from oneself—all is so of itself. How could I know its reason?

Thus, to follow without aiding is to have no trace of beginning or end, inner or outer. But if one demands these proximate causes and forgets their self-so origin, attaching things to externals and losing the master within, then attachment and esteem arise. How could equanimity be attained?

'Content and unaware of being Zhou'—this is to delight in one’s own will, to find joy in one’s own nature, to act with ease and pleasure."

When one dreams of being a butterfly and forgets Zhou, this is no different from the distinction of life and death. Suddenly awakening, one feels only that Zhou is Zhou—this is merely called "awakening," yet it may well be another dream. Now, not knowing the butterfly is no different from the dream’s not knowing Zhou. Each suits its momentary will, so how can one prove the butterfly does not dream of being Zhou?

There are those who doze briefly yet dream of a hundred years—how then can one prove that this present hundred years is not the dream of a dozer? The distinction between waking and dreaming is no different from the debate over life and death. What now serves as self-comparison to suit one’s will arises from the fixity of these divisions, not from their absence.

Time does not pause even for an instant, nor does the present persist—thus yesterday’s dream has already transformed by today. Is the change of life and death any different? Why trouble the heart over such distinctions? When one is thus engaged, one does not know that the other dreams of being a butterfly. Taking it from a human perspective, in this single lifetime, one does not know whether the future will bring Lady Li—yet fools whisper to themselves, believing they know that life is joyful and death dreadful, as if they had never heard of the transformation of things.

Lü’s Annotation:
The relationship between the shadow’s attendant (wangliang) and the shadow is the same as that of ours with others—yet they do not know the shadow depends not on form, just as we do not know we depend not on others. For the shadow’s movement and stillness, sitting and rising, follow only the form, possessing no independent nature. Yet being without sentience, how could it know dependence? If one claims the shadow depends on form, then on what does form depend to exist? The shadow’s dependence on form is not like the snake’s reliance on its belly-scales to move or the cicada’s on its wings to fly. How can one know the reason for this being so or not so? If one can comprehend the insentience of things, then even the snake’s belly-scales and the cicada’s wings are without dependence.

Thus, when one is a butterfly, one flutters blissfully, unaware of Zhou; when one is Zhou, one stirs uneasily, unaware of the butterfly. If even the transformations of a single body are not self-known, how can things of differing forms know one another? When things do not know one another, each returns to its root; when things do not depend on one another, none finds its counterpart. How could there be any lack of uniformity?

Oral Exegesis:
In Zhuang Zhou’s case, the night’s transformation into a butterfly was a dream—yet he feared that the butterfly, existing there, might now take his present waking as a dream. Hence he said, “Does not know whether Zhou dreamed of being a butterfly or the butterfly dreamed of being Zhou.” This dream and waking must have a point of distinction, so he said, “Zhou and the butterfly must have a division.” This sentence seems to conclude yet does not, merely urging one to investigate the matter here.

Xu Xi:
Dream and waking are equal; things, self, small and large, right and wrong, life and death—all are equal. Others, in discussing this, would conclude with equality, but he coldly turns the phrase to overturn all previous arguments: “Zhou and the butterfly must have a division.” The unknowing take this as still making distinctions; the knowing see it as the mechanism by which both man and ox are lost. The words seem contrary, yet speak truly.

Supplementary Ink:
This further develops the earlier discussion of mutual dependence: the shadow’s attendant depends on the shadow, the shadow on form, form on creation—now I depend on others, others on Heaven. Thus, one need not depend on others; one may harmonize with Heaven’s natural boundaries and find sufficiency in the Heavenly within oneself.

To divide dream and waking between self and other: I am the butterfly in the dream, the other is Zhuang Zhou after waking. With one person divided between dream and waking, now the butterfly in the dream, now Zhuang Zhou after waking, he said, “There must be a division.” This is what is meant by “one yet two, two yet one.” If they were truly two, they would require mutual dependence; if originally one, there would be no need for dependence. The transformation of things speaks of past and present, dream and waking fused into one. Only after the transformation of things can one be “not a thing among things.”

General Observations from My Humble View:
The opening presents a dialogue between two masters, elaborating the inequality of human and earthly pipes to clarify the spontaneity of Heavenly pipes—not only does principle not depend on equality, but equality cannot reach it. Thus, in response to their questions, he cites evidence from the side and draws parallels, yet does not directly name the Heavenly pipes, wishing for the heart to intuit and grasp it for itself.

The myriad things entangle and disperse, flourish and fade, ever-changing in form and color, self-arising and self-ceasing, ultimately returning to the Heavenly pipes to rest. The Heavenly Axis is without form or sound, yet the source from which form and sound arise, the manifestation of divine transformation. If one can thoroughly investigate the origins of human and earthly pipes, then the Heavenly pipes may be known. As Guo’s commentary says, “Is there yet another thing? It is simply the myriad apertures, the bamboo flutes, joined in the commonality of living beings to together complete one Heaven.”

To the discussion of knowing words, waking and dreaming, the heart’s utterances, the blowing of approval or disapproval, right and wrong, life and death—are these not the same? The myriad apertures roar in fury, yet when one attains the center of the ring to respond to the inexhaustible, one is empty to receive things, and things are likewise unimpeded. This is forgetting while the other self-transforms—what is called “wind aiding the emptiness of apertures.”

“Heaven and earth as one finger, the myriad things as one horse”—this is using non-uniformity to unify the vast, the strange, the deceitful, the monstrous. The Dao unites them as one, not requiring uniformity yet naturally uniform. As for the monkey-keeper’s distribution of taro, the joy and anger it engenders, or Zhaowen’s zither playing, the completion and loss it reveals—these show that having a heart and acting intentionally are insufficient to transform things, let alone achieve uniformity.

Yet “Heaven and earth and I are born together, the myriad things and I are one”—this can be called uniformity. But one must guard against taking “one” and “words” as two, or “two” and “one” as three, which would be the omen of scattering and non-uniformity. Only by reaching “before there were things” and pouring from the inexhaustible, by awakening to the great dream and investigating the myriad ages to unify them, can one encompass the Dao of unifying the world’s things.

The shadow’s attendant questioning the shadow, not knowing the same yet different; the *Nanhua*’s butterfly dream—who can determine whether it is same or different? This thoroughly discusses the non-uniformity of self and other, life and death, waking and dreaming, yet ultimately returns to the transformation of things. The *Nanhua*’s “transformation” is the *Great Change*’s “spirit,” latent in the indistinct, manifest in daily use yet beyond knowing and knowledge. From this, one awakens to the myriad things as one form, the myriad forms as one transformation, the myriad transformations as one spirit. Illuminating the spirit and understanding it, transforming and penetrating it—who is thing, who is self? This is called the great uniformity.

Brush Notes:
The “Equalizing Things” chapter begins by unifying self and other, right and wrong, success and failure, more and less, small and large—yet when its words reach their utmost, it proceeds to investigate past and present, unify life and death, equate dream and waking, and harmonize the thousand changes and myriad transformations into one. This is what is called “understanding thoroughly without obstruction.”

Yet if self and other can be equalized, how can dream and waking be the same? For the actions of day and the dreams of night are one, though day is waking and night is sleep—a slight difference. Over time, when this is thoroughly understood, the actions of day and the dreams of night become indistinct, without division.

Jiang Yue said: “Waking can know dreams, but dreams cannot know waking—thus waking is certainly truer than dreams. What waking attains remains within thought and consideration; the foreknowledge of dreams arises outside thought and consideration—thus dreams are more numinous than waking. The waking of each day has its regular patterns; the dreams of each night often lack continuity. The difference between dream and waking is thus so great—how much more so the great change of life and death? If one is not such a person, can one avoid drowning in creation?”

Nevertheless, if one can early awaken to dream and waking, then the coming and going of life and death are also not worth discussing.

**Chapter Three: The Main Principle of Nurturing Life**
*(Guo Xiang’s Commentary: Life is preserved through nurturing, and thus nurturing life is the ultimate principle. Yet if nurturing exceeds its proper limit, it harms life—this is not the true principle of nurturing life.)*

Our life has limits, but knowledge is boundless. To pursue the boundless with the limited is perilous. And to persist in such pursuit is perilous indeed. In doing good, avoid proximity to fame; in doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment. Follow the central path as your constant guide—thus can you preserve the body, fulfill life, nurture your kin, and live out your years.
*(Perilous: as previously noted, meaning exhaustion. To follow the central path: to adhere to the middle. Zhao’s commentary: among the extraordinary meridians, the central vessel is the Governing Vessel; in clothing, it is the seam running down the back—also called the "governing" line. The *Book of Rites* and *Deep Robes* commentary: "constant" means unchanging.)*

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
Life has its limits—each receives a destined allotment. When one lifts heavy burdens or carries light ones with ease, this is the limit of one’s strength. Yet those who crave fame and dominance, even if they surpass others in physical prowess, still find their desires unfulfilled—this is the boundlessness of knowledge. Thus, the pursuit of knowledge arises from misjudgment and vanishes in profound equilibrium. Profound equilibrium means following one’s inherent limits without the slightest excess. Therefore, though bearing a weight of ten thousand *jun*, if it accords with one’s capacity, one suddenly forgets the weight upon the body. Though responding to ten thousand affairs, one remains oblivious to their presence—this is the true principle of nurturing life. But if one with finite nature seeks boundless knowledge, how can one avoid exhaustion? Already exhausted by knowledge, and yet failing to cease, one further employs knowledge to remedy it—this is nurturing that harms life, truly the greatest peril.

The only way is to forget good and evil, abide in the center, and let all things follow their own course, merging obscurely with what is most fitting. Thus, punishment and fame recede, and the integrity of principle resides within. "Following the central path as one’s constant guide" means taking the middle as one’s norm. If one attains the center and moves in profound accord, then preserving the body, fulfilling life, nurturing kin, and living out one’s years—none of these are impossible. Nurturing life does not seek to exceed one’s limits; it is merely the fulfillment of principle and the completion of one’s years.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
Life follows form and thus has an end; knowledge pursues things and thus is endless. To follow knowledge with life is perilous indeed. To persist in such pursuit is perilous to the end. The world knows beauty as beauty, and thus ugliness arises; it knows good as good, and thus what is not good arises. Good and evil both arise from knowledge—how far apart are they? Only by neither upholding the conduct of benevolence and righteousness to seek fame nor engaging in licentious and perverse acts to court punishment, but instead abandoning both good and evil and adhering to what cannot be otherwise as one’s constant—only then does one hollow out the heart, cast aside knowledge, and rest in the Dao of unknowing. What more could be added to preserving the body, fulfilling life, nurturing kin, and living out one’s years?

**Yi Du’s Remarks:**
When true nature is divided, good and evil arise; when good and evil are established, fame and punishment follow. Only by following the natural tendencies of life without diminishing or adding to the myriad things, merging with them without praise or blame, can one transcend the reach of fame and punishment. The world’s notion of good fame arises from those who fall short; its notion of evil fame arises from those who exceed. Some lightly regard life and pursue righteousness to seek fleeting fame; others covet life and chase profit, only to meet an untimely death midway—all are what is meant by "proximity to fame and punishment" in good and evil. They do not follow the natural tendencies of life but instead depart from what is excessive in themselves.

**Personal Observations:**
"In doing good, avoid proximity to fame; in doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment." If one cites the idea that "good not accumulated is insufficient to establish fame, evil not accumulated is insufficient to destroy the self" as evidence, then this is doing and yet approaching fame and punishment. If one cites the idea that "above, one does not dare to uphold the conduct of benevolence and righteousness; below, one does not dare to engage in licentious and perverse acts," then this is not doing and yet not approaching fame and punishment. The meaning here differs from the text. What the world calls good and evil merely observes their traces. The good and evil of the sage and worthy are impartial and without boundaries, acting through non-action—how could the common mind comprehend this?

To do good and evil yet not approach fame and punishment, or to not do good and evil yet remain without fame and punishment—both accord with principle. Now, to act without approaching fame and punishment is viewed by the world as good and evil, yet the heart of the sage and worthy constantly follows the central path, aligning with the spontaneity of Heaven’s principle. Thus, profit and harm cannot reach it, and it is where the Dao returns.

The character *du* (督, "governing") glosses the "middle" as the state before joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure arise—not the middle between good and evil. If, in the moment before the seven emotions arise, one follows this as the constant Dao, then the mind is empty, penetrating, and spiritually unobstructed, with nothing to bind it. One merges with the Supreme Ultimate in undifferentiated unity—how then could one know whether the body can be preserved, life fulfilled, kin nurtured, or years lived out?

---

Butcher Ding was carving an ox for Lord Wenhui. Where his hand touched, where his shoulder leaned, where his foot pressed, where his knee braced—*xi!* *huo!*—the sounds of the blade resounded in harmony. Every movement aligned with the rhythm of the *Sanglin* dance, matching the cadence of the *Jingshou* melody.

Lord Wenhui exclaimed, "Ah! Excellent! How has your skill reached such heights?"

Butcher Ding set down his knife and replied, "What your servant delights in is the Dao, which has advanced beyond mere skill."

When your servant first began carving oxen, all I saw was the whole ox. After three years, I no longer saw the ox in its entirety. Now, I meet it with my spirit rather than seeing it with my eyes; my senses cease, and my spirit moves as it wills. Following the natural patterns, I cleave along the great crevices, guide the blade through the great cavities, moving in accord with what is inherently so. My skill never touches the ligaments or tendons, much less the great bones.

A good butcher changes his knife once a year—because he cuts. A common butcher changes his knife every month—because he hacks. Your servant’s knife has now been used for nineteen years, carving several thousand oxen, yet its edge is as if newly whetted. For where the joints have space, and the blade has no thickness—when what has no thickness enters where there is space, how vast is the room for the blade to move! Thus, after nineteen years, the edge of my knife remains as if newly whetted.

Nevertheless, whenever I come to a complex joint, I perceive the difficulty, become cautious, focus my gaze, slow my movements, and move the blade with utmost care. Then—*huo!*—it falls apart like clods of earth scattered on the ground. I stand holding the knife, look all around, linger in satisfaction, then wipe the blade clean and put it away."

Lord Wenhui said, "Excellent! From Butcher Ding’s words, I have learned how to nurture life."

The "Jingshou" is the movement of the *Xianchi* music. *Xie* refers to the spaces between, as Li of Que explains; *kuan*, as Sima explains, means "void." *Ken* denotes the attachment of flesh to bone, while *qing* refers to the knotted junctures. *Gu* are the large bones. "Nineteen years" takes ten years as a measure, with nine years added to express its length. *Xing* is a whetstone.

To "wipe the knife" means to clean it.

Guo’s commentary:
From the hand’s contact to the *Jingshou*’s divisions, it speaks of following convenience to apply skill, leaving nothing unmastered or unprincipled—so perfectly attuned to the ox’s structure that it also harmonizes with the rhythm of the music. "Advancing beyond technique" means merely lodging the Dao within skill. What he loves is not the skill itself. What he sees is nothing but the ox, for he has yet to perceive the spaces within its structure. He has never seen the whole ox, only the spaces within its structure. He encounters it with spirit, not with the eyes—obscuring the divisions with principle. The senses of perception cease, and the spirit’s desires move; the faculties of inspection are abandoned, and the mind flows freely in accord with principle. Those who follow Heaven’s pattern do not cut across it. To "strike the great spaces" means to follow the bounded places and strike them to separate. To "guide through the great voids" means to follow the joints’ openings and guide the blade to divide them. He relies on what is inherently so, never applying the knife recklessly. The blade moves through emptiness, never encountering obstruction—this is the marvel of the technique. "Intertwined and clustered" describes the complex joints; "gaze fixed" means no longer directing attention elsewhere. "Movements slow" refers to the hand’s caution. "Moving the blade with utmost care" means that once the division is achieved, little force is needed. "Like clods of earth scattered on the ground" means the structure is understood so thoroughly that the knife leaves no trace, as if earth were merely gathered. "Wiping the knife and putting it away" means cleaning the blade and sheathing it. Since the knife can be nurtured, one knows that life can also be nurtured.

Lü’s commentary:
Things are obstructed by their solidity, while the Dao flows through emptiness. Before hearing the Dao, one sees nothing but things; after hearing the Dao, one sees nothing but the Dao. "Encountering with spirit, not with the eyes" illustrates that those who have heard the Dao grasp it with the heart, not with knowledge or perception. "The senses of perception cease, and the spirit’s desires move" means relying on Heaven’s pattern to reach the great bones.

This is indeed to have never seen the whole ox. In the world, there is nothing that is not the Dao, and nothing through which it does not flow—it is simply thus. What one sees is nothing but the ox, and the analogy of the blade wearing out and harming life: after nineteen years, the blade is as if newly sharpened, not because it has not harmed the life within. As for its form, there has never been a thing that does not resemble its joints having spaces between them. As for its life, there has never been a life that does not resemble the blade’s lack of thickness. In its roaming of the blade, there is ever ample room—does this not resemble one who embodies the Dao and roams among the ten thousand things? Nevertheless, whenever one reaches the dense clusters, I see the difficulty in proceeding—what people fear cannot but be feared. With caution, one becomes alert; the gaze is fixed, the movement slow, until one reaches perfection, wipes the blade, and sheathes it. Thus, being as careful at the end as at the beginning, there will be no failure.

Li Shibiao’s discourse:
Things are fundamentally no-things, and their essence naturally departs from the Dao, through which nothing does not flow—where then is there need for "dissolution"? What Zhuangzi calls "dissolving the ox" is to depart from things and empty the heart, never having seen the ox; to ride the void and follow principle, never having passed through the blade. This is also to dissolve through non-dissolution.

Moreover, nineteen years is not a short time, having traversed the cycles of yin and yang. The oxen dissolved number in the thousands, responding to the changes of worldly affairs—this is not a small matter. Yet the blade remains as if newly sharpened, for clinging to traces means that in an instant all has already shifted, while grasping the root means that from ancient times to the present, nothing departs. One’s own body is already illusory—what knife is there that can be wielded? The ten thousand things are all delusions—what ox is there that can be dissolved?

When both self and things are forgotten, subject and object vanish. Thus, without ever striking, the great gaps naturally part; without ever guiding, the great cavities naturally release. The blade moves with a *huo* sound, yet there is no labor in responding to things; the blade is set down, yet there is no burden of lingering things. In the end, "wiping the blade and sheathing it" is a return to non-use.

Viewed through the Dao, in dissolution there is no dissolution; if not obstructed, then dissolution is also unknowable. In obstruction there is no obstruction; if not dissolved, then obstruction also does not stand. From the perspective of Cook Ding, the ordinary cook dissolves obstructions. From the perspective of the ordinary cook, Cook Ding is obstructed by dissolution. When both dissolution and obstruction are relinquished, there is only emptiness. Roaming with this Dao beyond the ten thousand things—where then would there be any obstruction?

Yang Yongxiu remarked: "The *huo* sound of the blade never fails to strike the right note—it speaks of the rhythm of the cleaver’s dance in perfect measure. Thus we know that within heaven and earth, nothing is not music. The merchant’s bell harmonizes with the pitch of *huangzhong*; Cook Ding’s blade aligns with the *Sanglin* dance. Even the cowherd’s leaf-whistle and the chambered wife’s washing mallet—all correspond to tone. How could music ever be absent?"

Gongwen Xuan saw the Right Master and was startled, saying: "What manner of man is this? How is it that he is one-legged?" Was this given by heaven, or was it man’s doing? He replied: "It was heaven, not man. Heaven’s creation made him thus solitary; man’s form has its counterparts. From this we know it was heaven, not man."

The marsh pheasant takes ten steps for a single peck, a hundred steps for a single drink, yet it does not seek to be kept in a cage. Though its spirit may be royal, it finds no joy in such confinement.

[Note: Gongwen was a surname; the given name was Xuan, a man of Song.]

Guo’s commentary: *Jie* is the term for one who is partially amputated. To know what one cannot help is to acknowledge heaven. To violate what one knows is to act as man. Partial amputation is called *du*—solitary. The Master of a household may possess knowledge, yet if he cannot preserve both feet, then his knowledge is powerless. If the Right Master’s knowledge were to insist on preserving both, his spirit would be inwardly distressed, his body outwardly constrained. How could this be merely a matter of partial amputation?

When both feet walk together, it is called *having a counterpart*; in such a form, none doubt it is fate. Thus, to know the solitary is also not to claim it as oneself. Therefore, one who grasps the essence of life does not strive for what life cannot provide; one who grasps the essence of fate does not strive for what fate cannot accommodate. To preserve one’s natural state is all—seeking is the cage.

The cage is what confines the pheasant. To bow and rise between heaven and earth, to roam freely—this is the Way.

The realm of self-attainment is indeed the wondrous ground of nurturing life—why then seek to enter the cage and submit to confinement? For one begins in harmony yet ultimately never remains in harmony: this is the forgetting of harmony. When the spirit ever reigns supreme and the will’s qi overflows with ease, one naturally wanders in the clear and boundless expanse, suddenly unaware of goodness as goodness.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
Right Master was one whose form was human but whose nature was of Heaven. Standing solitary and steadfast, when Gongwen Xuan saw him, he doubted whether he was man or Heaven’s creation—this is what it means to be made solitary. What one attains from the principle of nature and fate is originally thus. As for engaging with things and taking on the appearance of having a counterpart, that is merely the human. The marsh pheasant drinking and pecking at ease, its heart roaming with Heaven and harmonizing with its nature and fate, serves as an analogy. Not seeking to be caged and tamed, its spirit reigns supreme, untroubled by restraint—this is the analogy of one who, though dwelling among men, cannot attain free wandering. The nurturance within the cage, even if it brings the spirit to reign supreme, is not what it naturally prefers; it is not as good as the rare yet self-attained drinking and pecking in the marsh.

**Bǐshèng’s Notes:**
"Solitary and steadfast" (*jié dú*): seeing the solitary, one doubts the solitary. If there is a counterpart, then it is no longer solitary. Right Master had forgotten both knowledge and perception, calmly roaming his heart in solitude. Gongwen Xuan, upon merely glimpsing him, already knew this, hence his startled question: "Is he of Heaven or of man? How did he come to this?" For Heaven’s creation of man naturally endows him with knowledge and perception, yet man cannot pair with it—this is Heaven’s doing. If one does not know that knowledge is self-knowing and perception is self-perceiving, but instead adds further knowledge and perception, then one has a counterpart and belongs to the human. This is what Laozi meant by "Why do you, sir, bring the crowd with you?" The marsh pheasant, though it may find drinking and pecking difficult, must take the cage as its dwelling, striving to refine its spirit. Yet that knowledge and perception are also man’s cage—without being a perfected person, how could one suspend and dissolve them?

When Lao Dan died, Qin Shi went to mourn him. After three cries, he departed. A disciple asked, "Was he not your Master’s friend?" Qin Shi replied, "He was." The disciple said, "Then is it proper to mourn him in this manner?" Qin Shi answered, "It is. At first, I thought him a man, but now I see he was not. Earlier, when I entered to offer condolences, I saw elders weeping for him as if for their own sons, and the young weeping as if for their own mothers. In their grief, they must have spoken words they ought not to have spoken and shed tears they ought not to have shed—this is fleeing from Heaven and betraying one’s true nature, forgetting what one has received. The ancients called this ‘the punishment of fleeing from Heaven.’ The Master came when it was his time, and he departed when it was fitting. To dwell in accord with the time and follow the natural order is to remain untouched by sorrow or joy. The ancients called this ‘the Great Release by the Lord.’"

It is like the flame passed from torch to torch—though the fuel is exhausted, the fire continues, and one does not know when it will end.

*(Note: The text records Qin Shi, though some versions write it as Yi. Guo Xiang’s commentary explains: Qin Shi mourned as others mourned, crying as others cried. The disciples found it strange that he did not linger by the door to observe the transformation, yet he cried three times, unaware that the perfected person is without fixed emotions and merely joins in the common lament. Thus, his conduct was fitting. The elders wept as if for sons, and the young as if for mothers—this arose from their prior attachment to the Master, bestowing kindness without grounding it in principle, leading to such excessive love.)*

The nature bestowed by Heaven endows each with its proper portion—this cannot be escaped, nor can it be augmented. To be overly moved by external things is not merely to flee from Heaven’s decree. Racing through the realms of sorrow and joy, though no corporal punishment be applied, one’s nature and emotions are already exhausted—is this not a form of punishment?

To arrive is to be born of itself; to depart is to die as principle dictates. Sorrow and joy arise from loss and gain. Yet the adept who merges with the transformations of the Dao is never unsettled, never out of harmony. Obscurely one with the workings of creation, there is nowhere that is not oneself—what gain or loss, what death or life could there be? Thus, abiding by what one has received, sorrow and joy find no place to lodge.

To take the entangled as "suspended" is to see the unattached as "released from suspension." Released from suspension, the passions of life and destiny are attained—this is the essence of nurturing life. "Exhausted" means fully spent; "fuel" is like the preceding fuel. The preceding fuel illustrates the principle of exhaustion, yet the fire is transmitted and does not perish. The heart attains the midst of nurturance, and so life continues without end. Clearly, nurturing life is the very means by which life lives.

Time does not come again; the present does not pause even once. Thus, human life is but a single breath, a single moment of attainment. The past breath is not the present breath, so nurturance continues life. The former fire is not the latter fire, so fuel transmits the blaze, and the blaze continues life. It is through nurturance that one reaches its utmost. How could the world know that what is exhausted is reborn?

---

Lü’s commentary:
The rite of condolence is to weep for the dead and console the living. To cry three times is to weep for the dead without sorrow; to leave without words is to console the living without sufficiency—this is why the disciples doubted Qin Shi’s lack of friendship. At first, I thought those who followed Lao Dan had all grasped his Way. Now, seeing the elders and youths weep in attachment, unable to rest in their time or abide in harmony, I know they are not true followers. For there must be those who speak without seeking words, weep without seeking tears—inner and outer in accord—this is how one guards against such excess.

What one receives from Heaven—the passions of life and destiny—has never been shaped by external things into sorrow or joy. To flee from Heaven and betray one’s nature, forgetting what one has received, is to desire escape from what is inescapably Heaven—yet one cannot avoid punishment. Knowing that arrival is to be at peace and departure is to follow principle, the ancients called this "the Great Release by the Lord," for one has never truly died.

The fire’s abode is the fuel, yet fire is not the fuel. Though the fuel is exhausted, the fire is transmitted—how could it end? The fire in this fuel is like the fire in that fuel; its transmission knows no end. Fire is likened to life, fuel to form. Understanding this, one knows that the means by which life lives has never had a beginning—how could sorrow or joy enter?

---

*Oral Exegesis*:
"Suspended" means the heart is entangled. "Lord" refers to Heaven. To know the spontaneity of Heaven’s principle is to see that even Heaven cannot bind one with life and death. Thus, it is called "the Lord’s release from suspension."

---

Liu Gai’s commentary:
The analogy of fire and fuel illustrates the spirit dwelling in form yet constantly shifting. The perfected of old, who carried their souls and regarded the body as an inn, did so for this reason—how could they cling to form and guard its honor?

---

*Brush Notes*:
Some Buddhist texts interpret this passage: the fire transmitted through fuel is like the spirit transmitted through form. The fire’s transmission differs from the fuel, just as the spirit’s differs from form. The former fuel is not the latter, revealing the subtlety of the "exhausted finger" technique. The former form is not the latter, awakening one to the depth of karmic conditions. The deluded see the body decay in one life and assume spirit and emotion perish with it—just as one sees fire expire in a single log and assumes its end is absolute. Is this not mistaken? Their insight is quite precise, yet to abandon life for life remains an incomplete discourse.

In my humble view, counting fuel by the finger, though fuel is plentiful and the finger limited, when fire is transmitted, it burns without immediate exhaustion. Molten metal does not leave the furnace; floating bubbles must return to the sea—this shows the unity of life and death. The earlier statement speaks of nurturing life; this speaks of life and death as one. Are they contradictory? Only by knowing the oneness of life and death can one truly nurture life.

---

*General Observations*:
Those who grasp the principle of nurturing form do not harm it; those who understand the Way of nurturing spirit do not act. Form is life’s abode; spirit is life’s master. The Way of emptiness and non-being is what nurtures the spirit. The world knows only how to nurture life but not how to nurture life’s master. The more they nurture, the more they lose their form—thus the true person teaches: do not follow the boundless with the bounded. This is the essence of nurturing life.

Those who embrace the Dao have no mind for good or evil; those who meet things with emptiness have no cause for punishment. Abiding in harmony without losing constancy is the principle of preserving life and fulfilling one’s years. The butcher’s metaphor illustrates responding to things: the knife represents life. After nineteen years, the blade is as if newly sharpened, cutting through complexity and chaos—how many times has it been used, yet one’s clarity remains unblemished? This is the master of life, who must be well nurtured. Only through daily cultivation can one succeed in this moment, where non-use becomes great use.

To sheath the blade well is to respond to things with leisure, to gather wisdom and conceal brilliance, letting things follow their nature and affairs reach their principle—yet one’s utility never diminishes. This is how the great recluses of old lived in the world, engaging with things yet always responsive and still, having attained this Way.

Thus, the essentials of learning the Dao begin with emptiness and stillness. Without emptiness, one cannot preserve the spirit; without stillness, one cannot return to destiny. When nature is whole and destiny restored, the work of nurturing life is complete. Like a mirror on its stand, it reflects without trace—what do things add to me? Ordinary people pursue things and lose their truth, cling to affairs and violate principle, tossed between gain and loss—how can they avoid harm? Thus, the pheasant in the marsh does not wish to be caged, as seen in later analogies. Lao Dan, the great sage, and Zhuangzi, his master, taught that death is but showing others how to rest in their time and abide in harmony, to guard constancy and fulfill one’s end. The marvel of transcending form and flying transformation is beyond the world’s measure. The death of a sage is called "spirit"—this is why Qin Shi mourned him with three cries, though he himself was a figure beyond conventional norms. Yet the disciples still doubted, so he explained: coming and going are fitting—rest in it, do not resist. This is the Lord’s release from suspension; the Creator cannot bind one.

To exhaust the principle of fuel is to see the fire transmitted endlessly. To exhaust the principle of nurturing form is to see the spirit preserved without perishing. Form ultimately has an end, but one cannot but nurture it. Thus, in the end, what is prized is...

To preserve wholeness and return it—when form is preserved and returned, the spirit is without error. Emerging from being and entering non-being, where can one go that is not right? Fuxi attained this and inherited the Mother of Qi; the Yellow Emperor attained this and ascended to the clouded heavens. Pengzu attained this and, riding the Tail of the Winnowing Basket, joined the ranks of the stars. The Supreme Ones say: "Those who die yet do not perish attain longevity."

*Zhuangzi Yi*, Scroll One
*(From the "Masters" section, Daoist category, Zhuangzi Yi, as included in the Imperial Four Treasuries)*

---

**Scroll Two**
**Chapter Four: "Amid the Human World"**
*(Guo’s commentary: Those who engage with the human world cannot depart from it. Yet the vicissitudes of the human realm differ with each generation. Only those who are without self-will and do not act on their own can adapt to change without bearing its burdens.)*

Yan Hui sought an audience with Confucius and asked leave to depart, saying, "Where shall I go?"
"To Wei," said Confucius.
"What shall I do there?"
Yan Hui replied: "I have heard that the lord of Wei is in his prime, yet his conduct is solitary and reckless. He governs his state lightly yet fails to see his own faults. Thus, the people perish—so many that they are measured by the state’s expanse, like reeds in a marsh. The people have nowhere to turn. I once heard you say, Master: 'Leave well-governed states and go to disordered ones. The physician’s gate is crowded with the ill.' I wish to apply what I have heard and ponder its principles, that the state might perhaps be cured."

Confucius said, "Alas! You will likely go only to be punished. The Way does not tolerate杂乱.杂乱 leads to excess; excess leads to disorder; disorder leads to anxiety—and anxiety cannot be remedied. The perfected ones of old first established it within themselves before establishing it in others. If what is established within yourself is not yet secure, how can you attend to the conduct of a violent man? Moreover, do you know how virtue is lost and whence knowledge arises?"

Names and knowledge arise from contention—contending for names, where men clash; knowledge, the instrument of contention. Both are ill-omened tools, not the means to perfect conduct. Moreover, when virtue is deep and trust steadfast, yet one’s qi remains unrecognized by others; when fame is heard but not contended for, yet one’s heart remains unrecognized, and one forcibly presents the language of benevolence and righteousness, the carpenter’s line and rule, before a violent man—this is to make others despise what is fine in you. Call it "harming others"; one who harms others will surely be harmed in return. How perilous to be such a harmer of men!

Furthermore, if you merely delight in the worthy and despise the unworthy, what use is it to seek distinction? If you refuse to instruct kings and lords, they will surely ride roughshod over others, provoking their defenses. Their eyes will dazzle, their complexion will level, their mouth will babble, their demeanor will take shape, and their heart will harden—this is like quenching fire with fire, flooding water with water. Call it "adding to the excess"; following the beginning without end, how perilous! With insincere, honeyed words, you will surely die before the violent man.

In ancient times, Jie killed Guan Longfeng, and Zhou killed Prince Bigan—both had cultivated themselves, humbling and soothing the people, yet contradicting their superiors. Thus, their rulers used their cultivation to cast them out: they were lovers of fame. In former days, Yao attacked Congzhi and Xu’ao, and Yu attacked the state of Youhu. Their lands were laid waste, their persons executed—yet their use of arms did not cease, their pursuit of substance knew no bounds. These were seekers of name and substance. Have you alone not heard of this? Even the sage cannot overcome name and substance—how much less can you?

Though it be so, you must have some purpose.

Pray, tell me: Yan Hui once came and said, "If I stand upright yet remain empty, strive earnestly and unite as one—would this suffice?"
I replied: "How could it be so? To take yang as fulfillment, to be full of brilliance and shifting hues—this is what the common man does not oppose. Following others' inclinations to seek their favor, the heart names this 'daily-accumulated virtue,' yet even this does not succeed—how much less can great virtue?
To cling rigidly without transformation, outwardly conforming while inwardly disdaining—how could this ever suffice?
Thus, if I inwardly straighten myself and outwardly bend, achieving compliance while aligning above: to be inwardly straight is to be a companion of Heaven. As a companion of Heaven, one knows that the Son of Heaven and oneself are both children of Heaven—yet would one alone seek to have one’s words approved by others, or seek others’ approval of oneself? Or would one fear others’ disapproval? If so, people would call one a child—this is what it means to be a companion of Heaven.
To be outwardly bent is to be a companion of men. Kneeling with clasped hands, bowing low—these are the rites of a minister. If all men do this, how dare I not do the same? To do what others do, others will find no fault—this is what it means to be a companion of men.
To achieve compliance while aligning above is to be a companion of antiquity. Though one’s words may seem admonishing, they are in truth the words of the ancients. What the ancients possessed, I do not possess. If so, though one be straight, it is no flaw—this is what it means to be a companion of antiquity. Would this then suffice?"
Confucius said: "How could it be so? Too many regulations and laws, though firm, are still without fault—yet this is all. How can one thus attain transformation? One who takes the mind as teacher remains so."

The annotations state:
- "Jiao" (蕉) is likened to grass and reeds.
- Cui interprets it as "its marshes appear as if mown," meaning the wilds are barren of green grass.
- Zhao explains: "The dead are measured by the state," where marshes filled with corpses use the marsh as their measure.
- As in "jiao yi" (蕉刈), the people are cut down like grass.
- Youhu was a state, now located in Hu County, Jingzhao. An abandoned dwelling is called "xu"; to die without heirs is to become a "li" (malevolent spirit). *Shu* and *shu* are synonymous. An ancient southern manuscript reads *yu* ().

Guo's commentary:
To act alone without sharing the people’s desires is to govern lightly. When a ruler lightly uses his state, every action stirs the people: one moment of anger brings corpses and flowing blood, one moment of joy fills the roads with carriages and caps. Thus, a ruler’s use of the state cannot be taken lightly.
Not seeing his faults, none dare admonish him. To lightly use the people’s lives is to treat them as expendable in death. "The dead are measured by the state"—like marshes of *jiao*, the whole state is cast into the realm of death, beyond counting, viewed as mere grass and reeds. The people have nowhere to turn.
The Dao does not tolerate杂乱. One must first rectify oneself and find the right person. If one does not find the right person, even a hundred physicians attending a single illness only deepen the doubt and fail to achieve a single cure.
The ancients’ perfected ones possessed the necessary qualities before engaging with the world. Those who do not empty their minds to respond to things but instead exhaust their thoughts in confronting difficulties reveal that what they hold within remains unsettled.
Only by externalizing knowledge to nurture the true, entrusting the wondrous to the multitude of talents, attributing merit and fame to others, and distancing oneself from personal concerns can one reach the conduct of violent men.
Moreover, virtue flows and scatters because of pride in fame. Knowledge spreads and overflows because of contention over goodness. Even Jie and Zhi, in what they prized and cherished, sought nothing beyond fame and goodness. Fame and knowledge are what the world employs, yet once fame arises, contention follows; once knowledge is used, strife emerges. Only by relinquishing fame and knowledge can one’s conduct be fully realized.
To offer a man a night-glowing pearl—few would not grasp their swords, for they do not yet understand. Yan Hui’s virtue, trustworthiness, and his reputation for non-contention—these they do not yet comprehend. To forcibly apply the standards of benevolence and righteousness to him would lead him to believe that Yan Hui seeks to destroy others to establish himself.
Thus, the perfected one does not employ the mind to order the world but empties the heart to respond to things. Sincerity and trust manifest in heaven and earth; non-contention flows through the myriad things. Only then do the myriad things return to embrace him, heaven and earth do not oppose him. When the resonance of virtue arises, the world responds; when the model of conduct shines, the six directions all follow. Only then can one traverse cold and heat, navigate order and chaos, without clashing with the逆鳞.
Those who harm others will inevitably be harmed in return. If one does not trust and accept, they will assume a contest for fame and retaliate with harm. If one can delight in the worthy and despise the foolish, hear righteousness and submit, one becomes an enlightened ruler. An enlightened ruler does not need worthy ministers. If you go, it will not be extraordinary; if you do not go, you will surely be harmed. To go with intention is not permissible; to respond without intention—if the response comes of itself, then there is nowhere one cannot go.
You need only remain silent and wordless. If you speak, kings and lords will wield their ruler’s authority to engage in verbal sparring, resisting admonition, adorning faults, and dazzling the eyes to confuse. Their countenance will flatten, unable to distinguish themselves from others. Their mouths will be occupied with self-justification, leaving no room for anything else. Their form and heart will conform, and they will release themselves to follow others. This is called "adding fuel to the fire," unable to save the situation but only furthering the other’s flourishing.
To follow the beginning endlessly, clinging to the usual and guarding the old, is to refuse change. Without trust, even earnest words become harmful when admonishing. Longfeng and Bigan took on the worries of those above while dwelling below—this was not their affair. Thus, their lord cast them out, unwilling to let ministers surpass their ruler in fame.
Violent rulers like Congzhi, Xuao, and Youhu were not merely indulgent in desire but also sought fame—though what they sought was not the Dao. Rulers who covet fame and lust for desire, even Yao and Yu could not transform them. Thus, to attack them with the multitude—how could you alone go empty-handed to transform them with the Dao?
Be upright and empty, rectify your form and empty your heart. Be diligent in one word, yielding and unwavering. To say "how could it be so?" is premature.
The Lord of Wei’s nature was arrogant and overbearing, swelling within and raging without—unyielding to the extreme. His countenance was unsettled, his joy and anger unpredictable. Such extreme obstinacy: when people provoke him with gratifying matters, he is overbearing and oppressive, then suppresses and humiliates them to seek ease, indulging his extravagant heart. Even minor virtues cannot be achieved. He will cling to his original intent, holding fast and refusing transformation. Your upright emptiness, diligent unity—outwardly conforming while inwardly unchanged—this is insufficient to transform him.
Yan Hui further proposed three principles:
- The inwardly straight is a companion of heaven: regarding things as without nobility or baseness, all equally receive life.
- Thus, whether good or not good, one entrusts it to impartiality. Seeking nothing from others, one relies on heaven’s principle, extending one’s nature and destiny like an infant’s straightforwardness.
- The outwardly bent is a companion of men: the outer form bends and curves, following what human affairs deem appropriate.
- To achieve compliance while aligning above is to be a companion of antiquity: achieving success in the present while comparing to the ancients—though this may seem like constant teaching with admonishing tones, one lodges straightness in antiquity, so it cannot be faulted.
Confucius still deemed this insufficient, for while it aligns with principle without contradiction, proposing three methods to govern and manage affairs does not merge with them. Though one may avoid blame and reproach, transformation remains unattained. This is because one clings to three arts to adapt to others, not entrusting the world to the mindless.

Lü's commentary:
Yan Hui wished to humble himself to extend the Dao, but the Master did not permit it, deeming杂多 a disturbance that cannot be remedied. First establishing oneself before establishing others—there is nowhere one cannot go. But Yan Hui’s self-establishment remains unsettled; how can he reach the conduct of violent men? Virtue scatters, knowledge emerges—tools of contention.
Moreover, profound virtue and steadfast trust suffice to reach others, enabling them to avoid baseness and perversity. Non-contention over names and ranks suffices to reach their hearts, preventing jealousy and doubt. Only then can one speak with them. Yet Yan Hui has not reached this and forcibly applies the language of benevolence and righteousness, standards and ink lines, to enlighten violent men before them—possessing beauty that others detest.
They merely love fame and contend with knowledge. To meet them with fame is to provoke them; to meet them with knowledge is to incite strife. If one can make them follow...

To wield these as lethal instruments is to invite calamity. Observe what they produce, and you will know what they revert to—Yan Hui’s approach would bring only disaster. If a ruler delights in worthiness and detests the unworthy, then you are already the same as he. Why seek difference? If you speak with him, you merely assent without instruction; he will surely exploit others, provoke contention, and fortify his defenses. His demeanor will bristle, his gaze will flash, and his heart will harden, seeking only escape or compliance—leaving no room for submission. This is like quenching water with water or fire with fire; compliance only begets endless beginnings.

He does not expect sincerity or depth from me, yet if I speak with him, I will surely perish before the violent. Long ago, Longfeng and Bigan cultivated themselves and soothed the people, yet their rulers, suspecting them of hoarding favor, cast them out—all for love of fame. Even Yao and Yu could not transform the barbarian states without destroying them. When it comes to names and realities, even sages cannot prevail—how much less can one like you?

Upright yet not utterly empty, striving yet not utterly unified, pride swells within and manifests without. To suppress others is to seek gratification; even minor virtue cannot be achieved—how much less great virtue? In correcting a ruler, one may achieve outward accord, but inwardly, he remains unchanged. What power is there to transform him?

To demand goodness from others based on one’s own words, to expect others to value what one despises—this is the error. From the perspective of the Dao, the Son of Heaven and oneself are both children of Heaven. What distinction is there between them? Heaven, humanity, and antiquity form a single fellowship.
