Yan Hui, if you could adapt to these three, perhaps it would be possible. Yet to respond to things without attaining unity and emptiness of mind—this is why there is so much excess.

Outwardly, you entrust rectitude to antiquity, which is to govern others by law rather than by person, altering what they know. This is not true discernment. Discernment lies in secretly observing others’ intentions and grasping them—then it is secure. Even so, no harm may come, and transformation may follow, for though you guide with your heart, you have not yet attained heartlessness.

The newly transmitted passage states:
The sage has no name—thus they act without action. They possess no knowledge—thus they attain nothing. Without action, things naturally return to them; attaining nothing, nothing contends with them. The common person clings to name and employs knowledge—thus they act with action and seek attainment. With action, things do not submit; with attainment, things inevitably contend. Hence it is said: "Name is that by which one is constrained; knowledge is the instrument of strife."

Shuixi observes:
The phrases *"with eyes that scheme"* and *"with countenance that flattens"* vividly capture the evasive demeanor of the moment. At such times, one suddenly loses one’s sense of self, compelled to yield and retreat, with no opportunity for debate. The mouth strives to speak but cannot—only the lips move in restless agitation, revealing the distress. Though no words are uttered, the shifting expressions and deferential gestures already betray submission. The heart concedes, thinking to let it pass for now, planning for later—such are the inevitable turns of human nature. Previous interpretations have often missed this.

*Bicheng* notes:
*"If only you do not proclaim to the kings and lords"*—here, *"proclaim"* means official announcement. *"You must not announce to the kings and lords"*—if one speaks thus, one will surely set others against each other. The subsequent warnings all refer to Yan Hui.

Yan Hui said: "I have no means to advance further. May I ask the method?"
Confucius replied: "Fast—I will tell you. If you act with intention, will it be easy? That which is called easy is not fitting for the vast heavens."
Yan Hui said: "My family is poor; for months I have not drunk wine or eaten meat. Is this what you mean by fasting?"
Confucius said: "This is the fasting for sacrifice, not the fasting of the mind."
Yan Hui said: "May I ask what the fasting of the mind is?"
Confucius said: "Unify your will. Do not listen with the ears, but listen with the mind. Do not listen with the mind, but listen with qi. Listening stops at the ears; the mind stops at signs. Qi is emptiness that awaits things. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness is the fasting of the mind."
Yan Hui said: "Before I was instructed, I was truly myself. Once instructed, I could no longer regard myself as existing. Can this be called emptiness?"
The Master said: "You have attained it."

"Let me tell you: if you can enter and wander within its enclosure without being moved by its name—entering, then you may sing; not entering, then stop. Without gate, without harm, dwelling in one abode and lodging in necessity—then you are close.

To leave no trace is easy; to walk without treading the earth is hard. To be employed by others is easy; to feign for Heaven is hard. We have heard of flying with wings, but never of flying without wings. We have heard of knowing with knowledge, but never of knowing without knowledge.

Behold that emptiness—from the vacant chamber, white arises; auspiciousness abides where it abides. Yet if one does not abide, this is called ‘sitting in motion.’ Following the ears and eyes inwardly, while the heart’s knowledge is cast outward—emptiness! Then ghosts and spirits will come to dwell, let alone men.

This is the transformation of the ten thousand things, the pivot of Yu and Shun, the path nearly trod by Fuxi and Qi. How much more so for those who are scattered?"

Guo’s commentary:
To act with intention is indeed not easy; to regard effort as easy is to miss its proper measure. The one-minded refers to abandoning heterodoxies and embracing singularity. To forsake the ears and eyes, to discard the heart’s intentions, and to accord with the self-attainment of qi and nature—this is emptiness awaiting things. Only when Dao gathers in emptiness, when the heart is emptied, does the supreme Dao gather in the breast.

Before one is made to turn inward by reality, one has not yet attained the fasting of the mind, and thus possesses a self. When one is made to have never turned inward, having already attained the fasting of the mind’s command, then one is without a self. To enter and wander within its bounds without being moved by its name is to let the heart roam freely, attaining fulfillment and abiding in reality. It is like the resonance of gong and shang notes, responding without intent—thus it is called "sounding."

To respond without intent is to follow the ears of others, not forcing a response. It is to let things be as they are, without a gate; to entrust the world to its natural ease, without harm. "Harm" means governance; "inevitability" is the necessity of principle. To embody the abode of utmost oneness and guard against the tally of necessity—this is near indeed. Principle is exhausted in this.

To not act is easy; to act without treading the earth is impossible. To not do is easy; to do without harming nature is unattainable. What the eyes and ears perceive is coarse, thus easily deceived. As for the subtle retribution of the natural, it is difficult to falsify. The less one loses of the real, the less incomplete one is; the more one loses of the real, the more incomplete one is. The retribution of loss and gain never fails to match its portion. To defy Heaven and feign falsity—is this not difficult?

The analogy of wings and knowledge speaks of requiring the proper means to accomplish a task. Without the abode of utmost emptiness, there is no way to obtain the reality of transforming things. To regard being as non-being is the vacant chamber; in the vacant chamber, pure whiteness arises alone. The gathering of auspiciousness lies in utmost emptiness and stillness.

As for not abiding where one should, not guarding against extremes—this is to sit in motion all day, galloping without cease. Thus, before external enemies arrive, one is already exhausted within. How can one transform things? To make the ears...

The eyes and ears closed, what is naturally attained lies in the function of the heart’s knowing—beyond the external. Thus, to follow one’s nature and proceed directly is to be in darkness nowhere, free even from the burden of obscurity and dimness, let alone the burdens of the human world. Things hold no inherent nobility or baseness; none exist apart from the heart’s knowing, the ears and eyes.

The ears and eyes are what connect the self to the world. Thus, what the world calls "knowing"—is it knowing because one desires to know? What it calls "seeing"—is it seeing because one strives to see? If knowing and seeing could be obtained through desire and effort, then could one desire to be worthy and become worthy, strive to be a sage and become a sage? Certainly not.

Yet the world fails to understand that knowing arises of itself, and so seeks to know through forced knowing; that seeing arises of itself, and so strives to see through forced seeing. Not recognizing that life arises of itself, one then attempts to generate life through forced generation. Thus, seeing the eyes, one demands the clarity of Li Lou; hearing the ears, one expects the acuity of Shi Kuang. The heart’s spirit races within, the ears and eyes exhaust themselves without, and the body finds no ease—how then can one guard against things? Without such guard, how can one harmonize with the changes of the human world or respond to the rhythms of generation upon generation? Never has this been possible.

The Dao in detail: ["What arises from deliberate action" has long been questioned by the ancients. Where there is thought, there must be alignment; where there is action, there must be caution. Thus, those who would illumine their virtue with spirit must first fast the heart—this is what Confucius taught Yan Hui.

Wenzi said: In higher learning, one listens with spirit; in middle learning, one listens with the heart; in lower learning, one listens with the ears. If listening stops at the ears, it is limited to what the ears can hear; if the heart stops at signs, it is confined to what the heart can align with. But when one listens with qi, there is nowhere it does not reach—vast, flowing, and unobstructed. This is using form without being used by form, engaging with things without being bound by things. Empty yet unimpeded, responsive yet not retaining, thus a single focus preserves the qi, preserving the qi leads to attaining emptiness, and attaining emptiness gathers the Dao. This is the meaning of fasting the heart.]

Xu Xi [notes]: "Fences" are external and need not be deep; "names" are without substance—even the virtue-less among kings and dukes are without substance. There are no gates without poison; all things bear poison. Do not regard their poison, for there has never been a gate without poison. This means that in the human world, nothing is too deep or too shallow—all is to be feared. Once one enters, it is like a traveler lodging at a desolate inn along a forsaken road, responding wearily without contrivance.]

Jingchuan [remarks]: The inner communion of the ears and eyes shares the same meaning as the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s "perfect penetration through the ear faculty."

*Brush Strokes* [states]: Whether serving as Heaven’s envoy or as man’s, whether in the state of never having been employed or in the state of being employed, when one’s service aligns [with the Dao], Yan Hui heard "fasting the heart" as emptiness and suddenly awakened. Thus it is said: "Yan Hui’s inability to move at will was due to the self."

One who can move at will does so without the self. The Master sighed in perfect admiration and further instructed him, saying: "You may wander within its confines yet remain unmoved by fame. When intent aligns, speak; when it does not, cease. Vast and without gate, serene and without poison—abide in this as though compelled, and you approach the threshold. This threshold is the verge of being without self.

To sever all traces is to reaffirm this principle: to cease movement and leave no trace is easy; to act without treading upon the earth is difficult. When employed by man, the self remains, making deception easy. When employed by Heaven, the self vanishes, making deception impossible. To know without relying on knowledge, to walk without relying on steps, to fly without relying on wings—this is the work of Heaven’s envoy. This is what is called emptiness. When the chamber is empty, brightness arises; when the heart is empty, the Dao gathers. It is not that auspiciousness exists, yet no greater auspiciousness can be found. For one who seeks to settle the body and lodge the mind, to abandon this is to have no refuge. Yet if one persists in this, what else is it but *sitting in distraction*?

*Sitting in distraction* is like speaking of *drowning on dry land*—the human heart naturally comes to rest, yet one stubbornly clings to the belief that it does not, like a horse tethered in its stall while its mind gallops a thousand miles. Even if one sits in silent seclusion among mountains and forests, this only compounds the disturbance. When the ears and eyes commune inwardly, there is no hearing or seeing external to the heart; when knowledge is absent, there is no thought or action. Only then can one speak of emptiness, and even spirits will come to dwell. How much more so for men? This is how one commands the transformations of the myriad things without being transformed by them—what the ancient sages practiced throughout their lives."

---

Ye [She] asked Master Gongzi Gao, who was about to be sent as an envoy to Qi: "The king has entrusted this mission to Zhu Liang, placing great importance on Qi’s treatment of envoys. They will likely show utmost respect but no urgency. Even a commoner cannot be swayed lightly—how much less a feudal lord? I am deeply apprehensive. You once told Zhu Liang: 'In all matters, great or small, few succeed without relying on the Dao to bring joy. If the matter fails, one inevitably faces human calamity; if it succeeds, one faces the calamity of yin and yang. Only those of virtue can succeed or fail without disaster.'

I eat coarse food and do not hoard, guarding against desire like a man of purity. Yet this morning I received my orders, and by evening I am drinking ice—does this not reveal my inner turmoil? Have I not yet reached the truth of the matter? For once the affair is underway, the calamity of yin and yang is already present. If it fails, the calamity of human retribution will follow. These are two outcomes, and as a minister, I am unworthy of such a task. Please instruct me."

Confucius replied: "Under heaven, there are two great precepts: the first is fate, the second is duty. Your love for your parents is fate—it cannot be untied from the heart. A minister’s service to his lord is duty—there is no place in heaven or earth where one may escape it. These are called the great precepts. Thus, in serving one’s parents, one finds peace regardless of circumstance—this is the perfection of filial piety. In serving one’s lord, one finds peace regardless of the task—this is the height of loyalty. In serving one’s own heart, sorrow and joy do not alter one’s bearing. To foresee the inevitable yet accept it as fate—this is the perfection of virtue.

For a minister or child, there are always unavoidable circumstances. To act according to the nature of affairs while forgetting the self—how could one have leisure to delight in life and fear death? Your conduct is already sufficient. Let me add what I have heard: In close dealings, trust must be mutual; in distant dealings, words must convey loyalty. Words may be transmitted, but those that please both sides or anger both sides are the most perilous in the world. When both are pleased, there is an excess of flattery; when both are angered, there is an excess of slander. All excess is falsehood. Falsehood breeds doubt in the listener, and the transmitter of such words invites misfortune. Thus, the proper teaching says: Transmit the constant truth, not the excess of words—then you approach perfection."

---

Guo’s commentary: "The king’s emphasis on Zhu Liang’s mission indicates a desire to make a request. His 'utmost respect without urgency' suggests fear of an empty display of courtesy without promptly fulfilling the request. In matters great or small, few succeed without relying on words to bring joy—this is what Confucius once told Zhu Liang. If the matter fails, there is the calamity of human retribution, for success would have brought joy, while failure invites anger. This is something even the King of Chu cannot avoid. If the matter succeeds, there is the calamity of yin and yang: though the external trouble may pass, joy and fear still wage war in the breast, freezing and scorching the five viscera.

Only those of virtue can entrust success or failure to others without distressing the heart. 'Guarding against desire like a man of purity' means facing fire without longing for coolness, revealing the frugality of his fare. His frugal fare and inner turmoil, leading him to drink ice, stem from genuine concern over the difficulty of the task, not the allure of fine food. Before the matter is resolved, he fears only failure. If it truly fails, fear will knot within while the net of punishment ensnares without—hence the two calamities.

'Cannot be untied from the heart' means it is naturally and firmly bound, impossible to undo. 'No place in heaven or earth to escape' means that among a thousand gathered, if none serves as master, disorder or dissolution follows. Many worthy men cannot serve many lords; no worthy men cannot serve no lord—this is the inevitable principle of heaven and man. If lords could be escaped and parents untied, they would not be precepts. Thus, they are called the great precepts.

To 'know the inevitable' is fate; to accept it is to be without sorrow or joy—how could one’s bearing change? Thus, one calmly regards all encounters as fate, without applying the heart to them, merging with the ultimate rightness as one, without joy or sorrow. Even in serving ordinary men, one finds no obstacle—how much more so for lord and parent?

Affairs have their inevitable principles, and reason is always coherent. For a minister or child, to undertake them is to ensure success; if the matter succeeds but the self is lost, such a case has never existed. Why trouble the heart over the self? If one’s commitment to the Dao is not steadfast and delight or aversion lingers, one cannot proceed with the ultimate rightness, and no success can be achieved in scheming for life or fearing death.

'Close dealings must be mutual in trust' means that proximity allows verification, so trust and submission are mutual. 'Distant dealings must convey loyalty through words' means that from afar, words convey intent. Words of pleasure or anger, if they exceed reality, should be transmitted without losing the mean—hence the difficulty. All excess is falsehood: the speaker’s words are suspect, and the transmitter’s embellishments are reckless. 'Mo' means doubt."

The transmitter of words incurs misfortune; when words are transmitted, exaggeration resembles deceit. The receiver, harboring doubt, then transmits them, and the transmitter arbitrarily alters their weight—thus fault arises.

Citing legal principles as evidence: though one may hear words that overstep in the moment, they should not be transmitted. One must invoke the speaker’s usual disposition and demand their sincere intent—only then does it approach wholeness.

Xu Xi says: Few do not rely on the Dao to achieve joyful completion; there has never been one who, departing from the Dao, could bring about perfect fulfillment without later regret. As for sustenance, grasping the coarse and guarding against desire, purity arises of itself. One may claim to serve through toil and labor, yet if there is no seeking in the world, even among family, how much more so within? To drink ice inwardly—if one chases profit and races outward, then anxiety and sorrow follow. Profound indeed is the distress!

Bi Sheng says: Lord Ye’s worries lay in gain and loss, yet the extreme of loss is nothing more than death. Thus the Master resolved it with life and death. Even those who speak of loyalty and filial piety can discuss serving their own hearts—how much less should joy and sorrow be applied to what lies ahead? For now, it is not easy to speak of. In serving the heart, the self is forgotten; when the self is forgotten, joy and sorrow have nowhere to settle—how could they be applied to what lies ahead? Thus it concludes: in the circumstances of acting, forget the self—how then would there be leisure to delight in life and abhor death? Delight in life and abhorrence of death are precisely what joy and sorrow consist of. Knowing there is nothing to be done and resting content in fate, Xu Xi says: this single phrase is magnanimous and clear, its discourse overflowing with ease. "Nothing to be done" does not mean despondency—such is its self-determination.

Moreover, those who contend with skill and strength begin with yang but invariably end...

Where contention arises from skill and strength, it begins with yang but invariably ends in yin—once extreme yin prevails, cunning and artifice abound. Those who drink wine with ritual propriety begin in order, yet invariably end in chaos—once excess prevails, extravagant pleasures multiply. All affairs follow this pattern: they begin in sincerity, yet invariably conclude in deceit. To despise their inception is to dismiss their simplicity; to neglect their conclusion is to invite their ruin. Grand words are but wind and waves; action is the loss of substance. For wind and waves stir easily, and the loss of substance courts danger. Thus, anger arises from no other cause than artful speech and biased words—like a beast at bay, its final cries are not chosen. Its qi scatters in disarray, and from this, the heart grows harsh and exacting. When exactingness becomes extreme, a base and unworthy heart inevitably responds, though one knows not why. If one does not know why, how can one foresee the end? Thus the *Fa Yan* says: "Do not alter decrees; do not urge completion—excess is harmful." To alter decrees and urge completion is perilous. Beauty lies in lasting success; evil, in failure to amend—can one not be cautious?

Moreover, to ride things and roam the heart, entrusting oneself to necessity to nurture the center—this is perfection. What need is there for contrived recompense? Better to deliver one’s mandate—this is the most difficult.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
Those who contend with skill and strength begin with playful rivalry, desiring victory. When passions run high, they secretly harbor harm for others and no longer follow reason. Those who drink wine with ritual propriety observe distinctions of rank and order in toasts. Yet when drunkenness and excess take hold, chaos spreads without restraint. For complexity arises from simplicity, and affairs emerge from prevention—this is an inevitable tendency. Words are wind and waves; thus, to act upon them is to lose substance. To abandon wind and waves and not act is to preserve substance. When affairs attain their substance, danger can be stabilized, and turmoil can be settled.

Anger arises from no other cause than artful speech exceeding reality and biased words missing the mark. Like a wild beast cornered, when pressed to its limit, its desperation spent, it does not choose harmonious sounds—its qi scatters in disarray, and violent rage arises, inviting blame in response. To be broad and accommodating is to draw all things to oneself. Yet when exactingness becomes too precise, a miserly heart arises unawares. If one does not awaken to this, how can one know where fortune and misfortune converge?

Thus the great person, vast and unconstrained, releases things into the realm of self-attainment—unlike others, they do not exhaust another’s joy. Therefore, the bonds of the Four Seas may be preserved. "Do not alter decrees" means transmitting their substance; "do not urge completion" means allowing them to reach fruition on their own.

Excess is harm in disguise—what is added ceases to be the natural truth. True beauty in completion lies in following the transformations of time, like planting seeds that cannot mature in a single morning. If one forces completion upon what another detests, regret and failure soon follow. Thus it is said: what is wrongly completed cannot be amended.

Riding things to roam the mind, entrusting oneself to necessity to nurture the center—words lodge in things to convey meaning, yielding to the inevitability of principle: this is the mark of perfect equilibrium. Such is the ultimate way of engaging with things. Why impose one’s intentions upon the natural recompense of things? Far better to devote oneself wholly to the task—this is the difficult path. To speak plainly, devotion is easiest, yet applying the heart through joy and anger makes it hard.

**New Transmission**
Silence cannot be disturbed by things, while speech invites response—and response disrupts stillness. Thus it is said: words are wind and waves. Without action, traces remain hidden; with action, traces become manifest. When traces appear externally, inner truth vanishes. Thus it is said: action is the loss of reality. Without stillness, one is moved; without inner truth, rest becomes difficult. Thus it is said: wind and waves easily stir, and the loss of reality easily endangers.

**Brush Jottings**
Those who transmit words of mutual joy or mutual anger yet dare not exceed them do so because ensuring a good end requires caution from the outset. Observe those who compete in strength: they begin with vigor but end in exhaustion. Those who drink begin with order but end in chaos. Thus one knows that human interactions start with trust but end in pettiness, and that small matters in life begin insignificantly but inevitably grow great.

A single word uttered may incite another’s fury—is this not a wind and wave? Once provoked, the person will act upon their anger—is this not the loss of reality? Thus, the arousal of wrath arises without cause: it stems from cunning speech and biased words, which invariably exceed the truth, disregarding right principle. Like a beast fearing death, it does not choose pleasing sounds; its breath issues forth in a frenzy, and the listener’s heart, too, becomes fierce—thus wrath is aroused.

Those who reprove others too harshly or scrutinize too severely do so in hope of another’s improvement. Yet if the other responds with an unworthy heart, one ought to know when to desist. If one fails to recognize this, resentment accumulates into harm, and the outcome will be unforeseeable—will it end, as before, in pettiness, or in something far greater?

When a lord’s command is altered at a general’s whim, or when unfinished affairs are forced through with urging, these are instances of excessive praise or blame. As it is said: excess is harmful. When words are exaggerated, the messenger courts disaster—how can one be without peril?

That which is beautifully accomplished endures: to bring out another’s goodness requires leisurely, deep, and prolonged engagement before it can take root. That which is badly done cannot be undone: a single resentful word may ruin a matter entirely, and by the time the heart hardens, regret will come too late.

Those who delight in excessive speech invariably harbor some intent and cannot remain empty. Thus it is with the ear.

Riding the things of the world while roaming the mind is to forget the self; entrusting oneself to necessity is to forget things. Thus, following its mandate and bringing it to fruition, I remain without intent—why must there be some action to repay it?

The Master’s teaching to Leaf Duke was once thought secondary to that given to Yan Hui, yet in truth it too could not depart from emptiness.

Yan He was about to instruct the Crown Prince of Duke Ling of Wei and so inquired of Qu Boyu: “There is a man here whose virtue is as if Heaven itself had slain him. If I deal with him without method, it will endanger our state; if I deal with him with method, it will endanger my person. His wisdom is just sufficient to perceive others’ faults but not their causes. In such a case, what am I to do?” Qu Boyu replied: “Excellent question! Be cautious, be prudent—rectify your own person! In form, nothing surpasses compliance; in mind, nothing surpasses harmony. Yet even these two have their perils: in compliance, one must not overstep; in harmony, one must not overreach. If in form you comply and overstep, you will invite collapse, ruin, downfall, and stumbling. If in mind you harmonize and overreach, you will invite clamor, fame, calamity, and misfortune. If he acts like an infant, then act like an infant with him. If he abandons all boundaries, then abandon all boundaries with him. If he casts off all limits, then cast off all limits with him. Reach this and you will enter the realm of flawlessness.

Do you not know the mantis? In its fury, it brandishes its arms to block the wheel-ruts of a chariot, unaware of its own incapacity—such is the beauty of its talent!”

Beware, take heed! When one accumulates boasts of one’s beauty and talent to provoke others, one approaches peril.

Do you not know the keeper of tigers? He dares not feed it living prey, lest it rouse the fury of killing. He dares not feed it whole prey, lest it rouse the fury of tearing. He times its hunger and satiety, he fathoms the heart of its rage. Though tigers and humans differ in kind, the tiger fawns upon its keeper—this is compliance. Thus, what provokes its killing is defiance.

Now, the lover of horses: he gathers their dung in a basket, collects their urine in a conch shell. Yet when a gnat or fly alights and he claps it too hastily, the horse breaks its bit, shatters its bridle, smashes its chest and head. His intent may be perfect, but his love may yet bring loss. Can one not be cautious?

The petty man’s nature is such that if you guide him by rules, he resents you; if you let him run unbounded, he brings chaos to the state. Unaware that the people’s faults arise from himself, he blames the people and never reforms. To rectify your person is to turn back and guard against both extremes—this is how one rectifies the self.

In form, nothing surpasses compliance; in mind, nothing surpasses harmony. Compliance does not mean discord, harmony does not mean sameness. “Compliance” means the form follows; “entering” means returning to sameness. “Harmony” means aiding with virtue; “exiting” means self-display. If you fully merge with another, you will stumble and not support them, perishing together. Thus, one should model oneself on Heaven and Earth, setting no petty distinctions.

If you display harmony and yet harbor resentment, you will invite the clamor of bearing shame and the fame of aiding others—he will resent your superiority and recklessly spawn calamity. Therefore, one should remain obscure, blending with the dust, so that none can draw near or distance themselves, benefit or harm you.

The seven lines beginning “If he acts like an infant...” speak of not setting sharp edges to provoke his scales. The mantis’s fury in raising its arms is not without beauty, yet it cannot match the chariot’s wheel-ruts. Now, knowing your incapacity yet forcing yourself to bear the task—this is the mantis’s fury.

“Accumulating boasts of your talent’s beauty to provoke others” is a path of danger. Hence the warning: “lest it rouse the fury of killing” means fearing that a killing intent will lead to rage. “Lest it rouse the fury of tearing” means that if you make the tiger bite and divide the prey itself, it will grow enraged from the effort. “Timing its hunger and satiety, fathoming the heart of its rage” means knowing why it rages and complying with it. Compliance with principle breeds affection even among different kinds; defiance of the proper order turns even the closest into enemies—this is why the tiger fawns upon its keeper.

Dung and urine are the basest things, yet he stores them in precious vessels—such is the utmost love for a horse. Clapping it too hastily breaks the bit, shatters the bridle, smashes its chest and head. Though he meant to remove the nuisance, startling the horse leads to this. “His intent may be perfect, but his love may yet bring loss” means that in striving to remove the nuisance, he acts rashly and causes destruction, losing what he loved. Thus, in all worldly dealings, one must be cautious in matters of compliance and defiance.

Lü’s Annotation: ["Approaching" errs by entering—entering makes one identical with it; "harmonizing" errs by departing—departing makes one different from it. Thus one falls into ruin, collapse, and downfall, becoming a portent of fame and ill omen. This is because in becoming identical with it, one does not know how to support it; in becoming different from it, one does not know how to comply with it. Treat it as an infant, guiding it to flawlessness—then, though you move with it without fixed method, you will not endanger the state; though you move with it by fixed method, you will not endanger yourself. For you follow what its nature already possesses and open the way for it—this is the subtlety of responding to its mechanism and transforming it. As when King Xuan favored courage and wealth, yet Mencius guided him toward the Kingly Way.]

Critique of *Zhuangzi*: [The six lines beginning "Treat it as an infant" correspond to "shaping" without desiring to enter; "guiding it to flawlessness" corresponds to "harmonizing" without desiring to depart. The passage on loving the horse illustrates the idea that what is beautifully formed endures, while what is badly formed cannot be altered.]

Supplementary Annotation: [The passage beginning "Treat it as an infant" is like the *Lotus Sutra*, where "if beings are to be delivered by the form of a bhikṣu, the Buddha appears as a bhikṣu to teach the Dharma; if they are to be delivered by the form of a woman, the Buddha appears as a woman to teach the Dharma." The phrase "clapping it too hastily" shows excessive love for the horse—seeing a mosquito, one suddenly swats it, startling the horse, which then reacts in alarm. Though the tiger is most ferocious, compliance tames it; though the horse is easily tamed, startling it makes it violent. Thus, in dealing with evil people, one must be cautious. If one does not carefully assess the moment or measure one’s strength, merely seeking to impose method upon the methodless, it is like the mantis angrily raising its arms to block the chariot wheel.]

When Master Carpenter Shi traveled to Qi, halfway along the road at Qu Yuan he saw an oak that was a sacred tree. It was so large that a hundred oxen could shelter in its shade; its girth measured a hundred spans. Its height towered above the mountain, and only after seventy feet did branches appear. A dozen or more of its side limbs could be made into boats. Spectators thronged around it like a marketplace, but the master carpenter did not glance at it and continued on his way without stopping. His disciple, having gazed his fill, ran to catch up with Master Carpenter Shi and said, "Since I took up the axe to follow you, Master, I have never seen timber so magnificent as this. Why did you not even deign to look at it, but walk on without pause?"

"Enough!" he said. "Say no more!"

A worthless tree—this!
Make it into a boat, and it sinks;
make it into a coffin or outer coffin, and it rots quickly;
make it into a vessel, and it breaks quickly;
make it into a door or gate, and it oozes sap;
make it into a pillar, and it is eaten by worms.
This is a tree of no use—
no purpose to which it can be put.
That is why it has attained such longevity.

Master Carpenter Shi returned home, and the sacred oak appeared to him in a dream, saying:
“With what will you compare me?
Will you compare me to the so-called ‘useful trees’?
Look at the crabapple, pear, orange, pomelo, and other fruit-bearing trees:
when their fruit ripens, they are stripped and humiliated;
their great branches are broken, their small branches are torn.
This is because their abilities bring suffering to their lives.
Thus they do not complete their Heaven-appointed years but die halfway,
having been struck down by the common world.
All things are like this.
As for me, I have sought to be of no use for a long time—
only now, on the verge of death, have I attained it.
This is of great use to me.
Had I been useful, could I have grown so vast?
Moreover, you and I are both things—
how could one thing judge another?
How could a man on the verge of death, a worthless man, know a worthless tree?”

Master Carpenter Shi awoke and interpreted his dream. His disciple said:
“If it seeks to be of no use, why does it serve as a sacred tree?”
He replied:
“Hush! Say no more.
It merely lodges there,
as if to escape the scorn of those who do not understand it.
Were it not a sacred tree, would it not have been felled long ago?”

Moreover, that which it preserves differs from the common—yet to praise it for its righteousness is far indeed. The untrammeled tree stands apart from those counted as useful; the so-called "cultivated trees" are but things that wound themselves through their very utility. "Only now, on the verge of death, have I attained it"—this speaks of how often others have looked askance at it, and only now does Carpenter Shi recognize its truth. "Of great use to me" means that the accumulation of uselessness becomes the greatest aid to life; had it been useful, it would long since have been felled. "How could a man on the verge of death, a worthless man, know a worthless tree?"—this is but his playful address to Carpenter Shi.

The disciple still finds fault, believing the tree takes pride in serving as a sacred tree, not merely seeking to be of no use. Carpenter Shi replies that the sacred tree merely lodges there of its own accord—it is not that the tree sought to become one. It regards the sacred tree as those who do not understand it, who would revile and afflict it. How could this be an honor? Its nature is to take uselessness as its use; even if it were not a sacred tree, it would still avoid the harm of being felled.

That which it preserves differs from the common: it takes having nothing to preserve as its preservation, while others take having something to preserve as theirs. The purpose of the sacred tree is to benefit others, nurture things, and restrain people from wrongdoing. Yet the useless remains serene, doing nothing, while the various talents naturally find their place; each attains its proper order without interference. This is how the useless preserves itself. For you to praise it as a sacred tree is to draw no closer to its truth.

Southward Master Ziqi wandered to the mound of Shang, where he saw a great tree. Its branches were so vast that a thousand chariots could shelter beneath them, finding shade and refuge. Ziqi exclaimed, "What tree is this? It must possess extraordinary timber!" Looking upward at its slender branches, he saw they were gnarled and twisted, unfit for beams or rafters. Gazing downward at its massive roots, he found them split and fissured, unsuitable for coffins or outer caskets. Tasting its leaves, his mouth blistered and burned. Inhaling its scent, he fell into a frenzied stupor that lasted three days without end.

Ziqi said, "This is truly a useless tree—yet it has grown so immense! Alas, the spirit-like person finds refuge in such uselessness. In the state of Song, there is a region called Jing where catalpa, cypress, and mulberry thrive. Those slender enough to grasp in one’s arms are felled by those seeking pegs for monkey traps. Those three or four spans in girth are cut down by those desiring lofty, renowned beams. Those seven or eight spans wide are hewn by the households of nobles and wealthy merchants in search of fine side planks. Thus, these trees do not live out their natural years but are prematurely felled by axes midway—such is the calamity of being useful.

"Hence, the ox with a white forehead, the pig with an upturned snout, or the man with hemorrhoids are deemed unfit to cross the river—this the shamans and priests have long known, for these are considered inauspicious. Yet this is precisely how the spirit-like person attains the greatest inauspiciousness."

The term *zhóu jiě* refers to wood grain that spirals and scatters; *chénɡ* denotes the sickness of drunkenness; *yì* are the pegs used to perch playful monkeys; *lì* signifies the beams of a house; *lǐ* should be written as *lì*, meaning lofty and renowned, or the grand households of the eminent. Sima [Biao] explains that *shàn bànɡ* refers to one complete side of a coffin. The phrase *shì hé* means to sink a person into the river as an offering, as in the case of Ximen Bao. Luo Miandao notes that in ancient times, the Son of Heaven performed the *jiě* sacrifice in spring, as recorded in the *Han Shu: Jiaosi Zhi*, where *jiě* means to absolve sins and seek blessings.

Guo’s commentary:
To conceal and shelter what one finds fragrant—its branches provide shade ample enough to hide a thousand chariots. The Heavenly King, being "useless," leaves the hundred officials to their tasks: the clear-sighted observe for him, the keen-eared listen for him, the wise counsel for him, and the brave defend for him. What, then, does he do? He remains profoundly silent, and yet the various talents do not fail in their proper roles—thus, "uselessness" is precisely what the truly useful depend upon. Therefore, the world delights in exalting him without tiring, and he rides upon the myriad things without harm.

The ox with a white forehead, the pig with an upturned snout, and the man with hemorrhoids—shamans and priests perform exorcisms to cast these three aside. They meticulously select only flawless, unblemished sacrificial animals before daring to use them. In this, the shamans and priests recognize that "uselessness" preserves wholeness. Yet wholeness in life is what the world calls auspicious. How strange that shamans and priests deem "uselessness" inauspicious and refuse to employ it!

The world deems such "inauspiciousness" that preserves life as the greatest auspice. The spirit-like person is one without fixed intent, who flows with things—thus, what the world calls the greatest auspice, the spirit-like person does not oppose.

**Lü’s Annotation:** The preceding passage discussed the great tree that completes its natural span through "uselessness," followed by the catalpa and cypress felled by axes due to their "usefulness." Thus, the sage and spirit-like person delve even deeper into the application of things, concealing their utility even more profoundly. Therefore, "uselessness" becomes the means by which usefulness is realized, and "non-material" becomes the instrument through which material is employed. Those who wander the world while sharing in the fortunes and misfortunes of the people must especially understand this.

There was a man named Zhīlí Fáng: his chin was hidden in his navel, his shoulders rose above his crown, his topknot pointed to the heavens, his five viscera’s points faced upward, his thighs flanked his ribs. By sewing and washing clothes, he earned enough to feed himself; by sifting and winnowing grain, he sustained ten others. When the authorities conscripted warriors, Zhīlí Fáng waved his arms among them; when major labor was demanded, he was excused due to his chronic ailment. When the state distributed grain to the infirm, he received three *zhong* and ten bundles of firewood. Though his body was deformed, he could still nourish himself and live out his natural years—how much more so one whose *virtue* is deformed?

**Guo’s Annotation:** When conscripting warriors, he waved his arms among them, relying on his "uselessness" and thus not hiding himself. When major labor was demanded, he was excused because he could not perform the work. If labor was not assigned, he accepted the rewards. Even one whose body was deformed could preserve himself thus. The spirit-like person is of no use to things, yet each thing attains its own use, returning merit and fame to the multitude of talents, blending with things without trace. Thus, he avoids the harms of the human world and dwells in the true beauty of constancy—this is one whose *virtue* is deformed.

**Following the Text:** *Xún* (navel) is interchangeable with *qí* (belly). A hunchback’s chin is hidden in the space between his navel. His shoulders rise above his crown because his head is lowered, making his shoulders higher than his crown. *Kuài* (topknot) is read as *cuō* (to gather). *Fáng* (to gather) is combined with *cuō* (to bind hair into a topknot). In ancient times, topknots were close to the nape, so when one’s back was bent and head lowered, the topknot pointed upward. *Guǎn* refers to the *shù* (acupuncture points), meaning the points of the five viscera all faced upward. The two thighs flanked the ribs, as the spine lies within the thighs, so the thighs were considered the ribs. *Cuò zhēn* means sewing clothes; *zhì xiè* means washing clothes. *Gǔ fáng bō jīng* means using a winnowing basket to sift grain.

Confucius traveled to Chu, where the madman Jiē Yú wandered near his gate, singing: *"Phoenix! Phoenix! How your virtue has declined! The future cannot be awaited, the past cannot be retrieved. When the world has the Dao, the sage achieves; when the world lacks the Dao, the sage survives. In this age, one barely escapes punishment. Blessings are lighter than feathers—who knows their weight? Disasters are heavier than earth—who knows how to avoid them? Cease! Cease! Applying virtue to others is perilous! Perilous! Drawing lines on the ground and following them—O brambles, brambles, do not harm my path! I walk my way—O thorns, thorns, do not wound my feet! The mountain tree seals itself, the grease feeds the flame. Cinnamon is edible, so it is felled; lacquer is useful, so it is slashed. All know the use of the useful, but none know the use of the useless!"*

**Guo’s Annotation:** *"Phoenix! Phoenix! How your virtue has declined!"*—This speaks of following the times and moving forward to fulfill what is fitting. The rise and fall of the world are too subtle to perceive, hence *"How your virtue has declined!"* The future cannot be awaited, the past cannot be retrieved—one must fully grasp the present moment’s fittingness. *"When the world has the Dao, the sage achieves; when the world lacks the Dao, the sage survives."*—This means leaving things to their natural course, where principle arises of itself. Achievement and survival are not of my doing—how could order or chaos alter one’s rhythm? Order seeks its own achievement, so abandoning achievement prevents failure; chaos seeks its own survival, so forgetting survival avoids death. *"In this age, one barely escapes punishment."*—This means not looking ahead or behind, but fully attending to the present moment’s fittingness. Only by merging with the times can one attain subtlety and completeness, escaping punishment and preserving one’s name. *"Blessings are lighter than feathers—who knows their weight?"*—Feet can walk, yet they are released; hands can grasp, yet they are entrusted. Ears hear what they hear, eyes see what they see—knowing when to stop at what one does not know, using what one can use, letting each thing use itself and act for itself, indulging one’s nature inwardly without the slightest concern for what lies beyond—this is the utmost ease of non-action. There has never been one who practiced non-action yet failed to preserve their nature and life. If one’s nature and life are preserved, yet it is not called blessing, such a principle has never been heard of. Thus, blessing is simply what was previously called wholeness—it is not borrowed from external things. How could it bear the weight of a goose feather?

To follow one’s nature in movement—such movement never exceeds its proper measure: this is the utmost ease in the world. To lift what lifts itself, to bear what bears itself—this is the utmost lightness in the world. Yet knowing injures the nature with boundlessness, and the heart sways the true with likes and dislikes. Thus, one abandons this utmost ease of non-action and pursues that utmost difficulty of action; one discards this utmost lightness of self-lifting and takes up that utmost weight of bearing others—this is the common affliction of the world.

Disaster is heavier than earth—who knows to avoid it? When one acts from what lies within the nature, even bearing ten thousand *jun* feels no weight. When external things are entrusted to it, though heavy, they do not exceed a fraction of a *zhu*—yet one may still prove unequal to the task. This is inner blessing. Thus, blessing is the lightest; this is outer disaster. Thus, disaster is the heaviest. That disaster is heavy yet none know to avoid it—this is the great delusion of the world.

To draw a line on the ground and make others follow it—its end cannot be concealed. To have done with one’s own concerns and face things without guarding against them—this is how the great person does not dazzle others with their own brilliance but lets others shine on their own; does not impose their virtue upon others but lets others attain on their own. Thus, they pervade and unite the ten thousand things, merging with the world as one, and inner and outer share in blessing.

To be deluded by yang is still to lose yang. If one loses yang yet entrusts oneself to solitude without being swayed by externals, then one’s conduct is whole. If the world all preserves their own wholeness, then all who bear the name of "self" are wholly preserved. In one’s conduct, if there is crookedness without harm to one’s feet, the crookedness completes the walk, and each is sufficient in itself. When there is use, it joins with others to achieve; when there is no use, it preserves its own life.

To carve one’s flesh and skin for the sake of the world—this is what the world knows. To allow the hundred clans not to lose their self-preservation and to let self and others both find harmony—this is so subtle that one does not sense its wonder within oneself.

When the world has the Dao, the sage can accomplish success; when the world lacks the Dao, the sage preserves life alone. In the present age—a time of chaos—merely escaping punishment is considered fortunate. How dare one seek anything more? To live in chaos and merely escape punishment to preserve life is but a feather’s blessing, yet one does not know to bear it. The disasters of a chaotic age often reach the point of killing the body—this is heavier than earth—yet one does not know to avoid them. To face others with virtue is the way to invite disaster; it is no better than drawing lines on the ground and rushing to follow them. How constrained and self-afflicting! How perilous!

The catalpa, the cassia, the cinnamon, the lacquer tree—all are felled and cannot hide themselves. Those who seek fame in the world to court disaster are like this.

To face others with virtue is not yet to be obscure in the Dao; to draw lines and rush to follow is not yet to erase one’s traces. "Deluded yang" speaks of dimming one’s own brightness to avoid harming the conduct of preserving life. "Crookedness" speaks of withdrawing the body and bending to preserve it, without harming the feet that can walk.

In "my conduct is crooked," *qiequ* should follow *Bixu* as *qiequ*. *Qiequ* does no harm to one’s feet, which aligns with the preceding text. This is likely due to a scribal error repeating "my conduct." "Deluded yang" encourages the Dao, saying it is like the fern. The fern grows thickly and can obscure the path of yang brightness, hence "deluded yang." This is a metaphorical expression, and its meaning is quite unusual—it is preserved to broaden the range of knowledge.

In living in the human world, the relationship between ruler and minister is of greatest importance and cannot be neglected. Yet one must carefully consider what is appropriate, prudently attend to the timing of advance and withdrawal, and observe past and present without shame. To transcend regret and resentment and preserve oneself alone—this is excellence.

Thus, when Yanzi was about to go to Wei, the Master thoroughly explained the many perils of serving a ruler: the clashing of fame and knowledge, the obstruction of the heart and qi, the eventual arrival of both praise and slander, the presence of banners before and axes behind—such things exist. How much more so for one harboring intentions of certainty, wishing to transform a young and willful ruler? How can one ensure no regret? Thus, the Master strongly dissuaded him, making the ruler of Wei aware that the worthy do not advance lightly, thereby strengthening his resolve to honor the Dao. Why would one lightly risk their nature to feed arrogance and provoke violent conduct?

Yanzi then spoke of being "upright within and yielding without," which might allow self-preservation. The Master said this would only avoid disaster—how could it reach transformation? One who transforms does not rely on words to gain trust, making others’ intentions dissolve. How could it lie in multiplying government laws to provoke opposition?

At this point, Yanzi had no further questions to ask about the method, for his thoughts were already empty, and his heavenly truth was in a state of empty receptivity. The Master seized this moment of awakening and instructed him to equalize, making his empty heart receptive to teaching: "Do not listen with the ears but with the heart; do not listen with the heart but with qi." Suddenly, he realized that there had never been a Yan Hui. With heart emptied and form forgotten, transforming things was no longer difficult.

When Zigao was about to be sent to Qi, he was instructed on the affairs of conduct, to forget the self, to observe the winds and waves, and to be wary of real loss. When Yanhe was about to go to Wei, he was instructed to approach without entering and to harmonize without departing, to understand the tiger’s anger and communicate the horse’s disposition—all to clarify the many ends of worldly perils and the difficulties beyond things. For those of high discernment, penetrating the subtleties and guarding advance and retreat with righteousness—this is acceptable.

As for the crooked catalpa and the sacred tree, to take "no preservation" as preservation; as for Shang Qiu’s extraordinary talent, to see without being divine yet be divine—this further explains how talent is a burden, yet the world does not awaken. Often, relying on talent to seek use without measuring one’s proper measure, fame arises and jealousy harms; profit accumulates and disaster arrives. Even if one wishes to preserve oneself in clumsy self-protection, it cannot be achieved.

Thus, the great meaning of this chapter lies in externally responding to the world while internally preserving the true Dao, not departing from it, and letting things transform themselves. The sages and worthies of old, when unavoidably involved in worldly affairs, all secretly followed this Dao. Hence, the exchanges between Confucius and Yanzi are recorded to elucidate this. At the end, the song of Jieyu is cited to dispel the traces of sages and worthies engaging in worldly action and to curb the insatiable pursuit of things by the multitude. The conclusion, with the disasters of the mountain tree, the fat of fire, the cassia, and the lacquer, serves as a stern warning to the world. Only by knowing the difficulty of navigating the world can one live in the world without difficulty.

The *Taishang* says: "Even the sage finds it difficult, hence in the end there is no difficulty."

This chapter begins with the exchanges between Confucius and Yanzi, followed by the analogies of Zigao and Yanhe. Its discussion of preserving the body, conducting righteousness, responding to things, and discerning subtleties thoroughly covers the way to live in the human world. It then continues with the catalpa, the sacred tree, Shang Qiu, and the hunchback, showing that in the world’s calamities and chaos, one ultimately cannot act. Even if one does well, it is better not to do at all—this is the highest. Thus, the chapter concludes with the song of Jieyu.

**From *Brush Jottings*:**
Master Shi Zhang said: *"The 'Nurturing Life' chapter is the teaching of transcending the world; the 'Living in the Human World' chapter is the teaching of abiding in the world."* I say: only after transcending the world can one abide in it—this is what Laozi meant by *"grasping the ancient Dao to steer the present being."*

**Chapter Five: The Sign of Full Virtue**

*(Guo’s Commentary: When virtue is full within, it responds to things without; inner and outer merge in profound unity, as if commanded by fate, while the bodily form is forgotten.
Supplemental Note: "Sign" means that when virtue is full within, it naturally manifests without—not something the form can augment or diminish, nor something knowledge can conceal or reveal. The examples described in this chapter suffice to make this clear.)*

In Lu there was a man named Wang Tai who had lost a foot, yet those who followed him were as numerous as those who followed Confucius. Chang Ji asked Confucius, saying: *"Wang Tai is a man who has lost a foot, yet those who follow him divide Lu equally with you. He does not teach when standing, nor discuss when seated; yet those who go to him empty return full. Is there truly a teaching without words, a shaping of the heart without form? What manner of man is he?"*

Confucius said: *"This master is a sage. I am merely one who follows behind and have not yet caught up. I intend to take him as my teacher—how much more should those who are not my equal! Why only Lu? I would lead the whole world to follow him."*

Chang Ji said: *"Though he is a man who has lost a foot, he surpasses even the worthy. If this is so, how does he employ his mind?"*

Confucius said: *"Life and death are great matters, yet they cannot alter him. Though heaven and earth collapse, he would not be lost with them. He examines what is without reliance, does not shift with things, commands the transformations of things, and guards their root."*

Chang Ji said: *"What does this mean?"*

Confucius said: *"Viewed from their differences, liver and gall are as distant as Chu and Yue. Viewed from their sameness, the myriad things are all one. If one is like this, why would he trouble his mind with what the ears and eyes deem fitting? He roams in the harmony of virtue with things, seeing their unity and not perceiving their loss—regarding the loss of his foot as if it were discarded earth."*

Chang Ji said: *"He cultivates himself, using his knowledge to attain his heart, and using his heart to attain its constancy. Why should things be able to sway him?"*

Confucius said: *"People do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water—only stillness can still the many. The earth receives its mandate, yet only the pine and cypress remain verdant through winter and summer. Heaven receives its mandate, yet only Shun was singularly upright. How fortunate is one who can rectify life and thereby rectify the many! The proof of preserving the beginning lies in the substance of fearlessness. A single brave warrior may charge into nine armies. Those who seek fame and can bind themselves are like this—how much more one who governs heaven and earth, stores the myriad things, treats the six limbs as a temporary abode, the ears and eyes as mere reflections, and whose knowledge knows what is known while the heart never dies! He will choose a day to ascend to the heavens, and people will follow him. How would he deign to make things his concern?"*

The annotation states: *"Nine armies: Cui and Li explain that the Son of Heaven commands six armies, the feudal lords three, together making nine. Ascending to the transcendent realm: Lü’s pronunciation is ‘xiá,’ meaning one who attains this Dao moves without hindrance, ascending to the realm of the mysterious and boundless. In the ‘King Mu’ chapter of the *Liezi*, the character ‘登假’ is also read as ‘xiá,’ confirming this."*

Guo’s commentary:
To depart in emptiness and return in fullness—each attains what is sufficient in itself. Though formless, the heart reaches completion; how strange that when the body is maimed, the heart becomes even more abundant! When the heart is whole, one leaves the body behind, forgets the five viscera, and suddenly wanders alone—none in the world can separate from it. Why would one need the state of Lu to lead the world in following? When spirit is complete and the heart fully realized, the body harmonizes with things, and the world cannot fathom this—how could it be merely one state?

The transformations of life and death are the greatest of changes. Yet one who moves with change is unaltered by life or death; though heaven and earth collapse, they but follow its course. To discern the unborrowed is to understand the constancy of nature and destiny. To not shift with things is to let things shift of themselves. To command the transformations of things is to take transformation as destiny without resistance. To guard one’s root is to never depart from the ultimate rightness.

Though liver and gallbladder may be as distant as Chu and Yue, their natures of tranquility and bitterness differ, and so their perceptions of beauty and ugliness diverge. Yet when the myriad things are seen as one, though what they find beautiful differs, each finds beauty in what it finds beautiful—thus all things share a single beauty. Each affirms what it affirms, and so the world shares a single affirmation.

If one distinguishes based on differences, then the world is nothing but differences, and the vast spectacle of governing heaven and earth and storing the myriad things arises from knowing that differences need not be distinguished. If one unites based on sameness, then the world is nothing but sameness, yet knowing that sameness need not be clung to, one then unites based on nothingness—thus right and wrong, beauty and ugliness, all dissolve into nothingness.

That I am right and others wrong, that I am beautiful and others ugly—from those with understanding down to the insects, none are free of this. Yet if one is clear about oneself but unclear about others, how is this different from the sage who merges with the world? Such a one illuminates the world through the world, and the world has no "I" to oppose. Thus, to see that the world has no opposition is to see that there is no "other" to be right. To see that the world has no rightness is to see that there is no "this" to be right. With right and wrong, this and other blended into one, one can ride change, follow transformation, encounter things without fear.

Not knowing the proper bounds of the ears and eyes, the heart roams freely.

The harmony of virtue arises from what is deemed unsuitable. Without beauty or ugliness, nothing is unsuitable—thus one forgets suitability. To forget suitability entirely is to be unburdened by anything; to be unburdened by all yet find nothing unattainable has never been heard of. Without unattainability, disharmony is also unheard of. Therefore, the heart roams freely between heaven and earth, unbound and unfettered, expansive and unobstructed.

Things are seen in their unity, not in what they lose. To embody the subtlety of the utmost principle is to find no thing dissimilar. With no thing dissimilar, life and death, change and transformation—nowhere do they cease to be the self. Thus, life is the self in its time, death is the self in its compliance; gathering is the self in its convergence, dispersal is the self in its divergence. Though gathering and dispersal differ, the self remains the self—hence, life is the self. There has never been gain, nor has death ever ceased to be the self; there has never been loss. The transformations of life and death are but one. Having observed this oneness, one is unbound and carefree, merging self and other, treating life and death as waking and dreaming, the body as a temporary abode. To depart from life is like shedding sandals; to sever a limb is like discarding dirt. I have never seen such things ensnare the heart.

Those who act for themselves with their knowledge suspect that Wang Tai could not forget knowledge and thus preserve himself. Those who attain the heart through their heart suspect they cannot abandon the heart and thus attain themselves. Those who attain their constant heart—what can things do to rank them highest? For to attain the constant heart is to proceed with equanimity. The suspicion that one cannot proceed with equanimity and thus exceeds the constant in accommodating things is what causes things to converge upon them.

The still water that serves as a mirror does not seek to mirror by stillness. Thus, the crowds gathered by Wang Tai came of their own accord—how could he have drawn them to follow him? Only stillness can still the many; if one moves to still them, one cannot remain among the stillness of all things. Only Shun stood alone. To speak directly: those who receive the pure qi of nature are exceedingly rare. Lower their heads, and they are but pines and cypresses; raise them, and they are but sages. Thus, all that is not upright comes seeking uprightness. If all things possessed complete integrity, pines and cypresses would hold no esteem; if all people were upright, great sages would hold no distinction—and none would turn to them. Those fortunate enough to be upright themselves and thus upright others are fortunate in their own uprightness, not in using uprightness to make others upright. Those who seek fame and bind themselves to it are not those who can abandon fame and be unburdened by all. To govern heaven and earth and store the myriad things is to embody all without obstruction. To lodge temporarily in the six senses is what is meant by a temporary abode.

The ears and eyes are but images—people use them, yet they are also used by them, not because they require ears and eyes. When knowledge moves with change and transformation, there is nowhere it does not govern—this is the oneness of knowledge. When the heart follows life and death, there is no time it is not alive—this heart has never died. Those who select auspicious days to ascend to heaven do so to avoid losing governance. Such a person makes no selection; they follow the movement of heaven and act in due time. Thus, those who borrow from them esteem them most. Their tranquility preserves their wholeness.

Therefore, it is said: *How would they deign to make things their concern?*

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Those who study the Dao study what they cannot study; they practice what they cannot practice. Thus, the parable of Wang Tai. Those who followed Confucius knew how to follow what they could practice but not what they could not—thus, even if all of Lu had followed him, it would have been no different from Wang Tai, merely a division. Following what they could practice, they stood to teach and sat to discuss; their teaching could not be without words, their accomplishments could not be without form. Following what they could not practice, they stood without teaching and sat without discussion, going forth empty and returning full. Confucius and Wang Tai were but outer and inner to each other. If one does not take what they could do as the task of a ruler or teacher, the usefulness of the useless is far from the common.

Who would change with life and death? Who would discard with collapse and ruin? To discern clearly that what is attained is real and does not shift with things is to remain unchanged by life and death, collapse and ruin—only to command transformation and things, not to be transformed, to guard one’s root and origin without departing. People only fail to see things as the same because their ears and eyes do not turn inward. Those who see things as the same do not know what ears and eyes should do—thus, they see things in their unity and do not see what they lose.

Changji said of Taihuai: his inner sagely Dao was for himself alone. With his knowledge, he attained his heart; with his heart, he attained his constant heart. What could things do to rank him highest and make him a ruler or teacher? Only stillness can still the many—this is why people followed him to seek a mirror. No tree does not receive its mandate from the earth, yet only pines and cypresses remain whole. No person does not receive their mandate from heaven, yet only Shun stood upright. If uprightness were unique to Shun, would he not consider it fortunate to be upright himself and thus make others upright? Now, those scholars who name themselves brave can yet charge into nine armies—how much more so one who governs heaven and earth, stores the myriad things, and does not change with life and death? They are not like those who seek fame and bind themselves to it. They select auspicious days to ascend to heaven, their comings and goings leisurely—how could such a person not be followed and esteemed?

**Xu Xi:**
To be beyond externals is to stand alone even if heaven and earth collapse, without reliance or dependence. To sit and watch the transformations of the myriad things, alone with that which preceded heaven and earth—this is what is called the origin, the begetter of heaven and earth.

**Yi Du:**
To govern the formed with the formless is to govern heaven; to store the myriad things with nothing is to store them. To command the six senses is to lodge without attachment; to embody the ears and eyes is to preserve without use. To know without being divided by things, to keep the heart without it perishing with the body, to control fate from within rather than without—this is how one selects auspicious days to ascend to heaven.

**Tong Yi:**
"For oneself" means their learning was not for others, yet others revered them—why? Because with their knowledge, they attained their heart, speaking of introspection to see their celestial ruler. With their heart, they attained their constant heart, as if a wanderer returning home, knowing this was their inherent estate. This only speaks of acting for oneself—what does it have to do with others? Yet others revered them thus, revealing Changji’s own attainment.

**Fu Mo:**
To be upright is to align with one’s nature and mandate; to align with one’s nature is to guard the origin; to guard the origin is to preserve the beginning.

The verification of preserving the beginning is like one cultivating courage—taking fearlessness as the essence and thus remaining unmoved in heart. Therefore, a single warrior can dominate nine armies. How much more so for one who guards the origin and aligns with their nature, preserving the beginning before any beginning arose? What sign could there be that they cannot command life and death, directing the transformations of things?

They govern heaven and earth, administer the myriad things, and lodge within the six bodily forms as mere images of ears and eyes. They say: "I and heaven, earth, and the myriad things share a single root and origin. Scattered, they become the ten thousand; gathered, they become the One. This is merely lodged within the six bodily forms, with ears and eyes as its images." People only cling to images and lose their heart, recklessly giving rise to knowledge. Thus, the heart is born from things and dies with things. Now, if one unifies their knowledge with what is known, the heart has never truly died—so why should life and death be feared?

Formerly, Liu Bing studied the Dao. A divine person told him: "Your heart’s power is keen and fierce—you will surely break through life and death." Those who study know that the matter of life and death is great. If one applies keen focus and vibrant energy, rousing themselves to break through like a fearless warrior with true courage, they can dominate life and death, moving freely without obstruction. This is the learning of liberation from life and death. Zhuangzi casually revealed this, yet at that time, the sutras of Western India had not yet arrived, and the Buddha’s teachings were already in China. Who can say the Buddha’s teaching is merely a foreign law?

**Bi Sheng:**
*"Receiving mandate from earth—only the pine and cypress remain upright, verdant through winter and summer. Receiving mandate from heaven—only Yao and Shun stand at the head of the myriad things."* The original text is uneven, seemingly missing words. Zhang Junfang’s collated edition reads: *"Receiving mandate from earth—only the pine and cypress remain upright."* It adds *"verdant through winter and summer"* and *"receiving mandate from heaven—only Yao and Shun stand at the head of the myriad things,"* supplying seven missing characters. This follows Guo’s commentary, which notes *"below, only the pine and cypress; above, only the sage."* Now, punctuating *"only the pine and cypress remain upright"* with *"only Yao and Shun stand"* makes the text coherent and the meaning complete.

Shentu Jia was a man without feet, yet he studied with Zichan of Zheng under Bohun Wuren. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay." The next day, they again sat together in the same hall. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay. Now, I am about to leave—can you stay? Are you not yielding? You see the one in power and do not avoid him—do you consider yourself equal to the one in power?"

Shentu Jia replied: "Within the Master’s gate, is there truly one in power? If you delight in your own power and only then let others see you, I have heard: *When a mirror is bright, dust does not settle; when dust settles, it is not bright.* Long association with the worthy leaves no faults. Now, what you take as great is the Master—yet you still speak like this. Is this not a fault?"

Zichan said: "You are already like this..."

Shentu Jia continued: "You still vie with Yao in claiming goodness—is your virtue not sufficient for self-reflection? Those who justify their faults and deem themselves undeserving of ruin are many; those who do not justify their faults and yet remain undeserving of survival are few. To know there is nothing to be done and yet rest content in it as fate—only those of virtue can do this. To wander within Yi’s drawn bow: the center is the mark. Yet whether one hits it or not is a matter of fate. Many are those with whole feet who mock my incomplete foot. I was enraged at first, but when I came to the Master’s place, my anger melted away and I returned to myself. Did the Master not cleanse me with goodness? I have followed you for nineteen years, yet you never once saw me as a man without a foot. Now, you walk with me within the realm of form, yet you seek me outside of form—is this not a fault?"

Zichan, startled, changed his expression and said, "You need not say more."

*(Guo’s commentary: "If I leave, you stay"—he was ashamed to walk alongside a man without a foot. The next day, he pressed the matter, wishing to ensure they would not walk together. "You consider yourself equal to the one in power"—he constantly took pride in his position, so to say "you consider yourself equal" was enough to show his lack of deference. "Within the Master’s gate, is there truly one in power?"—this was a place for discussing virtue, not calculating rank. "If you delight in your own power and only then let others see you"—he mocked his arrogance in office, wishing to put himself before others. "Long association with the worthy leaves no faults"—though he served a wise teacher, his mean and grudging heart had not yet departed, which was the true fault. "You are already like this"—his form was impaired. To not reflect on oneself and yet slight those in power, comparing oneself to those of virtue—his virtue was not enough to make up for the fault of his impaired form. "Those who justify their faults and deem themselves undeserving of ruin are many"—he often confessed his faults, claiming he did not deserve to perish. To silently acknowledge one’s faults and deem oneself deserving of death was rare. Yi was a skilled archer of old; the range of his bow and arrow was called the "drawn bow." Where profit and harm contend, the world is all Yi. Those who do not forget themselves, who let knowledge go and flow with things, all wander within Yi’s drawn bow. Though Zhang Yi went forth and Shan Bao stayed in, neither escaped the mark—whether one hits it or not depends solely on fate. Yet these petty ones each meet their own circumstances and do not know that fate is thus. Those who escape the harm of bow and arrow take themselves as skillful, delighting in their own success. When they fail to escape, they resent their mistakes, their spirits wounded and their dignity lost—these have not yet grasped the nature of fate. As for my life, it is not something I myself have given.)*

Within the span of a single life, within a hundred years, all that arises—sitting and rising, moving and resting, stillness and action, inclinations and aversions, temperament and intellect, abilities and possessions, all that is present and all that is absent, all that is done and all that is encountered—is not the self. The principle is simply thus. Yet to arbitrarily generate joy and sorrow within it is to go against nature and lose oneself.

Those who mock my incomplete limbs with their own completeness do not understand fate and thus mock. Those who bristle with anger upon seeing this mockery are likewise ignorant of fate and thus angered. Those who despondently turn back do so upon witnessing the perfected person’s understanding of fate and relinquishment of form, thereby relinquishing their former anger and returning to constancy.

Do I not know that you, Master, have cleansed me with goodness? Or do I not know that you have washed me with the virtuous Way? Am I capable of self-reflection? This is to forget the form and cast off burdens. For nineteen years, I have never known my own lameness—so thoroughly have I forgotten the form. The form lies without; virtue resides within. Now you and I wander in virtue, not in the exchange of forms, nor in seeking external favors. Is this not excessive? You need not speak further; once awakened, one wearies of excessive words.

**Limited View:**
Shentu accepted fate and forgot his lameness; his inner virtue was full, and thus he felt no sorrow outwardly. Zichan prized his rank and despised the lame, his heart ensnared by externals and blind to what lies within. Those who ought not to die are many; those who ought not to live are few. This is Shentu’s discourse on the preservation or loss of limbs: few are those who, upon becoming lame, recognize their own faults and accept them. Yet fortune and misfortune alike return to fate. Thus, Shentu’s lameness arose not from fault. Wandering within Yi’s drawn bow, none escape the mark; if one is not struck, it is mere luck. Living in the world, none escape suffering; if one avoids misfortune, it is also luck. Yet when others mock my misfortune because of their luck, I still harbor anger, for I have not forgotten myself. When I despondently turn back, I too have forgotten. Do I not know that you, Master, have cleansed me with goodness? Or is it my own awakening? Then both self and other are forgotten, subject and object are transformed—how can joy or anger arise? How can the form be sought?

In Lu there was a lame man named Shushan Wuzhi, who hobbled to see Confucius. Confucius said, “You were not careful before and thus incurred such suffering. Though you come now, what can be done?”

Wuzhi replied, “I was ignorant of my duties and recklessly used my body, which is why I lost my foot. Now I come because I still possess what is more honorable than feet, and thus I strive to preserve it. The heavens cover all without exception; the earth bears all without exception. I took you, Master, to be like heaven and earth—how could I have known you would be like this?”

Confucius said, “I am indeed narrow-minded. Why do you not come in? Please share what you have heard.” Wuzhi departed. Confucius said to his disciples, “Exert yourselves! Wuzhi is lame, yet still strives to study and make amends for his past misdeeds. How much more should those with complete virtue do so?”

Wuzhi said to Lao Dan, “Is Confucius not yet a perfected person? Why does he persistently seek you as a student? He seeks strange and marvelous fame, unaware that the perfected person regards such things as his own shackles.”

Lao Dan said, “Why not simply lead him to see life and death as a single thread, the permissible and impermissible as a single strand, thereby loosening his shackles? Would that not suffice?”

Wuzhi said, “How can one escape the punishment of heaven?”

**Guo’s Commentary:**
The heel and cheek. As for human life, the principle arises of itself.

“To simply refrain from action and allow things to arise of themselves—this is to value one’s person and know what truly matters.
