If, however, one forgets that things arise of themselves and instead meticulously guards and prides oneself on them, this is to use one’s person lightly and fail to know what truly matters. Thus the five viscera attack one another within, and hands and feet suffer injury without. Yet even one who reveres the foot still exists—this shows that the loss of a single foot is not enough to diminish one’s virtue. Clearly, the bodily frame is but a temporary abode. Abandoning self-importance and caution, allowing things to arise of themselves—this is the way to preserve wholeness.

Heaven does not act for the sake of covering, yet it constantly covers; Earth does not act for the sake of bearing, yet it constantly bears. If heaven and earth were to act for the sake of covering and bearing, they would at times rest. If a boat were to act for the sake of sinking yet float for people, it would at times founder. Thus, when things act for a purpose, they cannot fully sustain their existence. How can one who still clings to such ways demand that another be as meticulous as heaven and earth?

Wuzhi departed, having heard what he heard, and preserved his non-action. Why then did he persistently seek Lao Dan as a student? He was puzzled that Confucius was once again studying under Lao Dan.

One without self-interest learns, and others learn as well. The ancients studied for themselves; today, people study for others. Their divergence leads to this: they end up doing what others do. To teach others so that they attain self-realization is to guide them toward what is constant. To abandon oneself, imitate others, and chase external things is to seek an extraordinary reputation. Yet extraordinary reputations arise from what is constant.

Thus, the learner does not pursue illusions and marvels—illusions and marvels necessarily arise from learning. The practitioner of ritual does not seek florid shallowness—yet florid shallowness necessarily arises from ritual. This is an inevitable principle, something the perfected person cannot prevent. Why then regard it as one’s own shackles?

Why not simply lead him to see life and death as a single thread, the permissible and impermissible as a single strand, thereby loosening his shackles? To use direct principles to restrain him, hoping he will leave no traces—how can the punishment of heaven be escaped?

Confucius was not without restraint, yet when the principle of spontaneity moves, the shadow follows; when words are spoken, echoes respond. To accord with things is to establish a reputation and traces, yet one who accords with things does not do so for the sake of reputation. If not for the sake of reputation, one attains perfection—yet in the end, he cannot escape.”

Who then can untangle reputation? Thus, reputation is but shadow and echo—shadow and echo are the shackles of form and sound. When this principle is understood, reputation and traces may be abandoned, and one’s nature and life preserved.

**Supplementary Ink:**
Shushan Wuzhi knew there were those who prized their feet, so he sought to preserve them. When those who prized their feet were preserved, they saw the discarding of their feet as no different from discarding dirt. The Master, however, rejected other pursuits and studied to amend past misdeeds, unaware that such people do not arise from thoughts of good or evil—something not easily grasped by those bound by teaching.

Thus, Wuzhi and Lao Dan discussed in private: “Is the Master not yet a perfected person? Why does he so earnestly and reverently study under you?” He is ever hastening to seek a good name in the world, yet does not know that the perfected person regards this very thing as his own shackles. For the perfected person has no self, and the sage has no name. Like hands and feet, they are originally without shackles—those who bear shackles do so only because they create distinctions and bind themselves.

To loosen these shackles, one must reverse such distinctions and return to unity: regard life and death as a single thread, the permissible and impermissible as a single strand. Only then is it possible. To regard life and death as a single thread is to recognize that there was never a beginning to life—who then names death? To regard the permissible and impermissible as a single strand is to see that originally there was no right—what then is wrong? In this way, good and evil are but illusory dharmas, all distinctions mere deceptive names. There is no more essential way to free people from entanglement and remove their bonds. Yet those under heaven’s punishment remain suspended, unable to be freed.

*Heaven’s punishment* here refers to the inevitability of celestial retribution, an absolute and inescapable fate.

Duke Ai of Lu asked Confucius, saying: "In Wei there is an ugly man named Aitai Tuo. Men who dwell with him grow attached and cannot bear to leave. Women who see him beg their parents, saying, 'Rather than be another man’s wife, I would be this gentleman’s concubine'—there are already more than ten such cases, and the number does not cease. He has never been heard to initiate speech; he only responds in harmony. He holds no lordly position to aid others, nor does he possess wealth to fill their bellies. Moreover, his ugliness startles all under heaven. He harmonizes but does not lead; his knowledge does not extend beyond the four borders. Yet male and female alike gather to him—there must be something extraordinary about him. He is, after all, a man. I summoned him to observe, and indeed, his ugliness startled all under heaven. Yet after dwelling with me for less than a month, I began to take notice of him. Before a full year had passed, I trusted him completely. When the state had no chief minister, I offered him the governance. He responded with reluctance, as if seeking to decline, and I felt ashamed. In the end, I entrusted him with the state. Before long, he left me and departed. I grieved for him."

Should it be as though he had perished—should he leave this state joyless—what manner of man is he?

Confucius replied: "I, Qiu, once served as envoy to Chu. There I happened to see some young pigs nursing from their dead mother. After a brief moment, they all abandoned her and fled, no longer seeing her as their own. For what they loved in their mother was not her form, but that which animated her form. When warriors fall in battle, their burial does not include the ornaments of the living; those who have lost their feet receive no shoes—none are mourned for what they have lost at the root. The consorts of the Son of Heaven do not cut their nails or pierce their ears; those who take wives remain outside the inner chambers, no longer employed—all preserve their bodies intact. How much more, then, one whose virtue is whole?

Now, Ai Taituo has never spoken yet is trusted, has done no deed yet is beloved, so much so that others offer him a state, fearing only that he will not accept. He must be one whose talents are complete and whose virtue remains unmanifest."

Duke Ai said: "What do you mean by *talents complete*?"

Confucius replied: "Life and death, existence and annihilation, failure and success, poverty and wealth, worthiness and unworthiness, slander and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these are the changes of affairs, the movements of fate. They follow one another day and night, yet one’s knowledge cannot encompass them in advance."

At its inception, it cannot disturb the harmony of the bones nor penetrate the numinous abode. It allows harmony and ease to flow without losing joy, day and night unbroken, ever spring-like in its resonance with things. This is what it means to keep one’s talents whole—what arises in the heart in perfect accord with the seasons.

What is meant by *virtue remaining unmanifest*? Consider still water at its fullest: it may serve as a model. Within, it preserves itself; without, it does not sway. Virtue is the cultivation of perfect harmony. When virtue remains unmanifest, things cannot depart from it.

Another day, Duke Ai told Minzi: "At first, I believed that by facing south as lord of the realm, holding the people’s guiding thread, and grieving over their deaths, I had attained the utmost understanding. Now, having heard the words of the perfected one, I fear I lack its reality. I have taken my person lightly and forgotten my state. Between Confucius and me, there is no ruler and minister—only a bond of virtue as friends."

One who seeks no accumulation of emoluments nor gazes upon others’ bellies makes plain that he does not go for the sake of food. One who repels the world with ugliness makes plain that he does not go for the sake of outward beauty. One who harmonizes without leading does not summon others to come—it is they who draw near of themselves. One whose knowledge does not extend beyond the four bounds does not exhaust thought on what lies beyond his portion.

The one whose *power remains whole* harms nothing in the world: thus men and beasts do not scatter their herds, birds do not disorder their flights, and he becomes the spirit of the ten thousand things. One who responds only after deep silence is not startled by favor or disgrace, for his spirit remains undisturbed. One who drifts as though declining does so because others decline first—he merely declines in turn.

Fangzi fed at the breast of his dead mother: he was nourished by milk. The living are guided by *power and talent*; when these depart in death, the living flee as though they have lost their guiding thread. Thus one whose *inner power* is profound resembles an infant: nothing in the world harms him, for he has attained the thread and made it manifest. If the heart’s disposition is thus whole, then even if the form differs, things will not harm it. But if the heart’s disposition is lost, then even if the form is that of mother and child, it is not enough to secure their bond.

What gives form is *talent and power*. A funeral fan is the resource of martial prowess; if one dies in battle, what use are the wings of war? Loved shoes are for the sake of the feet; why would a man without feet cherish shoes? Without their root—feet—fan and shoes are nothing. The root of martial prowess is the foot. Not cutting, not piercing, preserves the form whole; one cannot employ it again for fear of injuring the form.

Selecting consorts and concubines, or cherishing a new bride, is done for the sake of physical beauty. Thus the wholeness of form prevents even the most exalted sentiments from swaying the chastity of a steadfast woman. When *power* is whole, things naturally love it.

Life and death, existence and extinction, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these principles are inherent and cannot be escaped. Thus human life is not a mistake.

All that life possesses is not possessed in vain. Though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things numerous, what I encounter is precisely what lies before me—even the gods of heaven and earth, the state, sages, and those of utmost strength and wisdom cannot transcend it. Thus, what one does not encounter cannot be encountered, and what one encounters cannot but be encountered; what one does not do cannot be done, and what one does must be done. Entrusting it to its proper place, it naturally fits. Fate proceeds and affairs transform without ceasing day or night, pressing forward without pause, lingering without halt. Therefore, one whose *power* is whole follows whatever is encountered and entrusts it to its course.

The beginning is not what knowledge can plan, nor the end what emotion can detain. How could one who understands that fate must proceed and affairs must transform scheme for the end or cling to the new? Even with utmost wisdom, one cannot plan for it. What has passed is gone—what can I do? If one knows that nature and fate are inherently as they should be, then though death and life, poverty and prosperity shift in a thousand transformations, one remains serene and unperturbed, harmony and principle residing within. Thus it is said: what is insufficient does not disturb the harmony of the numinous abode, for the spirit dwells in the abode of essence. What is utterly sufficient does not startle the spirit with sorrow or misfortune. Thus it is said: nothing may enter the numinous abode. When harmony and ease fill the nature, the numinous abode remains undisturbed; though one traverses the greatest changes, one does not lose one’s joy. Thus it is said: harmony and ease flow freely without losing joy, day and night without gap—all is entrusted to its constant course. To be spring for all things is what the multitude of life depends upon. Meeting and generating the seasons in the heart is to follow the four seasons and transform together with them.

The peace of the world is nowhere more perfect than in still water, for it is utterly without emotion and thus utterly level—hence the world takes it as the standard. Thus it is said: levelness is the perfection of still water, and it may serve as a model. Preserving it within while remaining undisturbed without is to preserve one’s clarity within and be without emotion without, becoming a profound mirror that illuminates all things without partiality. Thus one preserves its levelness and enacts its model. Affairs are accomplished and things are harmonized—this is called *virtue*. No affair is unaccomplished, no thing unharmonized—this is the formless *virtue*. Therefore, the world delights in esteeming it and never tires of it.

Following the root: The *Record of Rites* states that for three years of mourning and for one who has newly married, there is no service. Thus it is said: one who takes a wife remains outside and may not again be employed. "Day and night without gap" means that though death and life, poverty and wealth alternate day and night before us, I employ them without fissure or crevice to enter. Viewing them as one, they blend indistinguishably, becoming spring for all things. Just as the year has four seasons yet one does not see its summer, autumn, or winter but only sees it as spring—this is seeing the days and meeting things, generating the seasons in my heart. Thus, from the word "spring," the word "season" arises below, signifying that the seasons do not arise from the *qi* of yin and yang but from my heart.

Limited view: The meaning of "male and female" is sometimes taken from the *Liezi* as referring to birds and beasts, where male and female mate in front and rear to form herds. Yet examining the classics’ intent, when a man dwells with a woman, he thinks of her and cannot leave, and a woman wishes to be his concubine—thus male and female unite. The preceding words say that many men and women return to this. Those who die in battle do not use the *sha*; the *Fan Wu Yin* follows the *sha* in an absolute phrase. The *sha* is an implement for adorning martial prowess, shaped like a square fan, made of wood, covered in white cloth, painted with cloud patterns, and placed on either side of a chariot for self-defense.

Examining the *Liji*’s "Tan Gong" chapter and the "Mingtang Wei," it is recorded that the Zhou placed *sha* in their rituals. Zheng’s commentary states: the Son of Heaven used eight *sha*, each adorned with jade and hanging feathers; feudal lords used six *sha*, each adorned with a *gui* tablet; great officers used four *sha*; and scholars used two *sha*, each adorned with *rui* tassels. From this, it is clear that *sha* were universally employed in ancient funeral rites, not merely as martial adornments. I privately trace the original intent of the *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi]: the sages established rites to enable people to nurture life and send off the dead without regret. The Zhou used coffins and shrouds, decorated with willow and *sha*, with distinctions of rank and degree each fitting its proper measure—thus was the reverence for life’s end.

Those who die in bitter battle do not meet a proper end, and so in their burial, *sha* are not used. Their forms cannot be preserved whole—how then could one expect the full array of ritual objects? This is akin to one who has lost a foot having no use for shoes. This passage, beginning with the analogy of the child feeding from its dead mother, extends the metaphor to this point, layering comparisons to conclude: those whose virtue is full within have no need of external embellishment, while those whose inner power is depleted gain no benefit from outward adornment.

*Bisheng* states: "To *wang* is like the fullness of the moon—round, complete, and replete. Harmonious yet not initiating, one does not see their ability to lead affairs. Knowledge does not extend beyond the four realms, and one does not perceive their far-reaching strategy."

One possesses neither rank nor position, talent nor appearance—yet male and female alike turn to them in devotion. This is not that they compel things to preserve themselves, but that things preserve themselves through them. What manner of person is this? One wonders: where lies the power to move others? The analogy of the child at the breast suggests that form is not inherently lovable—it is what gives form that is lovable. A mother’s love takes what gives her child form as its foundation; in battle, martial prowess is the foundation; in conduct, the feet are the foundation. That Yutai Tuo was retained when present and missed when absent was because he possessed such a foundation.

Talent here refers to the "lesser talents" of Mencius—those whose talent is incomplete are often pleased with their own self-promotion. When talent is complete, virtue is full within. What need is there for form? Life and death, existence and annihilation, success and failure, wealth and poverty, worthiness and unworthiness, praise and blame, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—though their changes appear thus, one cannot grasp what brings them about. Thus, they are called *ming* (fate). If one knows the origin from which they arise, how could one remain indifferent? Yet though these changes alternate day and night without cease, their origin is such that even the wise cannot fathom it—this is what is meant by "never having had a beginning."

To know that there has never been a beginning—how then could one disturb the great harmony of one’s *lingfu* (spiritual abode)? Ye Yu, like Laozi, "seals the opening" of the senses, harmonizing and flowing without losing touch with the senses or things. This is the "formless" state, where one moves with the ten thousand changes yet never loses the proper moment. When water is still and level, all things align with it. Levelness allows it to preserve itself within; stillness prevents it from being disturbed without. The levelness of water is like the harmony of virtue.

This harmony is cultivated until it is complete—hence it is said, "the cultivation of completed harmony." Things cannot depart from it. This also explains the meaning of "formless": it is unity without division, the absence of change in life and death.

Yinqi, Zhili, Wuchun, and Shui—King Ling of Wei delighted in them, seeing in their deformities the wholeness of others. Their necks were like *dou* vessels, their shoulders like urns, their bellies like jars, their goiters vast. Duke Huan of Qi was ashamed before them, seeing in their deformities the wholeness of others. Thus, virtue may be long where form is forgotten. People forget what should be forgotten yet forget what should not be forgotten—this is called "true forgetting." Therefore, the sage wanders freely, while knowledge becomes a snare, schemes become glue, virtue becomes a bond, and skill becomes commerce. The sage does not scheme—what need is there for knowledge? He does not carve—what need is there for glue? He does not lose—what need is there for virtue? He does not trade—what need is there for commerce? These four are bestowed by Heaven. What is bestowed by Heaven is the Heavenly succession.

Having received sustenance from Heaven, what need is there for man? One may possess the form of a human but lack the passions of one. Having the form of a human, one mingles with others; lacking human passions, right and wrong do not adhere to one’s person. How trivial is that by which one is bound to humanity!

Alas! How vast! Alone, he completes his Heavenly endowment.

Huizi said to Zhuangzi: "Do humans truly lack passions?"
Zhuangzi replied: "Indeed."
Huizi asked: "If humans lack passions, how can they be called human?"
Zhuangzi said: "The Dao bestows upon them their appearance, Heaven bestows upon them their form—how can they not be called human?"
Huizi said: "If they are called human, how can they lack passions?"
Zhuangzi replied: "This is not what I mean by passions. What I call 'lacking passions' means that one does not inwardly harm the body with likes and dislikes, but always follows nature without artificially enhancing life."

Huizi asked: "If one does not enhance life, how can one possess a body?"
Zhuangzi said: "The Dao bestows upon them their appearance, Heaven bestows upon them their form—do not inwardly harm the body with likes and dislikes. Now, you are estranged from this: your spirit is wearied, your essence leans and sways, you hum while resting against a withered catalpa, and sleep with closed eyes. Heaven chose your form, yet you clamor about 'hard and white'—like the gatekeeper with crippled limbs, the one with a swollen goiter, or the hunchbacked jar-carrier."

Guo's commentary:
*"The gatekeeper with crippled limbs and the one without lips—these speak of partial passions leading one way: the ugly become more admirable, while the admirable become more ugly. 'Virtue has its strengths while form has its forgettings'—when virtue excels in harmonizing with things, one forgets ugliness; when it excels in resisting things, one forgets beauty. In life, they are cherished; in death, they are discarded—thus virtue is what the world does not forget, while form is what principle does not retain. Therefore, those who forget form do not truly forget; only those who do not forget form but forget virtue achieve true forgetting. The sage wanders in the realm of self-contentment, letting go without fail—his talents and virtue are complete. Knowledge becomes a snare, schemes become glue, virtue becomes a bond, and skill becomes commerce—these four arise naturally from one another, their principles already inherent. Thus, the sage has no use for his own contrivances. What is bestowed by Heaven is the Heavenly succession—it is naturally endowed. Having received this natural endowment, its principles are already sufficient. Though one may ponder deeply to avoid calamity or clearly admonish to evade misfortune, things do not occur at random; they are the safeguards of Heaven and Earth, the tendencies of the utmost principle. One must think for oneself—it is not I who thinks; one must not think for oneself—it is not I who does not think. Some think and escape; some think and do not escape; some do not think and escape; some do not think and do not escape—none of these are of my doing. What is there to do? Simply entrust it and let it come of itself."*

One who possesses the human form appears in semblance to others, yet lacking human sentiment, they are like the branch of a withered tree. To gather among people or disperse from them follows the natural Dao. One who does not take right and wrong to heart is without sentiment, and thus remains vast and unburdened, accepting all things without resistance—something those with sentiment cannot achieve. Thus, though their appearance is human, they alone fulfill their Heavenly nature. The Dao bestows their countenance, and Heaven grants their form—this speaks to human birth, which does not arise from sentiment. What life knows is not what sentiment knows. Therefore, those with sentiment strive for detachment yet cannot attain it; yet through detachment, one becomes perceptive and wise. Those with sentiment strive for sagehood yet cannot achieve it; yet through detachment, one becomes a sage. Is it only that sagehood is distant and detachment difficult to emulate? Even the most foolish, the deaf and blind, the crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs—if they cling to sentiment in their actions, they will never succeed. Whether distant or near, even if separated by but a fraction from the realm of Confucius and Yan Hui, they will never grasp it. Thus, observing all things, one returns to the self: the eyes cannot exchange their duty to achieve success, nor can the hands and feet substitute for one another’s tasks. When an infant is first born, it does not seek milk with its eyes, nor turn toward light with its ears; it does not grasp objects with its feet, nor attempt to walk with its hands. Are the hundred limbs without fixed roles? Is the body without an inherent master, governed solely by sentiment? If one is called human, how can they be without sentiment? Yet they fail to understand that form and appearance are not sentiment. What I call sentiment is not this—if right and wrong, likes and dislikes, are taken as sentiment, then one who is without right and wrong, without likes and dislikes, though possessing human form, is merely human in appearance. Where, then, does sentiment reside?

The person without sentiment does not harm their body with likes and dislikes. To proceed directly and accept what comes is not sentiment. To constantly follow nature without overstepping what is fitting is to remain within what is proper. Why seek to preserve the body if one does not understand that life arises of itself and principle is self-sufficient? Zhuangzi also said that the principle of life is already complete within form and appearance; simply entrusting it allows the body to endure. The sentiments of likes and dislikes do not enhance life but only harm the body, for life has its allotted measure. If the spirit does not rest within the bounds of its nature, it becomes external; if essence does not abide within the limit of its self-generation, it becomes exhausted. Thus, one walks leaning against a tree, chanting, or sits propped against a catalpa, sleeping—this is the self-imposed suffering of those with sentiment. Heaven selects the form to manifest purity and clarity. All that you do—expending spirit, exhausting essence, leaning against trees, propping against catalpas, chanting and sleeping—this is what the world calls sentiment. Yet it is said that Heaven selects, for sentiment does not give rise to these things—how much less anything else? Thus, though the myriad things and myriad forms, their actions and choices, all arise within the realm of non-sentiment, what use is sentiment in their midst?

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The man with no lips or a large goiter was esteemed for his virtue by two rulers, forgetting his form. People do not know how to preserve their spirit—this is what they forget. They are enslaved by sight, hearing, thought, and worry—this is what they do not forget. To forget what should not be forgotten and not forget what should be forgotten—this is called true forgetting. It is not merely the form that is forgotten; in true forgetting, the sage roams where things cannot escape and all are preserved. If it were so, then knowledge would be a calamity—calamity is not the root. Constraint would be glue—glue is what binds the scattered.

To connect through virtue is how disparate bodies are joined; to trade skill as merchandise is not how one makes vessels.

The sage does not scheme—what use is knowledge? Does not carve—what use is glue? Has no loss—what use is virtue? Does not traffic—what use is trade? These four are the Heavenly Market. Thus, though possessing human form, they lack human sentiment, for their roaming abides in true forgetting. If they mingled with others, would they not wander amid worldly right and wrong? Not gaining these at the self, they embody the Heavenly Equality. In the lesser, they belong to man; in the greater, to Heaven.

In appearance, their movements and dignified bearing are nothing but the Dao. In form, their six limbs and nine orifices are Heaven-born—this suffices to be human. Why doubt they cannot be without sentiment?

Hui Shi insisted on no sentiment, like wood or stone, unfit to be human. Zhuangzi said: "What I call sentiment is not gaining right and wrong at the self. What I call no sentiment is not allowing likes and dislikes to inwardly harm the body." If so, this suffices to preserve the self—why seek to augment life?

Hui Shi, not knowing that movement itself is stillness, clung to the withered paulownia to seek stillness. Precisely this ignorance is failing to grasp what enables action. He let form be chosen by Heaven, yet clamored about "hard and white"—how could it not be strange?

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
The sage roams beyond forgetting form and forgetting virtue. Though daily employing virtue, he does not pride himself, so glue and calamity never sprout. Not scheming gain or harm—what use is knowledge? Not carving emotion and nature—what use is glue? Having no loss of things—what use is virtue? Not hoarding goods and wealth—what use is trade? These four are all Heaven’s nurturance.

The dung beetle rolling its ball, the spider weaving its web—this is unplanned knowledge. Cloud-dragon and wind-tiger, pine and cypress, dodder and mistletoe—this is uncarved glue. Birds and beasts in forests, fish and turtles in rivers—this is lossless virtue. Each thing seeks its own benefit, each manages its own life—this is untraded commerce. These are what Heaven nurtures, hence "Heaven feeds the formed but not the sentimental." Gazing upon them, they resemble wooden chickens.

A foot-long face, with differing features—this the Dao bestows. A six-foot body, with hollows and cavities no different—this Heaven bestows. Neither belongs to sentiment. If Heaven entrusts you with form, how can there be sentiment? It merely lives and breathes of itself.

Now you possess human form, no different from others, yet forcibly clamor about "hard and white" and "same and different" before the crowd, calling yourself worthy—like smelted metal leaping from the furnace, how could it not be monstrous?

**Xun Ben’s Commentary:**
*Du* 脰 means the neck; *jianjian* 肩肩 describes its slender length. It speaks of delighting in the lipless man, yet seeing a whole person makes one feel his neck is too long and ugly, unworthy of regard. The *Rites of Zhou*’s "Artificer" says *shumu du* 數目顅脰, with the note "long-necked appearance." *Jian* 肩 and *du* 顅 are the same. *Gaowu* 槁梧 is today’s withered paulownia. Paulownia species vary, but only withered paulownia makes zithers and lutes, hence their name.

**Fu Mo’s Commentary:**
These three—ugly in form—could make the lords of Qi and Wei admire them, seeing whole men as inferior. They loved their virtue, forgetting their form. From this, we know: form has its shortcomings, virtue its strengths. Shortcomings can make others forget them, while in oneself, as if forgotten, must avoid the taint of ugliness. Strengths can make others not forget them, while in oneself, if not forgotten, must avoid the flaw of pride. To not forget what should be forgotten and forget what should not—this is true forgetting.

Taking the word "forgetting," I derive my own learning and use the sage to verify it. The sage truly forgets what should not be forgotten. His mind has somewhere to roam. He treats knowledge as calamity and does not rely on it; oaths and pacts as glue and does not use them; virtue and kindness as social engagement and does not value them; skill and ability as traded goods and does not possess them. Why? The sage neither thinks nor plans—what use is knowledge? Uncarved and unhewn—what use is glue? Fundamentally nothing is lost—what use is virtue? Deeply hidden, not for sale—what use is trade? Since he has no use for others, he roams with Heaven. Thus, it is called the Heavenly Market. In the Heavenly Market, the sage is fed by Heaven—what use is man? Though possessing human form, his form is small, yet without the sentiment of right and wrong, his Heaven is great.

"The Dao bestows features, Heaven bestows form"—appearance, form, image, and visage all arise from what has never had a beginning. The Dao bestows them, which is Heaven bestowing them. Hui Shi said: "Since it is called human, how can there be no sentiment?" He wanted them to be like withered wood and dead ashes to be without sentiment. Thus, Zhuangzi said: "This is not what I call no sentiment." It means not allowing likes and dislikes to inwardly harm the body, always following the self-so of life without augmenting it. Laozi said: "To augment life is called ominous." Zhuangzi’s text follows this. Hui Shi still did not awaken, saying: "Without augmenting life, how can one have a self?" He did not know life need not be augmented. The Dao bestows features, Heaven bestows form—life’s principles are sufficient in themselves. From this sufficiency, one cannot follow nature and arbitrarily generate likes and dislikes, chasing delusion and losing truth. This not only brings no benefit but also harms. Now, your spirit—was it not bestowed by the Dao, your form by Heaven? Yet you estrange your essence, labor your spirit, lean on trees, cling to the withered paulownia, chanting and sleeping. Heaven chose your form—nothing is lacking—yet you cannot follow it, merely clamoring about "hard and white," endlessly setting up right and wrong and same and different in the world, merely burdened by sentiment. Observing Hui Shi’s debate with Zhuangzi, he was entirely unclear about the matter. I do not know why Zhuangzi befriended him.

**Guan Jian’s General Discussion:**
What enables things to live is called virtue—this is Heaven’s pure endowment. From it, form is completed and life honored; through it, nature and the Heavenly Dao can be known. Since virtue originates in Heaven and is fulfilled in man, can one not cherish and esteem oneself?

Things’ correspondences and responses, particular details, serve as seals of virtue. When virtue is fulfilled, its success is great—there are those who assist Heaven and Earth, aiding transformation and nurturance. Thus, Wang Tai could inspire respect in Confucius, who wished to lead the world to follow him. His cultivation must have greatly surpassed others. Without teaching or discussion, learners came empty and left full. If not through mind connecting with mind, life and death unchanged, things commanded and the root preserved, transformation issuing from oneself—how could he achieve this?

Those who attain the Dao forget form by observing what they relinquish and what they lose. Only when one can halt the many does one reveal the clarity of halting through emptiness. All these serve as the Way to fulfill virtue. When virtue is fulfilled, things naturally gravitate toward it—just as pines and cypresses stand among common trees, or Yao and Shun among the people. Is this merely fortune in rightly ordering one’s life? The true fortune lies in rightly ordering the lives of others, while one’s own life and death, fortune and misfortune, are as insignificant as mustard seeds. Thus, choosing the day to ascend or depart, staying or leaving, rests with oneself—how could one be ensnared by external things?

Shentu Wuqu’s amputation was no greater a loss than being lame; to see the lame as whole is to see wholeness itself. Zichan, despite his noble rank as a minister, was arrogant toward the lame—though noble, he was base in spirit. Wuzhi, though without toes, was honored, for what remained was weightier than feet. Heaven’s punishment cannot be undone, yet one who accepts fate remains no different from the whole. Aitaita’s androgyny so captivated others that Duke Ai forgot his own flaws and wished to entrust him with the state—not because he loved his form, but because he loved what shaped his form.

Thus, when supreme harmony operates within, illness dissipates without; virtue renews daily, and the Dao connects with spiritual transformation. Affairs are accomplished, yet one does not claim merit, and there is nowhere one does not become the归宿 of all things. Duke Ai regarded Confucius as a "virtue-friend," for virtue’s honor transcends rank. Duke Ling saw Wushen as whole, for virtue’s honor transcends form. The sage’s realm merges with things without boundary—how vast! Only by perfecting one’s Heaven can one forget what others cannot forget, and the purest beauty becomes irresistible.

Huizi was rich in talent but poor in virtue. When asked about likes and dislikes, he answered in terms of nature and fate, thus deeply correcting his flaws. By embodying the Dao in appearance and transcending form, he remained unharmed by likes and dislikes. With form yet without attachment, he constantly aligned with spontaneity. At this stage, virtue is fulfilled, and things correspond—self and other both exhausted, right and wrong, likes and dislikes dissolved in wordless understanding. How could one exhaust spirit and labor essence to boast of "hard and white"? Taking the mutilated and disfigured as exemplars serves as a warning to those who exalt form over inner virtue.

**Chapter Six: The Great and Venerable Teacher**
*(Guo’s commentary: Though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things abundant, what they revere as teacher is the mindless.)*

One who knows Heaven’s doing and knows man’s doing has reached the utmost. To know Heaven’s doing is to be born of Heaven; to know man’s doing is to use one’s knowledge of the known to nourish one’s ignorance of the unknown, thus completing one’s Heaven-appointed years without premature death—this is the pinnacle of knowledge. Yet there is a peril: knowledge depends on conditions, and what it awaits remains uncertain. How can we be certain that what I call Heaven is not man, or what I call man is not Heaven? Only with the true person does true knowledge arise.

What is a true person? The true persons of old did not resist the few, did not dominate success, and did not scheme with scholars. Thus, they passed without regret and hit the mark without self-satisfaction. They ascended heights without trembling, entered water without getting wet, entered fire without burning—such is the knowledge that ascends to the Dao.

*(Guo’s commentary: To know Heaven’s and man’s doings is to know they are both spontaneous. Thus, one inwardly releases the self and outwardly guards against things, sharing the same task with the multitude of mysteries, yet nothing is left undone. "Heaven" means spontaneity. Those who act cannot truly act but act spontaneously; those who know cannot truly know but know spontaneously. Spontaneous knowing is not knowing; spontaneous acting is not acting. Thus, knowing arises from not-knowing, and acting arises from not-acting. Acting arises from not-acting, so non-action is primary; knowing arises from not-knowing, so not-knowing is fundamental. Therefore, the true person abandons knowledge yet knows, does not act yet acts, and lives spontaneously. By sitting in forgetfulness, one attains—thus knowledge is called "cut off" and action "gone.")*

Man’s life, though a mere seven feet in form, must possess the Five Constants. Thus, though the body is small, it upholds heaven and earth to sustain itself. Heaven, earth, and the myriad things—none can be absent for a single day. If one thing is missing, the living cannot live; if one principle is unfulfilled, one’s Heaven-appointed years cannot be completed. Yet what the body possesses, knowledge may not know; where principle resides, action may not act. Thus, what knowledge knows is little, while what the body possesses is much; what action does is few, while where principle resides is vast. Those above cannot measure it to seek completeness.

People’s knowledge need not be the same, nor should their actions dare to differ. Difference breeds artifice and loses the real. Some love knowledge tirelessly, exhausting their bodies—what they love is but a branch, yet the root is ruined. This is using what they know to harm what they do not know. But those with the fullest knowledge know man’s doing has limits, so they act without forcing; they know man’s knowledge has bounds, so they use it without excess. Thus, their knowledge does not exhaust itself in boundlessness, and within the body, knowing and not-knowing guard each other to remain whole. This is using what they know to nourish what they do not know.

The peril lies in saying that even the fullest knowledge is not as good as abandoning knowledge and entrusting oneself to Heaven’s carefree spontaneity. Knowledge cannot be without "can" or "cannot," so it must depend on conditions. But if one entrusts oneself to Heaven and lives, one meets things appropriately. What it awaits is uncertain—if it depends on conditions, there is no certainty. My life has limits (Heaven), but to seek to extend it is man. Yet this is merely man’s view. Things are all Heaven; Heaven is spontaneity. If all is spontaneity, then order and chaos, success and failure, encounter and non-encounter are not man’s doing but all spontaneous. Only with the true person does the world’s knowledge become truly unconfusable.

Not resisting the few means following the many; not dominating success means not relying on success to precede things; not scheming with scholars means following the heart’s direct path, and the multitude naturally gathers—not through scheming to achieve it, but simply preserving wholeness when meeting things without fault. Not taking gain and loss to heart—such is the principle’s inherent wholeness, not fear of death. Thus, the true person walks on land not to avoid getting wet, distances from fire not to escape heat, and makes no mistakes not through careful placement. Though not taking heat as heat, they never rush into fire; not taking wetness as wetness, they never step into water; not taking death as death, they never lose life. Thus, life—does it live by living?

The accomplished—does it accomplish by accomplishing? Thus, one who entrusts all and yet nothing fails to reach is the true person. How could they have preconceived notions about what they encounter? To speak of knowledge ascending to the Dao—how distant it is!

**Lü’s Annotation:**
To know what Heaven does is to know that what gives rise to me is Heaven. That which acts without acting, and in which humans have no part, is what knowledge cannot know. What knowledge can know is what humans do—thus, one nurtures what they do not know with what they do know. To say that knowledge nurtures life is not to make life follow knowledge; this is how one may live out their years without being cut short. What the world calls the pinnacle of knowledge does not surpass this, yet it still cannot avoid calamity. For what is called "knowing Heaven and knowing humans" must rely on knowledge to be correct—this is not the true essence of the Dao, and what it relies upon is inherently unstable. How then can we be certain that what we previously called "Heaven" is not human, or that what we called "human" is not Heaven? Only the true person possesses true knowledge, knowing with non-knowing and requiring no reliance. The world’s rights and wrongs are not uniform, so one merely follows the multitude—but following the multitude risks resisting the few. The earthly Dao achieves nothing yet succeeds in alternation; rigidity risks dominating success. Seeking unanimous counsel risks scheming with scholars. These are all traces of the sage’s response to the world, not their true essence. The true person embodies pure simplicity and selflessness—though they may err, they cannot but err; what regret could there be? Though they may act rightly, they cannot but act rightly; what self-satisfaction could there be? If so, then climbing heights is what I do—whom should I fear? Water and fire are also what I do—whom should I dread to wet or burn? Knowledge is not the Dao, yet the true person’s true knowledge can ascend to the Dao by borrowing from it. If so—

**New Transmission:**
Heaven and humans are both the Dao, and only those who fully embody the Dao can know what Heaven and humans do. To know what Heaven and humans do is to know with non-knowing. Knowing Heaven with non-knowing is to penetrate the wondrous principle of non-action; knowing humans with non-knowing is to exhaust the ultimate of action. This is Laozi’s "without desire, observe the subtle; with desire, observe the manifest." At this point, one cannot say it is not the pinnacle of knowledge, yet calamity still arises—because one knows the duality of Heaven and humans but not their unity. The far-seeing know that Heaven and humans are fundamentally the same, indistinguishably merged. This is what is meant by "emerging together yet differently named, together called the mysterious." Thus, only with the true person does true knowledge arise. True knowledge is non-knowing, yet it can uphold compliance to await the few, guard the feminine and appear deficient, not scheme nor strive, and scholars naturally gather. Thus it is said: not resisting the few, not dominating success, not scheming with scholars. How could the true person err in this way? If they ever err, it is not because they take gain and loss to heart. Not taking them to heart means having no mind for things; having no mind for things means not opposing them, and things will not harm them. Is this not how the true person differs from others? It is by entering the Dao through true knowledge. Thus it is said: knowledge ascends to the Dao by borrowing from it. If so—

**Personal Insight:**
"Few" refers to times of scarcity; "success" refers to times of abundance. In scarcity, one must comply to avoid harm; in abundance, one must be humble to avoid disaster. As for "scholars," it is explained through affairs: not thinking, not premeditating. If so, then in interactions and dealings, errors arise naturally—how could there be regret? Rightness also arises naturally—how could there be self-satisfaction? It is like drifting tiles or an empty boat: having no mind to oppose things, things do not resent them. With this, climbing heights—whom should one fear? With this, entering water and fire—what would wet or burn one? If even ascending to the Dao through knowledge is like this, how much more so for one who forgets knowledge and attains sudden awakening?

The true person of old slept without dreaming, awoke without worry, ate without relishing flavor, and breathed deeply. The true person’s breath reaches their heels; the common person’s breath reaches only their throat. Those who are submissive speak with a choked voice, as if obstructed; those with deep desires have shallow heavenly mechanisms. The true person of old did not delight in life nor detest death. Their going forth was not joyful, their return was not resistant. They came and went with ease, neither forgetting their origin nor seeking their end. They accepted and rejoiced in it, forgot and returned to it—this is called not using the mind to discard the Dao, not using humans to assist Heaven. This is called the true person.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
"Slept without dreaming" means having no intentions. "Awoke without worry" means being content with whatever they encounter.

The true person eats without relishing—food is simply what ought to be eaten. Their breath reaches the heels, arising from the very root. A choked voice sounds as if obstructed, for their qi is not smooth and unobstructed. When the root is deep and the utmost tranquility attained, one returns to unity, free from desire; thus, those with deep cravings have shallow heavenly mechanisms.

Those who do not delight in life nor detest death embody transformation itself. Without resistance or obstruction, they remain at ease and yield to it. Their coming and going is effortless, for they entrust themselves to the supreme principle, and thus their movements are never difficult. They forget all beginnings and endings, all changes and transformations—how could they merely forget life while still seeking the meaning of death?

To accept and rejoice is to question not what is received, for whatever they encounter brings no discomfort. To forget and return is to return not through conscious effort, but to the utmost. Human beings are tranquil by nature at birth, for this is Heaven’s nature. When moved by external things, desire arises from this nature. Yet the things that stir people are endless, and if one pursues them without restraint, the heavenly principle is extinguished.

The true person knows that using the mind goes against the Dao, and that assisting Heaven harms life, so they do not act thus.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
Without thoughts, one sleeps without dreaming; without cravings, one eats without relishing—then their breath becomes deep, reaching the heels. The heel is the origin of qi, the source from which breath arises. Just as the foot’s heel is the lowest part of the body, so too is the origin of breath described as the deepest. To go deeper still is to reach the point of no-breath.

The common person, having lost their foundation, is submissive, their voice choked as if obstructed—how could they attain breath that reaches the heels? Their heavenly mechanism is shallow, stirred by the slightest touch. But when breath reaches the heels, one distances oneself from external things.

Those who know life rejoice in it and detest death, resisting departure and rejecting return—this contradicts the so-called "carefree" state. It is to forsake the Dao with the heart, to love life and seek its origin, to fear death and seek its end. Unable to joyfully accept it or forgetfully return to it, they obscure their natural state and thus seek to enhance life—this is to assist Heaven.

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
When the heart is free of thought, the hun-soul is at ease and does not wander among things, so sleep is dreamless. When the body is without action, the shen-spirit is at rest and not enslaved by things, so waking is free of worry. When flavors are tasteless, one savors the flavor yet is not bound by flavor, so food is not relished.

**Xun Ben’s Annotation:**
Deep breath is as if stored in the feet; shallow breath emerges from the throat. In truth, the Sea of Qi is the root of breath. The "heavenly mechanism" refers to the natural movement of qi, that is, breath. The deeper the cravings, the shallower the breath—like those who are submissive, whose cravings run deep, whose voices choke as if obstructed, whose heavenly mechanism is shallow.

**Bi Sheng’s Annotation:**
"Departing the world" means to go forth—birth, coming, beginning, and receiving. "Returning to transformation" means to enter—death, going, ending, and returning. To know that the beginning has no true beginning is to not forget one’s origin. To know that the end has no true end is to not seek one’s end. Thus can one move in and out of transformation, play with life and death—what joy or aversion could there be? To "forsake the Dao with the heart" is to alter the heart even slightly, thereby abandoning the Dao. The Dao has no life or death, yet people hold dual minds—what is this if not discarding the Dao? To "assist Heaven" is as Laozi said: to constrict one’s dwelling, to loathe one’s life, and to seek enhancement beyond the realm of the living. The true person does not act thus. Even to fear death and seek liberation is but a secondary principle.

Those who are thus have a steadfast heart and a tranquil countenance, their foreheads broad and unadorned, their demeanor as chilling as autumn, as warming as spring. Their joy and anger flow with the four seasons, aligning with things without fixed limit. Thus, when the sage employs military force, he may destroy a state yet not lose the people’s hearts. His beneficence extends through ten thousand generations, yet he does not act out of love for others. To delight in things is not sagely; to have partiality is not benevolent; to follow the seasons is not worthy; to be obstructed by profit and harm is not noble; to act for fame and lose oneself is not a scholar; to lose one’s life without authenticity is not to serve others. Those like Hu Bujie, Wu Guang, Boyi, Shuqi, Jizi, Wu Zixu, Yu Jita, and Shentu Di serve others’ purposes, follow others’ paths, and do not follow their own—this is to be enslaved by others’ enslavement.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
To dwell in peace is to be steadfast. Though active, the tranquil remain unharmed in stillness. *Kui* describes the appearance of great simplicity. To seem as autumn, withering things, is not to act with authority; to seem as spring, nurturing things, is not to act with benevolence. Joy and anger flow with the four seasons, meaning one who embodies the Dao moves with change, like cold and heat—warm and stern without intent. Thus, the semblance of warmth and sternness, the rhythm of growth and decay, are merely named as joy and anger. To "align with things" is to be without intent toward them, so nothing is forced out of place, and nothing is out of place—thus none know its limit. In employing military force, he follows the people’s desire to perish, so they perish, and thus he does not lose their hearts. The sun ascends the sky, illuminating the six directions—not out of love for others, but naturally. Thus, the sage’s presence in the world is as warming as spring, naturally harmonious, so those who receive his blessings do not give thanks. It is as chilling as autumn frost, naturally descending, so those who wither do not resent it. The sage has no delight—things simply flow unimpeded where nothing obstructs them. He has no partiality.

To follow the principle is simply to let things exist as they are. As for the seasons, even the worthiest cannot compare to one who forgets time and naturally aligns with it. Unable to unify the path of right and wrong, pursuing profit and avoiding harm will damage virtue and burden one’s proper place.

The true scholar abandons fame and finds contentment within, so his name matches his reality, and fortune responds to his person. Those who lose their nature and force themselves to follow things are enslaved by many. How can they enslave others? Like Hu Bujie and Wu Guang, they all abandon themselves to serve others, sacrificing the self to harm the self.

*Lü’s Annotation:*
One whose heart and will are set on the Dao: when his appearance is tranquil, his spirit congeals, unmoving. When his brow is serene, he returns to simplicity, without affectation. Chill as autumn, he bears no hatred; warm as spring, he bears no love. Joy and anger flow through the four seasons, harmonizing with the harmony of Heaven—this is how he aligns with things. A state may perish, yet he does not lose the people’s hearts, for he has no intent to hate. His blessings extend for ten thousand generations, yet he does not act out of love. Toward things, he follows their natural unfolding. Toward benevolence, he forgets it entirely across the world. Toward the times, action and withdrawal rest with him. Even in hardship, he does not lose what he upholds—this is how the noble one’s steadfastness differs from that of the common people.

The scholar forgets loftiness and depth, abandons life and death—he enslaves others. Thus, from sages and worthies down to those who enslave others, though their ranks differ in honor and baseness, all must possess what is called the "real" to fulfill their names. Hu Bujie and Wu Guang were but slaves to those who enslave others, never attaining their own proper satisfaction. Only by acting without acting can one truly attain one’s own proper satisfaction.

*Bisheng’s Note:*
The character *zhi* (志), according to Zhao’s correction, should be *wang* (忘, "forget"), which aligns with the meaning of "tranquil appearance." His interpretation seems apt. As for Ji Fu’s explanation of "enslaving others," it likely derives from *Xumi*, where one ascends heights without fear and abandons life and death. The idea is subtle, yet when viewed alongside the later phrase "slaves to those who enslave others," it becomes even clearer that Master Zhuang’s analysis is precise.

The true person of old had a demeanor upright yet not partisan, appearing insufficient yet not submissive. His edges were sharp yet not rigid, vast in emptiness yet not ostentatious. His joy was abundant, as if pleased; his bearing was lofty, as if compelled. His advance was smooth, enhancing my countenance; his pause was yielding, deepening my virtue. Stern, he seemed worldly; aloof, he seemed beyond control. Connected, he seemed fond of seclusion. Oblivious, he forgot his words.

He took punishment as his body, ritual as his wings, wisdom as his timing, and virtue as his path. Taking punishment as his body, he was lenient in execution. Taking ritual as his wings, he moved through the world. Taking wisdom as his timing, he acted only when unavoidable. Taking virtue as his path, he spoke as if he had feet, reaching the hills—yet people truly believed he exerted himself in practice.

*Guo’s Annotation:*
"Upright yet not partisan" means aligning with things without forming cliques. "Empty and without excess" means appearing insufficient. "Lowering himself without fail to raise others" means appearing insufficient yet not submissive. "Sharp yet not rigid" means roaming alone without fixed attachment. "Vast yet not ostentatious" means expansive and free, reaching true substance. "Abundant joy" means the perfected person has no joy, yet his harmony is so complete it seems joyful. "Lofty, as if compelled" means his movements, stillness, actions, and pauses always reside at the extreme of naturalness. "Smooth advance" means he does not let things harm himself. "Yielding pause" means he has no direction to pursue. "Stern, seeming worldly" means the perfected person is not stern, yet moves in step with the world, appearing so. "Aloof, beyond control" means he is high and free, self-content. "Connected, seeming fond of seclusion" means his depth is boundless, his gate unseen. "Oblivious, forgetting words" means he does not know or recognize, yet the heavenly mechanism moves of itself.

The penal code is the embodiment of governance, yet it is not I who enact it; ritual is the world’s own conduct, not something I impose. Knowledge arises from the movement of the times, not from my leading; virtue is what others follow, not what I create. To take the penal code as one’s foundation is to entrust governance to its own course—though it kills, it is lenient. To take ritual as one’s wings is to follow the flow of the times, so nothing fails to proceed. High and low receive one another in an irreversible current; small and great gather in an inevitable momentum. Vast and without emotion, it is the repository of all knowledge. Embracing the confluence of a hundred streams, dwelling at the teacher of humanity’s extremity—what is there to do? Entrust the knowledge of the times to necessity, consign the affairs of the world to their natural course, and that is all.

The root is what gives rise to all things. Speaking in terms of nature, it is the root of nature. Each thing has what suffices, and what suffices is its root. To entrust the self-following of the myriad virtues is to join those with what suffices in reaching the root. When the root is reached, principle is exhausted. All this is accomplished by others; its completion does not lie with oneself. Thus, though one dwells at the extremity of ten thousand affairs, one remains ever at leisure, self-content, unaware of the passage of events through the body, oblivious to the presence of words in the mouth. Yet people’s great delusion is to call the perfected person’s effortless conduct "diligent action."

】Profound Dao【
Its form is righteous yet not cliquish, unapproachable in intimacy or distance. Seeming deficient yet not deferential, beyond valuation as noble or base. Angular yet not rigid, conduct though not rounded is not obstinate. Empty yet not ostentatious, patterns though not substantial do not destroy substance. Joyful, as if in harmonious ease. Lofty...

Pressed by necessity, only then does one respond—how replete! Advancing, my countenance is restrained, essence stored within, spirit issuing without. How harmonious! Halting, my virtue is employed outwardly, undissipated inwardly. How stern! How towering! How continuous! These three attain the utmost in non-action. How oblivious! Such words are the utmost in wordlessness.

The Dao of the perfected person reaches non-action and wordlessness, taking penal codes, rites, knowledge, and virtue as its root alone. The classics often compare the Dao to mountains and virtue to hills—Mount Miaogu, the hidden hills of Yinfen, Mount Juci, and the Kunlun mounds are such examples. That people mistake the perfected person’s effortless conduct for diligent action is like gazing upon the multitude of the ten thousand things and suspecting Heaven and Earth of laborious carving.

Thus, whether one favors it or not, it is unified; whether one unifies it or not, it remains one. Those who unify it walk with Heaven; those who do not walk with man. Heaven and man do not overcome one another—this is called the perfected person. Life and death are its constants, like night and day, like Heaven. That humans cannot partake in this is the nature of things. If one takes Heaven as father and still cherishes the body, how much more should one cherish that which transcends it? If one considers having a lord superior and still dies for the body, how much more should one die for the genuine?

When springs run dry, fish find themselves stranded together on land, moistening one another with breath, wetting one another with foam—yet how much better to forget each other in rivers and lakes. Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie, how much better to forget both and be transformed by the Dao.

Guo’s commentary:
To remain ever without intent yet follow others is to make no distinction between what one favors or disfavors, what one deems good or evil—all becomes one with them. That oneness is walking with Heaven; its absence is walking with man. The perfected person harmonizes Heaven and man, equalizing self and other, for their oneness admits no division. To lack oneness is to be without any lack of oneness—this is Heaven. To insist "that is that" and "this is this" is the way of man. The perfected person unites Heaven and man, aligning the myriad things without mutual rejection, for Heaven and man do not overcome one another. Thus, they are boundlessly without division, effortlessly without resistance, and profoundly one with all things.

Life and death are constants like night and day, the Way of Heaven. To know life and death is to grasp the ultimate of destiny—no delusion lies therein. They are but night and day; what bondage could there be? The perfected person, in daylight, attains daylight; in night, attains night. Taking life and death as day and night, what could they fail to attain? That humans fret and grieve over what they cannot possess is merely the nature of things, not principle. The transcendent is called "solitary transformation." No achievement of interdependence surpasses the perfection of solitary transformation.

What humans depend upon is Heaven; what Heaven engenders is solitary transformation. All regard Heaven as father, thus they endure day and night, cold and heat without complaint—how much more should they accept the transcendent, solitary transformation that reaches the ultimate of the mysterious and boundless? How could they not yield to it? The genuine is not borrowed from things but arises naturally. The inviolable nature of the natural extends far beyond mere obedience to a lord’s command.

Thus, the parable of the stranded fish: to love one another in scarcity is not as good as to forget one another in abundance. Praise and blame arise from insufficiency; in perfect sufficiency, good and evil are forgotten, life and death are left behind, and one becomes one with transformation. Boundless and without obstruction, what concern could there be for the whereabouts of Yao or Jie?

Lü’s commentary:
Things are seen by what unites them, not by what divides them. Thus, those who favor them call them beautiful and good, and beauty and goodness arise from this; those who disfavor them call them ugly and not good, and ugliness and not-goodness also arise from this. Therefore, favor and disfavor are one. Oneness is like still water; its absence is like flowing waves—yet both are water. Knowing this, one does not merely cease when ceasing.

That which is one walks with Heaven, retiring into concealment; that which is not one walks with man, sharing in the people’s fortunes and misfortunes. What comes without being summoned is destiny; what is done without being acted upon is Heaven. Thus, humans cannot possess certain things—this is the nature of things. Why should I indulge in sorrow or joy over them? Taking Heaven as that from which I am born, I still cherish the body—how much more should I cherish that which gave birth to my birth, my true Father? How transcendent! Could I not love it?

If one truly knows its transcendence and loves it, then life holds no cause for joy—this is evident. Do people merely consider having a ruler preferable? Even one’s own body perishes—how much more so that which is truly real? If one knows its essence and heeds it, then death holds no cause for fear—this is evident. The source of nature and destiny lies in the parched depths, yet people, stranded on the dry land of artifice, gasp and moisten one another with the damp foam of benevolence and righteousness—how much better to forget one another in the rivers and lakes of the Dao’s arts, oblivious to life and death, gathering and dispersal.

For delighting in life and loathing death is but human sentiment; the Dao is without death and without life. Praising Yao and condemning Jie is likewise but sentiment. Knowing both and forgetting both, transcending praise to embody the Dao—then that by which one forgets life and death is not originally different.

**New Transmission:**
The true person is without intent, and their likes and dislikes are thus unified. The true person embraces duality and is not one, and thus is in accord. Without intent and unified, they follow nature—hence it is said they "walk with Heaven." Embracing oneness and in accord, they may be moved by circumstances—hence it is said they "walk with man." Slander and praise are but the vicissitudes of worldly sentiment; though the sage responds to them, their heart is truly without them. Yet if one abandons worldly sentiment and insists on regarding the forgetting of both as correct, how then can one "walk with man"? This is what Zhuangzi criticizes, yet the foolish Confucians instead criticize Zhuangzi.

**Supplementary Notes:**
Only here is the reason for not delighting in life or loathing death revealed. "Like" is delight; "dislike" is loathing.

The reason for neither delighting in life nor loathing death is the knowledge of its oneness—this "one" is Heaven. Knowing its oneness, one does not assist Heaven with human effort nor discard the Dao with the heart. What is called "only with a true person can there be true knowledge" refers to knowing this alone—this is the true nature of things. Life and death are fated, like Heaven’s constant alternation of night and day, beyond human power to alter. This is the unchanging principle of things, what is called "transcendent and true." Humans cannot depart from this Dao, just as fish cannot leave water. If one departs from it, the one is no longer one, and right and wrong, slander and praise arise in confusion. How much better is it to forget both and be transformed by the Dao?

This is the oneness that unifies the one and the not-one. Not only should right and wrong, slander and praise be entrusted to mutual forgetting, but even the great change of life and death should be forgotten, without the slightest interference of human effort. Though life and death are not one, their oneness has never ceased to be one.

The great clod burdens me with form, wearies me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to perfect my life is to perfect my death. Hiding a boat in a ravine or a mountain in a marsh may seem secure, yet in the dead of night, a strong man may carry them away, and the unaware will not know. Though hiding the small and large may be fitting, there is still escape. But to hide the world within the world is to leave no room for escape—this is the great truth of things.

Only when one encounters the human form does one rejoice in it, yet the forms of humanity are but one of ten thousand transformations, without beginning or end. How can their joy be measured? Thus, the sage wanders where things cannot escape and abides where all are preserved—perfecting early death, perfecting old age, perfecting beginnings, perfecting ends. People still imitate this, let alone the myriad things that depend on it and the one transformation that awaits them.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Form, life, old age, and death are all myself. Thus, form burdens me, life wearies me, old age eases me, and death rests me. Though these four change, they have never ceased to be me—why should I cling to them? Death and life are both fate. If there is no perfection, so be it; if there is perfection, then life is not alone in being perfected. If one deems one’s life good, then one’s death is also good.

To illustrate the inescapability of life and death’s transformations, first present the extreme of inescapability, then clarify it with the inevitability of change, so as to follow transformation without attachment. The power of the powerless is greatest in transformation. Thus, one lifts heaven and earth to pursue the new, shoulders mountains and peaks to abandon the old. Without the slightest pause, one has already traversed the new—heaven and earth, the myriad things, are never still. The world is all renewed, yet one takes it as the old. Boats and mountains change daily, yet one sees them as before. Now, in the blink of an arm, they are gone, vanished in an instant.

Thus, the "I" of the past is no longer the "I" of the present. I and the present both pass—how can one constantly guard the old? Yet the world does not realize this, believing what is encountered now can be grasped and held. Is this not delusion? Not knowing one’s body is transformation and seeking to hide it so it does not change—though one may hide it most deeply and securely, each in its proper place, nothing can prevent its daily transformation. Thus, those who hide and possess cannot stop its escape, while those who do not hide and yield to transformation cannot be changed by change.

Without anything to hide and fully yielding to it, one is one with things and one with transformation. There is no inner or outer, no life or death—embodying heaven and earth, merging with change, seeking escape yet finding none. This is the great truth of things, not the petty concerns of a single corner.

The human form is but one encounter among ten thousand transformations. In the boundless, what one encounters is all like the human form—why should only the human form be delightful while other things bring no joy? Originally not human, one transforms into human, losing what was before. Losing the old and rejoicing in what is encountered—what is encountered in endless transformation? Where is there no encounter? Where there is encounter, there is joy—how can joy have limits?

The sage wanders the paths of transformation, drifts in the currents of daily renewal. The myriad things and myriad transformations transform with him; the boundless transforms with him—who can escape? In life, one is gone; in death, one is preserved. If in death one is preserved, then when is one not preserved?

Those who are content within a hundred years, who do not perfect youth but deny old age, cannot embody transformation or equalize life and death. Yet their equanimity and purity are still enough to serve as teachers for others. How much more so for those who profoundly unite with the myriad things and embody transformation—they are rightly the masters of the world.

Lü’s Annotation:
The great cosmos is by nature indifferent to me. If I do good in life, then my death must also be good—what have I to love or hate? Things, whether great or small, exist when the mind is present and perish when the mind is absent. If one acts contrary to the Dao, nothing remains that does not depart. Thus, hiding a boat or concealing a mountain in a ravine or marsh may seem secure, yet once the mind is distracted, they vanish in an instant. Even at the profoundest hour of midnight, if there is something to be hidden, and one hides it in the most recondite place, could any but the most powerful accomplish this? To conceal things large and small appropriately and still have them escape—how could this be the nature of ordinary things? The world is where the myriad things attain unity. Concealed within this unity, even the most powerful, though they might wish to bear it away, would find nowhere to take it. Without true knowledge, one cannot partake of this.

Sengzhao’s Treatise:
Zhuangzi’s concealing of the boat and Confucius’s lament over the flowing river both arise from the difficulty of retaining what has passed. Why is this? People assume that youth and prime are of the same body, that a hundred years share one substance, knowing only that the years depart but not sensing that the form follows. Thus, when the Brahmin left home and returned with white hair, his neighbors asked, “Is the man of former days still here?” The Brahmin replied, “I am like the man of former days, yet not the man of former days.” The neighbors were all astonished, not grasping his words. This is what is meant by “the powerful bear it away and hasten, while the deluded do not perceive”—is this not the case?

Jiang Yu:
Things embody transformation, and the body follows transformation, vanishing within a hundred years. Within this span, the great transformation occurs four times, cycling repeatedly. Seasons change, years shift, days alter, and months transform—even in the space of a single breath, a sigh before and after reveals difference. It is like the wind striking water: the former wave is not the latter wave. It is like a lamp in a jar: the later flame is not the earlier flame. In the space between lowering and raising one’s gaze, the form has already undergone ten thousand changes. The deluded are imperceptibly moved by creation, seeing only the traces of their own form and unaware of creation’s silent operation. They rejoice in a thing’s completion but do not know the principle of its decay is already latent. They lament a thing’s decay but do not know the principle of its completion has already advanced. Yangzi’s profound words, “The moon wanes in the east, not knowing it waxes in the west,” speak of the subtle shifts of the great transformation, the alternating advance of decay and completion.

To seek this in oneself: the toil of a hundred years—complexion, wisdom, demeanor, skin, nails, hair—changes without cease. How could this be clearer? Why, then, does one not awaken to it? This is the meaning of Zhuangzi’s discourse on concealing the boat and Confucius’s sigh over the flowing river.

Personal Insight:
Concealing the boat or hiding the mountain is a metaphor for man’s place within creation, where one cannot escape creation’s ceaseless change. All things in the world, if concealed, must escape; if they escape, they do not endure. Only when there is nothing to conceal do things not escape and all endure. The place where things do not escape and all endure is the realm of nothingness, the boundless wilds. To attain this and wander therein, to meet all things without intention, to be open and all-pervading—nothing is not preserved. This is the Dao of concealing the world within the world. Though one enters and exits the mechanism of life, undergoes ten thousand transformations, one sees only daily renewal—where can things escape?

Yet people, clinging to private views, often claim things as their own, deeming boats and mountains unchanging objects, ravines and marshes secure hiding places, forms and substances unalterable. They do not realize that the hidden pivot silently revolves, that not an inch of time halts, that things and earth transform together with form, all unknowing. If one wishes to transcend and escape transformation, is there a Dao for this? It is said: have no concealment, no attachment; let the mind wander with heaven. Even the present is unattainable—how could one know what is called escaping transformation?

The Dao possesses sentiment yet is without emotion; it holds constancy yet is without form. It may be transmitted but not received, attained yet not seen. It is self-originating, self-rooted—before heaven and earth existed, it stood firm from ancient times. Spirits and gods, emperors and thearchs, heaven and earth all arise from it, yet it does not reside above in the Great Ultimate, nor below within the Six Poles. Before heaven and earth were born, it was not ancient; though older than high antiquity, it is not aged.

Xi Wei attained it and thereby lifted heaven and earth; Fu Xi grasped it and thereby inherited the Mother of Qi. The Northern Dipper holds it and thus remains unerring through all ages; the sun and moon possess it and thus never cease their course. Kan Pi obtained it and thereby inherited Kunlun; Ping Yi mastered it and thereby roamed the great rivers. Jian Wu acquired it and thereby dwelled in the great mountains; the Yellow Emperor attained it and thereby ascended the cloudy heavens. Zhuan Xu secured it and thereby resided in the Dark Palace; Yu Qiang stood firm by it at the North Pole. The Queen Mother of the West gained it and thereby sat in Shaoguang—none know its beginning, none know its end. Peng Zu possessed it, reaching from the age of Yu to the Five Hegemons; Yi Yin obtained it and thereby assisted Wu Ding, encompassing all under heaven, riding the Eastern Ridge and Tail Stars to rank among the constellations.

The Dao has the sentiment of the insentient, hence it is without action; it has the constancy of the inconstant, hence it is without form. Though it has dwelled through ancient and modern times, none can receive and possess it—all may find refuge within it, yet none perceive its form. Before heaven and earth existed, it stood firm from ancient times, revealing that nothing does not depend on being, yet it is non-being. How could non-being generate spirits? It does not spirit gods and thearchs, yet gods and thearchs are spirited of themselves—this is the spirit of non-spiriting. It does not generate heaven and earth, yet heaven and earth generate themselves—this is the generation of non-generating.

Thus, if one’s achievements are insufficient to be deemed spirit, yet one does not spirit, then one is truly spirit. What merit is there to claim? What deeds are there to rely upon? The Dao is high yet not high, deep yet not deep, enduring yet not enduring, aged yet not aged—it is nowhere absent, yet wherever it is, it is not.

Moreover, it reaches all above and below, yet cannot be named by high or low; it pervades all within and without, yet cannot be termed inner or outer. It moves with transformation, so cannot be called enduring; it is ever without beginning or end, so cannot be called aged. From Xi Wei’s attainment to ranking among the stars, those who gain it do so by the Dao, yet this only clarifies their self-attainment. The Dao cannot cause them to attain it, nor can my own lack of attainment prevent their attainment.
