Thus, all who attain it do not rely on the Dao externally nor depend on themselves internally—they suddenly attain it and transform alone.

The difficulty of life lies precisely in this solitary transformation and self-attainment. Having already attained life, why fear not attaining it and strive for it? Thus, striving for life is truly insufficient to preserve life, for life does not arise from oneself. To strive for it is to harm one’s true life.

Lǚ’s Annotation:
Eyes and ears attain it to see and hear; hands and feet attain it to move—how could this not be endowed with sentiment? Cold and heat attain it to come and go; the myriad things attain it to be born and nurture—how could this not be endowed with sincerity? Yet seeking what enacts it, one cannot find it—it is formless. Sometimes it is understood without speech, sometimes it is present at a glance—this can be transmitted, yet none can possess it; it cannot be received. Only by the heart’s resonance does it suddenly align—this can be attained, yet no trace of it can be grasped; it cannot be seen. The birth of the myriad things has never lacked a root, yet this is self-rooted and self-originating. The myriad things arise only after heaven and earth, yet this existed before heaven and earth, enduring since antiquity. Ghostly lords attain me through spirit, yet I am not spirit—even ghostly lords remain without numinous response. Heaven and earth attain me through life, yet I am not life—even now, I remain as the Supreme Polarity. Depth and height describe its form; age and antiquity describe its time, yet I am without form and without time—thus the Dao is hidden and nameless.

The sages of antiquity differed in concealment or manifestation, yet none became sages without attaining the Dao. This was not limited to Xi Wei alone, nor to Kui or Kui. The Dao is the mother of all under heaven; from heaven downward, none have stood without attaining the Dao. This was not limited to the Dipper and the sun and moon alone—this is why it is called the Supreme Ancestral Master.

*Brush Records*:
The Supreme Ancestral Master is the Dao. Only here is it made clear that Kui emerged from the formless, non-active Dao. Yet to speak of it as possessing sentiment and sincerity is to describe it from the perspective of those who perceive its subtleties. Sentiment is the movement of stillness; sincerity is the tally of movement—this is the "sincerity" of which Laozi spoke when he said, "Within it, there is sincerity." The Great Simplicity is before qi is seen; the Great Beginning is the inception of qi, before qi is seen. As the father, qi is the mother. The Northern Dipper is the net’s rope of heaven, hence called the "Dipper’s rope." Kanpei is the name of a spirit, with a human face and beast’s body. The *Qingling Zhuan* states: Hua Yin of Tongxiang, a man who ingested eight minerals, became a water immortal and was called the River Earl. Another account says he bathed in the river on the gengzi day of the eighth month and drowned. The mountain spirit of Jianwu is undying; by Confucius’ time, the Yellow Emperor had attained the Dao and ascended at Mount Dinghu. The Dark Palace is the northern palace. The *Monthly Ordinances* states: Its lord is Zhuanxu, its spirit is Xuanming. Yushang is the sea god. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* says: On an islet in the Northern Sea there is a spirit with a human face and bird’s body, wearing two blue serpents as earrings and treading two red serpents, named Yushang. The Queen Mother of the West: The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* describes her as resembling a human, with a dog’s tail, disheveled hair, wearing a sheng, skilled in whistling, and dwelling by the banks of the Xun River. Emperor Wu of Han’s *Inner Biography* records the Queen Mother of the West and the Upper Prime Lady descending; the emperor admired their divine beauty as immortals. Shaoguang is the name of a mountain, also said to be the name of the western void. Kui is a star above the tail, said to ride the eastern rope between the Winnowing Basket and the Tail.

Nanbo Zikui asked Woman Yu [Yu]:
"Your years are advanced, yet your complexion is like that of a child—how is this?"
"I have heard the Dao."

Nanbo Zikui said, "Can the Dao be learned?"
She replied, "How could it be? You are not the right person.

Now, there is Bolang Yi, who possesses the talent of a sage but not the Dao of a sage, while I possess the Dao of a sage but not the talent of a sage. I wished to teach him, hoping he might truly become a sage. If not, teaching the Dao of a sage to one with the talent of a sage would be easy indeed.

I still guarded and instructed him. After three days, he was able to put the world outside himself. Once the world was outside, I again guarded and instructed him. After seven days, he was able to put things outside himself. Once things were outside, I again guarded and instructed him. After nine days, he was able to put life outside himself. Once life was outside, he could then attain morning clarity. With morning clarity, he could then perceive the solitary. Perceiving the solitary, he could then transcend past and present. Transcending past and present, he could then enter the realm of neither death nor life.

That which kills life does not die; that which gives life does not live. As for this thing: nothing it does not send forth, nothing it does not welcome, nothing it does not destroy, nothing it does not complete. Its name is *Yingning*—*Yingning* is that which achieves through disturbance."

Nanbo Zikui said, "Where did you alone learn this?"

The Master said, "I have heard it said: what I heard came from the disciple of *Fumo*; the disciple of *Fumo* heard it from the grandson of *Luosong*; the grandson of *Luosong* heard it from *Zhanming*; *Zhanming* heard it from *Niexu*; *Niexu* heard it from *Xuyi*; *Xuyi* heard it from *Wu'ou*; *Wu'ou* heard it from *Xuanning*; *Xuanning* heard it from *Canliao*; *Canliao* heard it from *Yishi*—that which kills life is not death, that which gives life is not life."

Guo Xiang's commentary:
To hear the Dao is to allow life to arise of itself, thus one’s qi and complexion remain whole. *Wai* means to relinquish. Things are what one requires from morning to night, yet they are difficult to forget. To put life outside is to abandon it entirely. To relinquish life is to cease hating death; ceasing to hate death, one finds peace in whatever is encountered, utterly unobstructed, acting upon the subtlest signs—this is morning clarity. To find peace in whatever is encountered is to forget all that comes before and after—this is perceiving the solitary. Without past or present, one moves with the solitary. Clinging to life brings death; hating death brings life. Without clinging or hating, there is neither death nor life. Allowing things to depart of themselves, nothing is not sent forth; allowing things to arrive of themselves, nothing is not welcomed; allowing things to be destroyed of themselves, nothing is not destroyed; allowing things to be completed of themselves, nothing is not completed. That which moves with things is itself moved by things, yet remains ever at peace. If things move while the solitary does not, this is defeat. Thus, to be moved yet allow it is to bring all things to their perfect fulfillment.

*Xuanning* names that which is not nothing yet is not being. To ascend by names to reach nothingness is to attain nothingness beyond names. Thus, though *Xuanning* is profound, it does not reach the ultimate, and so one must further entrust it to *Canliao*—profound upon profound. The principles of spontaneity may be cultivated through accumulated practice, ascending from the near to the far, refining from the coarse to the subtle. Thus, after seven layers, the name of nothingness is left behind; after nine layers, one doubts even the beginning of nothingness.

Lü Huiqing's commentary:
When one hears the Dao, cares and troubles cannot enter, which is why one’s years may lengthen while one’s countenance remains youthful. Those who possess the Dao of the sage grasp its great root and great source; those with the talent of the sage apply this Dao to the world and the state. Boliang Yi had the talent but not the Dao, so one must guard and instruct him, progressing from the coarse to the subtle. First putting the world outside, then putting things outside, then putting life outside—only then does one attain morning clarity, sinking into profound obscurity within the body until, self-examining, one reaches clarity at dawn. To perceive the solitary is for each thing to find its counterpart, without past or present, uniting the myriad ages into one pure whole. In the realm of neither death nor life, what dies is killed by me, yet I have never died; what lives is given life by me, yet I have never lived. Though sending forth and welcoming, destroying and completing all involve disturbance, I have never been imperiled—thus the name *Yingning*. *Yingning* is that which achieves through disturbance.

The Dao, when embodied, is the norm; what is discussed in texts and writings is but its secondary aspect. *Luosong* means to recite by threading together; "descendants" refers to where the Dao is generated. *Zhanming* is the clarity of perceiving principle; *Niexu* is to tread and practice it.

To employ through need is to utilize things in song and chant, delighting them. From *Fumo* to *Zhanming*, learning yields insight; from *Niexu* to *Ou*, practice leads to joy—yet none of these suffice as the embodied Dao. In *Xuanning*, there is no seeing, no knowing; in *Canliao*, there is neither "also" nor establishment. To doubt it as the beginning yet not know it as the beginning—this is how it begins.

**Following the Root:**
*Chaoche* means sudden, thorough clarity—not awaiting seven or nine days. To wither the form and kill the heart is to "kill life," yet not die; to indulge passions and indulge desires is to "give life," yet not live. "Sending forth" is disturbance; *Fumo* and *Luosong* borrow the names of texts and writings; *Zhanming* and *Niexu* borrow the names of ears and eyes; to "employ through need in song" borrows the names of laborers and ballads. *Canliao* means to merge with the vast, boundless beginning—profound and ever more profound.

**Secondary Aspects:**
Above, it speaks of attaining the Dao; here, it speaks of the Dao’s difficulty to hear and transmit. To "set aside the world" differs from "setting aside things." The world is distant yet things are near; the world is estranged while things are intimate. Thus, setting aside the world is easy, but setting aside things is hard. To set aside things is to assist in setting aside life; setting aside life is to forget the self. Only after forgetting the self can one reach *Chaoche*; only after *Chaoche* can one perceive the solitary. The solitary matches nothing. Perceiving the solitary, there is no past or present, no going or coming—this is how one may speak of the Dao.

It further explains how to enter the realm of neither life nor death: "Killing life" does not mean death, for the heart dies while the spirit lives; "giving life" does not mean life, for the heart lives while the spirit dies. The world engages in sending forth and welcoming, completing and destroying, intertwining with all things. The human heart wanders among them—now inclining toward one, now welcoming another; now fearing destruction, now achieving completion. Birth and death surge ceaselessly, never resting. Those who detest this seek to cast it aside, not realizing that removing the heart of birth and death is itself birth and death. How then can one enter the realm of neither death nor life? Now, there is no "sending forth."

No welcoming, no destroying, no completing—following what arrives of itself while I harbor no accommodating mind: this is called "touching tranquility." "Touching tranquility" means achieving completion through contact. It is to attain great stability amid the world’s tangled turmoil, thus realizing the true aspect without destroying the world’s appearances. How could this be the same as those who seek completion through severing and extinguishing the seeds of nature?

It is like written words on bamboo slips, recited verses in the Luoyang dialect, the vision of one who gazes clearly, the hearing of one who listens keenly, the movement of one who serves, the singing of one who chants. Profound and abyssal, vast and empty—doubting the beginning, doubting that there was ever a beginning at all. Speaking of the Dao, one grasps it through language and script, yet comprehends it with the heart and unites with it through spirit. This is how one’s own "dawn clarity" arises, and how one sees alone.

Zisi, Ziyu, Zili, and Zilai spoke among themselves, saying: "Who can take non-action as the head, life as the spine, and death as the rump? Who understands that death and life, existence and extinction, are of a single body? We would befriend such a one." The four looked at one another and smiled, their hearts in perfect accord. They then became friends.

Before long, Ziyu fell ill. Zisi went to inquire after him, saying: "How magnificent! That the Creator would make me like this—so hunched and twisted!" His back was arched, his hair grew upward, five organs protruded from his spine, his chin was tucked into his navel, his shoulders rose above his head, and his neck bones jutted toward the sky. The qi of yin and yang had become disordered, yet his heart remained at ease, untroubled. He hobbled to a well and gazed at his reflection, saying: "Alas! That the Creator would again make me like this—so hunched and twisted!"

Zisi said: "Do you resent it?"

He replied: "Why should I resent it? If, by degrees, the Creator were to transform my left arm into a rooster, I would use it to herald the dawn. If, by degrees, the Creator were to transform my right arm into a crossbow, I would use it to hunt an owl for roasting. If, by degrees, the Creator were to transform my buttocks into a wheel and my spirit into a horse, I would mount them—why ever change steeds?

Moreover, to gain is to meet one’s time; to lose is to follow the flow. Abiding in time and dwelling in flow, sorrow and joy cannot enter. This is what the ancients called ‘suspension and release.’ Yet if one cannot release oneself, things will bind one fast. For long now, things have not prevailed over Heaven—why then should I resent it?"

The *Comprehensive Meaning* states: "Head, spine, and tail are but the beginning and end of all things. All things begin in the formless and end in the formless—their birth and death are but the arising and ceasing of a single thought, the coming and going of a single breath. If one enters the state beyond death and birth, where then does one’s existence reside, if not beyond this seven-foot frame?"

Presently, Zilai fell ill, gasping for breath as if on the verge of death. His wife and children gathered around, weeping. Li went to inquire and shouted: "Away! Do not disturb the transformation!" Leaning against the doorframe, he spoke to Zilai: "How wondrous! The Creator—what will it make of you next? Where will it send you? Will it make you into a mouse’s liver? Or an insect’s arm?"

Zilai replied: "Wherever a child is sent by father and mother—east, west, south, or north—he must follow their command. How can one defy yin and yang, which stand to us as father and mother? If they bring me near death and I refuse to heed, I would be obstinate. What fault would lie with them? The Great Clod burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and reposes me in death. Thus, to treat my life well is to treat my death well.

Now, when the great smith smelts metal, the metal leaps up, crying, ‘I must become a *Mo Ye* sword!’ The smith would surely deem it an inauspicious metal. Yet once it assumes human form and declares, ‘I am a man! I am a man!’—the Creator must surely deem it an inauspicious being. Now, if we take heaven and earth as the great furnace and the Creator as the great smith, where can one go and not be at peace?" Thereupon, Zilai fell into a deep sleep, then awoke as if from a dream.

Guo's Annotation:
"Death and life are but waking and dreaming—by principle, one ought to dream without wishing to be startled awake, for when transformation comes, to rebuke it is to resist in vain. Since ancient times, some may have defied their parents’ commands, yet none have defied the changes of yin and yang or resisted the cycles of day and night. Death and life are no more than day and night, not something to oppose. When the time for death arrives, it is not something to forbid, yet stubbornly refusing to heed it only hastens one’s end through obstinacy. The swiftness of death arises from one’s own defiance, not from death itself. That which calls it ‘death’ exists in life, and thus to treat life well is to treat death well—principle remains constant in both. ‘I am a man! I am a man!’—this wish alone is like the metal leaping in the smelter. The world knows such metal is inauspicious, yet cannot allow it to transform of its own accord. The Dao of transformation encounters nothing it does not meet. Now, when it meets human form, was this done intentionally? Life is not made by design; it arises in its time. To cling to it and claim possession—is this not delusion? All know that metal bound to a purpose is inauspicious. Once one sees that the self is no different from that metal, the attachments of the heart may be untied. Untied, there is nothing that cannot be. ‘Falling into deep sleep, then awaking as if from a dream’—waking and dreaming remain as they are, unburdened by death or life."

Lü's Annotation:
"Mice and insects are what people most despise, and when their qi and form scatter, they become liver or limbs—things even more detested. At such a time, to ask what is despised or detested is to test Zilai’s equanimity. Knowing that yin and yang do not stand to us as father and mother, yet heeding them; knowing that the Great Clod reposes us in death, and thus treating it well—what need is there to ask, ‘What are you? What are you fit for?’ The metal leaping in the smelter is deemed inauspicious, and so too is the human wish to be human. Now, if we take heaven and earth as the furnace and the Creator as the smith, then mouse liver and insect limbs can be formed anywhere without hindrance. ‘Falling into deep sleep, then awaking as if from a dream’—the passage between death and life is as unhurried as waking and dreaming, unchanged by it."

Personal Insight:
"Man exists in the world as one among ten thousand things, and of those called ‘human,’ how many hundreds of millions are there? Why then do you cling to this? Release the stagnant mind and open the vast heart. The metaphor of smelted metal warns that the common fear of death, when inescapable, leads to calculations for future lives—yet even the slightest attachment entangles one for ten thousand kalpas. Like metal leaping in the smelter, it is only by being different that it seeks the *Mo Ye* sword, which cannot be guaranteed. Thus, the perfected person takes heaven and earth as the furnace and the Creator as the smith, moving with boundless transformation. Why must one say, ‘I am a man! I am a man!’ and worry over not attaining it? Observe how the ancients conducted themselves—were they ever constrained by life and death? For they took life as dreaming and death as waking. If death is waking, then what time is not waking?"

Zisang Hu, Mengzi Fan, and Zi Qin Zhang became friends, saying to one another, "Who can join together without joining, act together without acting? Who can ascend to heaven, roam in the mists, twist and turn without end, forgetting one another in life, with no final limit?" The three looked at one another and laughed, their hearts in perfect accord. They became friends.

After some time, Zisang Hu died. Before he was buried, Confucius heard of it and sent Zigong to assist with the rites. One wove a funeral mat, another played the zither, and they sang in harmony:
"Ah, Zisang Hu!
Ah, Zisang Hu!
You have returned to your true nature,
While we remain as men—alas!"

Zigong hurried forward and said, "May I ask if it is proper to sing before the corpse?"

The two looked at each other and laughed, saying, "What does he know of the meaning of ritual?"

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius, saying, "What sort of men are they? They cultivate conduct without form, treat their bodies as external, sing before the corpse without changing countenance—there is no name for them. What sort of men are they?"

Confucius said, "They roam beyond the bounds, while I roam within them. Beyond and within do not meet, yet I sent you to offer condolences—how boorish of me! They are about to join with the Creator as companions, roaming as one with heaven and earth. To them, life is an excrescent wen, death the bursting of a sore. How could they know the precedence of death and life? Borrowing from different things, lodging in the same body, they forget their livers and gallbladders, discard their ears and eyes, reversing and circling without beginning or end, wandering in confusion beyond the dust and grime, carefree in the realm of the unbounded."

The work of non-action—how could they be muddled into performing worldly rites to display before the eyes and ears of the multitude?

Zigong said, "Then upon what Way does the Master rely?"
Confucius said, "I am one of Heaven’s punished people. Yet though this be so, I share it with you."
Zigong said, "May I ask about its method?"
Confucius said, "Do fish create one another in water, or do men create one another in the Way? Water, by carving out pools, nourishes and sustains them—do they create one another? The Way, by doing nothing, gives rise to constancy. Thus it is said: Do fish forget one another in rivers and lakes? Do men forget one another in the arts of the Way?"

Zigong said, "May I ask about the extraordinary person?"
Confucius said, "The extraordinary person is extraordinary among men yet equal to Heaven. Thus it is said: Heaven’s petty man is man’s noble man; man’s noble man is Heaven’s petty man."

[To toy and tease, to trace the root—it is but play.]

Guo’s commentary:
Those who embody Heaven and Earth and guard against change—though their limbs serve different functions and their five viscera govern distinct conduits—never act in concert, yet all joints harmonize as one. This is to be in concert through non-concert. Never acting for one another, yet inner and outer both attain fulfillment—this is to act for one another through non-action. If one instead employs the mind’s intent to care for the limbs, or moves the thighs and arms to manage the viscera, the more one strives to nurture, the more inner and outer become exhausted. Thus, those who take all under Heaven as one body harbor no partial love within it. To toy and tease without limit is to be capable of all tasks. Forgetting life, one forgets all things—thus able to follow change and respond to transformation without end. Those who gaze at one another and laugh, their hearts in perfect accord, entrust clarity to the most intimate yet harbor no affectionate attachment. To weep when others weep is the mark of the conventional; to equalize life and death, forget sorrow and joy, and sing before the corpse is the aspiration of those beyond the bounds.

Those who know ritual and propriety must wander beyond to order within, guard the mother to preserve the child, and follow the promptings of their nature with straightforwardness. If one instead vaunts reputation, is bound by appearances, then filial piety cannot bear sincerity, nor kindness bear substance—father and son, elder and younger brother, harboring feelings, deceive one another. Is this the great meaning of ritual? Ritual has its ultimate extreme, where inner and outer merge—there has never been one who attained the utmost in wandering beyond yet failed to merge within, nor one who merged within yet failed to wander beyond. Thus the sage constantly wanders beyond to refine within, uses no mind to accord with things. Though all day long he moves his form, his spirit and countenance remain unchanged; though he bends and rises amid ten thousand affairs, he is serene and self-possessed.

To see the form yet not reach the spirit—this is the common burden of the world. Thus, when one sees him walking alongside the myriad things, none can say he has abandoned things and departed from men. When one observes him embodying transformation and responding to things, none can say he sits in forgetfulness and attains self-possession. How could it be only the sage who is not thus? Yet some must insist that the ultimate principle lacks this. Therefore, Zhuangzi, wishing to clarify the lineage of the flowing unity and awaken the world’s understanding, did not directly attribute such qualities to Confucius. Had he done so, some would have relied on their own views to reject it. Thus he transcended the sage’s inner traces and entrusted the realm beyond the bounds to those several masters. If one forgets what he has entrusted and seeks the great meaning of his composition, then the Way of wandering beyond to refine within lies open and clear, and Zhuangzi’s book is indeed discourse that transcends the vulgar and surpasses the age.

Offering condolences is a proximate affair of the bounded realm. Applied to those beyond the bounds, it is boorish. Those who roam as one with Heaven and Earth’s single qi are all merged in it—there is no duality. To take life as an excrescent wen—this is the temporary gathering of qi, not what they delight in. To take death as the bursting of a sore—this is the qi’s natural dispersal, not what they regret. Life and death alternate without beginning or end; going along with them, there is no going that is not acceptable. Thus they do not know where victory or defeat lies. Life and death, gathering and dispersal, transformation without direction—all are different things. Yet there is no difference that is not borrowed; what is borrowed, though different, together forms one body. Thus they forget their livers and gallbladders, discard their ears and eyes, entrust themselves to principle and merge with the flowing, forgetting even the viscera—what thing is worth recognizing? Never having begun to recognize, they release their bodies onto the path of transformation, darkly one with the waves of reversal, not knowing where beginning or end lies.

The work of non-action is not mere folded-hands silence. The realm beyond the dust and grime is not seclusion in mountains and forests. What they display before the multitude is all dust and grime—it is not the merging with things beyond the bounds. Zigong did not hear of nature and Heaven’s Way, so he saw what they relied upon but not the reason for their reliance. That upon which they rely is non-reliance—how could the world perceive this?

Those who punish the people treat the realm within the bounds as shackles—what they esteem lies beyond the bounds. Yet those who roam beyond depend on what is within, and those who depart from humanity conform to custom. Thus, those who possess the world do not take the world as their possession. Only by relinquishing things can one enter the multitude; only by sitting in forgetfulness can one respond to affairs. The more one relinquishes, the more one attains. Should one abide in this ultimate state, even if one wished to cast it aside, principle would inevitably return of itself—this is what neither heaven nor humanity can absolve.

Though my words to you are but shackles of the world, they are shared with you alone. My illumination has ever dwelt beyond. Humans and fish differ in their attainments, yet both proceed from non-affair to affair, from beyond the bounds to within, and only then are nourished and sustained in life’s constancy—none are not thus. Each is self-sufficient and mutually forgetful.

To roam beyond while darkly merging with what is within, to entrust the spontaneity of the myriad things, allowing each to fulfill its heavenly nature—this is how the Dao of emperors and kings is accomplished. Such is to stand apart from humanity yet equal heaven. In terms of spontaneity, there is no small or great among humans; in terms of human principle, those who equal heaven may be called *junzi*.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
To be with one another in non-being-with, to act for one another in non-acting—this is the place of returning to the root and recovering destiny. Ascending to heaven, one reaches the heights of great clarity; roaming in mist, one enters the gate of profound obscurity. Thus, stirring and probing without end, one finds no final exhaustion. For those who take returning to the real as joy, singing before the corpse is only fitting.

The former kings established rites to balance likes and dislikes and restore the rectitude of the human Dao. Was not taking joy in returning to the real the very intent of ritual? Roaming beyond the bounds, one becomes a companion of heaven—thus, to take death as joy is no cause for sorrow. Roaming within the bounds, one becomes a companion of humanity—thus, to take death as sorrow leaves no room for joy. If three such persons were to take death as joy, those who double death and forget life would be many. Without these three, one remains entangled between life and death, unable to untie the knot—this is what the perfected ones lament.

The aspirations of inner and outer differ, and thus they do not intersect. Confucius sent Zigong to offer condolences, wishing him to grasp the intent of ritual, which does not lie in the passions of nature and destiny, for the world’s subtlest principles are not confined within ritual and law. Roaming freely...

The qi of heaven and earth is neither yin nor yang. To take life as an excrescent growth, a hanging tumor, is to treat life as loss and indulge in it; to take death as the bursting of a tumor, the draining of an abscess, is to treat death as return and rejoice in it. Borrowing from other things, entrusting to the same body—these are not taken as real, like liver and gall, ears and eyes. When these are forgotten and abandoned, one cycles through beginning and end without knowing their bounds—how then could one be bound by the rites of the vulgar world?

Confucius, though roaming within the bounds, extolled the loftiness of those beyond. Zigong doubted that even while roaming within, his reliance might not lie there—for what one roams are traces, while what one relies upon is the heart. The "punishment of heaven" speaks of celestial penalties that cannot be undone. But Confucius embodied his nature, embraced the spirit, and roamed through the vulgar world—what reliance could burden his heart? Thus, though he roamed within the bounds, he need not go beyond; though he endured heaven’s punishment, he need not undo it.

He further drew an analogy with fish: digging a pond to provide sustenance does not require vast waters. To live without affairs and attain stillness does not require roaming beyond. To forget one another in rivers and lakes is not merely about digging ponds; to forget one another in the Dao and its arts is not merely about being without affairs. The eccentric who matches heaven does so by being external rather than internal.

The petty man of heaven is the noble man of humanity—these are they who are meticulous in ritual and law yet ignorant of the passions of nature and destiny.

Yan Hui asked Confucius, saying, "When Mengsun Cai’s mother died, he wept without tears, his heart felt no sorrow, and in mourning he showed no grief. Yet for these three absences, he was praised for his mastery of mourning—could it be that in the state of Lu there truly are those who lack the substance yet attain the name?"

Hui found this strange. Confucius replied, "Mengsun has indeed exhausted it—he has advanced beyond knowledge. He has simplified, yet cannot further simplify, for he has already simplified himself.

Mengsun does not know why he lives, does not know why he dies; does not know why to follow what comes before, does not know why to follow what comes after. If he has transformed into a thing, does he await the transformations he does not yet know? Moreover, as he is about to transform, how could he know what is not yet transformed? As he is about to remain untransformed, how could he know what has already transformed? You and I are but dreamers who have never yet awakened.

Furthermore, he may take on a startling form, yet his heart suffers no harm; he may dwell in a morning abode, yet death holds no emotion. Mengsun alone is awake—others weep, and so he weeps. This is simply what is fitting for him, and nothing more. We are together in this, are we not?

How could you know what I call ‘I’? You may dream of being a bird and soaring to the heavens, or of being a fish and sinking into the abyss—how can you tell whether these words now spoken are from one awake or one still dreaming? When one attains what is fitting, laughter does not follow; when one offers laughter, it does not dispel sorrow. At ease with change, he departs—thus he enters the vast emptiness and becomes one with heaven.

Guo’s commentary: In Lu, they observed his ritual; Yan Hui examined his heart. He had fully grasped the principle of life and death, responding to inner and outer with the movement of heaven—no knowledge can match this. Thus it is said he advanced beyond knowledge. He discerned life and death yet found no difference between them, as the four seasons proceed in their course. Having simplified and found nothing to reject, he was at ease in all things. At ease in all things, he did not let life and death weigh upon his mind but entrusted himself to spontaneous transformation. Life and death, turning and turning, become one with transformation—how could he forget what he knows in the present and fret over what he does not yet know? Having transformed and come to life, he knows the time before birth; about to transform and die, he knows the time after death. Thus he avoids nothing, follows nothing, and lives in accord with transformation.

Death and life are but waking and dreaming. If one dreams and takes it for waking, there is no way to prove that waking is not dreaming. If there is no way to prove that waking is not dreaming, then there is no way to prove that life is not death. Where do death and life, waking and dreaming truly lie? In whatever one encounters, there is nothing that is not self-possessed—why grieve over this and worry over that?

‘Startling form yet heart unharmed’ means that changes in form may shock the eye, yet they do not burden the heart with life and death. ‘Morning abode yet death without emotion’ means that the body’s transformations are like a dwelling renewed each day, yet the heart does not take them as death. The ever-awake man meets nothing with resistance, so when others weep, he weeps—this is simply what is fitting for him.

Life, death, and transformation are all my own—since all are from me, what have I lost? Never having lost myself, what cause for sorrow? Without resistance, when others weep, he weeps; without sorrow, he weeps yet feels no grief. Nothing is not myself.

Thus the mysterious unites inner and outer, pervades past and present, and daily renews with transformation—how could one know where the self resides? Dreaming of being a bird, dreaming of being a fish—this shows that in all things, one is self-possessed. The transformations of waking and dreaming are boundless, so the changes of life and death are likewise nothing to regret.

Wherever one arrives is fitting, and so one forgets what is fitting. Thus one does not laugh in time; when laughter is offered, it does not dispel sorrow. Grief and joy linger in the heart, and one cannot move with what is fitting. But Mengsun was always at ease, so he wept without grief and moved with transformation. At peace with change, he departed with it—thus he entered stillness and became one with heaven.

From this point up to Zisi, their attainment is the same; only their outward mourning differs, so their songs and weeping are not alike."

Lü’s commentary: Only one who knows that things have never truly existed sees no difference between inner and outer, life and death—why must one roam beyond the world and take death as joy, even singing before the corpse? Thus, in mourning, his weeping is the same as others’, yet he is not burdened by sorrow and grief—this is how he differs from others. This is illustrated through Mengsun Cai to show that the utmost attainment does not depart from the common customs of the world.

Life is as it is, death is as it is, weeping is as it is—though one may wish to simplify, one cannot. Those three masters, though they did not know where life, death, and existence reside, took life as mourning and death as returning—this was not truly knowing why one lives or why one dies. Taking the return to the real as joy and being admired by others—this was not truly following what comes before or what comes after.

Mengsun did not know why he lived or why he died, so in life he lost nothing, and in death he returned to nothing. Not following what comes before or what comes after, death held no joy for him, and life held no cause for admiration. Not only was this so, but he transformed into a thing, awaiting the transformations he did not yet know—and even he did not know them.

As he is about to transform, how could he know what is not yet transformed? As he is about to remain untransformed, how could he know what has already transformed? You and I are but dreamers who have never yet awakened.

He has a human form, so his form may startle, yet his heart is unmoved—thus it suffers no harm. Life and death are like night and day—thus he has a morning abode, yet death holds no emotion. This is why Mengsun alone is awake.

Only by knowing this does one weep when others weep, without tears or grief—this is simply what is fitting for him, and nothing to wonder at. You may now dream of being a bird or a fish, yet not know you are dreaming—how can you tell whether these words now spoken are from one awake or one dreaming? This clarifies that Mengsun had forgotten himself and alone was awake.

What is fitting is what one attains, not what one naturally possesses—thus one does not laugh in time. Laughter is what one offers, not what brings joy—thus one does not dispel sorrow in time. ‘Dispelling’ means to cast off sorrow and depart. Mengsun’s forgetting of life and death cannot be attained or offered. At ease with change, he knew it could not be resisted and followed it. Stillness is without obstruction; heaven is without attachment; oneness is without duality—the Dao is fully realized here."

Xun’s edition: "Advancing beyond knowledge" means surpassing knowledge of mourning rites. "Simplifying" means reducing. Those who study the Dao wish only to reduce their emotions, yet cannot—Mengsun had already reduced his.

"In the higher transformation, one becomes things—this refers to those already transformed. In the lower transformation, one is oneself—this refers to those not yet transformed. The transformations one does not know are those of oneself, the transformations one does not self-know are those that have reached one’s own body.

If one were to assume that those who died earlier transformed into things to await those not yet transformed whom they do not know—then how could those who are dead and about to transform know those who have not yet transformed? And how could those who are alive and about to remain untransformed know those who have already transformed?

Now, your use of *er* and *ru* (informal pronouns) corresponds to the lower *wu* (I/me). Parents are one’s kin; others may be addressed as *er* and *ru*. Mengsun merely noticed others weeping and wept along—his weeping arose not from within but from those he addressed as *er* and *ru*, treating his kin as if they were others’ kin.

From this, the term *wu* (I/me) arises below. Suppose Confucius were to say: ‘Moreover, Yan Hui and I do not compare to Mengsun, who regards his kin as others, addressing them as *wu*.’ Yet how can we be certain that what we call *wu* is truly so?

Thus, I clarify with the distinction between dream and waking: merely dreaming of becoming a fish or bird is not strange. But to dream of being a bird and flying straight to heaven, or of being a fish and diving deep into the abyss—clearly, one’s body is that fish or bird. Yet now, here in speech, how do we know this present moment is waking? Perhaps it is still a dream. From this perspective, what we call *wu* is truly unknowable.

Earlier, I said, ‘I alone am with you and have never awakened.’ Now I say, ‘Awakening may also be a dream’—this is a deeper level of attainment.

*Shi* (fitting) means contentment. Those who rejoice must laugh, but those who suddenly attain contentment harbor true joy and do not wait for laughter to feel at ease. *Xian xiao* (offering laughter) means suddenly offering one’s own laughter.

*Arranging* means disposition. Those who offer their own laughter do so unconsciously, unable to arrange it—this illustrates natural spontaneity, unconstrained by adherence to ritual and norms.

*At ease with change and departing* continues the above *pai* (arranging): life’s wealth, honor, poverty, and lowliness each have their destined allotment, like the Creator’s arrangement. One should simply accept it. Death is transformation—no more. *Liao* (stillness) conveys vast emptiness; *one* refers to the state before the Great Ultimate divided. Entering *liao*, heaven returns to its origin.

---

Yi’erzi saw Xu You, who asked, ‘How has Yao aided you?’

Yi’erzi replied, ‘Yao told me, “You must personally practice benevolence and righteousness and clearly distinguish right and wrong.”’

Xu You said, ‘Then why have you come? Yao has already branded you with benevolence and righteousness and mutilated you with right and wrong. How will you wander the boundless, carefree, and ever-shifting paths?’

Yi’erzi said, ‘Though so, I wish to wander their outskirts.’

Xu You said, ‘No. The blind cannot appreciate the beauty of brows and eyes; the blind cannot appreciate the patterns of blue and yellow embroidery.’

Yi’erzi said, ‘Wu Zhuang lost her beauty, Ju Liang lost his strength, and the Yellow Emperor lost his knowledge—all within the crucible and hammer. How do we know the Creator will not cease branding me, mend my mutilation, and let me ride completion to follow you, Master?’

Xu You said, ‘Alas, it cannot be known! Let me speak of the general principle. My Master! My Master! He bears the myriad things yet is not righteous; his blessings reach all generations yet he is not benevolent. He is older than high antiquity yet is not aged; he covers and supports heaven and earth, carves and shapes all forms yet is not skillful—this is the realm in which one wanders.

Destroying the Dao to make benevolence and righteousness is like branding; breaking the profound unity to make right and wrong is like mutilation. *Zisui* (carefree) describes the appearance of self-contentment. *Fan* (outskirts) means boundary.

*Wutongzi* (no pupil) is called *mang* (blind); *you tongzi* (having a pupil) is called *gu* (blind). *Ji* means broken.’

---

Guo’s commentary:
*Resource* means to supply and aid. *Branding with benevolence and righteousness, mutilating with right and wrong*—this speaks of self-injury through teaching by form, unable to return to the realm of self-contentment or the path without constraints.

*Wandering their outskirts* means not daring to seek the middle way, only wishing to wander near the boundary. Not all things in the world necessarily complete themselves; the principle of spontaneity sometimes requires smelting and forging to become vessels. Thus, Wu Zhuang, Ju Liang, and the Yellow Emperor all heard the Dao yet later lost what they pursued.

These are all figurative words to dispel the burdens of action. Following one’s nature directly is spontaneity. Going forth and harming one’s nature, yet able to change, is also spontaneity. How do we know that my spontaneity will not cease branding and mend mutilation, letting me ride the completed Dao to follow you, Master? To abandon and not tell you would perhaps not be the Creator’s ultimate intent.

*Ji* (bearing) the myriad things—all is thus of itself, with no love intervening. Where is benevolence and righteousness lodged? Not aged—daily renewed. Not skillful—natural. *This is the realm in which one wanders*—wandering in non-action and learning from the teacherless.

---

Lü’s commentary:
The great thoroughfare of the Dao is the boundless, carefree, and ever-shifting path. Wu Zhuang was naturally beautiful yet burdened by beauty; Ju Liang relied on strength yet was burdened by strength. The Yellow Emperor fasted in mind and served in form to return to non-knowing—yet initially could not avoid using knowledge.

The crucible is for smelting, the hammer for forging. These three lost their burdens not because their natures lacked them, but because of smelting and forging. How do we know the Creator will not cease branding, mend mutilation, and let me ride the completed mind to follow the Master’s non-action?

*Ji* (bearing) the myriad things, older than high antiquity, carving and shaping all forms—this is what I wander and take as my teacher. If you wish to cease branding and mend mutilation, take this as your teacher.

---

Yan Hui said, ‘I have advanced.’

Zhongni asked, ‘What do you mean?’

‘I have forgotten benevolence and righteousness.’

‘Good, but not yet sufficient.’

Another day, they met again.

‘I have advanced.’

‘What do you mean?’

‘I have forgotten ritual and music.’

‘Good, but not yet sufficient.’

Another day, they met again.

‘I have advanced.’

‘What do you mean?’

‘I sit in forgetfulness.’

Zhongni started and asked, ‘What is sitting in forgetfulness?’

Yan Hui said, ‘I cast off my limbs, dismiss my intelligence, leave my form, abandon knowledge, and merge with the Great Thoroughfare—this is called sitting in forgetfulness.’

Zhongni said, ‘Merged, you have no preferences; transformed, you have no constancy. You are truly worthy! I ask to follow after you.’

---

Guo’s commentary:
*I have advanced*—taking reduction as advancement. *Benevolence* is the trace of universal love; *righteousness* is the function of completing things. Love is not benevolence; benevolence is the trace of its practice.

The completion of things is not righteousness—righteousness is but the manifestation of its function. To preserve benevolence and righteousness is insufficient to understand the source of love and benefit. Without intent, forgetting them is permissible. Yet merely forgetting their traces is still not profound attainment. Ritual is the function of the body; music is the instrument of joyful life. To forget the instrument is not as good as forgetting that which makes the instrument possible.

What does sitting in forgetfulness not forget? Having forgotten the traces, one further forgets that which produces the traces. Internally, one is no longer aware of one’s own body; externally, one no longer knows there is heaven and earth. Then, vast and unobstructed, one merges with transformation as one’s very substance, and there is nothing that is not penetrated.

When nothing is not the same, there is never not suitability. Never not suitable—how could there be preferences or aversions? To be one with transformation is to follow only what transformation suits, and thus there is no constancy.

*Detailed Explanation of the Dao:*
If you take the sea as the hundred rivers, you see the rivers but not the sea. If you gather the hundred rivers into the sea, you see the sea but not the rivers. The Dao is the sea; benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music are the rivers. Yan Hui attained the Dao and forgot benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music—this is seeing the sea and forgetting the rivers, yet he still had not forgotten the Dao. When one leaves form and forgets things, abandons knowledge and forgets the mind, resting serenely without entanglement, where then is the Dao? It is forgotten along with oneself—this is why Yan Hui was truly worthy.

Righteousness is close to ritual; benevolence is close to music. Thus, forgetting righteousness precedes forgetting ritual, and forgetting benevolence precedes forgetting music. Yan Hui’s forgetting still had something not forgotten, and his advancement lay in what is called "reduction." Not forgetting what should be forgotten, one returns to sincerity. Reduce again and again, until there is no reduction—without attaining the subtlety of sitting in forgetfulness, how could one reach this?

*Lü’s Commentary:*
That by which one is human has been long established. Though awakening to the Dao may occur in a single moment of speech, returning to the absence of things is not the work of a day. Yan Hui heard of fasting the mind and, before there was ever a Yan Hui, awakened to the Dao in a single word. Yet his progress through benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, and finally sitting in forgetfulness was not the accumulation of a day. To be the same is to regard things as one, and thus have no preferences. To transform is to have no end. With no constancy, one is the same as the Great Thoroughfare—this is to be one with transformation.

Ziyu and Zisang were friends. When continuous rain fell for ten days, Ziyu said, "Zisang must be in dire straits." He wrapped rice and went to feed him. Arriving at Zisang’s door, he heard sounds like singing, like weeping, as Zisang plucked his zither. He sang, "Father? Mother? Heaven? Man? The voice cannot bear it!" and hurriedly recited his poem. Ziyu entered and asked, "Why do you sing your poem like this?"

Zisang said, "I pondered who brought me to this extremity but found no answer. How could my parents wish me to be poor? Heaven covers all without partiality; earth bears all without partiality. How could heaven and earth single me out for poverty? I sought the one who caused this but could not find it. Yet here I am at this extremity—it is fate!"

*Guo’s Commentary:*
These two acted for one another without acting for one another. Now, wrapping rice and going to feed him was simply following the principle of heaven and acting spontaneously—not acting for one another and then going. Why act like this? It was to avoid the appearance of sentiment, to hasten out and distance oneself from such reasoning. "It is fate"—this means all things are naturally so, without any doer.

*Lü’s Commentary:*
Zhuangzi discussed the great ancestral master, concluding with Mengsun Cai and Yan Hui, taking Confucius as one who embodied nature and held to spirit to wander through the world, and thus as the ultimate. Yet he feared that scholars might think Zisang’s followers inferior to Mengsun’s, and Ziyu’s followers inferior to Zisang’s, so he combined them for discussion. Their words all reach the point of fate and resting in it. Though the traces of these masters differ, in taking the Dao as the great ancestral master and reaching fate, they are one.

*General Observations:*
The ancestral master is what scholars uphold and revere—prefixed with "great," like saying "the father of all fathers." First, he discusses knowing heaven and knowing man, clarifying rightness and fate to establish the foundation. Then he speaks of the true person and true knowledge, who sleeps without dreaming and wakes without worry. People love their fathers and are loyal to their lords, yet still die for them—how much more so for those who are eminently true?

The value of the true lies in its reverence for the mandate, surpassing even that for a lord or father, yet the world is ignorant of this. Panting, spitting, and licking are not as good as forgetting one another in rivers and lakes. The great clod bears form, lets the old rest, and accepts death—this is the goodness of creation in shaping my form. Yet people often cling to life and fear death, so he sets forth the metaphors of hiding the boat in the ravine and hiding the mountain in the marsh to dispel their delusions. All that has form and life is bound to vanish, though ravines and marshes be deep and secure—how can they escape? Only by hiding the world within the world can one be without vanishing.

This is where the sage wanders, where transformation awaits. Born of heaven, born of earth, myriad transformations yet without beginning—why cling to the human form and secretly rejoice in it? Living in high antiquity without aging, ascending to the cloudy heavens and dwelling in the dark palace—these are the wondrous uses of the true person. The great ancestral master embodies this as the foundation, and the people and things of the world rely on it as their destiny.

Nü Yu’s "no past, no present" means life and death cannot bind him. Si Lai’s "no opposition, mutual friendship" means things and self cannot separate him. Thus, whether left in difficulty or right in ease, whether spirit horses or rump wheels, he listens to the transformation of creation and rests wherever he encounters it—this is what the ancients called "suspended release." Why trouble over insect arms or rat livers, or foolishly arouse doubts of smelting and forging?

Zifan, Qin Zhang, and Cheng sang to mourn Sang Hu, taking toil in the world as labor and friendship with the true as fortune—these wanderers beyond the world differ from the common. They roam with creation as their companion, so longevity and early death, poverty and success do not exhaust their transformations; heaven and earth, cold and heat cannot constrain their bodies.

Mengsun Cai was startled by form but unharmed in mind, dreaming of fish and birds, ascending to heaven and sinking into the abyss, at peace with momentary transformation. How could form intervene to alter his feelings? Yanzi cast off his body, dismissed his intelligence, sat in forgetfulness, and reached the ultimate—entering the cave of principle, continuing the lineage of the sage’s gate, truly the power of the master’s transformation.

As for Zisang, plucking his zither, singing and weeping, seeking the one who caused this but finding nothing, ultimately attributing it to fate—the true person, having attained the Dao, transcends fate, and worldly entanglements cannot bind him. What is called true knowledge is the thorough investigation of heaven and man, the unobstructed understanding of nature and fate without doubt.

Exhausting principle and fulfilling nature to reach fate is, in terms of self-cultivation, fate. Governing the transformations of things and preserving their origin is, in terms of ruling things, fate. Zisang exemplifies the former.

The command of things’ fate—is it not the great宗师 alone?

**Chapter Seven: Responding as Emperor**

Guo’s Commentary: *"To be without mind and yield to self-transformation—this is how one responds as emperor. Following this principle, this chapter expounds the application of responding as emperor. If an emperor awakens to this, he returns to the age of Grand Antiquity. Thus, the Inner Chapters conclude here."*

Nie Que questioned Wang Ni four times, and four times Wang Ni replied that he did not know. Nie Que leapt up in great joy and went to tell Master Puyi. Master Puyi said, *"Now you have finally understood! The Lord of Yu did not equal the Lord of Tai. The Lord of Yu concealed virtue to entice men—thus he gained men, yet never transcended the realm of the unhuman. The Lord of Tai slept in tranquil ease, awoke in carefree simplicity, now took himself for a horse, now for an ox. His knowledge was sincere, his virtue utterly genuine, and he never entered the realm of the unhuman."*

Guo’s Commentary: *"The Lord of Yu and the Lord of Tai were but traces of worldly affairs, not the source of traces. The source of traces is traceless. Who in the world names it? Never having been named, what victory or defeat could there be? Thus, riding the transformations of the multitude, treading the myriad ages, the world has its level paths and perilous ones, and traces may fall short. Those who take what they love as right and what others detest as wrong—those who make right and wrong their domain—are such. One who can depart from the domain of the unhuman must enter the realm where there is no unhuman. Thus, there is no gain, no loss, no right, no wrong. How could it be merely concealing virtue to entice men? To be horse or ox—what right or wrong of man is there in that? Entrusting to self-knowledge, his sincerity is trusted; entrusting to self-attainment, nothing he does enters the domain of right and wrong. This is how he cuts off the age of the Lord of Yu."*

Lü’s Commentary: *"The four questions—‘Do you know what things share as right?’ ‘Do you know what you do not know?’ ‘Then are things without knowledge?’ ‘What is called knowing—is it not non-knowing? What is called non-knowing—is it not knowing?’—Wang Ni answered all with ‘I do not know.’ What things share as right is limited to what one does not know. Wang Ni’s ‘not knowing’ is true not-knowing, embodied in practice. ‘Yu’ also means ‘anxious concern,’ and ‘Tai’ means ‘great stability.’ To have knowledge and be anxious is not as good as to be without knowledge and be greatly stable. The traces of the Lord of Yu still concealed virtue to entice men, and men followed him—thus he gained men. Yet to take concealed virtue as right and approve of it is not free from taking the absence of virtue as wrong and disapproving of it. This is never to depart from the unhuman. There is man and unhuman, confused and chaotic. The Lord of Tai slept in tranquil ease, awoke in carefree simplicity, took himself for horse or ox, and none found fault with him. Thus, his knowledge was trusted without doubt, his virtue genuine without pretense. How could he know the wrong of the unhuman and enter its realm? From Wang Ni’s perspective, it is clear that the Lord of Yu did not equal the Lord of Tai. ‘Did not equal’ refers to his traces. The Lord of Tai is the source of the Lord of Yu’s traces. To attain the source of traces, one must release the mind, free the spirit, and deeply enter the realm of Wang Ni’s ‘not knowing.’"*

Following the Source: *"The Lord of Yu harbored and concealed the Dao of virtue to entice and bind men’s hearts—thus he also gained men. Yet this still arose from human artifice, not as good as the unhuman, where one is together without being together. Thus it is said, ‘never departed from the unhuman.’ In high antiquity, the Lord of Tai rested naturally, without contrivance. Sometimes he took himself for a horse, sometimes for an ox, with no fixed name. This was because the Lord of Tai’s knowledge was truly sincere, his virtue utterly genuine, unlike the Lord of Yu, who concealed virtue to entice men. Yet this was not intentional, thus it is said, ‘never entered the unhuman.’ The phrase ‘never departed’ gives rise to ‘never entered.’"*

Jingchuan: *"This says that Shun still acted with intention. Yu arose from the human Dao, not from the Heavenly Dao. ‘Never entered the unhuman’—the Lord of Tai’s accord with the Heavenly Dao was spontaneous and uncontrived."*

Personal Insight: *"True knowledge is non-knowledge, thus it can be without non-knowledge. The Dao of emperors and kings especially requires forgetting knowledge to entrust things, letting the keen-eared listen, the clear-sighted see, the wise plan, the brave defend. I, however, sit upright and bring about governance through non-action. Is this not grand? The Dao accords with Heaven, and men return to it—this is the primary meaning of ‘responding as emperor.’"*

Jian Wu saw the madman Jie Yu. Jie Yu said, "What did Ri Zhongshi tell you?"
Jian Wu replied, "He told me that those who rule men must issue their own canons, models, principles, and measures—who would dare not listen and be transformed?"

Jie Yu said, "This is deceitful virtue. In governing the world, it is like fording the sea or dredging a river and making a mosquito carry a mountain. The governance of the sage does not proceed by rectifying others but first acts beyond rectification, then entrusts affairs to those capable of them. Moreover, birds fly high to avoid the harm of arrows and nets, and field mice burrow deep beneath sacred mounds to escape the peril of fumigation and digging. Yet you deem these two creatures devoid of knowledge!"

Guo’s Annotation: *"Deceitful virtue means imposing one’s own standards on things, causing them to lose their true nature. If one entrusts matters to the myriad things, affairs will be accomplished without effort; but if one seeks to govern the world with a single body, no task will be completed, and the burden will be unbearable. Thus, the sage’s governance consists in preserving what lies within each being’s proper sphere and rectifying their natures and lives—nothing more. They do not attempt what they cannot. Moreover, even birds and beasts each have their own means of survival. If emperors and kings entrust matters to them without interference, all will naturally come to fruition. Have you not even attained the level of these two creatures, who preserve themselves without needing instruction?"*

*Bisheng*: *"Ri Zhongshi was a man’s name. Canons, models, principles, and measures are all means to rectify others, yet they depart from inherent nature and thus are called deceitful virtue. Fording the sea will surely lead to drowning; dredging a river is difficult to accomplish; making a mosquito carry a mountain is beyond its capacity. Governing the world with deceitful virtue is no different. The sage’s governance does not proceed by rectifying others but by allowing self-governance to unfold naturally. Thus it is said, ‘acts beyond rectification and then entrusts affairs to those capable.’ They earnestly fulfill the capacities of their natures and lives—nothing more. The capacities of natures and lives mean that I practice non-action, and the people rectify themselves."*

Tian Gen wandered to the south of Yin, arriving at the banks of the Liaoshui. There he encountered the Nameless Man and asked him, "May I inquire how to govern the world?"
The Nameless Man said, "Begone, you vulgar man! Why do you ask so inopportunely? I am about to become a companion to the Creator. If I grow weary, I will ride the bird of boundless vastness to soar beyond the six directions and wander in the land of Nothing Whatever, dwelling in the wild expanse of open emptiness. Why do you trouble my heart with governing the world?"

He then added, "Let your mind wander in blandness, harmonize your qi with stillness, follow things as they are, and make no room for selfishness—thus the world will be governed."

Guo’s Annotation: *"To ask about governing the world is not to transcend the Great Beginning and abide in the mysterious darkness. To become a companion to the Creator is to allow things to act on their own. The ‘bird of boundless vastness’ refers to the scattered and fragmentary. Riding the fragmentary to gallop through the myriad things, one can come and go freely, roaming in the realm of self-attainment. It is not governance but self-governance. To wander the mind in blandness is to follow one’s nature without adornment. To harmonize qi with stillness is to rest in quiescence, abiding in one’s nature. To follow things without selfishness is to govern the world by allowing things to arise naturally. The mind’s desire to augment is selfishness. Selfishness is truly insufficient to generate life, while following the public preserves all."*

Lü’s Annotation: *"The Nameless Man is one who embodies the Dao. Those who embody the Dao have no preferences or aversions—here he speaks of joy and weariness as if they were the same as others’. When joyful, he becomes a companion to the Creator; when weary, he rides the bird of boundless vastness to soar beyond the six directions. Why? For such a person, existence and nonexistence lie within themselves; their comings and goings leave no trace. Who would take governing the world as their concern? Why do you trouble his heart with governing the world? To wander the mind in blandness, harmonize qi with stillness, follow things as they are, and make no room for selfishness—this is the way to govern the world without effort."*

*Bisheng*: *"‘Inopportunely’ means that if one acts with foresight in all matters, one will succeed. To act with foresight is to place oneself before governing the world, and thus one will fall behind. To become a companion to the Creator is to move with transformation without aiding it. Riding the boundless vastness to soar beyond the six directions is to traverse the void and tread the subtle, transcending yin and yang. Wandering in the land of Nothing Whatever and dwelling in the open emptiness is to reside in the realm of the Dao, the domain of empty sameness. This is the way of foresight, yet he still does not awaken to it, so he further clarifies it in plain words. To wander the mind is to be carefree and return to utmost stillness. Thus it is said, ‘wander the mind in blandness.’ To harmonize qi is to breathe deeply and return to utmost emptiness. Thus it is said, ‘harmonize qi with stillness.’ These are all to follow things as they are without imposing oneself upon them. Thus the world is governed. Indeed, to have no intention of governing the world yet to embody the way of governing the world—nothing is more wondrous than this."*

Yang Ziju saw Lao Dan and said, "Here is a man who responds swiftly, is strong and resolute, sees through things, and studies the Dao tirelessly. Can such a one be compared to an enlightened king?"
Lao Dan said, "In the eyes of the sage, such a man is like a petty functionary, bound by skill, ensnared by technique, laboring his body and startling his mind. Moreover, the patterns of tigers and leopards attract hunters, the agility of monkeys and apes leads to their capture, and the leaping of raccoon dogs brings them to the leash. Can such a one be compared to an enlightened king?"

Yang Ziju, startled, said, "May I ask about the governance of an enlightened king?"
Lao Dan said, "The governance of an enlightened king: his achievements cover the world yet seem not his own; he transforms and bestows upon the myriad things, yet the people do not rely on him. No name is raised, and things delight in themselves. He stands in the unfathomable and wanders in Nothingness."

Guo’s Annotation: *"Bound by skill, ensnared by technique, laboring the body and startling the mind—such efforts cannot secure one’s place, let alone compare to a sage-king. Tigers, leopards, monkeys, and raccoon dogs are all ensnared by their patterns and skills, not riding the void to master the boundless. If the world had no enlightened king, none could attain self-attainment. To cause self-attainment is truly the work of an enlightened king. Yet this work lies in non-action, returning the task to the world. When the world all attains self-mastery, it seems not the work of the enlightened king. The enlightened king fulfills the natures of things, so each person says, ‘I am thus of myself,’ without knowing they rely on the enlightened king. Though his achievements cover the world, he does not claim them as his own. Thus, things all believe they have attained themselves and rejoice. To stand in the unfathomable is to dwell in the path of transformation, daily renewing without fixed direction. To wander in Nothingness is to be one body with the myriad things, so what one wanders in is emptiness. If one cannot merge with things, one will be at odds with them and have no leisure to wander in emptiness."*

The Lü commentary states: Those who hasten toward affairs with urgency act with brute force, not overcoming things through softness. Those who penetrate all things do so not through knowing, but by guarding against knowledge—yet this is not the source of true clarity. One who studies the Dao without weariness has not yet reached the point of daily diminution to embody the Dao. To possess some skill is to labor the body; to bind the mind to some attachment is to startle the heart. This is like the mutual exchange of artisans, measuring short and long, having and lacking—it is not how the sage employs the world.

When tigers, leopards, apes, and hounds are lured into the hunt, each is taken by some means. Thus, those who labor the body and startle the heart to be employed by the world have brought it upon themselves through brute force and superficial clarity.

To borrow is to say that skill and strength are borrowed by others. If one does not dwell in power and does not rely on transformative generosity, then even those who possess something cannot claim it as their own, allowing things to rejoice of themselves. The reason for this lies in standing in the unfathomable and wandering in Nothingness.

Xun Ben’s notes: *Xū* means convicts; *yì* means to lead. Skill binds one through artifice. Convicts and laborers labor the body; those bound by skill and artifice startle the heart.

In Zheng there was a divine diviner named Ji Xian, who knew the life and death, survival and demise, fortune and misfortune, longevity and early death of people, predicting them by year, month, ten-day period, or day as if by spirit. When the people of Zheng saw him, they all fled. When Liezi saw him, he was enchanted. Returning home, he told Master Húzi: "At first, I thought your Dao was the ultimate—yet there is something even more ultimate."

Master Húzi said: "You and I have grasped its patterns but not yet its reality—how could we truly have attained the Dao? A flock of hens without a rooster—how could they lay eggs? Yet you take this Dao and contend with the world, and so you are deemed trustworthy. Thus others can divine your fate. Come, bring him here and let me show myself to him."

The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Master Húzi. Upon leaving, Ji Xian said to Liezi: "Alas! Your master is dead—he will not live. It will not be ten days before he perishes. I saw something strange in him: he was like damp ashes."

Liezi entered and wept, tears soaking his lapels, then told Master Húzi. Húzi said: "Just now, I showed him the earthly pattern, latent and still. Neither trembling nor upright, he likely saw me with my virtue’s mechanism sealed. Bring him again."

The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Master Húzi once more. Upon leaving, Ji Xian said to Liezi: "Fortunate that your master met me! He is recovering, fully alive. I saw his sealed mechanism shift."

Liezi entered and told Master Húzi. Húzi said: "Just now, I showed him heaven and earth. Name and reality did not enter, yet the mechanism arose from his heels—he likely saw my mechanism of goodness. Bring him again."

The next day, Liezi once more brought Ji Xian to see Master Húzi. Upon leaving, Ji Xian said to Liezi: "Your master is unsettled. I cannot divine him. Let him settle, and I will divine him again."

Liezi entered and told Master Húzi. Húzi said: "Just now, I showed him the Great Thoroughfare where nothing prevails. He likely saw my mechanism of balanced qi. The deep pool where the *ní* fish coils, the deep pool of still water, the deep pool of flowing water—each pool has nine names, and here I showed him three."

The next day, Liezi again brought Ji Xian to see Master Húzi. Before Húzi could steady himself, Ji Xian lost his composure and fled. Húzi said: "Pursue him!" Liezi chased him but could not catch up. Returning, he reported to Húzi: "He has vanished, disappeared—I could not reach him."

Húzi said: "Just now, I showed him what had never yet emerged from my source. I met him with emptiness, drifting and yielding, not knowing who or what he was. He took me for a withered vine, for drifting waves—thus he fled. Only then did Liezi realize he had never yet begun to learn. He returned home and for three years did not go out. He cooked for his wife, fed the pigs as if feeding people, and in all affairs remained unattached. He cast off carving and returned to simplicity, standing alone like an unworked clod. Amidst the tumult, he remained sealed—thus he ended."

The one who lingers is Huán Pánhuán—examining the resonance, he circles within the flowing domain where sound gathers. Sima Biao says it should read "coiling and gathering." The character *dì* follows *rén* and *diào*, pronounced *tuí*, written as 䍺—incorrect.

Guo’s commentary: He fled in dismay, unwilling to hear of his own death. "No male, how eggs?"—this speaks of Liezi’s failure to embrace the Dao. Without embracing the Dao, one has a heart; with a heart, one exalts one direction and clings to worldly certainty, thus becoming predictable. Motionless like a withered root, neither correcting nor flourishing, damp ash merging with lifelessness—this is the moment when the perfected person is without response. The perfected person’s movement is like heaven, their stillness like earth, their going like flowing water, their cessation like a deep abyss. The abyss’s silence and water’s flow, heaven’s movement and earth’s stillness—these are one in non-doing, naturally so.

Now, when Jì Xián saw him sitting as if a corpse, forgetting all, he called him near death; when he saw his spirit move and heaven follow, he called him alive. If one can respond without mind, principle naturally aligns with the mysterious tally, ascending and descending with the world as measure—only then can one master things and follow time without limit, beyond the diviner’s reckoning. This is the great meaning of "Responding to Emperors and Kings."

The virtue-mechanism untriggered is called "blocked power"—yet it is still a mechanism. Now, having realized yesterday’s vision saw only the blocked mechanism, he called it near death. Yet within heaven and earth, the work of covering and bearing is manifest—compared to earth’s pattern, is this not still external? This is the appearance of responsive resonance. Entrusting to naturalness, covering and bearing, the heavenly mechanism mysteriously responds, and the adornments of profit and fame become discarded things. The mechanism arises from the heel, ever originating at the utmost height. When it emerges and excels in another, that one perceives it. Abiding at the great harmony’s utmost, vast and serene, the heart merges with the mysterious and unites with the ten thousand directions—thus victory and defeat cannot find place between them. Without going, all is level; blending into oneness, even gazing through a tube at heaven, one cannot see its bounds—hence it seems uneven.

The abyss means still silence. Water, ever without mind, submits to external things—whether flowing or halting, whether the *ní* fish coils or the dragon leaps, it remains profoundly serene, never losing its still silence. The perfected person’s use and disuse differ, yet their mysterious silence is one. Thus, briefly presenting three differences to clarify: though waves flow and nine transformations arise, order and chaos swirl—abiding at the utmost, one remains blandly content, drifting in forgetfulness of action.

"Never yet emerged from my source" means that though transformations are endless, the deep root remains firmly settled. "Drifting and yielding" means without mind, following things’ transformations. "Not knowing who or what" means floating without attachment. Transforming and declining, worldly affairs flowing—there is nowhere it does not follow. The perfected person is one, yet responds to worldly changes and moves with the times—thus the diviner cannot fix his gaze, loses himself, and flees. This clarifies that "responding to emperors and kings" is without fixed method.

Feeding pigs as if feeding people—he forgot nobility and baseness. In affairs, he had no partiality, only what he encountered. Carving discarded, simplicity restored—he cast off ornament and took up reality. Standing alone like an unworked clod—external adornment gone. Though tumultuous, he remained sealed—thus he ended, allowing things to each complete themselves.

Lü’s commentary: As for its pattern, it is not yet exhausted; as for its reality, it is the place of unknowing. The Dao has never yet had things; emptiness, formlessness—nothing matches it. Like a flock of hens without a rooster, I do not respond to things, yet there is something stored in my breast—like eggs without a male. Thus, when the Dao clashes with the world and insists on certainty, it allows others to divine it. Earth shares the same power as yin—none can perceive it; showing earth’s pattern, it becomes perceptible. Without shock, there is no movement; without correction, no stillness. The mechanism is the barrier to movement.

At first, seeing damp ash, he thought it death, not knowing it was blocked. Only when there was life did he realize what he had seen before was blocked power, not the true. Heaven shares the same wave as yang—none can perceive it; showing heaven and earth, it becomes perceptible. When name and reality do not enter, there is non-doing; the mechanism arises from the heel, thus it is shown. Earth is where things naturally grow; the heel is where breath naturally arises—thus knowing it has life and excels is the mechanism.

Earth’s measure is yin overcoming yang; heaven and earth is yang overcoming yin. The great harmony overcomes nothing, yet is not one—thus it seems uneven. Overcoming nothing is equipoise—hence it is called balanced qi and mechanism. The meaning of the three abysses is to compare the heart: though good abysses flow or halt, whether the *ní* fish coils or the dragon leaps, they never cease to be abyssal. The great harmony overcoming nothing is likewise.

When "never yet emerged from my source," it is hidden in heaven, shown as nothing to show—thus he cannot perceive it, loses himself, and flees. Jì Xián divined others’ hearts with his heart; when I am without heart, what he uses to divine also cannot stand alone—thus it vanishes and cannot be regained. Empty and drifting, not knowing who or what—this is non-doing, non-action, its stillness. Taking it for decline—none know it is decline. Its movement—taking it for flowing waves—none know it is flow. Seeking me between movement and stillness, both are unattainable—this is why he fled.

Feeding pigs as if feeding people—he forgot the self. In affairs, no partiality—reaching the utmost emptiness. Carving discarded, simplicity restored; standing alone like an unworked clod; though tumultuous, remaining sealed—thus he ended. Though the ten thousand things stir, my seal remains unchanged.

Following the text: "No male, how eggs?"—as the *Cantong Qi* says, "A hen alone cannot lay eggs." This speaks of how if the dog leans toward one side, it cannot complete the Dao—an analogy for Liezi’s failure to fulfill reality. "Earth’s pattern" refers to mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees. Grasses and trees sprout, tranquil and still, showing no movement; each corrects its nature and life without human effort. One only senses the great earth’s silence—this is the meaning of the *Duren Jing*: "Divine wind still and silent, mountains and seas concealed in clouds. Heaven without floating haze, the four qi bright and clear. A kingdom’s earth, mountains, rivers, forests—all level, no longer high or low." This is the so-called "blocked virtue-mechanism"—blocked, closed, hidden, and unseen.

"Blocked power" is within closure, yet there is adaptability—slightly different from what was seen yesterday. "Blocked power" and "blocked virtue" are opposites.
