When all under heaven knew beauty as beauty, ugliness arose; when all knew goodness as goodness, not-goodness arose. All knew to condemn what they deemed unworthy, yet none knew to condemn what they already deemed worthy—beauty and goodness. Again, through non-action, even beauty and goodness are not the true nature of life. The people did not interact yet formed clans naturally—this is called the *zhongzhong* people. If one carries provisions to chase after the worthy, this is the flattery of the *yiyi*. Their teaching resembles a father’s; their admonitions...

The semblance of a son yet the murmuring of dissent—such is the fault of exalting the worthy and prizing knowledge. From knowledge arises the sage; from the sage arises the great thief. Both sage and great thief emerge from the same source of knowledge, hence this chapter consistently advocates the abandonment of knowledge.

In detail: The *Dao* tradition states, "Multifarious affairs breed enmity; excessive speech is the thief of virtue." The *yiyi* are those who engage in ceaseless activity, while the *zhunzhun* are those who indulge in endless chatter.

Tracing to the root: "Knowledge and deceit gradually poison," "hardness and whiteness," "resolving grime," and "sameness and difference"—by the pattern of the preceding text, these should likewise be three matters. "Knowledge and deceit gradually poison" refers to mutual deception through knowledge, which accumulates into venom. "Hardness and whiteness" denotes obstinate insistence on whiteness, while "sameness and difference" denotes conflating difference with sameness—both phrases appear in the writings of Gongsun Long. "Jie" means competing for supremacy, while "hua" (slippery) suggests evasiveness and instability. Those who obstinately insist on whiteness and argue against it engage in such competition, rendering it elusive and unstable. "Jie" (resolving) means defense, and "gou" (grime) refers to the dust on the body. "Resolving grime and sameness" means dissolving defenses as grime is shed. The first phrase addresses knowledge, while the next two address disputation.

The *chuan* (insect) is a small creature, and the *qiao* (sprout) is a small plant.

**General Observations on the Chapter:**
This chapter takes "plundering the chest" as its title. Examining the rhyme, *qu* (胠) means the side of the ribs, so *quqie* (胠箧) refers to opening the side of a chest to take things—an act of theft. Those who govern cannot cultivate the Dao and virtue to align with the natural inclinations of all under heaven; thus, ambitious villains usurp their authority for private gain, and the world suffers harm. *Nanhua* (Zhuangzi) strives to abolish sagacity and discard knowledge, smash measures and break scales, aspiring to restore the governance of non-action of high antiquity. Yet the essence of returning to purity and reverting to simplicity lies in illuminating true knowledge to correct one’s course and reverting to true goodness to preserve what one has received. If those entrusted with governance were all of the mind of the Master of Qiyuan, what worry would there be that the world’s Dao would not flourish or that the pure wind would not return?

**Chapter Eleven: "Preserving and Accommodating"**
To hear of "preserving and accommodating" the world is not to hear of "governing" the world. "Preserving" means fearing the world will corrupt its nature; "accommodating" means fearing the world will alter its virtue. If the world neither corrupts its nature nor alters its virtue, who would govern it?

In ancient times, when Yao governed the world, he made all under heaven joyful, and people delighted in their nature—this was not tranquility. When Jie governed the world, he made all under heaven weary, and people suffered in their nature—this was not contentment. That which is neither tranquil nor content is not virtue. Without virtue, nothing in the world can endure. When people are excessively joyful, they are harmed by yang; when excessively angry, they are harmed by yin. When yin and yang are both harmed, the four seasons do not arrive, the harmony of cold and heat is not achieved, and in turn, people’s physical forms are injured.

When people’s joy and anger are misplaced, their dwellings lack constancy, their thoughts are not self-possessed, and the mean is not attained. Thereupon, the world begins to distort and contend, to stand aloof and act perversely, and only then do the deeds of Robber Zhi and Zeng Shen and Shi Qiu arise. Thus, even if one were to reward all under heaven for their goodness, it would not suffice; even if one were to punish all under heaven for their evil, it would not be enough. The vastness of the world is insufficient for rewards and punishments. From the Three Dynasties onward, the world has been in tumult, ceaselessly occupied with rewards and punishments. When would they have leisure to settle into the natural conditions of their nature and destiny?

(*Note: "Accommodating" means tolerance.*)

The affliction of *cui* is illness; *pi* means excess; *assistance*. "Distorted and contentious" (*qiao jie*) signifies imbalance; "aloof and perverse" (*zhuo pi*) denotes conduct that is not level. Guo’s commentary: "To grant freedom is to govern; to govern is to disorder. Human life is inherently upright—if nothing sways it, then nature and destiny remain unharmed. Desires and aversions do not err. Those above cannot act without purpose; whatever they do, the people all rush toward it. Thus, when they are lured by admiration and fondness for desires, the people’s nature becomes licentious. What is prized in a sage-king is not his ability to govern, but his non-action that allows things to act of themselves. Without governance, there is no deviation or excess. Though Yao ruled the world with tolerance, his traces were those of governance. Though governance and disorder differ, their loss of the people’s serenity and contentment—causing them to vie for esteem, fear disgrace, and fail to find self-possession—is the same. Thus, to praise Yao and condemn Jie is no better than forgetting both. Only serenity and self-possession can endure. Joy and anger misplaced, dwellings without constancy—these are all the legacy of Yao and Jie, who caused the people’s joy and anger to exceed bounds and thus bring about these ills.

Humans, amidst heaven and earth, are most capable of disturbing the myriad beings and disrupting yin and yang with their intelligence, joy, and anger. Thus, between gain and loss, joy and anger gather, and the people’s hearts are drawn in. The harmony of cold and heat is broken, the seasons’ order is disrupted, the hundred measures falter, and the myriad affairs wither and fall. Admiration of rewards produces goodness, yet rewards cannot suffice; fear of punishments halts evil, yet punishments cannot prevail. Only by forgetting rewards and punishments and returning to innate goodness can nature and destiny be fully realized.

Rewards and punishments are how sage-kings address merit and fault—not to display encouragement or deterrence. Thus, when governance reaches its limit, it is abandoned, and only then can unity be restored. Yet from the Three Dynasties onward, rulers have followed these traces, ceaselessly competing with them, making what was merely a means their constant occupation. When would they have leisure to settle into the natural conditions of their nature and destiny?

Lü’s commentary: "The world is where the myriad things are one; their constant nature and constant virtue are none other than our own nature and virtue. To tolerate the world is to tolerate the self. *In* (to preserve) means to sustain without loss, to follow nature without addition. *You* (to tolerate) means to release without indulgence, like animals in an enclosure. Without excess or deviation, there is only non-action. With non-action, there is no self; without self, who governs the world? Thus, one forgets the right and wrong of Yao and Jie. Humans are born tranquil—what joy or suffering is there? To impose joy or suffering is to corrupt their nature; to corrupt their nature is to deviate from their virtue.

The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang, their harmony arising from the *qi* of the center. Humans all possess this harmonious *qi* to commune with heaven and earth. Yet Yao caused the people to delight in their nature, leading to great joy and excess of yang; Jie caused them to suffer in their nature, leading to great anger and excess of yin. Thus, their harmonious *qi* was harmed, the seasons’ bestowal was thwarted, the harmony of cold and heat was unmade, and in turn, the human form was injured. As for thoughts not self-possessed and the mean not attained—this is what is meant by mutual harm. Thereupon, the world began to see distorted, contentious, aloof, and perverse conduct—conduct that exalts height, exhausts scrutiny, defies imitation, and rejects fellowship. None of this is level, easy, balanced, or upright. This is why rewards and punishments cannot suffice, and why the natural conditions of nature and destiny cannot be settled.

Xu’s commentary: "*In* means only to lodge this body in the world, making it aware of the self without excess. *You* means to release it naturally, so that even its cunning and deceit seem forgotten, and it loses itself—yet its joy remains unharmed. This is non-deviation. Not distinguishing Yao from Jie, not separating joy from suffering—this is the truth of what is seen."

The *Xun Ben* commentary: "Joyful yet not serene—this is the fault of not preserving. Weary yet not content—this is the fault of not tolerating. *Pi* means assistance. Joy pertains to yang; anger to yin. When yin and yang in the human body are harmonized, there is no illness. But excess joy assists yang’s dominance; excess anger assists yin’s dominance. The following text uses the yin and yang of the four seasons to illustrate the yin and yang of the human body. 'The mean is not attained' means that affairs are left half-finished, without order."

The *Fu Mo* commentary: "This speaks of joy and suffering, using joy and anger as analogies. A single joy, though enough to gladden the heart, is not as good as no joy; a single anger, though enough to vent frustration, is not as good as no anger. A single Yao or Jie, though enough to govern the world, is not as good as no governance. Now, when people’s joy and anger are misplaced, their dwellings lack constancy, their thoughts are not self-possessed, and the mean is not attained—all this is the fault of governance. Thereupon, the people lose their constant nature, and the world sees distorted, contentious, aloof, and perverse conduct, along with the deeds of Robber Zhi and Zeng Shen. Distortion means to exaggerate and exceed in height; contention means to demand of others with excessive strictness; aloofness means to stand apart to the point of defiance; perversity means to strike with violence to the point of ferocity. Robber Zhi and Zeng Shen both exhibited these four traits—all of which disrupt the natural order, shatter harmony, and are ultimately the people who have lost their true nature and disordered their essence.

Driven to this, goodness becomes too much for rewards to supply, and evil too much for punishments to restrain. Thus, even the vastness of the world is insufficient for rewards and punishments. Those who rule the world are ceaselessly occupied with them, constantly chasing their traces. How could they have leisure to settle into the natural conditions of their nature and destiny? To settle the natural conditions of nature and destiny, one must set aside rewards and punishments, preserve and tolerate, and only then can the world’s nature be realized."

Moreover: "Delight in beauty is excess in form; delight in music is excess in sound; delight in benevolence is disorder in virtue; delight in righteousness is perversion of principle; delight in ritual is competition in technique; delight in music is competition in excess; delight in sagacity is competition in artifice; delight in knowledge is competition in fault-finding. If these eight exist in the world, the natural conditions of nature and destiny may yet be settled; if they vanish, it may yet be so. But when the world cannot settle the natural conditions of nature and destiny, these eight begin to carve, coil, and entangle, throwing the world into chaos. Yet the world then begins to honor and cherish them—how profound is the world’s delusion! Is this not far more than a mere error?"

To cast them aside, then—must one fast and purify oneself to speak of them, kneel and sit to present them, drum and sing to dance for them? What would I be doing in such a case?

Thus, when the noble person cannot but govern the world, nothing compares to non-action. Only through non-action can the natural conditions of nature and destiny be settled. Therefore, one who values their person above governing the world may be entrusted with the world; one who cherishes their person above governing the world may be charged with the world. Thus, if the noble person can but refrain from disturbing their five viscera, refrain from flaunting their keen hearing and clear sight, remain still as a corpse yet manifest like a dragon, silent as an abyss yet thunderous as a storm, move as a spirit yet follow heaven’s course, and act with effortless non-action—then the myriad things will rise and fall like steam. What leisure would I then have to govern the world?

If one must preserve these eight, one cannot fully follow the natural course—hence the state of being coiled and constricted, like a choked sack. To fail to relinquish them is already an error; to then exalt them as noble is even more deluded. It is not merely that they pass away like a lodged guest, but that they are treasured and esteemed in this way. Non-action does not mean clasping hands in silence; it means each following its own nature, so that one’s life and destiny are at peace. The "unavoidable" is not forced by threats or punishments; it is simply embracing the Dao, holding to simplicity, and entrusting oneself to the inevitable—thus the world finds peace of its own accord. If one轻身以赴刑, abandoning oneself to die for things, then even one’s own person cannot be at peace—how could the world be governed? Without unraveling, without flaunting—unraveling and flaunting cause harm. In movement and stillness, speech and silence, one maintains no fixed intent, but entrusts all to nature. The spirit moves in accord with things, heaven follows principle in its course—like drifting dust that stirs of itself, one simply follows the natural way.

As Lü’s commentary states: If the world does not preserve the true conditions of life and destiny, then what is called keen hearing, clear sight, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, sageliness, and wisdom—all are not in their proper state, and one cannot avoid disordering virtue and perverting ritual. Whether these eight exist or perish, one can say they bring no benefit or harm.

The true essence is carved into fragments yet never made whole, bound into scrolls yet never unfurled—piled in sorrowful heaps yet never guarded, knotted in tangles yet never undone. All these disorder the world, yet people revere them, cherish them, speak of them with fasting and solemnity, drum and sing to them in dance, believing the world’s ultimate truth lies therein. The age has been deluded for so long—what can I do?

To govern the world truly arises from necessity, not choice; to act through non-action—why then should I not value and cherish this body, offering it for the world’s sake? Only thus can one be entrusted with the world. To value is not to treat the self lightly; to cherish is not to endanger the self. Entrustment is like entrusting the body, lodging is like lodging a thing—thus value becomes weight, cherishing becomes care, entrustment becomes burden, lodging becomes commitment.

Without unraveling the five viscera, one cannot guard against excess; without flaunting benevolence and righteousness, keen hearing and clear sight cannot be restrained from attachment. In stillness, one abides like a corpse; in activity, one appears like a dragon—such appearances arise from non-action. In profound silence, thunderous voices emerge—such sounds arise from wordlessness. When the spirit moves, response follows; when heaven follows, things come unbidden. Thus, in effortless non-action, the myriad things pile like steaming grain—steaming grain is the breath of things piling upon one another. The myriad things return to this as dust gathers of itself—what leisure then remains to govern the world?

Following the root—[the "steaming grain" of the myriad things denotes how all are encompassed within our nurturing life, like steam accumulating to ripen]—Cui Qu asked Lao Dan, "If one does not govern the world, how can the human heart be safeguarded?"

Lao Dan replied, "Take care not to agitate the human heart. The human heart presses downward yet strives upward; between high and low, it is imprisoned and slain. Supple and yielding, it is yet hard and strong; sharp and incisive, it is carved and polished. When hot, it scorches like fire; when cold, it congeals like ice. In the space between a bow and a rise, it twice brushes against the bounds beyond the four seas. At rest, it is abyssal and still; in motion, it hangs like heaven. Proud and unbridled—can anything compare to the human heart?

In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor first used benevolence and righteousness to agitate the human heart. Yao and Shun thus wore their thighs bare of flesh and their shins bare of hair to nourish the forms of the world, fretting over their five viscera to enact benevolence and righteousness, straining their blood and qi to model laws and standards—yet still, they could not prevail. Yao then banished Huan Dou to Mount Chong, exiled the Three Miao to Sanwei, and consigned Gong Gong to Youdu—this was his failure to master the world.

By the time it reached the Three Kings, the world was thrown into great turmoil. Below were Jie and Zhi; above were Zeng and Shi; Confucians and Mohists arose in full force. Joy and anger bred mutual suspicion; foolishness and wisdom deceived one another; good and ill vied in reproach; falsehood and truth mocked each other—and thus the world declined. Great virtue diverged, and natures and destinies scattered. The world prized knowledge, and the common people exhausted themselves in pursuit. Thus it was."

Axes and saws shaped them, inked cords and marking lines cut them down, hammers and chisels split them open—thus the world fell into utter chaos, its spine broken. The fault lay in disturbing the human heart. Therefore, the worthy withdrew to dwell beneath towering cliffs and cavernous crags, while the lords of ten thousand chariots trembled in dread within their ancestral halls.

In this age, those condemned to death lie piled one upon another; those bound in wooden yokes press shoulder to shoulder; those subjected to punishment and execution stand in full view. Yet the Confucians and Mohists now stretch forth their toes and brandish their arms amid the fetters and shackles—ah, how extreme! Their shamelessness knows no bounds. How extreme indeed! I know not whether sagely wisdom is not itself the crossbeam and cangue’s mortise, whether benevolence and righteousness are not themselves the fetters and chisels’ tenon.

How do I know that Zeng and Shi are not the war cries of Jie and Zhi? Thus it is said: Cut off sageliness, cast aside wisdom, and the world will be greatly ordered.

The blade wounds, the halter strangles. To hang and yearn for the lofty, to admire the distant, is to extend and stretch. The inked cord and marking line execute and correct. "Spine-broken" describes trampling and treading upon one another. The *hengyang* is the long restraint that binds neck and shins; the *jiexi* is its crossbeam. "Stretching forth their toes" means their soles barely touch the ground; "brandishing their arms" means their hands and feet both rise as they speak. A *haoshi* is an arrow that whistles in flight—*Pu* says it is a great cry.

Guo’s commentary: To disturb is to wound their innate goodness; to push them down is to provoke their ascent; to urge them forward is to incite their defiance—so easily are they swayed. Only when there is no pushing down or urging forward can they be secure. If one can be yielding and supple, even the rigid and strong will soften. The scorching heat of wildfire and the freezing cold of solid ice both arise from the accumulation of joy and anger. If one neither carves nor polishes, preserving one’s natural simplicity, how can there be such extremes of ice and fire?

To bow and rise again is to sway the customs of all beneath heaven. Still them, and they become like a deep abyss; stir them, and they soar bound to the heavens. The human heart’s transformations know no bounds. If left to follow its course, it becomes still and flows freely; if bound and restrained, it stretches and collapses in arrogance. Such arrogance is an unstoppable force.

The Yellow Emperor did not act for benevolence and righteousness; he simply merged with things, and the traces of benevolence and righteousness appeared of themselves. Once these traces appeared, later ages inevitably followed them—thus the Yellow Emperor’s traces disturbed the world. The reputations of Yao and Shun are but their traces. I lodge in these traces, yet the traces are not me. Thus, the alarmed grow ever more alarmed with each generation, and their traces grow ever coarser. Coarseness and subtlety are but the smooth and rugged paths of one’s own making. Does the traveler ever change his feet?

Thus, the sage is one, yet there are differences between Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu. These distinctions are but the names of their times and ages; they do not suffice to name the sage’s true reality. Therefore, Yao and Shun—were they merely Yao and Shun? Though there may be traces of benevolence and righteousness, the appearances of distress and sorrow, that which underlies these traces remains whole.

From mutual suspicion in joy and anger to mutual mockery in falsehood and truth, none can equal the self-contentment of one who attains it. When great virtue diverges, small differences arise and do not stop at mere division. Knowledge is boundless, yet people covet it, so there is no way to satisfy their demands. Thus, axes and saws, hammers and chisels carve and shape their natures and destinies, bringing them to this pass. If one instead follows nature and abides in what is fitting, the worthy and foolish will each embrace their true feelings, the noble and base will each tread their proper places, and ruler and minister, high and low, will all attain their ultimate end—then the world will know no trouble.

These traces disturb the world’s heart, setting it galloping without cease. Thus, those of middling wisdom and below all adorn their natures outwardly to delude the masses. They hate the upright and revile the correct; factions gather and follow one another. Those who embrace authenticity lose their defenses, while those who exalt falsity seize the reins. Thus, rulers worry above, and the people suffer below.

This is the calamity wrought by rotten scholars clinging to traces. Instead of discarding traces and returning to unity, they brandish their arms and employ traces to govern traces—truly, their shamelessness knows no bounds. The *hengyang* uses *jiexi* as its crossbeam; fetters and shackles use chisels and tenons as their tools. Sagely wisdom and benevolent righteousness are far removed from the traces of crime. The farther the traces from crime, the more people esteem them; the more they esteem them, the more deceit arises. Where deceit arises, instruments to control villainy are never lacking.

Thus, discard what is esteemed, and deceit will not arise; the *hengyang* and fetters will be abolished. What need is there for chisels, tenons, crossbeams, or mortises? A *haoshi* is a fierce arrow—this means Zeng and Shi are the sharp tools of Jie and Zhi.

Cut off sageliness, cast aside wisdom, and remove what disturbs.

Guo’s commentary: To push the heart downward is to confine it like a prisoner; to urge it upward is to enrage and kill it. To pare and wound it is to leave it maimed and incomplete; to carve and polish it is to adorn it with ornament and strip it of substance—thus the qi of yin and yang is thrown into disorder. When it lies still, it stiffens; when it rises, it collapses in arrogance. To bind and restrain it, forcing it into closure and constraint, is to provoke the response of the unworthy heart.

Benevolence and righteousness are internal, so they distress the five viscera; laws and standards are external, so they strain the blood and qi. Yet when benevolence and righteousness are practiced, deceit and falsity arise; when laws and standards are displayed, violence and chaos erupt. Even Yao’s perfect governance could not avoid punishing the Four Fiends—how much less could the Three Dynasties and later ages?

"Condemned" means cut off; "executed" means disgraced.

Deputy Ink:

When the human heart is even slightly suppressed by others, it loses its resolve, its spirit withers, and it sinks. When it is even slightly spurred onward, it aspires to lofty heights and gazes into distant realms—up and down without constancy, rising and falling at the whim of others. Bound as if imprisoned, it trembles in fear; driven as if to slaughter, it will take this tranquil, plain, and unadorned heart and transform it into a false, artful guise, flattering those who surpass it. All the integrity and principles one has cultivated in life are carved and polished away, nearly exhausted. Such is the intent of those who dread suppression and crave advancement.

Speak of its restlessness, and it burns like scorching fire; speak of its trepidation, and it chills like congealing ice. Speak of its swiftness, and in the space between a single bow and rise, it twice reaches beyond the four seas. When it has yet to stir, its stillness is like an abyss; once stirred, it soars as distant as heaven, as drifting as clouds—heaven and abyss utterly sundered. Such is the indignant, perverse, arrogant, and unbridled state of the human heart.

Yao and Shun toiled, Tang and Wu waged war, hoping to restrain it with benevolence and righteousness. Yet once the door of benevolence and righteousness is opened, those below bear the names of cruelty and injustice as Jie and Zhi, while those above gain the reputations of practicing benevolence and righteousness as Zeng and Shi. Thus, the Confucians and Mohists each established teachings along these lines: those who agree with them are met with joy, those who differ with anger. Seeing only this, they deem themselves wise; failing to see that, they deem others foolish. What lies with them is good, and they condemn others for its absence; what lies with them is true, and they mock others as absurd. That side has its right and wrong, this side has its right and wrong—and the virtue of profound unity declines, the true nature of life and destiny is lost.

The people, then, exhaust their thoughts and energies, ceaselessly responding to demands—what is called "seeking exhaustion." Adzes, saws, inked cords, mallets, and chisels—all tools of punishment and execution—are employed when benevolence and righteousness are exhausted and penal laws are put to use, an inevitable course. In the end, it drives the worthy to withdraw and flee, leaving the lord of ten thousand chariots burdened with sorrow and isolated. Yet the followers of Confucius and Mozi still cling to their discourses on benevolence, righteousness, sagacity, and wisdom, rolling up their sleeves and striving to remedy the crisis. Who realizes that this very crisis arises from benevolence, righteousness, sagacity, and wisdom?

The tenons and mortises are the pegs of the pillory; the round tenon and square mortise are what fashion the fetters. Where there are pillories, there must be tenons and mortises; where fetters are made, tenons and mortises must be used—the two depend on each other. This illustrates how benevolence and righteousness inevitably invite transgression and strife, and how Zeng and Shi inevitably rely on Jie and Zhi.

Xu Shizhang said: "Jie and Zhi are the first arrows—like saying dissenting opinions are red banners."

When the Yellow Emperor had reigned as Son of Heaven for nineteen years, his decrees circulated throughout the land. Hearing that Guangchengzi dwelled upon Mount Kongtong, he went to see him, saying: "I have heard that you, Master, have attained the utmost Dao. I venture to ask about the essence of the utmost Dao. I wish to draw upon the essence of Heaven and Earth to aid the five grains and nourish the people. I also wish to govern yin and yang to bring all living things to fruition. How may this be done?"

Guangchengzi replied: "What you wish to inquire about is the substance of things; what you wish to govern is the ruin of things. Ever since you began to rule the world, clouds gather before they thicken into rain, grasses and trees wither before they yellow, and the light of the sun and moon grows ever more dim. And with your heart so full of petty cunning, how could you be fit to speak of the utmost Dao?"

The Yellow Emperor withdrew, relinquished the world, built a solitary chamber, and spread a mat of white couch grass. After dwelling in seclusion for three months, he went again to seek him. Guangchengzi lay with his head to the south. The Yellow Emperor approached from the north, crawling on his knees. He bowed twice, prostrated himself, and asked: "I have heard that you, Master, have attained the utmost Dao. I venture to ask how one may cultivate the body so as to endure long."

Guangchengzi sprang to his feet and said: "Excellent, your question! Come, I will tell you of the utmost Dao. The essence of the utmost Dao is profound and obscure; its ultimate reaches are dark and silent. See nothing, hear nothing, hold fast to spirit in stillness, and the body will right itself. Be still, be pure; do not weary your body, do not stir your essence, and you may live long. Let your eyes see nothing, your ears hear nothing, your heart know nothing, and your spirit will guard your body—your body will endure long. Be careful within, shut out the outer; much knowledge brings ruin. I will lead you to the source of great brightness, to the origin of utmost yang. I will guide you through the gate of profound obscurity, to the origin of utmost yin. Heaven and Earth have their offices, yin and yang their storehouses. Guard your body carefully, and things will flourish of themselves. I preserve the One and abide in harmony. Thus I have cultivated my body for one thousand two hundred years, yet my form has never decayed."

The Yellow Emperor bowed twice and prostrated himself, saying: "Guangchengzi is indeed Heaven!"

Guangchengzi said: "Come, I will tell you. That which is boundless, men all deem finite; that which is unfathomable, men all deem limited. Those who attain my Dao are emperors above and kings below; those who lose my Dao see light above and become earth below. Now the hundred creatures all arise from earth and return to earth. Therefore, I will leave you and enter the gate of the boundless, to wander in the wilds of the infinite. I share the light of the sun and moon, I abide with Heaven and Earth as constant. Let me vanish—what is distant to me? Let me fade—what is obscure to me? Men may all perish, yet I alone endure."

Here the essence stands firm, the clans gather—yet before they gather, rain speaks of scant moisture; before yellowing, leaves fall, speaking of excess killing qi. The shearing, fawning guise—startled, they rise abruptly. Creatures will naturally mature; if one does not govern the world, all things will assume their own tasks and mature.

One thousand two hundred years: Li Chunfeng’s *Register of Things* states that one thousand two hundred years is called a "great cycle," also termed the "lesser reckoning of yin and yang." The hundred creatures: Sima [Qian] says they are the hundred things.

"Mín" (泯) means to merge; "hūn" (昏) means the absence of mind—both denote the state of no-mind.

Guo’s commentary:
To inquire into the essence of the supreme Dao may be called "substance." Not allowing things to be as they are but seeking to govern them—this is destruction. If all men cultivate themselves and do not govern the world, the world will be well-governed. Thus it is praised.

"Yǎomíng" (窈冥), "hūnmò" (昏默)—all denote utter nothingness. Why do Laozi and Zhuangzi repeatedly speak of "nothing"? To clarify that what gives birth to things is no-thing, and things arise of themselves. They arise of themselves—not for the sake of arising. Then what agency is there in their arising for oneself?

Forget seeing and yet see of oneself; forget hearing and yet hear of oneself—then spirit is not disturbed, and form does not deviate. Do not labor your form, do not agitate your essence; let it move of itself, and thus remain at ease, tranquil, and undying. All this is following one’s nature in movement, hence long life.

Guard within to preserve your true [nature]; close without to maintain your allotted place. To know no bounds is to fail. To fathom the origin of yin and yang is to ascend into the great brightness, to enter the gate of the profound and obscure.

"Having offices, having storehouses"—this speaks only of allowing things to take their course. To take the utmost of one’s nature and destiny, to reach the ultimate of long life—this is all. Only when the body does not perish can one extend to other things.

Boundless and unfathomable, yet men deem them finite and limited—this is merely seeing one transformation. The titles of emperor and king rise and fall with the times, yet in attaining the Dao of adaptability to respond to the boundless, they are one. To lose the boundless Dao is to cling to one partial view and fail to harmonize above and below, hence the differing minds of high and low. Earth is without mind; born from no-mind, one should return to guard no-mind and wander alone.

To enter the boundless, to roam the infinite, is to move with transformation. To share the light of the sun and moon, to abide with Heaven and Earth as constant—all is entrusted to spontaneity. "Mín" and "hūn" mean that the coming and going of things are all unperceived. "Alone enduring" means taking death and life as one body, so there is nowhere that is not existence.

Lü’s commentary:
Above Kongtong, where there is no-thing and great passage—there the Dao is the uncarved block of nameless simplicity, hence "substance." Yin and yang are the dispersal of the Dao, hence "destruction." Cloud-qi does not wait for clans to gather before it spreads into desolation—this is not assisting their natural course but rather impairing it.

Dwelling in seclusion for three months, attaining utmost purity, following the wind to advance, tracing the root to seek it—only the Dao can govern the body and bring long life. This is truly inquiring into its essence.

"Yǎomíng" means formless; words cannot discuss it, thoughts cannot reach it. Yet there is something called "essence"—if it can be known or spoken, it is not the ultimate. Only when utterly dark and silent does one reach the ultimate of the Dao. This speaks of the Dao’s body.

Without seeing, without hearing—only then can one attain long life and enter the Dao. Embrace spirit with correctness, and form will not seek correctness yet be correct of itself. It must be still, must be pure—speaking of not disturbing it with turbidity. Form not labored remains whole; essence not agitated returns. Only then can one attain long life.

Spirit has no form yet attaches to things. If it does not attach to things but returns to nothing, where will it abide without seeing or knowing? Not guarding its form—where will it go? Guard within to block its openings; close without to shut its gates—this is the way to nurture and preserve spirit. The opposite is excess knowledge leading to failure.

Before men know the Dao, they are confined to yin and yang and never reach its origin. Without seeing, without hearing, without knowing, one ascends into the great brightness, enters the gate of the profound and obscure. Attaining this and exhausting it, one knows Heaven and Earth have their offices, and these are their offices; yin and yang have their storehouses, and these are their storehouses.

In this, guard your body carefully—things will mature of themselves. Why seek externally? The Yellow Emperor was further told that what was called "no seeing, no hearing" is the body of the Dao. As for its function: no seeing is how one sees of oneself; no hearing is how one hears of oneself; no knowing is how one knows of oneself.

The Dao as a thing is boundless and unfathomable, yet to stop at no seeing, hearing, or knowing is to take the boundless as finite, the unfathomable as limited. Those who attain the Dao become emperors and kings because their spirit and brightness give rise to emperors and kings. Those who lose the Dao see light and become earth because their form does not transcend the realm of illumination, covering, and bearing.

The hundred creatures are born from earth and return to earth because of their form. Thus, I will leave you, enter the boundless, and roam the infinite—those who deem this finite and limited do not know me. Sharing the light of the sun and moon, their brightness does not cease; abiding with Heaven and Earth as constant, their duration is endless.

"When I mín"—one does not know it is "when." "Far from me hūn"—one does not know it is "far." Men all perish, yet I alone endure—seeking within myself, I do not know what thing can bring one to this.

Of the myriad creatures, man is the most spiritually endowed. How many transformations does creation undergo to produce a human? And of humans, how many are wise and perspicacious enough to attain this? Yet they do not diligently pursue it—thus those who treasure kindness do not weary of speaking of it repeatedly.

】Su Zizhan【 annotates: In the *Classic of Mountains*, the Master of Broad Accomplishment governed the hexagrams *Tai*, *Yi*, *Zhun*, and *Meng*, directing the movements of the sun and moon—truly the Perfected One of antiquity and the teacher of the Yellow Emperor. That creatures possess substance and that they decay—such is their nature, for their essence lies in desire, while long life is sought externally through nurturing the people and fostering the multitude.

Is not immortality the true reality of things, and that which is called "nurturing the people and fostering the multitude" merely the surplus of the Dao? Clouds gather without waiting to cluster, and rain falls; plants and trees wither without waiting to yellow—this shows that even the essence of Heaven and Earth cannot sustain the depletion wrought by intentional effort. Thus, the omen of decline and ruin first appears in the sun and moon; if one observes with the body, the ears and eyes are the first to ail.

The Perfected One and the flatterer are like grain and weeds: where grain is sown, though the soil be barren, weeds do not grow; where weeds are sown, though the field be fertile, grain does not grow. Now, those who wish to study the Dao yet inquire with insincerity—how can the seed of the Dao take root in such false and obsequious soil? Dwelling in seclusion for three months, the mind of putting others before oneself has no place to act, and thus their questions sink into obscurity and silence. This is the method of attaining the Dao, yet it is not the Dao itself.

Those who study the Dao fear its dissipation and falsity; thus, the profound obscurity is the means to achieve unity, and the deep silence is the means to preserve authenticity. Below, another line is drawn to instruct: all are words of truth—"see nothing, hear nothing, embrace the spirit in stillness" is non-action; "the heart knows nothing" is non-thought; "be still, be pure, neither toil the body nor disturb the essence" is non-desire. When these three are complete, form and spirit unite; when form and spirit unite, long life is attained. If one is not cautious within and does not close off without, form and spirit separate.

As for the source of utmost yang and utmost yin, these two function like the sun and moon, water and fire—through them, one refines, transforms, solidifies qi, and congeals things. Establishing the root of long life in profound obscurity and deep silence, eliminating its harms through non-action, non-thought, and non-desire, and further employing utmost yin and utmost yang to solidify and congeal—this is all that is needed in one’s affairs. Heaven and Earth have their offices and govern themselves for me; yin and yang have their treasuries and store themselves for me. The task lies in oneself, while completion lies in them.

Things inherently have no end; their division is their completion, and their completion is their fulfillment.

Destruction—things have never truly died. Thus, long life is the inherent nature of things, not something I alone can achieve. I merely preserve unity and dwell in harmony, so I do not perceive their division, completion, or destruction. Do others all perish while I alone endure? Those who speak of studying the Dao—few indeed can wholly let their "others" die while preserving only their "I."

What can be seen, spoken of, abandoned, or grasped is the "other"; it is not the "I." What cannot be seen, spoken of, abandoned, or grasped—that is the true "I." Draw near to this, and you are enlightened; distance yourself, and you are foolish. Attain this, and you attain the Dao. Thus, when others all perish while I alone endure, this is what is meant.

*Following the root*:
Those who proceed reach their end. The "offices" are like government bureaus; the "treasuries" are like storehouses; "things" are like the contents within these bureaus and storehouses. Born, they rise to behold the light of sun and moon; dead, they descend to become earth. The union of twisted silk is dim and obscure. What I call "near" is the realm that approaches me—it is the gate of the boundless, the wilderness of the infinite. What I call "far" is the world that turns away from me—it is "depart from you." This is to say, after this departure, will the immortal realm that once drew near to me remain as inseparable as twisted silk? Will the world that now recedes from me vanish into obscurity, never to be seen again? For those who have not attained the Dao, do all perish while I alone endure? The three instances of "乎" convey a mournful pity for the world.

Cloud General was traveling east when he passed the branches of the *fuyao* tree and happened upon Hong Meng, who was just then slapping his thigh and leaping about in play. Cloud General, seeing him, halted abruptly and stood in astonishment, saying, "Old sir, who are you? What are you doing here?" Hong Meng continued slapping his thigh and leaping without pause. Cloud General said, "I wish to ask you something." Hong Meng looked up at Cloud General and said, "Hmm?" Cloud General said, "Heaven’s qi is disharmonious, Earth’s qi is pent up, the six qi are unbalanced, and the four seasons are out of order. Now I wish to blend the essence of the six qi to nurture all living things. What should I do?" Hong Meng slapped his thigh, leaped, and shook his head, saying, "I do not know! I do not know!" Cloud General could not press further.

Three years later, he traveled east again and passed through the wilds of Song, where he once more encountered Hong Meng. Cloud General was overjoyed, hastened forward, and said, "Has Heaven forgotten me? Has Heaven forgotten me?" He bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, and said, "I wish to hear your teaching, Hong Meng." Hong Meng said, "Wandering aimlessly, I know not what I seek; roaming wildly, I know not where I go. I drift and observe the unexpected—what do I know?" Cloud General said, "I, too, thought myself wild and aimless, yet the people followed wherever I went. I could not escape them, and now they imitate me. I wish to hear a single word from you." Hong Meng said, "You disrupt the warp of Heaven, oppose the nature of things, and thwart the mysterious workings of Heaven, preventing its completion. Beasts scatter from their herds, and birds cry out all night. Disaster reaches the grasses and trees, calamity befalls even the insects. Alas! This is the fault of those who govern men." Cloud General said, "Then what should I do?" Hong Meng said, "Ah, how poisonous! Rise lightly, rise lightly!"

Return, then! Cloud General said, "I have encountered the trials of Heaven—may I ask one final word?" Hong Meng replied, "Ah! Nurture your heart-mind. Dwell in emptiness, do nothing, and things will transform of themselves. Dissolve your form, expel your cleverness, and forget all distinctions with things—merge into the Great Sameness. Let the primal qi blend and vanish, unbind your heart-mind, release your spirit, and abide in utter non-attachment. Then the ten thousand things, drifting like clouds, will each return to their root. Each returns to its root, yet none knows it. Profoundly, profoundly murky—throughout life, never depart from this. If one claims to know it, one has already departed from it. Ask not its name, peer not into its conditions—things thus arise of themselves."

Cloud General said, "Heaven has bestowed virtue upon me, shown me silence, and through my own seeking, I have now attained it." He bowed twice, touched his head to the ground, rose, and departed.

The demeanor of rising and sitting in serene ease—yet one may still chafe at an inability to utterly dissolve and flow freely. Thus, one sends the heart-mind home: when use injures it, then to nurture the heart-mind is precisely not to employ it. Let principle and things alike be neither held in mind nor deliberately entrusted to spontaneity—then non-doing will transform of itself.

To merge into the Great Sameness is to be without boundary with things. To sit in oblivion, entrusting oneself to solitude—this is true return, for only in chaos and unknowing, allowing the self to return of itself, can one abide lifelong without departing from the root. To know and yet seek return is already to stray from return. To question, to peer—is to lose the self-arising. To know and yet not remain silent is ever to lose oneself.

---

Lü’s Commentary:
I do not claim this to be true knowing. All people have their seeking and their going; I alone know neither seeking nor going—simply abiding in unknowing. Though one may wander, one remains bound, as if shackled; yet when I observe the true nature of all under heaven, it is nothing more than this: the ten thousand things arise together, and I observe their return. In returning, there is no delusion—what more do I know? To deem oneself wild and unrestrained is still to act; to let the people roam free is still not non-doing. Heaven is non-doing; things are unknowing. To know, to act—is to disorder heaven’s warp, to contravene the nature of things, and thus fail to complete the mysterious work of heaven.

The year has its mysterious completion—this is the winter solstice. The month has its mysterious completion—this is the dark of the moon.

The day has its mysterious completion—this is midnight. And man, too, has his mysterious completion. Those of old who sought the abode of the true qi, preserving their spirit and beautifying their root, none failed to know this—though none spoke of it openly. Now, that disasters befall birds, beasts, and crawling things is simply due to the error of not governing through non-doing. To administer poison to cure illness is one thing; to govern through non-doing is like administering poison where no illness exists—how perilous! Return, then, to the root.

All men possess a mind bent on completion, yet it lies only in self-nurturance. In self-nurturance, there is nothing to be done, and things transform of themselves. When the bodily form dissolves, one knows not the six members; when keen perception is cast aside, one knows not the ears and eyes. Order lies within me; things lie without. The vast and boundless qi awaits things in its emptiness—when I and things forget one another, we merge with the vast and boundless. Then the heart is untied, the spirit released, and all is serene, without soul. This is how one abides in the Way of non-doing.

When the ten thousand things are just arising, I know them not; when I let things return to the root, I know not myself. Thus, chaos and vastness become one, and to the end of life, one never departs from it—without inquiry, without prying—and things arise of themselves. When one is without knowing, one knows not that one is without knowing. To say, “This is called ‘unknowing’” is to inquire after its name; to say, “Is this truly unknowing?” is to pry into its nature. It is like a thing just beginning to grow—if one picks at its root to examine it, none can grow. Heaven’s way of creating things is no different.

The common people all delight in others being like themselves and detest others being different from themselves. They desire those who are like them and do not desire those who are different—this is to take being part of the crowd as one’s heart. Yet how can one who takes being part of the crowd as their heart ever stand apart from the crowd? Relying on the crowd to secure what one has heard is not as good as the crowd’s many skills. Those who would rule others’ states grasp at the advantages of the Three Kings while blind to the dangers—this is to gamble with others’ states. How many gambles do not end in the ruin of others’ states? For every one that preserves another’s state, ten thousand and more are lost. How lamentable that those who hold land do not understand this!

Those who hold land possess great things. Those who possess great things cannot be ruled by things, and only by not being ruled by things can they rule things. How clear it is that those who are ruled by things are not things themselves! This is not merely about governing the world. Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces, going alone and coming alone—this is called "possessing alone." Those who possess alone are called the most noble.

The teachings of the great person are like form to shadow, sound to echo. When questioned, they respond, exhausting what lies in their heart, matching the world. They dwell without direction, move without fixed course, taking you by the hand to return to what disturbs you, roaming without bounds. Entering and exiting without sides, with the sun they have no beginning. They discourse on form and body, merging with the Great Unity. In the Great Unity, there is no end—where in no-end can one find "having"? Those who see "having" are the gentlemen of old; those who see "non-having" are friends of Heaven and Earth.

Guo’s commentary: The heart desires to stand apart from the crowd, to lead the many. The crowd all take standing apart as their heart, and thus they are the common people. If I too desired to stand apart, I would be no different from the crowd and could not surpass them. The crowd all take surpassing one another as their heart, yet I alone go nowhere without being the same—thus I am vastly different from the crowd and become their master. What I alone have heard is not as numerous as the crowd’s many skills, so I rely on the crowd to be at peace. If I did not rely on the crowd, the crowd’s thousands and tens of thousands would all be my enemies.

Those who would rule others’ states do not rely on the crowd’s self-governance but impose their own will—this is merely seeking the advantages of the Three Kings in ruling things while blind to the dangers of imposing their will. How could the Three Kings have gained their advantages by imposing their will? They relied on the world’s self-governance and left it at that. The world and I rely on one another to succeed. Now, if one alone controls the world, the world is blocked—how could one alone be unobstructed? Thus, one’s own body is not preserved, and the ten thousand regions suffer ruin.

One who cannot use things is used by things—this is to be a thing oneself. How can one who is a thing rule things? Unable to rule things, one is not fit to possess great things. Those who use things are not used by things. Not being used by things, they are not things. Not being things, they enable the things of the world to each attain their own. Relying on the world’s self-governance, they set the ten thousand things free without exhaustion.

People all distinguish themselves, yet I alone roam with the crowd—this is the one who goes alone and comes alone. Only this "possessing alone" can truly be called "possessing alone." To merge with the crowd in profound sameness is not to seek nobility from the crowd, yet the crowd cannot but honor them—this is the most noble. If one clings to one’s partial views and takes being uniquely different as one’s heart, then even if one aligns with a single purpose, one is but a thing among the common—no "possessing alone." Not yet able to possess alone, yet coveting rank and emblems, seizing what is not one’s due—how could the crowd follow? Thus, this is not the most noble.

The hearts of the common people are like form and sound; the teachings of the great person are like echo and shadow. What mind does the great person hold toward the world? Merely that of echo and shadow following form and sound. They allow each being’s inner inclinations to fully express themselves—those who ask become the host, those who respond become the counterpart. Without sound or silence, they await all things; without fixed direction, they turn and transform with things. Spontaneously stirring, they move of themselves. To guide the ten thousand things back to their self-moving nature—this is the perfection of non-action. Moving with transformation, they have no beginning; merging with the profound, they have no outward sign; advancing with daily renewal, they have no origin.

Those whose bodily forms unite with the Great Harmony resemble heaven and earth in appearance. If one clings to a self, one cannot achieve the Great Harmony. The greatest difficulty in the world lies in the self. Once the self is gone, the myriad existents need no longer be seen as existent. Those who perceive existence merely praise its name; those who perceive non-existence allow it to arise alone.

---

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The Dao’s non-action is natural; not only should the ruler embody it, but those who assist the ruler with the Dao must also rely on the multitude to bring tranquility, avoiding affairs in a state governed for the people. One person’s knowledge cannot match the collective skills of the many. To take sole responsibility for governing a state for others is to risk ruin—survival would be mere luck. The rulers and ministers of the Three Dynasties once found this advantageous, but later ages have often seen it as a calamity. Those who seek to govern for others grasp at its benefits while ignoring its harms.

When the Yellow Emperor asked Guangcheng and Yao met the Four Masters, all regarded the "great thing" as a peril. They sought to clarify that what I embody is the Dao—beyond the Dao, there is nothing, hence it is called "possessing alone." The great person’s teachings follow like echo and shadow after form and sound, never taking the lead in the world—this is how they serve as the counterpart.

Abiding in no-sound, they remain still and unmoving; acting without fixed direction, they have never set boundaries. Thus, they guide the world back to its spontaneous stirring, where stillness is not enforced—this is called "the ten thousand things arising together," allowing me to observe their return and store the world within the world. Therefore, they roam through the beginning and end of things, unbound by directions that could obstruct or times that could confine.

The *Song Lun* speaks: speech arises from non-speech. The body is form; form is an image of the formless. Thus, one achieves the Great Harmony and dissolves the self. Without self, how could there be existence? Gentle and benevolent, this is called the noble person. The sage’s way of harmonizing with others means that those who perceive existence may be called noble, but those who perceive non-existence transcend even the title of "friend of heaven and earth"—for what they share with others defies naming.

---

**Supplementary Notes:**
"Relying on the multitude to bring tranquility" means grounding one’s own knowledge in the multitude’s perceptions and insights—thus, one’s limitations compared to the many skills of the people become even more apparent. To exalt benevolence and righteousness, to delight in sagacity and wisdom, is but a common view.

"Guiding you" means leading the world toward the Dao.

Returning, it weaves and wanders without end—this coming, this going—speaking of its comings and goings as free and unrestrained, stirring and provoking without limit. Emerging and entering without side or support, it goes alone, comes alone, dependent on nothing. Since it has no end, how could it have a beginning? Since it has no beginning, how could it have an end? Thus it is said: "With the sun, it has no beginning." Here, the bodily form cannot hinder it, and it merges with the Great Harmony. This is what is meant by "form and spirit both wondrous, uniting with the Dao in truth."

In the Great Harmony, seeking what is one’s own cannot be attained—how could there be existence? Those who perceive existence are the noble persons of former times: the rulers and ministers of the Three Dynasties who governed with benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music all belong to this. Those who perceive non-existence are friends of heaven and earth, and none but those who are without self can partake in this.

That which is lowly yet cannot be neglected is the myriad things. That which is humble yet cannot be disregarded is the common people. That which is hidden yet cannot be left undone is affairs. That which is coarse yet cannot be omitted is the law. That which is distant yet cannot be abandoned is righteousness. That which is intimate yet cannot be narrowed is benevolence. That which is measured yet cannot be left unaccumulated is ritual. That which is centered yet cannot be left unexalted is virtue. That which is one yet cannot be left unchanged is the Dao. That which is numinous yet cannot be left unenacted is heaven.

Thus, the sage observes heaven yet does not assist, achieves virtue yet is not burdened, emerges from the Dao yet does not scheme, meets benevolence yet does not rely, refines righteousness yet does not accumulate, responds to ritual yet does not conceal, engages with affairs yet does not refuse, aligns with the law yet is not disordered, depends on the people yet does not slight them, and follows the myriad things yet does not abandon them. For what is there that can be done, yet cannot be left undone?

Those who do not understand heaven are not pure in virtue. Those who do not comprehend the Dao have no means by which they may act. Those who do not understand the Dao—how lamentable! What is the Dao? There is the Dao of heaven and the Dao of humanity. That which is without action yet revered is the Dao of heaven. That which acts yet is burdened is the Dao of humanity. The ruler follows the Dao of heaven; the minister follows the Dao of humanity. The distance between the Dao of heaven and the Dao of humanity is vast—this cannot be left unexamined.

Guo’s Commentary:
To govern by following their nature and entrusting them is order; to reverse their nature and oppress them is chaos. That the people and things are base and lowly stems from their inability to be entrusted. Thus, entrusting the lowly makes them noble, and following the base makes them exalted—this is the inevitable sign. Affairs are concealed in that which is distant, hence they are hidden there; each acts for itself, hence they cannot be left undone. One must only follow and entrust them.

The law is the trace of wondrous affairs—how can one, because the trace is coarse, fail to set forth the wondrous affair? Only by abiding in it does one thereby become distant from the near; then, suffering from partiality, one broadens it and calls it benevolence. As for ritual propriety, its trouble lies in being bound to one thing. If one embodies it in every thing, it accumulates and becomes all-encompassing. In affairs that are lowly, though they may hit the mark, it is not virtue. In affairs that are difficult, though they may be unified, it is not the Dao—how much less when they are not unified?

To hold to an intention and not act, though one be spirit-like, is not of heaven—how much less when one is not spirit-like? Observing heaven without assisting, one simply follows what is already so; virtue is not burdened, for it naturally accords with the lofty. Emerging from the Dao without scheming, one does not scheme yet is unified—this is why it is easy. Guarding benevolence without relying on it, for to rely on it is not to broaden it. Following one’s nature and dwelling in the distant is not accumulation. Naturally responding to ritual is not through avoidance. In affairs, one engages with principle; ability or inability is entrusted to oneself. Responding to movement by moving, there is no refusal or yielding. Governing the coarse with the wondrous, hence there is no disorder. Relying on the people to act for themselves is not to use them lightly. Following things and entrusting them is not to abandon their root.

How could one act with the aim of sufficiency? One’s body embodies this act, hence it cannot be stopped. Not understanding the natural leads to action, and with action, virtue is not pure. Unable to empty oneself and await things, one loses harmony in every affair—this is the lamentable state of those who do not understand the Dao.

The Dao of heaven resides above and entrusts the myriad things to act for themselves. The Dao of humanity is burdened by action and cannot follow its own attainment. The ruler aligns with the Dao of heaven, which is the same as heaven’s entrusting of things—naturally dwelling above them. The minister aligns with the Dao of humanity, each attending to their entrusted task. The ruler entrusts non-action and delegates to the hundred officials; the hundred officials have their respective duties, and the ruler does not intervene. Both, through non-action, attain their own fulfillment: the ruler’s Dao is ease, the minister’s Dao is toil. The difference between toil and ease cannot be spoken of on the same day. Without examination, the positions of ruler and minister become disordered.

**General Observations by the Humble Observer:**
When the noble person, out of necessity, oversees and governs the world, nothing is better than non-action. Thus, they cherish preserving the people and forgiving the multitude, never harboring a deliberate mind for governance. Therefore, the people of the world do not stray from their nature, and their virtue does not shift. Those who stand above the people maintain balanced joy and anger, and their rewards and punishments are just. This is because they follow the world’s self-governance and do not labor in governing it. Hence, the people are easy to follow, and the law is not obstructed.

Later rulers of the world lost the essential means to assist the age and nurture the people, instead focusing solely on rewards and punishments. Above, they were entangled in the disputes of Confucians, Mohists, Zeng, and Shi; below, they were bound by cangues, pillories, fetters, and shackles. Those who governed could not bear the toil, and the people had nowhere to place their hands and feet. Yet they still believed that benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom were sufficient to grasp the world’s sentiments, revering and cherishing them, passing them down through families and enacting them in states, never realizing they were tools to obstruct the people. This is why they wished to utterly abandon them.

If one truly heeds these words, then the world’s entrusted affairs and the manifestations of profound thunder lie herein. State governance does not descend into vulgarity, and the people’s hearts do not decay. With unhurried non-action, how would one have the leisure to govern the world?

Next, the questions of Cui and Qu are posed to elicit Lao Dan’s defense, clarifying that the fault in governance lies in disturbing the people’s hearts—this is the origin of cangues, pillories, fetters, and shackles, and the reason why Jie and Zhi profited from them. Thus, the Yellow Emperor sought the Dao from Kong Tong, who taught him the essentials of embracing the spirit, rectifying the form, clarity, and tranquility for long life: the body is the root, the family and state are secondary. There has never been a case where the body was well-governed yet the state was in chaos.

If today’s rulers of the world could vigorously practice the words of Guang Cheng, the governance of the Three Dynasties would not be difficult to restore. Heaven and earth, the officials, yin and yang—all reside within my non-action. This is the Dao of "Presiding and Forgiving." Hong Meng said: "It will cast off the body, dismiss hearing and sight, guard the root, and not depart"—this is the Dao of governing the self.

At the end of the chapter, the discussion of ruler and minister, ritual and law, leaves little unaddressed. It touches on the distinction between the Dao of heaven and the Dao of humanity, which lies in the difference between action and non-action. Though they seem unequal, what arises in the heart and manifests in deeds and undertakings is one and the same.

**Chapter Twelve: Heaven and Earth**
Though heaven and earth are vast, their transformations are uniform. Though the myriad things are numerous, their governance is one. Though the people are many, their lord is the ruler. The ruler originates from virtue and is completed by heaven. Thus, it is said: In high antiquity, those who ruled the world practiced non-action—only the virtue of heaven.

Viewing it through the Dao, the rulers of the world are upright. Viewing it through distinctions, the righteousness of ruler and minister is clear. Viewing it through abilities, the officials of the world are well-ordered. Viewing it broadly through the Dao, the responses of the myriad things are complete. Thus, that which penetrates heaven and earth is virtue; that which moves through the myriad things is the Dao. Governing people above is affairs; having skills is technique. Technique is encompassed by affairs; affairs are encompassed by righteousness; righteousness is encompassed by virtue; virtue is encompassed by the Dao; the Dao is encompassed by heaven. Thus, it is said: Those of old who nurtured the world desired nothing, and the world was sufficient; they acted not, and the myriad things were transformed; they were deep and still, and the hundred clans were settled.

The Record says: "Penetrating the One, all affairs are completed." Without deliberate mind, one obtains it, and spirits submit. (The Record’s origin is the original root; it is said to be the work of Laozi.)

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Heaven and earth are uniform in non-action and self-transformation. The myriad things are governed by self-attainment. The world, though of diverse minds, has the mindless as its lord. Taking virtue as its origin, nothing does not attain it. Attainment is self-attainment, hence it attains without gratitude—this is how heaven is completed. With non-action, one entrusts the natural movement; naturally, one is the ruler—is this not so?

Each abiding in their proper place is non-action in the superior position; action is in the inferior position. Officials each attend to their abilities, hence there is order. With non-action, the world responds with non-action. That which penetrates heaven and earth is virtue—it means the myriad things all attain it. That which moves through the myriad things is the Dao—it means the Dao does not obstruct its course, and the myriad things naturally attain their movement.

Governing people above means enabling each person to attain their own affairs. Technique is the peripheral use of the myriad things. The root and branches encompass each other, like the hand and arm embracing one another. When the body is harmonious, the hundred joints are all at ease; when the Dao of heaven is followed, the root and branches are all smooth. Thus, with one non-action, the governance of all is raised.

Lü’s Annotation:
The vastness of heaven and earth encompasses the myriad transformations, yet they have never reached an end. Though they transform, that by which they transform is uniform—without distinction of great or small, beauty or ugliness, long or short—this is precisely that by which they transform. The Dao gives birth to the One, and from it extends to the myriad things; how then could order arise from this? The One means each returns to its root without awareness—this is that by which order arises. Though the people are numerous, their ruler, the lord, originates from virtue, and thus his transformation pervades the uniformity of heaven and earth. When he completes himself in heaven, his governance reverts to the Oneness of the myriad things. These two are both called the Profound.

The ancients who ruled all under heaven practiced non-action, embodying the virtue of heaven alone. Viewed through the Dao, they never spoke, yet their speech was wordless. Could any lord of all under heaven fail to be upright? Viewed through the Dao, in their roles, non-action was lord and action was minister—could the righteousness of lord and minister ever be unclear? Viewed through the Dao, in their abilities, they were without ability yet lacked no ability—could any official fail to be well-governed? Viewed through the Dao in its ubiquity, there is nothing that is not the Dao—could the responses of the myriad things ever be incomplete?

That by which heaven and earth are heaven and earth is nothing more than attaining this. If a person attains this, their virtue communicates with heaven and earth, and the myriad things are none other than their Dao. The Dao as a thing is so great that those above employ it to govern people—then affairs are merely affairs, and if one has any skill, it is merely technique. Technique is encompassed by affairs, affairs by righteousness, righteousness by virtue, virtue by the Dao, and the Dao by heaven. When it is encompassed by heaven, how could that which nurtures all under heaven lie among technique, ability, affairs, or action?

Thus, when all under heaven is sufficient, when the hundred clans are settled, it is entirely because they communicate with the One, and what they attain is without intention.

Guan’s Observations:
Heaven and earth are supremely great, and the myriad people supremely numerous. Their governance and transformation are beyond reckoning, yet that which presides over them is the lord—how could the lord’s response to the world be mere chance? Originating from virtue, nothing can depart from it. Completing himself in heaven, people naturally turn toward him. His Dao is subtle and wondrous; it is forcibly named the Profound.

Thus, the ancients who ruled all under heaven practiced non-action, and their virtue harmonized with the natural. Viewed through the Dao, in their speech, their words harmonized with the Dao—could any lord fail to be upright? Viewed through the Dao, in their roles, their divisions harmonized with the Dao—could righteousness ever be unclear? Viewed through the Dao, in their abilities, their capacities harmonized with the Dao—could any official fail to be well-governed? Viewed through the Dao in its ubiquity, all things harmonized with the Dao—could their responses ever be incomplete?

From this, we know that in all under heaven, if any affair or thing departs from the Dao, it cannot stand on its own. That which communicates with heaven and earth is virtue—through virtue, one harmonizes with heaven and earth. That which moves through the myriad things is the Dao—through the Dao, one pervades all things. Those who esteem governing people, even if they indulge in punishments, rewards, and governance, are merely engaged in affairs. How much further do they stray from virtue and the Dao when they enter technique through skill?

The ancients who skillfully nurtured all under heaven had no other method: without desire, all under heaven was sufficient; without action, all under heaven transformed itself. Their minds were as still as deep waters—stirred, yet never muddied. How could the people fail to be settled? Communicating with the One, all affairs are complete. This is the teaching of the *Western Ascension*, where Laozi instructs Yin Xi: "Without intention, one attains, and spirits submit." This is what the *Book of Changes* means when it says, "Even heaven does not oppose it—how much less humans, how much less spirits?"

The Master said: The Dao is that which covers and sustains the myriad things—vast and boundless, great indeed! The noble person cannot but hollow out their heart to embrace it. To act without contrivance is called Heaven; to speak without contrivance is called virtue. To love others and benefit things is called humaneness. To harmonize differences without erasing them is called the great practice; to embrace diversity without limit is called magnanimity. To possess ten thousand differences is called abundance. Thus, holding fast to virtue is called discipline; the completion of virtue is called establishment. Following the Dao is called fulfillment; not allowing things to thwart one’s resolve is called wholeness.

The noble person who is enlightened regarding these ten principles will conceal their affairs as though veiled, for their heart is vast. They will act with such ease that the myriad things flow away like water. Such a one hides gold in the mountains and pearls in the abyss, neither coveting wealth nor drawing near to nobility and riches. They do not delight in long life nor mourn early death; they do not take glory in success nor shame in poverty. They do not constrain themselves for the sake of worldly gain, nor do they claim a share of it as private profit. They do not regard ruling the world as their own exalted position. In prominence, they illuminate all things as one treasury; in death and life, they see the same form.

*(The Master said—this continues the preceding as a quoted attestation, likely the recorded saying of Laozi cited above. The following passage, where the Master asks Lao Dan, clearly refers to Confucius.)*

Guo's Commentary:
To have a heart is to burden one’s natural spontaneity—thus it must be hollowed out and discarded. Not acting for this, yet this comes to be; not speaking for these words, yet these words arise of themselves—this is the Dao of Heaven. To love others and benefit things is to entrust them to the natural course of their nature and destiny. The myriad things, the myriad forms, each abide in their allotted place, not drawing others to be the same as oneself—only then is greatness achieved. Conduct that does not diverge into eccentricity is the profound sameness where self and other, the myriad things, naturally find accommodation. Thus, to have surplus is to possess the ten thousand differences—this is called wealth. To say, “I have no difference from them,” is to uniquely possess these ten thousand powers. This is the guiding principle of humanity; what is not accomplished through virtue cannot be called establishment.

“To follow the Dao is called completeness” means that the Dao is not partial to any single thing. Not allowing things to thwart one’s will results in inner self-possession; a great heart accommodates all affairs. Virtue and power overflow abundantly, allowing the myriad things to proceed on their own. Not prizing rare and precious things enables one to forget the self—how much more, then, wealth and property? “Not drawing near to nobility and riches” speaks of what comes and lodges of itself; the heart constantly distances itself from them. To forget both long life and early death is what is called “suspended release.” Having forgotten long life and early death, how much more the distinctions between poverty and success?

Not claiming worldly gain as private profit means entrusting it all to the myriad things. Not regarding ruling the world as one’s own exalted position means that glory, unawares, does not attach to the self. In prominence, one illuminates; in obscurity, one remains silent—this is all. The one treasury, the same form: like a cicada’s molting, there is nowhere it resides.

Lü's Commentary:
The Dao is so vast that a heart not hollowed out cannot embody it. To embody the Dao and act without contrivance is to appear human yet be of Heaven. To love and benefit in this way is called benevolence; to attain unity in this way is called great conduct. Not differing from the common is the utmost in magnanimity; to possess the ten thousand differences is the utmost in wealth. One who holds fast to virtue unites the one and completes the ten thousand, like the main cord that orders the net.

When virtue is perfected, one stands without reliance; when the Dao is within oneself, there is nothing to which one does not respond without completeness. Nothing can topple one who is whole—this is what is meant by “completeness.” The noble person hollows the heart in these ten matters alone. Turning inward to seek, one illuminates the heart’s greatness; when affairs find no obstruction, this is the effect of having hollowed it. Abundantly, the myriad things flow away—circulating without end.

Thus, one hides gold and pearls in mountains and abysses, unaware of the desirability of wealth and profit, nor ashamed of poverty and obscurity. One does not claim the world’s gain as private possession but entrusts it to all under Heaven. Not regarding ruling the world as one’s own exalted position: what benefits things is not oneself. In prominence, one illuminates—illuminating through virtue, not through rank. Dwelling above, one embodies the virtue of emperors and kings; dwelling below, one embodies the Dao of the profound sage and unadorned king. When the myriad things are complete within oneself, they form a single treasury. Whether things are coming to life or dying, dying or coming to life, they share the same form—this is all.

Detailed Explanation of the Dao:
When the myriad things are all complete within me, to possess them and not lose them is wealth. If the guiding cord is disordered, the eyes of the multitude are confused; if virtue is lost, the conduct of the multitude goes astray. Thus, “to follow the Dao is called completeness; not allowing things to thwart one’s will is called wholeness.”

“Veiled, the greatness of the heart’s affairs” refers to grasping the great image. “Abundantly, the myriad things flow away” refers to the world coming to one. Those of old who oversaw the world through the Dao showed without relying on traces, instructed without relying on words, allowing others to attain it themselves. The superior transforms the inferior without the allure of pleasure; the inferior delights in the superior without craving its scent. To hide gold and pearls in mountains and abysses is not to burden the self with things.
