Not calculating long life or early death, poverty or success, is not to sacrifice the Dao for the sake of the self.

Worldly gain is substantial, yet one does not claim it as private profit. The power of all under Heaven is weighty, yet one does not regard it as one’s own exalted position. That the myriad things cannot differ from one, that life and death cannot alter one—could one without a heart accomplish this?

The *Blue Void* states: When it begins with "The Master said," it refers to Zhuangzi receiving the esoteric teachings of Elder Sangong. The Dao is vast and boundless, filling all things; only those whose spirit is empty can contain it. Acting naturally accords with Heaven’s spontaneity, abiding in the center while speaking of the distant, free from discouragement in measuring life and engaging with things—such a heart never retreats. What others detest, I harbor no suspicion toward; harmonizing light with dust, I set no sharp edges, allowing the myriad things to flourish and the world to prosper. Upholding the highest virtue as its guiding principle, following the supreme principle to establish good governance, and aligning with true constancy without deviation—externally reflecting to preserve inner clarity—this is how one tempers the heart. Thus, affairs are all encompassed, principles all embraced, grace all abundant, and things all fulfilled.

Gold, pearls, and wealth are the roots of calamity; longevity or early death, poverty or success, are inner afflictions; private gain and exalted position are emotional maladies. If the heart is bound by even one of these, the will cannot be whole.

*Limited Views* states: Guo Xiang’s interpretation takes "manifest and thus bright" as a complete phrase, and most commentaries follow this, yet it seems disjointed from the following text. Master Fan Wulu connects it to the subsequent passage, which extends the meaning. I follow his approach: "To rule all under Heaven without regarding it as one’s own exaltation"—yet what is exalted does exist, manifesting in the clarity that the myriad things share a single repository, and life and death share the same form. If the myriad things share a single repository, there is no division of self and other; if life and death share the same form, there is no burden of coming or going. Is this not the ultimate achievement of an empty heart?

The Master said: The Dao dwells in profound depths, its clarity flowing like pure water. Metal and stone cannot remain silent; thus, they produce sound, yet without being struck, they do not ring. Who can determine the myriad things? The person of royal virtue moves with simplicity and feels shame in becoming entangled in affairs. Establishing the root and origin, their knowledge connects with the divine. Thus, their virtue is vast, and their heart, though moved by external things, does not precede them. Without the Dao, form does not arise; without virtue, life does not shine. To preserve form, exhaust life, establish virtue, and illuminate the Dao—is this not the person of royal virtue?

Vast and boundless, suddenly emerging, suddenly stirring—all things follow. This is the person of royal virtue. Seeing in darkness, hearing in silence—within darkness, they alone perceive clarity; within silence, they alone hear harmony. Thus, delving deeper and deeper, they can master things; attaining greater and greater spirit, they can refine essence. In their engagement with the myriad things, they are utterly without substance yet fulfill all requests, swiftly meeting their needs, whether great or small, long or short, near or far.

Guo’s commentary: Sound arises from stillness, illustrating that those who embody the Dao respond only when moved by things. Who can determine the myriad things? This speaks of responding to stimuli without fixed direction. The person of royal virtue acts with simplicity, not seeking entanglement in affairs. Establishing the root and origin, their knowledge connects with the divine—only by establishing the root and not opposing it can one act with simplicity and connect with the divine. Their virtue is thus vast, their heart moved by external things, not preceding them. "Suddenly" and "stirring" describe the appearance of responding without intention; since movement arises without intention, all things follow—this is the boundlessness of royal virtue. Thus, they can preserve form, exhaust life, establish virtue, illuminate the Dao, and achieve royal virtue. Seeing in darkness and hearing in silence, perceiving clarity and harmony—if sight and hearing do not rely on stillness, they become dim and discordant. Delving deeper and deeper, exhausting the source, they can then master things; attaining greater and greater spirit, reaching ultimate compliance, they can then exhaust subtlety. I remain still and let things take their course; their needs are naturally fulfilled, freely and without restraint, meeting their ultimate ends.

Lü’s commentary: "Profound in its dwelling" speaks of its depth and immobility; "flowing in its clarity"...

The purity of its speech flows without turbidity—such is the Dao and nothing more. If one deems it absent, even metal and stone cannot sound without it; if one deems it present, metal and stone do not resonate when unstruck. Who can determine this? In its purity, it mingles with nothing; in its passage, it leaves no trace. Not bound to affairs, things become clear and distinct; penetrating the spirit, it pervades the myriad things without obstruction—why then seek to be "bound to affairs"? The root is the Dao; affairs are its branches. Establish the root, and affairs naturally flow—this is the heart not seizing upon things, abiding in stillness alone, neither pursuing nor resisting, responding without hoarding.

The ear hears, the eye sees, the mouth speaks, the heart thinks—none of these are not the Dao. Yet if form does not follow the Dao, life does not arise; if daily use does not recognize it, the power within me cannot be illuminated. Thus, life is not virtue, nor is it clarity. Only by preserving form, exhausting life, establishing virtue, and illuminating the Dao does it rest within me, grasped and wielded to govern the present with the ancient.

Suddenly emerging and moving, the myriad things follow—this is the hidden, unanticipated arising of the heart, never contrived by force. Though the Dao as a thing cannot be seen, it is the very source of seeing; though it cannot be heard, it is the very source of hearing. Profound and able to encompass things, within it lies something tangible; spirit-like and able to refine, within it lies essence. Utterly formless yet supplying all needs, its richness is the inexhaustible treasury of heaven. Racing through time and seizing its lodging, whether great or small, long or short, distant or near, its allotment is never insufficient—this is what the *Yi* means by "each settling into its nature and destiny, preserving the great harmony."

Fu Mo’s commentary: "Metal and stone cannot sound without it; metal and stone do not resonate when unstruck"—does resonance belong to the Dao, or does the striking belong to the Dao? Who can determine this? If one fixes it in the unstruck metal and stone, why do they not sound? If one fixes it in the striking, other sounds should be the same as metal and stone. If one fixes it in emptiness, why does striking produce no sound? Such questioning urges deep reflection to attain understanding. "Pure passage" means its flowing through the myriad things is passage itself—unadulterated, unified, flowing and unobstructed.

The "pure passage" is emptiness, stillness, tranquility, quiescence, and non-action—never sinking into the midst of affairs or their appearances. Thus it is said: "It is ashamed to be entangled in affairs." Yet when one establishes the root and origin, grasping the essential Dao, one’s knowledge naturally communicates with the numinous. Therefore, one’s virtue is vast and sufficient to rule all under Heaven. That which gives me life is the Dao; that which illuminates me is virtue. When virtue is taken as illumination, illumination reaches its utmost. Yet the Dao and virtue are not two: originating from Heaven, it is the Dao—this is establishing the root and origin; attained within oneself, it is virtue—this is the knowledge that communicates with the numinous. Preserving one’s form and exhausting one’s life, the root and origin are established; establishing one’s virtue and illuminating the Dao, the kingly virtue is vast. Thus it is further praised: "Vast and boundless!" Suddenly emerging, suddenly moving, and the myriad things follow—truly, its flowing through the myriad things is inexhaustible. "Utterly non-being yet supplying every demand" means emptiness without depletion, movement yielding ever more, non-action yet nothing left undone. "Ranging freely and returning to its lodging" means that passage is called "far-reaching," and far-reaching is called "return"; extreme movement reverts to stillness. Some are great yet suddenly small, long yet suddenly short, or short yet suddenly long and distant—such is the person of kingly virtue.

The Yellow Emperor roamed north of the Red Water, ascended the heights of Mount Kunlun, and gazed southward. Upon returning, he lost his dark pearl. He sent Knowledge to seek it, but it was not found; he sent Li Zhu to seek it, but it was not found; he sent Chi Gou to seek it, but it was not found. Then he sent Xiang Wang, and Xiang Wang found it. The Yellow Emperor said, "How strange! Only Xiang Wang could obtain it!"

Guo’s commentary: This illustrates how one attains the true. To say that knowledge is insufficient to grasp the true, that keen hearing and sharp sight lead one further from the true—Xiang Wang obtained it, showing that attaining the true does not rely on the mind. Xiang Wang is the true itself.

Lü’s commentary: The north of the Red Water symbolizes the ultimate of the mysterious; Mount Kunlun is the highest within form. Gazing southward is to observe toward the light. The pearl, as a thing, cannot be sought through knowledge or recognition, so all attempts failed. Xiang, however, is not nothing; Wang is not something—neither being nor non-being, neither distinct nor obscure. This is how the dark pearl is obtained.

Yao’s teacher was Xu You; Xu You’s teacher was Nie Que; Nie Que’s teacher was Wang Ni; Wang Ni’s teacher was Pi Yi. Yao asked Xu You, "Could Nie Que be fit to match Heaven? I would rely on Wang Ni to assess him." Xu You said, "How perilous! How precarious! Nie Que’s nature is keen, wise, quick, and sharp—surpassing others. Yet he takes what he receives from man as if it were from Heaven. He scrutinizes prohibitions against transgressions but does not know the source of transgressions. Could such a one match Heaven? Moreover, he rides upon man rather than Heaven, bases himself on the body yet differs in form, exalts knowledge and races like fire, acts as a taskmaster, becomes entangled in things, looks in all directions and responds to them, adapts to every circumstance, and transforms with things yet has no constancy. How could he be fit to match Heaven? Nevertheless, he has clan and ancestry and can serve as a father to the multitude—but not as the father of fathers, for he is a leader in times of order and chaos. This is the calamity of facing north."

The bane of facing south.

Guo's commentary: "To 'match Heaven' means to be the Son of Heaven. Being overly keen and quick surpasses others, yet this causes people to strain toward him, repeatedly harming others. Taking what he receives from man as if it were from Heaven—this is using knowledge to seek a return to one's natural state. Transgressions arise from keenness and wisdom, yet he further employs knowledge to prohibit them, making his transgressions all the more severe. Thus it is said: 'There are no transgressions when knowledge is abandoned, not when prohibitions are enforced.' Riding upon man rather than Heaven—this speaks of granting him the world and letting later generations rely on knowledge while losing their true nature. If one takes the myriad things as the root, then the transformations of the multitude can be unified, and differing forms can be harmonized—this is the path. Yet if later generations are made to follow his example in controlling things, the myriad things will fall into disorder. 'Exalting knowledge and racing like fire'—this means that when the worthy hold positions at the forefront, knowledge and perception are exalted behind them, leading to frantic competition and fiery haste. 'Acting as a taskmaster'—this will give rise to the beginnings of later generations being enslaved by affairs. 'Becoming entangled in things'—this will lead later generations to be constrained and controlled by things. 'Looking in all directions and responding to things'—this will result in later generations directing and moving things with gestures, commanding responses and managing tasks. 'Adapting to every circumstance'—this will cause later generations to be unable to forget goodness and benefit others by responding to every circumstance. 'Transforming with things'—this will lead later generations to chase after things and lose their inner constancy. All these are expedient for the moment, yet today one receives their virtue, and tomorrow one bears their harm. Thus it is said: 'having no constancy.' 'Having clan and ancestry'—this means his deeds can be traced and imitated, leaving the mark of a father to the multitude. Yet a father of fathers is one who leaves the mark of marks. If one grants him the world, he will not merely be a ruler in times of order but a leader in times of chaos. Jie and Zhou were not able to kill worthy ministers; rather, they relied on the traces of sagely wisdom to bring them calamity. Tian Heng was not able to kill his lord; rather, he used benevolence and righteousness to harm him. Thus it is said: 'the calamity of facing north, the bane of facing south.'"

Lü's commentary: "His nature surpasses others, yet he does not dismiss keenness and abandon knowledge to act only when unavoidable. Taking what he receives from man as if it were from Heaven—this means he is not wholly aligned with Heaven. He scrutinizes prohibitions against transgressions but does not know their source, believing this aligns with non-action and matches Heaven. How could he not thereby discard Heaven for man? Basing himself on the body yet differing in form—this means he cannot be without self. Exalting knowledge and racing like fire—this means he cannot abandon knowledge, thus becoming enslaved by the world, entangled by things yet unable to free himself. Looking in all directions and responding to things—this is not sitting in stillness and letting the people act without knowing where to turn. Moreover, adapting to every circumstance—this is not establishing the root and origin, nor knowing the divine in all things. Thus he transforms with things yet has no constancy. How could he be fit to match Heaven?"

Personal observation: "Nie Que is keen, wise, and quick—his nature surpasses others. This discusses his talent but does not speak of his Dao. Taking what he receives from man as if it were from Heaven—this means he still engages in action to seek alignment with non-action. He scrutinizes prohibitions against transgressions but does not know their source. If one grants him the world, he will ride upon the traces of action to govern the people, causing the world to lose its natural nature. Basing himself on the body yet differing in form—this is like the liver and gallbladder being as distant as Chu and Yue. Exalting knowledge and racing like fire—this is the urgency of schemes and calculations. Acting as a taskmaster—this means being enslaved by affairs. Becoming entangled in things—this means being hindered by things. Looking in all directions and responding to things—this means not forgetting others. Adapting to every circumstance—this means not forgetting things. Transforming with things—this means chasing after things and changing with them. Having no constancy—this means losing one's original self. How could he be fit to match Heaven? Nevertheless, having clan and ancestry—this means Nie Que's learning also has its lineage and lord, and he has generally heard the Dao. He can serve as a father to the multitude but not as the father of fathers."

Yao observed this. The border guard of Huahua said, "Ah! Sage, I offer a blessing to you. May the sage live long!" Yao said, "I decline." "May the sage be wealthy!" Yao said, "I decline." "May the sage have many sons!" Yao said, "I decline." The border guard said, "Long life, wealth, and many sons—these are what all people desire. Why do you alone not desire them?" Yao said, "Many sons bring many fears; wealth brings many affairs; long life brings many humiliations. These three are not means to cultivate virtue, so I decline." The border guard said, "At first, I took you for a sage, but now you are merely a gentleman. Heaven gives birth to the myriad people and must assign them duties. If one has many sons and assigns them duties, what fear is there? If one is wealthy and lets others share it, what affairs are there? The sage dwells like a quail and eats like a fledgling, moves like a bird and leaves no trace. When the world has the Dao, he flourishes with all things; when the world lacks the Dao, he cultivates virtue and retreats into seclusion. After a thousand years, weary of the world, he departs and ascends as an immortal, riding the white clouds to the realm of the Emperor. The three calamities do not reach him, and his body remains free from harm—what humiliation is there?" The border guard departed, and Yao followed him, saying, "May I ask a question?" The border guard said, "Withdraw."

Guo's commentary: "Having many sons and assigning them duties ensures all things find their place and minds are settled. Being wealthy and entrusting it to the world means having no affairs. Dwelling like a quail means having no intention to seek comfort; eating like a fledgling means relying on things to be sufficient. Moving in accordance with one's nature leaves no extraordinary traces. Flourishing with all things—this is acting wildly and treading the great square. Cultivating virtue and retreating into seclusion—even the affairs of Tang and Wu, if they accord with Heaven and respond to people, are not without their intervals. The perfected person exhausts the length of life and embraces the changes of fortune. In life, they follow Heaven; in death, they transform with things. Weary of the world, ascending as an immortal, riding the clouds to the realm of the Emperor—this is the dispersal of the single qi, which reaches everywhere."

Lü's commentary: "The sage exhausts the Dao of Heaven, thus their body aligns with transformation, and things cannot burden them. The gentleman exhausts the Dao of man, thus fortune and misfortune are shared with the people. Long life, wealth, and many sons—though desired by all, one cannot but decline them due to the many affairs, fears, and humiliations they bring. Yao did not fail to exhaust the Dao of Heaven; his alignment with others was merely exhausting the Dao of man. Dwelling like a quail means not knowing where one resides; eating like a fledgling means not knowing where one's food comes from. Moving like a bird and leaving no trace means their path is unseen. The theories of immortals seek it through diet and breath control, but世儒 regard them as mad and do not believe them—both are mistaken. Those who embrace the spirit in life will also embrace the spirit in death. Those who preserve Heaven in life will also preserve Heaven in death. The *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents* both speak of 'being in Heaven.' Why then doubt ascending as an immortal? Yao was not someone who clung to appearances or was seen as such by others, so the border guard's withdrawal was what he embodied."

】 The "Secondary Ink" [asks]: *What is meant by "dwelling like a quail, eating like a fledgling, moving like a bird and leaving no trace"?*

The quail has no fixed dwelling; the fledgling depends on its mother’s feeding; the bird flies through empty space, passing without a trace—all embody the intent of effortless spontaneity. The sage’s mind in navigating the world is likewise.

The *Three Calamities* refer to what the Buddhist scriptures call the *Three Disasters*: water, fire, and wind.

When Yao ruled the world, Bo Cheng Zi Gao was enfeoffed as a lord. When Yao ceded the throne to Shun, and Shun to Yu, Bo Cheng Zi Gao resigned his lordship to till the soil. Yu went to see him and found him plowing in the fields. Yu hastened to stand downwind and asked: *"In the past, when Yao ruled the world, you were enfeoffed as a lord. Yao ceded to Shun, Shun ceded to me, yet you resigned your lordship to plow. May I ask the reason?"*

Zi Gao replied: *"In the past, when Yao ruled the world, he did not reward, yet the people were encouraged; he did not punish, yet the people stood in awe. Now you reward and punish, yet the people grow ever less humane. Virtue declines from this; punishments arise from this; the chaos of later ages begins from this. Sir, depart—do not hinder my work!"* He bent low, *yi yi*, and plowed on without looking back.

[The *Tongbian Jing* of Bo Cheng Zi Gao states: *"Since the opening of heaven and earth, my body has undergone one thousand three hundred transformations. Those of later ages who attain the Dao—Bo Cheng Zi Gao is one such."* "Do not hinder my work" means "do not interrupt my plowing." *Yi yi* describes the posture of bowing one’s head to till the soil.]

Guo’s commentary: *In Yu’s time, three sages succeeded one another, governance was perfected, virtue was complete, and merit was consummate—gradually receding, hence the historians had nothing to record. Confucius could find no gap to intervene, and thus, though Yu possessed the world, he did not partake in it. This is the presence that is absence. Thus, when assessing the era, Yu was the most excellent; when evaluating the men, though three sages, they were but one Yao. The age lacked sages, so the world’s heart suddenly turned to Qi. The utmost impartiality in occupying the throne is to entrust the world to the people—taking and giving are not one’s own. Thus, to lose it is not sought; to gain it is not refused. It comes in a flash, departs in simplicity. Therefore, though he was slandered by men of integrity and frugality, and his name ranks among the Three Kings, it is no wonder. Zhuangzi uses this to illustrate Yao’s flaws—flaws that began with Yao and were completed by Yu. How much more so for later ages without sages? He projects distant traces onto Zi Gao, making him abandon governance and not rule, intending to "cut off sagacity and return to unity, discard knowledge and attain tranquility." Yet in truth, this was never heard of. Zhuangzi’s words cannot be confined to a single path. Some trace the steps of the Yellow Emperor, some shave the shins of Yao and Shun—how could he merely exalt Yao and disparage Yu? Thus, one must set aside what he projects and record his intent to "cut off sagacity and discard knowledge."*】

At the Great Beginning, there was Non-Being; Non-Being had no Having, no name. From Unity all things arise. There was Unity, yet no form—things came to life through it, and this was called "virtue." Before form, there were divisions, yet no gaps—this was called "destiny." When movement abides and living things are born, and when things attain completion and life’s patterns emerge, this is called "form." When form embodies spirit, each possessing its own standard, this is called "nature." When nature is cultivated and returns to virtue, and when virtue reaches its fullness to merge with the Beginning, this merging is called "emptiness." Emptiness is vastness. The cries of beaks harmonize; the harmony of beaks merges with Heaven and Earth. Their merging is seamless, like a thread passing through—seeming foolish, seeming dim. This is called "mystic virtue," aligning with the Great Compliance.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
Non-Being has no Having, thus nothing to name. Unity is the inception of Having, the subtlest of all. Being subtlest, it has no physical pattern or form. That from which Unity arises arises from Supreme Unity, not from Non-Being. Yet why does Zhuangzi repeatedly invoke Non-Being at the origin? The origin is that which, before birth, attains birth—the difficulty of attaining birth lies neither in relying on Non-Being above nor in depending on knowledge below. It arises suddenly and spontaneously. Why then strive for life after life has already arisen, thereby losing its self-generated nature? Non-Being cannot create things, yet it is said that things come to life through it—this clarifies that the life of things is self-attained. To allow their self-attainment is what is called "virtue." Virtue, form, nature, and destiny are names established through transformation, yet in their self-so nature, they are one. When nature is cultivated and returns to virtue, it constantly attains itself through non-action, unlike the Beginning. If one acts midway, one’s embrace is filled with things. With things, even if one nurtures them, virtue diminishes. To speak without intention and yet speak is to harmonize with the cries of beaks. The harmony of beaks merges with Heaven and Earth, for Heaven and Earth also act without intention. Their merging is seamless, a merging of sitting-forgetting, not a merging through discernment. This is called "mystic virtue." When virtue is mystic, what it complies with is vast.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
Non-Being makes even Unity unattainable. Without a name, it is the arising of Unity, yet formless—the beginning of Heaven and Earth. Having already called it Unity, how can it remain nameless? This is what allows things to come to life, and thus it is called "virtue," the mother of the myriad things. That which is unformed has divisions yet no gaps—this is called "destiny," which admits no separation from the unformed. Only when movement abides and living things are born, and when things attain completion and life’s patterns emerge, is this called "form." When form embodies spirit without loss, each possessing its own standard without error, this is called "nature"—which does not lose what comes after form. There is nothing else to this: all things equally attain Unity to gain life, thus having divisions yet no gaps. Nature preserves spirit without loss, and spirit pervades the myriad things, filling Heaven and Earth. Therefore, when nature is cultivated and returns to virtue, it merges with the formless Unity. When virtue reaches its fullness to merge with the Beginning, even Non-Being becomes unattainable. This merging is emptiness; emptiness becomes vastness. Its vastness reaches the state before things ever existed. When vastness attains such non-differentiation, speaking in terms of non-action, the harmony of beaks merges. The harmony of beaks communicates with Heaven and Earth, merging with them. Between Heaven and Earth, it is like a bellows. The harmony of beaks merging with Heaven and Earth is like this. Their merging is seamless, not a merging sought after, nor a merging through knowledge or perception. This is called "mystic virtue," which originates in virtue and is completed by Heaven. Aligning with the Great Compliance means encountering nothing contrary.

**Liu’s Annotation:**
The Great Beginning is the inception of qi, thus there is Non-Being. The Great Commencement is the inception of form, thus there is no name. From Unity all things arise, and then there are names. Though Unity has no form, things come to life through it because of Unity. Before form, it is undifferentiated—it can be called undifferentiated, yet it already has divisions. "Moreover" does not imply long-lasting stability. "No gaps" means beginning and end are like a ring, seamless and unpointable. Within it lies essence; within it lies sincerity—this is what is meant by "before form, there are divisions." To establish virtue stealthily is what is meant by "moreover." To exist continuously without gaps is what is meant by "seamless." Yet when destiny descends, if it does not abide, it is insufficient to generate things. If it abides but does not move, it is sufficient to generate things but not the myriad things. When it abides, it is not without movement; when it moves, it does not harm its abiding—thus it can generate things. When things attain completion and life’s patterns emerge, this is called "form." When form embodies spirit, each possessing its own standard, this is called "nature." With life comes nature. When nature is obscured, one can know Heaven. Knowing Heaven, one returns to virtue. When virtue is perfected, it merges with the Dao.

**Following the Text:**
A question is posed: "At the Great Beginning, was there...?"

"Was there nothing?" The answer: "There was no 'having,' nor even this name. Yet within this 'nothing,' the One arises from it—there is the One, only not yet manifest or visible. This is what is called 'the Ultimateless and yet the Great Ultimate.' All things receiving this to be born is called 'virtue.' In its unmanifest state, the myriad principles are already complete, each with its own order and pattern, capable of distinction—yet for now, it is called 'destiny' precisely because it remains undifferentiated and seamless. When it abides, it cannot but move to generate things; each thing, once formed with its life-patterns, is called 'form.' When form embodies the primordial spirit, each possessing its own standard, this is called 'nature'—what is meant by 'each thing possessing a Great Ultimate.' Cultivating nature returns one to virtue; when virtue reaches its utmost, it merges with the unmanifest beginning. This merging is emptiness—emptiness of emptiness—where there is no right or wrong, no self or other. All in the world that clamor and contend with their beaks are united as one. When beaks are united in silence, they merge with Heaven and Earth—coiled like a thread drawn taut, seamlessly joined, appearing foolish, appearing dim, describing the meaning of union. Profound virtue is deep and wondrous; great compliance is following the natural without imposing the self."

*Oral Exegesis:*
"When beaks are united, there is no speech; when they cry out, there is speech. The 'union' of beaks and cries differs from the earlier 'union.' Here, the cries of beaks, though silent, become speech—thus merging with the natural. This natural union then merges with Heaven and Earth. Hence it is said, 'beaks united, coiled like a thread,' appearing foolish, appearing dim, describing this 'union.' This is profound and wondrous virtue, one with great compliance—the principle of the Great Beginning's naturalness."

Confucius asked Lao Dan: "There is one who practices the Way as if imitating—affirming what should not be affirmed, denying what should not be denied. A debater once said, 'Separating hardness and whiteness is like suspending a screen—so clear and evident.' Can such a one be called a sage?"

Lao Dan replied: "This is but a clerk’s skill, bound by technique, exhausting the body and disturbing the mind. A dog held on a leash grows anxious; a monkey’s agility, once brought from the mountains, becomes its trap. I tell you what you cannot hear and speak of what you cannot utter: all those with heads and feet yet without minds or ears are many. Those with form cannot compare with the formless and shapeless, which yet all endure—none of their movements or stillness, their deaths or lives, their rises or falls, belong to their own doing. Is governance in man, or in forgetting things, forgetting Heaven? Its name is 'forgetting the self.' One who forgets the self is called 'entering into Heaven.'"

*Xuanfang’s note:*
"Clear as a suspended room before one’s eyes." *Liu* (留) is also written as *li* (狸); one says, "a dog held on a leash grows anxious." *Bian* (便) means agility, as in being captured.

*Guo’s commentary:*
"Imitating and forcing the unallowable to be allowable, the unso to be so—this distorts one’s nature. 'Suspended screen' speaks of its loftiness and clarity. A dog held on a leash, a monkey’s agility—these lose their natural state. 'Heads and feet' are like beginnings and ends; 'without mind or ears' means self-transformation. Those with form are prone to change and cannot endure alongside the formless and shapeless. Thus, one who excels in the Way does not cling to old patterns but follows the daily renewal of transformation. Their movements and stillness, deaths and lives, flourishing and decline, rising and falling—none have constancy, all arise naturally, not by their own doing. Let go, and they attain spontaneity. Governance lies in man, not in self-assertion. Forgetting things and Heaven, what remains but the self? If even the self is forgotten, what more is there to know? This is unknowing and unperceiving, yet merging with the natural—called 'entering into Heaven.'"

*Bixu’s note:*
"Affirming the unallowable, denying the unso—adorned knowledge seeking difference. The debate over 'separating hardness and whiteness' is like suspending the heavens, making all clear. Exchanging falsehoods, bound by skill, wearying the body and startling the mind—like a hunting dog on a leash or a monkey in a cage, all suffer from their own abilities. 'Heads and feet' are visible forms; 'without mind or ears'—their intent is unknowable. Without ears, they cannot hear; without minds, they cannot speak. Those with form have heads and feet; the formless and shapeless have no mind or ears. Yet all endure—'none' is also without end. Their movements and stillness, deaths and lives, rises and falls—none belong to their own doing. Where does one return? Governance lies in man—self-governance alone. Forget things, and you merge with them; forget Heaven, and you merge with it; forget the self, and you become undivided. What is there you cannot enter?"

*Bisheng:*
"'As if imitating' means resembling. Confucius asked Lao Dan: 'There is one whose dwelling in the Way seems to resemble the sage—affirming what others deny, denying what others affirm. A skilled debater once said, "Dissecting hardness and whiteness is like holding up the heavens—clear for all to see." Can such a one be called a sage?' What you cannot hear, what hearing does not reach; what you cannot speak, what speech does not attain."

"Now, that which is without mind, without ears, without form, without shape—this the world knows to be nothing. Yet if one has a head and feet but is without mind and ears, possessing form yet without form or shape, and you utterly negate all these, where then can your hearing and speech be applied? However, what I call 'utterly negating' does not mean that movements and stillness, deaths and lives, rises and falls all differ from those of others. When others move, one moves; when others are still, one is still; when others live or die, one lives or dies; when others rise or fall, one rises or falls—yet ultimately, one cannot be called 'having' these, for one has forgotten them. Having forgotten things, and then forgotten Heaven—from which things arise—when both are forgotten, this is the utmost of forgetting. Such is called 'forgetting the self.' What distinguishes man from Heaven is his having a self. When the self is forgotten, what is this if not Heaven? This is called 'entering into Heaven'—none but the sage can achieve this. The later phrase 'governance lies in man' responds to the earlier 'one whose governance of the Way seems to resemble [the sage].' The meaning is quite clear."

Jiang Lümen *[note: "Mian"]* saw Jiche and said: "The Lord of Lu said to me, 'I request your instruction.' I could not refuse and have already spoken, but I do not know if it was appropriate. Allow me to present it to you. I said to the Lord of Lu: 'You must practice reverence and frugality, elevate those who are publicly spirited and loyal, and eliminate partiality and self-interest. Then who among the people would dare not be harmonious?' Jiche laughed heartily and said: 'If this is what you advise, then your words on the virtue of emperors and kings are like a mantis raising its arms to block a chariot’s wheel—it will surely not suffice. Moreover, if one acts thus, one’s own position will be perilous, and the observation tower will be crowded with those who come to cast their lots.' Jiang Lümen was startled and said: 'I am utterly bewildered by your words. Nevertheless, I wish to hear the drift of your teaching.'"

Jiche said: "When the Great Sage governs the world, he stirs and sways the people’s hearts, shaping them into teachings and transforming their customs. He eradicates their predatory minds and advances their solitary aspirations, as if these arose from their very nature, and the people remain unaware of how this comes to be. If this is so, how could one regard Yao and Shun’s teachings as an elder brother and this Way as a younger sibling? One would rather seek unity in virtue while keeping the mind at rest."

[Alternative readings: *Jiang* as *Jiang Lümen*, *Mian* as *Tun*; *ji* (輯) in *Er Ya* means "harmony"; *huòhuò* () denotes laughter, *xìxì* (覤覤) denotes alarm. *Yaodang* (摇荡) means "to stir like dancing."]

Guo’s commentary: ["One must practice reverence and frugality" does not mean forgetting frugality while being frugal, nor does "elevating the publicly spirited and loyal" mean forgetting loyalty while being loyal. Thus, though one eliminates partiality and self-interest, this is insufficient to counter the task of deceit. These are all ways of placing oneself on high, like a towering observation platform visible to all, compelling things to exceed their natural bounds and straining to multiply attachments. This is like raising one’s feet to cast lots—abandoning one’s foundational steps. Each mind has its own inclinations; they cannot be imitated. Therefore, if one stirs them by following their own stirring, though they are stirred, it is not by force. If one sways them by following their own swaying, though they are swayed, it is not by movement. Thus, their predatory minds are naturally eradicated, and their solitary aspirations naturally advance. Teachings are established, customs transformed, and all is harmonious without trace. Nature is restored, and all acts as if of its own accord, unaware of its origins. All say, "This is natural." *Mingxing* (溟涬) means self-valuing—one does not humbly defer to Yao and Shun, nor does one regard them as an elder brother. "Keeping the mind at rest" means not pursuing externals; if the mind is not at rest, virtue is not unified.]

Lü’s commentary: ["One must practice reverence and frugality" refers to restraining one’s nature to observe the people, which endangers one’s own position. "Elevating the publicly spirited and loyal" refers to exalting the worthy, which multiplies the observation platforms. If this is so, one cannot avoid leaving traces, and those who come to cast their lots will be many. When the Great Sage governs the world, he stirs and sways the people’s hearts, shaping them into teachings and transforming their customs—this is what is meant by "drumming and dancing them to exhaust their spirit." If the people do not peer at the traces left by their superiors to follow them, their predatory minds are eradicated, and their solitary aspirations advance as if by nature, unaware of how this comes to be. If this is so, virtue surpasses Yao and Shun, and one does not act as if regarding their teachings as an elder brother, humbly following as a younger sibling. One seeks unity in virtue while keeping the mind at rest; with the mind at rest, there is non-action, and the myriad things are transformed.]

Detailed Daoist commentary: ["One must practice reverence and frugality" is not non-action. "Elevating the publicly spirited and loyal" is exalting the worthy. The virtue of emperors and kings lies in non-action, so the world has no weariness from reverence; not exalting the worthy, so the world has no striving for superiority. Thus, one stirs them by following their own stirring and sways them by following their own swaying. Their predatory minds are thereby eradicated, and their solitary knowledge daily advances, as if by nature, while the people remain unaware of its origins. Now, if one forces reverence, frugality, and the elevation of the publicly spirited as tasks, this is to open the people’s Heaven and guide their predatory minds, to obstruct Heaven’s Heaven and diminish their solitary aspirations. How far is this from the virtue of emperors and kings? Delicacies may please and halt the passerby, but their benefit is fleeting and cannot last. Foam may be insufficient, yet it does not cause forgetfulness; its benefit is slight but all-encompassing. This is why the spirit-like person dislikes the multitude’s arrival and holds to the Great Image, so the world comes to them. As for drumming up the mantis’s raised arms or setting up the perilous form of an observation tower to make people rush together and cast their lots—is this not the logic of delicacies and foam? In the past, Shun was burdened by his sagacity, Liezi was startled by the gift of broth, Nanguozi was troubled by his knowledge being sold, and Gengsang Chu was vexed by his roles in the altars of soil and grain. The key lies in dwelling in shade to rest one’s shadow and abiding in stillness to quiet one’s traces—only then is perfection attained.]

Fang Sishan’s note: [By *mingxing*, he refers to the era of primordial chaos and governance through non-action, which is to say, the "Great Unity" of the "Canon of Yao" chapter. Such governance surpasses that of Yao and Shun; Yao and Shun’s teachings involve action, hence the question: "How could one regard Yao and Shun’s teachings as an elder brother and this Way as a younger sibling?" The phrasing is extraordinary, yet the meaning is clear. Some among the various commentaries say it means "self-valuing," others "bowing one’s head in humility," and still others "no distinction"—these seem to miss the mark.]

Zigong traveled south to Chu and, on his return to Jin, passed through Hanyin. There he saw an old man working in his vegetable garden. The man had dug a tunnel to enter a well, where he embraced a jar to draw water for irrigation. He toiled strenuously but accomplished little. Zigong said: "There is a device here that can irrigate a hundred furrows in a day, requiring little effort but yielding great results. Would you not like to use it?" The gardener looked up at him and said: "How does it work?" Zigong replied: "Carve wood into a machine—heavy at the back, light at the front—so that drawing water is like pulling a rope, swift as boiling over. Its name is a *gao* (桔槔)." The gardener flushed with anger, his expression changed, and he laughed: "I have heard from my teacher that those who use machines inevitably engage in machinations, and those who engage in machinations inevitably harbor a machinating mind. When a machinating mind resides in the breast, purity is incomplete. When purity is incomplete, the spirit is unsettled. When the spirit is unsettled, the Way cannot bear it. I am not ignorant of this—I am ashamed to do it." Zigong was taken aback, ashamed, and bowed his head without responding. After a while, the gardener said: "What are you doing?" Zigong replied: "I am a disciple of Confucius." The gardener said: "Are you not that learned man who compares himself to the sages, who struts about to overshadow the multitude, who sings mournful songs to sell your reputation throughout the world? You would do better to forget your spirit and vitality, cast off your bodily form, and perhaps approach something. Yet you cannot even govern yourself—how do you have leisure to govern the world? Be on your way!"

Zigong, abashed and crestfallen, his countenance wan and unsettled, walked thirty *li* before recovering. His disciples then asked: "Who was that man we met earlier? Why did you, Master, change your expression and lose composure, remaining unsettled for the rest of the day?"

Zigong replied: "At first, I thought there was but one man in the world—yet I did not know there was also such a man as this. I have heard from the Master that the Way of the sage seeks what is feasible, achieves what is complete, and expends little effort to yield great results. Yet this is not so in practice. Those who hold to the Way attain full virtue; those with full virtue attain full bodily form; those with full bodily form attain full spirit; and those with full spirit embody the Way of the sage. They entrust their lives to the people, moving alongside them without knowing where they go—vast and whole! They must forget the heart of that man, who neither pursues nor rejects what lies beyond his will, nor acts against his own mind. Though the world may praise him, he remains unmoved by what they call lofty; though the world may condemn him, he remains untroubled by what they call loss. Neither the world’s praise nor blame adds to or detracts from him—such is the man of complete virtue! Yet I am but a man tossed by the winds and waves."

Returning to Lu, he told Confucius what had transpired. Confucius said: "That man feigns the arts of Hundun. He grasps one aspect but not the other, cultivating his inner self while neglecting the outer. Those who embody clarity, enter simplicity, practice non-action, return to uncarved simplicity, embrace their nature, and hold fast to spirit while wandering among the common folk—you would be startled by such a one? Moreover, the arts of Hundun—how could you or I presume to understand them?"

[Textual variants: *Yitang* and Sima Biao’s edition read *yidang*, describing swift movement like a well-sweep. *Shi* glosses *man* as a look of shame, *yu yu* (or *yu xu*) as a demeanor of boastfulness, and *xu xu* as a state of self-loss.]

Guo’s commentary:
What is useful in its time is true wholeness. This man seeks wholeness by clinging to oneness and upholding antiquity, yet misses the point. Without forgetting or relinquishing, there is no path to approximation. "One man" refers to Confucius. The Way of the sage is simply the heart of the common people. Full spirit is the Way of the sage-king, not that of such a man. Zigong, hearing his feigned cultivation, was convinced, unaware that purity and wholeness are the same. This is like the followers of Song Rongzi, who fall short of complete virtue. Zigong’s confusion mirrors Liezi’s intoxication with Ji Xian. Confucius, recognizing his turn from the present toward the past and his preoccupation with worldly affairs, knew he was not a true Hundun. He merely emulates antiquity, clinging to the simplicity of uncarved wood, yet fails to adapt to the times and respond to things with ease. The true Hundun does not cultivate at all—how could he distinguish between inner and outer, favoring one over the other? Those who embody clarity, enter simplicity, practice non-action, return to uncarved simplicity, embrace their nature, and hold fast to spirit while wandering among the common folk are the true Hundun. Thus, moving with the world without losing themselves, though they wander among the common folk, they leave no trace—why should they startle you? Hundun and darkness are one—who can comprehend them? What the world recognizes is merely their outward form.

Lü’s Annotation: [To wield antiquity in governing the present is to make every daily act a technique of Hundun—why must one return to the primordial beginning of Heaven and Earth? Those who employ machinery and machinations, who engage in mechanical affairs and harbor mechanical minds, fail to see that the origin of the mechanical mind lies in a state where things have not yet arisen. Thus, they recognize one aspect but miss the other. Those who claim to forget spirit and qi, to cast off the body and its form in pursuit of the wholeness of virtue and the Dao, yet believe the Dao operates only within and not without, are merely cultivating the inner while neglecting the outer. "Clarity entering simplicity, wandering among the common folk"—this is what is meant by "discarding the mind and employing the form." When he first heard Zigong’s words, he was enraged, but later he laughed. It is fitting that he saw machinery as a burden and refused to engage in it, for it is through "not recognizing, not knowing" that one becomes Hundun. This chapter discusses the Heavenly virtue of non-action, yet lest some suppose non-action must resemble the Old Man of Hanyin, it clarifies that the true technique of Hundun is to wander among the common folk without being burdened by them.]

Xun’s Exegesis: [The phrase "like boiling water" describes swiftness, as when water boils over. "Pure white" refers to the original, unadulterated quality. "Dull-eyed" depicts a lack of vitality in the gaze. "Yu-yu" is a grammatical particle, akin to the colloquial "zai-hu" used to mock scholars. "Singing alone in sorrow" describes one who elevates their tone to make their voice resound across the world, all to sell their reputation. "Humble and self-effacing" means to keep to a lowly corner. "Feigning the technique of Hundun" is to falsely claim adherence to Hundun’s methods. Hundun is the Supreme Polarity. "Recognizing one but not the other" means fixating on a single aspect without duality. "Cultivating the inner but not the outer" is to attain self-mastery while forgetting the external world. The Old Man is one who embodies clarity, returns to simplicity, practices non-action, restores uncarved simplicity, embraces his nature, holds fast to spirit, and wanders among the common folk. Zigong’s learning was not equal to this, so he was bound to be startled. Moreover, neither you nor I can comprehend the technique of Hundun—is it not fitting that he was startled? By invoking Confucius’s words, the text clarifies that Hundun ought to be preserved in its entirety.]

Zhunmang was traveling east to the Great Abyss when he encountered Yuanfeng on the shores of the Eastern Sea. Yuanfeng asked, "Where are you going?" "To the Great Abyss," he replied. "What will you do there?" "The Great Abyss," he said, "as a thing..."

The Great Abyss may be poured into without ever filling, drawn from without ever depleting—there I shall wander."

Yuanfeng said, "Do you, Master, have no concern for the horizontal-eyed people? I would hear of sagely governance."

Zhunmang replied, "Sagely governance? Offices are bestowed without failing to suit, talents are promoted without failing to match. All matters are seen in their truth, and actions proceed as they must. Words and deeds arise from oneself, and the world is transformed. With a wave of the hand or a glance, the people of the four directions all arrive—this is called sagely governance. Would you hear of the virtuous person?"

"The virtuous person dwells without thought, moves without calculation, harbors neither right nor wrong, neither beauty nor ugliness. Within the four seas, all share in benefit and find joy; all are provided for and find peace. They are forlorn as an infant parted from its mother, bewildered as a traveler who has lost the Way. Wealth and resources abound, yet they know not whence they come; food and drink suffice, yet they know not from where they derive—such is the bearing of the virtuous person. Would you hear of the spirit person?"

"The supreme spirit rides the light, and form vanishes away—this is called luminous vastness. Life’s mandate is fulfilled, and true nature is exhausted. Heaven and Earth rejoice, and the myriad affairs dissolve; the ten thousand things return to their true nature—this is called primordial obscurity."

Guo’s commentary: "Acting as one must and thereby entrusting all to spontaneity, words and deeds arise from oneself and transform the world. If one compels things to act, they will not be transformed. That the people of the four directions all arrive means that with a mere gesture or glance, each attains their nature, for they are left to act of themselves. The virtuous person has no thought, no calculation, following only nature. Without right or wrong in the heart, they entrust all to the world, and all within the four seas share in benefit and provision without any trace of self-interest. Virtue is the trace of the spirit person, hence it is called ‘bearing.’ Riding the light means having no light, thus form vanishes away. Without self, one entrusts all to things, empty and without attachment—this is not darkness or obstruction. Nature is exhausted, life’s mandate is fulfilled, and Heaven and Earth rejoice. Affairs do not obstruct joy, and so there are no affairs. Nature returns, and primordial obscurity leaves no trace."

Lü’s commentary: "To pour without filling, to draw without depleting—such is the abundance of Heaven’s storehouse. Yuanfeng, not knowing that it suffices without limit to meet the needs of the ten thousand things, thought the Master had no concern for the horizontal-eyed people. Bestowing offices and promoting talents without failing to suit is not to lack concern for exalting worthies and employing the capable. Seeing all matters in their truth and acting as one must is not to compel people to conceal their nature and feign compliance. Words and deeds arise from oneself, and the world is transformed; with a wave of the hand or a glance, the people all arrive—this is not to rely on rewards to encourage or punishments to deter. This is the sage’s manifestation in governance, not the means by which virtue is cultivated. The virtuous person has no thought, no calculation, harbors neither right nor wrong, neither beauty nor ugliness—their heart is ever empty. That all within the four seas share in benefit and provision brings joy, and the world delights in following them without weariness. Like an infant parted from its mother, they know not where to turn; like a traveler who has lost the Way, they know not where to go. Wealth and resources abound, yet all within the four seas share in them; food and drink suffice, yet all within the four seas are provided for—this is the bearing of the virtuous person, not the means by which the spirit is attained. The vast expanse emits light to illuminate, but the spirit rides that light to illuminate, not merely as light or the vanishing of form. Thus, though it illuminates, it is vast. Fulfilling life’s mandate means casting off the old and returning to constancy; exhausting true nature means departing from falsity and abiding in reality. The myriad affairs dissolve, the utmost of emptiness is reached, and the ten thousand things return to their true nature. Luxuriant, they return to the root; mixed, they become one; obscure, even illumination is forgotten."

Fu Mo’s commentary: "Bestowing offices without failing to suit means no office is left vacant; promoting talents without failing to match means no worthy is overlooked. Seeing all matters in their truth and acting as one must means each person unfolds their true nature without pretense. Words and deeds arise from oneself, and the world is transformed—what is done and said is for oneself alone, without intent to act for others. Not harboring right or wrong, beauty or ugliness means right and wrong, beauty and ugliness do not reside in the heart—this is what is called ‘not thinking of good, not thinking of evil.’ The supreme spirit rides the light—this is what is meant by ‘proceeding above the great brightness.’ Form vanishes away—this is what is meant by ‘entering the gate of profound obscurity.’ Thus, it illuminates and penetrates the vast and boundless, no longer confined by form, hence it is called ‘luminous vastness.’"

Men Wuwei and Chi Zhang Manji observed King Wu’s army. Chi Zhang Manji said, "Is it not inferior to the governance of Youyu? Thus it has encountered this calamity."

Men Wuwei replied, "Was the world in harmony and then Youyu governed it, or was it in chaos and then he brought order?"

Chi Zhang Manji said, "For the world to be in harmony is the wish of all—why consider Youyu’s governance as Youyu’s remedy? It is like a bald man donning a wig or a sick man seeking a physician. The filial son administers medicine to heal his compassionate father, yet his countenance is scorched. The sage feels shame for this. In the age of utmost virtue, worthies are not exalted, the capable are not employed. Superiors are like the branches of a signpost, and the people are like wild deer. Upright yet not knowing it as righteousness, loving yet not knowing it as benevolence, truthful yet not knowing it as loyalty, proper yet not knowing it as trust—clumsy creatures moving and employing one another, yet not considering it a favor. Thus, actions leave no trace, and affairs leave no record."

Guo’s commentary: "These two sages both governed through chaos, so yielding and employing armies differ only in their times—there is no superiority between them. If the world is in harmony, each wish is fulfilled—why consider Youyu’s virtue and exalt him as ruler? Men Wuwei’s words are apt. Moreover, the world all suffers from the affliction of chaos, hence they seek Youyu’s remedy. The son who administers medicine to heal his father has a scorched countenance—those who govern the world do not do so for glory. In the age of utmost virtue, the worthy occupy their proper place, not because they are exalted; the capable act of themselves, not because they are employed. Superiors are like the branches of a signpost, emerging above things yet not self-aggrandizing; inferiors are like wild deer, released and self-content. Their benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and trust flow from nature, not from knowledge. Clumsy creatures employ one another through their own movement, hence they act without gratitude. The capable are left to act of themselves, hence actions leave no trace; each affair is confined to its proper place, hence no record is transmitted to others."

Lü’s commentary: "Youyu governed through chaos, and King Wu also governed through chaos—who does not take the world as their concern, yet falls short? Thus, Youyu is the world’s remedy for affliction."

Those who, bald, apply false hairpieces, or, ill, seek physicians—these are cases of disorder followed by order. Grasping medicine to mend one’s father’s appearance, their countenance yet flushed with urgency, the Dao does not reach the point of mutual forgetting, and the six relations remain discordant; such "filial piety" and "compassion" are indeed what the sage feels shame for. Thus, how could the governance of Youyu be deemed forced, or surpass that of King Wu? Viewed by its traces, even Fuxi and Suiren could not be called an age of utmost virtue; viewed by its heart, the subtlety of Youyu and King Wu is precisely what is meant by an age of utmost virtue. For they act through non-action, hence leave no name; leaving no name, their conduct leaves no trace, and affairs leave no transmission—who could presume to judge between them?

Bi Xu’s commentary: "Dan Zhu was unworthy, so Chong Hua replaced him; Yin Shou was cruel and evil, so the divine martial one subdued him—neither was a state of tranquil, equal governance. The black-headed people were afflicted, so Chong Hua treated them with the medicine of benevolence and righteousness—illness seeking physicians, disorder seeking order: could this be what a good physician or filial son wishes to hear? Not exalting the worthy, hence no contention; not employing the capable, hence no failure. Superiors are like the mindless branches of a signpost; inferiors are like wild deer, self-content. This, too, is the principle of resonance: where there is wrongdoing, righteousness appears; where there is hatred, benevolence emerges; where there is deceit, loyalty is revealed."

Where there is falsehood, trust becomes manifest—without the four principles above, the four matters below also vanish. The servitude of creatures in motion arises naturally, not as a bestowed favor. Without traces or transmission, it is not deemed extraordinary.

The filial son does not flatter his parents; the loyal minister does not fawn upon his lord—this is the flourishing of the minister-son. When parents’ words are heeded and their deeds deemed good, the world calls such a child unworthy. When the lord’s words are heeded and his deeds deemed good, the world calls such a minister unworthy. Yet how can this not be the natural way? What the world calls "heeding" is heeded, what it calls "good" is deemed good—yet it does not call such a one a flatterer.

Is it then that custom is stricter than kinship and more revered than lordship? To call a man "Dao-guided" provokes sudden anger; to call him a flatterer stirs instant outrage—yet all their lives, they guide others, all their lives, they flatter others. They assemble parables, adorn their words, and gather crowds, yet from beginning to end, root to branch, they do not hold themselves accountable. They drape themselves in robes, display vibrant colors, alter their expressions to ingratiate themselves with the age, yet never admit to being flatterers or followers of such men. They reconcile right and wrong yet never acknowledge themselves as common fools—the height of folly!

One who knows his folly is not utterly foolish; one who knows his confusion is not utterly confused. The utterly confused never awaken in their lifetime; the utterly foolish never gain wisdom. If three walk together and one is confused, the destination may yet be reached—for the confused are few. If two are confused, the effort is laborious and the goal unattained—for the confused prevail.

Yet now, with the whole world confused, though I have aspirations, they cannot be realized. Is this not lamentable? The great voice does not reach the ears of the village.

Breaking the yellow blossoms elicits a sudden burst of laughter—thus lofty speech never reaches the hearts of the common folk, and profound words do not emerge from vulgar speech, for the latter prevails.

To be led astray by two earthen jars and bells is to lose one’s way. Yet now, with the whole world deluded, though I have aspirations, how could they be realized? Knowing they cannot be realized and yet forcing them is but another delusion. Therefore, it is best to let go and not impose; if not imposed, who would share the sorrow?

---

**Guo’s Commentary:**
When one assents to the words of ruler or parent and acts with goodness, this merely defies convention to follow authority—hence the world calls it unfilial. Yet where lies true rightness? The world does not revere ruler or parent by following them, nor does it condemn flattery when one follows convention. If reverence cannot subdue others, then submission lies in conformity. Thus the sage never stands apart from the age but moves with its ebb and flow: when the age is august, he is august; when it is royal, he is royal. How could he oppose convention to impose himself?

The world deems conformity correct, calling it "guidance" or "flattery." Yet one may reject such terms with indignation while spending a lifetime in guidance, never seeking the Dao but merely striving to please. Those who reconcile metaphors, adorn words, and incur the charge of flattery—yet the world rewards them, gathers around them, and never faults their conformity. They reconcile right and wrong without calling themselves common folk, yet the world is so utterly foolish that it cannot but follow. The sage’s Dao is one, but the traces of emperors and kings differ—truly, the world’s delusion is insoluble. Thus one must follow and yield to it.

Though the whole world is deluded, though I possess the aspiration to seek the supreme Dao, it remains unattainable. Thus Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu merely followed their times. The great voice is not esteemed in narrow lanes; when vulgar folk hear a lewd tune, they laugh in unison. This is why the world never employs the sage but always relies on itself.

To be led astray by two earthen jars and bells is to lose one’s way—each clings to their own convictions, unaware of their destination. Better to align with them. Let go and do not impose; if not imposed, who would share the sorrow? Strive to suit the moment, and without forcing understanding, all may live without worry in this world.

---

**Following the Original Text:**
What the world calls loyal ministers and filial sons—those who admonish their superiors when they err and refuse flattery—are deemed flatterers if they follow ruler or parent. Yet those who follow worldly convention are never called flatterers. Does this mean one dares to admonish ruler or parent but not the world? Is the world more severe than kin, more revered than rulers?

Men reject the name of flattery, yet their conduct is a lifelong pursuit of it. They blend metaphors, embellish words, and seek to gather followers—what is this if not flattery? Yet they remain unaware. In one person, beginning and end, root and branch, never align in fault.

Below, this is applied to Shun: he donned robes and ruled the world, adorning the five colors with reverent dignity. Thus it is said: "He donned robes, displayed colors, and altered his expression." Shun thus ingratiated himself with the age yet never called himself a flatterer. He reconciled right and wrong without deeming himself one with the common folk—this is the height of folly!

The following uses conduct as analogy: if three walk together eastward and one wishes to go west, only one is deluded—there remains a chance of reaching the east. If two wish to go west, the deluded prevail, and the effort is laborious, the goal unattained.

*Yu Chi and Zhang Manji* (the speaker’s self-reference): "Though I have aspirations, they cannot be realized."

Below, music serves as analogy: earthen jars and bells (like the jars Qin kings struck) are ancient music, unpleasing to the masses. When vulgar music is heard, they rejoice. If two strike earthen jars as instruments, people delight in the novelty and are led astray—ancient music cannot prevail. Now, with the whole world deluded, though I have aspirations, how could they be realized? The repeated analogy deepens the lament.

The phrase "losing one’s way" connects to the prior section: above, it referred to conduct; here, to the path of music.

Here, these discussions concern the era of Youyu, and of King Wu there need be no further mention.

There was a man of Li who, when his son was born in the dead of night, hastily fetched fire to examine him, anxious lest the child resemble himself. Guo’s commentary: *"Li refers to an evil man. It means that none in the world wish to be evil—those who do evil are either driven by harsh servitude or deluded and lose their nature. Yet the deluded may reflect and return, while the evil may reflect and reform. Thus, if I do nothing, the world will transform itself."*

Fu Mo observes: *"The man of Li, fearing his son would resemble him, shows that all people know themselves—yet the profoundly foolish and confused may live their entire lives without understanding. Those who lack awareness are even less perceptive than the man of Li. This is meant to provoke deep reflection, conveying meaning beyond words."*

A century-old tree, split to make sacrificial goblets, is painted with azure and yellow patterns. Yet its offcuts lie discarded in the ditch. Compared to the goblets, the ditch’s scraps differ in beauty and ugliness, but in the loss of their nature, they are one and the same. Robber Zhi and Zeng Shen or Shi Qiu may differ in conduct and righteousness, yet in the loss of their nature, they are equal.

Moreover, the loss of nature takes five forms:
First, the five colors confuse the eyes, leaving them unclear.
Second, the five sounds confuse the ears, leaving them dull.
Third, the five odors cloy the nose, congesting the forehead.
Fourth, the five flavors cloy the mouth, leaving it numb and impaired.
Fifth, preferences and aversions agitate the heart, causing the nature to scatter and soar.
These five are all harms to life.

Yet Yang Zhu and Mo Di, striving apart, claim to have attained something—this is not what I call attainment. For if one’s attainment is merely distress, can it truly be called attainment?

Within the cage, the turtledove and owl may likewise claim attainment.
Moreover, chasing after sounds and colors to stifle the inner self,
donning kingfisher-feathered caps and sashes, clutching tablets and girding long ribbons to constrain the outer form—
within, the limbs swell against the inner bars;
without, layers of cords and snares entangle.
Though trapped within cords and snares, gazing fixedly, they still believe themselves to have attained—
then the bound prisoner, arms crossed and fingers contorted, or the tiger and leopard caged in sacks and pens,
may likewise claim attainment.

The five colors do not clarify but rather obscure; it is clarity that perceives colors.
The five sounds do not sharpen but rather dull; it is acuity that perceives sounds.
Extending this principle, the five odors congest the nose, the five flavors numb the mouth,
and preferences and aversions agitate the heart—
all act in this same manner.
Without preferences or aversions, the heart would remain undisturbed;
it is the agitation of preferences and aversions that scatters the nature, ceaselessly soaring.
Those like Yang Zhu and Mo Di, though undoubtedly talented scholars of the world,
never heard the Dao. Their knowledge did not extend beyond these five senses.
Thus, striving apart, they claimed attainment—
then the turtledove and owl in their cages may likewise claim attainment.
Stifling the inner self so the Dao cannot gather,
constraining the outer form so the heart cannot be freed—
with the limbs swollen against the inner bars and layers of cords and snares without,
from the perspective of one who has attained true liberation, their entrapment within cords and snares is plain to see.
Yet still they believe themselves to have attained—
then the bound prisoner, arms crossed and fingers contorted, or the tiger and leopard caged in sacks and pens,
may likewise claim attainment.

As Laozi said: "The five colors make men’s eyes blind; the five sounds make men’s ears deaf; the five flavors dull men’s palates."
For man’s life is by nature tranquil, undisturbed by external things;
his virtue is profound, unshaken by change.
Yet when false realms arise before him, the wellspring of spirit daily grows obscured,
until he forgets his priceless inherent nobility and pursues endless, decaying desires—
how could he not be deluded?
This is why the noble person values frugality.

The shards discarded in the ditch, repurposed as sacrificial chalices—what difference lies between glory and disgrace? Both are but withered wood. This aligns with the parable of Zang and Gu losing their sheep: sounds and colors, scents and flavors—all suffice to disorder one’s nature. The four are thus paired with pursuit and rejection to restrain them.

A *kunzong* is one who clashes with others; the bridge of the nose connects to the forehead. A "fouled mouth" defiles the speech. *Lishuang* denotes deviation and loss. Pursuit and rejection, right and wrong, likes and dislikes—when these muddle the heart, one’s natural nature is lost. The teachings of Yang Zhu and Mo Di are those that disorder the heart through pursuit and rejection. Though they entrap themselves with their doctrines, they claim attainment—if this is attainment, then a turtledove in a cage may likewise claim it. Such condemnation is severe indeed.

Their pursuit and rejection, their right and wrong, obstruct the chest—thus "their inner being is like kindling." The cap and sash of the scholar-official, the restraint of ritual—thus "their outer form is bound." Within, obstruction and fullness press like a palisade; without, ritual and form confine like fetters. Though others see their self-inflicted suffering as entrapment, they believe themselves to have attained—then the bound prisoner, the tiger in the cage, may likewise claim attainment. Here, the criticism of Yang and Mo reaches its sharpest point.

A Comprehensive Overview in My Limited View

This essay first discusses the great transformations of Heaven and Earth and the multitude of beings. For one who rules all under Heaven, in all observations, proceed with the Dao in straightforward conduct, govern with virtue through non-action and desirelessness, and ensure clear division of official duties—thus, among things that differ yet are made the same, none may deviate.

Nothing is greater than Heaven and Earth; nothing is more revered than the Dao and virtue. The sage’s Dao encompasses both covering and bearing, hence it is rightfully paired with them. The *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] elucidates the virtue of Heaven and Earth—this is the Way by which one unifies Heaven and Earth, governs the myriad things, and rules all under Heaven.

People see the sage’s multifaceted responses to things and suspect his wisdom and clarity far surpass others, yet they do not know these arise from the emptiness of the heart and non-action. Thus, one who possesses the virtue to rule all under Heaven establishes the root and source to rectify what lies within the self—then Heaven and Earth need not await union to unite, and the myriad beings need not await transformation to be transformed. Gazing, there is no form; listening, there is no sound—yet profound resonance and wondrous responses are unceasing.

Thus, the Yellow Emperor relinquished the mysterious pearl, and Xiangwang obtained it; Emperor Yao sought to yield to Nieque, and Xu You admonished him—this is to say, the Dao cannot be sought with intention, nor attained through wisdom and clarity. At Huafeng, the three blessings were requested of the sage, who then distributed wealth and conferred offices, ascending as an immortal of a thousand years—what encumbrance could there be? Zigao declined the lords and plowed in the wilds, demonstrating that when virtue declines, punishments arise; when worthy men retreat and the law is concealed, calamities accumulate, and chaos begins.

Therefore, one must return to the Great Beginning and Non-Being to thoroughly investigate the original nature of things and the source of life and destiny. When virtue aligns with the primordial, things will transform of themselves. Whether one affirms or denies, acts or does not, serves with reverence and frugality, or upholds impartial loyalty—these are but external exertions of the heart.

The shame of the man of Hanyin in using machinery, King Wu’s leading of troops to save the people—one embraces simplicity and guards authenticity, the other employs expedience to achieve righteousness. Their actions differ, yet neither departs from the Dao. As for those who terrify others like the madman Zisi, or the utterly deluded who remain benighted all their lives, or those who carve the unhewn into vessels, disturbing the heart and harming nature—if virtue is insufficient to preserve life, how can they govern all under Heaven? All such cases are those who mistake suffering for attainment, like the bitter toil of Yang and Mo, which is scarcely worth emulating.

To compare them to turtledoves and tigers is not merely to belittle them but to despise them most severely.

**Zhuangzi Yi, Volume 3**
*From the Siku Quanshu, "Masters" Section, Daoist Category, Zhuangzi Yi*
*Compiled by Jiao Hong of the Ming Dynasty*

**Chapter Thirteen: The Dao of Heaven**

The Dao of Heaven operates without accumulation, thus all things are brought to completion. The Dao of the Emperor operates without accumulation, thus all under Heaven submit. The Dao of the Sage operates without accumulation, thus all within the seas yield. One who is enlightened by Heaven, attuned to the Sage, and whose virtue is all-pervading and all-embracing—such a one acts of their own accord, yet remains profoundly still, without exception.

The stillness of the sage is not stillness for its own sake but stillness born of inherent goodness. When nothing in the myriad things can disturb the heart, stillness naturally follows. When water is still, it clearly reflects the brows and beard; its level surface serves as the carpenter’s standard. If still water can be so luminous, how much more so the spirit? The sage’s heart, in its stillness, mirrors Heaven and Earth and reflects the myriad things.

Vacuity, stillness, tranquility, simplicity, quiescence, and non-action—these are the level of Heaven and Earth and the perfection of the Dao and virtue. Thus do emperors, kings, sages, and worthies find repose in them. In repose, there is vacuity; in vacuity, there is fullness; in fullness, there is order. In vacuity, there is stillness; in stillness, there is movement; in movement, there is attainment. Stillness is non-action; in non-action, those charged with affairs bear their responsibilities. In non-action, there is ease; in ease, cares and troubles cannot abide, and longevity is attained.

Vacuity, stillness, tranquility, simplicity, quiescence, and non-action—these are the root of the myriad things. He who understands this and faces south becomes a Yao as ruler; he who understands this and faces north becomes a Shun as minister. By this, one embodies the virtue of emperors, kings, and the Son of Heaven; by this, one follows the Dao of the obscure sage and unadorned king. By this, one retires to wander among rivers, seas, mountains, and forests, and the people submit; by this, one advances to govern the world, and great merit and illustrious fame are achieved, uniting all under Heaven.

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
The Dao of Heaven, the Dao of the Emperor, and the Dao of the Sage—these three allow things to follow their nature without hindrance. Though all-pervading and all-embracing, they do not disrupt stillness. Stillness born of goodness will move in due time. When nothing in the myriad things can disturb the heart, one attains self-realization. If still water can be so luminous, how much more so the sage’s heart in stillness? For it possesses the capacity to let things be as they are, and thus its illumination is utterly penetrating. The level of Heaven and Earth and the perfection of the Dao and virtue arise from non-action. Repose does not mean inaction; movement attains its end when it does not lose its proper cause.

"Those charged with affairs bear their responsibilities" means that in non-action, the myriad talents and things each fulfill their duties and bear their own burdens. Thus, Shun and Yu possessed all under Heaven yet did not interfere—this is what is meant. "Ease" describes a state of unhurried self-possession. When one understands that the root of the myriad things lies in non-action, whether facing south or north, whether in high or low position, one attains the perfection of non-action. One who possesses the Dao and is followed by all under Heaven yet lacks rank is called an "unadorned king," valuing the Dao above all. By this, one retires to wander in seclusion like Xu You and Chao Fu, or advances to govern the world like Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou.

The scope of non-action is vast—what can it not accomplish? If the ruler does not assume the duties of the chief minister, then Yi and Lü remain still in their offices. If the chief minister does not take up the tasks of the hundred officials, then the hundred officials remain still in their governance. If the hundred officials do not interfere with the affairs of the common people, then the common people remain still and secure in their occupations.
