If the common people do not alter their natural abilities, then all under Heaven remains still in self-realization. From the Son of Heaven to the common people, down to the insects—who can achieve anything through action? Thus, the more one embodies non-action, the more exalted one becomes.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
Heaven and Earth revolve endlessly yet never accumulate anything, thus the myriad things are completed without carving or chiseling. The Dao of the Emperor encompasses ten thousand affairs in a single day yet never accumulates anything, thus all under Heaven submits without seeking favor. The Dao of the Sage is nowhere absent yet never accumulates anything, thus all under Heaven yields without coercion. One who is enlightened by Heaven and attuned to the Sage, knowing that all things operate without accumulation, embodies the all-pervading and all-embracing virtue of emperors and kings. In operation, there is endless transformation; without accumulation, there is nothing that lingers in the breast. Even one’s own actions become obscure, as if one has not acted at all—how much more so when others act in their own ways?

The stillness of the sage is not stillness for its own sake but stillness born of inherent goodness. If stillness were deemed good and then pursued, it would not be true stillness. When nothing in the myriad things can disturb the heart, stillness is its natural state—not something achieved through stillness. Why? The myriad things are born through me; if I do not give birth to them, what can disturb me? Thus, in their bustling activity, one observes their return; in their profusion, one sees their root. In returning to the root, they are naturally still.

If still water can be so luminous, how much more so the spirit, which extends above and coils below, pervading all without limit, and resides in the sage’s heart? Its stillness is not merely like water reflecting brows and beard or serving as a level standard—it is the mirror of Heaven and Earth, the reflection of the myriad things. Vacuity means nothing opposes it; stillness means unity without change; tranquility means peace in unknowing; simplicity means no entanglement with things; quiescence means utter motionlessness; non-action means harmony with the void. These six are the sage’s means of non-action, the level of Heaven and Earth, and the perfection of the Dao and virtue—where emperors, kings, sages, and worthies find repose.

When responding to the myriad changes and supplying the needs of the myriad things, if one lacks this, there is no repose, and the spirit is wearied by the multitude of affairs. How can one attain vacuity? Vacuity means hollowing the heart, concealing affairs, and possessing the myriad differences. Thus, vacuity leads to fullness; though things differ, their principle remains unconfused. Vacuity is not merely fullness in order but also stillness in movement and attainment in action. Who can remain tranquil amid prolonged movement? Stillness in movement means acting only when necessary and appropriately—thus movement attains its end.

Attaining vacuity to the point of stillness means nothing in the myriad things can disturb the heart, and non-action allows those charged with affairs to bear their responsibilities without my labor. In ease, there is no circumstance that does not accord; where can cares and troubles abide? Thus, longevity is attained. The root of the myriad things lies in non-action. He who understands this and faces south becomes a Yao as ruler; he who understands this and faces north becomes a Shun as minister. By this, one embodies the virtue of emperors, kings, and the Son of Heaven, or follows the Dao of the obscure sage and unadorned king. By this, one retires to wander in seclusion, and the people submit; by this, one advances to govern the world, achieving great merit, illustrious fame, and the unity of all under Heaven.

Understanding the discourse on emptiness and stillness, one finds that tranquility, indifference, silence, and desolation are but the same—only the terms differ. The teeming myriad things all grow from non-action, which is their root. The sages of antiquity, some faced south as Yao, some faced north as Shun; some dwelt above with the virtue of emperors and kings, the Son of Heaven, while others dwelt below with the Dao of obscure sages and unadorned kings. Some retired to wander in seclusion, others advanced to govern the world—yet their clarity regarding the root of the myriad things was one and the same.

*Brush Jottings*:
No accumulation, no stagnation. The imperial Dao refers to the virtue of emperors, kings, and the Son of Heaven; the sagely Dao refers to the Way of obscure sages and unadorned kings. These correspond to the branches, while the old annotations that assign them separately to the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors are incorrect. "Six penetrations and four openings" (六通四辟): *bi* (辟) is synonymous with *pi* (闢), meaning the six directions and four quarters are all thoroughly pervaded. "Obscure and dim" (昧然) means that keen hearing and sharp sight are entirely extinguished. "Level and centered" (平中) is the standard by which the great craftsman takes his measure, as in the *Rites of Zhou*, where the artisan levels the ground with a plumb line.

Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, indifference, silence, desolation, and non-action—these are the standards by which Heaven and Earth are aligned. Thus it is said: "The levelness of Heaven and Earth." *Yuyu* (俞俞) means contentment, like entering a state of ease. When one attains self-mastery, sorrow and grief cannot enter, and the body never declines. Thus it is said: "In *yuyu*, cares and troubles cannot abide, and longevity is attained." "Root" refers to the fundamental source. Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things all arise from emptiness and stillness, hence "the root of the myriad things." This is further expounded to make known that one’s security and destiny lie therein.

Stillness makes one sagely; movement makes one kingly. Non-action is revered, and simplicity is such that none under Heaven can rival its beauty. He who clearly understands the virtue of Heaven and Earth is called one who grasps the great root and great origin, who harmonizes with Heaven. This is how one harmonizes and regulates all under Heaven, and harmonizes with others. Harmonizing with others is called human joy; harmonizing with Heaven is called Heavenly joy. *Zhuangzi* says: "My master! My master! Who grinds up the myriad things yet is not cruel, who bestows blessings upon ten thousand generations yet is not benevolent, who is older than high antiquity yet is not long-lived, who covers and supports Heaven and Earth, carves and shapes the myriad forms yet is not skillful—this is called Heavenly joy." Thus it is said: "He who knows Heavenly joy lives by the movement of Heaven; when he dies, he transforms with things." Still, he shares virtue with yin; in movement, he shares the current with yang. Therefore, he who knows Heavenly joy bears no resentment from Heaven, no blame from others, no entanglement with things, and no curse from spirits. Thus it is said: "In movement, he is Heaven; in stillness, he is Earth." When the mind is settled and one rules all under Heaven, spirits do not haunt, and the soul does not weary. When the mind is settled, the myriad things submit. To extend emptiness and stillness to Heaven and Earth, and to penetrate the myriad things—this is called Heavenly joy. Heavenly joy is the heart of the sage by which he nurtures all under Heaven.

*Guo’s Commentary*:
Acting when it is time to act, ceasing when it is time to cease—naturally, all things revere and uphold him. Thus, only simplicity can rival the beauty of Heaven. He who harmonizes with Heaven regards non-action as the virtue of Heaven and Earth. By clarifying this root and origin, he does not oppose Heaven and Earth. He who harmonizes with others follows Heaven to respond to humanity, so when Heavenly harmony is complete, human harmony is also fulfilled. When Heavenly joy is attained, human joy is sufficient. "Grinding" (韲) means things changing and mixing together—it is merely their self-transformation, not the cruelty of my master. "Benevolence" (仁) is the name for universal love, but there is no love, so there is nothing to call benevolence. "Longevity" (寿) refers to distant expectations, but there are no expectations, so there is nothing to call longevity. "Skill" (巧) refers to the marvels of craft, but all things are self-so, so there is nothing to call skill. This is Heavenly joy—forgetting joy, yet joy is sufficient. Thus, in stillness, he shares virtue with yin; in movement, he shares the current with yang. Though movement and stillness differ, the mind is one. Always without mind, he rules all under Heaven without weariness. If my mind is at peace, the minds of the myriad things are connected; connected, they submit; disconnected, they rebel. What does the heart of the sage do to nurture all under Heaven? It is nothing but Heavenly joy.

*Lü’s Commentary*:
"Stillness makes one sagely" refers to the inner; "movement makes one kingly" refers to the outer. Non-action is revered, so those who serve under Heaven have no affairs to interfere with their talents. Knowing simplicity, none can rival its beauty, so those who govern all under Heaven have no need for ornamentation. It is simply a matter of clearly understanding the virtue of Heaven and Earth. Thus, whether dwelling above or below, advancing to govern or retiring to seclusion, though their paths differ, their great root and great origin are never distinct. Understanding this, one acts without action and harmonizes with Heaven; regulating all under Heaven, one harmonizes with others. Harmonizing with Heaven is called Heavenly joy; harmonizing with others is called human joy. It is merely a matter of taking this as one’s master. Grinding up things without cruelty, blessing generations without benevolence, shaping the myriad forms without skill—this is what *Zhuangzi* took as his master. Following the inherent inclinations of one’s heart as one’s master—who lacks a master? Thus, this joy does not come from without, and so it is called Heavenly joy. He who knows Heavenly joy lives by the movement of Heaven, and I have never been born; he dies and transforms with things, and I have never died. In stillness, he shares virtue with yin, yet does not know it as stillness; in movement, he shares the current with yang, yet does not know it as movement. He bears no resentment from Heaven, no blame from others, because he has never been in their realm. He is unburdened by things, unaccused by spirits, because he has never been in his own. In movement, he is Heaven; in stillness, he is Earth. When the mind is settled and one rules all under Heaven, spirits do not haunt, and the soul does not weary. When the mind is settled, the myriad things submit.

The reason Earth is as it is lies solely in the settling of the one mind. Thus, when one rules all under Heaven, externally, spirits do not haunt, and internally, the soul does not weary—how could the myriad things fail to submit? The mind settles because it is never not empty, never not still. I can extend this emptiness and stillness to Heaven and Earth, penetrating the myriad things—this is the Heavenly joy, the heart with which the sage nurtures all under Heaven.

**Limited Insight:**
The Dao within humans—when still, it is sageliness; when in motion, it is kingship. Both are exalted through non-action, beautiful in simplicity, just as the virtue of Heaven and Earth has never been contrived, never adorned, yet the movements of yin and yang, the four seasons, the sun and moon, mountains and rivers—are they not all manifestations of its workings and brilliance? This principle establishes the great root and great origin of all under Heaven. This root and origin are the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship, the harmony with Heaven. When applied to harmonize all under Heaven, it brings harmony with others—human joy and Heavenly joy both arise from harmony. Though their names differ, the source of their joy is one. Not harming things is not called cruelty; benefiting the world is not called benevolence—this is the forgetting of good and evil. Extending to the forgetting of longevity and skill, this is not constrained by time, not bound by ability or inability. The *Nanhua* takes this as its master, and this alone. In life, it moves with the natural course of Heaven; in death, it transforms with things. Movement must have its limit. Thus, in movement and stillness, it accords with the Heavenly Dao, bearing no resentment from Heaven, no blame from others, no burden from things, no reproach from spirits—this clarifies the source of its joy. In movement, it is Heaven; in stillness, it is Earth. This is the meaning of sharing virtue with yin and flowing with yang. When the one mind is settled and non-action prevails, all under Heaven turns toward it. Without reproach from spirits, spirits do not haunt; without burden from things, the soul does not weary. Conduct is blameless before the hidden and manifest—how could things fail to submit? There is no other reason than extending the principle of utmost emptiness and guarded stillness to Heaven and Earth, penetrating the myriad things. The heart with which the sage nurtures all under Heaven—how could it lie beyond this?

The virtue of emperors and kings takes Heaven and Earth as its model, the Dao and virtue as its master, and non-action as its constant. In non-action, one employs all under Heaven with ease; in action, one is employed by all under Heaven and falls short. Thus, the ancients valued non-action. When the ruler practices non-action, the subjects also practice non-action—this is the subjects sharing virtue with the ruler. When the subjects practice non-action, the ruler also practices non-action—this is the ruler sharing the Way with the subjects. If the subjects act, the ruler also acts—this is the ruler not ruling. If the ruler must practice non-action to employ all under Heaven, the subjects must act to be employed by all under Heaven—this is the unchanging Dao. Therefore, the ancient rulers of all under Heaven, though their wisdom encompassed Heaven and Earth, did not rely on their own plans; though their eloquence adorned the myriad things, they did not rely on their own explanations; though their abilities exhausted the seas and lands, they did not rely on their own actions. Heaven does not produce, yet the myriad things transform; Earth does not grow, yet the myriad things are nurtured; emperors and kings practice non-action, yet all under Heaven achieves success. Thus, nothing is more spirit-like than Heaven, nothing more abundant than Earth, nothing greater than emperors and kings. Therefore, the virtue of emperors and kings matches Heaven and Earth—this is the Way of riding Heaven and Earth, driving the myriad things, and employing the human realm.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
"Employing all under Heaven with ease" means having leisure. If one busily seeks to be used by things, one can be made a subject. Yet even as a subject, one has ease. The craftsman does not act in carving wood but acts in using the axe; the ruler does not act in handling affairs but acts in employing ministers. When ministers handle affairs and the ruler employs ministers, when the axe carves wood and the craftsman uses the axe, each fulfills their capacity—this is the natural principle of Heaven, not contrivance. If the ruler takes over the affairs of ministers, he is no longer a ruler; if ministers wield the ruler’s authority, they are no longer ministers. Thus, when each attends to their duties, the principle of non-action reaches its perfection. Those who employ all under Heaven also act, but this acting arises from following their nature, hence it is called non-action. Those who are employed by all under Heaven also act on their own, but since those below handle affairs, even Yao and Yu as ministers are called "acting." Thus, in the context of ruler and subject, the ruler is still and the subject is active; in the context of antiquity and the present, Yao and Shun practiced non-action while Tang and Wu had affairs. Yet each acted according to their nature, and the celestial mechanism unfolded—who in antiquity or the present, ruler or subject, truly acted? The ruler’s error lies in being unable to practice non-action and instead taking over the duties of ministers. If Gao Yao could not exercise his judgment and Hou Ji could not carry out his planting, then all talents would lose their roles, and the ruler would be burdened by labor. Thus, the ruler dons the imperial crown, veils his eyes, and entrusts all under Heaven to them—when all under Heaven can act on their own, this is non-action that accomplishes everything. Therefore, both ruler and subject practice non-action. When the ruler practices non-action, he employs those below; when those below practice non-action, they act on their own. The transformation and nurturing of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things—this is what is meant by "naturally so." Emperors and kings practice non-action, yet all under Heaven achieves success—success arises from them, aligning with the non-action of Heaven and Earth.

The Lü commentary states: "In non-action, one person employs all under Heaven, and all under Heaven serves that person—thus there is abundance. In action, all under Heaven employs one person, and that person serves all under Heaven—thus there is insufficiency. Is it not clear? Heaven does not act with pure virtue; virtue is simply non-action. Therefore, when the superior practices non-action, the inferior also practices non-action, aligning with the superior—this is called 'accord with virtue and the Dao.' Thus, there is Heaven and there is humanity: non-action is the honored Way of Heaven, while action is the encumbrance of the human Way. Therefore, when the inferior acts, the superior also acts, aligning with the inferior—this is called 'speaking of the Dao.' The superior must practice non-action to employ all under Heaven, while the inferior must act to be employed by all under Heaven. This is the unchanging Dao.

Thus, the ancient kings of all under Heaven knew not to deliberate for themselves, for all under Heaven deliberated for them; not to speak for themselves, for all under Heaven spoke for them; not to act for themselves, for all under Heaven acted for them. Heaven does not produce, yet the myriad things transform—it is not that I produce them. Earth does not grow, yet the myriad things are nurtured—it is not that I nurture them. Emperors and kings practice non-action, yet all under Heaven achieves success—it is not that I accomplish it. This is why Heaven is divine, Earth is abundant, and emperors and kings are great. Non-action is how the Dao rides Heaven and Earth, gallops through the myriad things, and governs the human realm.

The root lies with the superior, the branches with the inferior; the essential lies with the ruler, the details with the ministers. The deployment of the three armies and the five weapons is the branch of virtue. Rewards and punishments, benefits and harms, the five punishments, and the establishment of laws are the branch of teaching. Ritual, laws, measurements, punishments, names, and precedents are the detailed governance of order. The sounds of bells and drums, the forms of feathered banners, are the branch of music. Weeping, mourning garments, and the gradations of funeral attire are the branch of grief. These five branches require the operation of spirit and the movement of the mind’s art before they can follow.

The branches were practiced by the ancients, but they are not what should come first. The ruler precedes the minister, the father precedes the son, the elder brother precedes the younger, the elder precedes the younger, the man precedes the woman, the husband precedes the wife—this is the order of precedence in human relations, following the course of Heaven and Earth. Thus, the sage takes this as a model: Heaven is honored, Earth is lowly—this is the position of the divine and the bright. Spring and summer come first, autumn and winter follow—this is the sequence of the four seasons. The myriad things transform and take shape, flourishing and declining, changing and flowing—all have their inherent patterns. If even Heaven and Earth, though supremely divine, have an order of honor and precedence, how much more so does the human Way?

In ancestral temples, kinship is honored; in court, respect is honored; in village communities, age is honored; in conduct, worthiness is honored—this is the order of the Great Dao. To speak of the Dao while violating its order is not the Dao. To speak of the Dao while not following the Dao—how can one grasp the Dao?"

The Guo commentary states: "Spirit and the mind’s art are the root of the five branches. If allowed to move naturally, the branches of the five affairs will rise of themselves without need for effort—this is why the root comes first. Though the precedence of ruler and minister, father and son, is a human affair, it arises from the utmost principle and is not something the sage fabricated. Clearly, the order of honor and precedence is something even things cannot be without. The order of the Great Dao is not merely what human relations honor—it is why the Dao is taken as having order."

The Lü commentary states: "Knowing the five branches requires the operation of spirit and the mind’s art before they can follow. Thus, the so-called 'emptiness, tranquility, stillness, and non-action' are the very Way to preserve spirit, clarify the mind’s art, and nurture the root. Nurture the root, and the branches will follow. The branches were practiced by the ancients, but they are not what should come first. The ruler precedes the minister... down to the husband preceding the wife—this is the order of honor in the human Way. Even Heaven, though divine, holds the honored position above, while Earth, though bright, resides below. Spring and summer generate and come first, while autumn and winter complete and follow. From the myriad things’ initial transformation to their sprouting and taking shape, from the subtle to the manifest, all have their forms—flourishing and decline, change and transformation all have their inherent patterns and cannot be altered. If even Heaven and Earth, though unfathomably divine, have an order of honor and precedence, how can the root and branches, the superior and inferior of the human Way, be reversed?

Not only the precedence of ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, elder and younger brother arise from the principle of Heaven and Earth. Even in ancestral temples, court, village communities, and conduct—wherever one is at a given time—each has what it honors and cannot be disordered. All are but the order of the Great Dao. Thus, to speak of the Dao while violating its order—how can one grasp the Dao?"

The Oral Explanation states: "From this point onward, it further discusses action, taking non-action as the root and action as the branch. The essential lies with the ruler’s non-action, while the details lie with the minister’s action. Military power and civil virtue are auxiliary—thus it is said, 'The deployment of the three armies and the five weapons is the branch of virtue.' The five weapons are the bow, *shu*, spear, halberd, and shield. Clarifying punishments to assist teaching—thus it is said, 'Rewards and punishments, benefits and harms, the five punishments, and the establishment of laws are the branch of teaching.' Measurements and gradations, names and things, precedents and examples, meticulous details—all are the branch of governance."

"Rites, laws, measurements, gradations, bells, drums, feathered banners—none of these are the root of ritual and music. As it is said, 'Is it only about jade and silk, bells and drums?' These are but the branches of mourning. Thus, it is better to grieve sincerely than to merely follow its outward forms. The movement of intent and spirit, the activation of the mind’s art—these arise first, and the external forms follow. This is to say, all branches originate from the inner heart. The ancients had scholars who understood this, yet what should come first is not what they took as primary. What should come first is emptiness, stillness, tranquility, silence, and non-action—nothing more.

From this perspective, how could Zhuangzi ever have intended to entirely abandon the use of military power, punishments, ritual, and music? What should come first comes first; what should come after comes after—all are the natural principles of Heaven and Earth. Thus it is said, 'Nobility and humility, priority and posteriority, are the movements of Heaven and Earth.' The sage takes them as models. Heaven and Earth, the four seasons—these are also metaphors. *Hua* means transformation; *zuo* means generation. As the *Book of Songs* says of the *wei* plant, 'It grows, it stops'—this is an example. *Meng meng* refers to sprouts; *qu qu* refers to distinctions. This speaks of how things are born and their forms differ. Changing with the times, first flourishing and then declining—this too is a metaphor for the order of priority and posteriority, the gradations of flourishing and decline.

That which flourishes does not flourish in a single moment; that which declines does not decline in a single moment—all have their sequence. Thus, the gradations of flourishing and decline arise from priority and posteriority, and priority and posteriority also apply to nobility and humility. In conducting affairs, esteeming worthiness means prioritizing the worthy in assigning duties. Age and rank, nobility and worthiness—these too are the natural principles of the world. Thus it is said, 'This is the order of the Great Dao.' How can one grasp the Dao if one does not know its order?

In ancestral temples, kinship is esteemed, and the generations of the *zhao* and *mu* are arranged in sequence."

The newly transmitted text states: The preceding passage clarifies this by showing how [Yao] faced north to serve as Shun’s minister—thus, the Way of the minister should be non-action. Here, it further speaks of "the end lying below" and "the details pertaining to the minister," where the earlier passage addressed the mind and this one addresses the proper station. Where there is a root, there must be an end—how could the end ever depart from the root? The root is simply the principle of non-action. Knowing this principle and following it, the Five Relations proceed of themselves. Thus it is said, "These five require the movement of spirit and the activation of the mind’s art before they can be followed."

Master Zhuang deeply understood the principle of spontaneity—what is called "knowing Heaven"—and here, in speaking of the order of ruler and minister, father and son, elder and younger brother, husband and wife, male and female, nobility and humility, priority and posteriority, he also demonstrated what is called "knowing man." Xunzi criticized Zhuangzi for being obscured by Heaven and not knowing man—how could this be a case of not knowing man?

Therefore, those of old who illuminated the Great Dao first illuminated Heaven, then followed with virtue and power. Once virtue and power were illuminated, benevolence and righteousness followed. Once benevolence and righteousness were illuminated, the observance of distinctions followed. Once distinctions were illuminated, forms and names followed. Once forms and names were illuminated, the delegation of tasks followed. Once tasks were delegated, the tracing of origins and examination of outcomes followed. Once origins and outcomes were traced and examined, right and wrong followed. Once right and wrong were illuminated, rewards and punishments followed. Once rewards and punishments were illuminated, the foolish and the wise found their proper places, the noble and the base assumed their stations, the benevolent and the worthy, the unworthy and the compliant—each followed their nature, each fulfilled their capacities, each adhered to their names.

With this, one serves superiors; with this, one nurtures inferiors; with this, one governs things; with this, one cultivates the self. Wisdom and schemes are not employed, for one must return to Heaven—this is called the Great Peace, the ultimate of governance.

Thus, the *Book* says: "There are forms, there are names." Forms and names existed among the ancients, but they were not what came first. Those who spoke of the Great Dao in ancient times underwent five transformations before forms and names could be established, nine transformations before rewards and punishments could be discussed. To rush to speak of forms and names is to not know the root; to rush to speak of rewards and punishments is to not know the beginning. To speak in a way that inverts the Dao is to go against the Dao and yet claim understanding—what men govern, how can one govern men?

To rush to speak of forms and names, rewards and punishments—this is to possess the tools of governance but not the Way of governance. Such things may be applied to the world, but they are insufficient to govern the world. These are called "disputers," men of partial understanding. Rituals, laws, measures, and degrees; forms, names, and detailed comparisons—these existed among the ancients. They are what inferiors use to serve superiors, not what superiors use to nurture inferiors. (Wu: Sima [Biao] explains: "transverse.")

Guo’s Annotation:
["Heaven" refers to spontaneity. Once spontaneity is made clear, things attain their Dao; when things attain their Dao, harmony and principle naturally align. When principle aligns, there is no loss of their proper roles; when roles are properly apportioned, each thing’s name accords with its form. Once forms and names are clarified, nothing remains to be altered—thus, following and entrusting come next. When things are entrusted to themselves, blame and responsibility dissolve. Next comes discernment: attaining one’s nature is deemed right, losing one’s nature is deemed wrong. Thus, right and wrong come next, and from there, rewards and punishments—these are the retribution for loss and attainment.

The Way of perfect governance originates in Heaven and culminates here. "Treading one’s position" means each speaks according to their capacity; "following one’s nature" means each acts according to their innate abilities. "Necessarily distinguishing their capacities" means no interchange of duties; "necessarily following their names" means names match reality, so proceeding from name to reality avoids excess.

From the clarification of Heaven to forms and names is the fifth stage; to rewards and punishments is the ninth—all follow the natural sequence of before and after. Those who govern others must adhere to this sequence, and the Way of governance shines brightly. Heaven does not abandon rewards and punishments, but one must not lose the order of before and after.

Those who employ the world must thoroughly comprehend the Way of following sequence, entrusting these matters to the multitude of talents—this is how superiors nurture inferiors.]

Lü’s Annotation:
["Heaven" is the ultimate of nature and destiny. To clarify the Dao without understanding Heaven is to call what is not the Dao "Dao," and what is not virtue "virtue." Only the true Dao and true virtue give rise to benevolence and righteousness. With benevolence on the left and righteousness on the right, there are distinctions and observances, forms become visible, and names can be spoken. With forms and names and no disorder, one follows and entrusts without losing talents and abilities. Internally examining the heart and externally scrutinizing traces, right and wrong attain their truth; rewards and punishments accord with principle. The foolish and the wise are placed appropriately and dare not transgress; the noble and the base tread their positions and dare not interchange. The benevolent and worthy, the unworthy, follow their natures and dare not feign.

"Necessarily distinguishing their capacities" means offices match their duties; "necessarily following their names" means names match reality. In all matters—governing inferiors, ordering things, cultivating the self—nothing does not proceed from this. When schemes are not employed, one must return to Heaven. This is how King Wen, though "not knowing, not perceiving," followed the decree of the Lord, and the many officers of Zhou all upheld the virtue of King Wen, responding to and serving Heaven—thus achieving Great Peace and equaling the heights of Tang and Yu.

To rush to speak of forms and names, rewards and punishments is to not know their root and beginning. Is not Heaven, with the Dao and virtue, their root and beginning? To invert is to not rectify, taking the branch as the root; to go against is to not follow, placing the later before the earlier. To speak of the Dao without the sequence of root and branch, before and after, is to create disorder. Self-created disorder is what men govern—how can one govern others?]

New Transmission:
[That upon which the myriad things depend for their existence is called Heaven.]

The movement from this to that is the Dao. What the Dao embodies in me is virtue. Virtue expressed as love is benevolence. Love that is fitting is righteousness. Benevolence has its before and after; righteousness has its above and below—this is called *fen* (distinction). The earlier does not usurp the later; the lower does not encroach upon the higher—this is called *shou* (observance). *Xing* (form) is the manifestation of this; *ming* (name) is the designation of this.

What is meant by the manifestation of this? It is the differentiation of noble and base, close and distant, by which things are adorned—this is the distinction in their forms. What is meant by the designation of this? It is the differentiation of noble and base, close and distant, by which things are named—this is the distinction in their designations. In their manifestations, noble and base each have their proper appearance; in their designations, close and distant each have their proper title.

Following the distinctions of close and distant, noble and base, and assigning tasks according to what is fitting—this is called *yinren* (following and employing). When tasks are assigned according to what is fitting, then one may let go without scrutiny—can this be done? One must trace to its essence and examine its affairs—this is called *yuanxing* (tracing and examining). Only when tracing and examining are clear can right and wrong be distinguished. Only when right and wrong are clear can rewards and punishments be applied.

The worthy and the foolish alike employ their fundamental nature, never abandoning themselves to imitate others or boast of their abilities—such is the folly of things.

In ancient times, Shun asked Yao, “How does the Heavenly King employ his mind?”
Yao said, “I do not act arrogantly toward those without recourse, nor do I neglect the destitute. I commend the young and pity women—this is how I employ my mind.”
Shun said, “It is fine, yet not great.”
Yao said, “Then how should it be?”
Shun said, “Manifesting the Heavenly virtue, one emerges in tranquility. The sun and moon shine, the four seasons proceed, as day and night follow their constant course. Clouds drift and rain descends.”
Yao said, “Then must one be entangled and troubled? You align with Heaven, while I align with man. Now, Heaven and Earth are what the ancients deemed great, what the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun all praised together. Thus, those of old who ruled all under Heaven—what did they do? They simply accorded with Heaven and Earth.”

Guo’s Commentary:
*Those without recourse* refers to the destitute; *not neglecting* means constantly bestowing kindness. Aligning with Heaven’s virtue, though active, remains tranquil—thus it is said, “emerges in tranquility.” The sun, moon, clouds, rain, four seasons, and day and night all act without contrivance, naturally. *Entangled and troubled* reveals one’s self-suspicion of busyness.

Lü’s Commentary:
Manifesting the Heavenly virtue, though active, is never without tranquility. The sun and moon shine, the four seasons proceed—advancing and receding, bending and extending—none is the work of contrivance. Day and night follow their constant course, succeeding one another without awareness of their arising. Clouds drift and rain descends, and all under Heaven is made even. Compared to this, how could Yao’s refusal to act arrogantly toward those without recourse or neglect the destitute not seem entangled? Shun’s words align with Heaven; Yao’s align with man. Yet the Confucians of the world know Yao only thus. Therefore, I set forth these two sages to clarify that what is great and universally praised lies in this—no different from the Yellow Emperor.

Confucius sought to deposit his writings in the Zhou archives. Zilu counseled, “I have heard that among the Zhou’s archivists is one named Lao Dan, who has resigned and returned home. If you wish to deposit your writings, Master, you might first visit him.”
Confucius said, “Very well.” He went to see Lao Dan, but Lao Dan refused. Thereupon, Confucius expounded the Twelve Classics to persuade him.
Lao Dan, struck by his words, said, “How vast! I would hear the essentials.”
Confucius said, “The essentials lie in benevolence and righteousness.”
Lao Dan said, “May I ask: are benevolence and righteousness part of human nature?”
Confucius said, “Indeed. The noble person who lacks benevolence cannot be perfected; without righteousness, they cannot live. Benevolence and righteousness are the true nature of humanity—what else could they be?”
Lao Dan said, “May I ask what benevolence and righteousness are?”
Confucius said, “Joyful harmony at the center, universal love, and selflessness—this is the essence of benevolence and righteousness.”
Lao Dan said, “Alas! Nearly so. But is not *universal love* rather impractical? And *selflessness*—is that not itself a form of partiality?”

Should you wish the world never to lose its shepherds, then know: Heaven and Earth have their constancy, sun and moon their brightness, stars and constellations their ordered ranks, birds and beasts their flocks, trees and plants their rootedness. If you but follow virtue in your conduct and tread the Way in your steps, you will have arrived—why then this restless striving? To brandish benevolence and righteousness is like beating a drum in search of a lost child. I fear, sir, you would disorder human nature.

[The *Zhengzang Simafu* notes: *Zang* means "to conceal." The *Twelve Classics* refer to the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn*—the Six Classics—with the addition of the Six *Weft* texts, making twelve. Another account holds that the *Changes*’ upper and lower canons, together with the Ten Wings, form twelve. Yet another says the *Spring and Autumn* spans twelve reigns. *Mu* means "to shepherd."]

Guo’s commentary: [This is what the common world calls benevolence and righteousness, hence the use of Confucius and Laozi to correct it. The perfectly humane act without love yet advances directly. What the world calls "selflessness" is but the abandonment of self to love others. Yet to love others is to desire their love in return—this is extreme partiality, not the forgetting of the private for the public. From "Heaven and Earth have their constancy" to "trees and plants their rootedness"—all are self-sufficient and require no "universal love." When affairs arise, love as duty demands, then stop: this is to forget benevolence and righteousness. To dwell on them constantly is to disorder the true.]

Lü’s commentary: [Confucius, unheeded in his time, wished to conceal his words to await later noble persons. The *Twelve Classics* refer to the *Spring and Autumn*, through which Confucius ordered the world. Concealing its marvelous use without ever speaking of it, the *Twelve Classics*’ ordering of the world amounted to nothing more than benevolence and righteousness. Laozi, cutting off learning and returning to simplicity, revealed the true—thus benevolence and righteousness were to be cast aside, and it was fitting he deemed them not of human nature.

From the perspective of the human Dao: benevolence not only perfects the self but also completes things; righteousness not only establishes things but also establishes the self. The noble person’s flourishing lies in benevolence and righteousness, hence they are deemed the true nature of humanity.

From the perspective of the true Dao: "joyful harmony at the center" is not imposed from without. Nothing exists that is not joyful—this is the highest benevolence, acting without contrivance. "Universal love" is not the virtue of Heaven, nor does it resemble the spontaneous "walking and raining, acting and bestowing." Thus it is deemed impractical. All names arise from insufficiency—so "selflessness" is itself a form of partiality.

To wish the world never to lose its shepherds is to assist the spontaneity of the myriad things. From "Heaven and Earth have their constancy" to "trees and plants their rootedness"—this is what is meant by the spontaneity of things. Virtue is non-action; the Dao models itself on spontaneity—why then this restless striving? To beat a drum in search of a lost child is to say that the loss of human nature cannot be restored by benevolence and righteousness.]

The Dao of Lao Dan takes virtue and the Dao as its foundation, while the classics of Confucius take benevolence and righteousness as their root. Following virtue and aligning with the Dao, the world attains its nature through non-action; dwelling in benevolence and practicing righteousness, the world engages in action yet betrays its true feelings—this is why Zhuangzi employed the traces of Confucius to elucidate the matter. Inner harmony delights in all things: universal love is benevolence, selflessness is righteousness. Yet universal love inevitably fails to love some, which is not the highest benevolence. True benevolence knows no partiality; true righteousness does not objectify things. Thus the noble person values forgetting benevolence and righteousness to seek their ultimate expression. Confucius once said to Lao Dan, "I have studied the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn*—I have long immersed myself in them." This refers to the twelve classics, doubling the Six Classics into twelve.

Fang Sishan observed: One who grasps the essence of the teaching speaks only halfway before Laozi abruptly silences them. Nearly all later words, though seemingly close, fall short. Universal love arises from a mind intent on loving, yet it strays far from the Dao—hence it is called impractical. Beating a drum to seek a lost child only hastens their flight; likewise, governing the world by flaunting benevolence and righteousness only hastens chaos.

Shi Chengqi visited Laozi and asked, "I have heard that you are a sage. I did not hesitate to travel a great distance to see you, enduring a hundred nights of lodging and calloused feet without rest. Yet now I see you are no sage. You leave surplus grain to rot in rat burrows while abandoning your younger sister—this is not benevolence. You do not finish the food before you yet hoard without limit." Laozi remained unmoved. The next day, Shi Chengqi returned and said, "Yesterday I reproached you, but now my heart is at ease. Why is that?" Laozi replied, "Those of cunning wisdom and divine sagacity—I believed myself free of them. In the past, you called me an ox, and I accepted 'ox'; you called me a horse, and I accepted 'horse.' If one truly embodies a thing, others may name it, but to refuse is to invite calamity. I submit, always submit—not because submission exists, but because I have no submission."

Shi Chengqi stepped aside to avoid his shadow, then advanced and asked how to cultivate oneself. Laozi said, "Your countenance is haughty, your gaze piercing, your brow protruding, your mouth gaping, your bearing rigid—like a tethered horse. Your movements are restrained, your hair bristles, your scrutiny is mechanical, your cleverness betrays arrogance. All take you for untrustworthy. At the borderlands, there is one called 'the thief.'" (A hundred lodgings: Sima Biao explains this as stopping for a hundred days. *Jian*: calluses. The remainder of the text reads *xu*, meaning grain.)

Guo's commentary:
The phrase "defensive walls have surplus" speaks of his disregard for things, discarding them like worn sandals—this is unkindness, for he lacks even proximate compassion. Whether raw or cooked, nothing is exhausted before him; thus, he is ever in abundance. His accumulation is boundless, and the myriad things gather to his embrace. What comes, he receives, without setting narrow boundaries.

Shi Chengqi again appeared, his heart marred by self-reproach and biting criticism—this is what corrupts. To cast off the past: when called "ox" or "horse," he follows the name given to the thing, for it has substance, and thus neither slander nor praise disturbs his heart. If he were to accept these in his heart, both name and reality would burden him, and so he would again invite calamity. "Submission" refers to one’s bearing and conduct; not allowing slander or praise to harm oneself, one’s demeanor remains unchanged. If one acts with deliberate purpose, one cannot maintain constant submission.

"Crag-like" describes an uneasy, forward-leaning advance; "thrusting" means protruding. "Protruding" depicts the lofty display of beauty; "gaping" shows the open, roaring exchange. "Rigid" describes the strained, self-restraining posture—like a tethered horse, its will set on galloping. "Moving yet restrained" means not allowing oneself to relax. "Bristling" refers to the hair. "Mechanical" means swift in approach and retreat. "Scrutinizing" means discerning right and wrong with clarity.

The term "grandeur" refers to excess beyond one’s fundamental nature; skill in displaying grandeur leads to clumsiness in embracing simplicity. All these ten matters, by disregarding one’s inherent nature and destiny, become swayed by praise and blame—none are the Dao of cultivating the self.

At the borderlands, there are people who also recognize that your conduct is not that of a true person.

---
**Lü’s Annotation:**
When the mouse’s burrow holds surplus, it can be used to relieve the hunger of a younger sister, yet to abandon one’s younger sister is unbenevolent. If the raw and cooked are not fully consumed before one’s eyes, and one still takes without restraint while amassing without limit, this is unrighteous. Laozi abandoned learning and returned to simplicity, revealing the genuine to others. Yet when Shi Chengqi sought him through benevolence and righteousness, he responded with indifference—this was to dissolve his intentions and withdraw his heart.

If one deems oneself clever, divine, or sagely, believing one has transcended, then to abandon learning and return to simplicity is to have never possessed anything at all. Yet if you label certain acts as unbenevolent and others as unrighteous, this is like calling me an ox and naming me an ox, calling me a horse and naming me a horse. If the reality exists, others will assign the name, and I do not accept it—this is why I remain indifferent. To open one’s senses and engage in affairs while accepting such labels is to invite lifelong ruin, bringing calamity upon oneself.

My "submission" is constant; in this constancy, my heart never strays from the Dao. I do not submit because submission exists, nor do others truly regard me as diligent in practice. Shi Chengqi’s knowledge is insufficient to grasp the heart of the perfected person because what lies within him is inadequate.

If one’s bearing is "crag-like," it seems one does not engage with things; if one’s gaze is "thrusting," it pursues things outwardly. If one’s forehead is "protruding," it resembles raw simplicity; if one’s mouth is "gaping," it is as though words strain to escape. If one’s posture is "rigid," it appears unclear, yet the heart is like a tethered horse restrained. To be "moving yet restrained" is not an inability to act or to bristle; it is that the "mechanical" cannot be controlled. To "scrutinize with clarity" is not to borrow wisdom or skill; to perceive "grandeur" is not to preserve simplicity and restraint.

All these actions are merely deemed untrustworthy. Those at the borderlands do not wander within the Dao; to steal what is not theirs is to take what does not belong to them.

---
**Bishu’s Notes:**
The old interpretation of "abandoning one’s younger sister" as "unlearned" is overly forced. The intended meaning is that the *Mei* clan abandoned their surplus in the embankment. Laozi advocated frugality and thrift, thus reproaching wasteful abandonment. That the raw and cooked are not fully consumed before one’s eyes while amassing without limit is the proof of frugality.

If cleverness, knowledge, divinity, and sageliness still reside in the chest, there will inevitably be discord. Now, if one dissolves and transcends these, then to call it benevolence...

To call it "unbenevolent" is also permissible—even to call it "horse and ox" would not be amiss. Why? Because to know benevolence or its absence is still not to grasp its reality. If one perceives this reality yet refuses to accept it, one has already incurred the misfortune of unbenevolence; to accept it now would only compound the transgression.

*Serving* means compliance. My compliance with others is simply my habitual way—it is not an intentional act of submission. Thus, it is said: "I serve." Constant service is not service for the sake of service.

*Wild geese in formation* describes how they avoid their shadows, sidling as they advance. *Treading forward* depicts steady progress, heel to toe. *Cliff-like* signifies divergence, a gaze that clashes and darts. *Broad at the center, tapering at both ends* depicts a forehead’s shape. *Gaping mouth* conveys an open, stern, and resolute demeanor. Those who flaunt their refined tastes and set themselves apart present such a bearing.

*To move yet restrain, to be poised to strike yet forcibly hold back*—this describes a horse tethered yet ever straining to bolt, as if on the verge of breaking free yet forcibly restrained.

*Mechanism* refers to scrutinizing the trigger; *to examine* means to observe its workings in detail. *Cleverness and skill* lead to arrogance, which is plainly visible. The more cunning one becomes, the deeper the holes bored into the uncarved block, until the primordial simplicity is destroyed. Thus, it is called "untrustworthy," for it is not aligned with the natural disposition of life.

Like borderlands, each with its own boundaries, those who favor deceit constantly watch for gaps to exploit for personal gain. Thus, rival states regard them as thieves. The untrustworthy, who adorn themselves thickly to aggrandize themselves and obscure others, are no different from thieves—like the "tunneling and climbing" bandits Mencius spoke of.

The Master said: The Dao in its vastness does not terminate in the great, nor in its subtlety does it neglect the small. Thus, the ten thousand things are complete. Boundless, it admits all; unfathomable, it cannot be plumbed. Manifest virtue, benevolence, and righteousness are but the vestiges of spirit—who but the perfected person can stabilize them?

The perfected person engages with the world, yet how vast it is! Yet it is not enough to burden them. The world brandishes its power, yet they do not join in its pursuits. They discern the unreal and do not follow profit’s shifts. They grasp the essence of things and hold fast to their root. Thus, though they encompass heaven and earth and embrace the ten thousand things, their spirit is never constrained.

In harmony with the Dao, in accord with virtue, they relegate benevolence and righteousness, treat ritual and music as guests—the perfected person’s heart is thus settled.

Guo’s commentary: The perfected person employs the world yet does not fear its vastness. "Not joining in its pursuits" means to remain still and follow along. "Not following profit’s shifts" means to act with authenticity and proceed directly. "Relegating benevolence and righteousness" means advancing the Dao and virtue. "Treating ritual and music as guests" means taking essence and nature as primary. The perfected person’s heart is settled—settled in non-action.

Lü’s commentary: "In its vastness does not terminate" means heaven and earth are not separate from its embrace. "In its subtlety does not neglect" means even the autumn hair awaits its completion. Of the things under heaven, is there any not encompassed? Boundless, it admits all; unfathomable, it cannot be plumbed—this is how the Dao becomes spirit. Flowing forth, it takes form; losing its form, it becomes virtue; decaying, it becomes benevolence and righteousness—these are but the vestiges of spirit. Who but the perfected person can stabilize them?

"Engaging with the world is not enough to burden them"—they can abandon the world. "The world brandishes its power, yet they do not join in its pursuits"—they forget the world. Forgetting the world, they do not follow profit’s shifts. Able to abandon the world, they hold fast to their root. The spirit is constrained only by not knowing this.

Not obstructing the Dao, not adulterating virtue, relegating benevolence and righteousness without clinging, treating ritual and music as guests without making them primary—only then is the heart settled.

Detailed Explanation of the Dao: The great must have an end; the small is often overlooked. The Dao does not terminate in the great nor neglect the small. Great and small do not depart from the embodied, yet the formless does not concern itself with great or small. To discuss the Dao in terms of great and small is but to grasp at the fish-trap and rabbit-snare.

What the spirit responds to lies outside—when the external is forgotten, the spirit is whole. What the heart preserves lies within—when the internal is forgotten, the heart is still. Heaven, earth, and the ten thousand things are external; thus, to forget and abandon them is to ensure the spirit is never constrained. Benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music are internal; thus, to relegate and treat them as guests is to settle the heart.

What the world values in the Dao is the written word. Yet writing is but speech, and speech has its value. What is valued in speech is meaning. What meaning follows cannot be transmitted through words. Yet the world, valuing words, transmits books. Though the world values them, they are still not truly valuable.

*For* (read in the falling tone) what is valued is not the true value. Thus, what can be seen are forms and colors; what can be heard are names and sounds. Alas! The world takes forms, colors, names, and sounds as sufficient to grasp the essence of things. Yet if forms, colors, names, and sounds are truly insufficient to grasp that essence, then the knowing do not speak, and the speaking do not know—how could the world recognize this?

Duke Huan was reading in the hall when Wheelwright Pian was hewing a wheel below. Setting down his mallet and chisel, he ascended and asked Duke Huan: "May I dare ask what words my lord is reading?"

"The words of the sages," replied the Duke.

"Are the sages still alive?"

"They are already dead."

"Then what my lord reads are but the dregs of the ancients."

Duke Huan said: "This ruler reads—how can a wheelwright presume to comment? If you have an explanation, speak; if not, you die."

Wheelwright Pian said: "Your servant observes from his own craft: when hewing a wheel, if too slow, it is smooth but not secure; if too fast, it is rough and does not fit. Not too slow, not too fast—it is grasped by the hand and responds to the heart. The mouth cannot express it, yet a certain skill resides within. I cannot make my son understand it, nor can my son receive it from me. Thus, at seventy years old, I am still hewing wheels. If the ancients and their untransmittable truths are dead, then what my lord reads are but the dregs of the ancients."

*(Duke Huan was Duke Huan of Qi. Wheelwright Pian was a craftsman named Pian. "Dregs" refers to the lees of fermented grain; another version reads "husks." "Smooth" means loose; "rough" means tight.)*

Guo's Annotation:
What is truly noble lies not in what is called noble, for its nobility ever resides beyond words and meaning. Only those who forget words and discard texts may grasp that reality. This is the intent of "cutting off learning" and "abandoning esteem." Wheelwright Pian could not make his son understand—each thing has its nature, and teaching is of no avail. The affairs of antiquity have perished in antiquity; even if transmitted, how could they make the ancient present in the now? The ancient is not in the present, and present affairs have already changed. Thus, to cut off learning, follow one’s nature, and move with the transformations of time—only then may one arrive.

Lü's Annotation:
Zhuangzi speaks here to urge scholars to forget words and texts, seeking not among forms, colors, names, or reputations. Hewing wheels is a coarse matter, yet the slow and fast, the smooth and rough, grasped by the hand and responding to the heart—even father and son cannot make one another understand or receive it. How much more difficult, then, is the transmission of the Dao as a thing! If one cannot seek it in the heart but only reads books, then the analogy of dregs is no empty word.

Detailed Explanation of the Dao:
Words in texts relate to meaning as forms, colors, sounds, and names relate to reality. Reality cannot be obtained from forms, colors, names, or sounds; meaning cannot be transmitted through words in texts—this is certain. Thus, the adept in the *Yi* obtains the meaning and forgets the images, obtains the images and forgets the words. The adept in poetry obtains the intent and forgets the phrases, obtains the phrases and forgets the lines. Is this not what is meant by "when the sacrifice is over, the straw dogs are discarded," "the pure essence flows away, and the dregs are cast aside"? It is why Duke Huan, through Wheelwright Pian, awakened to the futility of reading books, and why Wang Shou, through Xu Feng, rose to dance and burn his texts.

A Humble Overview and General Discussion:
This chapter takes "Heavenly Dao" as its title, prominently marking its beginning. It then sets forth the Dao of the Emperor, the Dao of the Sage, the Dao of the Dark Sage, and the unadorned kingly enterprise, all centered on the Dao and virtue, the constant of non-action—this is the Dao that rides Heaven and Earth, drives the myriad things, and serves the governance of human society. In its middle sections, it enumerates virtue, teaching, ritual, music, benevolence, righteousness, the division of duties, names, rewards, and punishments—all the instruments of ordering the world—yet none depart from the constant of the human Dao. Why? For one who excels in discoursing on the Heavenly Dao must be grounded in the human capacity to fulfill the human Dao, and thus may match Heaven. Heaven and humanity communicate; root and branch are one, vast without limit, deep beyond fathoming. How can one know that Heaven is not human, or that humanity is not Heaven?

When it discusses the five transformations and the establishment of names, the nine transformations and the application of rewards and punishments, these are the unchanging principles of all ages, the means by which human standards are set and the Heavenly Dao is praised. As for the Heavenly virtue emerging in tranquility, the sun and moon shining, the four seasons proceeding, day and night following their course, clouds moving and rain falling—these are Heaven’s self-expression, its solitary luminosity and spontaneous transformation. How could the Dao of Earth or the Dao of humanity fail to follow?

The cultivation of governance instruments to order the Dao is a common discourse of past and present. Yet some use them to bring order, while others use them to bring chaos—this is because they do not know the sequence of root and branch, before and after, or the proper balance of detail and essentials in ruler and minister. The world says that the *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] often esteems non-action and neglects governance instruments, but observing what this chapter sets forth—ritual, music, and political teachings—its subtlety and precision surpass what other masters can attain. All emerge naturally from Heaven’s principle, merely enacted through human agency.

If one truly understands the principle of spontaneity, one may proceed from governance instruments to comprehend the Dao of governance, so that ruler and minister, father and son, birds and beasts, grasses and trees all attain their proper place. The world will beat time on the earth and sing, unaware of imperial power—this may be called non-action. Yet when Confucius wished to hide his books and unrolled the classics to expound them to Cheng Qi, or when he was asked about cultivating the self and his countenance became stern—these were cases of following humanity and forgetting Heaven, which is why Lao Dan did not approve.

Only the perfected person knows that benevolence and righteousness are the branches of the Dao, and ritual and music are its guests. They can be Heavenly and human, exhaust the real and guard the root, and their spirit is never troubled. Thus, though there be an age, it is not enough to burden them. In the end, it takes the analogy of "obtaining meaning from discarded texts" and "dregs and lees" through Wheelwright Pian, for it fears that scholars may follow traces and forget the heart, abandon the root and pursue the branches, thereby drifting ever farther from the Dao. One should thoroughly investigate what the sage does not forget, so that scholars may themselves cut off learning and enter the profound, and those who would transmit may attain the transmission without transmission—then the heart of Heaven and Earth and the sages will be seen. Why cling to the dregs and lees of the ancients?

**Chapter Fourteen: The Turning of Heaven**

Does Heaven turn? Does Earth abide? Do the sun and moon contend for their places? Who governs and sustains this? Who weaves and upholds this? Who, without toil, propels and moves it? Is there some mechanism that compels it, leaving it no choice? Or does it revolve of itself, unable to cease? Does cloud become rain? Does rain become cloud? Who bestows and dispenses this? Who, without toil, indulges in excess and urges it on? The wind rises from the north, now west, now east, drifting aloft—who exhales and inhales this? Who, without toil, stirs and scatters it? May I ask the reason?

Wu Xian Chao replied: Come, I shall tell you. Heaven possesses the Six Limits and the Five Constants. When emperors and kings align with them, there is order; when they oppose them, there is chaos. The affairs of the Nine Luo bring governance to completion and virtue to fulfillment, illuminating the lands below. All under Heaven uphold them—this is called the Supreme August.

*(Alternative readings: "aloft" for "in the heights"; "wandering" for "drifting"; "whirlwind" for "gale." Wu Xian was a minister of Yin named Chao. The Six Limits refer to the four directions, above, and below. The Five Constants are the Five Phases. The Nine Luo are the nine regions of the realm.)*

Guo’s commentary:
Heaven does not turn yet moves of itself; Earth does not abide yet rests of itself; the sun and moon do not contend for their places yet alternate and pass away of themselves. Who governs and sustains this? All is self-so. Without it, nothing could be propelled; with it, each acts of its own accord. Then who, without toil, propels and moves it? None—each moves of itself.

Thus, being self-so, it cannot be known. Clouds and rain—these two cannot act upon each other, yet each is self-so. May I ask why? The question is posed precisely to illustrate the reason for their self-so nature. In proximate matters, one may discern their causes, yet tracing their origins to the utmost reveals no cause but their self-so nature. Being self-so, one can only accord with it: to accord is order, to oppose is chaos. This is because acquired learning may be altered, but Heaven-endowed nature cannot be reversed. Order is achieved, virtue is perfected, and the lands below are illuminated—all under Heaven uphold them because they accord with what is self-so.

---

Lü’s commentary:
Heaven’s movement, Earth’s stillness—I know not their true movement or true stillness. The sun and moon’s contest for position—I know not their true contest. Seeking their governor, their propelling force, yields nothing. Water ascends to become clouds, clouds dissolve to become rain—seeking their bestower of bounty or their indulgent joy yields nothing. Winds rise from the west, drift eastward, wandering without constancy—seeking their exhalation, inhalation, or sweeping force yields nothing. This is the unfathomable workings of the Dao, manifesting as the numinous. To know the numinous is to understand that all governance, bounty, and sweeping force arise from this alone. The Five Constants correspond to the Five Fortunes; when applied, the Five Fortunes bring authority, while the Six Limits bring calamity. To accord with them is auspicious; to oppose them is inauspicious. The Nine Luo are the *Luoshu*’s nine categories, whose application extends to fortune and calamity. When order is achieved, virtue is perfected, the lands below are illuminated, and all under Heaven uphold them—this is the Supreme August. The Supreme August harnesses Heaven and Earth, drives the sun and moon, dispenses clouds and rain, exhales and inhales the winds and qi, yet abides in the realm of non-action. Must one seek this in the primordial age?

---

Xiang Dao’s explication:
Heaven and Earth’s movement and stillness, the sun and moon’s coming and going—clouds emerge from Earth yet originate in Heaven, rain descends from Heaven yet originates in Earth, winds blow eastward yet arise from the north. Their covering and bearing, their illumination and oversight, their defense and nourishment—none are willed; all are borne of the Dao’s self-so nature. The wild horses drift yet do not move, the whirlwind topples mountains yet remains still, rivers rush yet do not flow, the sun and moon traverse the heavens yet do not revolve. Thus, Heaven and Earth’s movement and stillness arise from their non-movement and non-stillness; the sun and moon’s coming and going arise from their non-coming and non-going. Who can truly fathom their governor? Who knows what is meant by a true master?

---

Xun Ben’s note:
The sun and moon share the ecliptic, hence the phrase “contest for position.” The mechanism is as if bound by a cord—without it, they cannot halt. Winds arise from the north, proceed westward and eastward, then ascend and wander. They arise from the north and thus naturally move south, so the south need not be mentioned; they ascend from below, so the below need not be mentioned.

---

The Grand Steward Dang of Shang asked Zhuangzi about benevolence. Zhuangzi said, “Tigers and wolves are benevolent.”
Dang asked, “What do you mean?”
Zhuangzi replied, “Father and son are affectionate—why are they not benevolent?”
Dang said, “May I ask about perfect benevolence?”
Zhuangzi said, “Perfect benevolence has no partiality.”
Dang said, “I have heard that without partiality, there is no love; without love, there is no filial piety. Can perfect benevolence be unfilial?”
Zhuangzi said, “Not so. Perfect benevolence is loftier still. Filial piety is insufficient to describe it—this is not a matter of surpassing filial piety, but of falling short of it. One who travels south to Ying turns northward and does not see Mount Fang—why? Because it lies too far away. Thus, it is easier to practice filial piety with reverence than with love; easier to practice it with love than to forget one’s parents; easier to forget one’s parents than to make one’s parents forget oneself; easier to make one’s parents forget oneself than to forget all under Heaven; easier to forget all under Heaven than to make all under Heaven forget oneself. Virtue left Yao and Shun behind without effort; their beneficence extended to ten thousand generations, yet none in the world knew it. How could one merely sigh and speak of benevolence and filial piety?”

Ah! Filial piety, fraternal duty, benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, trustworthiness, chastity, and integrity—these are all virtues by which one exhorts oneself to toil in service of one’s power, yet they are not worthy of praise. Thus it is said: the most noble discard state rank as one; the most wealthy discard state wealth as one; the most aspiring discard fame and reputation as one. Therefore, the Dao does not waver.

Guo’s commentary:
“Having no kin” does not mean to slight or despise them. The human body is one whole, yet it has no kin: the head naturally resides above, the feet naturally reside below, the organs dwell within, the skin and hair lie without. Within the body, outer and inner, above and below, noble and base, honored and humble each fulfill their utmost, yet there is no partial love among them. Thus, perfect benevolence suffices. Therefore, the five relations and six clans, the worthy and the foolish, the near and the far—none lose their place in the world, for this is the natural principle. What need is there for “having kin”? Filial piety is not worth speaking of; only when one speaks of it in the realm of forgetting benevolence and forgetting filial piety does one reach the ultimate. All names arise from insufficiency, so only by transcending the names of benevolence and filial piety and entering the realm of namelessness does one attain the ultimate. Mount Fang lies in the north, yet one traveling south to observe it finds it ever more distant. Perfect benevolence lies in having no kin, yet when one speaks of it in terms of benevolence and love, Ying may be seen, but it grows ever more distant. Though benevolence and filial piety may be manifest, they are ever farther from the ultimate principle. The perfectly benevolent one finds all parts of the body fitting, and thus goes through the day without self-awareness. When the sage is above, he does not act with purpose; he lets all things follow their own course and find their own fulfillment. When each finds its own fulfillment, all affairs naturally fit, all beings naturally suffice, and how could the world fail to forget itself? When all forget themselves, where does the ruler reside? This is what is called “mutual forgetting.” Only when virtue leaves Yao and Shun behind are the virtues of Yao and Shun complete. If one binds it in the heart, it is not self-attainment. The world knows it not, and all is serene and constantly fitting. Those who sigh and speak of benevolence and filial piety have lost themselves in rivers and lakes and think only of wetting their lips. “Discarding” means to cast away. The noble lies in the person; if one forgets even the person, how much more state rank? This is the ultimate nobility. The most wealthy is self-sufficient alone; thus, one discards the wealth of all under Heaven. The most aspiring is contentment; attaining contentment, the names of benevolence and filial piety all depart. Therefore, the Dao does not waver, casting off the flower and taking the fruit.

Lü’s commentary:
The common world takes love as benevolence, yet how can the mutual affection of tiger and wolf father and child not be called benevolence? As for perfect benevolence, it is the benevolence of Heaven and Earth and the sage. It merges with the Dao in substance and acts without purpose—how could it harbor intention within? This is why perfect benevolence has no kin. To say “having no kin, then no love; no love, then no filial piety” is speech that falls short of filial piety. Perfect benevolence has no kin, and thus it surpasses speech of filial piety. One traveling south does not see Mount Fang because it lies too far away. Perfect benevolence renders speech of filial piety insufficient, for it too lies too far away. Reverence is ritual; love is emotion; forgetting kin is the Dao. Forgetting kin is forgetting what lies within oneself; making one’s kin forget oneself is forgetting what lies in others. Mutually forgetting all under Heaven means I can put the world outside myself, yet when all under Heaven mutually forget me, the world goes forth and we forget one another. Practicing benevolence to this point, virtue leaves Yao and Shun behind without effort; beneficence extends to ten thousand generations, yet none in the world knows it. This is called merging with the Dao in substance and acting without purpose. How could one merely sigh and speak of benevolence and filial piety?

From the perspective of perfect benevolence, filial piety, fraternal duty, benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, trustworthiness, chastity, and integrity are all virtues by which one exhorts oneself to toil in service of one’s power—how could they be worthy of praise? Thus, the most noble discard state rank as one; the most wealthy discard state wealth as one. This is to grasp the nobility and wealth of all under Heaven and control its ranks and riches. The most aspiring discard fame and reputation as one. Cultivating what one may aspire to and reaching perfect benevolence, even if one discards filial piety and fraternal duty, their fame and reputation are already included within. The Dao does not waver, for the Dao is present wherever one goes.

Northern Gate Cheng asked the Yellow Emperor, saying: "When Your Majesty performed the music of *Xianchi* in the wilds of Dongting, at first I heard it and was afraid; I heard it again and grew weary; at last I heard it and was bewildered—adrift, silent, and no longer myself."

The Emperor said: "You were nearly so! I performed it with human affairs, verified it with the movements of Heaven, conducted it with ritual propriety, and established it with the Great Purity. The supreme music first responds to human affairs, accords with the principles of Heaven, proceeds through the Five Virtues, and answers to spontaneity. Only then does it harmonize the four seasons and bring all things into perfect harmony. The four seasons arise in succession, and the myriad things follow their generation—now flourishing, now declining; the patterns of civil and martial order alternate; now clarity, now turbidity; yin and yang blend in harmony, their radiance flowing as sound. When hibernating creatures first stir, I startle them with thunder. In the end, it has no tail; in the beginning, no head—now dying, now living; now collapsing, now rising. What is constant is inexhaustible, yet one cannot await it—thus you were afraid.

Then I performed it with the harmony of yin and yang, illuminated it with the brightness of sun and moon. Its sound could be short or long, soft or firm, its transformations uniform yet not fixed—thus it ever abides. It filled the valleys, filled the hollows, filled every crevice, guarding the spirit with things as its measure. Its sound soared and spread, its name lofty and luminous. Thus, spirits guarded its depths, while the sun, moon, and stars followed their courses. I halted it at the bounded, yet let it flow into the boundless. You wished to ponder it but could not comprehend it; to gaze upon it but could not see it; to pursue it but could not overtake it."

Perchance standing in the boundless Way of the four voids, leaning upon a withered catalpa to chant—
your eyes reach their limit in what they long to see,
your strength falters in what they long to pursue.
I, having already fallen short, ceased.
When form fills emptiness, it becomes utterly supple.
You, supple, thus grew lax.

Then I played for you a sound without laxity,
tuned it to the mandate of spontaneity.
Thus it seemed to merge with the chase, to flourish in thickets and groves,
joyous yet without form,
spreading and unfurling without trailing,
dim and obscure yet soundless,
moving without direction,
dwelling in profound seclusion.
Some call it death, some life;
some call it substance, some glory.
Flowing, scattering, shifting—no constant master.
The world doubts it, yet the sage examines it.
The sage is one who penetrates to reality and fulfills the mandate.
The celestial mechanism is not displayed, yet the five officials are all in place—
this is called celestial music.
Though wordless, the heart delights.
Thus the Lord of Yán composed a hymn for it, saying:
*Hear it yet hear no sound,
see it yet see no form.
Filling heaven and earth,
enveloping the six directions—
you long to listen yet find no point of contact,
and thus are bewildered.*

Music begins with fear—
fear, thus reverence.
Then I followed with laxity—
laxity, thus escape.
Finally, bewilderment—
bewilderment, thus folly.
Folly, thus the Way.
The Way can be borne and journeyed with together.

The *Fèn* Sima states: "I am but a servant." *Kēng*, according to the *Ěryǎ*, means "void." Guo’s commentary: "This is what is called ‘sitting in forgetfulness’—not finding oneself in self-possession. The ultimate music is not a matter of sounds and tones. It must first accord with Heaven, respond to man, be grasped by the heart, and suit the nature; only then is it expressed in sound and performed in melody. Thus, the music of *Xiánchí* could only be completed after the transformation of the Yellow Emperor. The natural pitch-pipes fill the space between Heaven and Earth, but if one merely follows without seizing, the ultimate music is preserved whole. Therefore, one acts in accordance with its spontaneous arising, employing its inherent movements—without beginning, without end, revolving without limit, taking transformation as its constant. Thus, what is constant is inexhaustible.

At first hearing, the inexhaustible transformations cannot be met with uniformity, so one is fearful and listens with reverence. It is performed with yin and yang, illuminated by the sun and moon—this is called ‘employing the Dao of Heaven.’ Equalizing all within transformation without fixity, it thus constantly fills valleys and voids; the ultimate music is all-pervading. The paths of the senses are guarded, the gates of perception sealed. Taking things as measure, the great system remains uncarved. Its sounds are expansive and harmonious—what is called ‘manifesting harmony.’ When the name is fitting, the reality is lofty and luminous. Thus, spirits do not depart from their places, and the sun and stars do not lose their courses, abiding within limits while dwelling at the utmost extreme. Flowing without cessation, they follow transformation wherever it goes.

Contemplation cannot fathom it; pursuit cannot overtake it. Thus, one is dimly resigned, allowing transformation to depart, standing carefree amid the fourfold emptiness—this is called ‘boundless openness.’ Chanting beneath the withered *wú* tree, there is nothing left to be done. The knowledge and power of things each have their limits; when form fills emptiness, there is no self. Without self, one can be supple and yielding. Supple and yielding, one follows one’s nature, and the emotion of reverence slackens. Once the intent slackens, one attains the state beyond slackness—this is the ultimate."
