What is endowed by fate is not through action—all is natural. In undifferentiated oneness, unbound, it arises amidst the thicket. Supreme joy lies in nothing more than attunement; attunement resides within the body, thus requiring no separate form. Its unfolding is effortless, self-spreading without strain—this is what is called "supreme joy." Moving without fixed direction, dwelling in profound obscurity—this is what is called "tranquil extremity." Life and death, flourishing and decay, flow and shift without fixed abode; their resonance changes with things.

The world doubts this, yet the sages verify it. The enlightened sage responds to the world not by initiating, but by comprehending emotions and fulfilling fate. Those who speak of emotions and fate draw from this. Joy forgotten is joy fulfilled; it is not through display that one is prepared. The heart delights in attunement, not in words. The hymn of Youyan is the joy of no-joy—the ultimate joy. Startled and reverent in listening, one venerates the ear, yet this is not the great harmony. Next comes slackness, and thus one retreats, traces gradually fading. Delusion gives rise to foolishness; thus the Dao takes "no-knowledge" as foolishness, and foolishness becomes the ultimate.

---
**Lü’s Annotation:**
Joy is the Dao itself. In the vast wilderness of Dongting, in boundless expanses, when music is played, though people praise it as heavenly principle, true joy emerges from emptiness. Conduct guided by ritual and righteousness arises from the Great Purity, while music established in the Grand Beginning. The four seasons and the myriad things—none are not joy. Prosperity and decline, civil and martial arts, the warp and weft of governance—these cannot be disordered. The harmony of clear and turbid, yin and yang—never discordant. Its resonance flows luminously between heaven and earth, yet without stimulus, it does not manifest.

Seeking its root and branch, it has no beginning, no end. Life and death surge forth, yet what is constant is inexhaustible and one—unawaitable. Thus, one fears this, for there is no "other." I demonstrate it through humanity, and they enter through humanity. Yet entering through humanity, the myriad transformations differ—what is called "one" cannot be awaited. How fitting is this fear!

Moreover, when played with yin and yang, illuminated by sun and moon, it is simply heaven. Its duration is not fixed; it fills valleys and brims ravines. Guarding the spirit in its place, taking things as measure—this is how resonance arises. Effortless and unconstrained by the cosmos, lofty and luminous—this is how it becomes heaven. The spirit guards the obscure; the sun and stars follow their courses, abiding within limits. Flowing without cessation, it follows transformation wherever it goes. Contemplation cannot fathom it; pursuit cannot overtake it. The eye exhausts its vision, strength falters, and one becomes supple and yielding—thus slackness arises. There is no "other." I demonstrate it through heaven, and they receive it through heaven. Again, I play it with no slackness, harmonizing with the natural. Undifferentiated, it follows the thicket’s growth—the myriad things flourish abundantly.

Forest joy has no form; each returns to its root. Its unfolding is effortless, moving without fixed direction. Dwelling in profound obscurity, it is soundless. Life and death, flourishing and decay, shift without constancy—thus it is not constrained by the one. This is what the world doubts, yet the sage embodies it in rising, dwelling, and all moments, never departing. What is called a sage is none other than one who comprehends emotions and fulfills fate. Hearing and seeing—nothing is not this. Thus, it is simply the heavenly mechanism. This is the heavenly joy: wordless yet delighting the heart.

Therefore, the hymn of Youyan and the marvel of *Xianchi*—such is their wonder. If you wish to hear it, you must do so without attachment, for my hearing is not employed—hence delusion. There is no other reason: it is the forgetting of the self, the forgetting of humanity.

Only heaven—this is where fear begins, hence the dread of spirits. Then comes negligence, hence escape. Finally, confusion, hence folly. The reason the self cannot bear the Dao is its brilliance of knowledge and perception. Only by shedding knowledge and embracing folly can one bear the Dao and journey with it in unity.

Following the root, vast and boundless, the spirit unsettled, silently the mouth unable to speak, the heart ill at ease, never self-content. The four seasons and the myriad things speak of the spontaneity of creation and transformation—prosperity and decline, civil and martial, clarity and turbidity, yin and yang—alluding to their rhythmic cadence. "Flowing light" describes the radiance of their sound, smooth and luminous.

This line harmonizes with the preceding rhyme, pure and unadulterated. When hibernating creatures first stir, I startle them with thunder. In the end, no tail; in the beginning, no head—suddenly arising, suddenly ceasing, like thunder’s unfathomable might. One death, one life; one collapse, one rise—ever constant, unending, yet the "one" cannot be awaited. Read as a continuous sequence: one death follows one life, one collapse follows one rise, cycling endlessly without pause. How can one hesitate or wait?

Beimen Cheng, hearing this music, was filled with terror. I then played for him the harmony of yin and yang, illuminating it with the brightness of sun and moon. Though harmonious, distinctions remained—this is what is called "luminous clarity." Its sound could be short or long, soft or firm, ever-changing yet uniform, thus always luminously clear. Whether in valleys or ravines, the sound fills all—where it flows, it saturates. "Stopping up the ears" means merely blocking them; "sealing the eyes" means merely closing them. My music does not rely on keen hearing or sharp sight but guards the spirit, following the measure of things as they are. The sound’s magnitude arises from the capacity of what receives it. The music’s resonance expands boundlessly; its name looms vast and manifest. The spirit guards its mystery; sun, moon, and stars follow their courses, each unconfused. I halt it at the finite, flow it into the infinite—sometimes halting, sometimes flowing, without constancy.

Though you may strive to comprehend it, you cannot know it; though you may gaze upon it, you cannot see it; though you may pursue it, you cannot reach it. Helplessly adrift, you stand at the crossroads of emptiness, leaning against a withered catalpa, chanting—only to find your eyes exhausted, your strength spent. This is what is meant by "though you wish to follow, there is no way."

Once it becomes unattainable, you see only its form filling the void, and your heart drifts, slackening of its own accord. I then played for him the sound of "no negligence"—what is called "no negligence" is attuned to the natural mandate of heaven, flowing as spontaneously as fate. Thus, its sound blends indistinctly, surging forth in clusters, rejoicing together like a forest, yet without form—this is what is called "continuous resonance."

When it spreads and acts, it exhausts all without residue; when it trails into profound obscurity, it falls utterly silent. In motion, it has no fixed direction; in stillness, it dwells in unfathomable depths, beyond measure. Some call it death, some life; some call it substance, some flourishing—only its ceaseless flux is seen, its sound without constancy. Thus, one doubts and examines its principles, consulting the sage, for only the sage can fathom human emotions and fulfill heaven’s mandate. This music is not for any but the sage.

This "mandate" echoes the earlier "attuned to the natural mandate." The heavenly mechanism neither unfolds nor restrains—its subtle workings are ever-present. The five officials are all complete; the five tones they govern are fully equipped. "Heavenly joy" is the natural mandate itself—ineffable yet delighting the heart. I cite the hymn of Youyan to reveal the marvel beyond sound.

If you wish to hear its wonder, you must not cling, for my hearing is not employed—hence confusion. Fear sharpens the spirit, as if haunted by spirits—hence "dread." Negligence exhausts the heart’s strength, making one wish to flee—hence "escape." Confusion clouds knowledge—hence "folly." Only through folly can one enter the Dao, and only then can one bear it and journey alongside.

This discussion of music extends to the Dao. The passage, though seemingly abrupt like the music played in the wilds of Dongting—without head or tail, difficult to grasp at first—unfolds with coherence upon careful reflection. It originates from Confucius’ discourse on music to the Grand Master, yet Zhuangzi does not merely repeat old words. His discussion of music naturally achieves such subtlety.

Confucius traveled west to Wei. Yan Yuan asked Shi Jin, “What of your master’s conduct?”
Shi Jin replied, “Alas! Your master is doomed to hardship.”
Yan Yuan said, “How so?”
Shi Jin said, “Before the straw dogs are presented…”

When the straw dogs are yet to be presented, they are stored in fine baskets, wrapped in embroidered cloths; the invocators and shamans fast and purify themselves to prepare them. Once presented and used, passersby trample their heads and spines, while gatherers of kindling take them for fuel—no more. Yet should one again store them in fine baskets, wrap them in embroidered cloths, and rest or sleep beneath them, they would surely suffer nightmares or frequent confusion.

Now, your master has taken the already-used straw dogs of the former kings, and with his disciples, rests and sleeps beneath them. Thus, he was felled like a tree in Song, erased his tracks in Wei, and found himself in dire straits between Shang and Zhou—was this not his nightmare? Besieged between Chen and Cai, seven days without cooked food, death and life as close as neighbors—was this not his confusion?

In water, nothing surpasses the use of a boat; on land, nothing surpasses the use of a cart. It is because a boat can traverse water that one would seek to push it on land—yet to do so would be futile for a lifetime, covering but a few paces. Are ancient and modern times not like water and land? Are Zhou and Lu not like boat and cart? To seek to implement Zhou’s ways in Lu is like pushing a boat on land—laborious yet fruitless, and one’s person will surely meet with misfortune. He does not understand the transmission of the boundless, which responds to things without exhaustion.

Moreover, have you alone not seen the well-sweep? Pulled, it bows; released, it rises. What pulls it is not the pull of man, and so it bows and rises without offending anyone. Thus, the rites, righteousness, laws, and standards of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors were not prized for their sameness but for their efficacy in governance. The rites, righteousness, laws, and standards of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors—are they not like the crabapple, pear, orange, and pomelo? Their flavors differ, yet all are pleasing to the mouth. Thus, rites, righteousness, laws, and standards are things that change with the times.

Now, if one were to take an ape and dress it in the robes of the Duke of Zhou, it would surely gnaw, tear, and rend them, casting them off entirely before being satisfied. Observe the differences between ancient and modern times—are they not like the differences between an ape and the Duke of Zhou?

When Xishi suffered from a heart ailment, she knit her brows in her village, and the village’s ugly women, seeing this, thought it beautiful. Returning home, they too clutched their chests and knit their brows. The village’s rich men, seeing this, firmly shut their doors and refused to come out; the poor, seeing it, took their wives and children and fled. They knew the beauty of knitting brows but did not know why it was beautiful.

Alas! Your master is doomed to hardship.

The herb *su* is taken as grass, and *mi* (眯), according to Sima Biao, means "to press down." Some texts write it as *yan* (魇), referring to nightmares and strange visions. To knit the brows is called *pin* (矉).

Guo Xiang’s commentary states: "Discarded things, when useless in their time, only invite further calamities. The notion of dreams and *mi* alludes to the idea of abolishing sagacity and discarding knowledge—nothing is to be slighted. The rituals and laws of the former kings served to suit their times; when their time has passed and they are not abandoned, they become monstrosities for the people, giving rise to the beginnings of affectation and imitation. Thus, as times change and the world transforms, rituals must also adapt. Following things without attachment is how one achieves effortless success.

The rituals, virtues, laws, and standards of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors aimed only to suit their times and respond to the needs of governance. What one age deemed beautiful, another might deem ugly. Only by adapting to the times can all things be fitting. Thus, rituals and virtues, when used in their proper time, are like Xishi; when clung to past their time, they become like the ugly women."

Expounding on the Dao:
"The songs of Qi, Chu, Yan, and Wei differ in melody yet all bring joy; the wails of the Nine Yi and Eight Man differ in sound yet all evoke sorrow. Therefore, the sage’s governance of the world rides the times to establish what is fitting and follows the people to set laws. If it truly benefits the state, methods need not be uniform; if it truly suits the matter, rituals need not be the same. Thus, Fuxi and Shennong taught without punishment; the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun punished without anger. The Xia valued substance over ornament; the Zhou valued ornament over substance. Can the laws of antiquity be applied today? Can today’s laws be rigidly adhered to antiquity? Confucius drew from the past to guide the present—not to cling to it, but to trace the path back to its origin.

Master Jin feared that the world would drown in the ills of clinging to traces, so he first compared it to straw dogs and boats, then to the shadoof and citrus fruits, and finally to apes and ugliness—just as the ways of antiquity and Zhou cannot be made one with the present."

At fifty-one, Confucius had yet to hear the Dao. He traveled south to Pei to visit Lao Dan, who said: "Have you come? I have heard you are a worthy man of the north. Have you attained the Dao?"
Confucius replied: "I have not."
Lao Dan asked: "How have you sought it?"
Confucius said: "I sought it in regulations and measures for five years but did not attain it."
Lao Dan asked: "How else have you sought it?"
Confucius said: "I sought it in yin and yang for twelve years but still did not attain it."
Lao Dan said: "Indeed. If the Dao could be offered, none would fail to offer it to their lord; if it could be presented, none would fail to present it to their parents; if it could be told, none would fail to tell it to their brothers; if it could be given, none would fail to give it to their children and grandchildren. Yet it cannot—there is no other reason: without an inner host, it does not stay; without an outer standard, it does not proceed. What issues from within cannot be received from without; the sage does not issue it. What enters from without has no host within; the sage does not store it. The name is a public vessel—it cannot be taken in excess.

Benevolence and righteousness are the temporary lodgings of the former kings. One may stay a night but cannot dwell there long. To gaze upon them and demand much is to invite trouble. The utmost person of antiquity borrowed the Dao from benevolence and lodged in righteousness to wander in the emptiness of freedom, to eat from the fields of simplicity, and to stand in the garden of non-giving. Freedom is effortless action; simplicity is easy nurturance; non-giving means no loss. The ancients called this the wandering of gathering truth.

Those who take wealth as right cannot relinquish emolument; those who take fame as right cannot relinquish renown. Those who cling to power cannot share authority. Grasping it, they tremble; releasing it, they grieve—and in all this, they have nothing to reflect upon, no mirror to see what never rests. These are the people punished by Heaven. Resentment and gratitude, taking and giving, admonition and teaching, life and death—these eight are the instruments of rectification. Only those who follow great changes without obstruction can wield them.

Thus, it is said: 'Rectification is rectitude.' If one’s heart does not accept this, the gate of Heaven will not open."

Guo Xiang’s commentary: "This all borrows from Confucius and Laozi to clarify the meaning of abolishing learning. 'Without an inner host, it does not stay' means that without the capacity to receive the Dao in the center, even if one hears it, it passes by. 'Without an outer standard, it does not proceed' means that without an inner host, external things also lack proper alignment, so there is no communication.

What issues from within is the sage’s Dao, but it only emerges when there is one outside capable of receiving it. What enters from without is learning that forms one’s nature, but even if it forms through borrowed learning, it must have an inner host—without one, there is no place to store the sagely Dao.

The name is what the world shares; excessive adornment and taking beyond what is real cause disorder. *Qulu* (temporary lodging) is like a travelers’ inn. Benevolence and righteousness are human nature, but human nature changes with the times. To wander and lodge without attachment is like passing through without hindrance; to be bound to one place is to be seen, and where there is seeing, falsity arises. Falsity arises, and demands multiply.

Borrowing the Dao and lodging in righteousness means adapting to the times without fixed traces. Freedom is effortless action; effortful action is not benevolence or righteousness. Following simplicity makes nurturance easy. 'Non-giving' means not harming oneself for the sake of things. Wandering and following one’s nature is gathering truth; gathering truth means appearances are not falsified.

The world has no one who burdens themselves with what they reject, yet all perish in what they affirm. To perish in what one affirms is not to stand in the garden of non-giving."

The sorrow of relinquishment is that one cannot grasp it without trembling. To have nothing to reflect upon and peer into what never ceases—this means knowing how to advance but not how to stop, and thus one’s nature and life are lost. "To be executed at the Gate of Heaven without opening" speaks of clinging to the old without change, and thus losing the correct path.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
The Dao gives birth to the One, the One gives birth to the Two, the Two gives birth to the Three, yet the Dao is not the One, Two, or Three. Seeking it in measurements and numbers does not go beyond the bounds of numbers, thus after five years one has yet to attain the Dao. Dividing it into yin and yang, the Dao is not yin and yang. Seeking it in yin and yang does not go beyond the vastness of the heavens, thus after twelve years one has yet to attain the Dao. The reason it cannot be offered to one’s parents, told to one’s brothers and descendants, is that within there is no master, and without there is no correctness. With no master within, though I wish to bestow it, the other does not stop. With no correctness without, though the other wishes to receive it, I cannot enact it. That things have a master is inherent to them. The Dao within oneself is simply one’s inherent possession; to lack it and yet possess it is to have no master within and thus no stopping. That archery has correctness is how it is received. The Dao in relation to others is simply what they receive; to lack what they receive and yet force it is to have no correctness without and thus no enactment. What issues from within is not received from without. The sage does not issue forth because there is no correctness. What enters from without has no master within. The sage does not store it because there is no stopping. Not storing it means it cannot be pushed and taken in—this is the meaning.

Thus, the Dao cannot be sought in measurements, numbers, or yin and yang. Seek it within oneself alone. Fame cannot be excessively taken; excessive taking dissipates virtue. Benevolence and righteousness cannot be long dwelled in; long dwelling leads to encounter and multiplied demands. Wandering freely means there is nowhere one does not reach. Following simplicity makes one’s seeking easy to sustain. "Non-giving" means not exchanging with things. In this way, all one gathers is nothing but truth. Inability to yield emolument means knowing only wealth. Inability to yield fame means knowing only prominence. Inability to yield power to others means knowing only authority. Those who cling to power and relinquishment harm their nature most severely. To have nothing to reflect upon and peer into the turbid water is to be deluded by the clear abyss. To never cease is to incur Heaven’s punishment, which cannot be undone. Gratitude and resentment, giving and taking, admonition and instruction, life and death—these eight are the instruments of correctness, not the Dao of correctness. Only by following great change without obstruction can one employ the instruments’ Dao. Using the instruments by means of the Dao—this is how correctness becomes correctness. The Gate of Heaven is the path by which one enters and exits, following great change without obstruction. To think otherwise is to know that the Gate of Heaven does not open.

**New Transmission:**
The Dao gathers in emptiness, and emptiness suffices to contain the Dao. Emptiness is unity, and its movement is unimpeded. Thus, without emptiness, it does not gather. Hence, "with no master within, there is no stopping." Without unity, there is no unimpeded movement. Hence, "with no correctness without, there is no enactment." What gathers within must move without—this is what is meant by issuing from within. What issues from within—how could it be received from without? This is why the sage firmly guards it. Thus, "what issues from within is not received from without; the sage does not issue forth." What moves without is due to gathering within—this is what is meant by entering from without. What enters from without—how could it gather without emptiness? This is why the sage must enact it. Thus, "what enters from without has no master within; the sage does not store it." This is Lao Dan’s discourse on the beginning and end of entering the Dao and putting it into practice.

**Xu Xi:**
"Encounter and multiplied demands" means that whenever one sees these, one will expect and demand of me. If even one is unmet, the former is lost. "To have nothing to reflect upon and peer into what never ceases" means having no sight of true principle, only peering into the ceaselessness of desires—this is the punishment of the people.

**Fu Mo:**
Gratitude and resentment, giving and taking, admonition and instruction, life and death—these are the instruments by which one corrects others. "Change" refers to the great matter of life and death. "Without obstruction" means responding to the moment with clarity, like a single blade cutting two—no obstruction remains. Using these instruments with such a person allows one not to be turned by circumstances and to wander in the realm of freedom. If one’s heart thinks otherwise, there is external seeing but no master within, and the Gate of Heaven does not open. The Gate of Heaven refers to the numinous palace, also derived from Laozi’s "opening and closing of the Gate of Heaven."

Confucius visited Lao Dan and spoke of benevolence and righteousness. Lao Dan said: "When chaff blinds the eyes, the heavens and earth and the four directions shift places. When mosquitoes and gnats bite the skin, one cannot sleep through the night. Benevolence and righteousness, so overwhelming—nothing confounds the heart more! If you, Master, could make the world not lose its simplicity, you would also move with the wind and stand with total virtue. Why then exert yourself like one carrying a great drum in search of a lost child? The swan does not bathe daily yet remains white; the crow does not blacken daily yet remains black. The simplicity of black and white is not sufficient for distinction. The spectacle of fame and reputation is not sufficient for vastness. When the spring dries up, fish find themselves together on land, exhaling moisture upon one another, wetting each other with foam—better to forget one another in the rivers and lakes."

Confucius visited Lao Dan and returned without speaking for three days. His disciples asked: "Master, when you saw Lao Dan, what advice did you receive?" Confucius said: "Only now have I truly seen the dragon! The dragon coalesces to form its body, scatters to form its patterns, riding the..."

The clouds and qi nourish the Yin and Yang—yet when I open my mouth, I cannot speak. What advice could I possibly offer Lao Dan?

Zi Gong said: "Then are there indeed men who dwell like corpses yet manifest as dragons, who thunder like thunder yet remain as silent as the abyss, whose movements are like those of Heaven and Earth? Might I be permitted to witness such a one?" Thereupon, he announced Confucius’s arrival to Lao Dan. Lao Dan was just then reclining in the hall and responded faintly: "The years have borne me away—what warning could you have for me?"

Zi Gong said: "The governance of the Three Kings and Five Emperors differed in method, yet their renown was the same. Why then do you alone deem them not sages?"

Lao Dan said: "Young man, come closer. Why do you say their methods differed?"

Zi Gong replied: "Yao ceded to Shun, Shun ceded to Yu. Yu labored with toil, while Tang wielded the sword. King Wen submitted to Zhou yet dared not oppose him; King Wu opposed Zhou yet would not submit. Thus I say their methods differed."

Lao Dan said: "Young man, come closer, and I will tell you of the governance of the Three Kings and Five Emperors. The governance of the Yellow Emperor made the hearts of the people one: when a man’s kin died, he did not weep, yet none reproached him. The governance of Yao made the hearts of the people affectionate: when a man killed for his kin, none reproached him. The governance of Shun made the hearts of the people competitive: pregnant women gave birth in ten months, and their children spoke at five months, yet before they could even toddle, some began to die young. The governance of Yu made the hearts of the people change: men grew cunning, and warfare followed its own order. Killing thieves was not considered killing men, and the world became a breeding ground for strife. Thus did the world grow greatly alarmed, and the Ru and Mo schools arose, each with its own standards. And now—what need have women to speak of such things?

I tell you: the governance of the Three August Ones and Five Emperors was called ‘order,’ yet no disorder was greater. The wisdom of the Three Kings contradicted the brightness of sun and moon, disrupted the essence of mountains and rivers, and threw into chaos the workings of the four seasons. Their cunning was more venomous than the sting of a scorpion’s tail or the bite of a centipede. Even the smallest creatures could not preserve the integrity of their natures—yet they still called themselves sages. Is this not shameful? Truly, it is shameless."

Zi Gong stood uneasily, shifting his feet.

A child speaks at five months—this is called hasty instruction. "Who" means distinguishing others' intentions. Before learning to laugh, one already selects people—this is called competing for swift mastery. If one cannot harmonize self and other, the heart contends over closeness and distance, and thus one does not fulfill one’s natural lifespan.

Warfare arises from compliance with words, for the world already harbors disobedience. Thieves naturally deserve death; killing them is compliance. Thus, only through killing can the myriad things be greatly equalized, and each person distinguishes themselves—this is how people become their own kind.

Following the flow of a hundred generations and guarding against the present age’s changes, this corruption has reached such a point—not through Yu. Thus it is said: the world is but an ear. The traces of sagely wisdom do not disrupt the world, yet the world inevitably falls into this chaos.

Ru and Mo both arose from this, the corruption of a hundred generations. Now, even women act in rebellion above and below—this is not due to the irrationality of the founders, but the corruption of the utmost principle has come to this. What more is there to say?

Though the governance of the Three Kings and Five Emperors did not escape corruption, Zi Gong originally believed Laozi alone surpassed the Three Kings and sought to equate the Three Kings with the Five Emperors. Now, seeing Laozi universally condemn the Five Emperors and extend his critique to the Three August Ones, he loses the basis of his argument.

---

Lü’s commentary:
Laozi likened benevolence and righteousness to chaff blinding the eyes or mosquitoes stinging the skin—thus, the Five Emperors and Three Kings were rightfully deemed unworthy of sageliness. Yet Zi Gong sought to reconcile them through yielding and contention, compliance and rebellion. In terms of their traces, altering the people’s hearts is no better than fostering kinship, and fostering kinship is no better than unity. All alike fail to avoid governing the world and making the people develop intentions—yet this is called "order," though the world’s chaos begins here.

If one employs cunning, it is not only the Five Emperors and Three Kings who will contradict the brightness of sun and moon below, disrupt the essence of mountains and rivers, and make their wisdom more venomous than the sting of a scorpion’s tail. Even the beasts that dwell in mountains and forests, active by night and resting by day, though starving and parched, still keep their distance on the rivers and lakes—how much more so the smallest creatures! Zi Gong, hearing Laozi’s condemnation of the Three August Ones and Five Emperors yet unable to grasp the grounds for it, stood uneasily, shifting his feet.

---

Supplementary Ink:
The governance of the Yellow Emperor made the people’s hearts unified—utterly pure and singular. Yao made the people cherish kinship, fostering harmony among the nine clans. When one killed in accordance with kinship, the people did not condemn it, for affection and ritual were uniquely exalted in kinship, while all else was diminished—yet the people did not feel slighted.

Shun made the people’s hearts contend—compete, that is. The Yu Emperor esteemed worthiness, so he made the people vie with one another. Contention ruptures harmonious qi, and the body’s mechanisms open prematurely, so that pregnant women give birth in ten months, children speak at five months, and before learning to laugh, they distinguish "who." No wonder they die young.

Yu made the people’s hearts change—change from the ancient ways. Each person developed intentions, each had their own scheming heart. Warfare arises from compliance, for using arms is deemed compliance. Those who kill are executed; those who kill thieves are blameless. Thus, killing thieves is not killing people. Each guards their own interests, mutually on alert—the world is thus. Hence, it is said: "each becomes their own kind," and the world is but an ear.

The great beginnings of men and women—ancient people established order: thirty for marriage, twenty for betrothal. Young girls were not held to human norms. Yet now—how could it be otherwise? The hearts of cunning and vigilance, the customs of deceit and shallowness—need one speak of them? Thus it is said: what more is there to say?

The passage bears a strong resemblance to the chapter *"The Great Dao is for the Public"* in the *Record of Ritual*. Confucius said to Laozi: "I, Qiu, have studied the Six Classics—*Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn*—and believed myself well-versed in their origins. Yet in expounding the Way of the former kings and clarifying the traces of Zhou and Shao, I have petitioned seventy-two rulers, and not one has put my words into practice. How difficult it is to persuade men! Is the Dao truly so hard to illuminate?"

Laozi replied: "Fortunate indeed that you have not met a ruler of a well-ordered age. The Six Classics are but the worn traces of the former kings—how could they be the essence of those traces? What you speak of now are still traces. Tracks are what emerge from shoes, but are tracks the same as shoes? When white egrets gaze at one another, their pupils do not move, yet the wind transforms them. The male insect cries on the wind above, and the female responds from the wind below, and transformation occurs. Thus, male and female arise of themselves. The nature wrought by the wind cannot be altered; fate cannot be changed; the seasons cannot be halted; the Dao cannot be obstructed. If one attains the Dao, there is nothing that cannot be done; if one loses it, there is nothing that can be preserved."

Confucius did not emerge for three months before returning to see Laozi, saying: "I have grasped it! The young of crows and magpies, the fry of fish, the mating of mayflies—those with younger siblings weep for their elder brothers. For too long, I, Qiu, have not transformed with the world; how could I transform others?"

Laozi said: "Good. You have grasped it."

The term "wind transformation" (feng hua), as noted by Sima, refers to the transmission of qi through wind that gives rise to transformation. The *lei* is a beast mentioned in the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*: "On Mount Danyuan, there is a beast resembling a leopard but with a mane; its name is *lei*, and it reproduces as both male and female." Guo Pu’s commentary cites the *Zhuangzi* to explain this. Crows (*wu*) nurture their young by hatching them; fish reproduce through the foam they expel without direct mating; and the "slender-waisted" refers to wasps and their kin.

Guo’s annotation states: What leaves traces is true nature. To follow the true nature of things is to leave traces like the Six Classics. Yet in human affairs today, the natural is treated as the shoe, and the Six Classics as mere traces. The white egret gazes with unmoving pupils, and transformation occurs through the wind; insects respond to each other’s calls without physical union, and transformation follows. Thus, in wind transformation, the male and female of the *lei* each possess their own means of mutual resonance, and the variations of this resonance are boundless. If one grasps the essence of this resonance, transformation is effortless—even distant resonance can lead to wind transformation. Nature, fate, seasons, and the Dao: the perfected person harmonizes with and flows through them all. One who attains the Dao finds nothing impossible; one who loses it finds nothing that can be preserved. The transformations of crows, fish, and wasps speak to the natural dispositions of all things. "The elder brother weeps for his younger sibling" illustrates how human nature, abandoning the elder to favor the younger, elicits such a response. To "transform with the world" is to allow things to transform of themselves. If one inverts the Six Classics to expound upon this, one erects barriers.

Lü’s annotation states: The Six Classics are the laws of the former kings, clearly set forth in measures and records, yet they are not the means by which transformation occurs. The means of transformation lies in spirit and illumination alone. Traces arise from the shoe, but are traces the shoe itself? To govern the world by such means is surely ineffective. The white egret gazes without moving its pupils, and wind transformation occurs through mutual resonance of spirit, not sound. The male insect cries on the upper wind, and the female responds from the lower wind, their resonance arising from sound, not form. The *lei* reproduces as both male and female, thus exemplifying wind transformation. All such phenomena arise because nature differs and cannot be altered, fate is fixed and cannot be changed, the seasons proceed and cannot be halted, and the Dao flows and cannot be obstructed. How could mere words or speculative thought grasp this? To understand how the world is transformed, one must seek not in the remnants of the past but in the Dao itself.

Confucius did not emerge for three months, gaining insight during his fasting and bodily discipline. He realized that crows, magpies, fish, and wasps all give life, yet their means of doing so are never the same—this is knowledge beyond knowing. Transformation alone matters. "The elder brother weeps for his younger sibling" is a matter of human sentiment, for transformation is uniform, yet sentiment, even among brothers, is not. To expect others to transform is difficult indeed. For too long has it been so.

The Master did not align with transformation to become human; rather, he embodied the Dao without reaching the point of becoming human alongside the Creator. How then could he transform others? Those who study Confucius yet fail to grasp the essence behind his traces suffer precisely from this flaw.

The four lines—"crows and magpies nurture their young," "an elder brother weeps for his younger sibling"—may seem obscure at first reading, but upon deeper reflection, the principles of transformation are vast. For within them are manifest the four modes of birth—womb, egg, moisture, and transformation—though people remain unaware. The principles of heaven and earth’s fullness and emptiness, the mechanisms of creation’s growth and decline, though silently operating in formlessness, are all revealed through the four births. Among the four births, humans hold primacy; among the multitudes, the sage holds primacy. The sage aligns with transformation to become human, and in knowing transformation, one knows heaven.

Thus, this chapter concludes with a discussion of transformation. If one does not govern heaven and earth, administer the myriad things, and move independently beyond the realm of nurturing and transforming, how can one transform others? As the *Daodejing* states, "The highest virtue takes no action, yet the people transform themselves." Observe the wind-borne transformation of the egret, the hatching of crows and magpies, the foam-borne birth of fish, and the ritualized procreation of wasps—all arise from natural disposition and are perfected through concentrated effort. This mutual resonance, this unquestionable response, is called transformation.

Humans, being the most spiritually endowed, possess a transformation even more wondrous than these, yet it does not transcend the principles of nature or the power of concentrated effort.

**A Humble Overview**

This treatise begins by expounding the movements of heaven and the positions of earth, posing questions about the circulation of the sun and moon, the flow of wind and clouds. It answers that the Six Poles and Five Constants, along with the governance of the Three Sovereigns, follow the celestial rotations and enact virtue and education—thus, through non-action, the people transform themselves, delighting in spontaneity. Next, it discusses supreme benevolence as impartial and supreme honor as rejecting rank, both embodying the principle of celestial motion through effortless action.

Further, it speaks of the grand music performed at Dongting, illuminating the profound subtleties of the Great Dao—orchestrated through yin and yang, conducted with ritual and righteousness—establishing the foundation of resonance between heaven and humanity. Harmonizing the four seasons, fostering the great harmony of the myriad things, and aligning cold and heat in proper sequence constitute the wellspring of generation and transformation. Movement without fixed direction yet abiding in profound stillness, the celestial mechanism settled and the five officials complete—this allows for latent concealment or manifest emergence in response to things, unbound by form. Where sound is exhausted, celestial wandering arrives, and nowhere does it reach that is not perfect harmony; where resonance fades, supreme music abides, and nowhere does it dwell that is not ultimate joy.

As for governance, policies compared to withered straw dogs and laws likened to inverted pearwood or the tearing of Zhou Gong’s robes by apes, or an ugly woman mimicking Xi Shi’s beauty—these illustrate that politics must be fitting and timely. Cooking the fresh lies in not stirring; those who rule must embody the Dao, emulate heaven, and move in accord with transformation, rhythmically guiding the times. Their grace and nurturance will bring things to full maturity—how could there be any who remain untransformed?

When Confucius saw Laozi, he marveled at him as a dragon, for he had united humanity with heaven but had not yet achieved complete transformation. Upon hearing the wondrous subtleties of the profound thunder, he then discarded the vestiges of the Six Classics to investigate their essence. If one’s traces do not exceed three months and one becomes a person of transformation, then one’s traces align with humanity while one’s essence merges with heaven.

The *Book of Changes* states, "The movement of heaven is strong"—this is the essence of its rotation. "Essence and qi become things; the wandering soul becomes change"—this is the essence of its transformation. Ah!

Those who carve their intent and exalt conduct, distancing themselves from the world and differing from common customs, whose lofty discourse is but resentment and slander—these are but extremes. Such are the preferences of the recluses of mountain valleys, those who are not of this world, the withered and emaciated who plunge into the abyss.

Those who speak of benevolence and righteousness, loyalty and trust, reverence and frugality, deference and yielding—these are but cultivated refinements. Such are the preferences of the scholars of peaceful eras, the instructive and edifying, those who wander and dwell in study.

Those who speak of great achievements, establishing great names, observing the rites between ruler and minister, rectifying high and low—these are but governance. Such are the preferences of the courtiers, those who honor their lords and strengthen their states, the achievers and consolidators.

Those who dwell in marshes and wilds, abide in leisure and openness, fish and idle, doing nothing—these are but inaction. Such are the preferences of the recluses of rivers and seas, those who flee the world, the idle and unoccupied.

Those who blow and exhale, inhale and absorb, expel the old and take in the new, imitate the bear’s climbing and the bird’s stretching—these are but longevity. Such are the preferences of the practitioners of Dao-yin, those who nurture the body, the long-lived like Pengzu.

Yet those who do not carve their intent yet rise high, who lack benevolence and righteousness yet are refined, who lack achievements and fame yet govern, who lack rivers and seas yet are at leisure, who do not practice Dao-yin yet live long—nothing do they forget, and nothing do they lack. Serene and boundless, all excellences follow them. This is the Dao of heaven and earth, the virtue of the sage.

Thus it is said: "Tranquility, indifference, stillness, emptiness, and non-action—these are the equilibrium of heaven and earth and the substance of the Dao and virtue."

Those who resent and slander the world as lacking the Dao resent only their own failure to meet with it. "Bear-climbing" is like the bear’s ascent of trees to guide the qi; "bird-stretching" is like the bird’s cries and groans. Dao-yin is the guiding of qi to harmonize it and the stretching of the body to soften it.

Guo’s commentary: These several masters each follow their own preferences, indulging their inclinations and pursuing their own methods—this too is a way of attaining freedom. Yet such practices merely allow each to attain their own satisfaction. How could they extend to all things without exception? As for enabling the myriad things each to fulfill their allotted portion without losing themselves, this must be entrusted to non-attachment and non-action. "Not carving the intent" refers to what is called "spontaneity." "Nothing is not forgotten, nothing is not possessed" means that only through forgetting can one possess; if one clings to possession, one cannot remedy forgetfulness. Thus possession is not possession through possessing, but possession through forgetting. If one forces oneself to act, one cannot attain boundlessness, and all evils arise.

Heaven and earth do not act for the sake of the myriad things, yet the myriad things arise of themselves. The sage does not act for the sake of the hundred practices, yet the hundred practices are accomplished of themselves. This is the equilibrium of heaven and earth and the substance of the Dao and virtue. If it were not for stillness, emptiness, and non-action, this equilibrium would be imperiled and this substance lost.

The newly transmitted passage states: Those scholars of mountain valleys and peaceful eras, those who strengthen their states or withdraw to nurture their forms—all are bound by the self. With the self comes the heart-mind; with the heart-mind comes inescapable delusion, each thus confined to a single corner. Those who delight in mountains and marshes go forth but cannot return; those who serve in court enter but cannot depart; those content with teaching bend but cannot extend; those devoted to nurturing form preserve but cannot forget. This is not the natural state of true nature—it is the distortion of their intent that makes it so. How could this be the same as the sage?

The sage is simply without self. Without self, there is no heart-mind; without heart-mind, there is no delusion. Thus, forgetting form, one penetrates all affairs. Ascending to the utmost Dao, one enters the vast oneness of heaven—was this achieved through forced effort and lofty ambition? Benefiting beings and moistening the world arises not from external imposition—was this accomplished through practicing benevolence and righteousness? Vast and boundless, governing the world through non-interference—was this done to establish merit and fame? Profoundly still and obscurely silent, roaming freely in the realm of self-attainment—was this sought by dwelling in rivers and lakes for leisure? Qi gentle and integrity whole, the form never declines—was this attained through pursuing breathwork and longevity? Existing yet not existing, absent yet not absent, none know its end, yet the utmost Dao gathers of itself. All is the supreme subtlety of non-action, and only the sage attains it.

Thus it is said: The sage rests in perfect ease.

Then it is level and easy. Level and easy, then tranquil and at rest. Level, easy, tranquil, and at rest—then cares and troubles cannot enter, and pernicious qi cannot assail. Thus their virtue remains whole and their spirit unharmed.

Thus it is said: The sage’s life follows the course of Heaven; their death is the transformation of things. At rest, they share the power of yin; in motion, they move with the waves of yang. They do not precede fortune, nor do they initiate misfortune. They respond only after being stirred, move only when pressed, and rise only when there is no alternative. Abandoning knowledge and old habits, they follow Heaven’s principle—thus they suffer no heavenly disasters, no burdens from things, no human reproach, no blame from spirits. Their life is like floating; their death, like repose. They neither scheme nor plan ahead. Radiant, yet not dazzling; trustworthy, yet not demanding. In sleep, they do not dream; in wakefulness, they know no care. Their spirit is pure, their soul unwearied.

Empty and tranquil, at rest and still—only thus do they accord with Heaven’s virtue.

Thus it is said: Sorrow and joy are deviations of virtue; delight and anger are transgressions of the Dao; likes and dislikes are losses of virtue. The heart free of sorrow and joy is the perfection of virtue. Unchanging unity is the perfection of stillness. Nothing to oppose is the perfection of emptiness. No interaction with things is the perfection of blandness. Nothing to resist is the perfection of purity.

Guo’s commentary: *"At rest—tranquil, still, and silent; at peace—empty, without action. Though passing through..."*

The transformations of perilous obstacles are ever level and free from difficulty. Calamity arises from action, and action likewise arises from calamity—thus, level ease and tranquil stillness complete one another.

Anxieties and misfortunes cannot enter; perverse qi cannot assail, for one merges indistinguishably with the correct principle and proceeds as one with it. Thus, their virtue remains whole and their spirit unharmed.

As for those who are neither level nor bland—do they merely injure their form? Their spirit and virtue perish together within.

The movements of Heaven proceed by their own nature; the transformations of things shed their forms without attachment. In activity and stillness, they are without intent, entrusting themselves to yin and yang. They respond only after being moved, acting only when encounters arise. They rise when compelled, following principle in their arising—this is what I mean by "compelled." The naturalness of Heaven’s principle knows no action within its realm. Thus, disaster arises from opposing Heaven, and entanglements arise from resisting things.

Those who harmonize with others are many, and these must be correct. Therefore, free from human reproach, they align with self-attainment; free from demonic blame, their life drifts and their death rests, floating without attachment.

They do not scheme, entrusting themselves to Heaven’s principle; they do not plan ahead, responding only when principle arrives. Radiant, yet not dazzling—they employ the world’s own radiance, not their own brilliance. Trustworthy, yet not demanding—they employ the world’s own trustworthiness, not their own expectations.

Desiring nothing, their sleep is dreamless, their wakefulness carefree. Their spirit is pure, their soul unwearied—thus do they unite with Heaven and Earth in the virtue of tranquil stillness.

Supreme virtue is ever at ease, so emotions hold no sway. Still and unified, they cannot be altered. Their heart is open and utterly empty—this is the perfection of emptiness.

Things come of themselves. The most bland have no emotional entanglement with things; if mixed with turbid desires, there will be that which does not accord.

]

Lü’s Annotation:
The sage rests in perfect ease, never enslaving the mind to choices of acceptance or rejection. When level, there is no bias; when changing, there is no struggle. Serene and knowing nothing, tranquil and unengaged with things—this is what is meant by “stillness and non-action,” and it is no more than this.

Worry and misfortune, along with pathogenic qi, gain entry and strike only because of knowledge. Knowledge engages with things, and gaps arise between them. Yet life itself is the movement of Heaven, and thus has never truly been born—so why rejoice at emergence? Transformation of things is the process of Heaven, and thus has never truly died—so why resist reversion? Stillness shares its virtue with yin, yet one does not perceive it as stillness. Movement flows with yang, yet one does not perceive it as movement.

Not seeking fortune first, fortune too remains unaware. Not initiating calamity, calamity too does not arrive. For when fortune is sought first or calamity initiated, there is no resonance in response, no compulsion to act—only necessity arising from the use of knowledge and deliberate effort, which is the way of ordinary people. Following the natural spontaneity of Heaven’s principle, Heaven cannot bring disaster, things cannot impose burdens—thus there is no human fault or blame.

How fitting, then, that life drifts and death rests, without resonance yet still; things arrive and one responds, emanating Heaven’s radiance yet not dazzling. Within, there is trust yet no covenant; dreamless sleep and carefree wakefulness are the same. Purity is unadulterated, untiring, and non-action is the virtue of Heaven—this is how the sage rules all under Heaven.

Grief and joy are emotions difficult to dispel, hence they become deviations in virtue. Anger and delight arise and vanish in an instant, hence they become excesses in the Dao. All four stem from likes and dislikes—likes and dislikes are the unmanifest forms of grief, joy, anger, and delight.

If the human mind is filled with ten thousand thoughts all day without cease, how can it attain even a moment of stillness? The sage, free from sorrow and joy, reaches unity and remains unchanging—this is the ultimate stillness. Unobstructed and unopposed, like an empty boat striking objects yet not provoking anger—this is the ultimate emptiness. Unengaged with things, there is no flavor—this is the ultimate blandness. Thus, even entering water or treading fire, there is nowhere that is not oneself. How could there be resistance? This is the ultimate purity.

Fang’s Inquiry:
What distinguishes the characters *wu* (忤, opposition) and *ni* (逆, resistance) that they are spoken of separately? Reflecting on *xu* (虚, emptiness) and *cui* (粹, purity), one sees that to comply with affairs and respond to things without discord or friction, how could this be achieved without the utmost emptiness? With a mind utterly pure and unadulterated, it naturally encompasses all images and contains all things without resistance.

Thus it is said: when form labors without rest, it becomes exhausted; when essence is employed without cease, it becomes weary. Weariness leads to depletion. Water’s nature, unadulterated, is clear; undisturbed, it is level. Stagnant and blocked, it cannot remain clear—this is the image of Heaven’s virtue.

Thus it is said: pure and unadulterated, still and unified without change, bland and non-active, moving in accord with Heaven’s course—this is the way to nurture the spirit.

One who possesses a Gan-Yue sword keeps it cased and hidden, never daring to use it—such is its supreme value. The spirit reaches in all four directions, flowing without limit, ascending to the heavens, coiling through the earth, transforming and nurturing the myriad things. It cannot be represented in form; its name is “co-equal with the Emperor.” The Dao of pure simplicity guards only the spirit, holding fast without loss, uniting with the spirit as one. Its essence communicates, harmonizing with Heaven’s order.

A rustic saying goes: “The common man values profit, the upright scholar values reputation, the worthy prizes aspiration, the sage treasures essence.” *Su* (素, simplicity) means having nothing mixed with it; *chun* (纯, purity) means not scattering one’s spirit. One who embodies pure simplicity is called a *zhenren* (真人, true person).

[Sima’s Note: Gan refers to Wu. Gan Stream is a great river in Yue where famous swords are produced.]

Guo’s Annotation:
Without rest, there is exhaustion; without cease, there is weariness; weariness leads to depletion—all things have their proper measure, which must not be lost. Water’s nature, an image of Heaven’s virtue, is without intent yet harmonizes with all. Pure and unadulterated, nothing is not in perfect accord. Still and unified without change, it constantly abides in what is proper. Bland and non-active, it merely prevents excess. Moving in accord with Heaven’s course—if one moves in pursuit of things, that is the movement of man.

One who cherishes a sword still keeps it cased and hidden—how much more should one dare to lightly use the spirit? The spirit reaches in all four directions, ascending to the heavens, coiling through the earth. Embracing the ultimate of Heaven and Earth, responding to the patterns of the myriad things—this is the nature of the spirit. Thus it is so.

If one achieves the work of Heaven and Earth, it is by following Heaven’s course, not by lightly using the spirit. Transforming and nurturing the myriad things, its name is “co-equal with the Emperor,” for what it nurtures is boundless, like the Heavenly Emperor who does not act. Pure simplicity, unlost, unites with the spirit as one. Constantly guarding pure simplicity in utmost stillness, undisturbed by externals—this is prevention.

Essence is the true nature of things. Uniting with the spirit is not about guarding the spirit, nor is treasuring essence about prizing essence—yet in practice, one values guarding it. If purity is taken as not being diminished, then even if a hundred deeds are performed together and ten thousand changes are encompassed, it is still purity. If simplicity is taken as not being mixed, then even with dragon patterns and phoenix forms, appearing with extraordinary beauty, it is still simplicity. But if one cannot preserve one’s natural quality and mixes it with external adornments, then even the markings of dogs and sheep—how can that be called pure simplicity?

Lü’s Annotation:
Observing the sage’s heart—empty, non-existent, serene, and bland—one sees that even when engaged in affairs all day, the spirit does not labor. The ancients spoke of “setting aside the mind and employing the form,” of seeing and hearing without using the ears and eyes—this is the way. Now, one must “entrust the ears.”

The eyes are ensnared by sights and sounds, the mind enslaved by grasping and rejecting—thus the form labors without rest, the essence is expended without cease, until exhaustion and depletion are only fitting. The nature of water is clarity and levelness, inherently so by nature; it remains unadulterated and unmoving. To know this yet take stagnation and blockage as "unmoving" is to fail to attain clarity. The image of Heaven’s virtue is likewise: purity without admixture is the image of water’s clarity; stillness and oneness without change is the image of water’s levelness. Yet when water moves, it follows the Way of Heaven—not taking stagnation and blockage as the image of "unmoving." The various arts of the world impose restraints through emptiness and stillness, unaware of observing return amid the surge of activity, of returning to the root amid the teeming profusion—this is because they do not know the Dao of nurturing the spirit. Yet the people of the world believe that nurturing the form is sufficient to preserve life, though it is not even comparable to the sheathing of a sword for its sharpness. The spirit spans Heaven and coils upon Earth—how could its utility be limited to the sharpness of a sword from Gan or Yue? Its name is shared with the Emperor—how could its value be merely that of a treasured blade? Yet they do not know to hone it with purity, to sheath it with stillness and oneness, to store it through non-action, to guide it by the Heavenly movement—this is to fail to understand the distinction between noble and base. Only the spirit is to be preserved; preserve it with pure simplicity alone. When one preserves it, there is what is called "preserving"; to preserve without loss is for the preserver and the preserved to merge as one. *Lun* is principle. When a person accords with Heavenly principle, they are simply Heaven. This is why the sage values essence. Simplicity is without admixture; essence is without diminution. Only the true person can achieve this.

**Guan’s General Discussion:**
This chapter is titled "Carving the Intent," for it speaks of carving and honing one’s intent, defying the world, correcting customs, embracing austerity, and bearing responsibility alone—things the world cannot do—hoping others will follow, no different from yoking an ox or bridling a horse, losing their naturalness. To know the long virtue is to disperse the people; the beginning of difficulty in governance lies here. Thus *Nanhua* recounts the differing aspirations of the ancients: Boyi and Shuqi’s defiance, Confucius and Mencius’s cultivation, Yi Yin and Fu Yue’s governance, Xu You and Chao Fu’s reclusion, Laozi and Pengzu’s longevity. Judging by their traces, none seem entirely without bias, yet they remain sages and worthies because their actions do not entangle them in being, their non-action does not drown them in non-being. They adapt to the possibilities of the times and the utility of the self—this is why they value emptiness, non-action, levelness, ease, tranquility, the Heavenly movement, and the transformation of things, sharing virtue and riding the same wave. Knowing the past does not linger; movement accords with Heavenly principle—then how could calamity and entanglement arise? How could life and death, plans and worries, disturb them? Thus, stillness, emptiness, tranquility, and purity do not clash with things, ultimately culminating in the work of nurturing the spirit. The analogy of sheathing the sword from Gan and Yue is extended: how lightly do people regard the body, yet they remain so deluded. Therefore, the argument begins by rejecting the habit of carving the intent and exalting conduct, and concludes by affirming that one who embodies pure simplicity is a true person. Thus, it is clear that those who carve and exalt are false. For nurturing life, pure simplicity is fundamental; for pure simplicity, preserving the spirit is primary. When one merges with the spirit as one, the great root of the Dao is established—what need is there to fuss over trifles and engage in carving the intent and exalting conduct?

To refine one’s nature through vulgar learning in pursuit of returning to its origin, or to muddy the marrow of desire with vulgar thoughts in pursuit of attaining clarity—these are called the benighted masses. Those who cultivated the Dao in antiquity nurtured knowledge with tranquility, never employing knowledge as a means. This is called using knowledge to nurture tranquility. When knowledge and tranquility mutually nurture one another, harmony and principle emerge from one’s nature.

Virtue is harmony; the Dao is principle. Virtue admits all without exclusion—this is benevolence. The Dao governs all without disorder—this is righteousness. When righteousness is luminous, things draw near—this is loyalty. When the center is pure and solid, returning to genuine feeling—this is joy. When trust is enacted and the body is composed, conforming to refinement—this is propriety. If propriety and music are practiced in isolation, the world falls into chaos.

Those who rectify themselves yet remain benighted have already lost virtue. When virtue is lost, one becomes reckless; when reckless, things inevitably lose their nature.

Guo’s Commentary:
One who has already refined their nature through the vulgar, yet seeks to restore the root of life and destiny through vulgar learning, strays further from the Way the more they pursue it. One who has already disturbed their mind with the vulgar, yet labors thought to seek clarity, drifts further from truth the more they refine their thinking. To dispel ignorance, one must depart from the vulgar, relinquish desire, and only then approach the threshold.

Tranquility gives rise to knowledge; when knowledge does not stray, nature is not lost. If one does not employ knowledge as a means but allows it to arise naturally, then though knowledge encompasses all things, one remains serene and self-content. Knowledge that does not act as interference does no harm to tranquility; tranquility that acts of itself does no injury to knowledge. When the two mutually nurture one another, how could the division of harmony and principle arise from anything else?

Harmony, therefore, admits nothing that is not the Dao; principle admits nothing that is not governed. The all-embracing is not enacted as benevolence, yet the traces of benevolence manifest. The all-governing is not enacted as righteousness, yet the efficacy of righteousness becomes evident. If righteousness is luminous but does not arise from loyalty, things grow more distant. When benevolence and righteousness emerge from the center and return to the original disposition, the will is fulfilled. When the will is fulfilled, its outward expression is joy.

Faithfulness in conduct, accommodation in form, following the natural rhythms of spontaneity—its outward manifestation is ritual. If one imposes the practices of a single region or the joys of a single will upon the world, then one locality gains while the myriad regions lose. When each rectifies its nature and destiny, self-cultivating its inherent virtue, it does not use this to override that. If one uses this to override that, how could one not lose one’s nature?

**Lü’s Commentary:**
To refine one’s nature through conventional customs is ever troubled by the error of embellishing life and losing one’s original state; if one then seeks to restore it through vulgar learning, one strays even further. To muddy one’s desires with conventional customs is ever troubled by the error of abandoning simplicity and confounding one’s clarity; if one then seeks to attain it through reflection, one becomes even more obscured. Tranquility rests in what is so without knowing why—this is how one nurtures knowledge, not by seeking clarity through reflection. Life arises without employing knowledge, and thus does not differ from it—this is how one nurtures tranquility, not by restoring one’s original state through vulgar learning. The numinous clarity of the *Yijing*, the "elusive and indistinct" of Laozi, the "tranquility and knowledge" of Zhuangzi—these are in truth one and the same. Those in antiquity who cultivated the Dao never failed to nurture these two in mutual exchange and thereby attain mastery. The flaw of tranquility lies in obscurity, where it cannot radiate illumination; the flaw of knowledge lies in rigidity, where it cannot return to undifferentiated unity. When these two nurture one another, harmony and principle emerge from one’s nature—not from anything external.

That which pervades Heaven and Earth is virtue; virtue is harmony. That which courses through the myriad things is the Dao; the Dao is principle. The essence of virtue is harmony, and its function admits all without exclusion—this is benevolence. The essence of the Dao is principle, and its function governs all without exception—this is righteousness. When righteousness is luminous, things cannot but draw near in loyalty. When the center is pure and unfeigned, joy arises from it. Sincerity resides within and takes form without, becoming pattern and ritual. Ritual is the attenuation of loyalty and sincerity, the harbinger of disorder. When the myriad things each rectify their nature and destiny, they self-cultivate their inherent virtue—what need is there for virtue to override others? When ritual and music are practiced in isolation, the Dao and virtue grow ever more distant, and one cannot avoid overriding others. Overriding leads things to lose their nature, and this is why the world falls into chaos.

**Bǐshèng’s Notes:**
"Refining one’s nature through conventional learning" and "muddying one’s desires through conventional reflection" are complete phrases—previous interpretations have erred. Nature is not restored through learning, yet vulgar learning cannot restore nature. Clarity is not attained through reflection, yet vulgar reflection cannot seek clarity. What is called "vulgar" stands in contrast to the real, for the moment one moves in thought, one strays; how much more so when refining through imitation, where the mind is already misaligned. Not only does this fail to penetrate one’s obscurity, but it only deepens one’s delusion.

To nurture knowledge with tranquility is the essential path to restoring nature and attaining clarity. Knowledge is the awakened nature of humanity—this nature can be nurtured by tranquility but cannot be refined through learning or confounded by reflection. Tranquility is the state of non-action and spontaneity. To speak of "nurturing knowledge" seems to imply an intention toward knowledge, yet one does not realize that the essence of knowledge is emptiness, profound stillness, and utter absence of attachment. It is having knowledge while in truth not acting through knowledge. Thus, it is also called "nurturing tranquility with knowledge." Tranquility is what Chan Buddhists call "non-knowledge"; knowledge is what they call "knowing the nothing." When in tranquility, knowledge resides in tranquility; when in knowledge, tranquility resides in knowledge. Hence, it is said that knowledge and tranquility nurture one another. In this way, the Dao, virtue, benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, ritual, and music are all unified, like a tree with roots where flowers and fruit flourish together—what is attained cannot be called partial practice.

If one does not proceed from nature but merely pursues ritual and music, one chases the branches and forgets the root, becoming fragmented by vulgar learning, and the world falls into chaos. Why? When knowledge and tranquility nurture one another, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music merge into the Dao and virtue. When knowledge and tranquility lose one another, the Dao and virtue branch into benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music. This is the distinction between true and vulgar learning.

The ancients dwelled in primordial chaos, moving with their age and attaining serene indifference.

At that time, yin and yang harmonized in stillness, spirits remained undisturbed, the four seasons kept their proper rhythm, the myriad things suffered no harm, and all living beings met no untimely end. Though humans possessed knowledge, they had no use for it—this was called "perfect unity." At that time, none acted, yet all naturally followed their course.

When virtue declined, Sui Ren and Fu Xi first ruled the world, thus following the age yet failing to achieve unity. When virtue declined further, Shen Nong and the Yellow Emperor first ruled the world, thus bringing peace yet failing to follow the age. When virtue declined still further, Yao and Shun first ruled the world, initiating the flow of governance and transformation, where purity thinned and simplicity scattered. They departed from the Dao to pursue perilous virtue, acting through goodness. Then, they abandoned nature to follow the heart-mind. As heart-minds vied with one another in knowledge, it proved insufficient to stabilize the world. Thus, they adorned it with culture, expanded it with erudition, eroded authenticity, and drowned the heart-mind. Only then did the people begin to grow confused and disordered, unable to return to their original nature and recover their primal state.

The decline of virtue arose because sages did not succeed one another in rule. Those above could not practice non-action but instead coveted the traces of non-action, leading to such corruption. "Following yet not unified"—the world had already lost unity, and confusion could not be resolved, so they merely released it without further inquiry, following what was natural in its own place. "At peace yet not following"—they found peace in what was naturally peaceful. The sage has no fixed heart-mind but allows the world to achieve its own completion. Whether the age grows pure or thin is not the sage’s doing. The sage can only allow the world to attain its own nature—how could the sage make the world attain sageliness? Thus, the traces of emperors and kings shift with the age, yet the Dao of the sage has never been incomplete.

Goodness exceeds what is fitting in its praise, so though there is goodness, the Dao is not fully realized. Acting contrary to nature, one establishes conduct yet fails to level virtue. Abandoning nature to follow the heart-mind—speaking of the heart-mind as self-serving—is to lose nature. "Heart-minds vying with one another in knowledge" means that competing heart-minds strive to be first in recognition, leaving no room to follow nature. "Knowledge insufficient to stabilize the world" means that forgetting knowledge and following nature is what truly stabilizes. Culture and erudition are adornments of the heart-mind and essence, not the root of life and destiny.

From this perspective, the world has lost the Dao, and the Dao has lost the world—they mutually lose one another. How can the person of the Dao arise in the world? How can the world arise through the Dao? Though the Dao cannot arise in the world and the world cannot arise through the Dao, even if the sage does not dwell in mountain forests, their virtue remains hidden. Thus, the so-called "hidden scholars" of old did not conceal their bodies and remain unseen, nor did they shut their words and refuse to speak, nor did they hide their knowledge and refrain from expressing it. The great error lies in timing and destiny. When timing and destiny align and one acts greatly in the world, they return to unity without trace. When timing and destiny are greatly thwarted in the world, they deeply root themselves, secure their utmost foundation, and await—this is the way to preserve oneself.

The Dao endures in the world because it is not prized. Yet when the world endures, it prizes the Dao, and in prizing it, the Dao is lost. The Dao cannot prevent the world from prizing it, nor can the world avoid prizing the Dao—thus they mutually lose one another. If not prized, they would mutually arise. The reason they do not arise now is due to the emotions that stir them. How can they arise? Through the absence of prizing. If one does not hide oneself but instead employs things, the world and the Dao will mutually arise—what need is there for concealment?

Not knowing to return to unity to cease traces, yet chasing traces to seek unity, the more one obtains traces, the more one loses unity—this is the great error. Even if one rises in body to clarify it, opens words to express it, or displays knowledge to reveal it, how can they mutually arise? It only leads to mutual loss. When timing and destiny are greatly realized, this is the time of serene indifference—returning to unity without trace means returning to the nature of things, and the nature of things unifies itself, leaving no trace. When timing and destiny are greatly thwarted, this is a time that cannot achieve serene indifference. Yet even in an age of affairs, the sage has never failed to remain serene. Thus, they deeply root themselves, secure their utmost foundation, and await the world’s self-fulfillment—this is how the Dao is not lost. There has never been a case where the self is preserved yet the world does not arise.

When the world and the Dao mutually arise, sages appear and the myriad things behold them. When the world and the Dao mutually lose one another, sages wander amidst世俗 yet remain unknown—thus they are already hidden. Why seek concealment in mountain forests? Returning to unity without trace is like the dream of Huaxu or the wanderings of Guye. Deeply rooting and securing the utmost foundation is like the unshakable—hibernation of dragons and snakes to preserve the self is no different. Observing Zhuangzi’s words, one senses his lament over the misfortune of timing and destiny. When the world and the Dao mutually lose one another, it is indeed cause for sorrow.

The ancients who preserved their selves did not adorn themselves with clever disputation, nor did they exhaust the world with knowledge, nor did they endanger virtue by exhausting it with knowledge. Solemnly abiding in their proper place, they returned to their nature—what more was there to do? The Dao is not diminished by petty conduct; virtue is not diminished by petty understanding. Petty understanding harms virtue; petty conduct harms the Dao. Thus it is said: rectify the self and that is all.

To be "joyfully whole" is what is meant by "attaining one’s aspiration." What the ancients called "attaining one’s aspiration" did not refer to carriages and caps of office. It meant that nothing could augment their joy. What is now called "attaining one’s aspiration" refers to carriages and caps of office. Yet carriages and caps are not one’s nature or destiny—they are transient things that come by chance, a temporary lodging. When they come, one cannot block them; when they depart, one cannot stop them. Thus, one does not indulge one’s aspirations for carriages and caps, nor does one follow worldly customs in poverty and constraint. Their joy is the same in both cases, and so they are simply without sorrow. Now, if the lodging departs and one is no longer joyful, then even in joy there has never been no dissipation. Thus it is said: those who lose themselves in things and forfeit their nature to custom are called "the people of inverted priorities."

Guo’s commentary: Not adorning oneself with clever disputation is simply to follow one’s true knowledge. Not exhausting the world with knowledge—this is the sentiment of tranquility. Not exhausting virtue with knowledge is simply to guard one’s self-possession. *Weiran* describes the bearing of one who stands alone in correctness. The Dao is not diminished by petty conduct—it roams the level path. Virtue is not diminished by petty understanding—it is vast and all-pervading. One attains one’s aspiration, singularly at peace in heart without the emotions of sorrow or joy. This is the wholeness of joy. "Nothing can augment their joy" means being whole within and sufficient. Coming cannot be blocked; departing cannot be stopped—these are matters of external things. Gain and loss do not pertain to me. Indifferent and at ease, one does not sense the lodging in the self. Vast and self-possessed, one does not know poverty in the self. "Both" refers to carriages and caps and to poverty and constraint. "Simply without sorrow" means there is no joy of exultation either. If the lodging departs and one is no longer joyful, then when it comes, there is dissipation. This is to exchange the inner for the outer. When the outer is full and the inner is diminished, one’s priorities are inverted.

Lü’s commentary: To preserve the self is simply to be still; to act in the world is not merely to be still but must respond to change without harming stillness—this is acceptable. Forgetting words, knowledge becomes all-knowing; abandoning knowledge, virtue becomes all-pervading. Solemnly abiding in one’s proper place, one need not flee the world or separate from things, for worldly things are not enough to burden one—this is the Dao of acting in the world. The Dao is not diminished by petty conduct; virtue is not diminished by petty understanding. Not diminishing oneself to follow the world—this is what is meant by "rectifying the self." To be "joyfully whole" is to have nothing augment one’s joy, to aspire to the Dao and seek to attain it—this is what is called "attaining one’s aspiration." The Dao is one’s nature and destiny; carriages and caps are a lodging of things. Now, if one exchanges the joy of having nothing augment it for the departure of this lodging, one loses the self and forfeits one’s nature—this is to be one of "inverted priorities."

Master Guan’s general discussion: The main idea of this chapter is that people, lacking transcendent and unworldly insight, cling to worldly entanglements and gradually lose their original nature, polishing their natures and slipping into desire amid custom. Though they have not committed overt evils, they greatly obstruct the Dao.
