To augment it with external learning and confuse it with reckless thoughts, seeking to return to the beginning and attain clarity, is like heading north while driving toward Ying. The True Person, fearing that scholars would dread its emptiness and vastness, finding nothing to exert effort upon, set forth the theory of the mutual nourishment of tranquility and knowledge, making it easier for people to enter.

When one dwells in the world, responding to opportunities and adapting to change, one cannot forget knowledge. When knowledge is employed, it harms tranquility. The key lies in carefully weighing what is appropriate and abiding in the Dao. When affairs come, knowledge is manifest; when affairs depart, tranquility remains. Over time, as these two are harmonized and both are transformed, spirit and soul, hun and po, merge into supreme harmony, aligning with nature and destiny in the realm of the subtle and formless, returning to the root of virtue and the Dao. From this, expanding outward, one dwells among the people of the world, blending into the indistinct and attaining tranquility. Though one possesses knowledge, there is nothing to employ it for—such transformation is vast indeed.

Alas, governance has lost its purity and harmony; custom has turned toward frivolity and shallowness. Departing from the Dao and endangering virtue, authenticity is drowned and the heart submerged. When the world and the Dao mutually lose one another, they cannot be restored. Only then do the sages of mountain forests, deeply rooting and securing the utmost foundation, await their encounter, whether morning or night. Preserving the self is how the Dao is preserved. The coming and going of the lodging allow no room for joy or sorrow—how then could clever disputation be of use? Their joy is whole, their aspiration attained, transcending carriages and caps.

Those who covet the glory of carriages and caps merely suffer from not knowing how to seek it. This is the Dao by which the sagely and worthy dwell in obscurity to preserve themselves.

**Chapter Seventeen: Autumn Floods**

When the autumn floods arrive, the hundred streams pour into the Yellow River. Its mighty currents swell so vast that between its banks and islets, oxen and horses cannot be distinguished. Thereupon, the River Lord rejoiced exultantly, believing all the world’s beauty to be contained within himself. Following the current eastward, he reached the Northern Sea. Turning to face the east, he saw no end to the waters. Thereupon, the River Lord turned his gaze, looked out across the expanse toward Ruo, and sighed:

“There is a common saying: ‘Having heard the Dao a hundred times, one believes none can compare to oneself.’ This describes me. Moreover, I once heard those who belittled Confucius’s learning and disparaged Boyi’s righteousness—at first, I did not believe it. Now, beholding the boundlessness of your realm, had I not come to your gate, I would have remained in peril, forever ridiculed by those of great understanding.”

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: “A frog in a well cannot speak of the sea, confined as it is by its narrow dwelling. A summer insect cannot speak of ice, bound as it is by its fleeting season. A scholar of limited learning cannot speak of the Dao, constrained as he is by his teachings. Now that you have emerged from your banks and beheld the great sea, you recognize your own insignificance—only then can you be spoken with about great principles.

Of all the waters under heaven, none are greater than the sea. The ten thousand rivers flow into it, yet it never fills, no matter when they cease. The Tail Pool drains it, yet it never empties, no matter when it ends. Unchanged by spring or autumn, unmoved by flood or drought—this surpasses the flow of the Yangtze and Yellow River, which cannot be measured in number. Yet I have never prided myself on this, for I compare my form to heaven and earth and receive my qi from yin and yang. Within heaven and earth, I am but a pebble or a twig in a great mountain. Even if I were to consider myself small, how could I take pride in it? Measure the Four Seas within heaven and earth—are they not like a tiny crevice in a vast marsh? Measure the Central States within the seas—are they not like a grain of millet in a granary?

The number of things is called ‘ten thousand,’ yet humans occupy but one among them. The people of the Nine Provinces, where grain is grown and boats and carriages travel, are but one among them. Compared to the ten thousand things, are they not like the tip of a hair on a horse’s body? The Five Emperors’ succession, the Three Kings’ strife, the benevolent’s worries, the devoted officials’ labors—all are encompassed in this. Boyi renounced it to gain fame; Confucius discoursed on it to display his erudition—this was their self-aggrandizement. Are they not like your former pride in your waters?

The River Lord said: “Then may I consider heaven and earth great and the tip of a hair small?”

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: “No. The measure of things is boundless, time knows no end, divisions are not constant, and beginnings and ends have no fixed origin. Thus, the one of great wisdom observes both near and far—small without paucity, great without excess—knowing that measure is infinite. Verifying past and present, he is at ease in remoteness and untroubled in proximity, unhurried in grasping and unstrained in reaching. Knowing time has no end, he examines its flow.”

The fluctuations of fullness and emptiness—thus one gains without delight and loses without sorrow, knowing that divisions are not constant. Clearly perceiving the level path, one lives without elation and dies without calamity, knowing that beginnings and ends have no fixed origin. Calculating what a person knows does not compare to what he does not know; the time of his life does not compare to the time before his birth. To seek the exhaustion of the greatest realm through what is most minute—this is why one becomes confused and cannot attain self-realization.

From this perspective, how can the tip of a hair suffice to determine the limit of the most subtle? And how can heaven and earth suffice to exhaust the realm of the greatest? Guo’s commentary: *"The measure of things is boundless"*—each thing has its own measure. *"Time knows no end"*—death and life are both the movement of time. *"Divisions are not constant"*—gain and loss are both divisions. *"Beginnings and ends have no fixed origin"*—each day is new. *"Small without paucity, great without excess"*—each is self-sufficient and without surplus. *"Knowing measure is infinite"*—by grasping and observing, one knows that things near and far, great and small, each have their measure. *"Verifying past and present"*—*xiang* means "illumination"; *gu* means "past and present." *"Remote"* means "distant"; *duo* means "near." *"Knowing time has no end"*—by verifying past and present, one knows that transformations do not cease with death and life, thus one is not troubled by length nor strained by brevity. Observing the alternation of fullness and emptiness, one knows that divisions are not constant in gain—thus one can forget sorrow and joy. *"Clearly perceiving"*...

The unobstructed Way speaks of death and life as the ever-renewing proper Dao. When the renewal of beginnings and ends is made clear, one knows that the old cannot be clung to or retained. Thus, one traverses the new without alarm and relinquishes the old without surprise—death and life’s transformations are as one. What one knows has its limits; each life has its allotted years. Better to rest content with the portion one has received. To seek the great with the small is ultimately futile. When each abides in its own portion, small and great are both sufficient.

If the tip of an autumn hair does not seek the workings of heaven and earth, then all the surplus of the body’s circumference becomes discarded matter. If heaven and earth are not seen as greater than an autumn hair, then merely regarding one’s form and appearance is self-sufficient. How, then, can one know the definiteness of the fine or the definiteness of the great?

---

Lü’s Commentary:
The Dao is neither small nor great—how could it have a fixed form? Now, heaven and earth I deem the utmost in greatness, yet what I know of them cannot be exhausted. Thus, what I call great—is it truly great? What I call small—is it truly small? Small is not paucity; great is not excess. This is to know that measure is infinite.

What I took as past is past, what I take as present is present. Before one speaks, the present has already become past. Thus, what is called past and present—how can they have an end? Verifying that past and present are both old, one is distant yet not troubled, brief yet not strained. This is to know that time has no end.

How can I fret and wait for a hundred years’ reign? That is to be distant and troubled. Pengzu was renowned for his longevity, yet when the common people compare themselves to him, they are brief and strained.

At noon the sun declines; when the moon is full, it wanes. Observing the alternation of fullness and emptiness, one gains yet does not rejoice, loses yet does not sorrow—knowing that divisions are not constant.

There is a beginning, then there must be an end; there is an end, then there must be a beginning. Tracing the beginning to its end, one understands that the unobstructed Way is such that life brings no joy, death brings no calamity—knowing that beginnings and ends cannot be clung to. Thus, what things call time, divisions, beginnings, and ends—are they truly known? To know yet not truly know is to know that what is known is surely not as good as what is unknown.

To live is to have knowledge; before birth, there is no knowledge. Thus, the time of one’s life is surely not as good as the time before one’s birth. Knowledge is the smallest; the infinite is the greatest. To seek the realm of the infinitely great with the smallest is to become lost and self-defeated.

---

Guan’s Observations:
If one can know that the measures of things, their times, and their divisions are not constant, then what need is there to examine beginnings and ends, small and great, much and little? When the impermanence of past and present is made clear, this principle becomes evident.

*Yao* means the duration of time; *duo* means the swiftness of change. Not being troubled means no weariness with one’s life; not being strained means no seeking to augment one’s life. Lifespan is fixed—one abides in it and that is all. People cannot but be born, cannot but have knowledge. Yet the sutra says, “Better not to know; better not to have been born.” This is because worldly people do not pursue true knowledge but seek delusive knowledge; they do not pursue the wholeness of life but seek to augment life. With the limited they chase the infinite, forgetting their inherent portion while coveting what lies beyond. With the harm and benefit that lie within themselves, they cannot see clearly—how then can they determine the boundaries of things, the fine and the great?

Better not to know—Wang Ni’s response to Nie Que’s question is an example. Better not to have been born—the skull’s unwillingness to return to the toils of the human world is another. Yet one is already born, already knows. How, then, can one free oneself? By taking non-birth as birth and non-knowledge as knowledge—then what burden is life? What possession is knowledge?

---

He Bo said: “Those who discuss the world all say that the most refined is formless, the greatest cannot be encompassed—is this a true reflection of reality?”

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: “From the fine one views the great—it is not fully seen; from the great one views the fine—it is not clearly perceived. The subtlety of the refined and small, the vastness of the great and abundant—these are the advantages of their respective conditions.

The refined and coarse are expected to have form. What is formless cannot be divided by numbers; what cannot be encompassed cannot be exhausted by numbers. What can be discussed in words is the coarse aspect of things; what can be conveyed by intention is the refined aspect of things. What cannot be discussed in words, what cannot be examined or conveyed by intention, does not depend on refinement or coarseness.

Thus, the conduct of the great person does not depart from harming others, yet does not overvalue benevolence and kindness. In action, they are not for profit, nor do they despise gatekeepers and servants. They do not contend over goods and wealth, nor do they overvalue deference and yielding in affairs. They do not borrow from others, nor do they eat excessively through force. They do not despise the greedy and corrupt, and their conduct differs from the common, yet they do not overvalue being unconventional. They follow the crowd yet do not despise flatterers and sycophants. The world’s ranks and emoluments are insufficient to encourage them; punishments and shame are insufficient to humiliate them. They know that right and wrong cannot be divided, that the fine and the great cannot be demarcated.”

It is said: “The Dao-person does not hear; the utmost virtue is not attained; the great person has no self.” This is the ultimate in abiding by one’s portion.

---

Guo’s Commentary:
The eye’s vision has a constant limit and cannot be without bounds. Thus, in regard to the great, there is what it cannot fully see; in regard to the fine, there is what it cannot clearly perceive. This is simply what the eye cannot reach. The refined and the great are not nonexistent—how could one know that what is formless and cannot be encompassed is so?

Great and small differ, so their advantages cannot be the same. If something is formless and cannot be encompassed, then it has no such differing advantages. There is refinement and coarseness—thus there cannot be formlessness. Only when there is nothing at all—then what refinement or coarseness could there be?

Words and intentions are something, yet what they express and intend is nothing. Thus, to seek beyond words and intentions is to enter the realm of no-words and no-intentions—only then does one reach the ultimate.

The great person has no intentions and follows the natural course. With every step, they tread on auspicious ground—how could they take the path of harming others? Without harm, they do not overvalue their kindness. In action, they do not act for profit—they respond to principle, and principle itself is without harm.

They do not despise gatekeepers and servants—they assign positions according to ability, and each is fittingly placed. It is not that they despise them and thus assign them to such posts. They do not contend over goods and wealth—each is made to abide by their fixed portion.

They do not overvalue deference and yielding—they act appropriately and that is all. They do not borrow from others—each is made to rely on themselves. They do not eat excessively—their strength is sufficient and that is all. They do not despise the greedy and corrupt—principle itself is without desire.

Their conduct differs from the common, yet they alone have no fixed preferences—thus they differ from the common. They do not overvalue being unconventional—they follow principle and naturally differ. They act in accord with the crowd yet do not despise flatterers and sycophants—they follow what the crowd does and are naturally upright.

Ranks and emoluments are insufficient to encourage them; punishments and shame are insufficient to humiliate them—external matters do not lodge in their hearts. Knowing that right and wrong, the fine and the great, cannot be divided, they merge with the mysterious. They let things be, and the natures of things communicate of themselves—thus merit and fame return to things.

Thus the Daoist does not hear of "gain"—what is called gain arises from loss. When things each have no loss, the name of "gain" departs. Therefore, the utmost virtue does not "attain"—the great person simply allows things to be, and thus has no self. To reach the utmost of one’s allotted portion is to restrain oneself to that portion—thus it is a guard.

Only that which is boundless, formless, and cannot be encompassed is truly so.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
When one views the great from the perspective of the small, the eye’s power does not reach it—this is merely a failure to exhaust it, not that it cannot be encompassed. When one views the small from the perspective of the great, the midge perched on a mosquito’s eyelash is unseen—this is merely a failure of clarity, not that it is formless. The coarse and the fine are manifest in form; the formless is a matter of calculation that cannot be divided; the unencompassable is a matter of calculation that cannot be exhausted. What can be spoken of belongs to the coarse of things; what can be grasped by intention belongs to the fine of things. The Dao, however, transcends both speech and intention—it does not await the fine or the coarse.

Thus the conduct of the great person does not depart from harming the nature of others—yet they do not overvalue benevolence and kindness, for these are not deliberate acts. The gatekeeper acts for profit; the deferential do not contend. They eat by their own strength and do not rely on others. The greedy and corrupt are the opposite. Those who affect eccentricity make it their business to differ from the common; the sycophantic follow their lord or kin rather than the crowd. All this arises from nature. The world’s ranks, emoluments, punishments, and shames are insufficient to encourage or restrain them.

How could they know the divisions of right and wrong or the distinctions of fine and great? One who can restrain themselves to the utmost of their allotted portion, reaching the point where nothing is divided—this is why the Daoist does not hear of it, why the utmost virtue does not "attain," and why the great person has no self.

**Detailed Explanation of the Dao:**
The great person, in relation to the world, forgets things with the mind and forgets the mind with the Dao. They do not depart from harming others—yet one might suspect they overvalue benevolence and kindness, but they do not. They do not contend over wealth—yet one might suspect they overvalue deference, but they do not. They do not rely on others for tasks or consume more than their strength allows—yet one might suspect they despise the greedy and corrupt, but they do not. Their conduct differs from the common—yet one might suspect they overvalue eccentricity, but they do not. They do not despise gatekeepers to exalt themselves, nor do they despise the greedy and corrupt to purify themselves, nor do they despise sycophants to prove their uprightness.

Thus, ranks and punishments do not disturb their inner being; right and wrong, fine and great, are not worth distinguishing externally. Then what room is there in the heart for the coarse and fine that lie in speech and intention? Therefore, to hear is not truly to hear; to gain is to have nothing attained. Reaching the point of having no self, "I" am lost—how then could there be things? Without restraining oneself to one’s allotted portion and reaching its utmost, one is not equal to this.

**Personal Insight:**
When one views the great from the perspective of the small, it ends in failure to exhaust it—yet the great does not end there. When one views the small from the perspective of the great, it ends in failure of clarity—yet the small is not formless. The fine is the utmost of the small; the vast is the fullness of the great. Though small and great differ, both have form and number, and thus are subject to formation and decay. When the fine reaches the formless and the great reaches the unencompassable, they are not fixed by form nor divided by number—thus they are free from formation and decay.

The coarse of things can be spoken of; the fine can be grasped by intention. That which transcends the coarse and fine cannot be reached by speech or intention. What cannot be reached by speech or intention, nor divided by form or number—is this not the Dao? Thus the great person takes benefiting things as their priority yet does not overvalue benevolence and kindness. They are not moved by profit yet do not despise those who pursue it—all this describes the conduct of the great person, which differs from the common. Even sycophancy is not despised, allowing the noble and the base to follow their own paths. Right and wrong, fine and great, are not worth distinguishing—then how could ranks, punishments, encouragements, or restraints be of any use?

**He Bo said:** Where is the boundary between the outer and inner of things? Where is the distinction between noble and base? Where is the distinction between small and great?

**The Lord of the Northern Sea said:** From the perspective of the Dao, things have no nobility or baseness. From the perspective of things, each exalts itself and despises others. From the perspective of the common, nobility and baseness do not lie in oneself. From the perspective of difference, if you take what is great in something and make it great, then nothing is not great; if you take what is small in something and make it small, then nothing is not small. Knowing that heaven and earth are but a grain of millet, and that the tip of a hair is a mountain—then the distinctions of difference are seen.

From the perspective of function, if you take what something has and affirm its having, then nothing does not have; if you take what something lacks and affirm its lacking, then nothing does not lack. Knowing that east and west are opposites yet cannot be without each other—then the divisions of function are fixed. From the perspective of tendencies, if you affirm what something affirms, then nothing is not affirmed; if you negate what something negates, then nothing is not negated. Knowing that Yao and Jie each affirmed themselves and negated the other—then the tendencies of conduct are seen.

In ancient times, Yao and Shun yielded and became emperors; Kuai yielded and was destroyed. Tang and Wu contended and became kings; Bai Gong contended and was annihilated. From this, we see that the rites of contention and yielding, the conduct of Yao and Jie, have their times—nothing can be taken as constant.

Thus, when we follow a thing’s nature and deem it sufficient to name it great, then the finest hair-tip and the towering mountain share the same name; when we follow its lack of excess and call it small, then heaven-and-earth and the tiniest grain of millet share the same designation. But if one observes differences without proceeding by this Dao, then differences accumulate, infinitesimal inclinations tilt, and distinctions become impossible to fathom.

All under heaven take each other as “that” and “this,” and both “that” and “this” wish to act for themselves—hence the opposition of east and west. Yet “that” and “this” together form lips and teeth: lips and teeth never act for each other, yet when the lips perish, the teeth grow cold. Thus, “that” acting for itself accomplishes my benefit—this is the way of opposition that cannot do without each other. Therefore, if we follow their self-directed action yet deny its merit, then all merit under heaven is denied; if we recognize their mutual indispensability and affirm its merit, then all merit under heaven is affirmed.

Now, if one forgets the merit of self-directed action and instead dwells on the kindness of acting for others, the more diligently one bestows kindness, the thinner it grows, and the more the world loses its proper work while human nature overflows in chaos. Thus, the apportionment of merit can never be fixed.

All things are so of themselves, hence nothing is not so; all things oppose each other, hence nothing is not opposed. Where nothing is not opposed, nothing is so; where nothing is not so, nothing is opposed. One who is neither so nor opposed is Yao; one who is both so and opposed is Jie. Yet these two rulers each received their natural endowment from heaven and could not act for each other. Thus, observing Yao and Jie reveals the tendencies of all under heaven: their inability to act for each other is manifest.

Those who receive all under heaven by responding to heaven and aligning with the people—on the surface, their traces are the traces of contention and yielding. Yet those who trace their traces miss the source of those traces, and so perish.

The Lü commentary states:
Viewing things through the Dao, how can there be noble and base? Viewing them through things themselves, each deems itself noble and others base—but the Dao is not a thing. Viewing them through custom, noble and base lie not in oneself—but the Dao is not custom. Since the Dao is neither thing nor custom, it is neither noble nor base. Magnify what is deemed great, diminish what is deemed small; know that heaven and earth differ from the Great Void, that a grain of millet or a hair’s tip differs from the formless, and that hills and mountains differ from the imperceptible—then the measure of such differences becomes clear. Yet the Dao is not difference, and thus not great or small.

Affirm what is affirmed, negate what is negated; know that east must have west, that without east there is no west, that Yao and Jie each arose from self-affirmation and mutual negation—then the tendencies of all become manifest. Yet the Dao is not tendency, and thus not affirmation or negation. If this is so, then one who embodies the Dao forgets both sides and rests in equilibrium. How could the Heavenly Equality trouble itself with distinctions of noble and base, great and small?

If Yao and Shun’s yielding is deemed right, then Zihuai perished by yielding; if Tang and Wu’s contention is deemed right, then the Duke of Bai perished by contending. The rites of yielding and contending, the conduct of Yao and Jie—noble and base shift with the times and cannot be taken as constant.

A roof beam can batter down a city wall yet cannot plug a mouse-hole—this speaks of differing implements. The swift steed Qiji or Hua-liu gallops a thousand li in a day yet cannot catch a mouse—this speaks of differing skills. The owl snatches fleas at night, discerning the finest hairs, yet by day stares blindly and sees not hills or mountains—this speaks of differing natures. Thus it is said: He who takes right as his teacher yet admits no wrong, takes order as his teacher yet admits no chaos, has not yet understood the principles of heaven and earth or the conditions of the myriad things. This is like taking heaven as teacher yet excluding earth, taking yin as teacher yet excluding yang—its impossibility is manifest. Yet those who cling to such speech without ceasing are either fools or deceivers.

The succession of emperors and kings differs; the inheritance of the Three Dynasties differs. Those who defy their times and customs are called usurpers; those who accord with their times and customs are called righteous. How silently flows the River Earl! How could a woman know the gate of noble and base, the house of great and small?

Guo’s commentary states:
Following their differences and letting each take its course, nothing among the myriad things is misplaced. The principles of heaven and earth and the conditions of the myriad things deem attaining me as right and losing me as wrong, fitting nature as order and losing harmony as chaos. Different natures and distinct capacities give rise to right and wrong without fixed standard. If one takes one’s own right as absolute, then others cannot but be wrong—this is knowing oneself yet not seeing others. Thus, viewing through the Dao, right and wrong have no fixed place. Entrusting all to the Heavenly Equality and letting both sides proceed freely, then differing directions and distinct paths all attain their due. Heaven and earth, yin and yang, give rise to each other; right and wrong, order and chaos, intermingle. What is there to discard?

What custom deems noble may later be deemed base; what things deem great one age may deem small another. Thus, following the traces of things cannot but lead to differences—this is why the Five Emperors and Three Kings differed. The Lü commentary states: A roof beam cannot plug a mouse-hole; a swift steed cannot catch a mouse; an owl cannot see by day—these three differ, yet to seek to equalize them is to fail to understand the principles of heaven and the conditions of things. To speak only of singular right or only of plural paths...

A humble observation:
Different implements have different uses, different skills have different capacities, different natures have different conveniences—they cannot be judged by a single standard. To take order as teacher yet admit no chaos, to take yin as teacher yet admit no yang, is not to understand the principles of heaven and earth and the myriad things. Abdication and succession, compliance and defiance, each follows its time—there is no need for much speech. Even if one speaks, it only addresses traces. How could one know the origin of noble and base, great and small? To know the origin of noble and base, great and small, one must seek it where things have not yet begun.

The River Earl said: Then what should I do? What should I not do? How should I decide my acceptance or rejection, my pursuit or abandonment? What will become of me in the end?

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: Viewing through the Dao, what is noble? What is base? This is called "reversal and return," free from constraint, where will and Dao are greatly at odds. What is few? What is many? This is called "alternation and application," free from singularity, where conduct and Dao are out of step. How solemn! A state with a ruler has no private virtue—how reverent! A sacrifice with an altar has no private blessing—how boundless! Like the four directions without limit, without boundaries, embracing the myriad things—who bears and who assists? This is called "without direction." The myriad things are one in equality—who is short? Who is long?

The Dao has no end or beginning; things have death and birth. Not relying on their completion, now empty, now full, they do not settle in their forms. Years cannot be lifted, time cannot be halted. Ebb and flow, fullness and emptiness, end and then begin—this is how one speaks of the great meaning’s direction, discusses the principles of the myriad things.

Things’ arising is like galloping, like racing—no movement without change, no moment without shift. What should one do? What should one not do? They will of course transform themselves.

Guo’s commentary states:
"Reversal and return" refers to the way of noble and base, which turns and repeats endlessly. Self-constraint leads to disharmony with the Dao; following one’s portion means application is without constancy. "Out of step with the Dao" means inability to follow change, hence not equal to the Dao. "No private virtue" means impartiality alone. "No private blessing" means what all under heaven seek together. "Without boundaries" means boundless, without fixed place. "Embracing the myriad things, who bears and who assists?" speaks of encompassing and guiding all beings, returning them to their proper portions and balancing their comings and goings. How could one support the distant and assist the near?

Only by being without direction can one take the myriad things as direction, and both long and short be sufficient. Life and death are but endless transformations—not true end or beginning. Not relying on their completion means completion has no constant abode. "Not settling in their forms" means forms do not take form as their position and guard it without change. "Years cannot be lifted" means wishing to lift them and make them depart, yet being unable. "Time cannot be halted" means wishing to halt it and make it stop, yet being unable. "Fullness and emptiness, end and beginning" means daily renewal of transformation, never abiding.

"Like galloping, like racing"—one should simply follow their use, for there is no change without shift, nothing to grasp and hold. What should one do? What should one not do? They will of course transform themselves.

If one intervenes with action or inaction amidst these transformations, one disrupts their natural course.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
Scholars ordinarily remain entangled in things. Upon hearing the Dao’s teaching that nothing is noble or base, they become confused in matters of action and inaction, acceptance and rejection, not knowing where to turn—rightly so.

What is called noble or base is merely the reversal of things, not the Dao. Reversal entails departure and return: returning is noble, departing is base. Broadness entails depletion: depletion is noble, broadness is base. One should let the mind roam freely without constraint, for if one clings to purpose, one becomes greatly obstructed and cannot align with the Dao.

What is called few or many is merely the exchange and bestowal of things, not the Dao. Exchange entails flourishing and withering: withering is few, flourishing is many. Bestowal entails gathering and dispersing: dispersing is many, gathering is few. One should proceed with both without favoring one over the other, for if one acts singularly, one falls out of step with the Dao.

"Without private virtue" means not relying solely on the ruler one serves—this is what it means to have no constraint in purpose. "Without private blessing" means not bestowing favor solely upon those one sacrifices to—this is what it means to proceed without singularity. "Without boundaries" means being in accord with the Dao and not greatly obstructed.

Who, then, bears and assists? This is called having no fixed direction, treating all things as equal, and aligning with the Dao without discord. Relying on their completion means not understanding that end and beginning cannot be grasped; settling in form means not perceiving that fullness and emptiness have no constancy. "Years cannot be lifted," so one remains at ease without vexation; "time cannot be halted," so one acts without strain. The waxing and waning of fullness and emptiness, the end and the beginning—these are but the movements of Heaven. This is how one speaks of the Dao’s boundlessness and discusses the principles of all things. Why, then, entangle the mind in matters of acceptance and rejection?

"Like galloping, like racing"—if transformations shift imperceptibly, why fix the mind on action or inaction? They will of course transform themselves, proceeding without need for arrangement. This is what it means to let things transform naturally.

**Detailed Explanation of the Dao:**
"Broadness" refers to level ground; reversal restores it to a slope. The distinction between level and sloped has no fixed norm—how is the alternation of noble and base any different?

Bestowal is the function of benevolence; exchange is giving without clinging to benevolence. How can one calculate the tally of many or few? In reversal, one forgets noble and base and is not burdened by reputation; in exchange, one forgets many and few and is not bound by profit. If one does not thus return to the true, it has never been achieved.

**Bi Xu’s Annotation:**
Noble and base have no fixed master but flow in constant alternation—this is the norm. The great Dao is utterly smooth, and the mind roams freely in accord—this is alignment. One’s allotment is determined by fate, and the few exchange while the many bestow—this is fitting. The ways of the world are uneven, and one’s conduct adapts to change—this is principle.

If virtue is private, it lacks sternness; if blessing is private, it does not endure. If boundaries exist, it is not all-pervading. Having a fixed direction entails bearing and assisting, but if one clings to such support, the virtue of embracing all things is lost.

Forget the self, and there is no long or short; forget the mind, and there is no life or death; forget position, and there is no fullness or emptiness; forget years, and one follows transformation; forget time, and one follows change; forget the waxing and waning of fullness and emptiness, and who then determines end and beginning?

Things are never not born, never not transformed—their changes are like galloping, their shifts like racing. They are but yin and yang, the four seasons. They will of course transform themselves; why concern the mind with action or inaction?

The River Earl said, "If so, then what is the value of the Dao?"
The Lord of the Northern Sea replied, "One who knows the Dao necessarily grasps principle; one who grasps principle necessarily understands adaptability; one who understands adaptability does not let things harm the self. The one of utmost virtue cannot be burned by fire, drowned by water, harmed by cold or heat, or injured by birds or beasts. This is not to say one belittles them, but rather that one discerns safety and danger, finds peace in fortune and misfortune, and is cautious in approach and retreat—nothing can harm them.

Thus it is said: Heaven is within, humans are without; virtue resides in Heaven. To know the conduct of Heaven and humans is to take Heaven as fundamental. Abiding in attainment, one flexes and extends, returns to the essential, and speaks of the ultimate, saying: What is Heaven? What is human?

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: 'Oxen and horses having four legs is called Heaven; placing a halter on a horse’s head or a ring through an ox’s nose is called human.' Thus it is said: Do not let the human obliterate Heaven; do not let the artificial obliterate fate; do not pursue fame at the expense of attainment. Guard this carefully and do not lose it—this is called returning to the true."

**Guo’s Annotation:**
What is the value of the Dao? It lies in its self-transformation. One who knows the Dao knows their own inability. Inability—

Then how could anything else give me life? I am self-generated. And yet my four limbs, hundred parts, five viscera, and spirit—none act, yet all form of themselves. What further intention could there be after life and completion?

One who grasps this principle must be able to dismiss excessive knowledge, relinquish the emotions that seek to prolong life, and ride change while responding to contingency. Thus, one is not harmed within by what is without, nor injured by things, and so remains whole. Therefore, what the heart finds at peace cannot be endangered by danger; where intention finds nothing unsuitable, suffering cannot cause suffering.

This is not to say one should treat such things lightly—even what the heart finds at peace should not be allowed to encroach. Discerning safety and peril, one knows they cannot be escaped; abiding in fortune and misfortune, one rests in what fate encounters. Carefully weighing departure and approach, one examines what is not one’s own—thus, nothing can be taken as harm, and so nothing can harm.

That the Heavenly is within and the human without means the natural resides within, while what follows the natural resides without. Thus, the *Great Master* says: "One who knows what Heaven and humans do has attained the ultimate." Clarifying the division of inner and outer, one sees that neither acts. Virtue resides in Heaven—let humans follow their nature, and knowledge will flow unrestrained, losing its original purity. The knowledge of the natural acts on its own and does not exceed its allotted portion. Therefore, though it moves in the external, it always takes the Heavenly as its root. Abiding in attainment—this is it.

The pacing and flexing of steps—these words speak of responding to opportunities as they arise, giving rise to such changes. To return to essentials and speak of ultimates is to know that though knowledge may span heaven and earth, and affairs may touch the myriad things, one never loses sight of the essential and the ultimate. Thus, the Dao of Heaven and humans remains whole.

In human life, can one not harness oxen and ride horses? And in harnessing oxen and riding horses, can one not bridle and rein them? That oxen and horses do not refuse bridles and reins is because it is the fixed mandate of Heaven. If it accords with the Heavenly mandate, then though it may be entrusted to human affairs, its root remains in Heaven. Yet if one overworks them beyond measure, drives them out of step, and loses rhythm, then the Heavenly principle is extinguished. Where lies the mandate if one does not follow their natural actions but instead forces them? What one attains has a constant allotment; to pursue fame is to exceed it. Returning to one’s true nature—truth resides within the bounds of one’s inherent nature.

---
**Lü’s Commentary:**
Allowing things to transform of themselves—this is the Dao. The River Earl did not awaken, so he asked what was noble about the Dao. Sea If explained that understanding principles and discerning expedients, not allowing things to harm oneself—these are the affairs of one who knows the Dao, but not the ultimate attainment of embodying the Dao. As for being unharmed by water or fire, unassailed by cold or heat—this is how one who embodies the Dao is by nature. It is not that one belittles them.

To examine safety and danger, to be cautious in departure and approach, so that nothing can harm—this is to know the Dao, understand principles, and discern expedients. To be at peace with fortune and misfortune, knowing they cannot be helped and accepting them—this is the Heavenly within. To examine departure and approach is to know that what humans fear cannot but be feared—this is the human without. Through this, one enters virtue. Though one may not yet be Heavenly and not human, virtue resides in Heaven.

To know the actions of Heaven and humans is rooted in the Heavenly position. In attainment, one emerges from Heaven and turns toward the human; in pacing and flexing, in returning to essentials and speaking of ultimates, one moves from the human back to Heaven. From "not using the human to extinguish the Heavenly" to this—this is called returning to one’s true nature. In this, how could one’s relation to the Dao be merely a matter of knowing it?

Here the limited view—from the opening of this chapter to this point, six questions and answers unfold like wind driving distant waves, gradually nearing and surging until, at this moment, snow-white breakers spray forth, overwhelming the senses. In an instant, all settles, and the water’s gleam stretches boundless, a single azure embracing heaven and humanity. The breath of falsehood returns to truth; within the empty, still center, something profound stirs.

The man of utmost virtue, proceeding from the human to illuminate the Heavenly, employing adaptability to grasp principle, examining safety and danger, carefully weighing departure and approach—what thing could harm him? Yet he never relies on this to lord over others. The Heavenly within establishes his essence; the human without serves his function. Virtue residing in Heaven unites with the spirit, boundless and unfathomable. Abiding in Heavenly essence and dwelling in virtue, he bends and extends with the world; returning to essentials and speaking of ultimates, he never loses his true nature. Thus, the Way of conducting oneself and others is complete.

Hence, the River Lord’s mind was guarded, his understanding deepened, and he asked no further questions.

---

The single-footed *kuí* pitied the centipede: “I stride with one foot—you have no such ease. Now you command ten thousand feet—how do you manage?”
The centipede replied, “Not so. Have you not seen one who spits? When he sprays, the large droplets are like pearls, the small like mist, and those scattering downward are beyond counting. Now I move by Heavenly mechanism, yet I know not how it is so.”

The centipede said to the snake, “I walk with many feet, yet I do not match you, who have none. Why?”
The snake said, “How can the movement of the Heavenly mechanism be altered? What use have I for feet?”

The snake said to the wind, “I move by flexing my spine and ribs—there is something to it. Now you rise in a great rush from the Northern Sea and rush into the Southern Sea, yet seem as if you were nothing. Why?”
The wind said, “Indeed, I rise in a great rush from the Northern Sea and enter the Southern Sea. Yet if one points a finger at me, I am overcome; if one blocks me, I am also overcome. Nevertheless, to snap great trees and topple vast halls—only I can do this. Thus, to turn many small defeats into a great victory—only the sage can achieve this.”

Sima [Biao] says: The *kuí* has one foot; the centipede, many; the snake, none; the wind, no form. The eye has form here but sees there; the mind, being formless, reaches everywhere without hindrance.

Guo [Xiang]’s commentary: When things are born, they do not know they are being born, and thus their living is not a matter of knowing how to live. How, then, could their walking be a matter of knowing how to walk? Thus, the feet do not know how they walk, the eyes do not know how they see, the mind does not know how it knows—yet all move forward of themselves, at ease. The rhythms of slowness and speed, the discernment of keen and dull—some can do these, some cannot, but none of it is “me.” Yet some, desiring to possess their bodies and pride themselves on their abilities, go against the Heavenly mechanism and harm the vessel of the spirit. The utmost person knows the Heavenly mechanism cannot be altered, so he discards keen hearing and sharp sight, abandons knowledge and planning, and in utter forgetfulness, lets things move of themselves. Thus, there is no movement that is not free and unfettered. When the Heavenly mechanism is allowed to flow without contention, even small defeats are overcome. Yet when one rides the myriad things, guiding the multitude of talents, letting each talent find its own way and each thing act of itself, then nothing in the world is not free and unfettered—this is how the sage achieves great victory.

Lü [Huiqing]’s commentary: The *kuí*, with one foot, pities the centipede’s many feet; the centipede, with many feet, pities the snake’s lack of feet; the snake, moving by flexing its spine and ribs, pities the wind, which rises in a great rush from the Northern Sea and enters the Southern Sea. Thus, the eye, bound to one place, sees another, while the mind, seeing nothing, reaches everywhere without hindrance—this is evident. The *kuí* finds one foot easy and pities the centipede’s many feet as difficult; the centipede finds many feet easy and pities the snake’s lack of feet as difficult. Yet when the Heavenly mechanism moves, none knows how it is so—how then can difficulty or ease lie in having many or few, having or lacking? From this, we know that wind, eye, and mind all arise from spontaneity. How could the River Lord’s petty calculations of high and low, few and many compare to this? The wind turns small defeats into great victory, yet the human eye and mind, whose spirit far surpasses the wind, cannot attain what is called “seeing without seeing, knowing without knowing,” and thus cannot master the great victory over the myriad things. Is this true knowledge?

Detailed Dao: To rely on feet is to find one foot inferior to ten thousand, so the *kuí* pities the centipede. To be burdened by feet is to find ten thousand inferior to none, so the centipede pities the snake. The snake has something, yet seeing nothing as insufficient, it pities the wind. The wind rushes forth—yet finding having direction inadequate, it pities the eye. The eye merely governs sight, while the mind governs all, so it is said to be pitied.

---

Confucius was traveling in Kuang when men of Song surrounded him in several layers, yet he continued singing without pause. Zilu entered and asked, “How can you be so joyful, Master?”
Confucius said, “Come, let me tell you. I have long avoided adversity, yet I cannot escape fate. I have long sought success, yet I have not attained it.”

Yet I have not met with the right time. Had I lived in the age of Yao and Shun, the world would have known no destitute men—not through any wisdom of mine in attaining success. Had I lived in the age of Jie and Zhou, the world would have known no flourishing men—not through any failure of wisdom on my part. Such is the way of time and circumstance.

He who travels by water without avoiding dragons and serpents displays the courage of a fisherman. He who travels by land without avoiding rhinoceroses and tigers displays the courage of a hunter. He who faces flashing blades and regards death as life displays the courage of a warrior. He who knows that adversity is bound to fate, that success comes in its proper time, and stands before great peril without fear—this is the courage of the sage.

You may rest now. My fate is governed by forces beyond me.

Shortly after, an armored officer approached and said, “We mistook you for Yang Hu, hence the siege. Now that we know otherwise, we beg leave to withdraw.”

Sima Biao notes: “Song” should read “Wei”; Kuang was a town in Wei.
Guo Xiang comments: To clarify the unyielding nature of time and fate, the text illustrates it through the attempt to avoid adversity. “Such is the way of time and circumstance” means one should not weary the mind over success or failure. The courage of the fisherman, hunter, and warrior each finds comfort in its own domain; the sage finds comfort in all. Knowing fate is not within one’s control, one need not trouble the heart. He who is at peace with fate finds freedom wherever he goes—thus, being besieged in Kuang or imprisoned in Youli is no different from resting in the Purple Ultimate Hall.

Bi Xu comments: When Confucius traveled in Kuang and was surrounded by men of Song, it was said that all defenses were overcome—yet when they realized their mistake and withdrew, this was called the “great victory.”

Gongsun Long asked Wei Mou, “In my youth, I studied the Master’s Way. In maturity, I came to understand the practice of benevolence and righteousness. I harmonized sameness and difference, separated hardness and whiteness, affirmed the not-so, denied the not-not, confounded the wisdom of the Hundred Schools, and silenced the eloquence of all disputants. I thought myself perfectly enlightened—yet now I hear the words of Zhuangzi and feel lost, as if adrift. I cannot debate them, nor do I grasp them. I cannot even open my mouth to ask. May I inquire into the method?”

Prince Mou of Wei sighed deeply, looked up to the sky, and laughed, “Have you never heard of the frog in the shallow well? It said to the turtle of the Eastern Sea, ‘How joyful I am! I leap and prance upon the well’s railing, rest in the broken bricks of its walls. When I plunge into the water, it supports my armpits and cradles my chin. When I trample the mud, it covers my feet and ankles. I look around at the shrimp, crabs, and tadpoles—none can compare to me! Moreover, to command the water of a single ravine and stand astride the joy of a shallow well—this is perfection. Why not come in and see for yourself?’

The turtle of the Eastern Sea had not yet placed its left foot in the well when its right knee was already stuck. It withdrew, stepped back, and told the frog of the sea: ‘A distance of a thousand *li* cannot convey its vastness; a height of a thousand *ren* cannot measure its depth. In the time of Yu, floods lasted nine years out of ten, yet the sea did not swell. In the time of Tang, droughts lasted seven years out of eight, yet its shores did not recede. Not to be moved by the passage of time, nor altered by the increase or decrease of water—this is the great joy of the Eastern Sea.’

At this, the frog in the shallow well was stunned, dismayed, and utterly at a loss. Now, you who do not even know the bounds of right and wrong yet wish to examine Zhuangzi’s words—this is like a mosquito trying to carry a mountain or a centipede racing across a river. It is beyond your strength. And you who do not comprehend the subtleties of his discourse yet seek only momentary advantage—are you not like the frog in the shallow well?

Moreover, he treads upon the Yellow Springs and ascends the Great Emperor, unbound by south or north, released in all four directions, lost in the unfathomable. Unconfined by east or west, he begins in the darkest mystery and returns to the great thoroughfare. Yet you seek to measure him with narrow vision, to grasp him with disputation—this is like using a tube to view the sky or a bodkin to probe the earth. Is it not too small a thing? Go now.”

Moreover, have you alone not heard of the young man of Shouling who went to Handan to learn its way of walking? Before he had mastered the state’s skill, he had already forgotten his own way of walking—so he could only crawl home on all fours. If you do not leave now, you will forget your own way and lose your own calling.

Gongsun Long’s mouth gaped open and would not close, his tongue lifted and would not descend, until he fled like a *han* (a red insect) or a centipede. Guo’s commentary: To monopolize a puddle’s water and strut about in the joy of a shallow well is like a small bird contenting itself with thistles and brambles. The left foot has not yet entered when the right is already entangled—how could one who understands the great not roam in the small? It is not that he does not delight in it, but that the small cannot envy the great. Each thing has its proper place; one cannot forcibly emulate another. Beginning in the darkest mystery and returning to the great thoroughfare—this speaks of his boundlessness. He who roams the limitless cannot be grasped by disputation or scrutiny. Those unequal to the task should depart. To imitate another is to lose both.

Lü’s commentary: The bounds of right and wrong speak of their origins. To grasp the origin of right and wrong is to see Yao and Jie as one, to know and not know as the same. From this perspective, one is left speechless, with no room for argument. From the Yellow Springs to the six directions below, from the Great Emperor to the Great Ultimate above—unbound by south or north, released in all four directions, lost in the unfathomable. Forgetting darkness and light, without direction, one enters the numinous. Unconfined by east or west, beginning in the darkest mystery and returning to the great thoroughfare, one merges with the harmonious center, transcends the spirit, and attains clarity. In short, this is what is meant by the six penetrations and four openings, form filling emptiness—this is it. This meaning cannot be exhausted in words, nor can it be debated. Yet to seek it with narrow vision, to grasp it with disputation, is like using a tube to view the sky or a bodkin to probe the earth.

Oral exegesis: Gongsun Long was a disputer of his time, like a red insect in a shallow well. In the hollow of a well, *han*-insects, crabs, and tadpoles all circle within it—hence the saying, “returning to the *han*-insects, crabs, and tadpoles.” Nine years of floods, seven years of drought—truly, all things perish. Zhuangzi wrote of ten years of floods and eight years of drought, but this is a separate matter. *Shishi* means startled; *shangju* is a small insect. *Ci* means to tread; *dahuang* is heaven. To tread below upon the Yellow Springs and ascend above to heaven speaks of his lofty and distant vision. *Shiran* means released; *sijie* means four directions unbound. *Lunyu buce* means entering the unfathomable. Beginning in the darkest mystery speaks of the time before the limitless; returning to the great thoroughfare means returning to the ultimate Dao. *Guoneng* refers to the way of walking practiced in Handan.

Zhuangzi was fishing in the Pu River when the King of Chu sent two great ministers to approach him first, saying, “We wish to trouble you with the affairs of the kingdom.” Zhuangzi held his fishing rod and did not turn, saying, “I have heard that in Chu there is a divine turtle that has been dead for three thousand years. The king keeps it wrapped in silk and stored in a casket in the ancestral temple. Would this turtle rather have died and left its bones to be venerated, or lived and dragged its tail through the mud?” The two ministers said, “It would rather live and drag its tail through the mud.” Zhuangzi said, “Go away. I will drag my tail through the mud.”

Guo’s commentary: The divine turtle is a metaphor for how each nature has its own place of rest.
Lü’s commentary: Zhuangzi did not know the dead—he spoke thus to rescue those of his time who pursued profit and forgot life. Only the two ministers’ understanding was sufficient for this.
Personal insight: Zhuangzi declined the summons with the turtle as a metaphor. Formerly, Tao Zhuo, when living in seclusion, yoked two strong oxen to answer an imperial summons—one was confined by the whip and bridle, the other roamed freely among the water and grass. This is the same idea.

When Huizi was prime minister of Liang, Zhuangzi went to see him. Someone said to Huizi, “Zhuangzi is coming to replace you as prime minister.” Thereupon, Huizi became alarmed and searched the state for three days and three nights. Zhuangzi went to see him and said, “In the south there is a bird called the *yuanchu*—have you heard of it? The *yuanchu* sets out from the South Sea and flies to the North Sea. It will not perch except on a parasol tree, will not eat except bamboo fruit, and will not drink except from sweet springs. At that moment, an owl had found a rotten rat. When the *yuanchu* flew over, it looked up and cried, ‘Hah!’ Now do you wish to use your state of Liang to ‘hah’ at me?”

Guo’s commentary: “Searched the state” means to muster troops and marshal forces. The *yuanchu* is a metaphor for how desires differ, and each has its own limits.
Supplementary notes: The *yuanchu* is a young phoenix; *lian* fruit is bamboo fruit. *Hah* is the sound of anger, fearing the loss of its food. The ways of the world and the feelings of men—seeing this, one can burst into laughter. Zhuangzi vividly depicted the petty man’s fear of loss with a single word. How splendid! Personal insight: *Sou* in the commentary means to search the state; Guo’s commentary takes *sou* as *shou* (to hunt). But if an owl has found a rotten rat and cries *hah*, how can it compare to the taste of bamboo fruit and sweet springs, or the perch on a verdant parasol tree?

Zhuangzi and Huizi were strolling on the bridge over the Hao River. Zhuangzi said, “The *tiao* fish swim out so leisurely—this is the joy of fish.” Huizi said, “You are not a fish—how do you know the joy of fish?” Zhuangzi said, “You are not me—how do you know I do not know the joy of fish?” Huizi said, “I am not you, so of course I do not know you. You are certainly not a fish, so your not knowing the joy of fish is complete.” Zhuangzi said, “Let us return to the beginning. When you said, ‘How do you know the joy of fish?’ you already knew I knew it and asked me. I know it here on the Hao.”

Guo’s commentary: Zhuangzi said, “You are not me, so you can know that I am not a fish—then I am not a fish, so I can know the joy of fish.” Huizi abandoned the root of his words and quibbled to make his point. Zhuangzi followed Huizi’s original words, saying, “You are not a fish, so you have no way of knowing it. Now you are not me, yet you say, ‘How do you know the joy of fish?’ This means you know I am not a fish. If you know I am not a fish, then all who know one another can know one another in this way—there is no need to be the fish to know the fish. So, following your ‘How do you know?’—you already knew what I knew. And now you ask me again—I simply know it here on the Hao. Why wait to enter the water? What is born in a place and finds rest there—heaven and earth cannot change its place, yin and yang cannot alter its nature. Thus, to know what is comfortable for land-dwellers and infer the joy of water-dwellers is hardly the subtlest point.”

The *Deputy Ink*—Huizi said, “You and the fish dwell in different realms, water and land. How then can you know the joy of fish?” Zhuangzi borrowed his words and turned them back, saying, “You are not me—how do you know I do not know the joy of fish?” Huizi again borrowed his words and shifted them, saying, “I am not you, so of course I do not know you. Yet even you and I, both of the same kind, remain divided by the barrier of self and other and do not fully know one another. How much less, then, can you know the fish, who are not of our kind? By this reasoning, there is no possible way for you to know the fish at all.”

At this, Zhuangzi countered directly: “Let us return to the original words. All this back-and-forth debate of ours is but branch and leaf—it is not the root of the matter. Following the original thread, you already know that I know the fish. Yet you still ask me—precisely to seek the reason why I know the joy of fish. Not to understand the principles of things and the feelings of others is naturally something one may infer. I dwell at ease upon the Hao, and thus the joy of those beneath its waters goes without saying. As the ancients said, Zhuangzi was skilled at understanding the feelings of things—this is why.”

Li Shibiao: “Nothing is without the Dao, and so it is with me.”

"Is there any distinction in nature that is not sufficient unto itself? The celestial principle is thus with me. How could there be, though the affinity between things and myself be as such? For there exists a wondrous principle that knows without deliberate knowing, that grasps subtleties in silent communion—a reception so primal it cannot escape what precedes it. This is how Zhuangzi knew the joy of fish at Hao’s edge.

Now, to emerge and soar, to glide and swim—free from the peril of nets, untroubled by the need to moisten parched gills—leisurely within the bounds of a single watercourse: is this to be deemed the joy of fish? And if this is the joy of fish, why must one await Nan Hua to recognize it? For the joy of fish lies in the Dao, not in the water; what Nan Hua knew lay in joy, not in fish. Fish forget the water, and thus their joy is complete; man forgets the fish, and thus his knowing is whole.

Here, Zhuangzi would have remained silent. Hui Shi, too, would have asked nothing—yet this debate arose. Without inquiry, the ultimate words find no foothold; without words, the subtleties of the Dao remain unseen. It serves but to dispel the obstruction of later ages, the delusion that divides things and self into two.

Things will ever have their own nature—how could Zhuangzi, not being a fish, know the joy of fish? The self will ever have its own nature—how could you, not being me, know that I do not know the joy of fish? Knowing and not knowing are but the branches of the Dao. This is why I urged returning to the root. As for those who know neither root nor branch—ancients have spoken of this before: the eye is like the ear, the ear..."

The eye is like the ear, the ear like the nose, the nose like the mouth—what is within me is thus alike. Seeing life as death, seeing oneself as fish, seeing swine as men, seeing men as swine—what is within things is thus alike. If this be so, then everywhere is the ultimate wandering, and nowhere is not a wondrous place; every thing is true joy, and nowhere is not the harmony of Heaven. Why alone the joy of the minnows at Hao Bridge?

I know that Zhuangzi and the fish were never divided. Only those who understand that supreme joy is no-joy, true knowing is no-knowing, may speak of this.

**General Observations on the Chapter**

This chapter, titled "Autumn Floods," employs the dialogue between the River Lord and the Ocean Spirit to illustrate the principles of the small and the great, the refined and the coarse, clarifying the view of the Dao, things, functions, and tendencies—all rooted in nature, without nobility or baseness, success or failure, gain or loss, but fitting to their time. Through repeated debate and refutation, it ultimately returns to the idea that one must not use the human to obliterate the Heavenly, nor use the artificial to obliterate fate, but seek sufficiency within the bounds of one’s nature—this is called returning to the true, which lies beyond the reach of words, thoughts, or discernment.

Next, it discusses how the centipede pities the snake, and the snake pities the wind, using this to illustrate how people, ashamed of their own talents and knowledge, fail to realize that the mechanisms of Heaven cannot be altered, and that what is small may overcome what is great. Truly understanding this principle, each thing is sufficient in its own nature—what is there to pity? With nothing to pity, there is nothing to envy; thus, the longing of aspiration ceases, and the intent to discriminate dissolves. This is the ultimate essence.

When Confucius traveled to Kuang and faced danger without fear, he knew that fate was determined by the Creator, not by the people of Kuang. If one were to be obstructed or humiliated by adversity, how could the courage of the sage be seen? The well-frog and the sea turtle exemplify the earlier principle of the River Lord and the Ocean Spirit, returning to the understanding of principle and the exercise of adaptability, where no thing can cause harm. Yet the world, sunk in turbidity and narrow in vision, even when aware of sages and worthies before them, still clings to aspiration, like disciples imitating their masters’ steps, only to lose their own footing—seeking what is long with what is short, pursuing what is beyond one’s nature. Such efforts are not only futile but harmful.

The discussion of the divine turtle, which would rather drag its tail in the mud, and the phoenix chick, which has no attachment to rotten mice, laments the shallowness of the age and the obstruction of the Dao. The chapter concludes with Zhuangzi and Huizi’s debate at Hao Bridge, asserting that the natures of things and self are fundamentally the same, merely separated by form and thus unable to know one another. When united in nature, their joy is the same here as there—what one finds peaceful, the joy of the fish is no wonder. Yet those who exhaust themselves in debate while forgetting the root of nature and fate—this is truly strange.

These words are not only a remedy for Huizi’s deep-seated delusion but also a warning to the world: those who cling to a single master’s teachings and take pleasure in their own entanglement are no different from the River Lord, who boasted of his abundance of water. Thus, the chapter’s intent is brought to a close.

From the *Zi Bu* (Masters Section), *Daoist Category*, *Zhuangzi Yi*:
*Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*, *Zhuangzi Yi*, Scroll Five
Compiled by Jiao Hong of the Ming Dynasty

**Chapter Eighteen: "Ultimate Joy"**

Is there in the world an ultimate joy, or is there not? Is there a way to preserve life, or is there not? What should one do? What should one rely upon? What should one avoid? Where should one dwell? What should one pursue? What should one abandon? What should one delight in? What should one detest?

What the world honors are wealth, nobility, longevity, and virtue. What it delights in are bodily ease, rich flavors, fine garments, beautiful sights, and harmonious sounds. What it despises are poverty, lowliness, early death, and vice. What it suffers are the inability to rest at ease, to savor rich flavors, to wear fine garments, to behold beauty, or to hear harmonious sounds. Those who cannot attain these things are deeply troubled and fearful for their bodies—how foolish!

The wealthy exhaust themselves with toil, amassing wealth they cannot fully use—how alienated they are from their own bodies! The noble lie awake at night, fretting over right and wrong—how estranged they are from their own bodies! Human life is born with sorrow. The long-lived grow dull and weary, their prolonged sorrow never ending—what suffering! How distant they are from their own bodies!

The steadfast knight is praised by the world for his goodness—yet this is not enough to preserve his own life. I do not know whether goodness is truly good or truly not good. If it is deemed good yet insufficient to preserve life, or deemed not good yet sufficient to preserve others, then we may say: when loyal remonstrance goes unheeded, one should withdraw and not contend. Thus, when Wu Zixu contended and was destroyed in body, even his name did not endure—was there truly goodness in this, or was there none?

As for what the common world pursues and delights in, I do not know whether such delight is truly delight or truly not delight. I observe that those who rush together in pursuit of worldly pleasures do so with such urgency, as if they cannot help themselves, all claiming it is delight—yet I do not find it delightful, nor do I find it not delightful. Is there truly delight in this, or is there none?

I hold that non-action is true delight—yet it is precisely what the world deems most bitter. Thus it is said: the utmost delight is without delight; the utmost praise is without praise. The right and wrong of the world cannot truly be settled. Nevertheless, non-action can settle right and wrong. The utmost delight preserves life—only non-action comes close to this. Let me attempt to speak of it:

Heaven is non-active and thereby clear;
Earth is non-active and thereby tranquil.
When the two non-actions unite,
the ten thousand things are transformed.
Vast and obscure,
elusive and intangible—
from whence do they arise?

Vast and obscure, elusive and intangible—yet is there truly form in this? The ten thousand things, each in its own thriving, all grow from non-action. Thus it is said: Heaven and Earth are non-active, yet nothing remains undone. As for man—who can attain non-action?

[Annotations from commentators:
* "Crouching and following" (蹲循) suggests compliance without resistance; "roaming and hastening" (逡巡) describes the rush toward death. "Thronging" (誙誙) depicts the crowd’s frenzy; "each in its own thriving" (职职) means each thing has its proper place, while "flourishing" (繁植) describes their proliferation.]

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
Only when joy is forgotten does delight become sufficient; only when delight is sufficient does life endure. Shall we call this "having delight"? Yet the utmost delight is without joy. Shall we call it "having no delight"? Yet life is preserved, and care is absent. To cling to avoidance or pursuit, delight or aversion—none of these eight suffice to preserve life. Only by making no choices and yielding to what one encounters can wholeness be attained.

All flavors, sights, sounds, and pleasures—losing them harms not the form, while gaining them damages the nature. Yet people grieve over their absence, thus revealing their folly. To guard one’s form, know contentment; to cherish one’s form, find self-sufficiency within. Only by relinquishing life can one forget care; only by forgetting care can life become delightful. When life is delightful, the form is mine to possess, wealth is mine to claim, honor is mine to enjoy.

The resolute man sees goodness—yet it is not enough to preserve life, for goodness may exceed what is fitting and thus fail to aid others. "Crouching and following" means not contending; only the virtue of the Mean is fitting. Whether in goodness or its absence, one should follow the central course as one’s guiding principle.

The thronging masses hasten toward what they deem delightful, even unto death. That I neither delight in it nor fail to delight—this is to be free of attachment and let things take their course. The delight of non-action is simply freedom from care. The world takes clamor and splendor as delight, beauty and goodness as praise—yet the right and wrong of the world cannot truly be settled. If I practice non-action and leave the world’s right and wrong to itself, then right and wrong will settle themselves.

The utmost delight preserves life—only non-action comes close to this. When the people are content, my life nears preservation. Heaven and Earth are naturally clear and tranquil; they do not act, yet all things harmonize of themselves. Thus the ten thousand things are transformed, as if by design. Yet if one acts, there will be times of stagnation. That from which things arise—they arise of themselves, not through any act of creation. That which has no form is the form of non-action. That which grows from non-action grows of itself.

When man attains non-action, delight arises without delight.

Guan Jian’s reflections:
Man dwells in an illusory realm where delight is hard to attain and life hard to preserve. Thus this chapter begins by lamenting that the utmost delight and preservation of life cannot be assured. Yet if one abides in one’s natural lot, making no claims of avoidance or pursuit, then what delight or aversion remains?

What the world delights in—wealth, honor, longevity, goodness, rich flavors, sights, and sounds—yet beauty and goodness cannot always be had. What lies below, what brings suffering—poverty, lowliness, early death, evil, unfulfilled desires. If one wanders in the realm of things’ origins, one may yet forget them—how could external burdens reach one?

Yet observe the rich, who exhaust their bodies with illness; the noble, who weary their minds with cares; the long-lived, who endure prolonged sorrow over not dying—all have estranged their forms and drifted far from the Way. Even the resolute man’s path fails to preserve life. Thus, in loyal remonstrance, do not contend; gently guide and enlighten, that the ruler may avoid errors and the minister fulfill his duty—this is the flourishing of ruler and minister.

As for Wu Zixu, who contended and perished, yet thereby won fame—was this truly good, or was it not? Observe the world’s so-called delights: are they truly delightful, or not? I hold that non-action is true delight, yet the world deems it bitter—thus its inclinations are clear. Only by knowing that the utmost delight is without delight can one see that the world’s delights are not true delight. Only by knowing that the utmost praise is without praise can one see that the resolute man’s striving is not true fame. Then one may rest in non-action and thereby settle the right and wrong of the world.

Thus, those who seek the utmost delight and preservation of life come closest through non-action. Heaven and Earth are non-active and thereby clear and tranquil, so the ten thousand things are transformed. If man can practice non-action, how could things fail to be transformed?

---

When Zhuangzi’s wife died, Huizi came to offer condolences. Zhuangzi was squatting, drumming on a basin and singing. Huizi said, "You lived with her, raised children together, and grew old—yet not weeping at her death would be enough. To drum on a basin and sing—is this not excessive?"

Zhuangzi replied, "Not so. When she first died, how could I not have felt grief? Yet I examined her beginning and found that originally there was no life. Not only was there no life—originally there was no form. Not only was there no form—originally there was no qi. Amidst the vast and obscure, a transformation occurred, and there was qi; the qi transformed, and there was form; the form transformed, and there was life. Now there is another transformation, and she has died. This is like the passing of spring and autumn, winter and summer, the turning of the four seasons. She now lies peacefully in the great chamber, and I follow wailing loudly—would this not show a failure to understand fate? Thus I stopped."

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
Before enlightenment, there is grief; after enlightenment, it ceases. This is how one instructs those with attachments, urging them to extend this principle to cast off burdens.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary:
What Zhuangzi valued aligns with Confucius and Mengsun Cai, yet his conduct resembles that of Zisang Bo, Zifan, and Zi Qinzhang. Why? The corruption of the human Way lies in the world’s submersion in the perversity of sorrow and joy, which extinguishes Heaven’s principle. Thus the remedy lies in such conduct.

---

Zhili Shu and Gu Jieshu were observing the mound of Mingbo, the wasteland of Kunlun, where the Yellow Emperor once rested. Suddenly, a willow sprouted from Gu Jieshu’s left elbow, startling him. Zhili Shu asked, "Do you dislike it?"

Gu Jieshu replied, "No—why should I dislike it? Life is a temporary borrowing; the borrower is but dust and grime. Death and life are like day and night. Moreover, you and I observed transformation, and transformation has reached me—why should I dislike it?"

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
This first shows attachment, then seeks the ultimate principle to cast it off. If one were to say, "I am originally without attachment, thus free from care," then those with attachments would remain trapped in the distant realm of remoteness, bewildered by the confines of sorrow and joy.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary:
Where the Yellow Emperor rested, the heart dies and the form withers, like soil unaware of the willow sprouting from the elbow. The willow is a thing of easy growth; Gu Jieshu’s initial reaction was unavoidable shock and dislike. Yet he ultimately understood that life is a temporary borrowing, mere dust and grime—why dislike it? The ancients’ way of observing transformation was like this.

Following the path of origin:
*Mingbo* is a posthumous title, akin to the *Mingmo Jun* mentioned in the *Wen Xuan*; *Mingbo’s Mound* is a tomb for the dead. This tomb lies in the wasteland of Kunlun, where the Yellow Emperor once rested. Moved by this, one realizes that unlike the Yellow Emperor, who ascended as an immortal, this person died. The *liu* refers to the willow wood used to screen the coffin—*sandalwood bows* were placed against the walls by the Zhou people, and the *liu* garments were draped over them. Zhili Shu and Gu Jieshu, observing among the ruins and graves, found their thoughts suddenly manifest: a coffin-screening willow sprouted from the left elbow—a dire omen, portending death. Thus, their minds were shaken, startled, and repulsed. After Zhili Shu expressed his aversion, he asked Gu Jieshu, "Do you find it repulsive?" Gu Jieshu replied, "I feel no aversion. Life is but a temporary borrowing—what is called the *four great elements* conjoined in假合. Since life is but a borrowed state, it is no more than dust and grime gathering. Why cling or struggle? Death and life are as constant as day and night—what is there to fear or dread? Transformation is death. Mencius even likened transformation to *not letting soil cling to the skin*—I say, you and I came to the graveyard to observe others’ deaths, and now we witness this inauspicious sign. Death will come to me as surely as it comes to all. Why should I dislike it?" Some interpret *liu* as the willow tree, but this seems inconsistent with the text’s meaning.

When Zhuangzi traveled to Chu, he saw an empty skull, its form stark and desiccated. He struck it with his horse whip and questioned it: "Did you, sir, covet life and lose the Dao, bringing this upon yourself? Or did you meet your end through the fall of a state, executed by axe and halberd? Or did you commit some unworthy deed, shamed before your parents, wife, and children, and so came to this?"

"Or did you suffer from cold and hunger, bringing you to this end? Or did your years naturally reach their term?" With these words, Zhuangzi finished speaking, then took the skull as a pillow and lay down to sleep. At midnight, the skull appeared to him in a dream and said, "Your words resemble those of a sophist. All that you have mentioned are the burdens of the living. In death, none of these remain.
