Would you like to hear the truth of death?"

Zhuangzi replied, "Indeed, I would."

The skull said, "In death, there is no lord above nor minister below, nor the affairs of the four seasons. One roams freely, taking heaven and earth as spring and autumn. Even the joy of a king facing south cannot surpass this."

Zhuangzi, unconvinced, said, "If I were to have the Controller of Fate restore your form—returning your bones, flesh, and skin, and bringing back your parents, wife, children, neighbors, and acquaintances—would you desire this?"

The skull furrowed its brow deeply and replied, "How could I abandon the joy of a king facing south to return to the toils of the human world?"

---

Guo Xiang’s commentary: The old saying that Zhuangzi delighted in death and despised life is mistaken. If this were so, what would it mean to equalize life and death? The meaning of equalization is to be at peace in life and at peace in death. Once the emotions of life and death are equalized, there is no need to grieve over death while living. This is Zhuangzi’s intent.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: To trace the origin and grasp the end is to understand the discourse on life and death, for they are but one body. Those who covet life and fear death are certainly mistaken, but those who delight in death and despise life—how can they be said to treat life and death as one? Zhuangzi spoke thus because the world’s greatest affliction lies in coveting life and fearing death. In this light, how could the joy of a king facing south be spoken of without purpose?

Bi Xu’s commentary: Those who cherish life find joy in worldly affairs, while those who embrace death see the human world as toil. Only those who transcend life and death can discuss its great outline.

New Transmission: Life is but the temporary gathering of a single *qi*, and death its temporary dispersal. Life is not necessarily without action, nor is death necessarily with action. The incompleteness of supreme joy lies in what is not necessarily without action, while its completeness lies in what is not necessarily with action. This is why Zhuangzi spoke of the skull’s unwillingness to abandon the joy of a king facing south. The six bodily forms are but lodgings for the self. In life, they temporarily gather with *qi*; in death, they temporarily disperse with *qi*. Gathering and dispersal are not inherently mine—how then can I claim ownership of the self? To claim ownership of the self is to fail to forget form. Failing to forget form leads to action, and action that clashes with things like blades prevents the supreme joy from being inwardly complete. This aligns with the skull’s reluctance to return to the human world.

---

When Yan Yuan traveled east to Qi, Confucius wore a worried expression. Zigong stepped down from his mat and asked, "May this student dare to ask why, when Yan Yuan travels to Qi, the Master wears a worried expression?"

Confucius replied, "Excellent question. Formerly, Guanzi spoke words I greatly admired: *'A small sack cannot hold a large thing; a short rope cannot draw from a deep well.'* Such is the way of fate—it has its completion, and form has its fitting place. It cannot be diminished or augmented. I fear that Yan Yuan will speak to the Marquis of Qi of the Dao of Yao, Shun, the Yellow Emperor, and further expound the words of Suiren and Shennong. He will seek within himself and find nothing, and finding nothing, he will confuse others. Confusion leads to death. Have you alone not heard the tale? Formerly, a seabird alighted in the outskirts of Lu. The Marquis of Lu welcomed it with an escort, offered it wine in the ancestral temple, played the *Nine Shao* as music, and prepared a grand feast of sacrificial oxen. The bird, however, looked on with sorrow and dread, refusing to eat a single morsel or drink a single cup. After three days, it died. This was nourishing the bird with what nourishes oneself, not with what nourishes the bird. To nourish the bird with what nourishes the bird, one should let it roost in deep forests, roam open plains, float on rivers and lakes, feed on fish and frogs, follow its flock in flight, and rest at ease. It abhors human speech—why subject it to such clamor? When the music of *Xianchi* and *Nine Shao* was performed in the wilds of Dongting, birds heard it and flew away, beasts heard it and fled, fish heard it and dove deep, while people, hearing it suddenly, gathered to watch. Fish live in water and thrive, but humans drown in it—they must have different likes and dislikes, hence their differences. Thus, the sages of old did not unify abilities or standardize affairs. Names were confined to reality, and meanings were set to fit. This is called *tiaoda* (orderly flow) and *fuchi* (fortune sustained)."

---

Guo Xiang’s commentary: It cannot be diminished or augmented, so one should simply follow it. Seeking within and finding nothing leads to seeking without. Abandoning the inner for the outer—is this not confusion? *"Did not unify abilities or standardize affairs"* means each follows their nature. *"Names confined to reality"* and *"meanings set to fit"* ensure orderly flow, while *"fortune sustained"* means the constant of nature is preserved.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: The tale of the seabird is meant to urge scholars to reflect deeply and act cautiously. The differences between a city wall’s moat and a cave’s hole, the skills of a thousand-mile net and a hunting trap, the natures of night-bright and day-dark—these are why the sages did not unify abilities or standardize affairs. *"Names confined to reality"* avoids excessive names; *"meanings set to fit"* avoids excessive application. *"Orderly flow"* means following the length of each branch without seeking uniformity, for seeking uniformity leads to disorder. *"Fortune sustained"* means adhering to one’s allotted share without overreaching, for overreaching leads to loss.

Bi Xu’s commentary: Fate received naturally cannot be forced—like a small bag, how can it contain a large thing? One’s endowment and allotted share cannot be altered—like a short rope, how can it draw from a deep well? The seabird’s alarm at the *Nine Shao* is like the Marquis of Qi’s alarm at the august Dao. People vary in worthiness, so none can unify affairs; times differ between ancient and modern, so none can standardize them. If names and realities do not exceed their bounds, there is order without blockage; if principles and applications fit, misfortune departs without peril.

---

Liezi was eating by the roadside when he saw a hundred-year-old skull. He plucked some mugwort, pointed at it, and said, "Only you and I know that you have never died, never been born. Do you truly find nourishment in this?"

"Do you truly delight in this? The seed has its potential: when it obtains water, it becomes *fang*; when it obtains the border of water and earth, it becomes a frog; when the *pin*’s husk grows on a mound, it becomes *lingxi*; *lingxi* obtaining dense shade becomes *wuzu*; the root of *wuzu* becomes a grub, its leaves become butterflies. The butterflies in time transform into insects, born beneath the stove, their form like a cast-off shell, their name *quduo*. After a thousand days, *quduo* becomes a bird called *ganyu*; the saliva of *ganyu* becomes *simi*; *simi* becomes *shixi*; *yilu* is born from *shixi*. *Huangkuang* is born from *yilu*; *maomao* and *rui* are born from *jiuyou*; *fuquan* is born from decayed matter; *yangxi* compared to unopened bamboo gives birth to *qingning*; *qingning* gives birth to *chengcheng*; *chengcheng* gives birth to horses; horses give birth to humans; humans in turn return to the mechanism. All things emerge from the mechanism, all things enter into the mechanism."

[Guo’s annotation: "Never having died, never having been born—each delights in what it encounters. Is there truly nourishment? Is there truly delight? The reality of nourishment and delight has no fixed abode. 'The seed has its potential' speaks of transformations whose number cannot be exhausted. From 'when it obtains water, it becomes *fang*' to 'all things enter into the mechanism'—this speaks of one qi and myriad forms, of transformation without death or birth."]

[Lü’s annotation: "The wandering soul transforms without ceasing, going everywhere—what does a hundred-year-old skull know? When the heart is hollowed to the point of no-knowledge, then one knows it has never been born, never died, and is equal to it. Do you truly find nourishment and fear death? Do I truly delight and rejoice in life? Only by knowing the wandering soul goes everywhere and that essence and qi are things—does their seed truly have potential? Thus *fang* and the *pin*’s husk, *lingxi*, are one kind: some obtain the border of water and earth, some obtain mounds, and their lives differ. *Wuzu*, grubs, butterflies, and mounds are also one kind: some obtain dense shade, some roots, some leaves, and their transformations differ. *Quduo*, *ganyu*, *simi*, *shixi*, and *xu* are also one kind: some are born beneath the stove, some after long days, some from saliva, and their lives differ. *Huangkuang* compared to *jiuyou*, *maomao* and *rui* compared to *fuquan*, *yangxi* compared to unopened bamboo—one does not know the origin of their seed. *Qingning*, *chengcheng*."]

One kind they are—yet horses and humans are born of themselves. Thus, some things are born of the emotionless, some of the emotional; some emotionless things give rise to the emotional, some emotional things to the emotionless—all the work of the wandering soul and essence-qi. All that Master Lie spoke of, he had heard and seen and thus knew; but what he had never heard or seen—could one exhaust its telling?

**Bi Xu** notes:
I have never died—does life truly bring joy? You have never lived—does death truly bring nurturance? This seeks to fathom the principle of neither death nor birth. Once, Master Lie encountered a frog by the roadside and, pointing to it, discoursed on the mechanism of transformation: when frogs sense the qi of fire, they become quails; when they obtain water, they mate and breed. The *Shuowen* says: *fan* (蟠) reversed becomes *yi* (螠), which clings to water’s edge, where moss grows like clothing—this is the origin of tadpoles. *Yi* (螠) left on hills and mounds transforms into a plant called *lingxi* (陵舄), known medicinally as *cheqian* grass. Here, the emotional enters the emotionless, as when earthworms become lilies. *Yuqi* (郁栖) is dung and soil. The *wuzu* grass grows by water and is commonly called "ink grass" or "crow’s beard," used in prescriptions—one plant with roots and leaves differing due to the yin and yang of qi. Some things arise through mutual dependence, defying broad generalization. Butterflies, drawn to *yuqi*, transform into *quduo* (鸲掇): at first, their forms are pure, as if newly shed; after a thousand days, they can fly. Their foam becomes the *simi* (斯弥) insect. This speaks of endless mutual transformation between small and great. *Simi* feeding on vinegar and below clarifies how emotional beings change upon contact. *Maorui* (瞀芮) are fireflies born from rotting grass and decaying *fuquan* (腐蠸). Here, the emotionless becomes emotional, as when moldy wheat turns into butterflies. *Fuquan* gives rise to *yangxi* (羊奚), which is *yangti* vegetable—emotional returning to the emotionless. *Yangxi* and old, unopened bamboo combine, two emotionless things uniting to produce *qingning* (青宁), a creature resembling a hedgehog. Common folk say: "Where bamboo thickets decay, hedgehogs abound." The *Shizi* says: "The people of Yue call leopards *cheng* (程)." Some say *cheng* refers to tapirs. The *Soushen Ji* records that during Duke Xiao of Qin’s reign, a horse gave birth to a human—likely the five phases and six qi interacting with things to produce inexplicable changes.

**Jiang Yu** notes:
A skull, after a hundred years, may have its wandering soul transform again into a human, who then lives another hundred years before dying. If it transforms into other things, its deaths and rebirths would be incalculable. Yet the empty skull remains, its form still discernible. Master Lie alone grasped the wonder of his own body, while the skull had undergone a hundred years of change. Thus, Master Lie pointed to it and said: "Only you and I know that we have never died, never been born." Here, Master Lie, drawing on what he had seen and known of their origins, posed a question to the skull to illustrate the transformations of the myriad things. Some things are born through emotion, some through imagination; those born of moisture arise through union and response, while those formed by transformation arise through separation and correspondence. Emotion, imagination, union, and separation intermingle, shifting between great and small—all emerging and entering through the *mechanism*, yet equally containing the supreme principle, without distinction. What, then, is this *mechanism*? How do the myriad things emerge and enter through it? The *Suwen* says: "When emergence and entry cease, the spiritual mechanism of transformation perishes." For the success and failure of the myriad things depend on movement. Movement without end gives rise to change and transformation. Thus, without emergence and entry, there would be no birth, growth, maturity, or aging. Yet though emergence and entry differ, their mechanism is one; though their mechanism is subtle, it is revealed through emergence and entry. The mechanism operates through emergence and entry, yet one cannot say emergence and entry *are* the mechanism, nor can one seek the mechanism apart from emergence and entry. With each emergence and entry, the spiritual mechanism moves. The *Yinfu Jing* says: "Heaven’s nature is human; the human heart is the mechanism." This speaks of the myriad things emerging from and entering into the mechanism—yet why single out humans, if not because humans are the most spiritually endowed of the myriad things, and thus exemplify them all?

**Fu Mo** notes:
Beneath the brambles lay a skull. Master Lie lifted the brambles and pointed to it, saying: "Only you and I know that we have never died." Examining its origin, we see it has never been born. If it has never been born, it should not expect nurturance; if it has never died, why fear annihilation or seek joy? Such delight in life and death is but delusion. You and I alike dwell in the great forge of creation—whether as *fang* (防) or liver worms, arms or legs—we are but what we transform into.

Surveying the varieties of transformation, consider those arising from moisture: earth’s dust, blown by the breath of the *xi* (息), floats upon water, each speck trailing another like silk threads—this is called *fang* (防). It is the precursor of water moss, which first appears where water and earth meet. When water receives the qi of earth, it congeals into substance, called the "clothing of frogs and clams"—that is, *shuixi* (水舄). Growing in water, it is *shuixi*, as in the *Book of Songs*: "We gather the *xu* (藚)." Frogs and clams cling beneath it as their clothing. When it grows on mounds, it becomes *lingxi* (陵舄), the *fu yi* (芣苡) of the *Book of Songs*—one thing with water and land variants. *Lingxi* obtaining *yuqi* (郁栖) transforms into *wuzu* (乌足); *yuqi* is dung and soil. *Wuzu* is also a plant name: its roots become *qicao* (蛴螬) grubs, its leaves butterflies—*xu* (胥) insects. Butterflies and *yi* (螠) further transform into other insects. Generally, when plants become insects, their forms are soft and wriggling. Those born in fields or beneath wild stoves, receiving the qi of fire, transform into insects without skin or shell, resembling newly shed skins—these are *quduo* (鸲掇). *Quduo* burrow into earth for a thousand days, then transform into birds called *ganyu* (干余). The foam of *ganyu* becomes *simi* (斯弥); *simi* becomes *shike* (食榼), the vinegar gnat. Fond of sourness, they gather around vinegar—hence "vinegar-eaters." *Shike* give rise to *yilu* (颐辂); *yilu* to *jiuyou* (九猷); *jiuyou* to *huangkuang* (黄軦); *huangkuang* to *fuquan* (腐蠸); *fuquan* to *maorui* (瞀芮)—each generating the next, all insects. *Yangxi* (羊奚) compared to old, unopened bamboo forms one phrase: *yangxi* is a plant whose roots resemble turnips, and when its roots connect with bamboo that has long ceased to sprout, they produce *qingning* (青宁), a bamboo-root insect. Tracing its origin, an old man once saw a five-inch-long insect, with an inch or so remaining—was this not the so-called *qingning*, the bamboo root yet to transform? *Cheng* (程) is an alternate name for leopards. The *Mengxi Bitan* notes that the people of Yanzhou still call tigers and leopards *cheng*.

The *qingning* gives rise to the *cheng*; the *cheng* gives rise to the horse; the horse gives rise to man—such matters exist in the world. As the histories record, the Wu Ling Man of Changsha were born from beasts, their primal ancestor conceived from the wombs of wolves and deer. One cannot restrict such transformations by the limits of ear and eye.

Where *qi* stirs, there is *ji* (mechanism); what emerges from *ji* is life, what enters into *ji* is death. Between heaven and earth, there is only the ceaseless circulation of the two *qi*—yin and yang. Nurturing them, delighting in them—why trouble the heart? Simply follow their natural transformations.

**A Humble Overview**

This chapter, titled "Utmost Joy," begins by discussing the burdens of existence, the manifold sorrows that compel one to flee or stay, yet leave one at a loss for how to preserve life. What is the reason? I contend that when, amid suffering, the heart generates revulsion and fiercely longs for return, joy will soon arrive. Thus, what the vulgar call "joy" may not truly be joy at all.

For all things under heaven, prosperity contains decline, and extremity must transform. The solitary minister and the grieving son—vigilant in heart, anxious in thought—attain insight precisely through this. Thus, one knows that poverty, lowliness, and sorrow forge the jade girl’s success, for the mechanisms of fortune and misfortune always lie in mutual concealment. The world is mired in the realm of sorrow and joy, unable to escape. How can one find peace in the nature of life and destiny?

Therefore, in the end, the absence of joy and praise is the highest praise and utmost joy. Later, the chapter records the song of the drum and basin and the skull’s reply, both taking what others find joyless as their own joy. How could such joy be shared with the vulgar?

In the middle, it describes observing transformations, where those touched by change undergo elbow mutations without aversion, while those who seek themselves in vain hear music and are startled by sorrow. This teaches that following transformation makes all joys equal, while resisting one’s nature—even in nurturance—is not true joy.

Finally, it discusses the inconstancy of human, plant, insect, and beast transformations, concluding: all emerge from *ji*, all return to *ji*. How vast is *ji*! Who can relax or tighten it? All that pertains to form and vessel arises from this. Birth and death, transformation and circulation—endless. Whether one delights in life and abhors death, or rejoices in death and wearies of life, one is trapped in partiality and not the essence of joy.

Only when there is no joy and no non-joy, no life and no non-life, does one cease to be enslaved by transformation or driven by *ji*. Attaining the wondrous emptiness of the Great Expansion—unified, uncontrived—vanishing into boundlessness, profound and abiding: this is the utmost joy.

**Chapter Nineteen: Attaining Life**

One who attains the nature of life does not pursue what life cannot provide. One who attains the nature of destiny does not pursue what knowledge cannot address. Why? To nurture the body, one must first rely on things. Yet there are cases where things are abundant, yet the body is not nurtured. To have life, one must first avoid separation from form. Yet there are cases where form is not separated, yet life perishes.

Life’s arrival cannot be refused; its departure cannot be halted. Alas! The people of the world believe that nurturing the body suffices to preserve life, yet nurturing the body does not suffice to preserve life. Then what in the world is worth pursuing? Though it may not suffice, one cannot avoid pursuing it—such pursuit is inescapable.

To escape the pursuit of form, nothing surpasses abandoning the world. Abandoning the world eliminates burdens; without burdens, one is upright and balanced. Upright and balanced, one exchanges life with the other; exchanging life, one approaches the subtle. What need is there to abandon affairs or forsake life? Abandoning affairs spares the body from labor; forsaking life preserves the essence from depletion.

When the body is whole and essence restored, one becomes one with heaven. Heaven and earth are the parents of the myriad things: united, they form bodies; scattered, they begin anew. When form and essence are not depleted, this is called "shifting essence," and essence returns to harmonize with heaven.

*Guo’s Annotation*: What life cannot provide are external things. What knowledge cannot address lies beyond destiny. Knowing when to stop within one’s allotment, matching one’s life with things—this is sufficient.

Excess brings harm. Clinging too rigidly to form leads to the loss of life; knowing what lies beyond one’s control, one acts without attachment, yet anxiety lingers within—thus, the more one nurtures, the more one loses. The more lavishly one tends, the swifter death approaches. Better to release and follow one’s nature. What each being is allotted arises from the utmost principle, and thus cannot be avoided.

Therefore, those skilled in nurturing life follow and yield to it. What is called "exchanging life" is daily renewal. Entrusting oneself to daily renewal, one’s nature and destiny are fully realized. Abandoning affairs spares the body from labor; forsaking life preserves the essence from depletion. Thus, in this forsaking and abandoning, form remains whole and essence restored, becoming one with heaven—both without contrivance.

Heaven and earth, parents of the myriad things, are impartial in their nurturing and thus give birth to all things. United, they form bodies; scattered, they begin anew. Wherever they are, all is impermanent. Those who can shift essence move in harmony with transformation; returning to assist heaven is to restore and aid its spontaneity.

*Lü’s Annotation*:
What life cannot provide is not what sustains it. What knowledge cannot address is what lies beyond knowing. Generally, those who do not nurture form do so because their pursuit of life is excessive, not because external things are insufficient. Those who lose life do so because they drive themselves toward death, not because form has departed from life. From this, we know that nurturing form is ultimately insufficient to preserve life—yet how can one abandon the world? One cannot escape the need to sustain form. To escape sustaining form, one must engage with the world without entanglement. Without entanglement, one is upright and balanced; upright and balanced, one ceases to regard form and affairs as burdens and exchanges life with the other. What is called "exchanging life" is to attain subtlety. Affairs are not worth abandoning; life is not worth forsaking. Not abandoning affairs burdens one with labor; not forsaking life depletes one’s essence. When form is whole and essence restored, virtue returns to its origin.

The myriad things receive essence from heaven and form from earth. Their union is how we come to have bodies—when heaven and earth intermingle, the myriad things transform in harmony. Their scattering is how things begin anew—when male and female unite, the myriad things are born. United, essence is not depleted; scattered, it can shift. Not depleting preserves essence; shifting returns it to its source within heaven. Thus, what is called preserving life—is it not wondrous?

*Liu’s Summary*:
Life is what I possess; destiny is ordained by heaven. Those who fully comprehend life understand heaven; those who fully comprehend destiny never forget humanity. What life cannot provide, one lets go—thus, whatever can be let go of, one does not pursue. What knowledge cannot address, one accepts—thus, whatever can be accepted, one seeks nothing beyond. Without seeking, without contrivance, one merges with the Dao.

Yet in the world, the burdens of form, worldly affairs, and external things are ever entwined and inseparable. Form is not the Dao; the world is not the self—entanglement lies in external things. Examining these three through principle, their burdens are easily shed. If burdens can be cast off, what does the world mean to me? If the world can be abandoned, what do I envy in form? Without attachment to the world, without envy of form, one attains the utmost in comprehending life and destiny.

*Xun’s Paraphrase*:
"Returning to assist heaven" rhymes with "shifting" (汀移). "Shifting" echoes the earlier "exchanging" (更), meaning one can renew and shift with it. Life originally possesses this essence, but toiling in worldly affairs nearly loses it. Now, by exchanging life, one regains this essence. What grants me this life is heaven; if I can preserve this life with heaven, this is "assisting heaven."

*Liezi asked Guanyin*:
The perfected person moves unseen without obstruction, walks through fire without heat, traverses the realm of the myriad things without fear. May I ask how one attains this?

*Guanyin replied*:
This is the preservation of pure qi. It does not belong to the ranks of knowledge, skill, or boldness. Let me tell you: all that has appearance, form, sound, or color is merely "thing." How can things be distant from one another? How can one attain what lies beyond?

Before form, there is only color—this is the origin of things. Without form, it comes to rest. Without transformation, it cannot be exhausted. Those who grasp this exhaustively are still bound to things. Those who attain and rest in it—where will they dwell?

To abide by the unexcessive measure and conceal oneself within the boundless principle, to wander amidst the beginning and end of the myriad things—unifying their nature, nurturing their qi, harmonizing their virtue to commune with the origin of things. Those who attain this preserve heaven in its entirety, their spirit whole without fissure—how could things find entry?

Consider the drunkard who falls from a carriage: though the fall be swift, he does not die. His bones and joints are the same as others’, yet the harm he suffers differs—his spirit remains whole. He knows not the riding, nor the falling; life and death, terror and dread do not enter his breast. Thus, he is awakened to things yet unbroken by them. If one preserved by wine may yet be thus, how much more so one preserved by heaven? The sage conceals himself in heaven, and thus nothing can harm him.

The avenger does not break the sword Mo Gan, though it be wielded by one with vengeful intent; the flying shard of tile elicits no resentment. Thus, the world attains equilibrium—hence no wars of conquest, no punishments of slaughter—all arises from this Dao.

Not to open the heaven within man but to open the heaven of heaven: opening heaven gives rise to virtue; opening man gives rise to harm. To be unwearied in one’s heaven, not neglectful of the people—this is to approach the genuine.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
His mind is empty, thus he can master the fullness of things; attaining perfect accord, nothing is impossible. It is not that things come to him—how can things be distant from one another? Only the mindless alone transcend. All are beings of form and color, yet none surpass him; ever wandering at the utmost limit, he is not constrained by things. Abiding by the unexcessive measure, he rests within his allotted portion. Concealed within the boundless principle, he darkly harmonizes with transformation, ever renewed. Wandering amidst the beginning and end of the myriad things—this is the utmost of things. To unify their nature is to adorn it; to nurture their qi is to deplete it if directed by the mind. To harmonize their virtue is to sunder it with things. All things arise of themselves.

Like the drunkard who falls from the carriage, he loses what he knows—not through nature, but through absence of mind. The sage conceals himself in heaven, thus does not peer beyond the bounds of his nature. Hence it is said: "Concealed." Gan Jiang and Mo Ye may be wielded against a foe, yet the avenger does not seek to break them—this is because he is without mind. A flying shard of tile may strike a man, yet none resent it—this is because it is without intent. Thus, the world attains equilibrium; all inequity arises from intent. The Dao of no-intent is vast.

Without thought, one knows—this is opening heaven. With thought, one responds—this is opening man. Opening heaven is the movement of nature; opening man is the function of knowledge. When nature moves and encounters things fittingly, one forgets all else—thus virtue arises. When knowledge functions, one follows stimuli, striving without cease—thus harm arises. To act by the nature of heaven is to preserve human principle; the afflictions of the people, the rise of artifice, ever lie in the function of knowledge, not in the movement of nature.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
The revolutions of heaven and earth, the transformations of the myriad things—what are they if not qi? Truly, if one preserves pure qi, there is no obstruction, no heat, no peril—nothing strange in this. It is simply the attainment of utmost emptiness—how could knowledge, skill, or boldness compare?

Consider the dragon: when its body coalesces, it ascends and coils without limit; when its form disperses, it enters the formless, unseen. This too is but qi. All that has appearance, form, sound, or color is merely "thing." How can things be distant from one another? How can one attain what lies beyond? Before all, there is only color—this is the origin of things. Before this, there was no thing; with color, things have come to be. How can one speak of preserving pure qi or wandering in utmost emptiness?

The origin of things is formless—without appearance, form, sound, or color—thus it comes to rest. Without transformation, it cannot be exhausted. Those who grasp this exhaustively are still bound to things. Those who attain and rest in it—where will they dwell? To abide by the unexcessive measure is to be neither bright nor dim, fittingly attuned without excess. Concealed within the boundless principle, beginning and end are reversed—this cannot be exhausted. Wandering amidst the beginning and end of the myriad things—this is the so-called origin, formless and at rest, without transformation.

To unify nature is not to divide it; to nurture qi is not to deplete it; to harmonize virtue is to commune with the origin of things. Thus, nature is cultivated, virtue returned, and one becomes one with the creator of things. Formless, one preserves wholeness without flaw—how could things find entry?

One preserved by wine does not let life and death, terror and dread enter his breast—how much more so one preserved by heaven? Thus, nothing can harm him. There is ever one who wields death; when men encounter it, it is like Gan Jiang or a flying shard—this is why the world attains equilibrium. Though states be conquered, there are no wars of conquest.

Opening heaven gives rise to virtue—this is to forget all, to be without knowledge or action. Opening man gives rise to harm—this is to have intent, to have eyes for things. To be unwearied in one’s heaven is to open it alone; not to neglect the people is to fear what they fear. If the people know this, they approach the genuine.

】 Jiang Yu 【

The perfected person does not depart from the genuine. When the genuine resides within, what among the myriad things could suffice to alter it? This is why one may enter water without getting wet, enter fire without being burned, or ascend heights without trembling. Guan Yin spoke of this as the guarding of pure qi—pure, that is, in the sense of never diminishing one’s spirit. Not diminishing one’s spirit is what it means to be genuine.

Those who are cunning, resolute, and intent on overcoming things harbor suspicion within and rely on surging qi without. Even a single limb or fragment of their body would not find room between heaven and earth—how then could water or fire come near? Only when pure qi is guarded within do knowledge and perception revolve back, sight and hearing withdraw inward, and none can discern whether it is water or fire, for one has become one body with them. This is why there is nowhere one may enter without finding ease.

Forms, images, sounds, and colors are all called "forms." All things, arising from nonbeing into being, must begin with movement and thus generate form. Before the Great Simplicity, form and substance first take shape; yet the Great Simplicity does not reach the Great Beginning—how then could it attain the Prior? Only one who treats things as things yet is not a thing may reach the Prior. This is what Laozi meant by "there is a thing, undifferentiated and complete." All that has form belongs to creation; when form ceases, transformation halts.

One who attains this Dao and exhausts it departs from form and transcends transformation, reaching the Prior where things dissolve and right and wrong vanish. Even standing alone in correctness is insufficient to name it. It is supremely easy to know, supremely easy to practice, and does not violate the natural patterns of the myriad things—this is no profound measure. One who meets it does not see its head, and following it does not see its tail—this is the thread without beginning. Moving through the myriad things, the myriad things receive it to wax and wane, fill and empty; its bounds cannot be exhausted. Roaming through the beginning and end of the myriad things, one unifies one’s nature and does not waver, nurtures one’s qi and does not deplete it, embraces one’s virtue and does not scatter it. Thus can one ascend and roam with the creator of things—this is to penetrate what things are created from. Penetrating what things are created from, one can become heaven. Becoming heaven is to become spirit. Guarding wholeness in heaven is for one’s spirit to be without flaw. When one’s spirit is without flaw, the guarding of pure qi is firm—how could things find entry?

Spirit gives birth to form, and form completes spirit. Without spirit, form cannot arise; without form, spirit cannot be perfected. Spirit desires not to diminish its wholeness, yet it may be diminished by having knowledge. Form desires not to harm its completeness, yet it is harmed by opposing things. Yet spirit gives birth to form—one who cherishes form does not necessarily guard spirit; one who contains spirit, however, cannot be opposed by things.

The drunkard, falling from a carriage, remains unaware—this is how spirit is preserved whole. When spirit is whole, life and death, terror and dread cannot move one’s center. Though one may fall from a carriage, it can only harm one’s form, not one’s spirit. This is what it means to encounter harm differently from others—thus, though injured, one does not die. Yet such wholeness is attained by wine-drinkers through drowning their knowledge in intoxication, not through knowing and forgetting emotion. As for one who is not drunk, knowledge remains clear and is not forgotten even for a moment. Thus, though one may not die, one may still be injured. But if one truly knows non-knowing, even water and fire cannot scorch or drown—how much less a fall from a carriage? This is the wholeness guarded by heaven, which nothing can harm. The sage conceals this—it is the Dao of long life and enduring vision.】

The *Comprehensive Meaning* states:
To originate is to be without form, without beginning;
To cease is to be without transformation, without end.
How could things ever reach an ultimate limit?
Yet those who speak of "transcending transformation and preserving spirit" mean that external things do not obstruct the substance of the Great Void.

Fangzi adds:
"Virtue gives life" refers to the heavenly virtue emerging in tranquility;
"Bandits give life" refers to the six bandits plundering one another—
Thus heaven may be constant,
But it cannot be offered;
Man may be cautious,
But he cannot be negligent.

Confucius, traveling to Chu, came upon a hunchbacked man in the forest catching cicadas with a sticky pole as easily as if picking them up. Confucius said, "You are skillful indeed! Is there a Dao to this?"
The man replied, "I have a Dao. After five or six months of piling pellets, if I can stack two without dropping them, I will lose only a few; if I can stack three without dropping them, I will lose only one in ten; if I can stack five without dropping them, it is as easy as picking them up. When I position my body, I stand as still as a tree stump; when I hold my arm, it is as steady as a branch of withered wood. Though the world is vast and things are many, I am aware of nothing but the cicada’s wings. I do not turn aside, nor do I waver, nor do I allow the myriad things to distract me from the cicada’s wings—how could I fail?"
Confucius turned to his disciples and said, "Where intention is undivided, it approaches the divine—does this not describe the hunchbacked elder?"

Cui Zhuan states, "橛株拘 refers to a stake preventing a tree." Originally, *疑于神* was written as *凝*; considering the context below, it should be *疑*. Here we follow Dongpo’s emendation.

Guo’s commentary: "Stacking two pellets without dropping them demonstrates the steadiness of the hand—thus, in catching cicadas, losses are but a trifle. Stacking three without dropping them, losses grow fewer still; stacking five without dropping them, steadiness reaches its perfection, and nothing is lost. Positioning the body like a stake, holding the arm like a branch of withered wood—this is the height of stillness. How could one fail? To say one forgets that in order to gain this is to speak of relinquishing one thing to attain another."

Lü’s commentary: "To grasp the Way of catching cicadas is to understand the preservation of pure qi—its undivided intention is precisely like this."

Jiang Yu: "Learning to catch cicadas by stacking pellets: pellets, as objects, can roll and turn, yet one can pile them without dropping them. From this, one may infer the stability of his stance, the precision of his arm, and the undividedness of his intention. With such skill, catching cicadas becomes as easy as picking them up. The cicada’s wings are light and swift, yet to seize them as if plucking them—this is to advance in the Dao. How could this belong to the realm of mere cleverness? Thus he says, 'I have a Dao.' When he positions his body like a stake and holds his arm like a branch of withered wood, he forgets himself within; when he does not allow the myriad things to distract him from the cicada’s wings, he forgets things without. With both self and things forgotten, how could he fail to catch cicadas? Thus Confucius sighs that his undivided intention approaches the divine. When intention is divided, spirit is depleted; when intention is unified, spirit is whole. This is what is meant by preserving pure qi—nothing more.

The cicada, though dwelling in lowly filth, aspires to lofty purity. It sings in season, seeks no sustenance, and makes no demands—thus it embodies the Way of form and dhyāna, which is why it is chosen as the object of pursuit."

---

Yan Yuan asked Confucius, "I once crossed the deep pool of Shang. The ferryman handled the boat as if by divine skill. I asked him, 'Can one learn to handle a boat?' He replied, 'One can. Those skilled in swimming can do so after a few attempts; as for divers, they have never seen a boat yet handle it with ease.' I questioned him further, but he would not explain. May I ask what this means?"

Confucius said, "Those skilled in swimming can do so after a few attempts because they forget the water. As for divers who have never seen a boat yet handle it with ease—they regard the depths as if they were hills, and a boat’s capsizing as if it were a cart rolling backward. Though countless dangers lie before them, none enter their minds. They are at ease no matter where they turn.

Those who wager with tiles play skillfully; those who wager with hooks grow cautious; those who wager with gold grow anxious. Their skill is the same, yet their concern for external things makes them clumsy within. All who are burdened by externals are inwardly inept."

Guo’s commentary: "Though things have their nature, they must be taught and practiced before they become second nature. One who regards the depths as hills thus sees a boat’s capsizing in the deep as a cart rolling backward on a slope. Though capsizings and reversals are many, he remains unperturbed, for his nature is at ease—whatever he encounters, he is composed. Observing those who wager: the more valuable the stake, the more their minds grow anxious. Those who wish to nurture life and preserve their inner being—should they not refrain from such burdens?"

Lü’s commentary: "From the ferryman’s handling of the boat and the wagering of gold, we see that one who preserves form and restores essence does not abandon the world or neglect life—only one whose spirit is without flaw can achieve this."

Jiang Yu: "Water bears the boat. To learn the ferryman’s skill in handling a boat yet fail to learn his essence is to fall short of his mastery. One practiced in water, adept at swimming, though untrained in boating, may yet match the ferryman’s skill. But one unaccustomed to water, trembling in fear, ever dreading drowning—how could he handle a boat? Thus, those who take water lightly can be taught; those who forget water can do so after a few attempts. As for divers, they have never seen a boat yet handle it with ease—this is because they have not only forgotten water but also forgotten the boat. Thus, they are at ease no matter where they turn.

Crossing water is like traversing peril; guiding the world is like steering a boat to ferry others to a place of no difficulty. Only one with the Dao can lightly forget worldly affairs, moving through myriad changes without ever being hindered. In governing the world, such a one is at ease.

The more valuable the stake, the more the mind grows anxious; the more anxious the mind, the more wit dulls and skill is lost. Skill lies within, while things lie without—once skill is mastered, why grow clumsy over external concerns? If one insists on valuing externals, even treating gold as mere tiles, one may remain skillful in all things, yet the stake will never leave oneself. But this cannot be forced—only one with the Dao achieves it naturally.

At first, one may be skillful; in the end, one may grow clumsy. Thus, skill may appear clumsy, for if one’s cleverness does not linger, one may not perceive the weight of the stake and may yet act skillfully in all matters. Is not the cleverness prized by the world in truth the greatest clumsiness? Hence it is said, 'Great skill appears clumsy.'"

---

Tian Kaizhi visited Duke Wei of Zhou. The Duke said, "I have heard that Zhu Shen studies the arts of longevity. You have associated with Zhu Shen—what have you learned from him?"

Tian Kaizhi replied, "Kaizhi merely sweeps the courtyard with a broom—what could I have learned from the Master?"

The Duke said, "Tianzi, do not be modest. I wish to hear it."

Kaizhi said, "I have heard the Master say, 'One who nurtures life well is like a shepherd: he watches those who lag behind and whips them.'"

The Duke asked, "What does this mean?"

Tian Kaizhi said, "In Lu there was a man named Shan Bao who lived in the mountains, drinking from streams, and did not compete with others for profit. At seventy, his complexion was still that of a child. Unfortunately, he encountered a hungry tiger, which killed and ate him. There was also a man named Zhang Yi who frequented the gates of the wealthy, running errands for all. At forty, he suffered from internal heat and died.

Bao nurtured his inner being, yet the tiger devoured his outer form; Yi nurtured his outer form, yet illness attacked his inner being. These two did not whip those who lagged behind."

Confucius said, "Do not retreat into hiding, nor stand exposed in the open—dwell in the center. If one attains the right measure in these three, one will reach the utmost. On perilous paths, if one in ten is killed, fathers and sons, brothers and kin will warn one another, and none will dare venture out without a large escort—is this not wisdom?"

The things people fear most lie in their bedding and at their meals, yet they fail to guard against them—this is their error.

Guo’s commentary: Those who study focus on the mean and adhere to one method, but when they exceed proper bounds, they fail to attain the balance of thorough caution. "Whipping those who lag behind" means correcting what falls short. "Hiding" is already inward, yet to further "enter" is excessive inwardness; "exposure" is already outward, yet to further "go out" is excessive outwardness. Like withered wood, one should be without intent and stand in the center. If these three attain their proper measure, one will reach the utmost, and reality will align with the name. On the road, if one in ten is killed, people grow greatly fearful, yet the harms of lust and desire lead them to death, and none avoid them—this is the gravest error.

Lü’s commentary: Shan Bao was one who preserved his form yet lost his life, while Zhang Yi was one who had excess in external things yet neglected his form. Bao turned inward and hid, Yi turned outward and exposed himself—both acted with intent. Standing in the center without intent is not like those who lag behind.

Following the text: Those who have already advanced need no whipping; only those who lag behind require it. This illustrates that one who has cultivated the inner need not further refine it but should cultivate the outer, while one who has cultivated the outer need not further refine it but should cultivate the inner. "Standing like withered wood" means standing in the center, neither entering nor going out.

The sacrificial officer, Xuan Duan, approached the pen to address the pig, saying: "Why do you hate death? I will raise you for three months, fast for ten days, purify for three, and lay you on white straw, placing your shoulders and rump upon the carved sacrificial platter—will you accept this?" Planning for the pig, he said: "Better to eat chaff and糟 and remain in the pen." Planning for himself, he said: "If in life one attains the honor of high rank and in death rests upon painted shields amid woven mats, one accepts it." For the pig, he rejects it; for himself, he embraces it. What makes the pig different?

Guo’s commentary: The desire for abundance leads to the loss of the body—this principle applies equally to humans and beasts.

Lü’s commentary: Planning for the pig, he rejects it; planning for himself, he accepts it. Is it that he values himself less than the pig? It is the world that burdens him. Only by abandoning the world and relinquishing life can one be free of burdens.

Yi Du’s interpretation: For the sacred turtle, he would rather drag its tail through the mud than leave its bones to be venerated; for the pig, he would rather eat chaff and糟 in the pen than be placed upon the carved platter. This means that going against the principles of life and nature to dwell in wealth and honor is worse than following them and delighting in poverty and lowliness. Zhuangzi compares himself to the sacred turtle and the worldly to the pig—his meaning is clear.

Explanation of terms: *Xuan Duan* refers to a ceremonial cap. *Fang* means to feed. *Dun* is a shield. *Ju lǚ* refers to woven mats used to bundle things. In the *Zuozhuan*, a chef was killed for undercooking a bear’s paw and placed in a basket—this is the same idea.

Fang Sishan’s note: *Dun dun* in the *Lu Shi Yin Yi* states the character should be *chūn*, a painted funeral carriage for carrying coffins. *Ju* should be *zōu* (zǐ guān), and *lǚ* should be *lóu* (lì jiǔ), referring to burial in woven mats. The *Liji*’s *Tan Gong* chapter states: "For the burial of the Son of Heaven, they apply *zōu* mud to the dragon-painted *chūn* with an outer coffin," and "they set up *lóu* screens." *Zōu* means to gather wood, cover the coffin, and apply mud. *Chūn* refers to the dragon patterns. The text’s meaning is that those who pursue wealth and honor in death would not exchange it for the pig’s life—how much less should humans be inferior to pigs?

Duke Huan was hunting in the marsh when Guan Zhong drove his chariot. They saw a *kui* spirit. The Duke grasped Guan Zhong’s hand and asked, "What did you see?" Guan Zhong replied, "I saw nothing." The Duke returned, sighing and muttering, and fell ill, taking to his bed for days without emerging. A Qi scholar named Huangzi Gao’ao said, "The Duke has harmed himself—how can the *kui* harm him? When pent-up *qi* scatters and does not return, it causes insufficiency; if it rises but does not descend, it makes one prone to anger; if it descends but does not rise, it makes one prone to forgetfulness; if it neither rises nor descends but lodges in the center of the body, at the heart, it causes illness." Duke Huan asked, "Then are there *kui* spirits?" He replied, "There are. In the depths, there is *Shen*; in the hearth, *Lüzao*; in the door’s lintel, *Jihu*. The clamor of the inner walls and the dust of the eastern corner house *Beie*; in the northwest, *Longyue*. In the water, there is *Wangxiang*; on the hills, *Shan*; in the mountains, *Kui*; in the wilds, *Fanghuang*; in the marshes, *Weiyi*." The Duke asked, "What does *Weiyi* look like?" Huangzi said, "*Weiyi* is as large as a wheel hub, as long as a chariot shaft, clad in purple robes with a vermilion cap. As a creature, it hates the sound of thunderous chariots and, upon hearing it, clutches its head and stands. Those who see it are nearly doomed to greatness." Duke Huan laughed heartily and said, "This is what I saw!" He then straightened his robes and cap, sat with Huangzi, and before the day was out, his illness had vanished.

Guo’s Annotation: [This passage speaks of how distress arises from delusion, obscuring clarity, while the resolution of affliction restores one’s nature, revealing the principle.]

Lü’s Annotation: [Here it is said that anxiety and doubt summon demons—though they possess no power to harm, one harms oneself. When doubt dissipates, illness, though still present, departs of its own accord. Thus, to be whole in Heaven and allow nothing external to intrude is to ensure nothing can harm one.]

Personal Insight: [Duke Huan’s illness stemmed from doubt; when Gao Ao dispelled his delusions, the delusions ceased. This reveals that the presence or absence of demons arises from the mind’s arising and ceasing, and that the mind’s likes and dislikes are but human delusions. When delusion departs, likes and dislikes return to their true nature; when the original mind is clear, arising and ceasing no longer depend on external forces. Today, those who chase delusion and lose their true nature all fall ill at the sight of demons. Gao Ao’s words—*"You harm yourself; how can demons harm you?"*—serve as an excellent remedy. This is akin to the child’s heartache vanishing when the clay figurine is cast aside, or the suspicion of illness fading once the bow’s shadow is gone. Though the recorded demon names seem fantastical, the *Kongzi Jia Yu* also mentions *Kui* and *Wangxiang*, and the *Zuozhuan* recounts the tale of the *Xin Gui*, while the *Shi* records the Historian’s presentation of jade to the Lord of Haochi—demons are not entirely nonexistent. Yet when yin and yang each finds its proper place, neither harms the other. As the classics say, *"When the world follows the Dao, its demons lose their numinosity."*]

Master Jisheng raised fighting cocks for the king. After ten days, the king asked, *"Are the cocks ready?"*
*"Not yet,"* he replied. *"They are still hollow and arrogant, relying on their qi."*
After another ten days, the king asked again.
*"Not yet,"* he said. *"They still respond to shadows and reflections."*
After another ten days, the king inquired once more.
*"Not yet,"* he answered. *"Their gaze is still fierce, and their qi remains overbearing."*
After another ten days, the king asked again.
*"Nearly so,"* he said. *"Though other cocks may crow, this one remains unchanged. From a distance, it resembles a wooden cock. Its virtue is complete. No other cock dares respond; they turn and flee instead."*

Guo’s Annotation: [This passage speaks of nurturing to the point of wholeness, rendering one invincible externally—how much more so when one is whole within?]

Zhang Zhan’s Annotation: [This analogy of raising cocks illustrates the cultivation of life: being hollow and relying on qi is to be empty yet self-important; responding to shadows and reflections is to grasp at fleeting perceptions. A fierce gaze and overbearing qi seek victory over others. When the cock crows yet remains unchanged, it no longer reacts to provocation, forgetting both victory and defeat. When it appears like a wooden cock and no other cock dares respond, one realizes that the perfection of virtue not only stills one’s own mind but also prevents others from harboring intentions. This is the pinnacle of cultivation.]

Jiang Yu’s Annotation: [The cock is a creature of wood, and wood rubbing against wood ignites—hence its combative nature. Hollow arrogance and reliance on qi lead to aggression; though no opponent is present, it seeks conflict relentlessly. How can such a cock avoid fear, let alone ensure victory? Thus, when asked if it is ready to fight, the answer is *"Not yet."*
Still responding to shadows and reflections means it reacts to the mere sight of a shadow’s movement. A fierce gaze and overbearing qi mean it chases illusory perceptions, reacting to every provocation. When an opponent appears, it musters its ferocity to confront it—yet a fierce gaze unsettles the spirit, and overbearing qi disturbs the mind. Though it does not engage, its heart is stirred within, and its spirit falters without, merely suppressing rather than resolving its agitation. Hence, *"Not yet."*
Later, though the cock crows, it remains unchanged, appearing like a wooden cock—its virtue is complete. Internally, it forgets its qi; externally, it forgets its form. Though other cocks may crow in challenge, it does not hear them. How does this differ from withered wood? Thus, the virtue of non-contention reaches its zenith—*"complete."*
No cock in the world can rival it; all turn and submit, as Laozi subdued the Hu barbarians or Confucius won over his disciples. The heart is the Crimson Palace; in birds, it is the Vermilion Bird. The sage nurtures it within, ensuring sufficiency without greed, satiety without contention—thus none in the world can contend with him. The common man merely tends to it externally, leaving the Vermilion Bird perpetually hungry, soaring across the eight directions in pursuit of gain. Without greed, it cannot fill its desires; without contention, it cannot satisfy its cravings—until death brings an end. How lamentable!]

Personal Insight: [*"Are the cocks ready?"* should follow the *Liezi*, reading *"Are the cocks ready to fight?"* The *Zhuangzi* text is likely abbreviated.]

Confucius observed the waters of Lüliang, which plunged thirty *ren* deep, with foam stretching forty *li*, where soft-shelled turtles, alligators, fish, and turtles could not swim. He saw a man swimming there and assumed he was in distress, seeking to drown himself. He sent his disciples along the current to rescue him. After several hundred paces, the man emerged, his hair unbound, singing as he strolled beneath the embankment. Confucius followed and asked him,
*"I took you for a demon, but you are a man. May I ask if there is a Dao to treading water?"*
*"No,"* the man replied. *"I have no Dao. I began with what was innate, grew with my nature, and matured with my destiny."*

The swimmer said, *"I enter with the whirlpool and emerge with the surge—following the Dao of water without imposing my will. This is how I tread it."*

Confucius asked, *"What do you mean by 'beginning with what was innate, growing with your nature, and maturing with your destiny'?"*

The man replied, *"I was born on the hills and at ease on the hills—this is my innate endowment. I grew up in the water and at ease in the water—this is my nature. I do not know why it is so, yet it is so—this is my destiny."*

---

**Guo’s Annotation:**
*"The swirling vortex where water grinds and spirals inward is the 'whirlpool' (齊); the surging swell where it coils and bursts forth is the 'surge' (汨). To follow the Dao of water without imposing one’s will is to yield to the water, not to oneself. This passage shows that when one possesses a particular ability and entrusts oneself to it, nothing in the world is difficult. Applying this effortless mastery to the Dao of life and generation—where could one not pass through?"*

**Zhang Zhan’s Annotation:**
*"Lüliang is in present-day Pengcheng Prefecture. The *Erya* states, 'A rock that severs the water is called a *liang* (梁).' 'Beginning with what was innate' means abiding in one’s original simplicity; thus, one is at ease wherever one encounters. 'Growing with one’s nature' means following the principles of nature, so nothing opposes it. 'Maturing with one’s destiny' refers to the principle of spontaneity—what cannot be known, yet knowing that it cannot be known, is called destiny."*

**Lü’s Annotation:**
*"Following the principles of nature and destiny, one enters with the whirlpool and emerges with the surge, yielding to the Dao of water without imposing one’s will—this is why one can tread it. But where even soft-shelled turtles and alligators cannot swim, one must harmonize one’s virtue with the utmost reaches of things to traverse it. Only then is there nowhere one cannot tread and be at ease. 'Born on the hills and at ease on the hills' refers to innate endowment, which is not a matter of nature but of human effort. 'Growing up in the water and at ease in the water' refers to nature, which is one’s particular ability. If one lacks this nature and merely practices, one may acquire the skill but never surpass what others cannot achieve."*

**Jiang Yu’s Annotation:**
*"Water-born creatures do not swiftly change their nature. Humans, too, are born on land and at ease on land. Yet the man of Lüliang could swim where soft-shelled turtles, alligators, fish, and turtles could not—this was his particular nature. Only because he possessed this nature could he grow up in the water and be at ease in it. Though at ease in the water, if he did not reach the point of 'not knowing why it is so, yet it is so,' he would not have truly followed the Dao of water without imposing his will—and thus would not have attained such mastery. His words ultimately return to destiny. Such a man is what the text calls 'one who has attained it to traverse great rivers.'"*

**Editor’s Note:**
*"The man of Lüliang treading water and singing—his marvel lies in following the Dao of water without imposing his will, so the water cannot harm him. If one conducts oneself in the world by following the Dao of others without imposing one’s will, others will not harm one either. Extending this principle to all interactions—where could one not preserve wholeness? 'Beginning with what was innate' means forming habits that become second nature; 'growing with one’s nature' means..."*

The long-standing nature formed by habit becomes spontaneous. When it reaches the point of destiny, one forgets the water and does not know why it is so, yet it is so—this is called preserving wholeness in Heaven. This chapter aligns with the meaning of "being in accord with things without harming them," and these words may well serve as the standard for navigating the world.

---

Ziqing carved wood into a *ju*. When the *ju* was completed, those who saw it marveled as if it were the work of spirits. The Duke of Lu saw it and asked, "What technique did you use to make it?" He replied, "Your servant is but a craftsman—what technique could I possess? Nevertheless, there is one thing: when I was about to make the *ju*, I never dared to deplete my *qi*. I first fasted to still my mind. After three days of fasting, I no longer dared to entertain thoughts of reward, rank, or emolument. After five days, I no longer dared to entertain thoughts of praise or blame, skill or clumsiness. After seven days, I suddenly forgot that I had four limbs and a body. At that time, I had no thought of the court; my skill became concentrated, and external distractions dissolved. Only then did I enter the mountain forest to observe the natural forms of the trees. When I saw one whose shape matched the *ju*, I set my hand to it—otherwise, I would stop. Thus, I joined Heaven with Heaven. Is this not why the vessel seems the work of spirits?"

**Annotations:**
*Ju*: A wooden percussion instrument resembling a crouching tiger, with twenty-seven serrated teeth on its back, used to mark the end of music.

---

Guo’s Commentary: "When one regards the court as nothing, all longing and admiration vanish. Skill becomes concentrated, and external distractions dissolve—all matters outside one’s nature are cast aside. Only then does one select the appropriate material and set one’s hand to it, joining Heaven with Heaven without departing from spontaneity. This is how one fully follows the marvel of things, so the work seems the work of spirits."

Lü’s Commentary: "If the vessel seems the work of spirits because of this, then if external distractions have not dissolved and one seeks to wander among the creations of things, one cannot attain such mastery."

---

Dudu’s Note: "The craftsman’s name was Qing. The *ju* is a musical instrument, also called *yu*, shaped like a crouching tiger. He never depleted his *qi* but emptied himself and stilled his mind. He did not entertain thoughts of reward, rank, or emolument, thus forgetting profit. He did not entertain thoughts of praise or blame, skill or clumsiness, thus forgetting fame. Forgetting that he had four limbs and a body, his spirit became whole and united with Heaven. Thus, he regarded the court as nothing, and the distractions of external matters dissolved. Only then did he enter the mountain forest to observe the shapes of the trees. When he found one that matched the *ju*, he set his hand to it without forcing it. He extended his own Heaven to join with the Heaven of the thing—this is why the vessel seems the work of spirits."

---

Dongye Ji presented his charioteering to Duke Zhuang. He advanced and retreated in perfect alignment, turned left and right in perfect arcs. The Duke thought even Wen could not surpass him and had him drive a hundred circuits and return. Yan He encountered him and entered to see the Duke, saying, "Ji’s horses are about to fail." The Duke remained silent and did not respond. Soon after, the horses indeed failed and returned. The Duke asked, "How did you know?" He replied, "His horses’ strength was exhausted, yet he still demanded more—hence I said they would fail."

Guo’s Commentary: "The horses’ strength was exhausted, yet he still demanded more—hence they failed. This shows that even the most fitting cannot be exceeded."

Lü’s Commentary: "Ji’s charioteering was superb, yet he could not avoid failure once the horses’ strength was exhausted. If one acts according to the Dao yet strives for what life cannot provide, or knows what cannot be known, how can one succeed?"

Bixu’s Note: "His driving aligned with the compass and square like weaving patterned silk. When made to turn back, he completed a hundred circuits, each retracing the same path. Han Ying said, 'Shun was skilled in employing people; Zaofu was skilled in employing horses. If one does not exhaust the people, there will be no idle people; if one does not exhaust the horses, there will be no idle horses. The stumbling and failure of horses arise from excessive restraint; the exhaustion of people’s knowledge arises from harsh governance. Thus, those who understand destiny do not strive for what cannot be known or done.'"

Guan’s Insight: "Holding the reins like weaving, the two outer horses danced—this illustrates the meaning of 'even Wen could not surpass him.' Weaving involves gathering threads here to form patterns there, just as a skilled charioteer holds the reins above while the horses harmonize below. 'A hundred circuits' means driving in circles without cease—hence it was known they would fail. When strength is exhausted yet one still demands more, not only will the horses fail, but the man will also be worn out."

---

Gongchui turned his hand and surpassed the compass and square. His fingers transformed with things without his mind interfering, so his spirit’s terrace was unified and unobstructed.

Guo’s Commentary: "Even with Gongchui’s skill, he still relied on the compass and square—this speaks of following the ease of things."

Lü’s Commentary: "Gongchui turned his hand and surpassed the compass and square, meaning his movements matched the compass and square without revealing the traces. His fingers met things as if transformed by nature, without waiting for the mind’s deliberation to align with the square and circle. Only thus is the spirit’s terrace unified and unobstructed. This is the proof of not interfering with the mind. When one forgets the feet, the shoes fit; forgets the waist, the belt fits; forgets right and wrong, the mind fits; does not change inwardly nor follow outwardly, the affairs one guards fit. One begins with fitting and never ceases to fit—this is the fitting that forgets fitting."

Guo’s Commentary: "When all parts of the body are fitting, one forgets the body entirely. Right and wrong arise from not fitting. Where one encounters and finds peace, there is no change or following—thus knowledge fits. Yet one who knows fitting is still not truly fitting."

Bixu’s Note: "Forgetting the feet and waist are minor matters; forgetting right and wrong is the root. How much more so for minor matters? Inwardly and outwardly, all one encounters is fitting and constantly fitting—this is the fitting without fitting. Gongchui’s marvel is also like this."

---

There was a man named Sun Xiu who came to the gate and reproached Master Bian Qingzi, saying, "Xiu lives in his village and is not seen as cultivated. When facing difficulties, he is not seen as brave. Yet when tilling the fields, he does not meet with good years; when serving his lord, he does not meet with the times. He is cast out by his village, expelled by his district—what crime has he committed? Is it Heaven? Is it Xiu’s misfortune to meet with this destiny?"

Master Bian said, "Have you alone not heard of the Perfect Man’s way of conducting himself? He forgets his liver and gall, leaves behind his ears and eyes, wandering in vagueness beyond the dust and grime, roaming in freedom..."

Sun Xiu left, and Master Bian entered to sit. After a while, he looked up to the heavens and sighed. His disciples asked, "Master, why do you sigh?"

Master Bian said, "Earlier, Sun Xiu came, and I told him of the Perfect Man’s virtue. I fear he was startled and thus fell into confusion."

The disciples said, "Not so. If Sun Xiu’s words were right and yours were wrong, he naturally could not be confused. If Sun Xiu’s words were wrong and yours were right, he was already confused when he came—how is this your fault?"

Master Bian said, "Not so. Once, a bird alighted in the outskirts of Lu. The Lord of Lu, delighted, prepared a grand feast to welcome it, playing the *Nine Shao* to entertain it. Yet the bird grew sorrowful and fearful, refusing to eat or drink. This is called nourishing a bird with what nourishes oneself. As for nourishing a bird with what nourishes a bird, one should let it roost in deep forests, float upon rivers and lakes, and feed on whatever it encounters—then it would be at ease even on level ground.

Now, Sun Xiu is a man of simple understanding and little learning. When I told him of the Perfect Man’s virtue, it was like burdening a mouse with chariots and horses or delighting a sparrow with bells and drums. How could he not be startled?"

【*Kuan* (款) and *kuan* (窾) both mean "small aperture"; *qi* (启) means "to open." *Kuan-qi* (款启) refers to limited understanding.】

Guo’s Annotation: [*To forget the liver and gall, to leave behind the ears and eyes, to obscurely entrust oneself to the natural—all that is not true nature is but dust and grime. All that is done by the self is the work of non-action. To follow one’s nature and act is not to rely on doing; to let things grow of themselves is not to govern their growth. To nourish a bird with what nourishes a bird is to suit its own convenience.* This chapter speaks of those who skillfully nourish life: each follows the suitability of their nature to reach the utmost.]

Lü’s Annotation: [*The purport of this chapter lies in preserving life to attain spiritual wholeness, essence restored, and unity with Heaven. What Sun Xiu does is the very opposite. When he heard these words, he could not but grow anxious, casting fearful glances and refusing to eat or drink. Thus, the chapter concludes with the analogy of the seabird.*]

Personal Insight: [*To delight in Heaven and know fate is to be without sorrow; to fathom principle and exhaust nature—what doubt remains? What Sun Xiu describes stands in stark contrast to the teachings of Heavenly mandate and human nature. Thus, Master Bian instructed him in the conduct of the Perfect Man: to forget the liver and gall is to empty the inner self; to leave behind the ears and eyes is to still the outer. Only then may one wander beyond the dust and grime—all the affairs and traces of the human world are but dust and grime. To depart from these is to make every action, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying, the work of non-action. This is what is called "transcending the world while within it." What is there to rely upon? What growth is there to govern? Now, you adorn your knowledge and cultivate your person until you shine like the sun and moon, yet in grasping at worldly calamities, you may—if fortunate—preserve your form without incurring Heaven’s wrath. How then could you have leisure to resent Heaven? This is why I deeply warn you of your delusion and urge you to return to true understanding.*]

New Compilation: [*The Way of preserving life is known only to the Perfect Man. To speak of it to one who is not a Perfect Man is like nourishing a bird with grand feasts and the *Nine Shao*—how could it not be startled? This is why Master Bian feared Sun Xiu’s confusion. Zhuangzi composed this to awaken the world to the principle of preserving life, yet the worldly cannot be abruptly told of this Way. Thus, he concluded with Master Bian’s lament, embedding his meaning within it. If Zhuangzi may be said to have fully expressed his intent, then so be it.*]

**General Remarks on the Chapter:**
This chapter begins by discussing life, which all people value. Some harm it through excessive nourishment, while life lies with Heaven and cannot be defied; others destroy it through reckless action. If one comprehends these two extremes, one can preserve life and rest content in fate—this is the Way of deep roots and firm foundations, of long life and enduring vision. Thus, all that life does not require, all that fate cannot endure, must be kept at a distance. Know what is not one’s proper duty, and hold fast to the purity and wholeness of Heaven, which cannot be parted from even for an instant.

Consider the drunkard’s indifference to chariots or the swordsman’s disregard for the *Mo Gan*—what room is there for concern? The cicada-catcher and the boatman exemplify mastery through accumulated practice; the shepherd fears the path and drives his flock from behind to avoid danger. The tale of the pig warns those who covet rank, while the *xuan*-bird parable shows how many are deluded by the inability to obscure the false. The subsequent analogies, varied as they are, all serve to expound the theme of life—truly earnest and incisive.

What nourishes human life has its fixed allotment: it is not gained by seeking nor lost by neglect. The troubles of life often arise unexpectedly, neither foreseen nor evaded, neither outwitted nor escaped. One must cultivate human affairs to accord with Heavenly principle, seeking only to be without remorse. Longevity or early death, fortune or misfortune—these are not to be eagerly pursued. Whether one retreats to mountain valleys for pure cultivation or serves in the court to manage affairs, whether inwardly nourishing life or outwardly governing others, it is all but the beautification of human relations and the promotion of teaching, ultimately converging in the principle of the Dao and virtue.

Yet how many truly know life’s weight and heed the warnings in the comforts of bed and board? Only when one appears like a wooden rooster, yet when employed, never exhausts their strength—only then have they grasped the principle of life and nearly attained the conduct of the Perfect Man.

The chapter concludes with the seabird of Lu, which grew sorrowful at the sound of bells and drums. When the outer nourishment is lost, the inner nature is harmed. If one knows how to nourish, one knows how to preserve. The key lies in understanding one’s own life, extending this to benefit all things, and harmonizing with them. To forget suitability is to find no suitability unmet.

**Chapter Twenty: "Mountain Trees"**

In the mountains, Zhuangzi came upon a great tree with luxuriant branches and leaves. A woodcutter stood beside it but did not fell it. When asked why, he replied, "It is of no use." Zhuangzi said, "This tree, by being useless, has fulfilled its Heaven-appointed years."

Zhuangzi then emerged from the mountains and lodged at the home of an old friend. Delighted, his friend ordered a servant to kill a goose and cook it. The servant asked, "One can caw, the other cannot—which should we kill?" The host replied, "Kill the one that cannot caw."

The next day, a disciple asked Zhuangzi, "Yesterday, the tree in the mountains, by being useless, fulfilled its Heaven-appointed years. Today, our host’s goose, by being useless, met its death. Where would you, Master, choose to stand?" Zhuangzi laughed and said, "I would stand between usefulness and uselessness. Yet to stand between usefulness and uselessness is still to resemble without being it—thus one remains entangled in trouble.

"As for those who ride the Dao and float upon virtue, it is otherwise: they bear neither praise nor blame, now a dragon, now a snake, transforming with the times, never clinging to one form. Ascending and descending, they take harmony as their measure, floating upon the Ancestor of the Myriad Things. Treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by things—how could they be ensnared? This is the method of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor.

"But as for the passions of the myriad things and the conventions of human relations, it is not so: union invites separation, completion invites destruction, integrity invites injury, honor invites criticism, action invites loss, worth invites scheming, and worthlessness invites deceit. How can one be certain of anything? Alas! Disciples, take heed—only in the realm of the Dao and virtue is there refuge."

【Tradition: Sima comments, "This refers to matters that can be practiced."】
Guo's Annotation: ["If one were to dwell here, one would still not escape entanglement. As for those who ride the Dao and float freely—Zhuangzi also dwells therein. How could one be certain of anything? Since certainty is unattainable, one cannot rely on a single method. Only those who transform with the times can devise change while remaining perpetually unobstructed."]

Lü's Annotation: ["That sages and worthies are often unaccommodated by the world stems from the entanglement inherent in talent. Thus, Zhuangzi repeatedly warns against the burdens of talent. Yet fools and the unworthy, unable to make themselves heard, are often destroyed—how can one be certain that not being talented ensures escape? The trees of the mountain and the master’s geese share the same fate. Therefore, one seeks to dwell between talent and lack of talent, yet this still resembles the Dao without being the Dao. For the essence of the Dao does not cling to either extreme, nor does it reside in the center. Thus, even dwelling between talent and lack of talent does not escape entanglement. But those who ride the Dao and float freely bear neither praise nor blame, cannot be valued or disdained, are now a dragon, now a snake, and cannot be fixed as sage or commoner. Their waxing and waning transform with the times, now ascending, now concealing, harmonious yet never discordant—how could this depend on dwelling between talent and lack of talent? It is merely floating upon the Ancestor of the Myriad Things. The Ancestor of the Myriad Things may be called the Father of All. If one treats things as things yet is not treated as a thing by things, how could one be ensnared? As for the passions of the myriad things and the conventions of human relations, union invites separation, completion invites destruction, integrity invites injury, honor invites criticism, action invites loss, worth invites scheming, and worthlessness invites deceit. How can one dwelling between talent and lack of talent be certain of escaping entanglement? Those who seek to be free of entanglement must find refuge only in the realm of the Dao and virtue."]

Xu Xi’s Note: ["Separation, destruction, injury, criticism, and loss—all arise from human reluctance to rejoice in one another. The worthy are envied and schemed against, while the unworthy are deceived. Such is the bitter taste of this shallow and vicious world."]

Jilao of Shinan met the Lord of Lu, who wore a troubled expression. Jilao asked, "Why does my lord appear troubled?"
The Lord of Lu replied, "I have studied the Way of the former kings and cultivated the legacy of my predecessors. I reverence the spirits, honor the worthy, and act with filial devotion, never straying for even a moment. Yet I cannot escape misfortune—this is why I am troubled."
Jilao said, "My lord’s method for dispelling misfortune is too shallow. The sleek fox and the patterned leopard dwell in the mountains and forests, resting in caves and grottos—this is their stillness. They move by night and rest by day—this is their caution. Though hungry and thirsty, even in dire straits, they still keep their distance from the rivers and lakes while seeking food—this is their steadfastness. Yet they cannot escape the calamities of nets, snares, and traps. What crime have they committed? Their pelts are their undoing. Is the state of Lu not my lord’s pelt? I wish for my lord to carve away his form, shed his pelt, wash his heart, and relinquish desire, then wander in the wilds where no one dwells. In the southern lands of Yue, there is a settlement called the Kingdom of Establishing Virtue. Its people are simple and guileless, with few private interests and scant desires.
