They know how to act but not how to hoard, give without seeking reward, do not know where righteousness leads, and do not understand where ritual guides. Wild and uninhibited, they tread the great square of the Dao. In life, they find joy; in death, they are buried. I wish for my lord to abandon your state, cast off custom, and walk alongside the Dao."
The Lord of Lu said, "That path is distant and perilous, with rivers and mountains in between. I have no boat or carriage—what am I to do?"
Jilao replied, "Do not be haughty in form, do not linger in residence—let these be your carriage."
The Lord of Lu said, "That path is secluded and remote, with no people. Who would be my neighbor? I have no provisions, no food—how could I reach it?"
Jilao said, "Lessen your lord’s expenditures, reduce your lord’s desires. Though you have no provisions, you will find sufficiency. Cross the river and float upon the sea. Gaze into the distance, and you will not see its shores. The farther you go, the more boundless it becomes. Those who see you off will turn back from the shore, and you will be far from them. Thus, those who possess others are burdened, and those who are possessed by others are troubled. Yao neither possessed others nor was possessed by them. I wish to free you of your burdens, dispel your troubles, and wander alone with the Dao in the boundless realm. When a square boat crosses the river and an empty boat drifts into it, even a hot-tempered man would not grow angry. But if there were a person aboard, he would shout to make way. If unheard the first time, he would shout again, and if still unheard, he would curse. Before, he was not angry, but now he is—because before, the boat was empty, and now it is not."

When empty before, now full—if one can empty oneself and wander through the world, who could harm them?

Guo’s commentary:
To possess a self and take pride in one’s state, though one may harbor ten thousand cares and honor worthies while pursuing good deeds, one’s anxieties only deepen. Thus, let there be no self, no state, and entrust all to spontaneous transformation. To send one to Nanyue is to choose its remoteness from Lu. If each follows their own pace and every person treads their own path, then the ten thousand directions are attained—is this not vast? To leave one’s state and abandon customs is to sweep clean the heart’s chamber.

You, however, take this as truly sending them to Nanyue. "Form’s haughty obstruction" refers to lingering and stagnation; "form harmonizing with things" and "heart transforming with things" describe relying on things to bear oneself. If you can reduce expenditures and curb desires, nothing will be lacking. Crossing rivers and floating on seas without seeing their shores is a metaphor for cutting off passions and desires to a great distance. If you wish to sever them, the people will each return to guard their proper place, and you will be far from them—transcending and standing alone above the ten thousand things.

Those who "possess others" do so for private gain.

One who "sees possession in others" is one who is enslaved by others. Thus, though Yao possessed the world, he entrusted it all to the hundred officials and committed it to the ten thousand things without partaking in it—this is not "possessing others." Relying on the people and entrusting things without being enslaved by them—this is not "seeing possession in others." Those who wander in the boundless realm wish to be utterly free from the cares of state; though the world may change, their emptiness remains, and thus they avoid harm—this is one and the same.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
Those who take the state of Lu as their skin give rise to afflictions—this is the inability to forget one’s state. For if form is not abandoned, the state becomes a burden; hollowing out form is how one sheds the skin. If the heart is not pure, desires become a stain; washing the heart is how one sheds desire. Separating from man and entering Heaven—this is how one wanders in the wilds of no-man’s-land, where the state of established virtue and the realm of the Dao are founded. Its people are simple and desire little, untouched by refinement and unconcerned with hoarding. They supply what is sought when it is sought, yet do not expect repayment; they act with benevolence yet do not regard it as favor. Unaware of where duty leads, they do not value comings and goings; ignorant of ritual’s course, they act at will yet tread the great Way. What brings joy or sorrow does not cling to them, for they remain unchanged from beginning to end. Such is the state of established virtue. Yet those who cannot wander within it are merely fettered by state and custom. Abandoning virtue and discarding custom, one walks alongside the Dao—then the destination is reached without toil.

The Dao is near and utterly smooth, yet people regard it as distant and perilous because they are haughty in form and fail to yield, lingering in place without advancing. If one makes a chariot of formless haughtiness and non-lingering, and provisions of reduced expenditures and curbed desires, what hindrance could prevent arrival? Do you not see its shores? The boundless journey—those who see you off turn back at the shore, constrained by emptiness and daunted by its depth and remoteness, none dare proceed. From this point, you stand alone without peer, and none can follow. Is this not wandering? This is neither "possessing others" nor "seeing possession in others." Such was Yao’s way of being Yao.

The boundless realm and the state of established virtue are what the previous chapter called the "ancestor of the ten thousand things" and the "homeland of virtue and the Dao." Next, the discussion turns to the empty boat that strikes another yet arouses no anger. Those who ride the Dao and float through the world are likewise thus.

Duke Ling of Wei commissioned Beigong She to levy taxes and cast bells, erecting an altar beyond the outer gate of the capital. In three months, the bells were completed, suspended in upper and lower tiers. Prince Qingji saw this and asked, "What method did you employ?"

She replied, "In the space of oneness, I dared not impose any artifice. I have heard that once carving and polishing are done, one returns to simplicity. How vast and unknowing! How careless and doubtful! How clustered and boundless! It sends off the departing and welcomes the arriving—those who come are not barred, those who go are not stopped. It follows the strong and unyielding, bends with the crooked and compliant, and relies on their self-exhaustion. Thus, though taxes were levied day and night, not a hair was harmed—how much more so for those who tread the great path?"

---

When Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food, Taigong Ren came to offer condolences, asking, "You nearly died, did you not?"

"Yes," Confucius replied.

"Do you detest death?"

"Yes."

Ren said, "Let me speak of the way of not dying. In the Eastern Sea, there is a bird called *Yidai*. As a bird, it flutters and drifts, appearing incapable. It flies only when drawn by others, perches only when pressed, never dares to advance first or retreat last, and never eats before tasting the leftovers. Thus, it is never expelled from the flock, and others never harm it. This is how it avoids disaster. The straightest trees are felled first, the sweetest wells run dry first. As for you, you adorn your knowledge to startle the foolish, cultivate yourself to expose impurity, and stride forth as if bearing the sun and moon—how could you escape harm?

Long ago, I heard from a man of great completion: 'Those who boast achieve no merit; those who accomplish destroy their names; those who succeed lose their integrity. Who can relinquish merit and fame to return to the common? The Dao flows unseen, dwelling where it is obtained without being named. Abide in purity, remain constant, and you approach madness. Erase your traces, discard your power, and do not seek merit or fame. Thus, no one blames you, and you blame no one. The perfected do not strive—why do you delight in this?'"

Confucius said, "Well said."

He severed ties with his acquaintances, parted from his disciples, and fled to the great marshes. Clad in coarse cloth, he ate the leavings of mulberry silkworms and wild chestnuts. Entering among beasts, he did not disrupt their herds; entering among birds, he did not disturb their flocks. Birds and beasts felt no aversion toward him—how much less would humans?

[Fēnfēn zhìzhì: Sima Biao explains this as a leisurely, unhurried demeanor. Pressed and threatened, he nested among the flock—Li Yun says this means he was squeezed among the birds, barely finding space to roost, so extreme was his avoidance of harm.]

Guo’s commentary: The sage has no preferences, neither hastening nor lingering, and his mind is free from fixed attachments. He does not dare to lead or follow but always abides in easeful centrality. In eating, he takes only what remains, content to follow things as they are. His conduct does not stand out, and he moves with the flock. Harm arises from the pursuit of knowledge and the scramble for advantage—this is why trees are felled and wells run dry. To scrutinize closely is to find minor differences and thus clash with the multitude. To merge in great sameness is to be without singularity in the world. Thus, what shines brightly is but the trace of profound obscurity.

He would lodge words to leave behind traces, so he used Chen and Cai as a pretext to convey his meaning. Those who rely on merit and fame as their accomplishment have never preserved their wholeness. Merit arises from the collective, so he returns it to the Dao, which moves dimly yet of itself. They all dwell in self-contentment—this is the conduct at hand, not something achieved through fame. Abiding in purity and constancy is likened to madness, for he moves without intention. Merit is accomplished by others, so power does not reside in him, and name and trace both vanish. Following his nature and yielding to others, each bears their own responsibility. Detached and without attachment, this is the perfected person.

Thus it is said: "The perfected do not strive." He severs ties with acquaintances and parts from disciples, relinquishing the world’s attachments. He does not disrupt herds or flocks, like plants and trees without intention, so birds and beasts do not fear him. This is the lodging of words to fully express the trust of utmost sincerity—where things find no ground for harm.

Lü’s commentary: *Fēnfēn zhìzhì*—though bustling, he is not disordered, seeming incapable yet not without ability. When drawn to fly or pressed to roost, he hesitates, compelled in movement and stillness. He does not dare to advance first or retreat last, neither emerging to display nor withdrawing to conceal. In eating, he does not taste first but takes only what remains, dwelling in the realm of non-contention. His conduct does not stand out, so he moves with others in the human flock. Knowing that the completion of merit and fame must bring loss, he abandons them to return to the multitude—this is the conduct of the man of great completion.

The Dao flows unseen, and when dwelling, none see his merit. When acting, none hear his name—this is virtue. Abiding in purity and constancy is likened to madness, a reckless and unrestrained course. Not pursuing merit and fame, he returns to the multitude. This is what is meant by "the man of the Dao can offer his surplus to the world."

The hardship of Chen and Cai—how to endure it was not for lack of means, but rather what knowledge could do nothing about. Those who study Confucius, if they do not understand what is meant by "not standing out in the ranks" and "being able to enter among birds and beasts," will scarcely avoid being burdened by the pursuit of merit and fame, walking as if beneath the sun and moon.

**Limited Insight:** The lines *"The Dao flows unseen, and when dwelling, none see his merit; when acting, none hear his name"* should be read with a pause after each couplet, their meaning then becoming clear. Guo Xiang, however, placed a commentary after the word *"unseen,"* leading later interpreters to follow suit. Only Lü Huiqing punctuated the lines as *"when dwelling"* and *"when acting,"* which is correct—*"merit"* should correspond to *"virtue,"* and *"name"* to *"unseen,"* harmonizing with the preceding text.

Confucius asked Zisang Hu, *"I was twice exiled from Lu, had my tree felled in Song, my traces erased in Wei, and was reduced to poverty in Shang and Zhou, besieged between Chen and Cai. I have endured these many misfortunes, yet my close relations have grown more distant, and my disciples and friends have scattered. Why is this?"*

Zisang Hu replied, *"Have you not heard of the man from Jia who fled? Lin Hui abandoned a jade worth a thousand gold pieces to carry a child on his back and flee. Someone asked, 'Was it for the sake of wealth? The child’s value in cloth is little. Was it for the sake of burden? The child’s weight is great.'"*

Lin Hui abandoned a jade worth a thousand gold pieces to carry a child on his back and flee—why? Lin Hui replied, *"That bond was forged by profit; this one is joined by Heaven. Those bound by profit abandon one another when pressed by poverty, calamity, or harm. Those joined by Heaven gather together when pressed by poverty, calamity, or harm. The distance between gathering and abandoning is vast indeed. Moreover, the friendship of the noble is as bland as water; the friendship of the petty is as sweet as sweet wine. The noble grow closer through blandness; the petty grow estranged through sweetness. Those who unite without cause will part without cause."*

Confucius said, *"I respectfully receive your instruction."* He walked slowly, wandering freely, and returned home. He abandoned his studies, discarded his books, and his disciples no longer drew near to him—yet their affection for him deepened and advanced.

Another day, Zisang Hu said, *"When Shun was about to die, he truly grew cold. Yu said, 'Take heed! In form, nothing surpasses following; in emotion, nothing surpasses spontaneity. Following ensures no separation; spontaneity ensures no toil. Without separation or toil, there is no need to seek adornment to match one’s form. Without seeking adornment to match one’s form, one naturally does not depend on external things."*

The Guo commentary states: *"The friendship of the noble person rejects profit, hence its blandness; their Dao aligns, hence their closeness. The friendship of the petty person adorns profit, hence its sweetness. Profit cannot endure, hence it inevitably severs. Those who unite without cause are bound by Heaven’s ties; if union arises not from cause, then cause is insufficient to sunder it. Those who unite through cause must part through cause. That their affection deepened and advanced was because they abandoned adornment and embraced simplicity. Following form and yielding to emotion, they did not force themselves with profit. Form, unborrowed, remains ever whole; emotion, unforced, remains ever at ease. Not seeking adornment to match form is to proceed with uncarved simplicity. To be thus is to need nothing external, for unadorned sufficiency is complete."*

The Lü commentary states: *"Confucius studied yet did not grasp what was meant by 'Heaven’s ties.' He made learning and books his sole pursuit, so his interactions with the world were merely human unions. 'In form, nothing surpasses following'—following ensures no separation, hence union. 'In emotion, nothing surpasses spontaneity'—spontaneity ensures no toil, hence ease. Without separation or toil, one rests in the naturalness of their inherent quality, and their nature’s allotment is already sufficient. Why seek adornment to match form? Not seeking adornment to match form, one naturally does not depend on external things. This is the utmost realization of abandoning learning and discarding books."*

A personal observation: *"The character '待' has no dual meaning. If form follows and does not separate, it remains ever present. If emotion yields and does not toil, one’s nature remains ever at ease. What is meant by 'I' is thus attained. What need is there for ritual adornment? What reliance on external things?"*

Zhuangzi wore coarse cloth patched with hemp, tied his sandals with cords, and passed by the King of Wei. The king said, *"Why is the Master so weary?"* Zhuangzi replied, *"Poverty, not weariness. A scholar possesses the Dao and virtue yet cannot practice them—that is weariness. Worn clothes and tattered sandals are poverty, not weariness. This is what is called 'not encountering the right time.' Have you alone not seen the leaping monkeys? When they obtain nanmu, catalpa, or camphor trees, they grasp the vines, swing through the branches, and reign as kings among them. Even Yi or Feng Meng could not glance askance at them. Yet when they find themselves among thorny jujubes, trifoliate oranges, or wolfthorns, they tread cautiously, glance sideways, tremble, and quake. This is not because their sinews and bones have suddenly stiffened and lost their suppleness, but because their circumstances are unfavorable, insufficient to display their abilities. Now, dwelling among benighted rulers and chaotic ministers, how can one avoid weariness? This is like the heart of Bi Gan being carved out—a clear warning!"*

The Guo commentary states: *"When one encounters the right time and place, they can extend their skills, so even the archers of old could not harm them. When circumstances are unfavorable and one forces action, they suffer execution."*

The Lü commentary states: *"Though he spoke so boldly, he was not harmed—proof of his emptying himself to wander through the world."*

A doubtful note: *"Zhuangzi used the leaping monkeys as a metaphor for himself. Obtaining nanmu, catalpa, or camphor trees is like a noble person encountering the right time. Dwelling among thorny jujubes or wolfthorns refers to facing benighted rulers and chaotic ministers. Even if one wishes to avoid weariness, it is impossible. If one forces straight words and practices the Dao, the warning of Bi Gan’s carved-out heart is manifest."*

An oral exegesis: *"'大布' means coarse cloth; '緳' means a belt. '系履' means mending worn sandals with cords. '惫' means illness. '揽' means to grasp. '蔓' means to entwine. '王长' describes their spirit flourishing and their will fulfilled. '不柔'—the character '加急' above emphasizes the monkeys’ agility."*

Confucius was stranded between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food. Leaning on a withered tree with his left hand and striking its branches with his right, he sang the airs of the Yàn clan. The melody had its structure but not its measures, its sound but not its modes. The sound of wood and the sound of man blended so piercingly that they resonated in the hearts of others. Yan Hui stood with hands clasped, turned his gaze, and watched. Confucius, fearing that Hui would broaden his own path and reach greatness, or love him and reach sorrow, said, *"Hui, not to accept Heaven’s diminishment is easy; not to accept man’s benefit is difficult. There is no beginning that is not an end. Man and Heaven are one. Who is it that sings now?"* Hui said, *"May I ask what 'not to accept Heaven’s diminishment is easy' means?"* Confucius said, *"Hunger, thirst, cold, heat, poverty, and constraint—these are the movements of Heaven and Earth, the outpouring of the turning of things. To speak of going along with them is to say one moves with them."*

A minister dare not abandon his duty, for even in holding to the Way of ministerhood, it is thus—how much more so in awaiting Heaven’s decree? What is meant by *"not to accept man’s benefit is difficult"*? Confucius said: *"At first, one is employed in all four directions, and ranks and emoluments arrive without end—yet what things deem profitable is not one’s own. My fate lies beyond me. The noble man does not steal; the worthy man does not pilfer. If I were to take these, what would I be? Thus it is said: No bird is wiser than the swallow. Where its eyes deem unsuitable, it will not even glance, though the fruit fall before it—it abandons it and flees, so wary is it of men. Yet it nests among men, where altars of soil and grain endure. What is meant by *'there is no beginning that is not an end'*?*

Confucius said: *"Things transform in their myriad forms, yet one knows not who succeeds them. One knows where they end; one knows where they begin. To align oneself and await them is all. What is meant by *'man and Heaven are one'*? Confucius said: *"There is man, and there is Heaven; there is Heaven, and there is also Heaven. That man cannot possess Heaven’s nature—this is why the sage, at ease in his embodiment, flows with the passing and comes to rest."*

*(Guo’s commentary: To the coming of Heaven’s diminishment, one only responds with equanimity—thus it is easy. Yet the adventitious gifts of things cannot be restrained. What is now called a beginning was yesterday’s end, so what is called a beginning is precisely an end. This speaks to the boundlessness of transformation. Man and Heaven are one—both are of spontaneity.)*

To follow one’s spontaneity is to sing without the singer being the self. The movements of Heaven and Earth cannot be escaped; to flow with them is to be unknowing and unperceiving, yet in accord with the Emperor’s decree. Wherever one is, all is at ease—without taking diminishment as diminishment, one awaits Heaven yet suffers no loss. Resonance and response extend in all directions, thus one may harness the advantages of lofty and great things. Yet this is not seeking and taking; rather, one’s mandate lies beyond. It is said: in human life, there must be a mandate that engages with things externally—unlike clay or stone, which are confined to form and substance alone. To steal is to take privately; the attainment of rank and emolument by worthy men and gentlemen is not private taking, but merely receiving. Like the swallow that flees men yet enters human dwellings, this is called wisdom. How much more so the perfected person, who is mysteriously one with all under Heaven—thus all under Heaven delight in exalting him without weariness, joining together to establish altars for him. This is why not receiving benefit from others is so difficult. Day and night succeed one another without end; thus to align oneself and await them is to harbor no anxiety. All that is called Heaven is luminous, acting without contrivance, being spontaneous. To speak of spontaneity is to speak of spontaneity—how could man intentionally possess this spontaneity? It is spontaneity alone. Thus it is said: *nature*. Therefore the sage, at ease and without self-importance, embodies transformation and flows with it.

*(Lü’s commentary: The airs of the Yanyu clan are but the odes of the Yanyu clan—already without self, and if one extends this, one creates great love; if one cherishes the self, one creates sorrow. Not to receive Heaven’s diminishment is easy; not to receive others’ benefit is difficult. Now, to accept only Heaven’s diminishment—why extend the self to create greatness? Without beginning yet not without end, one aligns and awaits them. Man and Heaven are one—at ease, embodying the passing, and that is all. Why cherish the self to create sorrow? To know the singer of today is to know how beginning and end, Heaven and man, are all contained therein. The movements of Heaven and Earth cannot be halted by man; the outpouring of the turning of things cannot be closed by man. Not to receive Heaven’s diminishment is to flow with it, not daring to regard it as loss and flee. Even the way of serving as a minister does not dare to flee—how much less the way of awaiting Heaven? This is why not receiving Heaven’s diminishment is easy. Rank and emolument arrive together; if one receives what is advantageous from external things as benefit, how is this different from stealing? The gentleman, amidst the convergence of all directions, regards what is advantageous to things as not his own. "My mandate lies beyond"—thus he does not dare to receive and take. Like the swallow that flees men yet enters human dwellings, all under Heaven join together to establish altars for him, and this cannot be refused. This is why not receiving others’ benefit is difficult. To transform the myriad things without knowing who succeeds them is to be untransformed. How then can one know their beginning and end? There is man, and there is Heaven—both are Heaven alone. That man cannot possess Heaven’s nature—this is why there is man. To know it as Heaven is to be at ease, embodying the passing, and come to rest.)*

*(Oral Exegesis: The withered tree is the stalk; the withered branch is the switch—this is what the "Equalizing Things" chapter calls the "switch-branch." Without number, without rhythm; without gong or jue, not conforming to the five tones. To extend the self is to honor the self. To seek with the intent of honoring the self is to create boundlessness; to think with the intent of loving the self is to reach sorrow. "Man and Heaven are one"—all within me is Heaven’s principle. Not to receive Heaven’s diminishment is to be poor yet joyful; not to receive others’ benefit is to be rich yet not excessive. When Heaven’s diminishment comes, one cannot but be at ease—thus it is easy. When others’ benefit arrives, one wishes to decline but cannot—thus it is difficult. "Imprisoned and obstructed"—unable to proceed, yet if pushed, it does not leave. The outpouring of the turning of things, the coming and going of qi and destiny—all is Heaven. I too flow with it, too, and pour forth with it—thus it is said: "to flow with them," which is what is meant by "flowing with the times" and "flowing with the times to their limit." Even the ruler’s command cannot be disobeyed—how much less Heaven’s mandate? This is why not receiving Heaven’s diminishment is easy. "At first use"—when this thought first arises, all directions converge, and affairs follow without obstruction. Rank and emolument arrive from without—this too is the mandate of the times, thus it is said: "My mandate lies beyond." To receive emolument without merit is shameful to the gentleman, who regards it as stealing. Though I may wish not to take it, there are those who push it and cannot be refused—like Gongsun He, who wept upon being appointed minister. This is why not receiving others’ benefit is difficult. "Without beginning yet not without end"—though one does not know their beginning and end, one abides within the transformations of creation and awaits them. Man is born of Heaven, thus it is said: "There is man, and there is Heaven." Heaven too is created by the transformations of creation, thus it is said: "There is Heaven, and there is also Heaven." Nature is the nature of Heaven’s mandate; this nature is born with life. All that man’s nature possesses at birth is received from Heaven—how could man possess it himself? Thus the sage abides in it at ease, exhausting his life alone.)*

*(Supplementary Ink: To extend the self to the point of greatness is to go too far in extending the self; to love the self to the point of sorrow is to go too far in loving the self. Here, the principle of Heaven and man, diminishment and benefit, beginning and end, is expounded in one thread. Urgently, one must determine: who is the singer? Who is the one who equalizes things? Who is the angry one? Who is the "who"? Who can know this "who"? To know who receives and who does not receive, and to seek the truth to the end, one will see that there is no receiver, nor is there one who does not receive—yet Heaven’s decree is settled within me. If not Yanzi, who is sufficient to discuss this?)*

*(Brush Jottings: "Plowing open"—like plowing a field, the soil is loosened. Hunger and thirst, cold and heat, poverty and obstruction—all are the flowing of Heaven and Earth’s qi, the movement and outpouring that animates the myriad things and cannot be stopped. How can man escape it? One can only flow with it. The yiyi is a swallow—unable to keep up, without leisure.)*

The term "實" here aligns with the *Yijing*’s "seeking one’s own mouthful"—it is the substance of the altars of soil and grain, the time of the spring and autumn sacrifices to the altars. The noble person regards unearned rank and emolument as theft; how could he willingly take them? Yet what is ordained may leave him no choice. Thus it is said: "It is not of oneself." The mandate lies beyond. Like the swallow that perches where it ought not, though it spurns the morsel, it cannot but heed the gaze of others—its fear of men is extreme. Yet it cannot but dwell among them, for the time of the altars seems to drive it, leaving it no autonomy. The swallow comes at the spring sacrifice and departs at the autumn sacrifice, hence these words. Though the passage is not hard to understand, old commentaries are often mistaken; I have briefly clarified it.

---

Zhuang Zhou wandered into the thicket of Mount Diao-ling, where he saw an unusual magpie coming from the south. Its wings spanned seven feet; its eyes measured an inch across. It brushed Zhou’s forehead and alighted in the chestnut grove. Zhuang Zhou said, “What bird is this? Its wings are vast, yet it does not fly far; its eyes are large, yet it does not see clearly.” He hitched up his robe, strode forward, took up his sling, and waited. He saw a cicada that had found a fine shelter and forgotten its body; a mantis, seizing the shade, struck at it, seeing only its gain and forgetting its form; the strange magpie, drawn by the advantage, saw only the profit and forgot its true nature. Zhuang Zhou started and said, “Ah! Things indeed entangle one another; the two creatures summon each other’s doom.” He cast aside his sling and turned to flee, but the gamekeeper pursued him with curses. Zhuang Zhou returned home and for three months did not leave his courtyard.

Lin Qie followed and asked, “Master, why have you been so withdrawn of late?”
Zhuang Zhou said, “I guarded my form and forgot my body. I gazed at muddy water and was lost in clear depths. Moreover, I have heard from the Master: ‘When you enter a custom, follow its ways.’ Now I wandered into Diao-ling and forgot myself; the strange magpie brushed my forehead; I wandered into the chestnut grove and forgot my true nature. The gamekeeper of the chestnut grove took me for a thief. That is why I have not left my courtyard.”

*(Sima [Biao] says: “Diao-ling is the name of a mound; *fan* means ‘thicket.’”)*

"A shift of an inch may turn back an inch—this is the greatness of Yin. Twisting and turning is called *shi*; Li Yun says *yi* means great, *shi* means hard to see, and thus one does not perceive. People linger—Sima [Biao] says this means waiting for an opportunity. *Sui* means curses. ‘Three months’ should likely be ‘three days,’ as the phrase *qingjian* suggests.

Guo’s commentary: Holding a leaf to hide oneself from the cicada, one forgets the form that the strange magpie saw. The eye can see, the wing can fly—this is the bird’s true nature. Now, seeing profit, it forgets this. Those who mutually seek profit always mutually burden one another. One who desires something from things will find things desiring something from them—this is what is meant by ‘things inherently burden one another; the two *kuang* summon each other’s doom.’ *Sui* means to question. To dwell in the human world is to encounter both level ground and peril. If one applies the form of level ground to this world without measuring what is fitting for this world, this is ‘guarding the form and forgetting the body.’ ‘Gazing at muddy water and being lost in clear depths’ means seeing that and not understanding it, thus using that to see oneself and nearly forgetting the way of reflection. ‘Entering a custom and following its ways’ means not violating its prohibitions. ‘Taking me for a thief’ means taking the questioning as theft.

Zhuangzi extends impartiality to all under heaven, so he often conveys meaning through words. Thus, he disparages Confucius, belittles Lao Dan, attacks the Three Sovereigns above, and laments the suffering of his own body below.

Lü’s commentary: Following the profit of the strange magpie and pursuing the desires of the ears and eyes is ‘guarding the form.’ Not knowing that the gamekeeper’s curses are enough to bring shame is ‘forgetting the body.’ Movement and engagement with things is muddy water; stillness and profound observation is the clear abyss. The perfected person is never for a moment lost in the clear abyss, but Zhuangzi speaks of this to show that roaming the world with emptiness—like his words to the King of Wei—though sufficient to avoid harm, still fears what others fear and cannot but act accordingly.

When Master Yang traveled to Song, he lodged at an inn. The innkeeper had two concubines: one beautiful, the other ugly. The ugly one was honored, while the beautiful one was despised. Master Yang asked the reason, and the innkeeper’s servant replied, ‘The beautiful one considers herself beautiful, but I do not see her beauty. The ugly one considers herself ugly, but I do not see her ugliness.’ Master Yang said, ‘Disciples, take note: act with worthiness and discard self-regard. Where can you go and not be loved?’ (Sima [Biao] says: Master Yang is Yang Zhu.)

Guo’s commentary: The way of self-regard is never appropriate.

Zhang Zhan: Pride, arrogance, and self-praise are what the spirits do not support. Humbling oneself and following principle is what all under heaven delights in yielding to. With this, who can resist?

Xin Yi: Those who wish to preserve their nature and live out their Heaven-appointed years should forget their form externally. When the form is forgotten, what one attains and where one goes—how could there be anything not attained? This is why Master Yang valued the innkeeper’s servant’s words. ‘The beautiful one considers herself beautiful, but I do not see her beauty; the ugly one considers herself ugly, but I do not see her ugliness’—this is forgetting the form externally, so that beauty and ugliness are both forgotten. How could this not fulfill the feelings of preserving one’s nature? Thus, Zhuangzi speaks of this at the end of the chapter.

Jiang Yu: Beauty and ugliness arise from deluded perception. Honoring one and despising the other is not the true principle. What is detestable about the innkeeper’s concubine is not her beauty but her reliance on it, which leads to her being despised. What is admirable about the innkeeper is not his ability to despise the beautiful one but his not perceiving her beauty, and thus valuing her. If the innkeeper’s concubine did not rely on her beauty and discarded self-regard, then wherever she went, she would be loved. Laozi said, ‘When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness arises’—it is not that beauty is detestable, but that detesting it comes from knowing it as beauty.

General Observations: This chapter is titled after the mountain tree, echoing the meaning of the great *chu* and oak—both preserved their Heaven-appointed years by being useless. The argument is set against the goose killed for not cawing, showing that Master Nan Hua’s view of worldly conventions is well-considered.

That a tree preserves its life by being gnarled is certainly so, yet the longevity or early death, success or failure of things each depends on fate and what they encounter. One cannot say that uselessness is a rule for fortunate escape. Both usefulness and uselessness are entangled in traces; the middle path between them still involves confusion, for it resembles yet is not the true way. Thus, one cannot avoid entanglement unless one leaves these three behind, upholds the Dao and virtue, floats with things, moves with the times, transcends things and origins without entanglement, sheds the outer skin without disaster. Then the kingdom of great virtue is not far off and will come of itself.

Like an empty boat striking another—no anger arises. Like levying taxes without harming even a hair—all is met with a heartless response, and things respond in kind. The highest discourse: the hardship of Chen and Cai does not compare to the *yiyi* bird’s knowledge of the mantis and cicada, or the magpie’s unawareness of the sling and its bearer. These all dwell in usefulness but have not reached perfection, so they cannot avoid entanglement. Lin Hui abandoned his jade to carry the infant and flee. Emperor Shun ordered Yu to value form but follow the heart’s inclinations—thus knowing to honor Heaven’s bonds without relying on external things. Wearing coarse cloth and passing the King of Wei, striking a withered branch and singing to the Lord of Yan—this shows that dwelling in poverty is not exhaustion, and knowing the ease of reducing desires means others will come to benefit you. Dwelling in this has its way.

The conclusion—acting with worthiness and discarding self-regard—transcends the distinction between usefulness and uselessness and is truly the semblance of the Way."

Thus the true person does not dread repeated admonitions, urging the learner to advance another step beyond the pole’s tip.

**Chapter Twenty-One: Tian Zifang**

Tian Zifang was in attendance upon Marquis Wen of Wei. Several times he mentioned Xi Gong, and the Marquis said, “Is Xi Gong your teacher?”
Zifang replied, “No. He is a man from my village of Wuze. He speaks of the Way often and aptly, so Wuze praises him.”
The Marquis said, “Then have you no teacher?”
Zifang said, “I do.”
“Who is your teacher?”
Zifang said, “Dongguo Shunzi.”
The Marquis said, “Then why have you never mentioned him?”
Zifang said, “His way of being is this: his appearance is that of a true person, yet his nature is empty of Heaven’s artifice; he follows things while preserving his authenticity; he is clear yet accommodates others. When things lack the Way, he rectifies his bearing to awaken them, dissolving their intentions. How could Wuze be worthy of mention beside him?”
Zifang departed, and the Marquis was lost in thought all day, saying nothing. He summoned his minister to stand before him and said, “How distant indeed is the noble one of perfect virtue! At first, I took sagely wisdom and benevolent righteousness as the ultimate in words and deeds. But when I heard of Zifang’s teacher, my form dissolved and I did not wish to move; my mouth was sealed and I did not wish to speak. What I have learned is but a clod of earth. Truly, Wei has become a burden to me.”

*(Note: "lost in thought" renders the descriptive term; "clod of earth" renders "土梗," a figurative term for something insubstantial.)*

Guo Xiang’s commentary: Dongguo Shunzi’s appearance was the same as others’, yet he alone followed nature, empty and yielding to things. Thus his authenticity was never lost. The clarity of others suffers from excessive purity; his clarity accommodated things, making him one with Heaven. Clear and empty, he rectified himself, and the perversity of things dissolved of itself. “His form did not wish to move, his mouth did not wish to speak”—this was his self-awareness of his nearness. A “clod of earth” is not a true thing. “Wei has become a burden to me” means he knew that the most noble thing is to take human rank as a burden.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: His way of being was true, so his appearance was naturally that of a person yet of Heaven. The hearts of ordinary people never, for even a moment, cease to follow things; the true person is empty, following things while preserving authenticity. The clarity of ordinary people suffers from excessive scrutiny; the true person is clear yet accommodates things. When things lack the Way, he rectifies his bearing to awaken them, so what he imparts does not lie in repeated admonitions; when others’ intentions dissolve, what they reform does not lie in the midst of action. Sagely wisdom and benevolent righteousness are but words and deeds; Zifang’s teacher embodied the Dao and its virtue. Seek them in conduct and they cannot be found, so his form dissolved and he did not wish to move; seek them in speech and they cannot be found, so his mouth was sealed and he did not wish to speak. This is not something learning can attain, so he knew what he had learned was but a clod of earth.

When Wenbo Xuezi traveled to Qi, he lodged in Lu. A man of Lu requested an audience, but Wenbo Xuezi said, “No. I have heard that the noble ones of the Central States are enlightened in ritual propriety but coarse in understanding the human heart. I do not wish to meet him.”
When he returned to Qi and lodged again in Lu, the same man requested an audience. Wenbo Xuezi said, “Last time he sought to see me, and now he seeks to see me again—he must have some way to rouse me.”
He went out to meet the guest and, upon returning, sighed. The next day, he saw the guest again and, upon returning, sighed once more. His servant said, “Every time you meet this guest, you return and sigh. Why?”
He said, “I already told you: the people of the Central States are enlightened in ritual propriety but coarse in understanding the human heart. The one who saw me before advanced and retreated as if following a compass and square, moved with the dignity of a dragon or tiger. When he admonished me, it was like a son; when he guided me, it was like a father. That is why I sighed.”

Confucius met him but said nothing. Zilu said, “Master, you have long wished to see Wenbo Xuezi. Now that you have seen him, why do you not speak?”

Confucius said, “In such a man, the Way is present the moment one’s gaze falls upon him. There is no room even for words.”

Guo’s commentary: *[His advance and retreat follow compass and square; his bearing is as composed as a dragon or tiger. His steps coil and stretch, his traces meander. When he admonished me, it was like a son; when he guided me, it was like a father—such are the embellishments of ritual propriety. Seeing him and saying nothing, I already understood his heart. There is no room for words: the moment my eyes met his, my intent was conveyed, leaving no space for his virtuous resonance.]*

Lü’s commentary: *[Advance and retreat follow compass and square, so his dignity is meticulous in every turn. His bearing is as composed as a dragon or tiger, so his adaptability emerges in moments of ease. When he admonished me like a son and guided me like a father, he did not grasp me in the space between my brows—this is what is meant by ‘enlightened in ritual propriety but coarse in understanding the human heart.’ Such are the flaws of ritual propriety, and the people of Lu are especially prone to them. Dongguo Shunzi’s upright demeanor awakens things; Wenbo Xuezi’s gaze alone makes the Way present. This is how the sages and worthies of old interacted—was it not subtle indeed?]*

Yan Yuan asked Confucius, “When you walk, I walk; when you hasten, I hasten; when you run, I run; when you sprint, leaving all behind, I can only stare in your dust. Yet, Master—when you do not speak, others trust you; when you do not form alliances, others gather around you; when you have no vessels, the people dance before you. How is this so?”

Confucius said, “How can you not examine this? There is no greater sorrow than the death of the heart, and the death of the person is secondary to it. The sun rises in the east and sets in the westernmost reaches—nothing in the world does not follow its pattern. Those with eyes and feet rely on it to accomplish their tasks. When it rises, they exist; when it sets, they perish. All things are thus: they depend on it. Death depends on it, and life does too. Once I received this completed form, I did not change but awaited its end, responding to things and moving, day and night without pause, yet never knowing where it would conclude. Vague and formless, I accepted this shape. Knowing fate, I could not plan for what lay ahead. With each passing day, I age. To spend my whole life with you, only to lose you in the space of an arm’s length—is this not sorrowful? You cling to what is already gone. Seeking what is no more is like searching for a horse in a market long past. I have worn you as my garment, yet you have utterly forgotten me. Though you have forgotten, why should you worry? Even if you forget, there remains something in me that does not forget.”

Guo’s commentary: *[The heart takes death as death, thereby hastening its own demise. The swiftness of this death arises from sorrow’s self-destruction. Without sorrow, it would be nothing; with sorrow, the death of the heart is the greatest sorrow of all. All things follow the sun’s pattern—all are visible. The eye completes vision; the foot completes movement. Only what is unseen is considered perished, yet it never truly perishes. What depends on concealment is called death; what depends on manifestation is called life. In truth, there is no death or life. What cannot change from being to non-being receives its completed form, then transforms endlessly. Responding to things without intent, day and night without pause, it is ever-renewing, never knowing its end. Not taking death as death, it is as if perfumed by its own form. What more is there to do? Knowing fate is not bound to what lies ahead but moves with change—thus it passes. Change cannot be grasped or held. Though you cling to my arm, you cannot make it stay. If you mourn death, this too is cause for sorrow. Yet people do not mourn this—why mourn death alone? The market is no place to stop a horse. To seek what once was is to seek what cannot be regained. A person’s life is like a horse passing through the market—never pausing, the old and new succeed one another without cease, day and night. ‘Clinging’ means seeing what I see. What you see in me is ever-new, so what is past is already gone. How could you possess it? ‘Wearing’ means contemplating its presence. ‘Utterly forgotten’ means the past vanishes swiftly. You depart, and suddenly you think of me, always feeling you cannot keep up. You wear me as a garment, yet you too are utterly forgotten—it is the same for both. Whether worthy or sagely, none can halt this. What does not forget remains: it is nourished by daily renewal. Though you forget the old me, the new me has already arrived. It was never not me—why should you worry? Thus one can leave the俗 behind, transcend the dust, and merge with all things without obstruction.]*

Lü’s commentary: *[When you walk, I walk...]*

To hasten, to gallop—these can be pursued and overtaken. Yet when one attains trust without speech, harmony without alliance, and the people follow of themselves, advancing without knowing why—this is like one who flees in wild abandon, leaving all dust behind, while those who turn to look lag far behind.

The mind that has never known death does not recognize death. Only when the mind dies does the person die in turn—this is the greatest sorrow. The sun rises in the east and sets in the west; all things follow its course, yet only those with eyes and feet depend on it to accomplish their ends. When it rises, they exist; when it sets, they perish—yet the sun itself knows neither existence nor extinction. Things depend on it for life and death, but what they depend on has never known life or death. Thus, my trust without speech, my harmony without alliance, my people’s spontaneous following—all come down to this alone.

If I were to receive my completed form and remain unchanged, awaiting exhaustion, acting in accord with things day and night without respite, then I too would depend on things for life, like all the myriad beings. How could I embody what I depend on and reach the point of not knowing why it is so? If I were to pass my days thus, unchanging, awaiting exhaustion—would that not be cause for sorrow? Indeed, there is no greater sorrow.

You seek the place where I flee in wild abandon, leaving all dust behind, yet find nothing—is this not clinging? What you cling to, I do not see. What I do not cling to—how could the human mind, which grasps or abandons, possesses or loses, ever find something to cling to? That has already vanished. To seek it as if it still exists is no different from searching for a horse in an empty market. The market is where horses pass through, not where they dwell.

I wear you, yet utterly forget you—thus, what is called "I" no longer exists. You wear me, yet utterly forget me—thus, what is called "you" no longer exists. Why then should you worry about utter forgetting? Though you forget the old me, what is not forgotten remains. Thus, the one who flees in wild abandon, leaving all dust behind, can be seen.

Following the Root says: "I clasped arms with you, yet lost you—from that moment, there has been no step where I did not accompany you. I have shown you this Way all my life, yet now you say it is unattainable. It is as if we never clasped both arms, only one, and then lost each other—is this not cause for sorrow?

What you speak of is but the fleeting appearances of me that you see."

Seeing is but seeing—yet that Master exists unto himself. He has already attained perfect purity and emptiness, while you seek him as though he were something substantial, like searching for a horse in the market. The market is indeed where horses are sold, yet how can horses be constantly present there? As the *Book of Songs* says: "In the central path, there are tiles." The central path is the road through the courtyard, for the market where horses are sold must have a road to allow the horses’ entry and exit. The *Book of Han* records that west of the Jianzhang Palace lay a central path spanning dozens of *li*. Yang Xiong’s *Preface to the "Rhapsody on the Imperial Hunt"* speaks of "sweet dew descending in its courtyard, sweet springs flowing through its path," and Ban Gu’s *Rhapsody on the Western Capital* says, "before the central path, behind the Great Pond"—all referring to this same "path." *Fu* means to wear or bear. My bearing your words and your bearing my words—both should be utterly forgotten. Yet I fear Yan Yuan will worry he may never attain this. Still, why should you worry? Within forgetting, there remains that which is not forgotten. What is forgotten is attachment; what is not forgotten is the utmost truth. If you completely forget my old teachings, then the attainment of no-attainment becomes true attainment, and what is called "not forgotten" resides precisely here.

Confucius visited Lao Dan. Lao Dan had just bathed and was letting his hair dry, standing still as though he were not human. Confucius withdrew and waited. After a while, he saw him and said, "Was I deluded, or is it truly so? Just now, Master, your form and body stood like withered wood, as if you had left things behind and stood apart from others in solitude." Lao Dan said, "I let my mind wander in the beginning of things." Confucius asked, "What do you mean?" Lao Dan replied, "The mind is blocked and cannot know; the mouth is shut and cannot speak. Let me try to explain it to you. It approaches utmost yin, so still and silent; it approaches utmost yang, so blazing and bright. Stillness and silence emerge from Heaven; blazing brightness arises from Earth."

The two of Heaven and Earth intermingle to form harmony, and from this all things are born. Some take this as their guiding principle, yet none see its form. The ebb and flow of fullness and emptiness, the alternation of darkness and light—each day transforms, each month changes. There is action, yet none see its work. Life has its source of sprouting; death has its place of return. Beginning and end stand in opposition, yet without origin, none know where it ends. Is this not the ultimate?

Confucius said, "May I ask about wandering in this state?"

Lao Dan said, "To attain this is the utmost beauty, the utmost joy. Having attained the utmost beauty, one wanders in the utmost joy—this is called the Perfect Person."

Confucius said, "I wish to hear the method."

Lao Dan replied, "Beasts that feed on grass do not resent changing marshes; creatures born in water do not resent changing streams. They undergo small changes yet do not lose their great constancy. Joy, anger, sorrow, and delight do not enter their breast. Thus, the world and the myriad things are unified in the One. If one attains this unity and becomes one with it, then the four limbs and hundred parts of the body become mere dust and grime, while life and death, beginning and end, become like day and night—nothing can disturb them. How much less could the distinctions of gain and loss, fortune and misfortune intrude? Those who discard servitude do so as if casting off mud and mire, knowing the body is nobler than servitude. Nobility lies within oneself and is not lost amid change. Moreover, the myriad transformations have never had an end—who could trouble the heart of one who has already become the Dao? Such a one is freed."

Confucius said, "Master, your virtue matches Heaven and Earth, yet you still rely on profound words to cultivate the mind. Of the ancients, who could surpass this?"

Lao Dan said, "Not so. Water, when poured, acts without contrivance, yet its nature is spontaneous. The Perfect Person, in relation to virtue, does not cultivate it, yet things cannot depart from it. Like Heaven, which is naturally high; Earth, which is naturally thick; the sun and moon, which are naturally bright—what cultivation is needed?

Confucius departed and told Yan Hui, "In my relation to the Dao, am I not like a vinegar fly? How slight is the Master’s unfolding of my covering! I did not know the great completeness of Heaven and Earth."

Guo’s commentary:
To be "zhé" is to seem not of human stillness and desolation in their utmost—having left things and departed from others to stand alone. Only when mind and body are absent do external things depart. At the beginning, there was nothing, then suddenly there was existence, roaming in the origin of things, and only then does one realize that things do not act but exist of themselves. The heart is troubled, the mouth agape—this is to urge Confucius to seek beyond words and meanings. As for "discussing," it is but an attempt to discuss yin and yang to approximate the formless of earlier times. I dare not be certain. "Issuing from Heaven, emerging from Earth" speaks of their intercourse. No visible structure marks its form, yet it is so of itself. "Changing by day, transforming by month" never clings to the old. No sign of its work is seen, for it is so of itself and thus without work. Birth sprouts from what has not yet gathered; death returns to dispersion—this is what is meant by "meeting it, one does not see its head; following it, one does not see its tail." Attaining the utmost beauty and roaming in the utmost joy—there is no beauty or joy in them. Death and life are but small changes. Knowing them as small changes, one does not lose the great constancy; thus joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness do not enter the breast. Knowing the body is nobler than a servant, one discards it like dust. If one knows that the changes of death and life are all within the self, then what is noble is the self, and the self moves with change—thus nothing is lost. Is one who has already become the Dao freed from this? This is what is called "suspended liberation." Lao Dan said that Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon, all do not cultivate or act yet attain of themselves. The "vinegar fly" is the midge in the jar. Confucius said that his completeness compared to Lao Dan’s was like the jar compared to Heaven and Earth.

Lü’s commentary:
Before things began to be, in rising, sitting, speaking, or silence—what was not roaming in the origin of things? The heart is troubled, and thus it is not what knowledge can know; the mouth is agape, and thus it is not what words can express. To "discuss" it is not to reach its utmost. Yin and yang intermingle to form harmony, and things are born. Whether distant as the year or near as the day, whether external as the myriad things or internal as the single body, all possess this. Some take it as their structure, yet no form is seen. Growth and decay, change and transformation—it is thus and no more. Birth sprouts, death returns; beginning and end are without end—it is thus and no more. What was earlier called the origin of things is likely this. What the world calls beauty and joy is not the utmost beauty and joy. Only by attaining this does one reach the utmost beauty and joy. The beast’s ease in the marsh, the fish’s ease in water—these are small changes that do not lose the great constancy of marsh and water. One who attains this and roams in it—nothing in the world is not unified and the same. Thus death and life cannot disturb it, let alone the trifles of gain and loss, fortune and misfortune. Knowing the body is nobler than a servant, what is noble is within the self. Though small changes occur, how could one lose what is noble for the sake of what is base? The boundlessness of the myriad things—how could it burden the heart? Is one who has already become the Dao freed from this? This is the reason.

One who can preserve the Dao wholly is thus able to preserve fate wholly—when fate is preserved, there is no greater joy. The Dao is the utmost beauty in the world; fate is the utmost joy of the myriad things. The utmost beauty emerges from the Dao yet cannot be seen when beheld; the utmost joy emerges from fate yet cannot be grasped when sought. One who enters the Dao can thereby preserve fate; one who possesses beauty can thereby possess joy. These two cannot be fully attained except by the perfected person. Thus it is said: to obtain the utmost beauty and roam in the utmost joy is to be a perfected person.

The *Blue Void* says:
The withered tree, detached from things—this describes one who conceals essence and stores spirit. Forsaking companions, standing alone—this describes one who severs duality and enters the vast. Roaming in the origin of things, never departing from its source.

To imitate knowledge is to weary the heart; to desire speech is to stammer the mouth. Departing from the heart and forgetting words—this comes close. The solemn yin qi descends below; the blazing yang qi ascends above. The two forces intermingle and harmonize, and the myriad things wondrously transform—this is called having a guiding principle. Yet no form is seen, no signs appear; its ebb and flow follow number, its obscurity and brightness follow constancy—this is called having creation and action. Yet no effort is discerned, no function perceived. In life, it sprouts from the indistinct; in death, it returns to the profound darkness. Without beginning, none know its origin; without end, none know its limit. If not for this Dao, what could serve as the master and lord of things?

Confucius again asked how one roams in this. To study the Dao—what is there to gain? To gain its utmost beauty and utmost joy is all. Regarding death and life, it is like the beast’s ease in the marsh, the fish’s ease in water—a fleeting, minor change. Why lament it?

The world is a crucible that fuses the myriad things into one. Viewed from what they share, even one’s own hundred limbs are but stench and rot. This life and death are like waking and dreaming—how much more so all else?

Thus, viewing the reins of governance and the trappings of rank is like the beast’s shift of marsh or the fish’s shift of water—this is what is called "external transformation while the inner remains untransformed." Nobility lies within me; it has never ceased to be mine. Its joy knows no bounds—how could there be suffering? It is like water, drawn and poured, ever flowing and beneficent—what need is there for contrivance? The perfected person’s virtue and power spread far and wide—what need is there for cultivation or regulation? It is like the height of heaven, the depth of earth, the brightness of sun and moon—what need is there for refinement?

Therefore, the Master compared himself to a jar or a gnat, casting off all coverings to recognize the great wholeness of heaven and earth.

---

Zhuangzi visited Duke Ai of Lu. The Duke said, "In Lu, there are many Confucians but few who follow your Way."

Zhuangzi replied, "Lu has few Confucians."

The Duke said, "The entire state of Lu wears the garb of Confucians—how can you say there are few?"

Zhuangzi said, "I have heard that Confucians wear round caps to know the seasons, square shoes to know the earth’s forms, and jade pendants at their belts to act with caution when matters arise. Those who possess the Dao may not wear its garb, and those who wear its garb may not know the Dao. If you truly believe otherwise, why not issue a decree throughout the state: 'Those who lack this Dao yet wear its garb shall be put to death'?"

The Duke issued the decree for five days, and no one in Lu dared wear the Confucian garb—save for one man, who stood at the palace gate in full Confucian attire. The Duke summoned him and questioned him on state affairs. Though the questions shifted a thousand ways, his answers never faltered.

Zhuangzi said, "In all of Lu, there is but one Confucian—can this be called many?"

---

Guo’s commentary: *One whose virtue is full within does not adorn the outer.*
Lü’s commentary: *Zhuangzi often borrowed Confucius’ questions to disciples of Laozi to show that so-called sagely wisdom does not exhaust the utmost Dao. Without these words, scholars would have no way to know the true worth of revering Confucius.*

---

Baili Xi’s rank and emoluments did not enter his heart, so when he fed cattle, the cattle grew fat. This made Duke Mu of Qin forget his lowly status and entrust him with governance. The Lord of Yu did not let life and death enter his heart, so he was able to move others.

Guo’s commentary: *One who is self-content within preserves all things without.*
Lü’s commentary: *Whether in small matters like Baili Xi’s rise to power or great ones like the Lord of Yu’s influence, none who let external things enter their hearts have ever reached such heights.*

---

When the Lord of Song was about to have a painting made, all the court artists arrived, bowed, and stood in attendance. Half had already prepared their brushes and mixed their ink, but one artist arrived late. He strolled in unhurriedly, without haste, and did not stand after bowing. The Lord sent someone to observe him and found him in his quarters, stripped to the waist, legs splayed like a winnowing basket.

The Lord said, "He will do—this is a true painter."

Guo’s commentary: *One who is inwardly sufficient is at ease in spirit and settled in mind.*

---

King Wen was observing at Zang when he saw an old man fishing. Yet his fishing was no fishing—he held the rod not to catch fish, but because fishing was his way of fishing.

The old man’s fishing was his constant way. King Wen wished to raise him and entrust him with governance, yet feared his ministers and elders would not accept it. He wished to let the matter rest, yet could not bear that the people would be left without a ruler. Thus, at dawn he gathered his ministers and said: *"Formerly, I dreamed of a worthy man, dark of complexion and with a full beard, riding a dappled horse with one red hoof. He called out, ‘Entrust governance to the old man of Zang—perhaps the people may yet recover.’"*

The ministers, startled, said: *"This was the former lord, our king!"*

King Wen replied: *"Then let us divine it."*
The ministers said: *"The former lord’s command—what further divination is needed?"*

Thereupon, they welcomed the old man of Zang and entrusted him with governance. He altered no laws, issued no unilateral decrees. After three years, King Wen surveyed the realm: the ranks of scholars had dissolved, factions dispersed; officials no longer cultivated virtue; and grain measures dared not cross the four borders. When the ranks of scholars dissolved and factions dispersed, it was because all esteemed unity. When officials no longer cultivated virtue, it was because all shared the same purpose. When grain measures dared not cross the four borders, it was because the feudal lords harbored no divided loyalties.

King Wen then bowed northward and asked him as Grand Preceptor: *"Can governance extend to all under Heaven?"*
The old man of Zang remained silent and gave no answer. That evening, he fled in the night and was never heard from again.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: *"Was King Wen still not enlightened? Why then did he rely on a dream?"*
Confucius said: *"Be still and say no more. King Wen had already perfected it—what need is there for further criticism? He merely followed the moment."*

The annotations state:
*"Pian Zhu Ti Li" refers to a horse with one red hoof. "Zhi" means ranks. "San qun" means not nurturing followers. "Bu cheng de" means not pursuing merit or fame, as Sima explains. "Six hu four dou" is called a yu-measure.*

Guo's commentary:
*Not holding to his fishing—where the fisherman ultimately seeks nothing—nor weighing gain and loss in his mind, he merely borrowed fishing as a guise. "Esteeming unity" refers to what is called "blending one’s light and merging with the dust." "Not perfecting virtue" then means "sharing the same tasks," for one who purifies and completes oneself naturally differs from the common pursuits. "Grain measures dare not cross the borders" means that all under Heaven trust one another, thus unifying standards of measurement, weights, and balances. One who achieves merit does not claim it for oneself; thus, when the task is accomplished, one must withdraw, and when the name is established, one must depart. Only when name departs and self retreats can governance extend to all under Heaven. "King Wen perfected it" means he entrusted matters to his ministers rather than taking them upon himself—this is what "perfecting" means. "The moment" refers to the interval when the people’s sentiments are on the verge of awakening but have not yet done so; thus, King Wen followed and elicited it to align with their fundamental disposition.*

Lü's commentary:
*Knowing that the man of Zang was capable of governance, he grasped it in the space between fishing and not fishing. He entrusted it to a dream and set it by divination, yet did not divine—above, fearing the unease of great ministers and elders, and below, fearing the people’s loss of Heaven’s mandate. The laws and statutes, the Six Canons and Eight Regulations, were received from the Son of Heaven; this was the Way of a single state. If no decrees were issued domestically, they could then be shared with the feudal lords before being extended—this is how governance could reach all under Heaven. "Dissolving ranks" means dismantling the factions one has established. "Grain measures" means not adhering to the ancient standards of measurement.*

Bixu's notes:
*"Fishing and not fishing" refers to the straight hook, using fishing as a pretext while awaiting the right moment. "Dissolving ranks and dispersing followers" means that when the state is well-governed, loyal ministers no longer need to admonish from behind crumbling walls. "Officials not perfecting virtue" means the people are pure and governance is simple. "Grain measures not crossing borders" means the times are harmonious and the years abundant. "Esteeming unity" means ruler and ministers share one heart. "Sharing the same tasks" means the four classes of people engage in their proper occupations.*

Xun's edition:
*"Fishing the fishable" means angling for what can be caught—namely, fish. "Ordinary fishing" means casually casting a line without intent. It is not that he held his fishing rod to catch fish but rather that he had no intention of fishing, merely casting his line as usual. "No decrees issued" means he never issued a single command. "Dissolving ranks" means dismantling what one has established, not seeking to stand apart from others. This follows the example of Lü Wang, though it does not explicitly name him.*

Liu's summary:
*In the Three Dynasties, the straight Way was practiced. Knowing the man of Zang was virtuous, entrusting governance to him would have sufficed—why resort to a dream to convince the ministers?*

For one who knows the Dao, they must penetrate principle and understand adaptability—this is the Dao of Heaven. Self-trust is permissible; adaptability to others is indispensable—how could it be abandoned? Confucius and King Wen fully embodied this, yet even Yanzi fell short in some respects. Thus, the dream of Gaozong was not without reason. Gaozong was precisely one who "practiced the straight Way." His spirit reached in all four directions, flowing in unison with Heaven and Earth. The verification of utmost sincerity in the interplay of Heaven and humanity is like shadow and echo. That he dreamed of bestowing a worthy assistant is hardly cause for doubt.

Zhuangzi’s parable suggests that King Wen, wishing to demonstrate adaptability, examined antiquity to validate the present, hence feigning a dream to convince others. Some scholars, extrapolating from the discourse on Zang the Elder, apply it to Fu Yue—this is mistaken.

**Personal Observations:**
The character *fu* (夫) in *fufu* (夫夫) should be read as *tai* (大), as in the Qin Shi Huang stele inscription. The seal script forms of *fu* (夫) and *da* (大) closely resemble one another.

*Planting* (植) refers to what Fan Wulu calls border markers—wooden stakes erected as boundaries, like the Elm Pass and Willow Barrier. *Dismantling ranks* (坏植) means disbanding troops and withdrawing defenses, merging neighboring domains into one—this is the custom of *shangtong* (尚同).

In Yue Yi’s letter to the King of Yan, he writes: "The plantings of Jiqiu were relocated to the bamboo groves of the Wen River." Xu Guang’s annotation explains that Yan’s borders were moved to the Wen River in Qi, where boundary markers were established.

When Lie Yukou shot for Bohun Wuren, he drew the bow to its fullest, balanced a cup of water on his elbow, and loosed the arrow. The arrow struck the target, and the next followed in its wake—at that moment, he was like a wooden figurine. Bohun Wuren said, "This is the shooting of one who shoots, not the shooting of one who does not shoot. Let me ascend a high mountain with you, tread upon perilous rocks, and stand at the edge of a hundred-fathom abyss—could you still shoot then?"

Thereupon, Bohun Wuren climbed the high mountain, stepped onto the treacherous rocks, and stood at the brink of the sheer drop. Turning, he retreated until his heels hung over the edge, then bowed and beckoned Lie Yukou forward. Lie Yukou prostrated himself, drenched in sweat down to his heels. Bohun Wuren said, "The perfected person gazes upward into the azure sky, delves downward into the Yellow Springs, and roams to the eight limits—yet their spirit and qi remain unchanged. Now you tremble, your eyes dart about in fear. Your inner state is perilous indeed!"

*Guan* (贯), as Sima explains, refers to the arrowhead.

"Xun" (*Er Ya* glosses as "xunli," meaning trembling), referring to the darting of the eyes. He Chengtian’s *Zuan* states: "The people of Wu call the blinking of eyes 'xunmu.'" Guo’s commentary: "Ying guan" means the arrowhead is full; the left hand is steady as a cabinet, the right hand firm as a branch. The right hand releases the shot while the left hand remains unaware—thus one may place a cup of water upon it. "Shi shi fu ta" means the arrow, once loosed, returns in rapid succession. "Fang shi fu yu" describes how the previous arrow has not yet reached the target when the next is already lodged in the cup on the elbow, illustrating the marvel of such swiftness. "Xiang ren" refers to the perfection of stillness. "Huichi" means to roam freely.

When virtue fills the inner self, spirit brims outward, and no place—whether distant or near, hidden or deep—remains obscure. Thus one discerns the pivot of danger and safety yet remains serene and self-possessed. Failing to grasp this ultimate distinction, one succumbs to fear, and in fear, much is lost. How could this apply only to archery?

Lü’s commentary: "Yin zhi ying guan" refers to the fullness of the draw; "zhi zhou cuo beishui" to the perfect levelness of the elbow bearing the cup. The first arrow is loosed, and as it returns in succession, the next arrow is already lodged in the cup—this describes the seamless continuity of the shots. "Xiang ren" means the mind is undivided. This is the archery of shooting, not the archery of non-shooting. The latter is what is called "the preservation of pure qi," not a matter of knowledge, skill, or boldness. Thus, when ascending mountains or facing abysses, the mind remains unmoved, and every shot finds its mark. To roam freely to the eight limits with spirit and qi unchanged is only fitting.

Jiang Yu’s commentary: The archery of shooting aims at what lies beyond; the archery of non-shooting abides in what lies within. The former is sometimes possible, sometimes not; the latter admits no impossibility. In this, one resembles the "xiang ren," for there is nothing to fear. The one who prostrates and sweats does so because the heart clings to pride. The mountain’s height, the rock’s peril, the abyss’s depth—none of these inherently harm a person. Those who tread upon them do not necessarily meet disaster. Yet when one clings to life, pursues external things, or hoards pride, no calamity is beyond reach. In the end, things cannot harm one, but one’s own heart brings harm upon itself, even to the point of losing life, and still one does not awaken. The perfected person, however, does not stray from the true. In ascending and treading, they differ not from others—only in their inner preservation of pure qi, unaware of any height or depth to fear. Thus, they go anywhere as the "xiang ren," roaming freely to the eight limits with spirit and qi unchanged. This is all there is to it.

*Bi Sheng*: Luo Miandao says: "Shi shi fu ta" means the arrow, once loosed, returns in succession to the previous one. "Fang shi fu yu" means the next arrow is already lodged in the cup as the current one is released. Fan Wulu argues that "fang shi" is like "fang zhou" (parallel boats), meaning the arrows are held side by side, already resting in the cup—not that the cup of water is placed on the elbow. Guo’s interpretation is incorrect.

Jianwu asked Sunshu Ao, "You have thrice served as Prime Minister yet show no pride, and thrice been dismissed without sorrow. At first, I doubted you, but now I see your countenance so carefree—how do you cultivate your mind?"

Sunshu Ao replied, "How do I surpass others? I accept what comes, for it cannot be refused, and let go of what departs, for it cannot be stopped."

I hold that gain and loss are not of me, and so I show no sorrowful countenance—how do I surpass others? Moreover, I know not whether it lies in that other or in myself, whether it lies in that other and is lost to me, or lies in myself and is lost to that other. That one may hesitate, may look all around—what leisure has he to know? Is man noble and man base?

Confucius heard of this and said: "The true person of old—sages could not sway them with persuasion, beauties could not seduce them with excess, thieves could not plunder them by force, Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor could not befriend them. Life and death are indeed great, yet they undergo no change—how much less, then, rank and emolument? Such a one’s spirit threads through the great mountains without obstruction, abides in deep springs without wetting, dwells in the lowly and minute without weariness. It fills heaven and earth, and the more it is given to others, the more it possesses."

The King of Chu sat with the Lord of Fan. After a while, the King of Chu’s attendants said, "Fan has perished three times." The Lord of Fan replied, "Fan’s perishing is not enough to lose what I preserve. If Fan’s perishing is not enough to lose what I preserve, then Chu’s preservation is not enough to preserve what is preserved." From this perspective, Fan has never truly perished, and Chu has never truly existed.

**General Remarks on the Text:**
This chapter begins with Master Zifang’s teaching, where a countenance of heaven and virtue’s latent radiance—beyond all praise—was sufficient to awaken the Marquis Wen to the error of his learning and the burden of Wei’s state. Such is the power of a virtuous teacher: a single word awakens the ruler. Why fear, then, that the Way will not be established or the self not stand firm?

Confucius, upon meeting Wenbo Xuezi, perceived the Dao in a mere glance—thus the moment of enlightenment did not lie in the tedium of didactic instruction. When Yanzi marveled at the transcendent, leaving all dust behind, his gaze fixed upon what lay beyond, the great transformation had already shifted imperceptibly. Why seek it only in the fleeting instant when an opportunity slips through one’s grasp? Laozi wandered at the origin of things, while Confucius recognized his detachment from men and independence—such encounters with the wondrous were so profound that further questioning would have been superfluous. Yet without seizing the moment to expound the principle, how could later learners be enlightened? Thus, he elucidated the mysteries of yin-yang harmonizing and the generation of beings, tracing their sprouts to their ultimate return, so that all might grasp the great wholeness of heaven and earth and forget the petty changes of the bodily form. Such was the sagely heart of enriching the Dao and aiding all things.

When Duke Ai remarked that Lu had many Ru scholars, he judged by robes and caps; Zhuangzi examined their conduct and substance, thus finding them wanting. Yet when Confucius was hailed throughout the state and stood alone, it revealed that the true Dao is indestructible while false learning fades easily. How could the clear mirror of discernment be deceived? When King Wen raised the Elder of Zang, governance was achieved, yet he fled by night—this showed that those with intent to govern must urgently employ the worthy, while those who respond to things without attachment do not cling to achievement. The Way of ruler and minister reaches its perfection here, setting a standard for ten thousand generations.

As for Bohun, who observed Lie Yukou through archery, or the minister Shu Ao, who was dismissed thrice yet showed no distress—these were men of ultimate destiny, detached from men and merged with heaven, one with transformation, casting off the eight directions, unmoved by life or death. Only when learning the Dao reaches this point can it be called ultimate; otherwise, one merely pursues externals while endangering the inner self. In the end, the parable of the King of Chu and the lord whose state and self rise and fall clarifies the distinction between things and self, inner and outer—truly one who knows the weight of priorities.

*Knowing Northward Wandering, Chapter Twenty-Two*

At the Black Waters, Knowing Northward Wandered. Ascending the mound of Kunfen, he chanced upon Non-Action Spoken. Knowing said to Non-Action Spoken, "I wish to ask you: how does one think, how does one contemplate to know the Dao? Where does one abide, what does one practice to be at peace with the Dao? From what does one proceed, by what path does one attain the Dao?" Three questions he posed, yet Non-Action Spoken made no reply. Not that he would not answer—he did not know how to answer.
