Knowing, having gained no answer, returned south of the White Waters. Ascending Fox Tower, he saw Mad Qu. Knowing repeated his questions to Mad Qu. Mad Qu said, "Ah! I know it—I would tell you, but mid-speech I forget what I wished to say."

Knowing, having gained no answer, returned to the Emperor’s palace and questioned the Yellow Emperor. The Yellow Emperor said, "Without thought, without contemplation—only then does one begin to know the Dao. Without abiding, without practice—only then does one begin to be at peace with the Dao. Without proceeding, without path—only then does one begin to attain the Dao."

Knowing asked the Yellow Emperor, "You and I know it; they and they do not. Which of us is right?" The Yellow Emperor said, "That Non-Action Spoken—he is truly so. Mad Qu resembles him. You and I, in the end, do not approach it. For the knowing do not speak; the speaking do not know. Thus the sage enacts the teaching without words. The Dao cannot be attained; virtue cannot be reached. Benevolence may be practiced; righteousness may be diminished; ritual is mutual pretense.

Thus it is said: Lose the Dao, then virtue follows; lose virtue, then benevolence follows; lose benevolence, then righteousness follows; lose righteousness, then ritual follows. Ritual is the flower of the Dao and the beginning of chaos. Thus it is said: One who practices the Dao daily diminishes—diminishes again and again, until one reaches non-action. With non-action, there is nothing that is not done. Now that one has become a thing, to return again to the root—is this not difficult? How easy it is—only for the great person!"

Life is the companion of death; death is the beginning of life. Who knows their order? The life of humans is the gathering of qi—gathered, it becomes life; scattered, it becomes death. If death and life are companions, what cause for distress have I?

All things are one. What they deem wondrous is called "spirit-like marvel"; what they despise is called "foul decay." Yet foul decay transforms into spirit-like marvel, and spirit-like marvel transforms into foul decay. Thus it is said: Throughout the world, there is but a single qi.

Therefore the sage values oneness.

Huangdi said: "I asked Wuweiwei. Wuweiwei did not respond to me—not that he would not respond, but that he did not know how to respond. I asked Kuang Qu. Kuang Qu wished to tell me but did not tell me—not that he would not tell me, but that in wishing to tell, he forgot it.

Now I ask you: You know it—why then are we not close?"

Huangdi said: "He is truly right because he does not know. This one resembles it because he forgets. You and I will never be close because you know."

Kuang Qu heard this and regarded Huangdi as one who knew words.

[Guo's commentary: To let things follow their own course is the teaching without words. The Dao resides in spontaneity and cannot be attained through speech. Not losing virtue is called "virtue," yet to speak of virtue is not to reach it. Ritual has its constants, from which arise the distortions of affectation. Daily diminishing is the shedding of artificial adornments. When adornments are gone and simplicity is whole, though one acts, it is as if one does not act. Things lose their proper place, hence there is action. The ease of returning to the root belongs only to the great person. The great person embodies transformation, thus transforming things is not difficult.

Those who know the Dao of transformation do not regard life and death as distinct, for they alternate as beginnings. If both are but gatherings, both are but scatterings—why should I be distressed? Distress arises from distinction. Each takes what it cherishes as spirit-like marvel and what it detests as foul decay. Yet what one cherishes, another may detest; what one detests, another may cherish. Thus all share in spirit-like marvel, all share in foul decay. In life and death, self and other—how are they different?

To take not-knowing as true is to know; to take knowing as closeness is to be far from it. Clearly, spontaneity is not something attainable through words or knowledge. One must dwell in the realm of wordlessness. First, the standard of wordlessness is raised; then clarity is entrusted to Huangdi, so that the obscurity of spontaneity may be guarded against and made visible.]

Lü’s Annotation:
The Dao has no fixed direction, thus it cannot be attained; to seek attainment is to summon it to come. Virtue resides within me, thus it cannot be reached; to seek arrival is to go from self to other. Virtue is non-action, yet benevolence may be enacted. Benevolence then becomes what is esteemed, while righteousness may be diminished. Ritual is performed, yet none respond—flailing arms and forcing compliance is but mutual pretense, the very source of chaos. Therefore, those who practice the Dao daily diminish until they reach non-action, whereupon benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music cannot but perish. Yet when non-action becomes all-action, which of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, or music is not the Dao? Now that one has become a thing, one possesses knowledge and desires to return to the root—is this not difficult? The great person shines brilliantly, and things cannot obscure them; returning to the root amid the teeming multitudes is but an easy matter. Birth and death, beginning and end—without origin, without order—qi gathers to form life, qi scatters to form death. To know that the gathering and scattering of qi are transient—what cause for distress? Thus the myriad things are one. What one cherishes is deemed spirit-like marvel, what one detests is deemed foul decay—these two transform into one another. From this, we know that all under heaven shares a single qi, which is why the sage values unity.

Bi Xu:
To withdraw sight and reverse hearing, all existents are empty. To take knowledge as right and ignorance as wrong is to compound error. Moreover, true reality and true knowing are both obstacles to the Dao, the most difficult to remove. One must first diminish knowledge, then diminish ignorance, until reaching non-knowing. Only after no-diminishing does non-action arise, and in non-action, nothing is not done. In non-action, there is no self—is this not the great person? Only by forgetting life can death not bind; only by forgetting death can one recover the source of life. To regard life and death as a single thread—what aversion or attachment could find leisure?

Brush Strokes:
Non-action is called true reality, for it does not speak. Huangdi’s distance from it arises from his speech. This clinging to appearances and contention over them—this is the great matter. Huangdi’s relation to the Dao is no less than that of non-action. In the *Vimalakīrti Sutra*, when the bodhisattvas discussed the Dharma-gate of non-duality, Vimalakīrti alone remained silent. His intent was that silence is supreme. Yet when Śāriputra remained silent, the goddess did not approve, saying: "The liberated one is neither within nor without, nor between the two. Speech and scripture are likewise neither within nor without, nor between the two. Therefore, one does not depart from speech and scripture to speak of the marks of liberation." Knowing this, speech and silence are one, knowing and not-knowing are one. Thought and reflection may also lead to the Dao; dwelling in a place and wearing robes may also accord with the Dao; following and guiding may also attain the Dao. Why? Because when thought is utterly empty, dwelling and robes have no place; when there is no following, there is no Dao to follow—yet the Dao is not truly a Dao.

Heaven and earth possess great beauty yet do not speak; the four seasons have bright patterns yet do not debate; the myriad things have completed principles yet do not explain. The sage traces the beauty of heaven and earth and penetrates the principles of the myriad things. Thus the perfected person practices non-action, and the great sage does not act—this is called observing heaven and earth. Now, that numinous clarity and utmost refinement, along with the hundred transformations of things—life and death, square and round—none know their root. Yet suddenly, the myriad things have existed since antiquity. The six directions are vast, yet nothing lies beyond their bounds; the autumn down is minute, yet it awaits completion to form a body. All under heaven floats and sinks, never constant throughout life. Yin and yang, the four seasons, move in their courses, each maintaining its order. Obscure yet not absent, effortless yet spirit-like, the myriad things are nurtured without awareness—this is called the root. Through it, one may observe heaven.

Guo’s Annotation:
Non-action means allowing things to act of themselves; not-acting is merely following and yielding. To observe heaven and earth is to observe their forms and emulate their fittingness, so as to be no different from them. To be with the hundred transformations is to let the hundred things transform themselves while the numinous does not seize control. The dead have already died of themselves; the living have already lived of themselves. The round have already become round of themselves; the square have already become square of themselves. None has acted upon their root, thus none knows it. "Since antiquity, they have existed of themselves" means they do not depend on action to exist. "The six directions have not departed from their bounds" is a crude calculation—if one reckons the six directions within the boundless, it is shallow. "The autumn down awaits completion to form a body" means that though the autumn down is small, it is not nothing, nor can it contain its own substance. "Never constant" means daily renewal. "Moving in their courses, each maintaining its order" means they do not depend on action.

The manifestly existent is already lost—thus, in obscurity and purity, when form appears, numinosity is gone. Therefore, when qi accumulates smoothly yet fails to grasp the root of its inherent nature, one does not know by what it is accumulated.

To observe Heaven is to observe in unison with Heaven.

---

**Lü’s Commentary:**
That Heaven and Earth act without action yet lack nothing is the great beauty. The four seasons transform and alternate, beginning and ending without confusion—this is the luminous model. Though the myriad things are many, the Dao is present in all—this is the principle of completion. Beauty fills their midst; models can be emulated; principles reach everywhere without obstruction—all return to the Dao alone. The sage traces beauty to its source, comprehends principle, and knows that what is not acted upon exists naturally. Thus, observing Heaven and Earth suffices.

Now, the numinous and most refined, along with the hundred transformations—if one regards them as things, those things have already died, lived, become round, or become square. How could one know their root? Yet though unseen, the ten thousand things are none other than it. Since antiquity, it has inherently existed—it has never departed. Yin and yang, the four seasons, each attain their order. If not for it, who would act? If it were lost yet present, formless yet numinous, it could not be sought between existence and non-existence. The myriad things interpenetrate through this yet do not know why—this is called the root.

---

**Personal Reflection:**
Does the sage embody Heaven and Earth to nurture the myriad things merely as an inert, actionless block like a wooden puppet? No—acting yet without acting, creating yet without creating, like the movement of celestial seasons or the nurturing of earthly fertility, it does not transgress naturalness. Aligning with Heaven and Earth’s numinous and most refined, the flourishing and withering forms of the hundred transformations are clearly visible, yet none know who acts. This is what is called the root.

Though unseen, the ten thousand things are its very essence—this is the meaning of "the teeming multitude." Since antiquity, the Dao has inherently existed, unchanging. Thus, vast, it pervades the six directions; minute, it enters the autumn down. With things, it flows in the same current, daily renewed. Yin and yang move together in order. If lost yet present, it is dimly discernible as something; if formless yet numinous, it is obscurely manifest in clarity. The myriad things are all born and nurtured through this, yet do not know it as their root. What is called the root—how could it be sought elsewhere? Returning to one’s own body, one finds what gives life—this is it. Knowing the root and abiding by it without departure is called "returning to the root." Returning to the root is called "tranquility"; tranquility is called "reverting to destiny." Destiny is Heaven. Thus, it is said: one can observe Heaven.

Beigyi was asked about the Dao by Nie Que. Beigyi said: "Align your form, unify your gaze—Heaven’s harmony will arrive. Gather your knowledge, unify your measure—the spirit will come. Abiding in virtue will beautify you; the Dao will reside within you. Your pupils will be as bright as a newborn calf’s, seeking no reasons for things."

Before he finished speaking, Nie Que fell asleep. Beigyi, greatly pleased, sang as he departed, saying: "A form like withered bones, a heart like dead ashes—truly, such knowing does not cling to the past. Vague and obscure, without intent, it cannot be schemed with. What manner of person is this?"

Shun asked Cheng: "Can the Dao be possessed and held?"
Cheng replied: "Your body is not your own possession—how could you possess the Dao?"
Shun said: "If my body is not my own, then whose is it?"
Cheng said: "It is Heaven and Earth’s entrusted form. Life is not your possession—it is Heaven and Earth’s entrusted harmony. Nature and destiny are not your possession—they are Heaven and Earth’s entrusted compliance. Even your descendants are not your possession—they are Heaven and Earth’s entrusted shedding. Thus, in movement, you know not where you go; in stillness, you know not what you hold; in eating, you know not the taste. These are the workings of Heaven and Earth’s vigorous yang qi—how could you possess them?"

The body is not something you can possess—it simply exists of itself. If the body were yours to possess, then beauty, ugliness, life, and death would be yours to control. Yet when qi gathers and you are born, you cannot forbid it; when qi scatters and you die, you cannot prevent it. Clearly, it is an entrustment that forms itself—it is not yours to own. Even descendants are but qi’s self-entrusted shedding. Movement, stillness, eating, and drinking all arise from this spontaneous process, so you do not know them. Vigorous yang is like movement itself. Those who understand this Dao may relinquish the body and forget life.

Yet when Shun inquired of his ministers, it was only because he could not but assume the throne after Yao—once the illustrious virtue had its beginning, he had already departed from the Dao. Thus his words were but a pretext. As for the ministers, they were those who aided the ruler with the Dao.

Confucius asked Lao Dan, “This evening, may I dare inquire about the supreme Dao?”
Lao Dan replied, “Purify yourself through fasting, cleanse your heart through abstention, and wash your spirit as with snow. Strike down your knowledge and then we may speak of the Dao—how profound and ineffable it is! Let me tell you its broad outlines. Luminous clarity arises from obscurity; order emerges from formlessness. Spirit arises from the Dao, while form originates from essence. All things take shape through form, thus the nine orifices belong to the womb-born, and the eight orifices to the egg-born. Their coming leaves no trace; their going has no boundary. Without gate or chamber, they are open on all four sides, vast and boundless.

Those who stray from this find their limbs stiff and their thoughts muddled, their ears and eyes sharp yet their minds wearied, their responses to things without constancy. Heaven cannot but be high, Earth cannot but be broad, the sun and moon cannot but move, and the myriad things cannot but flourish—such is the Dao. Moreover, vast learning does not necessarily bring knowledge, nor does eloquence necessarily bring wisdom. The sage guards against these. As for that which, when increased, is not more, and when diminished, is not less—the sage preserves it. How profound it is!"

Vast it stands, towering like the sea—how majestic! Its end returns to its beginning. It measures and sustains the myriad things without exhaustion, and this is the Dao of the noble person. Is it external to things? All things turn to it for sustenance, yet it is never exhausted—such is the Dao.

Within the central realms there are those who, neither yin nor yang, dwell between Heaven and Earth, simply being human. Yet they will return to their origin. Viewed from their root, the living are but dim and turbid things. Though some live long and others die young, how great is the difference? All is but a fleeting moment. How then can one judge Yao and Jie as right or wrong? Even the ripened fruits of trees have their principles; though human relationships are difficult to order, the sage encounters them without resistance, passes them without clinging, harmonizes and responds—this is virtue. To meet and respond by chance—this is the Dao. It is from this that emperors rise and kings emerge.

Human life between Heaven and Earth is like a white colt passing through a gap—gone in an instant. Suddenly, vigorously, all things emerge; gently, limpidly, all things return. Already transformed, they are born; again transformed, they die. Living things mourn this; humans grieve it. They break their Heaven-given bow cases, scatter their Heaven-given quivers, entangled and lost. The hun and po depart, and the body follows—all return to the great homecoming.

The formless takes form; form returns to the formless—this all people know in common, yet it is not what those who strive for the ultimate concern themselves with. This is what the multitude discusses together, but those who reach the Dao do not discuss it, and those who discuss it do not reach it. Clearly seeing what cannot be encountered, arguing is not as good as silence. The Dao cannot be heard; hearing it is not as good as stopping the ears—this is called the great attainment.

*(Annotations within the text: "Wooden fruits are called *guo*; herbaceous fruits are called *luo*. *Taō* is a bow case; *zhì* is a clothing bag.")*

Guo’s Commentary [states: "The dark and formless is called the Dao—all clarify its solitary arising without reliance. Form fundamentally arises from essence, proceeding from essence to the coarse. Though the myriad things generate one another through form, this too is simply natural. Thus, embryo and egg cannot alter their kind in generation, demonstrating the unfeignability of spirit and qi. Those who follow the nature of spontaneity and wander the traceless path release their forms amid Heaven and Earth, entrusting their spirit beyond the eight directions. Thus, they have no gate, no chamber—fourfold open, august, and carefree—roaming the Six Directions in step with transformation.

When a person encounters this Dao at birth, their Heaven-endowed nature remains whole and their spirit settled; Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things can only be as they naturally are—not that the Dao compels them. Therefore, the sage guards against and discards knowledge and wisdom, entrusting them to spontaneity, allowing each to preserve its proper allotment alone, without employing knowledge or wisdom. Like the sea, it receives all without limit. Ending, it begins again, moving with transformation. Using things without being enslaved by them, it is never exhausted—this clarifies that the Dao’s abundance lies in not being abundant, and that things naturally attain fulfillment when it is not abundant. Hence it is said: this is the Dao. To speak of the ultimate Dao as ‘without achievement’—only ‘without achievement’ suffices to name the Dao.

It is neither yin nor yang, without partiality, simply and directly human. Haughtily self-releasing, it finds peace in whatever it encounters, utterly devoid of achievement or fame. Returning to the source is not chasing after ends. Obscuring and steeping things is simply gathering qi. Life and death are not yet sufficient to distinguish—how much less the span between long and short life? Fruits and gourds have their principles; it is said that things are without principle, but one should simply follow them. Human relations involve the vicissitudes of knowledge and wisdom, hence their difficulty. Yet knowledge and wisdom are merely self-ranked—one should simply follow and entrust them, encountering without opposing, passing without clinging. This is called harmony and accord.

The rise of emperors and kings is no more than this. The fleeting white colt is not worth lamenting—‘going out’ and ‘entering’ are but names for transformation. It is said that nothing under Heaven does not change. Having transformed and been born, it transforms again and dies—both are transformation. Living things lament it; dead things do not lament. People grieve it; the dead do not grieve. Loosening the Heaven-given bow case and scattering the Heaven-given quiver speak of solitary release. ‘Entangled and lost’ describes the swirling of transformation. The great homecoming is using the mind without effort amid it all. The formless taking form completes it; if one shapes form, one ruins it. Striving does not reach it; humbly and unknowingly, one attains it. Clearly seeing what cannot be encountered, arguing is not as good as silence. Darkly arriving, it is encountered. Silencing and stopping the ears, there is nothing to chase—hence the great attainment."]

Lü’s Commentary [states: "Spirit and Dao are still luminous; at the ultimate of the Dao, it is dark. When things achieve their life-principle, there is order; when their essence is most true, it is formless. Yet the myriad things generate one another through form, coming and going without trace, fourfold open and august. Entering and wandering here, one rests in the profound mystery of the myriad things. By vigorously contemplating and grasping its use, there is no limit—Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things’ generation and completion are none other than this.

Broadness is not knowledge; eloquence is not wisdom. The sage has already guarded against them—what seems gain is not gain, what seems loss is not loss, for these are what the sage preserves. Abyssal! Vast! No one knows its bounds. There is movement, there is measure—these are not within the Dao. What the myriad things rely upon is not reliance on externals. Seeking the Dao thus, one finds its whereabouts.

Neither yin nor yang, only following the Dao—straight and simply human, the same as others. Returning to the source is the same as Heaven. ‘Obscuring and steeping’ speaks of what is not prized. Long and short life are equal in view—how can Yao and Jie be distinguished? Fruits and gourds have their principles; all things share them. Human relations are self-ranked—this is the order of the great Dao. Not opposing, not clinging, not leaving, not taking—this is called harmony and response. Virtue’s so-called ‘partial completion’ and response to stimuli—Dao does not examine or proclaim.

The rise of emperors and kings is no more than this Dao. Human life is like a colt passing a crack—nothing can be detained. Things lament, people grieve, because they do not understand that there was never birth, never death. Loosening the bow case is relaxation without constraint; scattering the quiver is rolling and unrolling without hindrance. The hun and po depart, and the body follows—this speaks of not going out. The great smelter does not shape the formless taking form; form returning to the formless—all people know this in common, but it is not what those who strive for the ultimate concern themselves with. Attaining it, one embodies it; not attaining it, one merely discusses it. Clearly seeing the Dao, there is nothing to encounter—hence arguing is not as good as silence. Truly hearing the Dao, there is nothing to hear—hence hearing is not as good as stopping the ears. Speaking without words, listening without hearing—this is called the great attainment."]

Following the Original [states: "It is said that one need not be broad or eloquent—the sage already has a fixed saying. The sage’s saying cannot be diminished or augmented. Abyssal!" ]

The Way is like the vast sea—majestic and boundless. Its end returns to its beginning, thus extolling the sage’s Dao: its measure encompasses the ten thousand things without exhaustion, yet this is merely the Way of the noble person. For they still harbor intent toward externals. All that lies beyond them—the ten thousand things—proceed to draw from it without exhaustion, and this is their Way. Yet speech is insufficient to convey the Dao.

Within the central realms, there are those who transcend beyond yin and yang, dwelling between heaven and earth as if merely passing as humans. They will return to their origin—the origin is the Great Void. Viewed from the Great Void, human life is like *yìyǐ*—fermented plum juice. The *Liji* annotates *yǐ* as plum broth, and *yìn* as long-fermented. Yet even long-fermented broth—how long can it last? Thus, all that people debate and expound are but fleeting discourses.

Though fruits and melons are humble things, their branches, flowers, and fruits still follow patterns of order—ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, friends—these human relations, though seemingly complex and arduous, serve to establish rank and sequence. The sage, dwelling amidst human relations, encounters them without resistance, never abandoning them; passes beyond them without attachment, never lingering. Harmonizing with them and responding—this is virtue. Aligning with them and responding—this is the Dao. The rise of emperors and kings all proceeds from this.

In turmoil and flux, the appearance of unraveling bow-cases and discarded scrolls—form emerging from the formless, and form dissolving into the formless. *Zhí* means encounter.

The essentials of the Great Dao cannot be encountered through mere clarity of vision—thus eloquence is not as good as silence.
*Supplementary Note:* Things encounter one another through duality, yet the Dao is simply one. To perceive the Dao with clarity is to enter into oneness—hence there is no encounter.

Dongguo Zi asked Zhuangzi, “Where is this so-called Dao?”
Zhuangzi replied, “There is nowhere it is not.”
Dongguo Zi said, “You must specify before I can understand.”
Zhuangzi said, “It is in the ant.”
“How can it be so lowly?”
“It is in the weeds.”
“How can it be even lower?”
“It is in the tiles and bricks.”
“How can it be still lower?”
“It is in excrement and urine.”
Dongguo Zi made no reply.

Zhuangzi said, “Your question, Master, fundamentally fails to reach the essence. When Zheng Huo asked the market inspector about the weight of a pig, the lower he felt, the more accurate the measure. You, too, should not insist on certainty—nothing escapes the all-pervading Dao. Such is the case with grand pronouncements as well. ‘All-encompassing,’ ‘universal,’ and ‘complete’—these three are different names for the same reality, their meaning one and the same.

Have we not wandered together in the Palace of Non-Being? There, in shared discourse, we find no end to our discussion. Have we not practiced non-action together? Serene and still, vast and clear, harmonious and at ease—my will is already at rest, yet I know not where it arrives. Departing and returning, I know not where it halts. I have already come and gone, yet I know not where it ends. Wandering freely, I enter the boundless—great knowledge penetrates, yet I know not where it reaches its limit.

That which is a thing among things merges with things without boundary, yet things have boundaries—this is what we call the boundary of things. The boundary of the boundless is the boundlessness of boundaries. We speak of fullness and emptiness, decline and decay, yet that which is fullness is not fullness, that which is emptiness is not emptiness. That which is decline is not decline, that which is decay is not decay. That which is root and branch is not root and branch, that which is accumulation and dispersal is not accumulation and dispersal.”

*(The market inspector is the overseer of the market.)*

Guo’s Commentary:
To expect a definitive answer is to demand a name and location for it. *Zhi* (substance) is the standard—it is said to be nowhere absent, yet to marvel at its presence here is to fall short of true *zhi*. *Xi* is the great pig. The market inspector who treads upon the pig to gauge its fatness knows that the more he treads upon the harder-to-fat areas, the better he grasps the essence of the pig’s fatness. Now, to inquire into the Dao’s whereabouts and constantly compare it to the lowly is to see that the Dao does not flee from things. This must be so. If one insists that the Dao escapes things, then the Dao is not all-pervading. A Dao that is not all-pervading is insufficient to be called the great Dao. The same applies to grand discourse: it is clear that the Dao does not flee from things. If one roams where there is something, one cannot encompass all. Only by discussing them together can one know that the Dao is nowhere absent. Knowing that the Dao is nowhere absent, one can then wander freely, untethered, and roam the boundless.

“Tranquil and still, vast and clear, harmonious and at ease”—these all arise from non-action. “Liao, my aspiration” means empty and void; if the aspiration is empty, then there is nowhere to go. With nowhere to go, one goes yet does not know where one arrives. If there is somewhere to go, then the principle has not yet stirred, yet the aspiration is already startled. “Coming and going without knowing where it halts” is to follow the natural course. “Wandering freely without knowing where it ends” means merely coming and going without relying on knowledge—it is not that there is no coming and going. Coming and going are the constant principles of nature. Can they have an end?

*Feng hong* refers to vast emptiness. Great knowledge roams the boundless, following the transformations of things as they please, hence it does not know. “That which is a thing among things” means there is no thing, yet things are things of themselves. Things are things of themselves, hence they are obscure. Things have boundaries, so they cannot be obscure together—this is what is truly called the boundary of things. The “boundless” merely clarifies that things are things of themselves. That which is a thing among things is ultimately no thing at all. Where, then, is its boundary? Having clarified that “that which is a thing among things” is no thing, and that things are not things of themselves, then who is the doer? All is suddenly and naturally so.

Lü’s Commentary:
Ants have knowledge yet are most minute; millet and weeds have no knowledge yet possess life; tiles and bricks have no life yet have form; excrement and urine have form yet are foul and decayed. If these are the Dao, then it is clear that the Dao is nowhere absent. One may expect the Dao to reside in these four, for they are its substance. To consider them too lowly and then ask again is to fall short of substance.

The one who treads upon the pig, descending further with each comparison, expects the Dao to be ever lower—how could this not be further from its true substance? Yet one insists on fleeing from things to assert that there is nothing in which the Dao is not present. Thus, though the previous four differ, they all embody the Dao’s essence, just as speech that is all-encompassing shares a single intent. To roam the Palace of Nothingness and find their convergence—how could these four not be the Dao? Though the myriad things arise together, when they return to non-action, then in tranquility, vastness, harmony, and ease, all revert to their root, empty and void. If my aspiration does not chase after things, then there is nowhere to go, and I do not know where I arrive. Coming and going, I do not know where it halts; wandering freely, I do not know where it ends. This is the Dao’s never having been a thing, and things’ being nothing but the Dao.

Thus, wandering freely in vast emptiness, great knowledge enters yet does not know where it reaches its limit. From this, one knows that “that which is a thing among things” merges with things without boundary. Small and great cannot be differentiated; things have boundaries—this is what we call the boundary of things, not “that which is a thing among things.” The boundary of the boundless is the boundlessness of boundaries, just as the formless is the form of forms. Fullness and emptiness belong to things; that which creates fullness and emptiness is the Dao. The same applies to decline and decay, root and branch, accumulation and dispersal. Then who is it that creates millet, weeds, ants, tiles, bricks, excrement, and urine?

Following the Original Text:
*Qi* means to specify in speech. *Zhi* is the root. The question is vague and does not reach the root, hence my response is as such. *Zheng huo* refers to the *Yili* (Book of Etiquette and Ceremonial), where the *sizheng* and *sihuo* oversee the archery ritual. The market inspector who treads upon the pig to know its weight is like the *sizheng* and *sihuo*—though their duties differ, they serve the same purpose in the archery ritual, hence the analogy. To tread upon the pig is to step from its upper body to its lower body; the lower one goes, the clearer the comparison of fatness and leanness becomes. Commonly, a pig is considered fat when its two thighs are equal—this illustrates that the lower one goes, the more evident the comparison, and thus the Dao becomes visible.

Supplementary Notes:
*Xi* is the great pig. *Lü* means to tread upon it with the foot.

The fatness or leanness of a pig can be known by treading upon its rump, for the rump is the lowest part of the creature. Thus, "below" must imply certainty. Only with certainty can one proceed to inquiry, hence the saying: "You must not insist on certainty, nor say it is uncertain—where, after all, could the Dao be escaped?" That by which a thing is called the Dao is ultimately one with the thing itself. Thus, the supreme Dao is as such, and so too are the supreme words: though "all-encompassing," "pervasive," and "universal" differ in phrasing, their meaning is one.

To speak all day of the profound and wondrous is no different from ashes and dregs. Yet though I speak of the Dao with words, and you inquire of the Dao with questions, neither words nor questions are the Dao itself. Shall we advance a step further together, wandering in the Palace of Non-Being, discussing the learning that knows no end or limit? In such unity, I have nothing to say, and you have nothing to hear—shall we be still and tranquil, vast and clear, harmonious and at ease? How boundless and distant is my aspiration! Distant, it seems to have a destination, yet in truth it goes nowhere. Going nowhere, it abides in serene constancy. If there is coming and going, it is merely the fitting arrival of the moment, the fitting departure in accord with it. Abiding in timeliness and accordance, one knows not where it rests. For once there is a resting place, one knows departure but not arrival, or arrival but not departure—both are grasping and not natural. Thus, I have come and gone without knowing what it is ultimately like, wandering in the vast and open wilderness, entering into the great knowledge without knowing its limits.

"Great knowledge" is but another name for the great Dao. This is what is meant by "wandering with you in the Palace of Non-Being, discussing without end or limit." All things are the Dao, yet the Dao is nowhere while being nowhere absent. Thus, it is said to have no boundaries, for boundaries belong to things. To speak of a thing having boundaries is to speak of the boundaries of things; the Dao, however, is the boundary that is no boundary. It is not that the Dao is separate from things and called by another name—it is simply the boundary that is no boundary.

What is called a boundary refers to fullness and emptiness, decline and decay—all of which have two sides. The Dao, however, is called fullness yet is not fullness, called emptiness yet is not emptiness, called decline yet is not decline, called decay yet is not decay, called root and branch yet is not root and branch, called accumulation and dispersal yet is not accumulation and dispersal. As Master Zhang said: "The two are present, hence it is unfathomable." Such is the case.

Fang Sishan notes: "All-encompassing, pervasive, universal—these are phrases with different words but one principle. To be able to be without action, tranquil and vast, harmonious and at ease—this is perfection. *Liaoyi* is a word praising its utmost stillness. Having boundaries means knowing its limits; having no boundaries means not knowing its limits. Not knowing its limits is to be one with all things. Being one with all things, it alone can be full yet not full, empty yet not empty, in decline yet not in decline, in decay yet not in decay—this is the boundary that is no boundary."

E, called Ahegan, studied with Shennong under Old Dragon Ji. Once, Shennong shut his door and meditated through the day. At noon, E opened the door and entered, saying, "Old Dragon is dead." Shennong leaned on his staff and rose, then suddenly dropped it and laughed, saying, "Heaven knew my stubbornness and arrogance, so it abandoned me and let him die. The Master died without eliciting my wild words—what a pity!" Yan Gang, upon hearing this, said: "Those who embody the Dao are the ones upon whom the noble of the world depend. Yet even one who has not attained so much as a hair’s tip or a ten-thousandth part of the Dao still knows to conceal his wild words upon death—how much more so for those who truly embody the Dao! It is formless to sight, soundless to hearing, and those who discuss it call it obscure. Thus, they speak of the Dao but do not reach the Dao."

Thereupon, Taiqing asked Wuqiong: "Do you know the Dao?" Wuqiong said, "I do not." He asked again. Wuwei said, "I know the Dao." Taiqing said, "Does your knowing the Dao have a pattern?" Wuwei said, "It does." Taiqing said, "What is its pattern?" Wuwei said, "I know the Dao can be noble, can be base, can be constrained, can be dispersed—this is the pattern by which I know the Dao." Taiqing, taking these words, asked Wushi: "If this is so, then Wuqiong’s not knowing and Wuwei’s knowing—which is right and which is wrong?" Wushi said, "Not knowing is profound; knowing is shallow. Not knowing is internal; knowing is external." Thereupon, Taiqing sighed and said, "Is not knowing, then, knowing? Is knowing, then, not knowing? Who knows the knowing of not knowing?"

Wushi said: "The Dao cannot be heard—what is heard is not it. The Dao cannot be seen—what is seen is not it. The Dao cannot be spoken—what is spoken is not it. Do you know that which gives form to the formless? The Dao should not be named." Wushi said: "One who answers when asked about the Dao does not know the Dao. Even the one who asks about the Dao has not heard the Dao. The Dao has no questions; questions have no answers. To ask questions is to ask about limits; to answer is to lack inwardness. To lack inwardness while facing questions about limits—is this not to observe externally? Within the cosmos, do you not know? Thus, one does not pass beyond the Great Beginning, does not wander in the Great Void, does not roam beyond Kunlun."

Guo's Commentary:
[When Liezi] awoke to the fact that death is nothing to be startled by, he put down his staff and laughed. From Jianwu downward, all took the ultimate words as madness and did not believe them. Thus, none but Lao Long and Lian Shu and their like were worthy of discourse. The gentleman’s concern with words that embody the Dao is the very foundation of humanity. The tip of an autumn hair is minute, yet even this does not attain one ten-thousandth of it. Concealing his mad words, he died to illuminate that the ultimate Dao cannot be attained through words. It lies solely in self-realization. Though obscure, it is still not the Dao—this clarifies the namelessness of the Dao. All attainment does not come from knowledge but from obscurity, silently completing itself in the realm of the unseen and unheard, only then reaching it. To know the formless in forms is merely to speak of forms shaping themselves. The shaper of forms ultimately has no thing. The Dao has a name, yet ultimately no thing, so naming cannot capture it. Not knowing, one asks; to answer when asked is not the Dao. Not to answer is not what the questioner can attain, so though one asks, in the end one does not hear it. Without questions, without answers—this is the meaning of cutting off learning, abandoning teaching, and returning to spontaneity. "Questions about limits" refers to demanding the empty. To respond with what is actually nonexistent yet provisionally existent is external. As for those who wander freely between heaven and earth, roam the void, and traverse the distant to enter the obscure—it is enough not to respond.

Lü's Commentary:
Those who embody the Dao are the very foundation to which all gentlemen in the world are tied. Sagehood, life, kingship, and completion—none are not bound to this. Now, in regard to the Dao, one has not attained even one ten-thousandth of the tip of an autumn hair—this is the essence of what is called "attaining oneness." Yet one still knows to conceal one’s mad words and die—how much more so for those who embody the Dao and whose myriad transformations have never begun to have limits? Lao Long concealed his mad words and died, all because the Dao as a thing is not within the reach of seeing and hearing. Those who discuss it call it obscure, yet it cannot be discussed in words, so to discuss the Dao is not the Dao. Tai Qing heard a discussion of the Dao that was not the Dao and took it as sufficient to seek in the infinite, yet the infinite cannot be known. Non-action is not originally non-action; one knows that there is nothing worth doing and so does not act—this is how it is known. Otherwise, it would be mere emptiness. To know that the Dao can be noble or base, contracted or dispersed, is to be bound by calculation. Wu Shi reaches the limit of the beginning that comes from itself. Thus, to know not-knowing is profound; to know is shallow. Not-knowing is internal; knowing is external. Tai Qing sighed in the midst of the Great Purity, saying, "Not knowing is knowing the infinite—this is so. Knowing is not knowing non-action—this is so. Who knows the knowing of not knowing? Only Wu Shi." The Dao cannot be heard or seen; if spoken, then what is heard, seen, or spoken—who is it? Only after there is form is there name. To know the shaper of forms as formless—this is why the Dao should not be named. Thus, one who hears hearing does not hear; one who sees seeing does not see; one who speaks speaking does not speak. It can be known that one who answers when asked about the Dao does not know the Dao. Even one who asks about the Dao has not heard the Dao. The Dao has no questions, for the questioner cannot attain it. Questions have no answers, for the answerer cannot attain it. All is because there has never yet been a thing. To ask questions is to ask about limits, not knowing the infinite and taking questioning as nothing. To answer is to lack inwardness, not having attained the fact that there has never yet been a thing within. To lack inwardness while facing questions about limits—is this not to observe externally? Within the cosmos, do you not know? Thus, one does not pass beyond the Great Beginning, does not wander in the Great Void, and so does not know the height of forms, while heaven, earth, and the myriad things are contained within it.

He who follows the root—opening the door with a *zha*, pushing it wide, the sound of a staff clattering to the ground—pointed to Old Dragon Ji and said: "I have nowhere to vent my wild words. Those who die speaking my words say, 'What I spoke was mostly reckless and ignorant.' While Old Dragon Ji lived, I could pose questions to seek his correction. Now that Old Dragon Ji is dead, I have nowhere to vent my wild words, and so they too shall perish with my death. Now, in the Dao, I have not attained even the tiniest fraction—like the tip of an autumn hair—yet I point to Shen Nong. If I conceal my wild words, there is nothing to vent. In human discourse, this is called 'obscurity.' Those who discuss the Dao describe it as formless and soundless, and so they merely call it 'obscurity.'"

Guangyao asked Wu You, "Master, do you possess that which is called 'Wu You'?" Guangyao could not frame his question and instead stared intently at Wu You’s appearance—profoundly empty, utterly vacant. He gazed all day without seeing, listened without hearing, and grasped without obtaining. Guangyao said, "This is perfection! Who could attain such a state? I can attain 'having no-thing,' yet I have not attained 'having no no-thing.' How could one reach this state of 'Wu You'?" [Note: "When it comes to 'Wu You,' this should be 'having no no-thing'—a scribal error.]

Guo’s Commentary: "This conveys the meaning of cutting off learning. In the Dao, severing it leads the learner back to the root. Thus, the excellence of learning lies precisely in non-learning."

Lü’s Commentary: "Guangyao is the vast expanse emitting light, yet when it illuminates 'Wu You,' there is no illumination left. This is why Guangyao, unable to discern whether it was 'having' or 'no-thing,' could not frame his question. Profoundly empty, utterly vacant—sight, hearing, and touch could not reach it. This is why it is called 'Wu You.' Precisely because it has 'no-thing,' Guangyao could not attain 'having no no-thing,' and thus could not reach 'Wu You.' When it comes to 'Wu You,' how could one reach it from anywhere?"

The Great Marshal’s hook-forger was eighty years old yet never erred by even a hair’s breadth. The Great Marshal asked, "Are you skillful, or do you possess the Dao?" The forger replied, "I have my discipline. At twenty, I took delight in forging hooks. I beheld nothing else—nothing but hooks did I examine. This is using what is employed by relying on what is not employed. With age, I have mastered its use—how much more so for that which is never not employed? What thing would not draw upon it?" [Note: The Great Marshal is the Grand Minister of War. In the region between the three Wei rivers of Jiangdong, a *chui* is called a *gou*, a type of sword.]

Guo’s Commentary: "He gauges the weight of hooks without the slightest deviation. Utterly free of attachment, all things respond as they come."

Lü’s Commentary: "Only the Dao is both without use and without non-use."

Ran Qiu asked Confucius, "Before there was Heaven and Earth, could it be known?"
Confucius replied, "It could. The ancient was as the present is."

Ran Qiu, having posed his question amiss, withdrew. The next day, he returned and said, "Yesterday, I asked whether what preceded Heaven and Earth could be known. You said it could, that the ancient was as the present is. Yesterday, I was enlightened; today, I am benighted. May I ask what this means?"
Confucius said, "Yesterday’s enlightenment came because the spirit first received it. Today’s benightedness arises because you now seek it through what is not spirit. Without ancient, without present, without beginning, without end—could there be descendants without there first being sons? Could there?"

Ran Qiu did not respond. Confucius said, "Enough. No answer is needed. Do not use life to give rise to death; do not use death to give rise to life. Do life and death depend on something? All share one body. Is there something that existed before Heaven and Earth? That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. Things emerge, yet nothing precedes them. As there are things, so there are things—without end. The sage’s love for humanity never ceases; this, too, is drawn from this."

Guo’s Commentary:
"Confucius says that Heaven and Earth are ever-abiding, for there was never a time when they were not. With an empty mind, one awaits destiny—this is the spirit’s reception. To seek through thought is to invite further confusion. Not only does the nonexistent fail to transform into existence, but the existent also fails to transform into nonexistence. Thus, as a thing, existence undergoes a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations yet never becomes nonexistent. Therefore, from antiquity, there has never been a time of nonbeing, and it abides eternally. 'Descendants' speaks of generations without end. Its essence has a source; it cannot arise from nothing. Thus, there are generations, and so there are descendants; one cannot have grandsons without first having sons. Likewise, Heaven and Earth cannot first have been nonexistent and now exist. Death is but the solitary transformation of the dead; it is not that life gives rise to this death. Life, too, is but a solitary transformation. Life and death, each sufficient unto itself, form their own bodies—who could precede things? I take yin and yang to precede things, yet yin and yang are themselves but things. Who, then, precedes yin and yang? I take spontaneity to precede them, yet spontaneity is but the self-so of things. I take the supreme Dao to precede them, yet the supreme Dao is but supreme nothingness. Having nothing, what could precede it? Who, then, precedes things? Yet there are things without end, making clear that the spontaneity of things is not caused by anything. The sage’s ceaseless love for humanity is also drawn from this self-so. Thus, benevolence flows through a hundred generations without ceasing."

Lü’s Commentary:
"Who named Heaven and Earth? To know how Heaven and Earth are named is to know how they came to be. To know how they came to be is to know that before Heaven and Earth, it was as it is now. The spirit first receives it, attaining without thought. Yet you now seek it through what is not spirit—this is why it is not spirit. Ancient and present, end and beginning, are mutually dependent; without dependence, all is without. If you understand this, you will know what is meant by 'before Heaven and Earth.' That it can be known means that there can be descendants without first having sons. I refrain from answering to prevent you from seeking with an intentful mind. For the mind has its so-called life, and only then can it give rise to its death; the mind has its so-called death, and only then can it give rise to its life. This is the error of seeking with an intentful mind. Do life and death depend on something? The body is originally without dependence. Whether dependent or independent, all share one body. Knowing that life and death form one body, how could there be something that existed before Heaven and Earth? That which existed before Heaven and Earth gives rise to things. That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. Thus, things emerge, yet nothing precedes them. What is called 'the thing formed in chaos before Heaven and Earth' is but 'as there are things, so there are things'—without end. It has never begun to have things. The sage’s ceaseless love for humanity is also drawn from this. This is how Qian’s origin governs Heaven. The noble person embodies this to lead others."

Yi Du’s Commentary:
"Could what preceded Heaven and Earth truly be known? By inferring from what came after, it can be known. Xunzi said, 'The Way of the hundred kings lies in the later kings.' A thousand years ago is as today. At first, Ran Qiu asked with an empty mind; emptiness gives rise to spirit, so he was enlightened. Later, he heard the words but did not comprehend; his mind was obstructed, and what was not spirit arose, so he became benighted. Without ancient, without present, without beginning, without end—this is spoken of the spirit. Originally, there was no death; death arises from life. Originally, there was no life; life arises from death. Life and death each have their own body; neither depends on the other. The *Great Change* does not show qi; it is neither form nor qi. Thus, it can give rise to things. That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. Though it emerges before things, it cannot precede them. As there are things, so there are things—without end. The sage’s love for things is not benevolence, yet his love never ceases. This, too, is drawn from this."

Guan Jian’s Commentary:
"Ran Qiu’s question had the force of thunder splitting mountains. The Master answered casually, causing him to pose his question amiss and withdraw. The measure of the sage’s capacity is thus revealed. The human body models Heaven and Earth; what preceded Heaven and Earth is the original state of one’s own body. Knowing the original state of one’s body is to know what preceded Heaven and Earth. Knowing what preceded Heaven and Earth is also inferred from what came after. The sage holds to the ancient to govern the present, and so must be able to infer the present to illuminate the ancient. How could it be merely that a hundred generations can be known? Heaven and Earth are but tiny things in the void, the greatest of all things with form. Form arises from the formless and must ultimately return to dissolution. Yet humans, dwelling in brief lives, cannot see this—like summer insects that know nothing of ice. 'The spirit first receives it'—to know its spirit is to be spirit. 'Yet you now seek it through what is not spirit'—not knowing the spirit within what is not spirit. Yesterday’s enlightenment came from using knowledge to seek what is called spirit; the spirit first received it. Today’s benightedness comes from hearing the Dao and forgetting knowledge; within what is not spirit, the spirit resides. Why must you seek further? Let him return to illuminate the source of the mind, attaining non-attainment, neither enlightened nor benighted, without ancient or present. Then life and death cannot bind him. 'Do not use life to give rise to death; do not use death to give rise to life'—each transforms alone, without dependence. All share one body. Is there something that existed before Heaven and Earth? That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. Things emerge, yet nothing precedes them. As there are things, so there are things—without end. The sage’s ceaseless love for humanity is also drawn from this self-so."

Just as the breath you now exhale is not the breath you inhaled before, just as the flame before is not the flame after—this principle having been raised again, the question arises: Was there something that existed before Heaven and Earth? It is said that only the Dao dwells before Heaven and Earth; there is no thing that precedes Heaven and Earth. That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. The Dao gives birth to Heaven and Earth and the myriad things, yet it cannot be named as a thing. Once a thing emerges, it enters the realm of form and vessels, and thus cannot be what preceded things. It is because there are things that this is so.

Because there are things, from the One arise the Ten Thousand; from the Ten Thousand arise the countless, which daily press upon us. Few indeed are those who can stand firm and independent, unconfused by them. Thus we know that the endlessness of people and things arises from the endlessness of creation. Therefore, the sage’s heart of ceaseless love extends to all things without end. Yet all alike cannot escape the scattering of pure simplicity into dissipation. The governance of the Great Ancients through non-action cannot be recovered.

If one wishes to return to the governance of non-action of the Great Ancients, must one not seek well that which is before one’s own Heaven?

Yan Yuan asked Confucius, saying: "Hui has once heard from the Master that one should neither send off nor welcome anything. May Hui ask about its wandering?"

Confucius said: "The people of antiquity transformed externally but remained untransformed internally. The people of today transform internally but remain untransformed externally. Those who transform with things are one with transformation; those who do not transform are also one. Where is the stability in transformation or non-transformation? Where is the harmony with them? One must be in accord with them, yet not be excessive.

The parks of the House of Xiwei, the gardens of the Yellow Emperor, the palaces of the Lord of Yu, the chambers of Tang and Wu—these were all places where the noble person, such as the followers of Ru and Mo, took teachers and used right and wrong to guard against each other. How much more so for the people of today?

The sage dwells among things without harming them; one who does not harm things cannot be harmed by things."

Only one who harms nothing can truly accompany others in meeting and parting. Mountains and forests, hills and marshes—do they bring me joy? My joy is not yet complete when sorrow already follows. Sorrow and joy come, and I cannot resist them; they depart, and I cannot halt them. How lamentable that the people of this world are but transient lodgers in the realm of things.

Those who know what they encounter yet do not know what they do not encounter, who know what they can do yet cannot do what they cannot—such ignorance and inability are unavoidable for all people. Yet to strive to avoid what cannot be avoided—is this not also lamentable?

Ultimate words transcend speech; ultimate action transcends doing. To equate knowledge with what is known is shallow indeed.

Guo’s commentary:
*By aligning the mind with form, form transforms of itself. Using the mind to direct form, one remains externally untransformed; with a constant absence of mind, one is unified in non-transformation. Only one who is unified in non-transformation can merge with the transformations of things. Whether transforming or not, all is left to the other—this is the absence of mind. Without mind, one allows spontaneous transformation, neither meeting nor following, neither conforming nor resisting, neither excessive nor deficient. To speak of "not meeting, not following" is to stop where one is content.
The parks, gardens, palaces, and chambers—these are where those without mind and who follow transformation dwell, the very places where the sages roamed.
"Preventing" means harmonizing. The followers of Ru and Mo, who took teachers to harmonize the most difficult things in the world, could still achieve harmony through absence of mind—how much more so for ordinary people?
To dwell among things without harming them is the utmost compliance. Things cannot harm one because the matter lies entirely with oneself. With absence of mind comes utmost compliance; with utmost compliance comes the ability to be free from obstruction, and thus one’s righteousness surpasses that of meeting and following.
Mountains, forests, hills, and marshes are no better than I, yet I find joy in them—this is joy without cause. Joy without cause is also sorrow without cause; thus, what brings joy is not truly joyful, and what brings sorrow is not truly sorrowful.
The people of this world cannot sit in forgetfulness and find contentment, so their sorrow and joy are merely lodged in things, like transient guests.
What one’s knowledge encounters is what one knows; what it does not encounter is what one does not know. What one cannot do cannot be forced into ability. From this perspective, knowledge and ignorance, ability and inability—control does not lie with me. One must entrust it all to nature.
Ignorance and inability are unavoidable for all people, for each is born with their own allotment.
Ultimate words and ultimate actions arise from self-attainment. What is gained through knowledge is but the work of scholars—hence, it is shallow.*

The Lü commentary states:
The ancients, when external things transformed, would transform with them and pass away; when things did not transform internally, there remained something unforgotten within. The people of today, when things transform internally, their hearts align with them, yet when things do not transform externally, they measure themselves against what lies ahead and do not perceive the passage of days.

Those who transform with things are unified—if there is no transformation, how can there be transformation? If there is transformation and non-transformation, then this is not the means by which non-transformation operates. How can one then move in harmony with things? Their conduct is like a gallop that cannot be halted.

To move with things without excess is neither to lead nor to follow—merely to respond without reservation. We speak of enclosures, gardens, palaces, and chambers: as the world declines further, those who wander grow fewer, and their dwellings grow narrower.

The gentlemen of the Ru and Mo schools still use right and wrong to guard against one another—such guarding inflicts deep harm. How much worse is it for the people of today, who do not move in harmony with one another?

It is difficult indeed.

The sage engages with things without harming them, allowing right and wrong to proceed side by side and come to rest in the harmony of Heaven. How can things harm what is evenly balanced? Thus, though the sage may lead and follow others, he wanders alone in the realm of no leading and no following.

The people of the world are enslaved by external things, and sorrow and joy find their way into their abodes. Mountains, forests, rivers, and plains may bring me joy, but it is not yet complete—sorrow soon follows. These two alternate without cease. Their coming cannot be resisted, their going cannot be stopped; thus, the self is merely lodged in things, like a transient guest.

One knows what one encounters but not what one does not encounter. When one encounters, one aligns with things; when one does not encounter, one departs from them. One can do what one is able to do but does not know what one cannot do. When able, one is enslaved by things; when unable, one enslaves things.

Ignorance and inability are unavoidable for all people—these are one’s inherent endowments, all of which can be sought. Yet people strive to avoid them. To reject what is unavoidable for all is to lose one’s nature most grievously. Is this not lamentable?

Ultimate words abandon words; ultimate actions abandon actions. To equalize what knowledge knows and strive to avoid what all people cannot avoid—though one may know it, such knowledge is shallow.

Those who follow their root—externally transformed yet internally untransformed—respond to things while the mind does not move with them. Internally transformed yet externally untransformed, the mind has no constancy and is jostled by affairs and things. To be transformed with things is external transformation; to remain untransformed is internal non-transformation. What is peace? What is meant by transformation? What is meant by non-transformation? How can one grind against them without being worn away, leaving scarcely anything intact?

From the leather-clad sages, the Yellow Emperor, and the era of Yao and Shun down to the Tang and Wu dynasties, and further to the Confucians, Mohists, and the School of Names—all have engaged in debates of right and wrong, guarding against one another. How much more so for people today? Guarding against one another is even more severe than grinding. Gardens are narrower than parks, and chambers are deeper than halls—each step only deepens the entrenchment. The character *shāng* (傷, harm) here reflects the *mó* (磨, grinding) and *fáng* (防, guarding) above.

**Supplementary Annotation:**
What human knowledge and consideration reach is called "encounter," yet what one encounters is limited. What one’s strength and capacity reach is called "ability," yet what one can do is limited. Thus, one cannot avoid having things one does not know or cannot do. If one does not rest in the truth of one’s nature and fate but vainly seeks beyond one’s allotted portion to be without ignorance or inability, then though one exhausts one’s essence and depletes one’s strength, what one does not know or cannot do only increases. Is this not lamentable? This is not discussed in terms of Heaven and humanity.

**General Observations:**
This chapter takes "knowledge" as its theme, for knowledge is the origin of action and speech. *The Northern Wanderer* seeks the root, implying a return to the source. The *Mysterious Waters* are most wondrous, yet they retain the merit of nourishing things. The parable of having a mind for the Dao—without non-action and non-assertion, one remains obscure to the Dao.

Thus, the three questions go unanswered, for not-knowing is true knowledge. The Yellow Emperor’s answers grow clearer, yet they draw no nearer to the Dao. Therefore, the sage sheds form, abandons knowledge, casts off the body, and dismisses hearing. Through non-action, the myriad things are completed; without speech, the world is transformed. One knows the Dao cannot be possessed, the body cannot be privatized. The existence of things arises from non-existence; the world is pervaded by a single qi. The wondrous and the foul alternate; yin and yang intermingle, spontaneously generating, bursting forth, and silently receding—this is common to all.

To be transformed with things yet remain untransformed is unique to the sage. Life and death follow transformation; one conceals one’s traces and lets go. Abiding in transformation, one follows transformation—without transformation, nothing is not transformed. Forgetting transformation, one is transformed; at peace with transformation, how could one not be at peace?

Each step descends further, hence the Dao resides in tiles and bricks. It employs what is borrowed, not what is owned, thus it excels. The hammer and hook—knowing today, one knows the beginning of Heaven and Earth. Without abiding, one does not depart. Without approaching or withdrawing, one harmonizes the transformations of inner and outer. Engaging with things, one is not harmed.

From this, one knows that those who do not depend on circumstances to be still are still in all things; those who do not depend on things to be joyful are joyful in all things. Transformation cannot move them, nor can burdens encroach. One day may be as a hundred years, a hundred years as a day—how can one know that today’s dwelling is not the Heaven and Earth within a gourd?

Observing the world’s people, they treat things as transient lodgings, yet repeatedly harm their lives and injure their natures through what they encounter and what they can do—no different from sinking sandalwood into a furnace, its fragrance rising only as its form turns to ash. Better to preserve one’s authenticity in not-encountering and inability.

The highest say: the teaching without words, the benefit of non-action—few in the world attain them. Thus, the *Nanhua* concludes the Outer Chapters with "ultimate words abandon words; ultimate actions abandon actions."

**Volume Six of *Zhuangzi Yi* from the *Siku Quanshu*, compiled by Jiao Hong of the Ming Dynasty**
**Miscellaneous Chapters: "Gengsang Chu" (Chapter Twenty-Three)**

Among Lao Dan’s disciples was one named Gengsang Chu, who had partially grasped the Master’s Dao. He went north to dwell on Mount Weilei. Those among his retainers who were cunningly clever departed from him; those among his concubines who were ostentatiously kind kept their distance. Only the dull-witted and the self-contented remained to serve him. After three years, Weilei flourished. The people of Weilei said to one another: “When Master Gengsang first arrived, we found him strange and extraordinary. Now, when we reckon by the day, we feel we have not enough; when we reckon by the year, we find we have more than enough. He must be a sage! Why do we not together offer him the sacrifices due to the spirits of the soil and grain?”

When Gengsang Chu heard this, he turned to face south with a troubled countenance. His disciples were perplexed. Gengsang Chu said: “Disciples, why are you perplexed by me? When spring’s qi stirs, the hundred grasses grow; when autumn arrives in its proper time, the myriad treasures ripen. Is it that spring and autumn achieve this of themselves? The Great Dao has already been at work. I have heard that the perfected person dwells like a corpse in a walled chamber, yet the common people rush about wildly, not knowing where to turn. Now, with the petty folk of Weilei, I am secretly being exalted. They wish to place me among the worthy on their sacrificial platters—am I to become a mere marker for others? This is why I cannot let go of Lao Dan’s words.”

---

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
*Huaran* describes those who adorn their cleverness; *qieran*, those who flaunt their kindness. *Yongzhong* refers to the unrefined; *yangzhang*, to self-contentment. The disciples were perplexed because Gengsang Chu had abandoned cleverness and embraced simplicity. He moves in accord with the four seasons, achieving nothing by deliberate effort. Spring and autumn bring growth and fruition, all through the natural course of the Dao, so he does nothing. The perfected person dwells like a corpse, and the people come of their own accord—not through any exercise of knowledge. Thus, he does not wish to become a marker for others. Laozi said: “When his task is accomplished and his work done, the people all say, ‘We have done it ourselves.’” Now, the people of Weilei do the opposite, which is why Gengsang Chu was troubled.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary:
Lao Dan’s Dao rejects kindness and discards cleverness; it does not exalt worthiness. It does not seek to enlighten the people but to make them simple. Thus, his retainers and concubines who were kind and clever all departed, while only the dull-witted and rigid remained. *Huaran* and *qieran* describe petty cleverness and kindness; *yongzhong* and *yangzhang* denote slowness and inflexibility—these are not those who rely on knowledge or kindness. The people of Weilei were transformed by Gengsang Chu’s Dao, no longer employing cleverness but devoting themselves to clothing and food. Thus, the land flourished. His actions were sufficient to renew the people’s eyes and ears, so they found him strange and extraordinary. His Dao was one of non-action that brought about success, so when reckoned by the day, it seemed insufficient, but when reckoned by the year, it was more than enough. *Shi* and *zhu* refer to the sacrifices offered by rulers and ancestral temples; the people wished to honor him as such. Spring and autumn are the work of Heaven, unknown to the myriad things. The sage dwells like a corpse, and the people do not know where to turn. Now, the petty folk of Weilei wished to place Gengsang Chu among the worthy on their sacrificial platters—this is what is meant by being unable to prevent people from relying on one. How could he not refuse to become a marker for others?

---

The *Xun* edition:
The perfected person dwells like a corpse in a walled chamber, and the people rush about wildly, not knowing where to turn. This means the perfected person remains obscure, and people do not know his name, so they wander without direction. *Shao* is the same as *biao*: when a tree is raised as a marker, all can see it.

Liu Gai’s summary:
“When his task is accomplished and his work done, the people all say, ‘We have done it ourselves.’” Yet the people of Weilei wished to offer sacrifices to Gengsang Chu—was his grasp of the Dao still incomplete? I have heard that if one possesses true substance, people may offer a name, but one should not accept it; to accept is to invite misfortune. Hearing this, Gengsang Chu turned south with a troubled countenance—was his compliance with things still incomplete? I have also heard that Yao did not possess people; people saw him as possessing them. His legacy endures a thousand generations later, but it is only his traces. Thus, Gengsang Chu’s Dao had reached non-action, but it had not yet attained non-non-action.

---

The disciples said: “Not so. In a ditch of ordinary size, a great fish has no room to turn its body, and the minnows and eels become its masters. On a hillock of a few fathoms, a great beast has no place to conceal itself, and the foxes and badgers become its omens. Moreover, to honor the worthy, bestow abilities, praise goodness, and confer benefits—this has been the way since Yao and Shun. How much more so for the people of Weilei? Master, you should listen to them.”

Gengsang Chu said: “Come here, my little ones. A beast that can be enclosed in a carriage, if it leaves the mountains, cannot escape the nets and snares. A fish that can swallow a boat, if it is stranded on land, can be harmed by ants. Thus, birds and beasts do not weary of great heights; fish and turtles do not weary of great depths. For one who preserves his form and life, to hide himself is not to weary of profound obscurity—it is enough. Moreover, what are those two worthies to me?”

In their disputations, they would recklessly breach walls to plant brambles and thistles—combing their hair only to count grains of rice for cooking, all in petty fuss. How could such things suffice to benefit the world? Promote the worthy, and the people will contend with one another; employ cunning, and the people will steal from one another. These practices cannot enrich the people. The people’s pursuit of profit is relentless: sons kill fathers, ministers kill rulers; in broad daylight, they rob, and at noon, they tunnel through walls. I tell you, the root of great chaos must arise between the eras of Yao and Shun, and its branches will endure for a thousand generations. A thousand generations hence, there will surely be men who devour one another.

*(A fathom is eight feet; twice a fathom is a *chang*; six feet make a *bu*; seven feet make a *ren*. "Omens" refers to strange and uncanny things.)*

*(Guo’s commentary: The disciples believed that a great man must possess abundant emoluments, so they urged their master to heed them. His reply was to shun profit and avoid harm, thereby preserving his person whole—if one clings to emoluments, one becomes coarse and shallow, not even equal to fish and turtles. As for the two worthies, Yao and Shun, what merit is there in praising them? They will only cause later generations to recklessly engage in disruptive actions, planting disorder and filth.)*

The trimming of hair or the counting of grains is like tending to the tip of an awl or blade—when all is merged into oneness without deliberate action, only then can one achieve success. If one resists and contravenes one’s nature to await what one esteems, and if what is truly insufficient is pursued through cunning and artifice, then falsehood arises. To seek life through falsehood—how is this not theft? When the people are so ardent in their pursuit of profit that they cast aside all else, it stems from the traces left by Yao and Shun, their embellished deceits sowing the seeds of later corruption.

*(Lü’s commentary: Lao Dan regarded the root as refined and things as coarse, accumulation as insufficiency. Abiding in serene solitude, he dwelt with the spirit luminaries. Chu attained Lao Dan’s Dao, thus concealing himself without tiring of profound obscurity, leaving Yao and Shun’s virtue behind and refusing to emulate them. To distinguish Yao and Shun within the realm where things have never yet arisen—how is this different from chiseling a wall to plant mugwort? It is neither fitting nor useful. Only by aiding things in their natural course without presuming to act can one achieve simplicity and efficacy. Otherwise, it is like trimming hair or counting grains—how can this save the world? The sage’s governance renders the people without knowledge and without desire. Yet observing through the traces of Yao and Shun, one cannot avoid elevating the worthy and employing cunning, ultimately leading to mutual contention and plunder. Thus, the greatness of human nature is altered by knowledge and action, and from this arises the source of disorder.)*

Nan Rong Chu rose abruptly and sat upright, saying: "As for one such as Chu, my years have already grown long. To what end..."

Nan Rong Chu, grasping at this teaching, asked: "Is it truly possible to attain such words?"

Geng Sang Zi replied: "Preserve your form whole, embrace your life—do not let your thoughts and cares flutter restlessly. If you can do this for three years, then you may reach these words."

Nan Rong Chu said: "The eye and the form—I know not their difference, yet the blind cannot see themselves. The ear and the form—I know not their difference, yet the deaf cannot hear themselves. The heart and the form—I know not their difference, yet the mad cannot grasp themselves. The form and the form should be one, yet things somehow come between them. I long to seek and attain this, yet now you tell me: *Preserve your form whole, embrace your life—do not let your thoughts and cares flutter restlessly.* I strain to hear the Dao, but my ears alone are open."

Geng Sang Zi said: "My words are exhausted. The fleeing bee cannot transform the hornworm; the Yue chicken cannot hatch the swan’s egg, but the Lu chicken surely can. Chickens and chickens—their virtue is not different, yet some can and some cannot, for their capacities are inherently great or small. Now my capacity is small and insufficient to transform you. Why not go south to see Laozi?"

*(Annotations in original: Nan Rong Chu is listed as Nan Rong Chou in the *Gujin Ren Biao*. The "fleeing bee" is a small wasp. The "hornworm" is a large green caterpillar found in bean leaves. "Swan" here uses the ancient character for "crane.")*

Guo's commentary: *"Preserve your form"* means to guard your allotted portion; *"embrace your life"* means not to grasp at what lies beyond life. Eyes with eyes, ears with ears, minds with minds—their forms may resemble one another, yet their capacities differ. If there are differences, one cannot forcibly imitate another. *"Whole"* does not mean closed off; the two forms are open yet cannot attain one another—something must come between them. Having heard early that forms are separated, transformation thus becomes difficult.

Lü's commentary: Virtue left Yao and Shun behind not because it left no traces—it was perfect. Yet how could one prevent karma and still attain this? The answer: the form that humans constantly preserve, where spirit obtains life, is one and the same. How could external things be the affliction? But when ears and eyes cling to sounds and sights, nose and mouth cling to scents and flavors, and the mind is enslaved by things, then the form is diminished and not whole, life is severed and not embraced, and thoughts and cares flutter restlessly without cease. Thus one cannot be free of things. Only by preserving the form whole, embracing life, and having no restless thoughts can the constant mind be attained. Where then could so-called sagely wisdom, benevolence, and righteousness find a place? As for the ears...

The eyes do not distinguish sounds and colors, the mind’s knowing does not discern right and wrong—this is what the world calls deafness and madness. Yet for those who follow the Dao, not seeing for oneself is blindness, not hearing for oneself is deafness, not attaining for oneself is madness.
