Madness and sageliness lie only in whether one clings to thoughts or not. My form and another’s form both preserve spirit, and spirit has no fixed direction. How could there be anything that closes and does not open? The reason they seek each other yet cannot attain one another is merely that something intervenes. Though Chu claims never to have heard the Dao, what he knows already differs from ordinary people—he simply has not yet matched Zhuangzi’s words with his own heart.

The superficial may reach the ears, but when spirit awakens, it penetrates the heart. How could a puddle’s minnows know the transformation of the kun and peng? How could a wasp’s nest contain the fledgling of a roc? The principle is naturally so. This is why Gengsangzi declined Chu’s questions, wishing to conceal his mad words to preserve himself and defer to the ultimate principle with Lao Dan.

The human mind, eyes, and ears are all open, yet the mad cannot attain themselves, just as the deaf and blind perceive nothing. My form and others’ forms are fundamentally open and unobstructed, yet now they are divided by desires. Seeking mind with mind, they cannot attain one another. You taught me not to let thoughts flutter restlessly—if I strive in this, might I yet reach understanding? Chu’s words show no sign of liberation, and Gengsangzi, wishing to prevent further delusion, could only say, “My words are exhausted.”

Nanrong Chu carried provisions for seven days and nights until he reached Laozi’s abode. Laozi said, “Have you come from Chu?”
Nanrong Chu replied, “Yes.”
Laozi said, “Why have you brought so many people with you?”
Nanrong Chu looked back in alarm. Laozi said, “Do you not understand what I mean?”
Nanrong Chu bowed his head in shame, then looked up and sighed, “Now I have forgotten my answer and lost my question.”
Laozi said, “What do you mean?”
Nanrong Chu said, “Is it not so? People call me foolish, yet if I were wise, I would only grieve for my body. If I were not benevolent, I would harm others, yet if I were benevolent, I would grieve for myself. If I were not righteous, I would injure others, yet if I were righteous, I would grieve for myself. How can I escape this? These three concerns are what trouble me. I wish to ask you about them through Chu.”
Laozi said, “Just now, I saw it in the space between your brows, and thus I understood you. Now you speak again, and I believe you—yet you are so narrow-minded, as if you had lost your parents and were holding a pole to search for them in the sea. You are lost! Bewildered! You wish to return to your true nature yet have no way in. How pitiful!”

Nanrong Chu asked to enter and rest in the guest quarters. He summoned what he loved and cast aside what he despised. After ten days of sorrow, he saw Laozi again. Laozi said, “You have cleansed yourself—how thoroughly! Yet you remain so burdened.”

Yet within you, there lingers a lingering aversion. Those bound by external fetters cannot be grasped by clinging, nor can those shackled within be seized by twisting. How much less can those who let the Dao run wild and act without restraint hold fast to virtue and power?

Nanrong Chu said, “When a villager falls ill, another villager asks after him. The sick man can describe his illness, yet the one who is truly ill does not know his own sickness. Now, when I hear the great Dao, it is like taking medicine that only worsens my condition. I wish only to hear the classic of preserving life.”

Laozi said, “Can you embrace the One and never lose it? Can you foretell fortune and misfortune without divination? Can you come to rest? Can you cease striving? Can you abandon seeking in others and turn inward to seek in yourself? Can you be carefree? Can you be uncontrived? Can you be like a child?

A child may wail all day without hoarseness—such is the perfection of harmony. A child may clench its fist all day without cramping—such is the constancy of its power. A child may gaze all day without blinking—its attention is not fixed on externals. It walks without knowing where it goes, dwells without knowing what it does, moves with things and flows with their current. This is the classic of preserving life.”

The ears and eyes belong to the external, while the mind’s workings reside within. To preserve form and embrace life, nothing compares to forgetting the mind’s workings and abandoning the ears and eyes. Yet when sounds and sights entangle the external, the mind’s workings become obstructed within; when desires and aversions entangle the internal, the ears and eyes are lost to the external. Thus, only by having no gains and no losses can one attain thoroughfare. Even partial entanglement is unacceptable—how much worse when both external and internal are ensnared?

The ears and eyes are bewildered by the external, while the mind’s workings drift and surge within. Though one may grasp with frantic hands and bind with anxious care, one cannot halt it. Embracing the One without parting is to abide in one’s nature; not losing it is to return and find oneself. Rightness brings fortune, excess brings misfortune—no divination is needed. "Coming to rest" means resting within one’s allotment; "ceasing striving" means leaving no trace behind. "Abandoning seeking in others and turning inward" is to preserve the self without imitating others. "Carefree" means leaving no lingering traces; "uncontrived" means having no obstructions.

The throat does not grow hoarse because it lets sound emerge naturally, not through joy or anger. The hand does not cramp because it lets itself clench naturally, not through deliberate effort. The eyes do not blink because they let themselves see naturally, not fixed upon forms. Walking without knowing the destination, the feet proceed of their own accord, unobstructed. Dwelling without knowing what to do, the body follows its own course. Flowing with things and following their current—this is compliance. Moving with their waves, one’s own waves merge with theirs.

To know obstruction is to detest the mind’s turbulence and wish to cleanse it, returning to emptiness and stillness—this is to summon the good and dispel the bad. Yet one remains unable to practice this, and so the gloomy qi fills one’s essence, seeping and leaking. Where things cling and prove difficult to remove, one now resents the ears and eyes for being ensnared by sounds and sights, yet seeks to grasp and hold them—this is frantic restraint. Better to inwardly close off: when the mind does not go forth, the external is not entangled. As Laozi said, "Block the openings, shut the doors."

When the mind’s workings are entangled by affairs and endeavors, and one seeks to halt them one by one—this is anxious restraint. Better to outwardly close off: when things do not enter, the internal is not entangled. As Laozi said, "Open the gates, untie the tangles." Thus, in perfect stillness and non-action, the myriad things cannot disturb the mind. Otherwise, even those with the Way and its power may fail to maintain it—how much more those who merely imitate?

Those who hear the Dao know that from the beginning there has been nothing to do. You have diagnosed your own illness but lack the medicine of the great Dao; you wish only to hear the classic of preserving life. Preserving life takes non-action as its classic. The One is where the Dao arises, where auspiciousness abides—what need is there for divination? All this comes from halting one’s thoughts and endeavors and seeking within oneself. Carefree without attachment, uncontrived without obstruction—thus one becomes like a child.

If one’s howls arise from grief and rage yet remain unharmonized, how can their power not be hoarse? To the point of grasping without knowing it is a grasp, seeing without knowing it is sight—all movement and stillness arise from non-mind, flowing with things like waves in a current: this is the classic of preserving life.

**Following the Root:**
*"Vexation"* (韄) means binding things with leather to restrain them; *"barrier"* (揵) refers to the bolt of a door, closing it off. If one restrains the external with excessive complexity, rendering it ungraspable, one will instead shut it out internally. If one restrains the internal with delusion and chaos, rendering it ungraspable, one will instead shut it out externally. When both internal and external are bound, the affliction is thus.

**Brush Notes:**
To embrace the One and not lose it is what the *Dao De Jing* calls *"carrying spirit and soul, embracing the One, able to not part."* To know good and ill fortune without divination is *"not stepping out the door yet knowing the world, not peering through the window yet seeing the Dao of Heaven."* To halt is to know when to stop; to cease is to know contentment. Abandoning others to seek within oneself is *"the self-knowing are enlightened, the self-conquering are strong."* *"Carefree"* (翛然) is *"floating—how it may drift left or right!"* *"Uncontrived"* (侗然) is *"blended—how it seems turbid!"* *"Child"* is *"concentrating qi to attain softness, able to be like an infant."* Harmony at its utmost shares its power universally, not residing externally—this is what is meant by *"containing virtue in abundance, comparable to a newborn."*

Nanrong Chu said: "Then is this the virtue of the perfected person?"
"No," was the reply. "This is merely what is called *ice melting, frost dissolving.* The perfected person shares sustenance with others on earth and shares joy with them in heaven, not entangled by the gains and harms of people and things. They do not conspire in strangeness, do not scheme together, do not engage in affairs. They come and go carefree, uncontrived—this is called the classic of preserving life."
Chu said: "Then is this perfection?"
"Not yet. I have already told you: can you be like a child? A child moves without knowing what it does, walks without knowing where it goes. Its body is like the branch of a withered tree, its mind like dead ashes. In this state, misfortune does not arrive, nor does fortune. Fortune and misfortune have no place, nor do the calamities of others."

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Chu asks: "If one can reform oneself and apply these words, can this be called the virtue of the perfected person?" *"Ice melting, frost dissolving"* means being able—yet this is not something one achieves alone. *"Sharing sustenance, sharing joy"* arises from having no self, all being shared with things. Chu then asks: "Can one attain perfection simply by hearing these words?" The answer is no—these words are not perfection itself, but merely what one who hears and studies may follow. If one does not attain it oneself, then even hearing the words of perfection can only serve as a classic—how can one reach perfection? Thus, the learner does not reach it; the perfected does not learn. Misfortune and fortune arise from loss and gain; the calamities of others stem from love and hate. Now, with the extremity of a withered tree and dead ashes—utterly without emotion—love and hate, loss and gain have no way to arise.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The human mind, serene like water, is obstructed by knowledge and cannot remain empty—like water freezing into ice. Knowing the classic of preserving life, the ice melts and the frost dissolves. The perfected person’s mind is always like water, so their virtue is not cultivated yet things cannot depart from them. They share sustenance and joy without entanglement in gain and harm. Not conspiring in strangeness, they are not seen as strange by the world; not scheming together, they are not aligned with the world. Without attachment or obstruction, how could they fail to embrace the One and not lose it? Carefree and uncontrived—what more need be asked? This is why the perfected person is the constant of preserving life, yet not its ultimate. The so-called ultimate is merely what lies beyond knowing. The child’s not knowing where it goes or what it does, being like a withered tree or dead ashes—this is it. Misfortune and fortune arise from having a body and mind, governed by heaven, earth, and spirits. If one’s body is withered and mind is ash, how can they be burdened?

**Personal Insight:**
The true nature is like water—empty, bright, clear, and profound, neither existent nor nonexistent. When obscured by worldly desires, it congeals like water freezing into ice. Water is utterly clear yet freezes into impure ice; spirit is utterly numinous yet congeals into dull form. Hearing the Dao and awakening to principle, the ice melts and frost dissolves—what harm is there to clarity and numinosity? The problem lies in not turning inward to seek. *"Sharing sustenance on earth"* means tilling and laboring together; *"sharing joy in heaven"* means harmonizing with the great harmony. If so, how could the gains and harms of people and things reach them? What use are strange actions, schemes, or affairs? Coming and going, how could they not be at ease? How could the classic of life not be preserved? Attaining this in learning the Dao is already perfection—yet it is still called *"not yet."* When pressed on what perfection is, the earlier words about the child are repeated—this is the teacher’s technique, shifting the listener’s perspective to prevent attachment.

**When the abode of the spirit is stable and settled, it emits the light of heaven.** When it emits the light of heaven, people see the person, but the person has cultivation—only now is there constancy. Those with constancy are abandoned by people yet aided by heaven. What people abandon are called *"heavenly people"*; what heaven aids are called *"heavenly sons."* The learner learns what they cannot learn; the doer does what they cannot do; the debater debates what they cannot debate. Knowing when to stop at what cannot be known—this is perfection. If there is any deviation, the balance of heaven will ruin it.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
When the abode of virtue is stable and settled, what it emits is the light of heaven, not human brilliance. When the light of heaven emits itself, people see the person, and things see things—each seeing itself, not seeing what makes the other stable and settled. If one cultivates as a person, one naturally attains it. Thus, there is constant stability, and one can return to dwell in one’s own abode, naturally receiving aid. Going forth, one is a heavenly son; staying, one is a heavenly person—both arise from stability and self-attainment, not from striving. Thus, all one’s abilities—though acted upon—are not action; though practiced—are not learning; though spoken—are not debate. What cannot be known cannot be forced to know, so stopping at this is perfection. If one intends to act, one will surely fail, for principle ultimately cannot be forced.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The body is the abode of the person. Without obstruction or chaos, it emits the light of heaven. The light of heaven is unknowing and unperceiving, clear and penetrating. People see the person yet do not know their heaven—this is a person in appearance yet heaven in reality. Those who cultivate must reach heaven to endure. *"Abandoned by people"* means being among the crowd; *"aided by heaven"* means attaining heaven alone. The heavenly person is not something people can possess; the heavenly son arises from following heaven’s mandate. The things of the world can be known—thus, what can be learned is learned, what can be done is done, what can be debated is debated. Only the Dao cannot be known—thus, learning what cannot be learned is *"learning the unlearnable"* (as the classic says); doing what cannot be done is *"the Dao of the undone"*; debating what cannot be debated is *"the debate of the unspoken."* If one deviates from this and does not avoid action, one will fail.

To prepare things for the body’s form, to store against the unforeseen for the mind’s life, to revere the center to reach the other—if one is thus, then the myriad evils that arrive are all of heaven, not of man. They are not enough to disturb the marrow or become lodged within the *lingtai*. The *lingtai* has something it holds yet does not know what it holds, and what cannot be held. It does not see its own sincerity when it acts, and with every act it misses the mark; when karma enters and does not abide, with every change it becomes a loss—is this not doing evil? In the midst of clarity, can people condemn it as evil? In the midst of seclusion, can demons condemn it as evil? Only when one is enlightened can one act alone. Those who act within their contract remain within bounds; those who act beyond their contract set their minds on what is costly. To act without a name is merely to have light; to set one’s mind on what is costly is only to be a merchant. People see their striving as towering, yet it is but a hollow prominence. Those who exhaust themselves with things allow things to enter; those who merely accompany things cannot even contain themselves. One who can contain others yet cannot contain others has no kinship. One who has no kinship treats all people as enemies. No weapon is more cruel than the will; no bandit is more base than yin and yang. There is no escape from them between heaven and earth—unless yin and yang harm the mind, it is the mind that commands them.

---
**Guo’s Commentary:**
It means preparing for oneself and following the completion of form, allowing the mind to arise naturally—not through calculation or foresight. It reaches the other of its own accord, not by neglecting the center while revering the exterior. If one is thus and the myriad evils arrive, it is the natural principle of heaven’s ebb and flow. Evil that arises from action is of man; accepting it as fate is to remain undisturbed. What does not disturb the *lingtai* is the mind—clear and unobstructed, so that worries and misfortunes cannot enter. "Having something it holds" means not being moved by things, yet in truth it is not holding. If one knows what it holds and tries to hold it, holding is lost. Action that does not arise from one’s own sincerity—how can it be fitting? Affairs that do not reside within one’s proper role are thus lost. If one is without guilt in both the hidden and the manifest, one can act alone without fear, fulfilling one’s contract. Those who move within their bounds act without seeking a name; those who move beyond their bounds expect benefit or loss, seeking to expend themselves for things. To act without a name is to inherently possess this light and employ it. To set one’s mind on what is costly is, though one lacks it oneself, to borrow from others and trade like a merchant. Those who set their minds on what is costly appear to people as striving, yet they deem themselves secure. "Exhausting" refers to beginning and end; "merely accompanying" refers to acting beyond one’s contract while striving. One who strives cannot stand; one who can contain themselves cannot contain themselves, let alone contain others. How then can they have kinship? Thus, they treat all others as enemies, and their wills clash like scorching fire and congealing ice. Their weapons are sharper than swords and shields, for when the mind commands qi, yin and yang gather and bind in the five viscera. Wherever they reside, yin and yang are inescapable.

---
**Lü’s Commentary:**
The myriad things and I are one. "Preparing things for the body’s form" means that wherever one goes, things follow; when things come, the mind emerges—not born of foresight. Thus, reverence arises and reaches the other, not by holding externally but by revering to straighten the interior. If one is thus and the myriad evils arrive, they are of heaven, for they arise from not acting and thus failing. They are not enough to disturb the completion of the *lingtai*. When unmoved, it has something it holds, yet what holds it is unknown—it is held by not holding. Knowing this, what is called sincerity acts and must hit the mark; otherwise, reckless action brings misfortune—how could it be fitting? Karma enters from without yet has no master within, and thus it does not abide. "Does not abide" means it departs swiftly; "with every change it becomes a loss" refers to vulgar learning that seeks to return to the origin yet cannot avoid being deluded by *huanbi*. A contract is what governs things and possesses them. Acting with what one has within is acting within one’s contract—sincerity acting alone. Acting without what one has within is acting beyond one’s contract—sincerity is not seen, and the hidden and manifest are not unified. "Without a name" is the Dao, thus it is trustworthy yet does not expect; it does not expend. Those who act beyond their contract must first expect and expend to be trustworthy and to give. Only the ordinary have light that is not used, returning to its brightness; only merchants trade. It is merely a marketplace. People see their insufficiency and strive in admiration, like something towering and self-important. If one can see that things have never begun, then one exhausts things and has no self; with no self, things enter without obstruction—this is called knowing the constant and containing it. Otherwise, one merely accompanies things, and the self cannot contain itself. As it is said, "Your fragment of body will not be accepted by qi; your single joint will not be borne by the earth"—how then can one contain others? One who cannot contain others has no kinship; with no kinship, all people are as enemies. The will as a weapon harms the mind; *moye* blades harm the body. Bandits as thieves can be escaped, but the bandits of yin and yang cannot be escaped between heaven and earth. Only the perfected person weakens their will and does not insist, thus having no weapon. Hidden in the non-yin and non-yang, with no mind, the myriad things cannot steal from them.

---
**Xu’s Commentary:**
A contract is a union. Union within has no name; union without always has expectations and expenditures. One who strives to stand is seen by people as towering, yet is not truly towering—towering is not *kuang*. To speak of expectations and expenditures while forcing oneself is like this: pursuing things and going forth, things also enter—transformed by things. Those who merely accompany things are like those who temporarily agree yet their minds are not in it. With the mind not in it, the self cannot even contain itself—how can it be with others? Thus, outside the self there is no kinship; with no kinship, all are the people of the crowd.

---
**Supplementary Note:**
"Expecting expenditures" means seeking broadly and striving for much, like the saying "not discarding the small or the great"—thus it is likened to a merchant, meaning it is like commerce.

---
**Hong Mai’s Note:**
Guo Xiang said: "Having something it holds means not being moved by things, yet in truth it is not holding. If one knows what it holds and tries to hold it, holding is lost."

Chen Bixu said: "The true master abides within—following one’s formed mind as teacher." All these place their discourse beyond the realm of words and meaning, delving ever deeper into the profound, borrowing the words of *Zhuangzi* to expound, yet missing the original intent.

I once recall Hong Qingshan’s remark: "This chapter speaks of the Dao of holding the mind. If one does not know the means by which it is held, it can no longer be held." The two earlier interpretations were misled by the word "and," thus constructing their explanations accordingly.

The Dao flows through its allotted portion. What completes it also destroys it. What is detested in allotment is the allotment itself—what completes it is the very reason it is detested. Thus, emerging without return reveals its *gu*—emerging yet attaining is called attaining annihilation, possessing the reality of *gu* as one.

By means of the formed, one images the formless and settles it. Emerging without origin, entering without aperture—possessing reality yet nowhere to reside. Having growth yet no root, swiftness without source—this is space. Having growth yet no root, swiftness without source—this is time. There is that from which life arises, there is that from which...

The dead—does it have a "from"? The emergent—does it have a "from"? Entering and emerging without visible form—this is called the Celestial Gate. The Celestial Gate is Non-Being. All things emerge from Non-Being. Being cannot take Being as its Being; it must emerge from Non-Being. Yet Non-Being itself is not a "one" of Non-Being. The sage conceals himself therein.

Guo Xiang’s Annotation:
Completion and destruction are without constancy, yet the Dao flows through all allotments. Not abiding by one’s allotment while seeking completion—this is why allotment is detested. The root allotment is incomplete, yet one seeks completion through it—this is why completion is detested. If the root allotment were inherently complete, how could it be detested? Not returning to guard one’s allotment within, then death will not be long in coming. Not emerging yet attaining nothing—only then is life attained. Once one’s nature is extinguished, even if this life remains, how does it differ from *gu*? Even if this form remains, if one can be vast and without attachment, then life is preserved and form stabilized. Sudden emergence arises without root; sudden death occurs without source. What emerges does so from its own reality. That from which it emerges has no root or aperture. Space has four directions—above, below, and the four quarters—yet these are without limit. Time has the length of past and present, yet this length is without end. Death and life, emergence and entry—all occur suddenly of themselves, without cause, and thus no form is seen. The Celestial Gate is the great name for the convergence of the ten thousand things, like the "gate of all mysteries." Death and life, emergence and entry—sudden and self-so, without any agent. Yet gathering and scattering, concealment and revelation, give rise to the names of emergence and entry, though in truth there is no emergence, no entry, no gate. Where, then, could a gate reside? Thus, Non-Being is the gate. If Non-Being is the gate, then there is no gate. Before Being arises, what generates it? It must arise from itself. How could Being possess the power to generate Being? Clearly, Being cannot generate Being but arises of itself—not that Non-Being generates Being. If Non-Being could generate Being, what would Non-Being be? If Non-Being were a "one," it would be utterly null. That Non-Being is utterly null proves that Being arises suddenly of itself. Thus, the sage allows things to arise of themselves without generating life.

Lü Huiqing’s Annotation:
All things possess the Dao, so there is no completion or destruction—only their allotment, which is why the Dao flows through them. Completion is what gives rise to destruction; why detest allotment? Because it is completed. Why detest completion? Because of allotment. Completion is the fulfillment of allotment. If completion is set against allotment, then allotment becomes distinct from flow. If completion arises not from non-action but from deliberate effort, then it diverges from destruction. This is how the Dao disperses. Only by allotting without seeking completion, and completing without relying on completion, can one flow without obstruction. The Dao is without death or life, yet if there is life, it must return to what has never been born—then life is preserved. Emerging without returning, though alive, reveals its *gu*. Emerging and attaining—this is the result of deliberate action, and thus death is fitting. Extinguished yet possessing reality, it cannot return to the formless. Emerging without return and emerging to attain—how do these differ? Thus, their *gu* is one. Only by using the formed to image the formless can one settle it. Settled, one is not disturbed by death or life. Things that emerge must have a root, yet those emerging from the Dao have no root. Things that enter must have an aperture, yet those entering the Dao have no aperture. Things possessing reality must have a place, yet those emerging without root have reality without place. Things possessing growth must have a source, yet those entering without aperture have growth without source. Thus, the text should read: "Emerging without root, possessing reality; entering without aperture, possessing growth." Only then is the meaning complete. Space has four directions—above, below, and the four quarters—yet it possesses reality. If I take what is above me as "above," then what is above that becomes "below" for me. The same applies to what is below and the four quarters—where, then, is there a fixed place? Time has the length of past and present, yet it has no source. If I take the past as "past," then what comes after the present becomes "past"—where, then, is there a source? Realizing this, the cosmos cannot constrain one; the six directions open freely, and there is nowhere one is not present. Though death and life, emergence and entry exist, no form is seen—this is called the Celestial Gate. The Celestial Gate is Non-Being. Being cannot generate Being; it must emerge from Non-Being. The things of the world arise from Being, and Being arises from Non-Being—this is so. What is called "Non-Being" is not the absence of Being but the absence of any "one" of Non-Being—utter nullity. The sage conceals himself therein, roaming where things cannot escape and all are preserved.

The "Deputy Ink" [a metaphor for written teachings]:

The Dao is the uncarved simplicity of pre-heaven. When this simplicity scatters, it divides; when it divides, there is formation and destruction—but the Dao has never once departed from them. Thus, to penetrate its divisions, to penetrate its formations, to penetrate its destructions—none of these are not the Dao. When it divides, the Dao resides in the division; one need not seek completeness in its unity. The same holds true for formation and destruction: follow its inherent division, and each rests in what it ought to attain—thus, there is no aversion.

The aversion to division arises from the burden of seeking completeness. The aversion to seeking completeness stems from the notion that there is something to be complete. With this notion, one sees completeness but not division; thus, division brings anxiety. One sees formation but not destruction; thus, destruction brings sorrow. This is not knowing that the Dao is all-penetrating and cannot enter without self-attainment.

For one who knows the Dao, it is otherwise: though there be destruction and division, nothing is not at peace. When death comes, one is at peace with death and does not seek completeness in life. Thus, "emerging without returning" is the metaphor for emerging without returning—single-minded in this, without turning to that.

For humans, emerging and attaining this is the Dao of non-return. People call this death, yet how would they know that what perishes is not lost? Thus, to guard it is to have the reality of the "One." The One is the actual ground of principle. Therefore, extinction is not extinction, emptiness is not emptiness—this is because the metaphor of the "One" reveals the true principle of creation, which does not lie beyond it.

Thus, in human affairs, all is settled. Settled, there is no mind that seeks completeness, and formation and destruction, division and unity are all at peace. In life, one comes without root—hence it is called "emerging" without origin. In death, one departs without gate—hence it is called "entering" without aperture. Without origin, without aperture, there is no direction or place. Thus, it is said: "There is reality yet no place," and "There is length yet no beginning or end"—this is the true principle.

That there is reality yet no place means above and below, the four directions are all one. That there is length yet no beginning or end means past and present are all one. Emergence and entry, death and life—none do not proceed from this. Yet if one seeks its form, it is utterly unattainable. Hence, it is called the Celestial Gate.

To say that Non-Being is the Celestial Gate is not to posit Non-Being as something, but to negate even Non-Being. When both person and dharma are forgotten, subject and object are both relinquished—this is the sage’s desire to conceal the spirit. Beyond this, there is no refuge.

The ancients’ knowledge reached a certain point—where did it reach? It reached the point of taking what has not yet begun to be a thing as the ultimate. This is perfection, the utmost, beyond which nothing can be added. Those of the next rank took things as existing, regarding life as loss and death as return. Thus, they divided themselves. Those of yet another rank said: first there was Non-Being, then there was life, and life soon becomes death. They took Non-Being as the head, life as the body, and death as the tail. Who knows the one who abides in the unity of Being, Non-Being, death, and life? I would befriend such a one. Though these three ranks differ, they belong to the same clan—like the Zhao and Jing lineages, the eminent Dai, and the noble Jia, each distinguished by their insignia. They are not one, yet life is obscure, and when one declares, “This shifts,” it is as if one has spoken of this shift—but this is not what was meant. Nevertheless, it remains unknowable.

The sacrificial ox’s tripe and hooves may be separated, yet they cannot be truly separated. One who observes a house surveys its halls and ancestral temples, then proceeds to its privies. In this way, what is raised up is shifted. Thus, they propose: “Let us speak of this shift.” They take life as the root and knowledge as the teacher, riding upon right and wrong. As a result, names and realities become fixed, and the self is taken as the standard, leading people to treat it as their own measure. They even repay this measure with death. If this is so, then utility is deemed wisdom, disuse is deemed folly, success is deemed fame, and failure is deemed disgrace. This is the “shift” of people today.

This is like the cicada and the owl, which are the same in their sameness. Guo’s commentary: “Life as loss—loss is dispersion and departure toward gathering. Death as return—return is the restoration of fusion. Though one may wish to equalize them, they are already divided. Thus, some take Being as Non-Being, some take Being as One, and some divide and equalize them. Though these three differ in completeness and incompleteness, all can free their hearts from right and wrong, hence they are called the same clan. The Zhao, Jing, Dai, and Jia, though all of the same clan, are not identical—thus the three ranks mentioned earlier are again differentiated. *Yan* (obscurity) is simply the gathering of qi. Once it is openly divided, each takes what it takes as right. Since rightness has no constancy, it is called ‘shift.’ The shift of what is right has already been established before words. If one does not speak of the shift, the shift remains unknowable—hence the attempt to speak of it.

The sacrificial ox’s tripe and hooves are an analogy: things each have their use. *Yan* refers to privies. Halls and temples are for feasting, while privies are for relieving oneself. When one relieves oneself, the rightness of halls and temples shifts to the privy. Thus, the shift of right and wrong is now here, now there—who can make it constant? The perfected person thus rides upon it, equalizing all. In the ceaseless transformations of things, wherever there is life, there is the root. Taking knowledge as the teacher, though what is known differs, each takes their own knowledge as their teacher. Riding upon right and wrong means having no right or wrong. That names and realities are fixed means that the names and realities of things are each inherently their own. *Zhi* (substance) is the master. Things each take themselves as sufficient to be the master of right and wrong, all claiming to be right—thus none communicate. In holding to their position, they are not truly liberated. Those who distinguish wisdom and folly, fame and disgrace cannot follow what they encounter and find peace in it.

The people of profound antiquity had no right or wrong—what shift could there be? Thus, it is said: ‘The shift belongs to the people of today.’ To be the same in sameness is no different for the cicada and the owl.” Lü’s commentary: “Though the three ranks differ, all return to the Dao, just as they belong to the same clan, though the Zhao, Jing, Dai, and Jia differ in closeness and distance. That within the realm of what has not yet begun to be a thing there is life is like the skin having a blemish—it is not its true body. Yet the two schools’ discussions openly divide, one taking things as existing and regarding life as loss, the other taking the beginning as Non-Being, then suddenly there is life. Thus, the wholeness of what has not yet begun to be a thing shifts to become the blemish of having life—this too is unknowable.

It is like the sacrificial feast, which assembles a hundred things, including tripe and hooves. These cannot be called not part of the hundred things, yet they cannot be separated. They cannot be separated because they are at the base of the body. One who observes a house surveys its halls and temples, then proceeds to its privies. The privy cannot be called not part of the house, yet one cannot speak of it as grand. The observer does so because of its lowly place. The Dao is present everywhere, so one cannot speak of a shift. What is spoken of as right and wrong is like this. The two schools’ theories are thus called ‘raising the shift’—this is why they have not reached the utmost, not attained perfection.

The theory of the shift begins with the existence of life, thus taking life as the root. Life arises from having knowledge, thus taking knowledge as the teacher. Following this, they ride upon each other, and right and wrong multiply. When right and wrong shift, names and realities become fixed, and the self is taken as the standard. At its worst, one takes what one deems right as one’s own measure and holds to it, even repaying it with death. They do not know that the so-called self is also what has not yet begun to be a thing. Use and disuse, success and failure—none of these are the self. Yet they falsely create distinctions of wisdom and folly, fame and disgrace. This is the flaw of the ‘shift’ of people today. Like the owl being the same in its sameness, how can they know the greatness of the Celestial Pond?”

Bi Xu’s commentary: “The Zhao and Jing are collateral branches of the Chu ducal clan. *Zhuo Dai* refers to their grand attire, *Jia Shi* to their lofty lineage, and *Zhuo Feng* to their abundant domains and counties. Though their affairs differ, they do not depart from the Chu capital. Just as life and death, though different, both emerge from the primordial qi.” Xun Ben’s commentary: “*Dai* refers to office and rank, *Feng* to fiefdoms. Though the three ranks differ, they are like the Zhao and Jia, all of the Chu ducal clan, distinguished only by their offices or fiefs, hence their differences. *Yan* is the soot at the bottom of a cauldron. *Piran* means scattered. *Yi Shi* (shift) refers to what is called rightness being unstable. The soot at the bottom of a cauldron, once scattered, shifts without constancy—hence it is called ‘shift.’ Like the sacrificial feast, where tripe and hooves are divided on the platter, they can be separated, yet as parts of one ox’s body, they cannot be separated. Or like observing a house, one must survey its halls and temples to call it complete, yet one must also proceed to its privies. Observing one requires division, while uniting requires combination. This is the unknowable. From this perspective, where is there a true rightness? The cicada and the owl are two creatures, yet they are the same—and people are the same as them. Thus, it is said: ‘the same in sameness.’”

Guan Jian’s commentary: “Endowed with form and below, one desires to return to...”

“Never having begun with things—is this not difficult? All things that exist are illusions. When the mind abides, they abide; when the mind perishes, they perish. If my mind does not sprout, in solitude and independence, it may be called ‘never having begun with things.’ If by chance one attains this, then even life and death are but lodgings.

The ancients who attained the Dao could do so. Next are those who, though things exist and life and death are distinct, can treat life as loss and death as return—thus differing from ordinary people adrift in the flow of life and death. Yet another level says there is no distinction between life and death, from head to tail, from beginning to end.

Though these three differ, they all emerge from the Dao, just as the royal clans of Chu, though one, have the three surnames of Zhao, Qu, and Jing. The soot that cakes at the bottom of a cauldron resembles form yet is not form, arising from form. Humans, lodging in form to have life, are like that soot. In an instant, it scatters—what was called ‘I’ shifts elsewhere, and one cannot definitively speak of its being or non-being. Thus, let us speak in analogy: in the sacrificial feast, tripe and hooves complete the body of the offering to present to the spirits—they cannot be separated. Once the rite ends and the sacrificial meat is divided, they can be. Observing the ancestral temple evokes reverence; entering the privy, one cannot but guard against carelessness. All these are instances of shifting rightness.

Let us place the five characters ‘this is the unknowable’ before the five preceding sentences. As seen in Guo’s commentary below, people’s self-rightness arises from having life, and life gives rise to knowledge, which becomes their guide. These two, life and knowledge, ride upon each other without cease. If one stubbornly clings to them as names and realities, taking them as one’s own substance, they cannot be changed. This means one cannot see through the illusory dust and mistake the empty for the real. Taking names and realities as one’s own measure and repaying them with death—all this stems from self-rightness, which leads to such harm. The world follows this habit without awakening to its error, no different from the cicada and owl content with the elm and sandalwood, unaware of the roc’s journey of ninety thousand miles.”

*Jian*:
When one treads on a market-goer’s foot, one excuses oneself as careless; with an elder brother, one acts as a doting mother; with one’s parents, one simply does as they wish. Thus it is said: “Ultimate ritual does not involve others; ultimate rightness does not objectify; ultimate wisdom does not scheme; ultimate benevolence has no favorites; ultimate trust dispels gold and unblocks the will.”

Agitation of the will comes from six things: wealth, honor, prestige, fame, profit. Distortion of the mind comes from six: demeanor, movement, expression, principle, qi, intent. Encumbrance of virtue comes from six: aversion, desire, joy, anger, sorrow, delight. Obstruction of the Dao comes from six: departure, approach, taking, giving, knowledge, ability.

If these twenty-four are not swept from the breast, then:
No agitation—rectitude.
Rectitude—stillness.
Stillness—clarity.
Clarity—emptiness.
Emptiness—non-action, yet nothing is not done.

The Dao is the reverence of virtue; life is the radiance of virtue.”

The nature is the essence of life. The movement of nature is called action; its artificiality is called error. Knowledge is encounter; wisdom is strategy. What knowledge does not know is like a sidelong glance.

Movement from necessity is called virtue; movement without self-exclusion is called governance. Names may oppose each other, yet in reality they accord.

Guo’s Commentary:
If one treads on a stranger’s foot, one excuses oneself with carelessness; if it is an elder brother, one humbly apologizes without refusal; if it is a close relative, one does nothing—this is the plain sufficiency of understanding and forbearance. Not involving others means regarding others as oneself; regarding others as oneself means no mutual apologies—this is the ultimate of ritual. "Not objectifying" means each attains its proper place, so all things are oneself. To know only after scheming is not natural; thus, ultimate wisdom does not scheme. It is like the five viscera never having been intimate, yet benevolence already exists—thus, ultimate benevolence has no favorites. Gold and jade are but the substance of petty trust; great trust dispenses with them—thus, ultimate trust dispels gold.

This is called "ear" because it moves from nature itself, constituting true action, not contrived action. The eye’s ability to see is not knowing how to see but seeing; not knowing how to know but knowing—this is what is meant by natural. If one acts only after knowing, that knowing is artificial. To move only when compelled is to act with strength, thus to err. To act by imitating others is to invite chaos, for there are names of self and other. Yet if names are reversed to grasp reality, then they accord.

Lü’s Commentary:
If another draws a bow to shoot me, I speak of it with laughter, for they owe me no kindness; since I expect no kindness, treading on their foot requires no apology but carelessness. If a brother draws a bow to shoot me, I speak of it with tears, for they owe me kindness; since I expect kindness, even treading on their foot does not seem unloving—one merely humbles oneself without need for apology. For a close relative, kindness is utmost; no humility is needed.

From this we see: the ultimate of ritual, rightness, benevolence, and wisdom requires no external reliance. Understanding the intent of ritual yet not performing vulgar rituals to impress others—this is ritual that does not involve others. Acting appropriately without seeking appropriateness—this is rightness that does not objectify. Responding to events without prior scheming—this is wisdom that does not scheme. Treating the people as straw dogs yet enabling the world to be universally protective—this is benevolence without favorites. Trust is not expected to dispel gold—yet if one attains the Dao, these five are all perfected.

The will is where the mind goes; the mind is the harmony of virtue; virtue is the Dao within me. Thus, only by unblocking the will can the mind be liberated; only by removing encumbrances can obstructions be cleared. To cultivate the will, one values weakness—regarding wealth and honor as will is not weakness but rebellion. Thus, it must be unblocked. To cultivate the mind, one values emptiness—regarding movement and stillness as mind is not emptiness but distortion. Thus, it must be liberated. To perfect virtue, one must equalize the beginning—regarding desire and aversion as virtue’s encumbrance, they must be removed. To penetrate the Dao, one must unify—regarding departure and approach as the Dao’s obstruction, they must be cleared. If all these encumbrances are swept from the breast, the Dao gathers.

Without reverence, there is no Dao—thus, the Dao is the reverence of virtue. Without life, virtue cannot be seen—thus, life is the radiance of virtue. Nature is the essence of life; when nature moves and acts, artificiality arises and error occurs. Life without innate knowing is mere encounter; knowledge is not born with birth. To use knowledge only after scheming is strategy. What knowledge does not know is like the sidelong glance that does not see—yet that is precisely how it sees.

Thus, movement from necessity is nature’s action, not artificiality—this is called the Dao. Movement without self-exclusion means things and self are one; how can movement cause chaos? If one is truly thus, then though the world’s self and other, right and wrong may seem opposed in name, in reality they never fail to accord—because the Dao excludes nothing as "not-self."

The subtle and unrefined—can one make others praise them without self-promotion? The sage excels in being Heavenly yet appears clumsy among men. Can one excel in being Heavenly yet remain nimble among men? Only the complete person can do this; only the creaturely can be creaturely, only the Heavenly can be Heavenly. How can one despise Heaven? How can one despise the Heavenly in man—and how much more so the Heavenly in oneself?

A single sparrow encounters Yi—Yi must capture it, for that is his power. If one takes all under Heaven as one’s cage, then no sparrow can escape. Thus, Tang used a kitchen servant to enclose Yi Yin; Duke Mu of Qin used five sheepskins to enclose Bai Li Xi. Therefore, if one does not use what they love to enclose them, there is nothing that can be obtained.

The hunchbacked painter, though extravagant beyond measure, does not seek praise. The convict laborer climbs high without fear, forgetting life and death. Now, repeated practice without shame and guarding against others—guarding against others thus becomes one’s Heaven.

Therefore, one who respects without delight and insults without anger is only in harmony with Heavenly harmony. When anger arises from non-anger, then anger issues from non-anger. When action arises from non-action, then action issues from non-action. To desire stillness, level the qi; to desire spirit, follow the heart—this is having intent. To desire appropriateness, abide in necessity; necessity’s constancy is the sage’s Dao.

*(Guo’s commentary: "Excelling in the mean is to excel in receiving praise—principle and constancy are both present. Following nature is Heavenly; acting with intent is human.")*

One skilled in Heaven is thus adept among humans—this is called the "complete person," and the complete person is the sage. If an insect can guard its insect-nature, this is to be skilled in Heaven. Not knowing yet entrusting to it—this is called mastery. Heaven’s majesty seizes things, yet things must flee from it. All things under Heaven have their preferences, and each preference allows escape—where then lies the constancy of adornment? Adornment serves to embellish appearance. The mutilated one’s visage is already marred and incomplete, so they no longer harbor concern for beauty or ugliness, casting aside embellishment and abandoning it. The convict laborer, having no reliance on life, thus fears not death. Again, it is said: "without shame and guarding against others"—this speaks of not recognizing what others cherish. Devoid of human sentiment, one naturally becomes a "Heavenly person." If even the mutilated convict laborer can still harmonize with Heavenly harmony, how much more so the natural harmony of Heaven itself?

Anger arises from non-anger; action arises from non-action—thus, non-being cannot generate being, nor can being generate the intent to be. Leveling the qi brings stillness; following the heart brings spirit. Abiding in necessity makes all actions appropriate. Therefore, the sage takes this as the Dao—how could they seek non-action beyond the indistinct and obscure?

*(Lü’s commentary: "Within the classic are the Heavenly person, the spirit person, the perfected person, and the sage—here, there is also the 'complete person.'")*

The sage flees transformation—though skilled in Heaven, they remain clumsy in human affairs. The complete person, however, surpasses even this, for they are both skilled in Heaven and adept in human matters. Those creatures that crawl, breathe through beaks, gather in groups, or cluster in swarms—each performs its creaturely functions, yet knows not *why* it does so; this is the creaturely capacity. The Heavenly capacity, however, lies in not knowing *why* one is as one is. The complete person detests the Heaven of humans, for the Heaven of humans entails knowing what one does not know. As for the Heaven of Heaven—it guards against even this unknowing. If knowing *why* one is as one is still detestable, how much more so Heaven and humanity? How could one presume to deliberate over them?

When Yi aims at a sparrow, he is certain to hit it—such is the power of his skill. Those who do not fall within his aim are beyond the reach of that power. If one takes the world as a cage, then all things are trapped within it, with nowhere to escape—how much more so the sparrow? Only one who delves deeply, ever more deeply, and thereby penetrates the minds of all under Heaven can take the world as a cage. Thus, even figures like Yi Yin and Baili Xi could not escape it—they were caged by what they loved.

The maimed man, though scorned and slandered, may still cast aside fame and follow no set path; the convict laborer, though facing life and death, may still climb heights without fear. How much more so one who can guard against human influences—should they not be even more resolute and unyielding? Yet those who grow accustomed to such things through repeated exposure may still fail to guard against what others cannot. They take this as the Heavenly person, believing that the Heavenly person is merely one who guards against human influences. But this is to equate oneself with Heaven in a manner no different from the creatures. The complete person, the Heavenly person, and the sage share the same pattern, though their momentum differs.

Anger arises from non-anger as a constant; action arises from non-action as a constant. Non-anger and non-action are the states before things arise, the source from which all things emerge. Qi is emptiness awaiting things; humans cannot level it and instead agitate it, hence they are not still. If one can truly level the qi, there is nothing that will not become still. The heart, in humans, is spirit; humans cannot follow it and instead disturb it, hence they are not spirit. If one can truly follow the heart, there is nothing that will not become spirit. To act and desire appropriateness is to be constrained by necessity. Hesitation in initiating affairs, caution like crossing a river in winter—these are all expressions of acting from necessity.

*(Fangzi’s commentary: "The complete person detests Heaven—not Heaven itself, but the Heaven of humans. The Heaven of humans is constrained and harms life. Even the Heaven of humans is detestable, how much more so one’s own Heaven, or humanity? Is there anything that can overcome and yet remain unsettled? Only the creaturely capacity of Heaven—what is called the Heaven of Heaven. To guard against human influences is to share the same Heaven as creatures. The complete person and the Heavenly person share the same pattern as the sage, though their momentum stirs differently. Thus, the text concludes: ‘Acting from necessity—this is the Dao of the sage.’")*

*(General Observations: Guan Jian’s Summary)*
Master Gengsang’s grasp of the Laozi was concrete and thorough, yet what he had not yet attained still involved some attachment. Living secluded on Weilei, he was praised by the people for his virtue—this is the common way of sages and worthies in benefiting the world. Yet when the hearts of the multitude are moved and they wish to exalt him, the traces of love and benefit become manifest, and human feelings arise. Thus, what Nangong saw in him was no different from Weilei.

Fearing his virtue was insufficient to transform others, Gengsang sent him to see his teacher, hoping to shift his mindset and awaken him. This was a case of "passing the baton" to another, ensuring trust without doubt so that the profound teachings could take root. Upon entering the door, there was no gentle questioning or exchange—only a sudden shock, a wordless rebuke, a severing of all supports. This was the "letting go at the cliff’s edge," where the root of life hangs by a thread—how rare to encounter such a moment! Alas, Nangong could not immediately accept it and instead meandered, rambling on at length. Laozi diagnosed the source of his ailment and administered a sharp needle. Nangong then withdrew, dwelling in solitude, washing away his attachments, and returning for another audience—one could say he was good at receiving instruction and capable of renewal.

Thus, in their second encounter, Laozi seized the moment to point directly, sweeping away all his clinging obsessions. Gradually, he applied the medicine, urging him to reflect on his capacity to receive the Dao. Nangong, measuring his own vessel, wished only to hear the teachings on preserving life—seeing the Dao as a method to be expanded or contracted according to the person. Laozi taught him to embrace the One, seek within himself, return to infancy, and follow things—these are the general outlines of the teachings on preserving life.

The questioning reached its utmost, and the meaning returned to the child’s capacity: "Words have their source; affairs have their ruler." Next, the discussion of vast spaciousness arises from Heavenly illumination, the numinous terrace—one does not know what sustains it. The chamber is empty, and brightness arises naturally; there is no need to seek it eagerly with a mind of doing. The distinctions between outer and inner bonds, the metaphors of the sharp sword and the blunt blade—these enable the learner to discern weight and make clear choices.

There is no before or after in life and death; the ancestral temple and the privy each have their proper place. This is to awaken to the fundamental oneness of all life, shattering the delusion of fixed distinctions. The account of wealth, honor, desires, and aversions stirring the will and confounding the heart shows that the will must be unified and the heart emptied. Anything that entangles one in worldly burdens and obstructs clarity must be abandoned and kept far away. The sacrificial meats and organs may be scattered, for they are not eternal. Yi was skilled at hitting targets but clumsy in other matters—this is to store up fame.

All these are explanations to dissolve the common person’s attachments, to expand the transformation of emptiness and mystery, to merge Heaven and humanity, to transcend skill and clumsiness, to rise above things and self, right and wrong, praise and blame, respect and insult. Only then can one attain non-action and non-anger, stillness that levels the qi, and a heart that follows spirit. In this way, one becomes serene, dwelling alone with the numinous, stabilized in the One, and responding without limitation.

Xu Wuque was visited by Nü Shang, who then met with Duke Wu of Wei. The Duke greeted him, saying, "Master, you must be weary." He continued, "You have endured the hardships of mountain forests, and only now have you deigned to see me."

Xu Wuque replied, "I am weary because of you, my lord. What weariness have you endured on my account? If you indulge in desires and prolong your likes and dislikes, the true nature of life and destiny will sicken. If you suppress desires and restrain likes and dislikes, your ears and eyes will sicken. I weary you, my lord—what weariness have you endured on my account?"

Duke Wu, startled, made no reply. After a moment, Xu Wuque said, "Let me tell you something: I read dogs. A low-quality dog stops when it is full—this is the virtue of a wildcat. A middling-quality dog gazes like the sun. A high-quality dog seems to have lost its singular focus. Yet my reading of dogs is not as refined as my reading of horses. When I read horses, a straight one aligns with the marking line, a curved one with the hook, a square one with the carpenter’s square, and a round one with the compass—these are state horses. But they do not compare to the horses of the world. The horses of the world possess perfect form, as if guarding something, as if losing something, as if they have lost their singular focus. Such horses surpass all, leaving dust behind, their destination unknown."

Duke Wu was greatly pleased and laughed. When Xu Wuque departed, Nü Shang asked him, "Master, how did you alone manage to delight my lord? When I try to persuade him, I cite the *Book of Poetry*, the *Book of Documents*, ritual, and music. When I follow his inclinations, I present him with the *Golden Tablets* and the *Six Bow-Cases*. Those who serve him with great merit are too numerous to count, yet my lord has never once opened his mouth in response. How did you delight him so?"

Xu Wuque said, "I simply told him how I read dogs and horses."

Nü Shang said, "Is that all?"

Xu Wuque replied, "Have you not heard of the exiles of Yue? When they leave their state for a few days, they rejoice upon seeing those they know. After a month away, they rejoice upon seeing those they once saw in their homeland. After a year, they rejoice even upon seeing those who merely resemble people. Is it not true that the longer one is away from others, the deeper one’s longing for them grows? Those who flee into the emptiness of the wilds, where only brambles and thorns stand, where the paths are trodden only by weasels and badgers—even they, upon hearing the sound of human footsteps, rejoice at the echo. How much more so, then, for the voices of brothers and kin at one’s side?"

How long has it been since the true person’s words echoed at our lord’s side?

Guo’s commentary:
Desires and aversions, both inner and outer, have no cause—thus we call it affliction. To not respond is to not delight in his words. Yet what fault lies in the true person’s speech? It is only what things naturally favor that may be so. To expound at length without our lord ever parting his lips is like a lark rejoicing in bells and drums—hence the sorrow. To hear of reading dogs and horses and rejoice is like exiles seeing those they know: each longs for what accords with their fundamental nature. To attain what one favors is to be without longing; to be without longing is to forget the cause of one’s joy. The true person’s words thus accord with our lord’s nature. At first, he rejoices in attaining them; with time, he forgets them.

Lü’s commentary:
Xu Wuque resisted the might of Marquis Wu and admonished his affliction. The marquis, unwilling to yield, remained aloof and unresponsive. Xu Wuque thus employed the metaphor of reading dogs and horses to convey his own lack of seeking. Dogs of low quality act only when sated—like men who serve when hungry and seek when in need. Those of middling quality, like one gazing at the sun, see what is lofty and distant but cannot yet forget themselves; if even one aspect is forgotten, the rest may be inferred. Horses that meet the compass and square are state steeds—how much more so for the wandering of state scholars? Those within the realm belong to the world.

Those of superior quality attain completion without practice, naturally so—if preserved, none can share their joy; if lost, none can match them. To lose even one aspect is to lose one’s very self, not merely to lose it but to transcend all bounds, leaving dust far behind, unknown in their essence. How much more so for the scholars of the world who wander beyond the realm, unknowable in their nature?

This implies: if even the finest dogs and the world’s finest horses are thus, how could I presume to humble myself before your power? How could you fail to esteem me?

Marquis Wu grasped his meaning and rejoiced greatly. For words that meet the Dao are truly received. Words that do not accord with the Dao, though they be the *Book of Songs*, the *Book of Documents*, rites, or music, cannot move one. But words that accord with the Dao, though they speak of dogs and horses, suffice to bring joy.

When one loses the true nature of life and indulges in human artifice, it is like abandoning one’s homeland and kin to wander in distant lands, or fleeing into the void to dwell among foxes and weasels. What is called the "real" is the inherent nature one originally possesses, like the old bonds of homeland and kin. Unless one is utterly deluded, who could hear the coughs and whispers of a true person and not rejoice?

---

Wu Chou’s commentary:
Xu Wuque was a spirit-like person. He seized the moment and rode the tide without allowing his heart to intervene. Thus, his words subtly conveyed his intent. He followed the return of the Dao without opposing its principles, aligning with the other’s preferences without offending their sensibilities. Even the fierce and violent Marquis Wu was thus pleased and enlightened by his Dao-infused metaphors.

---

New Tradition’s commentary:
Marquis Wu’s nature was of middling quality. One could not abruptly instruct him in the ultimate Dao but had to guide him through what he already favored. This is why Xu Wuque spoke of dogs and horses. Yet Xu Wuque was not truly evaluating dogs and horses; he embedded the meaning of the Dao within them. The finest dogs, if one aspect is lost, seem as though they have lost everything—this describes one whose form is whole and whose spirit is sovereign, able to preserve their person. The world’s finest horses are those of completed talent—this describes one whose virtue is vast and settled, never losing their root. To preserve one’s person is to act without contrivance; to never lose one’s root is to be without use. Without contrivance and without use, one can enter into the profound.

---

Guan Jian’s observation:
The phrase "the world’s horses of completed talent" evokes an image of transcendent, dust-leaving excellence. Gazing at the sun and preserving even one aspect can be described, but the state of "losing one aspect" is harder to depict—unlike state steeds, which can be measured by compass and square. "One" refers to the first stirring of things, as if lost or vanished, lingering between presence and absence, its form and substance impossible to pin down. Only by guiding with the Dao can one win Marquis Wu’s heart, achieving an effect swifter than the *Book of Songs* or the arts of concealment.

---

Fang Sishan’s note:
Excessive desire harms the spirit; complete abstinence also impedes it. Only the perfected person can act within desire without being swept away—this is the true way to nurture the spirit. To act within desire without being swept away is the province of those who transcend life. The phrases "as if losing one aspect" and "as if losing one" are metaphors for transcending life. Lü’s interpretation, which takes them as metaphors for ministers preserving their position, is too shallow.

---

Xu Wuque met with Marquis Wu. The marquis said, "Master, you dwell in the mountains and forests, eating acorns and water-chestnuts, spurning scallions and leeks, yet you have long honored me with your presence. Are you now old? Do you crave the taste of wine and meat? Or has my state been blessed with good fortune?"

Xu Wuque replied, "Wuque was born in poverty and lowliness and has never dared to partake of your lordship’s wine and meat. I have come to trouble you."

The marquis asked, "How so? How do I trouble you?"

Xu Wuque said, "I trouble your spirit and your form."

The marquis asked, "What do you mean?"

Xu Wuque said, "The nurturing of heaven and earth is impartial—ascending high does not make one long, nor does dwelling low make one short. Yet you alone, as lord of ten thousand chariots, oppress the people of an entire state to nourish your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. The spirit does not authorize this itself. The spirit loves harmony and hates discord, for discord is sickness. Thus, I trouble you. What sickness do you suffer?"

The marquis said, "I have long wished to see you, Master. I desire to love the people and practice righteousness, to lay down arms—is this possible?"

Xu Wuque said, "No. To love the people is the beginning of harming them; to practice righteousness and lay down arms is the root of raising arms. If you proceed thus, you will fail and not succeed. All completion of beauty is an instrument of ugliness. Though you practice benevolence and righteousness, you will verge on falsity. Form inevitably creates form; completion inevitably invites change; change inevitably leads to external conflict. You must not parade cranes in formation between the watchtowers, nor gallop steeds in the palace courtyards, nor harbor rebellion in your gains. Do not seek to overcome others with skill, do not seek to overcome others with schemes, do not seek to overcome others with war.

Those who kill others, who seize others’ land to nourish their own selfishness and their own spirit—whose victory is good, whose defeat is bad? It lies with you. If you cannot stop, cultivate sincerity within your breast to respond to the feelings of heaven and earth, and do not disturb the people. Then death will have already departed, and you will no longer need to ask how to lay down arms."

---

Guo’s commentary:
Heaven and earth nurture all equally; they do not grant one the status of lord to indulge without limit. To oppress the people to nourish one’s ears, eyes, nose, and mouth is to violate the balance of heaven and earth. The spirit does not authorize itself; it shares with things. To share with things is harmony; to authorize oneself is discord.

The traces of loving the people are what the people esteem; esteeming is loving, and loving oneself is false. To practice righteousness is to make one’s name manifest; when names are manifest, competition arises, and competition leads to the loss of one’s true nature. How can one hope to lay down arms when father and son, ruler and minister, harbor feelings and deceive one another? Only by following non-action can one succeed.

Beauty completed in the present gives rise to falsity in the future; thus, the completion of beauty is an instrument of ugliness. When the lord practices benevolence and righteousness, the people will respond with falsity and not take it as real. Benevolence and righteousness have form, so false forms inevitably arise. Completion invites display, so there will be rebellion and change—this refers to losing one’s constant nature.

Cranes in formation are military arrays; watchtowers are high towers. Infantry are called "common"; one should not practice righteousness or love the people in this way. Nor should one parade troops or gallop horses. To gain and harbor rebellion is to lose the mean. Do not seek to overcome others with skill—guard your simplicity, and each will have its own ability, thus achieving balance. Do not seek to overcome others with schemes—follow true knowledge, and each will have its own strength, thus achieving equality. Do not seek to overcome others with war—respond to things with the Dao, and things will submit without the name of victory.

If one does not know what is good, even victory is not one’s own. If one cannot stop, it is better to cultivate one’s own sincerity so that armor and weapons have no place to be arrayed and are not laid down.

】 Lü’s Annotation【
To govern the state with knowledge is the state’s bane; to govern the state without knowledge is the state’s blessing. Thus, loving the people is but the beginning of harming them, and laying down arms is but the root of raising them—all because one relies on knowledge rather than the Dao.

When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness is already present; thus, the completion of beauty is but the vessel of ugliness. Once a vessel is formed, it has already departed from the Dao. Though there be the benevolence of loving the people and the righteousness of laying down arms, these are but artifices. The form of loving the people inherently contains the beginning of harm; the form of laying down arms inherently contains the root of war. Only when there is no form can there be nothing to create.

When cranes array themselves upon lofty towers, they are admired for their spectacle; when infantry and cavalry parade upon altars, they are toyed with and displayed—yet none of this is done out of necessity. Whenever one gains something contrary to the principle of heaven, rebellion is concealed within. To overcome others with skill is to rely on knowledge rather than the Dao; to overcome others with war is to rely on military strength rather than virtue. To kill men and seize lands to nourish one’s own selfishness and the selfishness of one’s spirit—those who praise such acts call it "good warfare" and "victory over others," yet who knows what is truly good and what is evil?

If a ruler must act, let it be out of necessity: cultivate sincerity to respond to the sentiment of heaven and earth, and all things will answer. Why then fear the death of the people or their escape?

】 Oral Exegesis【
"宾" is interchangeable with "摈" (to cast aside). "养生" means to nourish life. Heaven and earth give birth to things without distinction of high or low, noble or base. "和" means to be of the same kind; "奸" refers to selfishness. My spirit is originally one with the myriad things, yet desires and selfishness obscure this unity—this is what is detested. If a ruler is afflicted by this and remains unaware, I labor to admonish him.

To love the people with intent is to harm them; to lay down arms with intent is to raise them. To act with a mind of contrivance is to create forms; to fix upon forms is to solidify them. When the mind clings rigidly and does not transform, it injures the inner self, and external things disrupt and confuse it—this is called "external warfare." "鹤列" is the name of a battle formation; "丽谯" is the name of a tower; "锱坛" is a place of sacrifice. This means that if the human heart contends with things, even within a single chamber, it is as if troops and cavalry are arrayed before one, and all becomes a realm of strife.

Human nature deems gain as compliance and loss as rebellion; without gain, there is no loss—thus it is said, "Do not conceal rebellion within gain." "巧" refers to cunning, the machinations of the mind; intelligence and schemes arise from this cunning, and war arises from these schemes. To seek victory through such means is to gratify the selfishness of the eyes and ears. Though one may appear victorious, the mind is besieged by external things, and the spirit is wearied by the pursuit of victory alone.

Thus it is said: Where lies the evil of victory? Simply cultivate one’s inherent sincerity to respond to the natural reality of Heaven and Earth, and with nothing that opposes things, one will triumph without contention—then the people, though dead, are already freed. What need is there to seek the cessation of arms?

The Yellow Emperor was about to visit the Great Hidden One at Mount Juzi. Fangming drove the chariot, Changfang rode as the right attendant, and Zhang Ruo, Xi Peng, Kun Hun, and Huaji followed as the rear guard. When they reached the wilds of Xiangcheng, the Seven Sages all became lost, with no one to ask for the way. They happened upon a boy herding horses and inquired of him, saying, “Do you know Mount Juzi?”
“Yes,” he replied.
“Do you know where the Great Hidden One resides?”
“Yes,” he said.
The Yellow Emperor said, “How extraordinary! This boy not only knows Mount Juzi but also knows where the Great Hidden One resides. Let me ask you about governing the world.”
The boy said, “Governing the world is just like this—what more is there to do? When I was young, I wandered freely within the Six Directions. Then I fell ill with confusion, and an elder taught me, saying, ‘If you ride the chariot of the sun and wander in the wilds of Xiangcheng, now that my illness has slightly improved, I will once again wander beyond the Six Directions.’ Governing the world is just like this—what more is there to do?”
The Yellow Emperor said, “Governing the world is indeed not your concern, yet allow me to ask about it.” The boy declined, but the Yellow Emperor asked again, “How is governing the world different from this?”
The horse-herding boy replied, “It is no different from herding horses—simply remove those that harm the horses, and that is all.”
The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, called him “Heavenly Master,” and withdrew.

The scholars of knowledge take no delight without the changes of thought and contemplation; the disputatious scholars take no delight without the order of discourse; the scrutinizing scholars take no delight without the affairs of reproach and inquiry—all are confined by things. The world-summoning scholars rise in the court; the people-centered scholars glory in office; the sinew-and-strength scholars boast of hardship; the brave and daring scholars stir at peril; the martial scholars delight in war; the withered and emaciated scholars lodge in fame; the legal scholars expand governance; the ritual scholars revere demeanor; the benevolent and righteous scholars value connections; farmers, without the affairs of tilling and weeding, do not unite; merchants, without the affairs of markets and streets, do not unite; the common people, with their day-and-night labors, encourage the hundred crafts; artisans, with their skill in tools and machines, strengthen wealth; if money does not accumulate, the greedy worry; if power and influence do not excel, the boastful grieve. These followers of things delight in change, and when the times afford them use, they cannot be without action.

All these conform to the seasons yet do not accord with the transformations of things. They drive their natures and dispositions into the ten thousand things, never to return for their entire lives—how lamentable!

Those who cannot find contentment within and delight in things without are each confined by what they enjoy, so that the ten thousand things come of themselves without being summoned. From those who rise in the court to those who glory in office, the differences among scholars are like this, and those who encounter them cannot alter their ways. When their abilities align, their affairs align, and so they unite. When their work attains its purpose, they are encouraged. If their skill is not their own, then the nature of things finds what it desires and delights in. Power and influence arise from the changes of affairs. All these scholars are used according to their times, and when the times employ them, they cannot restrain themselves. If they do not encounter the times, though they wish to employ themselves, how could they succeed? Thus, nobility and baseness are not constant, and the abilities of scholars each have their limits, like the four seasons, which cannot be altered. When the times accord with their proper order, each has its use.

Therefore, those who conform to the seasons follow the sequence of time, but those who alter their natures do not accord with things. To accord with things without being things—what is this if not destruction? Not abiding in the abilities of a single household but instead pursuing the ten thousand directions to seek the profit of the times—thus there are those who crawl back in exhaustion, which is the cause for lament.

People all have a place of utmost joy; to attain it and wander therein is to be confined in a vastness indeed. Yet these scholars alone delight in the biases of their natures, thus confined by things and unable to confine things. From the world-summoning scholars to the followers of power and influence, though their inclinations differ, when the times afford them use, they cannot be without action—this is one in not knowing where the true ruler resides.

To act when the times afford use is not of one’s nature and destiny. The times have past and present, just as the years have cold and heat. Now, having encountered one occasion, they cling to it without release, unable to be without action. All these conform to the cold of the year yet do not know of the heat; they know the heat yet do not know of the cold, taking what they encounter as constant and not according with the transformations of things.
