People all have a true ruler within, yet they drive their natures and dispositions to chase things without knowing to return—this is what the utmost person laments.

**Translation:**

The *Comprehensive Meaning* states:
Those confined by things are two kinds—those who stand apart from affairs and employ cunning, and those who conform to the times are fifteen kinds—those who engage in affairs and expend effort. Those who "do not treat things as transformable" are those who cannot adapt to the changes of things. If things can transform, then form, though material, may yet attain spirit-like efficacy. The various arts and conditions previously described are all like things with fixed directions, incapable of transformation.

Zhuangzi said: "An archer who hits the mark without aiming beforehand is called a master archer—should all under heaven then be Yi?"
Hui Zi said: "They should."
Zhuangzi said: "If there is no shared standard under heaven, and each takes their own standard as right, should all under heaven then be Yao?"
Hui Zi said: "They should."
Zhuangzi said: "Then if the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Bing, along with you, make five—who is correct? Or perhaps someone like Lu Ju is right?"
His disciple said: "I have attained the Master’s Dao! I can boil a cauldron in winter and make ice in summer!"
Lu Ju said: "This merely summons yang with yang and yin with yin—it is not what I call the Dao. Shall I show you my Way?" My Dao lies herein.

Placing one zither in the hall and another in the chamber, when the gong note is struck, the gong note resonates; when the jue note is struck, the jue note resonates—their tonal laws are the same. Yet if one alters a single string’s tuning so that it no longer corresponds to the five notes, and then strikes it, all twenty-five strings will vibrate, though their sounds are not inherently different. Is this then the ruler of tones?

Hui Zi said: "Now the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Bing all engage me in debate, clashing with words, overpowering with phrases, and contending with voices—yet they have never begun by admitting their own errors. What is to be done?"

Zhuangzi said: "A man of Qi who was sent to execute someone in Song—though his mission was to guard the gate, he did not fulfill his request for a tripod; though his duty was to bind the criminal, he fulfilled his request for a bell. Yet he never left his domain, and nothing was left undone. A man of Chu who was sent as a gatekeeper and lodged elsewhere, in the dead of night when no one was present, fought with a boatman. Though he never encountered peril, he still incurred resentment.

[Guo’s commentary: Hitting the mark without prior aim is not true mastery. If one calls accidental hits mastery, then all under heaven could be called Yi. This cannot be. If one who hits by chance is Yi, then those who insist on their own rightness could likewise be called Yao. Zhuangzi uses this to show that those who hit the mark by mistake are not Yi, and those who insist on their own rightness are not Yao. If all were Yao, why would the five schools still contradict one another? It is like Lu Ju boasting to his disciple about striking the zither: both merely summon yang with yang, yet he claims this as his own achievement. If one alters a single string’s tuning, the five notes change accordingly—without sound, there is no resonance; with sound, they are not in harmony. Now, if this one string is altered and all twenty-five strings change, it is merely adjusting the tension to retune them. Lu Ju takes this as proof of his skill, yet it is nothing more than mutual resonance—he has not uniquely mastered the art.]"

The five masters each cling to their own views and affirm what they affirm—no different from Lu Ju boasting to his disciple without surpassing one another. Those who have never deemed themselves wrong each insist on their own rightness. Huizi then sought to take this as the ultimate truth, so Zhuangzi cited the case of the Qi man who abandoned his son in a foreign land, instructing the gatekeeper to guard him yet failing to preserve his life—such was the Qi man’s lack of compassion. Yet he, too, deemed himself right. Thus, he valued his bronze vessel, binding it with straw to prevent damage or loss, yet lost his son without searching far, neglecting the qi he had bestowed—yet he never once deemed himself wrong. Zhuangzi further invoked the Chu man who entrusted his son to a gatekeeper: both entrusted their sons, yet neither cast himself onto high ground or a steep bank. In the dead of night, he alone boarded another’s boat; before leaving the shore, he was already fighting with others. The conduct of these two men from Qi and Chu was no different, yet they never once deemed themselves wrong. Now, if the five masters insist on their own rightness, how are they any different?

**Lü’s Commentary:**
That all under heaven could be Yi is surely impossible. Huizi, recognizing that Zhuangzi’s words were directed at him, took them as admissible: to hit the mark is to be Yi, and to insist on one’s own rightness is to be Yao—no need for prior intent or impartial affirmation. This is what is meant by taking opposition to others as truth and victory over others as renown. Nevertheless, if the five masters are not all right, then the claim that all are Yao cannot stand. Otherwise, it is like Lu Ju tuning his zither—inevitably summoning resonance through sound alone—yet he deems himself superior to the other four masters, though in reality, he differs not at all. He may say, “I am no different from the four masters, yet if you grant me debate, I have never once deemed myself wrong—how does this compare?” Such words aim to establish the claim that all are Yao. Zhuangzi, through subtle speech, sought to move him: the bond between father and son is a matter of heavenly nature. Yet the Qi man abandoned his son in Song, entrusting him to a gatekeeper not to preserve his life but to illustrate how Hui Shi slighted the natural affection for life while prizing his bronze vessel, binding it with straw. In seeking his lost son, he never ventured beyond his domain—likening Hui Shi’s attachment to verbal debate and reputation as external things, cherishing them while enduring harm to what he received from heaven, losing it without seeking to recover, deeming it regrettable. The Chu man who entrusted his son to a gatekeeper is a metaphor for Hui Shi losing the true dwelling of his return, contending with others amid the obscurity of right and wrong, striving for victory without achieving anything—merely failing to adapt to things, which is not what is called wisdom.

**Following the Text:**
An archer must aim at the target beforehand and hit it to be called a skilled archer. Now, if one does not aim beforehand but merely hits the mark by chance and is thus called a skilled archer, then all under heaven would be Yi—is this admissible? This illustrates that without impartial affirmation, each affirms their own rightness, claiming all under heaven are Yao.

Is this admissible? Yang Zhu and Gongsun Long—during winter’s cold, they could kindle fire without flame; in summer’s heat, they could freeze water into ice. Though these feats seem marvelous, they merely rely on the yang’s resurgence at the winter solstice to summon yang and produce fire, or the yin’s resurgence at the summer solstice to summon yin and produce ice. Nothing extraordinary.

Place one zither in the hall and another in the chamber: strike the *gong* note on this zither, and the *gong* note on that zither resonates of its own accord; strike the *jiao* note on this one, and the *jiao* note on that one responds likewise. This may seem marvelous, yet because their tuning is identical, their sounds naturally harmonize—nothing extraordinary.

Take the case of Cao Shao-kui of the Tang, who understood musical temperament. In Luoyang, a monk’s chamber housed a chime stone that tolled day and night on its own. The monk, unsettled by the strangeness, fell ill. Shao-kui, who had long been on good terms with the monk, came to inquire after his illness. The monk told him what had happened. Just then, the temple bell was struck, and the chime stone sounded again in response. Shao-kui laughed and said, “Tomorrow, prepare a feast, and I will rid you of this.” The monk did as he said. After the meal, Shao-kui took a file from his sleeve, struck the chime stone several times, and left. The sound ceased. When the monk pressed him for an explanation, he said, “This chime stone shares the same temperament as the bell, so when one is struck, the other responds.” The monk rejoiced, and his illness was cured.

Another case: Li Sizhen obtained a carriage bell, and when he struck it, something beneath the earth responded. He dug and unearthed a bell—surely there was a resonance at work.

The *Record of Learning* states: “Striking a drum has no direct correspondence to the five notes, yet if one alters a single string’s tuning without aligning it to any of the five notes and strikes it, all twenty-five strings vibrate in response. Though this string is no different from the others, it alone can command them, for it serves as the master of the assembled scholars. Thus, when struck, none of the strings fail to obey its command.”

The sixty-four modes all arise from the *gong* note of *Huangzhong*, and *gong* is the sovereign, so it can govern the other temperaments. This, too, is common principle—nothing extraordinary.

If this is so, then Hui Shi’s self-affirmation is like the case of Lu Ju. Hui Shi replied: “Zhuangzi claims that I, along with the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Gongsun Long, make five schools, yet he cannot determine which is right. But since the arguments of the other four cannot refute me, I am right and they are wrong.”

*Ti* (蹢) means to hesitate, to walk without advancing. The *Record of Rites* says: “He hesitates, lingering.” *Chichu* (踟蹰) has the same meaning.

The *xing* bell and the *xing* tripod are akin to bells; the *Tang* hall and its paths are the thoroughfares of the courtyard. As the *Book of Songs* says: “Within the central hall-path, there are tiles.” The *Tang* servant refers to those who attend to the hall’s paths—messengers and orderlies—just as the *Rites of Zhou* speaks of “gatekeepers,” now commonly called “porters.”

There was a man of Qi who hesitated to entrust his son to Song, instead making him a gatekeeper there, casting him off to a foreign land because his form was imperfect. Yet though his form was imperfect, he was still his own flesh and blood—how could he bear to abandon him? Let us examine his motives: when seeking a *xing* bell, he bound and secured it, fearing even the slightest damage. How does this compare to discarding his own son? When seeking a *Tang* servant, he merely employed him to attend the hall’s paths and run errands, never sending him beyond the borders. How does this compare to abandoning his son in a foreign land? In this way, his principles of examination were flawed.

People are often blinded by distinctions of kinship and estrangement, nobility and baseness, nearness and distance, unaware of their own biases. This is like Hui Shi, who recognized the errors in the arguments of the four schools yet failed to see his own.

*Li* (離) and *li* (罹) both mean “to arrive.” *Cen* (岑) refers to a steep riverbank. A man of Chu, lodging on a boat and hesitating to become a gatekeeper in another land, quarreled with the boatman in the dead of night when no one was present. He did not consider that before reaching shore, it was unwise to provoke conflict—such actions only breed resentment. This is a further step: in disputes with others, one not only risks self-delusion but also invites disaster.

Zhuangzi, passing by Hui Shi’s grave while attending a funeral, turned to his followers and said: “There was a man of Ying who had a speck of plaster on the tip of his nose, as thin as a fly’s wing. He called upon Carpenter Shi to shave it off. Carpenter Shi swung his axe with such force that it created a gust of wind, and with perfect precision, he sliced away the plaster without harming the man’s nose. The man of Ying stood firm, his expression unchanged. When the Lord of Song Yuan heard of this, he summoned Carpenter Shi and said, ‘Try to do it for me.’ Carpenter Shi replied, ‘Your servant once could wield the axe in such a way. However, my partner has been dead for a long time. Since the Master’s passing, I have had no one to work with—I have no one to converse with.’”

Guo Xiang’s commentary: “To swing the axe with such force that it creates a gust of wind is to act with eyes closed and hands unrestrained. Yet without the unshakable composure of the partner, even the most skillful words and finest craftsmanship would be of no use.”

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: “It is precisely because of this that Zhuangzi repeatedly engaged with Hui Shi, deeply lamenting that he never reached such heights.”

When Guan Zhong fell ill, Duke Huan asked him, “Uncle, your illness has grown severe. Dare I ask—if it should become critical, to whom should I entrust the state?” Guan Zhong replied, “Whom does the Duke wish to appoint?” The Duke said, “Bao Shuya.” Guan Zhong said, “He will not do. His conduct is pure and upright, a fine gentleman. But when he encounters those who do not measure up to him, he does not associate with them. Moreover, once he hears of another’s fault, he never forgets it for the rest of his life. If you place him in charge of the state, he will above seek to control his lord and below oppose the people. It will not be long before he incurs the ruler’s displeasure.” The Duke said, “Then who is suitable?” Guan Zhong replied, “If you must choose, then Xi Peng will do. His character is such that he forgets those above him and does not alienate those below. He feels ashamed that he does not equal the Yellow Emperor, and he pities those who cannot keep up with him. To divide virtue among others is called sageliness; to divide wealth among others is called worthiness. To rule others with worthiness has never won their allegiance, but to humble oneself with worthiness has never failed to win their hearts. In governing the state, he remains unheard of; in managing his household, he remains unseen.”

If one must proceed, then Xi Peng is suitable—could this not be called a definitive judgment? "To hook" is to oppose; "to alienate" is to rebel. The *Liezi* renders this as "not defying those above and not betraying those below." Guo’s commentary states: "To forget those above and not alienate those below means to be lofty yet not overbearing. To pity those who cannot keep up with him is to leave none behind. If all affairs were heard and seen, they would converge upon oneself, leaving subordinates with no room to act—thus, to relinquish them is fitting. Yet since he cannot relinquish all, he is merely suitable."

Lü’s commentary states: "Capacity becomes impartiality; impartiality becomes kingship; kingship becomes Heaven; Heaven becomes the Dao. These five are all that one embodies. Impartiality thus enables one to act as a lord; kingship, as a king. The titles of lord and king arise from this. Could Xi Peng’s virtue be said to embody capacity that becomes impartiality?"

Jiang Yu states: "One who guards against those above governs with opacity; one who does not alienate those below nurtures a people of simplicity. To feel ashamed of not equaling the Yellow Emperor is to avoid self-satisfaction; to pity those who cannot keep up is to take saving goodness as one’s heart. To divide virtue among others so that all people may return to their mandate and restore constancy is the Dao of the sage. To divide wealth among others so that all people lack nothing in supporting their superiors and raising their dependents is the power of the worthy. To rule others with worthiness is like a mountain’s barren slopes; to humble oneself with worthiness is like a marsh’s fertile growth. As for 'in governing the state, he remains unheard of; in managing his household, he remains unseen,' this does not mean he truly does not see or hear—his Dao suffices to contain all. Herein lies why Xi Peng is suitable and Bao Shuya is not. In the *Preface to the 'Kudzu Sandals'* of the *Book of Songs*, it speaks of the parsimony and pettiness of the lord of Wei, while the poem itself says, 'It is only this petty heart'—thus critiquing how such pettiness harms governance."

King Wu of Wu was floating on the river when he ascended Mount Ju. The troop of monkeys, seeing him, scattered in alarm and fled into the dense thickets. One monkey, however, remained.

The monkey crouched and clambered, displaying its skill before the king. The king shot at it with swift precision, his arrows flying in rapid succession. The king ordered his attendants to hasten and shoot as well, but the monkey seized the arrows mid-flight. The king commanded his ministers to close in and shoot together, and the monkey was captured and killed. The king turned to his friend Yan Buyi and said, "This monkey flaunted its skill, relied on its agility, and scorned me—thus it met its end. Take heed! Alas, do not let your demeanor grow arrogant toward others!"

Yan Buyi returned home and studied under Dong Wu to uproot his prideful bearing. He renounced pleasure and declined honors. After three years, the people of the state praised him.

Nanbo Ziqi sat leaning against a table, gazing upward and sighing. Yan Chengzi entered and said, "Master, you surpass all things—can your form truly be made like withered bones, your heart like dead ashes?"

He replied, "Once I dwelled in a mountain cave..."

When Tian He caught sight of me, the multitudes of Qi celebrated thrice—yet I had already preceded him. Thus he knew me, and thus he sold me. Had I not possessed it, how could he have known? Had I not sold it, how could he have trafficked it? Alas! I grieve for those who lose themselves, and I grieve yet more for those who grieve for them, and I grieve still further for those who grieve over the grief of others. Thereafter, the distance grows ever greater with each day.

Guo's Annotation: The people of Qi celebrated thrice upon seeing Ziqi, taking it as an honor. Ziqi knew that such actions could not save others but only harm oneself, so he chose not to grieve. In this way, his sorrow gradually faded, his heart became still, and his form withered—thus the distance grew day by day.

Lü's Annotation: When Tian He glimpsed me, the state of Qi rejoiced thrice, for I had already preceded him in selling it, and thus he knew and trafficked it. The heart not yet emptied within leaves traces without, so others come to know it. The Dao of Heaven has never begun with things. If a rigid knowing remains stored in the heart, this is self-loss—loss meaning the forfeiture of one’s original heart. Ziqi grieved for those who lost themselves in this way, wishing them to return. Yet to know their loss and grieve for it is still loss, not return. I grieve further for those who grieve for others’ grief, for both the lost and those who grieve for them remain unaware of their state. This is why the distance grows daily. If one is not ensnared by things, how could the form not wither, the heart not turn to ashes?

When Confucius traveled to Chu, the people of Chu offered him wine. Sunshu Ao held the goblet and stood, while Shinan Yiliao received the wine and made a libation, saying, "People of ancient times—" Then he spoke to me, saying, "Qiu!"

Hearing the wordless words—have you never spoken of this? When Yiliao of Shinan juggled his pellets, the feuds of two clans dissolved; when Sunshu Ao slept soundly, holding his feather fan, the men of Ying sheathed their blades. I would wish for a beak three feet long—what they call the Way that is not the Way, this is what I call the eloquence of silence. Thus virtue gathers where the Dao unifies, and speech rests where knowledge reaches its limit. That which the Dao unifies, virtue cannot equal; what knowledge cannot know, debate cannot exhaust.

Names like "Confucian" or "Mohist" bring only misfortune. Thus the sea does not refuse the eastward flow—it is the utmost of greatness. The sage embraces heaven and earth, bestowing blessings upon the world, yet none know his name. Therefore, in life he bears no rank, in death no posthumous title; no wealth accumulates, no fame is established—this is called the Great Person. A dog is not good because it barks well; a person is not worthy because they speak well—how much less so for greatness? To be great is not enough to be called great—how much less so for virtue? Greatness is complete—none surpasses heaven and earth. What is there to seek? And yet greatness is complete.

One who knows completeness seeks nothing, loses nothing, discards nothing, does not alter the self for things. Returning to the self without exhaustion, following antiquity without friction—this is the sincerity of the Great Person. Guo’s commentary: "The ancients who spoke did so only to guard against uniformity. The sage does not speak; what he speaks are the words of the common people. Thus it is said: the wordless words. If one takes speech as non-speech, then though words issue from the mouth, they have never truly been spoken here—speech amid silence. Yiliao and Sunshu Ao settled disputes through quietude, remaining unperturbed, and conflicts dissolved of themselves. If what is spoken is not one’s own, then though one speaks all their life, it is as if they have never spoken. Thus a beak three feet long is hardly worth praising. The common person’s silence is not yet wordlessness—what he refers to as the two masters, this refers to Confucius.

What the Dao contains, though boundless, gathers in its great return to self-possession—thus it is one. Speech halts at its proper limit—what could be more ultimate? Each attains self-possession, not through sameness, yet the Dao remains one."

The knowing of what lies beyond one’s proper share—thus even eloquence cannot encompass it. The Ru and Mohists sought to unify what cannot be unified, to encompass what cannot be encompassed—hence their calamity. The sea receives all things without refusal, and so becomes vast; thus the sage, drifting and all-embracing, lets things take their course. In life, there is no rank to possess, yet none is lacking; in death, there is no posthumous title, for such titles name merit, and merit does not reside in oneself—though titled, it is not one’s own. The real does not accumulate, so the myriad things each know contentment. The name is not established, for merit is not one’s own doing—thus the name returns to things. This is called the Great Person. If one were to act and possess, one would be small indeed.

Excellence arises from nature, not from speech—how much less can the great be attained through effort? Only through spontaneity is it attained. Heaven and earth are greatly complete, yet not through seeking. One who knows their own completeness does not abandon the self to seek things—thus there is no seeking, no loss, no rejection. Returning to guard one’s own principle, one’s principle naturally flows unimpeded; following one’s constant nature, it arrives of itself—no polishing is needed. Without acting, one attains of itself—hence it is called *sincerity*.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Three persons not existing at the same time are here presented as a parable—what is called "wordless words" is not the absence of a beak. If one were truly like those two masters, then even with a beak three feet long, it would still be as if one had not spoken. Their conduct is called the *Dao of the non-Dao*; Confucius’ silence is called the *eloquence of wordlessness*. How could the world understand this? What virtue cannot unify, what eloquence cannot encompass, is fundamentally nameless. To halt at the nameless is where auspiciousness resides; otherwise, even if one’s name resembles that of the Ru or Mohists, one cannot avoid reckless action and calamity.

The Dao in the world is like the hundred rivers to the sea—receiving without refusal. The sage, likewise all-embracing, nourishes things without knowing whose they are. Without rank, without posthumous title—this is why the sage’s namelessness is great. If even excellence in speech cannot be considered worthy, how much less can greatness reside in words? Thus what knowing cannot know, what eloquence cannot encompass, gives rise to the *eloquence of wordlessness*. The sage does not act as great, for that would be insufficient to be great—how much less can one act to possess virtue? The Dao is one, yet virtue cannot unify it—hence there is the *Dao of the non-Dao*.

That by which heaven and earth are greatly complete is fundamentally without seeking, yet complete. People, too, have what may be called great completeness—it is nothing but *sincerity*. With sincerity, there is no seeking; without seeking, there is no loss, no rejection, for one is sufficient in oneself and does not exchange it for things. The Great Person knows that in oneself, the myriad things are not lacking—thus turning back, one is inexhaustible, enduring from high antiquity without decay. Hence, following it, one does not polish. *Sincerity* is that which, without striving, hits the mark; without thinking, attains; without acting, accomplishes.

**Xun’s Annotation:**
The ancients, in speaking thus, praised Confucius—not comparing him to men of today who beg for words. Sunshu Ao, son of Wei Jia, was named Yi; as a hunter, he became Prime Minister to King Zhuang of Chu, living before Confucius. Shi Nanyi Liao was skilled at juggling balls and bells, keeping eight in the air while one remained in hand. When Chu fought Song, Yi Liao bared his chest and stood before the army, juggling as the blades fell—both armies halted, and victory was won. Both lived before Confucius’ death, yet this is but a parable. These two resolved difficulties and stilled warfare through non-action—then what need have I for words? If words were of use, I would gladly have a beak three feet long. If words are of no use, then such a beak is useless.

Master Qi had eight sons, whom he arrayed before him. He summoned Jiu Fang Yin and said, "Examine my sons for me and tell me which is most auspicious." Jiu Fang Yin said, "Kun is most auspicious." Master Qi started in surprise and joy, asking, "In what way?" He replied, "Kun will share the ruler’s table for the rest of his life." Master Qi’s face fell, and he wept, saying, "What has my son done to reach such an extreme?" Jiu Fang Yin said, "To share the ruler’s table is to extend blessings to three clans—how much more to one’s parents? Now, sir, you hear this and weep—this is to shun good fortune. Your son is auspicious; you, his father, are not." Master Qi said, "Yin, how could you know that Kun is auspicious? His fortune will be exhausted in wine and meat, entering through nose and mouth—how could you know its source? I have never herded, yet a ewe was born in my inner chamber; I have never hunted, yet a quail was born in my secluded hall. Why should I find this strange?

What I share with my sons is wandering in heaven and earth. With them, I roam in joy through heaven; with them, I roam in sustenance upon earth. I do not share in their affairs, do not share in their plans, do not share in their strangeness. With them, I ride the sincerity of heaven and earth, not contending with things; with them, I drift and wander, not sharing in their affairs. What is fitting now is but the recompense of the vulgar world.

Wherever there are strange omens, there must be strange conduct—perhaps this is not the fault of my sons and me, but heaven’s doing. This is why I weep."

Within no time, he was sent bound to Yan, where bandits seized him on the road. To sell him whole would be difficult; to maim him would be easy. Thus they severed his foot and sold him in Qi, where he happened to be bought by Qu Gong, a wealthy man serving as street warden. There, he ate meat to the end of his days.

Nie Que encountered Xu You and asked, "Where are you going?"
"I am fleeing from Yao."
"Why so?"
"Yao teems with benevolence—yet I fear he will become the laughingstock of the world. Later generations may even turn to cannibalism. The people are not hard to gather: love them, and they draw near; benefit them, and they come; praise them, and they strive. But bring them what they detest, and they scatter. Love and benefit arise from benevolence and righteousness, yet those who discard them are few, while those who profit from them are many. The practice of benevolence and righteousness is neither sincere nor genuine—it is the device of ravenous birds and greedy beasts. Thus, one man’s restraints are used to control the world’s profit, like a single fleeting shadow. Yao knows that worthy men benefit the world, yet he does not see how they harm it."

Only those who stand beyond it understand: the worthy know this. There are the "warmly content," the "soaked and mired," and the "coiled and crouched." The so-called "warmly content" learn the words of a single master, then glow with private delight, smug in their sufficiency, unaware that nothing has truly begun—these are the "warmly content." The "soaked and mired" are like lice on a pig: they pick the sparse bristles, imagining them a vast palace or grand park, nestling in the crooks of hooves, the creases of knees, the gaps between teats, believing themselves secure in their cozy dens. They do not know that one morning the butcher will roll up his sleeves, spread the straw, and wield the torch—leaving them charred along with the pig. These advance and retreat within their bounds—these are the "soaked and mired." The "coiled and crouched" are like Shun. Mutton does not long for ants, but ants long for mutton—mutton reeks. Shun’s conduct reeked, and the people delighted in it. Thus he moved thrice, each time founding a city, until at Deng’s wastes a hundred thousand households gathered. Yao, hearing of Shun’s worthiness, raised him from barren soil, saying, “May his coming bring us blessing.” Shun was raised from barren soil, his years advanced, his hearing and sight dimmed.

The so-called "coiled and crouched" cannot rest or return—this is why the spirit-person abhors the thronging of crowds. When crowds throng, there is no harmony; without harmony, there is no benefit. Thus, they hold no one too dear, no one too distant, embracing virtue and kindling harmony to follow the world. This is what is called the "true person." To the ants, they abandon cunning; to the fish, they gain strategy; to the sheep, they forsake intention. With the eyes, they see; with the ears, they listen; with the heart, they reflect upon the heart. If such is the case, their equilibrium is like a plumb line, their transformations like the tracing of a curve.

Guo’s commentary:
This is the origin of contention among the benevolent—hence the calamities of later ages. Once benevolence and righteousness are practiced, pretense arises to enact them. Their traces become visible, and the greedy will borrow these tools to achieve their aims. If benevolence and righteousness each arose from genuine feeling, their restraints would never cease. To carve all things and all forms with a single blade is to wound them. Only by esteeming the worthy externally can the worthy remain unfeigned. The "cozy dens" exhaust their intentions in shaping teachings—how could they know of my solitary transformation in the mysterious darkness? Without the talent to comprehend change or transcend the world, clinging to momentary advantage, they are all but lice on swine. The sage’s form differs not from that of ordinary people—thus the ears and eyes. The use of the eyes may wane, yet the spirit remains ever whole. If one is immature in youth and declines in old age, can the sage’s sagacity be achieved in a single morning? The crowds come of their own accord, not drawn by desire. Clearly, Shun’s attainment of the realm arose from necessity, not choice. If he sought profit from the people, his blessings upon Shun would be but bodily toil. The ant, the fish, and the sheep—these three have yet to free their ears, eyes, heart, and intention. Thus, they cannot cast off the plumb line to find equilibrium or sever traces to reach the mysterious barrier.

Lü’s commentary:
The affairs of Shun and Yu—I understand them well.

Then this is but the instrument of those who mimic the greedy birds. To call it "benevolence and righteousness" is still to remain within the realm of knowledge; with knowledge, one is confined by form and instrument—this is not what the world shares in common. Thus, when one person’s defenses and controls benefit the world, it is no more than a single hiding place. This is not the natural, curved completion that leaves nothing behind.

What is called the root of great disorder must arise between Yao and Shun, while its branches persist a thousand generations later. This is it: taking warmth as right without knowing the world has ultimate sufficiency; taking beauty as right without knowing the world has ultimate perfection. Thus, learning the words of a single master, one deems oneself complete, unaware that what is named has never truly existed.

To be drenched is not to depart; to wait is to depend. Content in baseness and filth, one remains unaware of disaster. Therefore, to name it after the lice on swine is to gather and hoard without concealing its stench, causing the world to admire and turn toward oneself—hence the name of Shun. From learning the words of a single master without knowing that nothing has ever truly existed, one becomes mired in dependence when seeking profit and tangled in hoarding when facing harm. Speaking of Shun’s traces, what does the world add to me? It is enough to weary the body. Thus, speaking of hoarding, though the crowds come and turn toward one, even like Yao and Shun, this is what the spirit-person detests. Not comparing oneself to them, they come not for profit.

This is how the true person holds no extreme closeness or distance, embracing virtue and blending harmony to follow the world. The world delights and turns toward them; Shun, too, delights and follows. Shun regards the world as a worn-out sandal, and what makes Shun "Shun" he regards as dust, grime, chaff, and husks. What is this if not the spirit and the real?

The ant, with its knowledge, busies itself; the fish, by its depth, preserves its life; the sheep, with its intention, grows fierce. With the eye, one sees—what is seen is obtained. With the ear, one hears.

Then with the ear, one hears—what is heard is obtained. With the heart returning to the heart, one knows—what is known is obtained. Cast aside knowledge and intention, and one conceals the self in the depths of the abyss, attaining what is called seeing what is seen, hearing what is heard, knowing what is known. Then there is nowhere one goes that is not level, assisting things by their own nature without deliberate action. This is the Way of returning to one’s true state.

**Limited View:**
In governing the world, one ought to practice non-action and let transformation arise of itself. If one toils diligently, seeking to benefit and aid with effort, one will fall short and inevitably resort to artifice. Once artifice emerges, calamities and harms arise without end. Those who stand above the people must truly take the hearts of the common people as their own hearts. Though they do not practice benevolence and righteousness, they will unwittingly accord with them. Otherwise, it is like lending the tools of snares and nets to a greedy hunter—the harm done to creatures will only grow worse.

Thus, when one person imposes controls, seeking to benefit the world, it is like trying to grasp the nature of the myriad things in the fleeting moment of a blink. One knows only that exalting the worthy brings advantage, yet does not see how it harms later generations. Only by standing outside the realm of the worthy can one know this—one must rise above by a head’s height before one can see through it.

The "ant, fish, sheep" triad was spoken by Shun in response to a malodorous conduct, and his words were most extraordinary. He placed the ant first, the sheep next, and the fish last—not being transformed by the stench. The ant abandons knowledge, not being moved by malodorous conduct to sway others. The sheep abandons intention. Thus, superiors and inferiors each remain content in their station, without traces of emulating sages or exalting the worthy. Like fish that are never sated by the depths and gather in rivers and lakes—is this not a wise course? Thereafter, one uses the eye to see the eye, not deluded by forms; the ear to hear the ear, not confused by sounds; the heart to return to the heart, not enslaved by knowledge. Thus, one’s equilibrium is as straight as a plumb line, becoming a model for the world. In responding to the vicissitudes of affairs, one follows the spontaneity of principle—what worry is there that the world will not transform itself, or that one must govern it with deliberate effort?

*Comprehensive Meaning*: The ant is most minute, the sheep most yielding, yet neither is entirely without knowledge or intention. The true person adopts their minuteness and yielding, yet discards their knowledge and intention—just as fish gather in water and nothing more.

*Brush Jottings*: "Using the eye to see the eye" means not seeing with the self. "Using the ear to hear the ear" means not hearing with the self. "Using the heart to return to the heart" means not returning with the self. Only when the self exists does one fail to follow things, often losing equilibrium. When ears, eyes, and heart are all entrusted to things without any interference—this is what *Liezi* calls "discarding the heart and employing the form." How could it not be as level as a plumb line? As for changes, one follows them. "Changes" refer to the myriad transformations of things. Speaking of the heart alongside ears and eyes corresponds to the Buddhist scriptures’ six roots: intention, eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body—all sharing the same meaning of equilibrium. The plumb line represents change, and following it represents spontaneity. Wang Yuanze’s version reads: "Its equilibrium is like water; its straightness, like a plumb line; its changes, to be followed."

The true persons of antiquity treated things with the Heavenly, not imposing the human upon the Heavenly. The true persons of antiquity attained this; those who lost it were born to lose it.

Death is attaining it; death is losing it. Life is medicine—its true substance is *jǐn*, *jiégěng*, *jīyōng*, and *shǐlíng*. These are emperors in their time—how can one exhaust their praise? Goujian, with his three thousand armored men, perched upon Mount Fangjī, had only Fan Li who knew how to preserve what was doomed to perish; only Fan Li did not know why his own person would come to grief. Thus it is said: the owl’s eyes have their proper use; the crane’s legs have their proper measure—dissect them, and you harm them. Hence the lament: when the wind passes over the river, it diminishes it; when the sun passes over the river, it diminishes it. Yet if wind and sun were to contend in guarding the river, the river would deem them no disturbance at all. They rely on the source and proceed from it. Thus water guards earth; the reflection guards the person; things guard things. Hence, the eye’s clarity is perilous; the ear’s acuity is perilous; the heart’s pursuit of externals is perilous. All abilities stored in the treasury are perilous. When peril accumulates, it cannot keep pace with the growth of misfortune. Here lies its reversal: following merit brings its fruition. To wait long and then claim it as one’s own treasure—is this not lamentable? Thus, the ruin of states and the slaughter of peoples never cease, for they do not inquire into the cause.

(*Jǐn*, as Sima Biao notes, is *wūtóu*; *jīyōng* is *qiàn*; *shǐlíng* refers to *xīlíng*, as mentioned in the *Jìn Xué Jiě*.*)

Guo’s commentary: Abiding in non-action to await action—only thus can one attain it when action arises. Seeking non-action amid action only deepens entanglement. Life and death, gain and loss, each follow their abode. In life, one may attain it; in death, one may lose it again. What is needed is without baseness; what is untimely is without worth. Worth and baseness have their seasons—who can make them constant? Each suits its time; none can be universally applied. Thus, there are times of loss and times of grief. *Jiě* means "to sever." The formed naturally burden one another; only by transcending form can one remain unscathed. Though wind and sun pass over the river and truly diminish it, one does not perceive it. The unperceived is not the undiminished—it is the reliance on the source. Without intention, one rests within one’s allotment, thus attaining certainty. With intention, one strays into boundlessness, thus falling into peril. Therefore, value the inability to act and entrust oneself to the natural. *Cuì* means "to gather." If one cannot comprehend this, misfortune grows unchecked. Reversal lies in guarding one’s nature, where merit arises effortlessly. Haste precludes fruition—thus it is said: "its fruition." To wait long and claim it as one’s own treasure refers to possessing knowledge and ability. Thus, the calamities of ruin and slaughter are one’s own doing, for one does not inquire into the source of misfortune—only into the heart’s cultivation to avert it.

Lü’s commentary: Treating things with the Heavenly means responding without contrivance; imposing the human upon the Heavenly, though acting, is never true action. The true person does not know life or death—sometimes attaining it in life, sometimes losing it in death. Death: all things cannot but live by it. This speaks to those who take life lightly. Sometimes it is said: attaining it in life, losing it in death. Life: to take life as loss, death as return—this speaks to those who abhor death. Like medicine, some is sweet, some poisonous; in its time, it is emperor, otherwise a mere minister. To take life as gain and death as loss is medicine for those who take life lightly; to take life as loss and death as return is medicine for those who abhor death. Observe the illness and administer accordingly—its transformations are beyond enumeration. Minister Fan knew how to preserve Yue from ruin but did not know why his own person would come to grief. Like the owl’s eyes, which see at night but not by day, their use cannot be abandoned; the crane’s legs, which are long but not short, have their measure and cannot be severed. This is to be bound by form and not know the source. Wind and sun pass over the river, not without diminishing it, yet the river deems them no disturbance—it relies on the source and does not exhaust. One who penetrates the Dao is at home with all things, yet this too has its source. Water reaches every crevice in earth, every ant’s burrow; the reflection follows the person’s every movement—without emotion, it guards with certainty. The ear’s hearing, the eye’s seeing, the heart’s thinking—none departs for an instant, thus things guard things with certainty. Yet the ear’s acuity, the eye’s clarity, the heart’s intent are not like water and reflection, without emotion, and so cannot but fall into peril. All abilities stored in the treasury are perilous. The treasury refers to the five viscera; peril means resting where one should not. If one cannot keep pace with change, misfortune gathers. Only by tracing it back does one reverse it; following merit brings its fruition. To wait long—this is why the superior person diminishes and diminishes again, for peril cannot be perfected. Yet the world claims it as its own treasure—is this not lamentable?

The received text: From "the owl’s eyes" onward, five instances of *gù* ("thus") elaborate the meaning. The owl’s eyes are bright at night but dim by day—they have their proper use. The crane’s legs are long but not short—they have their proper measure. To sever them with a blade harms their life. This speaks to following the natural. The next passage drives the point home: it is not about forcing things to conform but having one’s own source, like water with its headwaters, thus guarding earth, guarding the person, guarding things. This principle originally abides without separation, like water guarding earth, the reflection guarding the person, things guarding things—settled and unchanging. The three instances of *dài* ("peril") reverse the three instances of *shěn* ("certainty"). If the heart, ears, and eyes pursue externals, they cannot remain settled and fall into peril.

Moreover, extending this principle further: whatever one possesses as ability becomes a harm. To display it is to conceal it within. The formation of peril is not yet beyond remedy, but the growth of calamity accumulates—this speaks to how swiftly misfortune arises when one does not act rightly. To reverse peril into security, to turn calamity into fortune, one must proceed step by step with gradual effort. Even those who are resolute and self-mastering must wait long before success—this speaks to how difficult it is to cultivate goodness.

Yet the people of the world indulge their desires—ears, eyes, keen perception, and cunning thought—as if they were treasures. Near at hand, they lose their lives; on a grand scale, they destroy states, slaughter the people, and their misfortunes never cease. This is because they do not inquire into these matters, nor has anyone enlightened them.

The *Xin Zan* states:
Water arises from earth yet does not depart from earth. Reflection arises from form yet does not depart from form. Things emerge from the Creator yet do not depart from the Creator. Thus it is said: guard them. They are settled, yet earth has no intention toward water, and water thus clings to it. Form has no intention toward reflection, and reflection thus arises. The Creator has no intention toward things, and things thus come to be. None of these three has any intention of mutual dependence.

How can the common world resemble this? The eye necessarily seeks clarity, the ear necessarily seeks acuity, the heart necessarily seeks to pursue externals. Thus, to necessarily seek clarity is to have intention toward clarity; to necessarily seek acuity is to have intention toward acuity; to necessarily seek to pursue externals is to have intention toward external things. Having intention toward keen perception and the pursuit of externals inevitably leads to peril—how can this be the Way of mutual dependence?

The utmost persons of antiquity knew that excessive knowledge is the root of calamity. Though wise, they never failed to relinquish wisdom, so misfortune could not entangle them. The common world, unable to do this, prides itself on its intelligence—this is why misfortune spreads unchecked.

Yet when misfortune first arises, it lurks within fortune, following its momentum—like Minister Fan Li, who initially preserved Yue. Thus it is said: its reversal depends on merit. But when it becomes a burden, it is not established in a single morning or evening. Consider Minister Fan Li, who in the end could not escape the loss of his life. Thus it is said: its fruition requires time. All this is summoned by intelligence.

The common world, unaware of this, instead treasures intelligence as the jewel of the self. Are these not the people described as "the benighted masses"?

Thus the foot’s relation to the ground: though it treads, it relies on what it does not tread to achieve its full reach. So too with human knowledge: though little, it relies on what it does not know to grasp what Heaven truly means. To know the Great Unity, to know the Great Yin, to know the Great Vision, to know the Great Equality, to know the Great Square, to know the Great Faith, to know the Great Constancy—this is perfection. The Great Unity unifies them; the Great Yin dissolves them like a crab’s molting; the Great Vision sees them; the Great Equality follows them; the Great Square embodies them; the Great Faith verifies them; the Great Constancy upholds them. In all, there is Heaven’s order, illumination, obscurity, and pivot—only then does one begin to possess them. Yet in dissolving them, one resembles one who does not dissolve; in knowing them, one resembles one who does not know. Only by not knowing does one truly know. In questioning them, one cannot be bound by limits, nor can one be without limits—intertwined and shifting, yet substantial. Past and present do not replace each other, nor can they be diminished. Can this not be called possessing great barriers?

To close is not to question—why then be perplexed? To resolve perplexity with non-perplexity is to return to non-perplexity—this is the highest non-perplexity.

To lift and draw them forth is to display their patterns. Guo’s commentary: Only when Heaven and Earth relinquish the myriad things can the wings of the cicada be known—how much more so for desiring to know what Heaven intends, can one do so without emptying the heart? The Great Oneness is the Dao. The Great Yin dissolves them; when its inner divisions are employed, the ten thousand affairs encounter no obstruction. To employ the self-manifestation of the myriad things is also the Great Eye. Following their fundamental nature so each attains its own is the Great Equality. To embody them so each attains its proper place is why the ten thousand directions all attain it—this is the Great Square. What is ordained has its appointed time, with no allowance for transgression—this is the Great Faith. When the real is unperturbed, it naturally stabilizes; thus, to uphold it with the Great Constancy is to not uphold it at all.

No thing is without its natural course; to follow it is illumination without contrivance. The utmost principle has its limit, but if one obscures it, one grasps its pivotal essence. That which begins them is the "other." Thus, I transmit without creating; to dissolve is to entrust it to the "other," and the "other" dissolves itself. Dissolution yields no merit, hence it resembles non-dissolution. Employing the "other’s" knowledge, hence it resembles non-knowing. If I do not know, then the "other’s" knowledge operates on its own. When the "other’s" knowledge operates on its own, there is nothing under Heaven that is not known. To be without limits is to respond to things appropriately without fixed methods. To be without absence of limits is for each to follow its own division. Though the myriad things are tangled and shifting, each thing possesses its own reality. Each possesses its own reality, so they cannot replace one another, nor can they be diminished—it is fitting that each exhausts its own division.

To guard and restrain them is to possess great barriers. If one questions these great barriers, then things have their ultimate divisions. Thus, Guo says: Entrusting oneself to the principle of things, what is there to be perplexed about? If perplexity cannot be dissolved, then the highest non-perplexity is the utmost foolishness. The sage follows and entrusts himself to it—hence the traces of emperors and kings differ, and their names vary with the age.

Lü’s commentary: What the feet tread is little; relying on what they do not tread, one can then be broadly good—this is what is meant by knowing non-use and only then can one speak of employing others’ knowledge. Relying little on what one does not know, one can then know what Heaven intends—thus the Great Oneness, the Great Yin, and even the Great Constancy can be known. Those who practice the Dao take the Great Oneness as their master, and there is nothing they do not penetrate. Entering the gate of profound obscurity, they reach the utmost yin’s principle and also arrive at the utmost yang’s source. Things bear yin and embrace yang, yet remain bound and cannot dissolve—this is because they do not know the source of the utmost yin.

The eye’s vision is limited; not seeing with the eye, there is nothing unseen. Following the One, none can equalize harmony with right and wrong—entrusting it to their twofold operation is following the Great Equality. Without south, without north, without east, without west—embodying the Great Square. Its essence is most real, and within it lies faith—verifying it with the Great Faith. Moisture burns without heat, rivers freeze without cold, thunder splits mountains, winds shake the sea, yet it remains unshaken—upholding it with the Great Constancy. To exhaust Heaven’s order is to halt at what knowledge does not know. Following illumination, though one does not know, there is nothing unknown. Obscuring the pivot, neither this nor that can find its counterpart. Beginning with the "other," that which responds to the "other" and "this" is inherently inexhaustible.

Dissolution resembles non-dissolution—words are originally unbound, hence non-dissolution precedes dissolution. Knowledge resembles non-knowing—it is originally without knowledge, hence non-knowing precedes knowing. This is how the utmost person roams among the common customs, appearing foolish and clumsy. To question with limits or without limits is to be bound by limits—this means seeking from one’s own boundaries, yet it cannot be sought between existence and non-existence. Tangled, it cannot be bound; shifting, it cannot be grasped—it is as if nothing exists, yet it possesses reality. Past and present do not replace each other and cannot be diminished.

Can one not call this possessing great barriers? Yang means to reveal its subtleties; Fang means to examine its reality. If the "other" does not question this, I cannot inform it with this. Only by seeing that there has never been a thing can one be without perplexity. To dissolve the perplexity of having things with this and still retain the state of never having had a thing is still perplexity. Only by dissolving it and returning to non-perplexity can one approach the Great Non-Perplexity.

Following the original text: What the feet tread is little, but what they do not tread is essential for action. What knowledge knows is little, but what it does not know is essential for great knowledge. The Great Oneness, the Great Yin, the Great Eye, the Great Equality, the Great Square, and the Great Faith—all are not confined to small matters. I consider them exhaustive, yet there is also Heaven’s inexhaustible. I consider following what one ought to do sufficient, yet there is also that which oversees it. I consider it profoundly obscure, yet there is also that which grasps its pivot. I consider it a beginning, yet there is also the "other"—the "other" itself is a beginning. Following the earlier statement that the Great Yin dissolves it, ultimately, this is dissolution, yet it resembles non-dissolution; this is knowledge, yet it resembles non-knowing. Only by not knowing does one then know—this aligns with the earlier statement about questioning without knowing.

Thus, in conclusion, the word "question" is introduced to bind it together. If one questions this Dao, which is fundamentally without boundaries yet also never without boundaries, it seems like the earlier debate over tangled hardness and whiteness, yet here it possesses reality. All things undergo replacement, but this cannot be replaced or diminished. *Heng* means to lift, and *fang* means to turn the hand repeatedly. When many lift and expound, answering with hands turning back and forth to point and display—this Dao, though spoken of as differing, is truly real. Is this not a great lifting and expounding, a handle for discourse? Why do people not question this and instead become perplexed by having something? If one can use one’s own non-perplexity to dissolve others’ perplexity, enabling them to return to non-perplexity, then all may achieve non-perplexity. Even without questioners, one still hopes for enlightened immortals among people—scholars often apply their minds in this way.

General observations from a limited perspective: Though Marquis Wu was fierce and stubborn, difficult to approach, and lacked persuasive discourse, the adept began by praising fine steeds to open his heart, also clarifying that a ruler’s regard for ministers must be discerning. Thus, he was initially rebuffed but ultimately aligned—this is because the good nature of the human heart cannot be entirely extinguished, just as one who leaves a country rejoices at seeing someone resembling a person. Upon meeting again, he then accepted loyal admonitions, even if harsh to the ear, to warn of his faults. Fond of harmony and detesting treachery, he fulfilled the essentials of self-cultivation—sincerity aligning with Heaven and Earth, exhausting the Dao of serving the state. Where does this lie? In acting with righteousness to benefit the people, laying down arms to seek governance.

The Yellow Emperor met Great Hiddenness, and the Seven Sages all became lost—this illustrates how, when the six senses are clouded, the heart’s ruler cannot alone be clear. If a ruler desires to see the great Dao, he must abolish sagacity and discard knowledge, seeking it in the spirit of guarding the heart and removing what harms the self. Then, Great Hiddenness will arrive without being sought.

Only in later generations did the various scholars diverge in their pursuits, concealing their inherent nature and turning toward the myriad things—no longer hoping to return to the root, thus drifting ever farther from the Dao. Take the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and the followers of Bing and Hui: each clung to one partial truth, claiming to have exhausted the Dao. Yet in their debates, when the thrust of their arguments struck true, they too could reveal the Dao’s subtleties—like the man of Ying whose foot-stamping aided the master carpenter’s work.

It is also said that only one with the talent of Xi Peng could bring forth Guan Zhong’s rise; arrogance hastens ruin, while humility invites praise—this serves to warn the world against pride and insolence. How could such posturing compare to those who still their hearts and wither their forms? Those who juggle balls or wield plumes remain entangled, their bonds difficult to undo.

Jiu Fang Gao discerned the essence of a horse without mentioning its lameness; Xu You, fearing Yao’s benevolence, fled to escape it—both saw the subtle and knew the manifest, prizing worthiness to secure advantage. The *jingen* and *weiling* herbs serve as imperial metaphors for how people shift with the wind; the Yellow River’s currents illustrate how transformation sweeps all things along. To cling to things is indeed delusion—yet none can avoid being swept away, and to be swept away is perilous.

Only one who knows contentment and does not tread upon the heart, who relies on unknowing, can fully embody Heaven to illuminate the Heaven in things. Then, one is no longer deluded and can resolve the world’s delusions. **Ze Yang, Twenty-Five**

Then Ze Yang journeyed to Chu, where Yi Jie spoke of him to the king, yet the king did not summon him. Yi Jie returned to Peng Yang and met with King Guo, saying, “Why did you not speak of me to the king?” King Guo replied, “I am not your equal—rather, Gong Yue Xiu is.” Peng Yang said, “What sort of man is this Gong Yue Xiu?” The king answered, “In winter, he spears turtles in Jiangxia; in summer, he rests in the mountain thickets. When someone passes by and asks, ‘Whose dwelling is this?’ he replies, ‘It is mine.’ Yi Jie is already incapable—how much more so am I? And I am not Yi Jie’s equal. As for Yi Jie’s character: though he lacks virtue, he possesses cunning. He does not commit himself wholeheartedly, yet his connections are firmly entangled in obscurity. In the realm of wealth and honor, men do not aid one another with virtue but instead assist in one another’s decline. The frozen borrow garments in spring; the sweltering long for winter’s return. The cold wind—such is the nature of the King of Chu. His form is august and stern; in matters of punishment, he grants no pardon, fierce as a tiger. If not for flatterers and men of true virtue, who could sway him? Thus the sage, in his poverty, makes his household forget their want; in his eminence, he makes kings and lords forget their ranks and titles, transforming them to humility. In his dealings with things, he delights in their harmony; in his dealings with men, he rejoices in their communion while preserving himself. Thus, though he may not speak, he intoxicates others with harmony; though he stands beside them, he transforms them, making fathers and sons fulfill their proper roles. How profound is his influence! Returning home, he remains in quiet unity with all he has bestowed. His effect on the human heart is as vast as this. Therefore it is said: await Gong Yue Xiu.

Guo’s commentary: King Guo, by praising Gong Yue Xiu’s character, sought to restrain Peng Yang’s eagerness to advance. He meant that he himself was not equal to Yi Jie, who pursued wealth and honor, forging connections through cunning and flattery to curry favor with superiors. “Assisting in decline” means that, in the rush to advance, virtue thins and reputation fades. The metaphor of cold and heat suggests that, though he follows the seasons’ gifts, he cannot meet Peng Yang’s expectations. The sage, serene and desireless, finds joy in what he encounters, prizing not extravagance but virtue. Thus his family forgets the bitterness of poverty; he scorns rank and title, valuing virtue instead. Detached, he sits in stillness, unaware of the honor upon him, so that kings and lords lose their sense of superiority. He delights in things without self-harm, rejoicing in their communion while preserving himself. Each finds contentment, and harmony flows without need for words. Standing beside others, he transforms them without relying on power, so that fathers and sons return to their proper places. His influence is like Heaven and Earth, quiet and unchanging. “Await Gong Yue Xiu” means he would have Peng Yang abandon the King of Chu and follow Gong Yue Xiu, whose tranquil virtue would settle the king’s restless heart.

Lü’s commentary: Gong Yue Xiu, being so free of desire, was surely trusted by the king. The spirit is the common ground of human hearts—it can be exhausted and yet still enter. Yi Jie claimed he could not enter, yet his connections were already entangled in the realm of wealth and honor, where men assist in one another’s decline. The frozen, in winter, borrow garments from spring; the sweltering, in summer, long for winter’s return—winter’s cold offers no relief. The King of Chu was harsh and cruel; only flatterers and men of true virtue could sway him. To speak of me to him was beyond my power. Only flatterers can bend a ruler’s integrity; only true virtue can bend his perversity. The flatterer is Yi Jie; the man of true virtue is Gong Yue Xiu. I delight in poverty and sit in stillness, so my family also forgets their want. When the Way is honored and virtue prized, rank and title lose their luster, and kings and lords are transformed to humility. He intoxicates others with harmony, his virtue sufficient to nourish the human heart without need for words. Standing beside others, he transforms them without relying on power. Fathers and sons return home, fulfilling their proper roles without neglecting human bonds. His influence is unified and unobtrusive, free from regret. When the human heart is so profoundly moved, its errors are undone. Gong Yue Xiu’s character is such that speaking of him to the king would surely be believed. Thus it is said: await Gong Yue Xiu.

Xun’s commentary: “Not committing himself wholeheartedly” means yielding to others so that none can fathom his motives. The frozen, encountering spring, find garments; the sweltering, meeting the cold wind, return to winter. This metaphor suggests that, though the King of Chu is steeped in desire, he is easily swayed by persuasion. To “sway” means to submit: flatterers do so with flattery, the upright with uprightness. “Transforming to humility” means becoming submissive. Standing beside others, he transforms them into proper father-son relationships. “How profound is his influence!” expresses admiration—whether concealing or employing his power, he remains unmoved, free from the common cravings of men. His effect is as vast as this. The passage from “This is my dwelling” to “assisting in decline” describes Gong Yue Xiu; from “The frozen” to “who could sway him” describes the King of Chu; and from “Thus the sage” onward describes following Gong Yue Xiu.

Fang’s commentary: The frozen must borrow garments, yet even thick clothing is not as warming as spring’s gentleness; the sweltering must seek wind, yet even a cool breeze is not as relieving as winter’s arrival. Those who covet power must rely on the favor of the mighty, yet even the mighty’s favor is not as noble as the self-sufficiency of retreat. With the King of Chu’s power, how much greater is his cold than winter’s chill, his heat than summer’s swelter! Those entangled in obscurity would weary of him—how could they succeed? Thus it is said: await Gong Yue Xiu—this is admonition.

The sage, in his thoroughness, is boundlessly intertwined with all things as one, yet unaware that this is his nature. He returns to his mandate, moves with spontaneity, and takes Heaven as his teacher. Others follow and name it. How troubling is knowledge, for the actions it guides are fleeting—when will they cease? How can one who is born beautiful rely on others for recognition? If not told, he does not know his beauty in others’ eyes. If he knows, he seems not to know; if he hears, he seems not to hear. His joy is endless, and others’ admiration for him is likewise unceasing—this is his nature. The sage’s love for others is such that, if not named, they do not know his love. If he knows, he seems not to know; if he hears, he seems not to hear. His love for others is endless, and their contentment in him is likewise unceasing—this is his nature.

Guo's Commentary:
[To "attain the intertwining" is what is called "penetrating the profound." It pervades all as one, with no inner or outer, yet all is thoroughly illuminated. If one does not know why it is so yet it is so—what is this if not nature? To "sway" is to sway of itself; to "act" is to act of itself. None fails to return to the mandate and take its naturalness as teacher. This is not striving for a name or exalting one’s traces—moving by following nature, one’s traces are naturally exalted, and thus others cannot humble the name. To act by relying on knowledge is to be entangled in cares and mirrors. A mirror reflects things impartially, and thus people admire it. How could the mirror know it is mirroring when it mirrors? If one is born mirror-like, others call it a mirror. If people do not tell one another, none knows their beauty in others. It is like the sage—others give the name. The mirror’s delightfulness lies in its lack of emotion: whether one knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, it reflects what comes before it, and thus is endless. If the mirror depended on hearing and knowing, it would cease at times. What one’s nature does not favor, how could it reflect for long? The sage’s love is like the mirror. Yet because it benefits things, others give the name. If people do not tell one another, none knows his love for others. Vast and unobstructed, he treats the hundred clans as straw dogs, yet the Dao accords with loving others—thus he can be endless. If love for others depended on hearing and knowing, it would wane at times. How could what nature does not settle in endure for long?]

Lü's Commentary:
[The human heart is entangled in affairs and things, unaware of the one body. Only the sage can penetrate this, thus inwardly not seeing the self and outwardly not seeing things—things and self are one. What he embodies is inherently all-pervading. That he does not know why it is so is limited to nature and not obtained from without. To "return to the mandate" is to return to the root; to "sway and act" is to be like the teeming grasses. Though still and returning to the mandate, this does not hinder swaying and acting. Thus, though speaking all day, he has not spoken; though acting all day, he has not acted—all is simply taking Heaven as teacher. What Heaven knows, he does not know. How could I know myself to be a sage? Others follow and name it. Without knowledge, there is no care. The multitude worries over knowledge, and their actions are like galloping—how could they have a moment of rest? How could one attain this? One born beautiful is given a mirror by others, and only after being told does he know his beauty in others. Whether knowing or not knowing, hearing or not hearing, his delight is endless, and others’ admiration for him is likewise unceasing—this arises from nature. The sage’s love for others is such that others give the name, and only after being told does one know it is love for others. Whether knowing or not knowing, hearing or not hearing, his love for others is endless, and others’ contentment in him is likewise unceasing—this arises from nature. It is not increased or diminished by knowing or not knowing, hearing or not hearing.]

Following the root, entangled in the intricacies of affairs and principles, only the sage can fully comprehend them. Throughout the body, nothing is not this principle, yet one does not know its source—this is called the nature. In stillness, it returns to the root and restores the mandate; in movement, its swaying and arising all accord with Heaven. Thus, people name it the sage. Worrying over knowledge, their actions are ever without respite—human life does not reach a hundred years, yet they constantly harbor the cares of a thousand. Gazing upon an old state or former capital, one feels unbounded joy. Even if hills, mounds, grasses, and trees have changed nine parts out of ten, the joy remains unbounded—how much more so for those who see what they see and hear what they hear?

A tower of ten *ren* hangs suspended amidst the multitude—this is the mystery. The house of Ran Xiang attained its central pivot, following completion without end or beginning, without limit or time. The one who transforms with things is not transformed. How could one ever abandon this to take Heaven as a teacher and fail to learn from it? All things would then be enslaved to what one takes as their task.

How is it that the sage has never begun with Heaven, never begun with man, never begun with a beginning, never begun with things? They move with the world without decline, their actions complete yet not excessive, their harmony perfect. How did Tang attain his minister of chariots, or the gatekeeper Yin Deng serve as his tutor? Following the master without constraint, he attained the capacity to follow completion and thus became its steward. The name of his name was Ying Fa, who grasped both aspects. Confucius, in exhausting his thoughts, served as his tutor. The house of Rong Cheng said: "Remove the days, and there are no years; no inside, no outside."

Unbounded joy, ease amidst the profound—*Yuan Jia* edition reads "leisure." Excessive indulgence, or as another says, ruin and decay.

Guo’s commentary: *"If even what one has long possessed still brings such unbounded joy, how much more so when one attains their true nature? To bind and unite—what one has always seen, what one has always heard, still brings such ease; how much more so when one embodies its essence and employs its nature? Though the multitude clings to habit, even in peril they remain at leisure; how much more so the sage, who knows no peril?*

*Ran Xiang was a sage-king of antiquity. Dwelling in emptiness, he followed things, and things formed themselves. With things, he had no end, no beginning; suddenly, all moved together. Thus, he transformed with things, yet remained constantly without self. Being constantly without self, he was constantly unchanging.*

*What is the use of striving? Why not abandon what one strives for? Only by having no master does one attain the mastery of Heaven. Yet even mastering Heaven is not free from subjugation—how can it suffice as a pursuit? If mastering Heaven is still insufficient, how much less so what lies below it? Only when Heaven, man, the beginning, and things are all absent does one achieve perfect union.*

*Thus, Tang entrusted matters to his hundred officials without interference. He allowed them to gather naturally, not confining them; to disperse freely, not releasing them. Even his ministers of chariots could follow the self-formation of things, and Tang attained this. Thus, his name was lent to things, and his merit did not reside in himself. The name and method are but traces of the past, not the true fulfillment.*

*Therefore, it is said: ‘Ying, free and without intent, entrusts governance to the many officials, and thus his name and traces appear in them.’ Confucius said: ‘What thought, what worry is there in the world? Thought is already exhausted.’ If even the slightest concern remains, how can one be still and unmoving, responding endlessly to the infinite, aiding the spontaneity of the myriad things?*

*Rong Chengzi said: ‘Remove the days, and there are no years.’ The reason we now have years and preserve days is because of life and death. If there were no death, no life, then the reckoning of years and days would be abolished. Without self and other, there is no inside or outside."*

The Lü commentary states: *Gazing upon the old brings joy—such is human nature. Even if the mulberry trees on the hills twist and entwine, one still feels this joy, yet this is merely to forget their origin. How much more so when what we see and hear has stood alongside heaven and earth, becoming our homeland for so long? Yet to perceive and hear it is like gazing from a towering terrace suspended amidst the multitude—nothing escapes its view. How boundless is this joy!*

*"Amidst the multitude"* refers to places devoid of people, where the center revolves endlessly without beginning or end, where things form spontaneously without agency. Thus, there is no termination or commencement, no moment of reckoning. *"Reckoning"* means calculation; when one merges with the transformations of things, if even one aspect remains untransformed, why would it not persist? Its movement is constant, without pause or cessation.

Those who seek to emulate heaven but fail merely follow things in their pursuits. The sage, however, has never distinguished between heaven and humanity, nor between beginnings and things. Moving in unison without cessation, complete yet unexhausted—this is what is called *"returning to the mandate"* and *"acting in accord."* The true emulator of heaven thus aligns with it.

Tang obtained the *Controller of Chariots*, who presided over regulation and governance. The *Gatekeeper* and *Steward of Constancy* were the offices he entered. *"Constancy"* refers to the enduring cultivation of the Dao. The *Controller of Chariots* is the mind’s rectitude; what it enters is the Dao. Constancy is the Dao’s permanence—all these take heaven as their teacher.

Only by following the teacher without being confined by things, and by obtaining the ability to *"follow completion,"* do names arise. Thus, the names of *Controller of Chariots* and others follow the completion of one’s mind, not the names of those who act with intent. Its essence is the Dao; its excess is the method. Observing the origin of names reveals the source of methods—this is called *"dual manifestation."* Though there is perception, if one does not realize that the world has never begun with thought or worry, it remains incomplete. Thus, Confucius exhausted all concerns to serve as its tutor. Yet Confucius was not Tang’s tutor.

By *"following completion,"* one attains what Ran Xiangshi obtained. From this, we know that the names of *Controller of Chariots* and others are allegories. *"Remove the days, and there are no years"*—thus, one does not recognize time. *"Without inside or outside"*—thus, one does not recognize space. Only those who exhaust all concerns can partake in this.

---

**Dubious Alone** states: *The joy of perceiving one’s nature is like the joy of seeing one’s old homeland. Even climbing a perilous high terrace becomes effortless with familiarity—how much more so for one who attains true nature?*

Ran Xiangshi and the sage-kings before the Three Sovereigns grasped the principle of true emptiness, revolving endlessly and following the myriad things to complete the Dao, without beginning, end, or reckoning. To *"merge with the transformations of things"* is to be one with them; not transforming in one aspect enables transformation in all. Why do those in the world who act with intent not abandon their doing and return to natural true nature? Yet those who deliberately seek to emulate heaven fail—how much more so those who follow things without return?

There has never been a heaven, a humanity, a beginning, or things—yet heaven, humanity, beginnings, and things exist of themselves. Moving through the world, they bend and extend without cessation; in full conduct, they guard humility without excess. How can they so merge with principle? The offices of *Controller of Chariots* and *Gatekeeper*, the title *"Steward of Constancy"*—these names of the Dao can serve as teachers for others.

The sage follows the teacher without being confined by the teacher, simply allowing spontaneity. For example, if the other is an infant, one becomes an infant with them. Tang obtained these three as his transmission, following them without confinement, aligning with and completing the Dao. Thus, Tang became the one who bore their names, while the traces of those three vanished from the world.

These names—*"excess method"* and *"dual manifestation"*—appeared in Tang. Though Tang was a sage who fulfilled the human Dao, his methods were not yet complete. By the time of Confucius, the world’s transformations were fully manifest, so he exhausted all concerns to establish and complete the methods—thus serving as Tang’s tutor.

---

**Following the Origin** states: *Heaven is spontaneity. To abandon the teacher and method is to depart from spontaneity. Those in the world who are not at peace with their nature sacrifice themselves to things, making them their affairs. How can such affairs align with the Dao?*

The sage transcends even heaven’s absence—what then remains of so-called humanity, beginnings, or things? Though moving alongside the world, they are not hindered; though engaging with affairs and things, their conduct is complete without falling into excess. How can this not align with the Dao?

What does *"dual"* refer to? The *Gatekeeper* and *Steward of Constancy*—some say these are Yi Yin. Tang took them as teachers without being bound by rules, achieving success through allegory. What they accomplished was merely to bear Tang’s names, making him renowned in the world. Yet names are external, surplus to one’s true nature—what benefit do they bring? They only make others see the ruler and minister as admirable.

Yet Confucius and his disciples exhausted their thoughts to serve the rulers of their time—this was excessive. The later quote from Rong Chengzi—*"The reason years are named as such is because they accumulate three hundred and sixty days. Remove the days, and there are no years"*—means that if one eliminates even the subtlest thought, the burden of external names vanishes. Without inside, there is no outside.

---
