**Xu Shichang** states: *From "Tang obtained the Controller of Chariots" onward, the three obtained their roles, mutually reinforcing one another—only thus can it be understood. The Yellow Emperor commanded Rong Cheng to create the calendar, hence his saying, "Remove the days, and there are no years." Some commentators mistakenly take Rong Cheng as an ancient sage.*

**Wei Ying** states: *Wei Ying made a covenant with Tian Houmou, who betrayed it. Wei Ying was enraged and intended to send an assassin. Xi Shou heard of this and found it shameful, saying: "You are a lord of ten thousand chariots—why resort to the methods of a commoner? Allow me to request two hundred thousand armored troops to attack him, capture his people, seize his cattle and horses, and make his lord’s back burn with fury before seizing his state. Let him flee, then strike his back and break his spine!"*

*Ji Zhi heard of this and found it shameful, saying: "Building a ten-ren wall only to tear it down—this is the toil of convict laborers. Now, for seven years, there has been no war..."*

This is the foundation of a king’s rule—Yan’s chaotic words must not be heeded.

Master Hua heard this and found it shameful, saying: "Those who speak well of attacking Qi are agents of chaos; those who speak well of not attacking are also agents of chaos. To call both attacking and not attacking agents of chaos—this too is the speech of an agent of chaos."

The lord said: "Then what should be done?"
He replied: "Your lordship need only seek the Dao."

Master Hui heard this and went to see Dai Jinren. Dai Jinren said: "There is a creature called the snail—do you know of it?"
The lord said: "Yes."
Dai Jinren continued: "On the left horn of the snail there is a state called Chus; on the right horn, a state called Mans. At times, they fight over territory, leaving tens of thousands of corpses. After pursuing the routed army for fifteen days, they return."
The lord said: "Alas! Are these empty words?"
Dai Jinren replied: "Allow me to make it real for you. When your mind roams the four directions, above and below—is there a limit?"
The lord said: "There is no limit."
Dai Jinren said: "To know the mind’s roaming in the boundless and then return to the realm of states that are known—do they seem as if they exist, as if they do not?"
The lord said: "Yes."
Dai Jinren said: "Within the known realm lies Wei; within Wei lies Liang; within Liang lies your lordship. Do you and the lord of Mans have any real distinction?"
The lord said: "There is no distinction."

The guest departed, and the lord was left in a daze, as if something had been lost. When the guest left, Master Hui saw the lord and said: "That guest is a great man—even a sage cannot compare to him."

Master Hui said: "Blowing into a pipe produces a resonant sound, but blowing into the ring of a sword’s hilt yields only a faint *xuē*. Yao and Shun are praised by all, yet speaking of Yao and Shun before Dai Jinren is like that faint *xuē*."

Guo's Annotation:
The snail is most minute, yet it bears two horns—truly, if one knew that what men contend over is as trifling as this, there would be no strife under Heaven. The realm where human footprints reach is called "the known"—this refers to all within the Four Seas. Now, though one may take the Four Seas as vast, when measured against the boundless, they seem as if they exist, as if they do not. The lord and the lord of Mans are both finite things; being finite, whether great or small, neither can be compared to the boundless. Even Heaven and Earth, sharing in the boundless, are all as nothing—how much less the Liang within Wei, the lord within Liang, that they should contend? Lost in a daze, as if something had been lost, he mourned the pettiness of what he had contended over. It is like the faint *xuē*—so slight it is scarcely heard.

Lü's Annotation:
No fault is greater than desire for what is desirable. To speak well of attacking Qi is to reveal the desirability of gain, which surely disorders men; to speak well of not attacking is to reveal the desirability of goodness, which also disorders men. To say that both attacking and not attacking disorder men is still to be trapped in partial views, which further disorders men. Only by seeking the Dao can one avoid clinging to one-sided views, and thus still the source of disorder. If one roams the mind in the boundless, then the Four Directions and the Six Realms—the known lands like Wei and Liang—are all but projections of one’s own heart. Not only is there no distinction between the lord and the lord of Mans, but even the known lands—Wei, Liang, and Mans—are without distinction. Knowing this, nothing is greater than a hair’s tip, and Mount Tai is small. The lord awakened to the fact that the origin of strife is fundamentally non-existent, and so he was left in a daze, as if something had been lost. The divine man, the sage, and the great man are fundamentally without superiority or inferiority—the difference lies only in how they are spoken of. Blowing into a pipe produces a resonant sound because it has something to receive; blowing into a sword’s hilt yields only a faint *xuē* because it has nothing to receive.

Fu Mo's Note:
Blowing into a pipe still produces a resonant sound, but blowing into the ring of a sword’s hilt yields only a faint *xuē*—why? The pipe’s bore is small, yet it allows form and qi to clash and produce sound. The ring of a sword’s hilt, when blown into, lets the breath pass with a faint *xuē*, unable to produce sound. Now, to speak of the sage before the great man is to cause the sage to lose his sageliness—how could there be any sound? Even the yielding Yao and Shun could find no place for their voices—how much less the contention of the lord of Mans?

Confucius was traveling in Chu and lodged at the home of a seller of millet-wine on Ant Mound. A neighbor, a man with his wife, servants, and concubines, climbed onto the roof. Zilu said: "What is this *zōngzōng* gathering?" Confucius said: "This is the servant of a sage. He buries himself among the people, hides himself in the wilds. His voice is stilled, his aspirations boundless. Though his mouth speaks, his heart has never spoken. Far from conforming to the world, his heart disdains to accompany it—this is one who sinks beneath the land. Is this not Yiliao of Shinan?" Zilu asked to go and summon him. Confucius said: "Enough. He knows that I am renowned, that I am traveling to Chu, and that I would surely have the King of Chu summon him. He would take me for a flatterer. If this is how he feels about flatterers, he would be ashamed to hear their words—how much more to see them in person?" Zilu went to look, but his house was empty.

The servant of a sage is a disciple of the sage. "Sinking beneath the land" means to appear eminent yet vanish like sinking without water. 】

Guo's Annotation:【"Buries himself among the people" means to be one with them. "Hides himself in the wilds" means neither to flourish in advancement nor wither in retreat. "His voice is stilled" means his fame is diminished. "His aspirations boundless" means he seeks long life. Though his words are those of the world, his heart differs from it. One who "sinks beneath the land" is like sinking without water. "Renowned" means manifest. "How could he remain?" means it would be better to leave him to follow his own aspirations—his house was empty, and indeed he had fled.】

Lü's Annotation:【Seeing Confucius arrive and climbing onto the roof was to show he would not engage with him, intending to ascend even higher. The servant of a sage, though possessing sagely virtue, buries himself among the people, so his conduct is not visible; hides himself in the wilds, so he does not dwell in the mean of virtue. His voice is stilled, his aspirations boundless—retreating into seclusion, he roams beyond the world. Though his mouth speaks, his heart has never spoken. He desires silence yet cannot remain silent, differs from the world yet disdains to accompany it, wishing to flee the world and depart. Though he wanders among men with sagely virtue, none recognize him—like one who dwells on land yet sinks. From Confucius’ perspective, his restless efforts to attend to the world seem like flattery. Yet if all were like Yiliao, then among the mass of people, who would save the sagely Way? It would fall to the ground and never rise again. Formerly, Weisheng Mu once took Confucius for a flatterer, and Confucius replied that he dared not. Here, with Yiliao, he calls himself a flatterer to clarify that what he values lies elsewhere, and his restless efforts are not by choice.】

Changwu’s border guard asked Zilao: "When you govern, do not be reckless; when you order the people, do not be careless. Formerly, when I planted grain, if I tilled recklessly, the harvest repaid me recklessly; if I weeded carelessly, the harvest repaid me carelessly. The next year, I changed my method—deepened the plowing and thoroughly harrowed—and the grain flourished and multiplied. I had my fill for the whole year." Zhuangzi heard this and said: "Now, those who cultivate their bodies and order their minds often resemble what the border guard described: they flee their Heaven, depart from their nature, extinguish their emotions, lose their spirit, and take the crowd as their model. Those who recklessly abandon their nature allow the sprouts of desire and aversion to become their nature. Like reeds and rushes, reeds and reeds, they begin to sprout, propping up our form and soon uprooting our nature. Together they burst forth, leaking and erupting without choosing their outlet—boils, scabies, abscesses, internal heat, and oily urine are all such cases."【"Qi" is the same as "fen," a method of plowing. "Wei" and "jia" are reeds. "Together they burst forth, leaking and erupting" means essence and qi scatter and drain, rising to leak above and seeping below, without choosing their outlet.】

Guo's Annotation:【"Reckless" and "careless" mean hasty, superficial, and incomplete in fulfilling one’s duties. "Changing the method" means exhausting one’s duties without omission. Fleeing, departing, extinguishing, and losing are all caused by following the crowd. If each fully realizes its utmost, how could reeds harm the grain? Desire and aversion injure the true nature. When form is propped up loosely, spirit and qi are harmed. If desire and aversion lead the nature without stopping at what is proper, the consequences below—bursting, leaking, and erupting—are the repayment for recklessness. Thus, in cultivating the nature, how can one not fully realize its utmost?】

Lü's Annotation:【The daily diminishing of the Way to reach non-action is how one cultivates the body and orders the mind. Yet to flee Heaven, depart from nature, extinguish spirit, and lose emotions by following the crowd without restraint is the height of recklessness. If one could calmly maintain what has not yet arisen and easily plan for it, with internal desires and aversions like reeds and external reeds and rushes propping up our form and uprooting our nature, then the Heavenly principle would be extinguished. At such a time, could one still govern it? The bursting, leaking, and erupting below are all the work of desire and aversion as calamities, seizing what is true.】

Yang Yongxiu:【Poor plowing is called "reckless"; poor weeding is called "careless." "Lu" is salty land, so plowing such land requires extra effort. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Way of Plowing" speaks of "strengthening the soil and weakening it." "Mang" is grassy land; the *Book of Songs* says, "They hew, they slash"—this is good plowing. Not treating the salty land or clearing the grassy land is called "reckless plowing." Weeding is like birds pecking at food—this is good weeding. The *Lüshi Chunqiu* says, "Good weeding lets the elder brother grow and removes the younger brother"—the elder brother is fine grain, the younger brother is weeds like smartweed. Poor weeding lets the younger brother grow and removes the elder—this is "careless." "Lie" means to dig up the soil along with it. It also says: when desires and aversions first sprout, they seem to prop up our form but immediately uproot our nature. The character "shi" (beginning) pairs with "xun" (soon)—the common reading of "jianjia shimeng" as a phrase is incorrect.】

Boju studied under Lao Dan and said: "I request to travel the world." Lao Dan said: "Enough. The world is the same as this."

Boju again asked Lao Dan, saying: "Where shall I begin?"
Lao Dan replied: "Begin with Qi."
When he arrived in Qi, he saw a man condemned to execution. He pushed forward, forced his way through the crowd, removed his court robes to cover the man, and cried out to Heaven, wailing: "Alas for you! Alas for you! The world suffers great calamity—yet you alone have been the first to encounter it. It is said: 'Do not steal, do not kill.' Yet once honor and disgrace are established, one sees what brings suffering; once wealth and property are amassed, one sees what sparks strife. Now, by establishing what brings people suffering and amassing what sparks their strife, you exhaust their strength without respite. How could this not lead to such an end?

The rulers of old held that success lay in the people and failure in themselves; that uprightness lay in the people and crookedness in themselves. Thus, if their person erred, they would withdraw and reproach themselves. Now it is not so: they conceal their faults as if the people were ignorant, and when great difficulties arise, they punish the people for not daring to bear them. When tasks are heavy, they penalize those who cannot endure them; when the path is distant, they execute those who cannot reach it. When the people know their strength is spent, they resort to deceit. Day by day, deceit multiplies—how could the people not be deceitful? When strength is insufficient, they feign ability; when knowledge is lacking, they deceive; when wealth is wanting, they steal. On whom can the blame for thievery and deceit rightly fall?"

The character *lí* (離) here—Master Chǔ’s note states it should be *yī* (一), likely a scribal error in transcription. Guo Xiang’s commentary: "Great calamity in killing" refers to the matters below. Once such calamity exists, even if one warns against it, how can it be avoided? Each attains their own Way, and thus there is no honor or disgrace, no gain or loss in tumult. Yet when honor and disgrace are established, one boasts of what is called disgrace and strains for what is called honor. Racing and striving between boasting and straining—what is this if not affliction? If one takes contentment as wealth, what is there to contend over?

When those above have preferences, those below cannot rest in their fundamental duties. If the ruler makes no errors, the people naturally attain the Way; if the ruler makes no deviations, the people naturally align with uprightness. How then do the natures and forms of things come to be lost? All stem from the ruler’s interference, leading to these calamities.

Thus, self-reproach returns to one’s nature; concealment obscures it. Employing one’s nature reveals it. Therefore, when revealed by things, all recognize them; when things are easily altered, all dare to treat them lightly. When tasks match their strength, all endure them; when distances suit their capacity, all reach them. But when the people know their strength is spent, they resort to deceit to avoid punishment. If the ruler daily fosters deceit, how can one expect the people not to be false? Whom can one blame?

Lü’s commentary: "A certain official, having once held office, removed his court robes to cover the deceased, fully expressing his compassion. Clearly, this man had once committed faults. Thus, he did not hesitate to criticize those above. If superiors cannot regulate honor and disgrace, the people see their afflictions; if they do not value wealth and goods, the people see their contentions. Now, those above impose afflictions on the people and gather their grievances, incite their contentions and multiply their disputes—how can they expect the people not to steal or kill, not to incur death? Tang and Wu said, ‘The myriad regions’ faults lie in me alone,’ taking attainment as belonging to the people and failure to themselves. Yi Yin said, ‘If even one man is not saved, it is my fault.’ When their person erred, they withdrew and reproached themselves. Now, it is not so: they feign ignorance, punish those who dare not bear, execute those who cannot endure, and kill those who cannot reach. This differs from the leniency of the former kings, who measured people’s strength and pitied their incapacity. When the people know their strength is spent, they cannot but resort to deceit. If those above multiply deceit, how can they expect those below not to be false?"

Qú Bóyù, at sixty, transformed sixty times, never failing to begin with what he deemed right and end by condemning it as wrong. How could he know that what he now called right was not the wrong of fifty-nine years prior? All things have life, yet none see their root; they emerge, yet none see their gate. People all honor the knowledge they possess but do not know to rely on what their knowledge does not grasp—only then can one be said not to harbor great doubt. Cease, cease! There is no escape from this. Is this what is meant by "so" and "so"?

Guo Xiang’s commentary: "Transformation means following the world without being bound to self or other, aligning with things and flowing with the changes in their nature. Yet the changes in things’ nature have no end, no root, no gate—suddenly, naturally, thus none see them. Only those who neither live nor emerge can perceive their gate and fathom their root. What I do not know, other things may know. Thus, employing the knowledge of things, there is nothing unknown; relying solely on my own knowledge, what I know is scant. Now, if one does not rely on things for knowledge but instead exalts one’s own, how is this not great doubt? Unable to employ others, one has no place to lodge the self. Those who claim to be ‘so’—the world does not affirm them."

Lü’s commentary: "At sixty, Bóyù transformed sixty times, never failing to begin with what he deemed right and end by condemning it as wrong—just as Confucius did. If knowledge does not rest in what it does not know, then what is called ‘right’ is not fixed. How can one know that what is now deemed right is not the wrong of fifty-nine years prior? Things live, yet none see their root; they emerge, yet none see their gate. What one’s knowledge does not grasp is precisely the source and emergence of the myriad things. Yet people all honor the knowledge they possess, while regarding what their knowledge does not grasp, they constantly fear its emptiness and do not rely on it. Each time, they reach the brink and turn back—how is this not great doubt? Cease, cease! There is no escape. Such words ultimately cannot reach the ultimate, nor can one’s person contain them. Though what is now said may be ‘so,’ how can one know it is truly so? One must observe words to verify them."

A humble view: People pass through others to form an age; affairs change to form transformations. Like mosquitoes or wild horses passing before one, their number is unknown, yet one’s true constancy never alters. If one knows this, life and death cannot move the heart. The life, death, emergence, and entry of things have root and gate. If one truly knows what one does not know, the root and gate of the myriad things can be seen. Their life, death, emergence, and entry follow constant principles—what confusion can there be? Yet what people know and can do is but one ten-thousandth of what they do not know and cannot. Even sages cannot exhaust all knowledge and ability—how can they escape the transformations of things? Though what I now say may be deemed ‘right,’ how can I know it is truly so?"

Confucius asked the Grand Historian Dàtāo, Bó Chángqiān, and Shǐ Wěi: "Duke Líng of Wèi indulged in wine and revelry, neglecting state affairs; he pursued hunting and archery, ignoring relations with the feudal lords. How then did he come to be called ‘Líng’?" Dàtāo replied, "It was because of this." Bó Chángqiān said, "Duke Líng had three wives, with whom he bathed promiscuously. When the historian Fáng presented the ceremonial silk, he supported him, his arrogance reaching such extremes..."

Seeing a worthy man, he was so reverent—this is why he was called ‘Líng.’ Shǐ Wěi said: "As for Duke Líng, when he died, divination for burial at the ancestral tomb proved inauspicious, while divination at Shāqiū proved auspicious. Digging several fathoms deep, they found a stone outer coffin. Washing it and examining it, they saw an inscription that read: *‘Do not rely upon his descendants’*—whereupon Duke Líng seized it and buried it there. That Duke Líng was called ‘Líng’ has long been so. How could those two men suffice to understand it?"

*(The promiscuous bathing vessel refers to the three wives; Shǐ Fáng was Shǐ Yú. ‘Do not rely upon his descendants’ means the lineage was unworthy of trust, thus allowing the Duke to secure this site for his tomb.)*

Lǚ’s annotation states: *"Bó Chángqiān judged by human standards, while Shǐ Wēi judged by Heaven’s decree. Judging by Heaven, even posthumous names are not something humans can determine."*

Fāng Sīshàn comments: *"The *Book of Posthumous Names* states: ‘Disorderly yet unharmed is called *Líng*’; ‘Virtue’s essence and clarity is called *Líng*.’ Given how the Lord of Wèi conducted himself, why was his posthumous name *Líng*? The implication is that it was insufficient to match his wickedness. *Fèngyù* is akin to what we now call ‘summoning for audience’; ‘supporting and guiding him’ speaks to propriety. The shared bathing was one matter, the audience another—they need not have occurred simultaneously. The general intent shifts from human affairs to Heaven’s will, departing from contrivance to honor spontaneity, merely using this as an analogy. *Lǐ* is also written as *mái*; examining the inscription’s rhymes, *zǐ* and *lǐ* form a perfect rhyme. Ancient texts refer to the grave as *hāolǐ*, so writing it as *mái* is likely incorrect."*

Shàozhī asked Dàgōng Tiáo: *"What is meant by ‘the speech of the mound and village’?"*
Dàgōng Tiáo replied: *"The ‘mound and village’ unites ten clans and a hundred names to form customs. It merges differences into sameness and disperses sameness into differences. Now, if you point to a horse’s hundred parts, you do not obtain the horse; yet when a horse stands before you, you unite its hundred parts and call it a horse. Thus, hills accumulate the low to become high; rivers converge waters to become vast. The great man unites all to become impartial. Therefore, what enters from without has a master yet is not grasped; what issues from within has a norm yet is not resisted. The four seasons have distinct *qi*, yet Heaven does not bestow them, and so the year is completed. The five offices have distinct duties, yet the ruler does not favor them, and so the state is well-governed. The civil and martial virtues of the great man are not bestowed, and so his power is complete. The myriad things have distinct principles, yet the Dao does not favor them, and so it is nameless. Nameless, it is non-action; through non-action, nothing is left undone. Time has endings and beginnings; the world has changes and transformations. Fortune and misfortune flow ceaselessly—where there is obstruction, there is also what is fitting. Those who sacrifice themselves for distinct faces have what is correct and what is awry. Compared to the great marsh, all materials find their measure; gazing upon the great mountain, trees and stones share the same altar. This is called ‘the speech of the mound and village.’"*

Shàozhī said: *"Then is this sufficient to be called the Dao?"*
Dàgōng Tiáo said: *"No. Now, if we tally the number of things, they exceed ten thousand, yet we designate them as ‘the ten thousand things’—using the term for what is most numerous to name them. Thus, Heaven and Earth are the greatest of forms; yīn and yáng are the greatest of *qi*; the Dao is what they share in common. If we follow their greatness to name and designate them, that is permissible. But if we claim to have already attained it, how could we compare to it?"*

Then, if one employs private disputation as an analogy, it is like dogs and horses—how far they fall short!

*(Annotations: In the *Rites of Zhou*, four wells make a hamlet, four hamlets a mound, five households a neighbor-group, and five neighbor-groups a village. "Gift" here means bestowal; "awry" means discordant; "face" means orientation. It is said that hearts differ, and thus right and wrong diverge—what is correct in one case may be awry in another. "Measure" means dwelling-place. Though regions and positions differ, all take the great marsh as their dwelling; though trees and stones vary in kind, all share the same altar upon the great mountain. This may be called "the speech of the mound and village.")*

Guo’s commentary:
When the great person holds no private interests in the world, the world’s customs become unified. What enters from without is the transformation wrought by the great person; what emerges from within is the nature of the people and things. Each nature attains its proper state, so the people harbor no contrary intentions. The transformation must reach impartiality, so the ruler holds to nothing—thus they can unite the mound and village and merge the world, unify the ten thousand things and level their differences.

Distinct *qi* naturally exists, so it can endure; if it were fundamentally nonexistent and merely bestowed by Heaven, it would at times be exhausted. Distinct offices naturally possess their talents, so they are entrusted accordingly. It is not that the great person privately bestows them. As for cultural refinement, it arises from culture itself; martial prowess arises from martiality itself—these are not gifts from the great person. If they depended on bestowal, they would at times be lacking. Not only cultural and martial traits, but all natures are thus: names are limited by reality, so "non-action" prevails; realities each act on their own, so "nothing is not done." Times and eras change, but the one without intent follows them. Fortune and misfortune flow ceaselessly, turning back and forth. What is discordant here may be fitting there; each affirms what it affirms and cannot depart from it. What is correct here may be awry there. Compared to the great marsh, no material is discarded; gazing upon the great mountain, differences are united as one.

The speech of the mound and village can thus reveal the world. Things numbered do not stop at ten thousand—how much less can the unnumbered be called sufficient to name the Dao? Things attain communication through their own openness; if one forcibly designates this as the Dao, it is what is meant by "the Dao that can be spoken." The name already exists—how then could one attain and compare to it? Now, the disputation of names falls far short. Thus, to call it the Dao is still insufficient. It must reside in the realm of namelessness and wordlessness before it is reached. Though there are names, none can compare to it.

Lü’s Annotation:
To unite surnames and given names is to make the village diverse yet one; to disperse the village is to make names identical yet distinct. It is not like the words of a single household, where differences cannot be united and unity cannot be dispersed. The hundred parts of the body are no less than a horse—point to them and you cannot call them a horse; yet stand them all together and call them a horse. By analogy, the great person does not regard their greatness in its entirety, for then even what is called "great" cannot be attained. Compare it to hills and mountains, rivers and streams—these are the ultimate in greatness.

Thus, when viewed from things, the myriad things are all complete within me. What enters from without has its master within, and though one holds to the ten thousand, nothing is excluded. When viewed from myself, it flows freely as the ten thousand things pass away. What issues from within has its correctness and does not resist; it circulates everywhere and nothing is left untouched.

Heaven does not bestow the four seasons based on what is inherently theirs—if its achievements were incomplete, the year would not be fulfilled. The ruler does not claim the work of the five offices as his own—if wisdom were not all-encompassing, the state would not be well-governed. King Wen and the Duke of Zhou had different talents; the myriad things have different principles. Yet their non-bestowal and non-appropriation are like this—without self-interest, there is no self; with no self, nothing can be named. With no name, there is non-action; with non-action, nothing is left undone.

Times change without ceasing; fortune and misfortune have no constancy. What is adverse may be fitting; what is good may become ominous. The dispositions of things each follow their own faces, not uniform—some are correct, some are awry. What is correct may become strange. Since the principles of things are not uniform, the Dao is what makes them impartial. The Dao is fundamentally a forced name—calling it the Dao is still insufficient. Originally nameless, yet named with a name, it already exists. How then could it be compared to the nameless?

Following the Root:
The great person unites and makes things impartial. Thus, what enters from without has the impartial Dao as its master within and does not cling. What issues from within has the impartial Dao as its counterpart without, correct and not resisting. It does not bestow, so does not treat as favor. Time has its endings and beginnings; the world has its changes and transformations—one cannot cling to uniformity.

Sincerity is real. Fortune follows goodness, misfortune follows excess—all are real principles. What is adverse may be fitting, like the old man who lost his horse—who knows if it is not fortune? Those who follow their own faces have what is correct and what is awry. People each follow their private intentions as if faces were not different, yet seeking to correct them only leads to deviation.

Personal Insight:
Within every village, there must be one venerable in age and virtue who examines the sentiments of the multitude and establishes discourse—like the so-called "moonlit critiques" or local proverbs that record customs and things. This is the speech of the village, uniting differences as one. Those who emerge from the same village have disparities in age, worth, success, and failure—unity becomes difference.

The greatness of the world arises from the village; the greatness of the Dao pervades all things. Dispersing unity into difference is like pointing to the hundred parts of a horse; uniting differences as one is like assembling the hundred parts and calling it a horse. In speech, there is union and dispersion; in profound insight, all returns to undifferentiated oneness. Principles have their ultimate, beyond which sound cannot reach.

Hills and mountains accumulate the lowly; rivers and streams gather waters. The great person unites impartiality—this principle is no different. If one can unite the village and attain fittingness, then uniting the sentiments of the world is likewise. It resides in the single word "impartiality." Laozi said: "Impartiality becomes kingly; the kingly is what the world turns toward—how could it be refused?"

Thus, what enters from without is learning. The noble person’s learning is mastered by the Dao. Mastering the Dao, things are without obstruction. What issues from within is thought. The noble person’s thought is correct in principle. Correct in principle, things have nowhere to resist. Just as the four seasons have different qi yet complete the year, and the five offices have different duties yet complete governance, all return to the virtue of the great person, who embodies and elucidates the Dao’s impartiality. How then could it be named?

With no name, there is non-action; with non-action, nothing is left undone—this is the necessary consequence of principle. Yet times have their changes; mechanisms have their hidden and manifest. There are those for whom adversity becomes fitting, and those for whom correctness becomes deviation—all due to following one’s own sentiments, thus unable to avoid divergent tendencies.

For example, the hundred materials of the great marsh unite in the use of the master carpenter—difference becomes unity. The trees and stones of the great mountain disperse into the world’s use—unity becomes difference. If one profoundly unites with principle and returns to the Dao, what debate remains over unity and difference?

The name "Dao" is insufficient to exhaust the Dao; the number "ten thousand" is insufficient to exhaust things. Each is spoken of in terms of its greatness. The greatest of forms is governed by Heaven and Earth; the greatest of qi is governed by yin and yang. The Dao governs Heaven and Earth, yin and yang—how could its greatness be measured? Yet once there is the name "Dao," it cannot be compared to the nameless. Thus, the Dao of the perfected person operates in namelessness—how could the world name it?

Little Knowledge said: "Within the four directions, within the six conjunctions, where do the myriad things arise? What is the great impartiality?"
Great Impartiality said: "Yin and yang illuminate, cover, and order each other; the four seasons replace, give birth to, and destroy each other. Desires and aversions, departures and approaches arise here in succession; male and female unite here in commonplace fashion. Safety and danger alternate; fortune and misfortune give birth to each other; urgency and leisure rub against each other. Gathering and scattering form the names and realities that can be recorded, the essences that can be noted.

Following the sequence of their principles, the succession of their movements—exhaustion returns to beginning, ending returns to commencement. This is what things possess, what words exhaust, what knowledge reaches—nothing more. Those who perceive the Dao do not follow what is abandoned, do not trace what arises. Where does this discussion end?"

Little Knowledge said: "Ji Zhen’s 'non-action' and Jie Zi’s 'or-activation'—which of these two theories is correct in its essence, which pervades its principles?"
Great Impartiality said: "Cocks crow and dogs bark—these are what people know. Even with great knowledge, one cannot speak of their spontaneous transformations, nor can one conceive of what they will become. Analyzing them precisely, they reach the point of no category; in greatness, they reach the point of being unencompassable. To activate them is to be inevitably constrained by things and ultimately considered excessive; to let them be is to have emptiness in reality and fullness in name. Having name and reality, they reside in things; having no name and no reality, they are in the emptiness of things. They can be spoken of, yet the more one speaks, the more distant they become. Before birth, they cannot be prevented; after death, they cannot be obstructed. Death and life are not far apart, yet their principles cannot be seen.

To activate them or let them be—both are doubtful assumptions. I observe their roots—they are without end. I seek their ends—they are without cessation. Without end, without cessation—speech is without it."

With things, they share principle; to activate them or let them be—this is the root of speech. With things, they begin and end—Dao cannot be possessed, possession cannot be without Dao. Dao is a name borrowed for its function, activated or left to be—within things, it is but a fragment. How then could it align with the great square?

Speech that suffices exhausts Dao in a day’s words; speech that does not suffice exhausts things in a day’s words. The ultimate of Dao and things cannot be borne by speech or silence—neither speech nor silence can discuss their limit.

*(Annotations within text: "Bridge-rise" denotes the swift onset of speech’s momentum; "following sequence" refers to transformations that proceed in order; "bridge-movement" signifies alternating and successive arrival.)*

Guo’s commentary:
When asked about the origin of things, some say Dao generates them. Yet yin-yang and the four seasons arise of themselves, not from nothing. All these affairs are thus said to be "acts" or "abandonments." They arise from the mutual illumination of yin-yang and the alternation of the four seasons. Beyond this lies spontaneity—who knows the cause of its mutual principles and activations? All belong to things, arising naturally, not from some power that enables them. Beyond things, nothing further exists, so knowledge cannot surpass the limits of things. Arising and ceasing occur of themselves, without origin or following. This is where discussion ends—it reaches spontaneity, hence there is no further discourse.

Jizhen said, "Dao does nothing." Jiezi said, "Dao sometimes activates, sometimes lets be"—it has the function of activating things. Yet things possess spontaneity, which no act can achieve. From this perspective, Jizhen’s words are correct. The utmost refinement and vastness arise not from action but of themselves. Things have mutual activation, which also occurs of itself. Thus, "letting be" is not the absence of things—all things arise and pass through "letting be." "Activating" makes them substantial, for they activate themselves; "letting be" makes them empty, for nothing activates them. Residing in names and realities, they are where things are; their reality is utmost emptiness. The more one seeks in speech, the more distant they become—only beyond speech and intention does one reach them.

Suddenly, they are born—we cannot prevent it; suddenly, they die—we cannot obstruct it. Near as they are in the body, we cannot see their spontaneity, yet we worry over them. These two—activating and letting be—are the world’s greatest doubts. The principles of things are endless, so their words are endless; only then do they share principle with things. To begin and end with things is to be constantly without action yet spontaneous. Dao cannot make possession exist; what exists is always spontaneous. Thus, it is said: Dao cannot be possessed, possession cannot be without Dao. Things proceed by it, so it is provisionally called Dao. How could a fragment align with the great square? Seeking Dao beyond speech and intention suffices; seeking it in speech and intention does not. The ultimate of things is always spontaneous, not residing in speech or silence. It reaches spontaneity—neither speech nor silence can discuss it.

Lü’s commentary:
Those of little knowledge call it Dao, yet once possessed, it cannot compare to Dao, hence they doubt its nonexistence. Asking whence all things arise—what governs them? The void. The sun and moon come and go, rise and set, wax and wane, illuminating and covering, ordering each other. Cold and heat, contraction and expansion, mutual generation and conquest, alternation and succession—things born between heaven and earth move with yin-yang and the four seasons. Desires and aversions, departures and approaches ride these to act; male and female, separation and union, movement and stillness follow constancy, hence there are peace and danger, fortune and misfortune, gathering and scattering. These are the names and realities that can be recorded, the essences that can be noted—none are beyond inquiry.

"Following sequence" means preceding and succeeding in order, mutually ordered without chaos. "Bridge" means riding them to act; "movement" means relying on them to cross. They activate each other without fixation. Exhaustion returns to beginning, end returns to start—yin-yang and the four seasons belong to things, not to Dao’s absence. Knowledge’s limit ends here; this is where all things arise, not where they are generated and arise. "The mother of the myriad things" is such a name.

Those who perceive Dao never lack things, so they do not follow what ceases; never possess things, so they do not trace what arises. Nameless, they emerge beyond the six directions—how could speech and knowledge reach them? Jizhen’s "letting be" follows what ceases; Jiezi’s "activating" traces what arises. The crowing of roosters and barking of dogs—these are their transformations, what they have already done. Their crowing and barking—these are their spontaneous transformations, what they will do. Utmost refinement has no within; utmost vastness has no beyond. Where then do "activating" and "letting be" reside? This is why they are not free from things—unattached to reality, they attach to emptiness. Taking names and realities as things’ residence, they do not know they never possessed them; taking namelessness and emptiness as things’ void, they do not know they never lacked them. Thus, the more they speak, the more distant they become.

Life and death cannot be avoided or halted—transcending speech and intention, though near in the body, they cannot be seen. "Activating" and "letting be" are both doubtful assumptions, not the true principle. Without end, one cannot see the beginning; without cessation, one cannot see the end. These are the principles of things, not their forms. "Activating" and "letting be" can be spoken of and conceived, yet they are not free from things, only beginning and ending—how can one see their endlessness and boundlessness?

Dao cannot be possessed because it has no possession; possession cannot be without it because it arises not from our absence. Thus, Dao is a provisional name—how can names be Dao? "Letting be" and "activating" are but fragments of things—how could they align with the great Dao? Speech that exhausts Dao is rare speech, spontaneous; speech that exhausts things is excessive speech, leading to exhaustion. Viewed from things, Dao is not things; viewed from Dao, no thing is not Dao. The ultimate of Dao and things cannot be borne by speech or silence. Speaking all one’s life without speaking—this is not speech; remaining silent all one’s life without not speaking—this is not silence. Only when discussion reaches this point does it attain its limit.

Xun’s commentary:
"Bridge-rise" means rising abruptly, separation and union. "Essence that can be noted" refers to recording the subtle. Speech’s limit is knowledge’s end—it reaches only things. Where speech ends and knowledge reaches is merely the limit of things. Only those who perceive Dao do not follow things’ end or trace things’ beginning—they return to nothingness. This is why debate ceases.

"Letting be" means nothing acts; Mencius said, "What acts without acting is Heaven." "Activating" means something causes it; Mencius said, "Acting or causing to act"—the two masters’ teachings differ thus. This is splitting hairs. The *Book of Songs* says, "The axe splits it"—splitting it refines it to no category, expands it to unencompassability. The *Doctrine of the Mean* speaks of "hair, which still has category"; "The bearing of heaven has no sound, no scent"—this is the utmost. The so-called "letting be" and "activating" are not free from things and ultimately have discrepancies.

Jingchuan states: *"Letting be"* is the Buddha’s nature of spontaneity; *"activating"* is the Buddha’s nature of dependent origination. Dwelling in words clings to things. *"Activating"* and *"letting be"* both arise from the origin of speech—thus speech has its root.

**General Observations on the Text**

This essay begins with Zeyang and Wang Guo’s discussion, invoking Shan Fan’s virtue to quell the clamor of marketplace striving, guiding people toward tranquility and harmony—this is to nourish others with harmony and transform them. Its benefit to governance is profound. People often chase things and lose themselves, growing ever more distant from the old capital; yet even from afar, one gazes toward it with longing. If one could but glimpse what they once saw and hear what they once heard, how joyful would they be? Governing the self is like governing a state: when the heart-king is upright, the five officials are well-ordered; when the ruler is upright, his ministers are worthy. This is not merely advantageous for the present—it is enough to inspire transformation for generations to come. Tang had his three ministers in the past, and later Confucius arose in his wake. Like the four seasons completing the year’s work, what distinction is there between inner heaven and outer humanity?

Next, it recounts Qi and Wei breaking their alliance and resorting to arms, drawing the analogy of the *Chu Man* to admonish the bellicose rulers of the time, exposing the narrowness of their habits and the futility of their conflicts. Confucius abandoned the ant-hill debate, for its traces invited suspicion; the border official discussed the *wei*-grain, cautioning against desire and aversion as harbingers of calamity—all demonstrating the essentials of engaging the world and cultivating the self. Bo Ju lamented the condemned man, taking his misfortune as his own; to rectify others, one must first rectify oneself. Qu Yuan adapted to the times, relying on what he knew and employing what he did not—this is the method of governing the people and transforming things. Duke Ling’s posthumous title of "Ling" was determined before his death; thus, all his actions were bound by fate, as if the Creator’s calculations were entrusted to human hands.

As for the words of the village: union and separation, sameness and difference—though a horse is not a hundred parts, it is named by its standing form. The great person unites all in public; the myriad things differ, yet the Dao is complete. Like the hundred materials of the great marsh or the trees and stones of Mount Tai, some share origins but serve different uses, some differ in source but share a common end—all within the bounds of form and qi. Through transformation, the utmost principle is exhausted.

The conclusion invokes Ji Zhen and Jiezi: both *you* and *wu* are attachments, inevitably caught in the cycle of things. Only by transcending speech and silence, where the heart fuses and intent is realized, does the ultimate discourse on things reside. Thus, one knows that what can be spoken or named is not the true constant, and that the Dao cannot be carried by either speech or silence. This is clear.

**Chapter Twenty-Six: External Things**

External things cannot be relied upon—thus, Long Feng was executed, Bi Gan slain, Jizi feigned madness, and E Lai put to death. Jie and Zhou perished. No ruler fails to desire loyalty from his ministers, yet loyalty does not necessarily earn trust. Thus, Wu Yun’s words: *"Flowing in the Yangtze,"* while Chang Hong died in Shu, his blood concealed for three years before transforming into jade. No parent fails to desire filial piety from their child, yet filial piety does not necessarily bring love. Thus, Xiaoji grieved, and Zeng Shen mourned.

When wood rubs against wood, it ignites; when metal and fire are held together, they melt. When yin and yang clash, heaven and earth convulse—hence thunder and lightning. Fire burns within water, consuming the great locust tree. Such profound sorrow leaves one trapped with no escape. The *chen* and *dun* cannot fulfill their hearts, suspended between heaven and earth, restless and oppressed, sunk in distress. As profit and harm grind against one another, fire blazes fiercely, and the multitude is consumed. The moon, though constant, cannot withstand the flames. Thus, one collapses, and the Dao is exhausted.

*(Wang [Bi] says: "Those who forget attachment to the self have no adversaries in the world; then external things have no necessity to rely upon.")*

*Chen* and *dun* are read as *chong* and *rong*, signifying the unsettled qi of fear and dread, two fluids in turmoil. *Wei*, *yu*, *min*, and *men* denote oppression and gloom; *shen* and *tun* mean deep distress. *Tui* means compliance.*

Guo’s commentary:
Good and evil outcomes alike cannot be predetermined—jade turns to azure from congealed blood, the utmost of sincerity and devotion. Loyalty is not necessarily met with trust, nor filial piety with love. Thus, the perfected person responds to things without fixed intent, adapting only to what befits the moment. Thunder, lightning, water, fire, and the burning locust tree—these are what is meant by "errant movement." If one cannot transcend form, one is bound to whatever form one encounters, sinking into sorrow or joy, with no right or wrong to guide them. The more one clings, the greater the difficulty; nowhere is there a firm foothold. Thus, one cannot fulfill their aspirations, suspended between heaven and earth, striving for what is lofty yet distant. Oppression, gloom, deep distress—these are not clarity, peace, or ease. The arising of fire is inner heat. To abandon profit is to harmonize, but if profit and harm linger in the heart, that harmony is consumed. The moon cannot overcome fire: when vast, it is dim and burdened; when small, it is bright and knows its limits. Only by yielding without clinging, forgetting form and attaining self-possession, is the Dao fully realized.

Lü’s commentary:
All that is not of one’s inherent nature and destiny is an external thing. Thus, it cannot be predetermined. Longfeng and Bigan took benevolence as something to rely upon and clung to it; Elai and Jie and Zhou took the lack of benevolence as something to rely upon and clung to it—all met with inescapable ruin. If one acts with goodness or evil yet remains distant from penal measures, what need is there for such clinging? External things cannot be predetermined not only in others but also in oneself. Rulers and parents all desire the loyalty and filial piety of their ministers and children, yet loyalty is not necessarily met with trust, nor filial piety with love. The desire for ministers and children to be loyal and filial lies within oneself. If the Dao has not yet reached its culmination in yielding, even what one desires remains an external thing and cannot be predetermined—how much less so in others? Wu Yun, Chang Hong, and others clung to what they expected from others, and thus met their deaths in sorrow. Their blood turned to azure, the utmost of devotion, yet even this could not ensure the fulfillment of their desire for loyalty in others. Is this not lamentable? When wood rubs together, it ignites; when similar natures interact, they cannot avoid mutual harm. When metal guards fire, it melts; when dissimilar natures interact, they cannot avoid mutual harm. From "the errant movement of yin and yang" onward, it speaks of great calamities from which there is no escape between heaven and earth: they shake into thunder, burst into lightning, emerge from the dissimilar, or harm the similar, even giving rise to fire that consumes harmony, leaving the moon unable to prevail. The great peril lies in having a self—how can one be without sorrow? Whether bound to the similar or the dissimilar, one is doubly trapped. *Chen* and *dun* cannot fulfill their desires, their hearts suspended between heaven and earth, oppressed and gloom-ridden, sunk in deep distress, unable to find resolution. This is like the errant movement of yin and yang, the great disorder of heaven and earth. As profit and harm grind against one another, fire blazes fiercely—this is like the time of thunder, lightning, and the burning locust tree. Even the clear and luminous nature, like the moon, cannot overcome the fire that consumes harmony. All this arises from having a fixed intent. Only by yielding does one let the heart roam freely, reaching the state of no intent, where the Dao is fully realized.

Yi Du’s commentary:
*Chen* and *dun* are doubt and confusion, preventing the completion of affairs and the fulfillment of intent. When aspirations are thwarted, there is oppression; when intentions are crossed, there is gloom. When encountering circumstances, one sinks; when touching things, one is mired. As profit and harm clash in the breast, fire arises, consuming harmony, and trust is no longer whole.

Bi Xu’s commentary:
The Dao rests within, yet affairs extend without. Even what lies within oneself cannot be predetermined—how much less external things? If benevolence and righteousness were predetermined, Boyi and Shuqi would not have starved to death. If wisdom were predetermined, Bigan would not have had his heart cut out. If loyalty were predetermined, Wu Yun and Chang Hong would not have been executed. Here, the loyal and worthy, the flattering and fortunate, are doubly trapped, with no escape. Wu Yun and Chang Hong knew to serve their lords with utmost loyalty but did not foresee that a lord’s treachery would bring disaster. Xiaoji and Zeng Shen knew to serve their parents with utmost filial piety but did not foresee that parental suspicion would bring sorrow. None of them understood the principle that external things cannot be predetermined. Elai, who followed Zhou, aided a kindred tyrant yet could not escape ruin—like wood rubbing together. Longfeng, who opposed Zhou, clashed with a tyrant of opposing nature yet met execution—like metal guarding fire. When yin and yang move errantly, heaven and earth fall into great disorder. When loyalty and filial piety are met with punishment, the state collapses. Loyalty and filial piety are what ministers and children must fulfill. Yet if, by misfortune, one encounters a dark ruler or stubborn father—perverse and violent—it is like fire in water, burning the great locust tree (as in the *Huainanzi*, where an old locust tree burst into flame). If one is loyal and remonstrates, sorrow befalls the minister; if one flatters and deceives, sorrow befalls the ruler—both fall into the calamity of action. Thus, sorrow runs deep, and one’s aspirations cannot be fulfilled. Desiring to stand lofty and resplendent between heaven and earth, yet finding the world’s ways in collapse, one is stifled, mired, and drowned, with no outlet for their abilities. As loyalty and flattery grind against one another, resentment and hatred blaze daily, and human harmony is consumed. Loyalty and filial piety are like the moon; arrogance and emptiness are like fire. The moon cannot overcome fire. Only by yielding without intent, attaining perfect compliance, is the Dao fully realized.

Kou Yi’s commentary:
In the time of Jie and Zhou, the worthy and the unworthy alike suffered calamity—nothing could be predetermined.

Chang Hong was exiled and returned to Shu, where he disemboweled himself and died; the people of Shu stored his blood in a casket, and after three years, it transformed into jade. When Emperor Yuan of Jin’s grain transports failed to arrive, he executed his minister, whose blood spurted upward against the pillars. The Qi, on the pretext of the "Bright Moon Decree," killed Hulü Guang, and his blood, spilled upon the ground, could not be extinguished—all instances of this same pattern. Xiao Ji, son of Gaozong of Yin, was driven away by his stepmother; Zeng Shen fled when his father wielded a great staff while weeding—both were harmed by their filial piety. Thus, external things cannot be relied upon.

Wood, by nature, holds no fire, yet friction generates it; metal, though utterly hard, melts when exposed to flame—all attest to the unreliability of certainty. During great thunderstorms, trees may be struck and burned. Thus it is said: "Within water there is fire, which burns the great locust tree." These are all cases of yin and yang clashing in their courses, giving rise to calamity.

Xun Ben’s commentary:
When rain falls and thunder roars, it is "water containing fire." Thunderfire can also burn wood, yet only the locust tree is mentioned here because it is the wood used to kindle fire. What follows speaks of the fire within the human heart—how people, beset by deep sorrow, become trapped between two perils, as previously described. Though wood grinds against wood and metal abides with fire, they ultimately cannot escape, for the heart cannot transcend considerations of gain and loss. Like insects stirring in hibernation before fully awakening, affairs fail to come to fruition. When matters do not succeed, the heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth, stifled, repressed, restless, and sunk in stagnation—afflicted by these manifold ills. As gain and harm grind against one another, the fire within the heart blazes ever more fiercely, ceaselessly, like the fire within water, flaring for a time. The masses are all consumed by this, their innate harmony scorched. The moon, by nature yin, is likewise transformed into fire, unable to withstand its proliferation. The subtlety of Heaven’s principle cannot contend with the blazing flames of human desire, and thus the Dao is lost in perfect compliance.

Hong Mai’s commentary:
The annotation states: "Great yet benighted, one is burdened by many entanglements; small yet enlightened, one knows one’s place." Zizhan’s citation instead reads: "Guo Xiang believed that being great yet benighted is inferior to being small yet enlightened—how vulgar!" This saying should be revised to: "The moon cannot overcome the candle." That which is bright in great matters must be dim in small ones. The moon can illuminate heaven and earth yet cannot light the tip of a hair—this is why it cannot overcome fire. Yet in the end, does fire overcome the moon, or does the moon overcome fire? I recall Zhu Yuanzheng’s *Pingzhou Ketan*, which records that Wang Jiefu, while in the Classics Bureau as a reviser, encountered the phrase "holding up a candle" in Buddhist scriptures, where it speaks of the "Brightness of the Sun, Moon, and Lamp Buddha." He asked, "How can lamplight compare to the sun and moon?" Lü Jifu replied: "The sun blazes by day, the moon blazes by night—does the lamp blaze as well?"

The sun and moon, though vast in their reach, serve without distinction where their light does not extend. Jiefu greatly approved of this. In my humble opinion, the essence of *Zhuangzi* lies in likening the human heart to the moon—serene, empty, and still—yet when assailed by profit and harm, a fire blazes forth to consume its harmony, and thus the moon cannot overcome it. This is not a matter of brightness or dimness.

*Supplementary Ink*:
Among the qi of the Five Phases, fire is the most fierce. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Wood and fire are companions; fire, though yin in root, is yang in abode, dwelling in wood. When stirred, it arises—yet in doing so, it injures its mother." Thus, when wood grates against wood, it ignites. The *Yinfu Jing* says: "Fire is born of wood, yet when calamity erupts, it must conquer"—this is the principle. Even metal, though utterly hard, when held with fire, is melted by it. If yin and yang become entangled and pent-up without release, then thunder strikes, lightning surges, and fire rises from water to burn the great locust tree. The locust is the wood of the East, which in its old age gives birth to fire. In the human body, this is what is called the "fire of the Five Emotions," which cannot be directly suppressed.

Therefore, those who embody the Dao are empty, still, tranquil, and desireless, practicing non-action—thus the fire of the Five Emotions is all at once subdued. Profit and harm do not disturb their hearts, and life and death bring no change to their selves. The common people are not so: unaware that external things cannot be relied upon, they clash and grind against one another in the vortex of profit and harm. Thereby, the fire within grows ever greater, and the harmony of heaven is consumed.

The moon, after all, cannot overcome fire. The moon is water, and water cannot overcome fire—this aligns with the medical notion that "one water cannot overcome five fires."

Zhuang Zhou was poor, so he went to borrow grain from the Marquis of the River. The Marquis said, "Very well. I will soon receive the taxes from my fief and will lend you three hundred gold pieces—will that suffice?" Zhuang Zhou flushed with anger and replied, "On my way here yesterday, I heard a cry from the middle of the road. I looked and saw a crucian carp in the rut of a wagon wheel."

Zhuang Zhou asked it, saying, "Crucian carp, where have you come from?"
It replied, "I am a minister of the waves from the Eastern Sea. Might you have a dou or sheng of water to keep me alive?"
Zhuang Zhou said, "Very well. I am about to journey south to persuade the kings of Wu and Yue to channel the waters of the Western River to welcome you—would that suffice?"
The crucian carp flushed with anger and replied, "I have lost my accustomed element and have nowhere to abide. A dou or sheng of water would suffice to keep me alive for now. Yet you speak of this—you might as well have sought me earlier in the dried-fish market."

*(The *Shuo Yuan* records the Marquis of the River as the Marquis of Wei, and "gold from the fief" as taxes from the domain. *Guang Ya* glosses "crucian" as *ji*. "Minister of the waves" is akin to a water official. "Accustomed element" refers to water. "For now" implies "if that were so, I could live." "Dried-fish market" refers to dried fish. The "kings of Wu and Yue" may be a scribal error for "local lord.")*

Guo Xiang’s commentary: *"To speak of what accords with principle, no matter how small—if it is not fitting, even greatness is of no benefit."*
Lü Huiqing’s commentary: *"Zhuangzi’s borrowing of grain makes clear that those who nourish life seek only to sustain the body and do not pursue excess."*

Ren Gongzi fashioned a great hook with a thick black line and fifty steers as bait. He crouched upon Mount Gui, cast his rod into the Eastern Sea, and fished day after day for a year without catching anything. Then, a great fish took the bait, dragging the massive hook down as it plunged, thrashing its fins and raising waves like mountains. The sea churned, the sound like thunder, and the spectacle terrified all within a thousand *li*. Ren Gongzi landed the fish, sliced it into strips, and dried it. From the Zhe River eastward to north of Mount Cangwu, none did not feast upon it. Thereafter, those of mediocre talent—peddlers of shallow rhetoric—all marveled and spread the tale.

Yet those who brandish their rods and chase minnows in ditches, guarding only the tiniest of catches, find it difficult to land a great fish. Those who adorn petty words to seek high office are far from true attainment. Thus, one who has never heard of Ren Gongzi’s manner of conduct is far indeed from being able to navigate the world.

The great black fishing line is vast indeed; mediocre talents assess others’ abilities. "Recited sayings" refer to well-rehearsed discourses. A "fine line" is a slender fishing cord. "County commands" resemble reward proclamations, seeking compliance with their stipulated standards.

Guo’s annotation: *As aspirations differ, so too do the proper scales for navigating the world—each suited to its own measure.*
Lü’s annotation: *Ren’s fishing illustrates how those who steer the world set their minds on great accomplishments, never seeking immediate results.*

Dubi’s note: *The castrated ox—when the great fish devours it, its might shakes a thousand* li*, showing that those with far-reaching minds may achieve late, yet their impact startles the world, and all share in their blessing. Later generations marvel and spread the word, for those who realize their ambitions across the world leave names for posterity—such were Yi Yin and the Grand Duke.*

Xuxi’s note: *Both passages invert external things to emphasize: the first speaks of the scholar’s fate, sometimes confined to the smallest measure; the second speaks of the scholar’s aspiration, which must await boundless opportunity—both are valid. Circumstances arise by chance, not to be judged by scale. When minnows are the catch, a pint or peck is great, and Ren Gongzi’s methods seem trivial.*

The Confucians built their households on poetry and ritual; the great Confucians proclaimed: "The east is stirring!"—what of affairs? The lesser Confucian replied: "I’ve yet to untie my skirt and jacket, but a pearl lies in my mouth." Poetry indeed contains this: *"The green-green wheat grows on the hillside slope; / Alive, you give nothing; dead, why clench a pearl?"* They seized his temples, pressed his whiskers, and with a metal mallet pried his jaw, carefully parting his cheeks to spare the pearl within.

Guo’s annotation: *Poetry and ritual are the traces left by former kings. If the person is unworthy, the Way cannot operate in vain—thus Confucians who misuse them for deceit prove that such traces cannot be relied upon.*
Lü’s annotation: *Petty Confucians wield the words of former kings to serve their own injustice—how do they differ from this?*

When Lao Laizi’s disciple went out to gather firewood and encountered Confucius, he returned and reported: "There is a man over there with a tall forehead and a hunched back, his ears set far back. His gaze seems to survey the Four Seas—I know not whose son he is." Lao Laizi said: "That is Qiu. Summon him." When Confucius arrived, Lao Laizi said: "Qiu, shed your bodily pride and your cultivated demeanor—only then can you be called a gentleman." Confucius bowed and withdrew, his expression troubled. He asked: "May I advance in my work?" Lao Laizi replied: *"One who cannot bear the wounds of a single generation yet courts calamity for ten thousand ages—is this not obstinate poverty, or perhaps a lack of broader vision? Kindness that feigns joy to mask obstinacy becomes a lifelong disgrace. The conduct of the common people advances thus: ears drawn by fame, bound by shared afflictions, praising Yao while condemning Jie—yet it is better to suspend judgment and close off such praise, for to act without error is impossible. The sage proceeds with deliberation to initiate affairs, ensuring success in every endeavor—how could it be otherwise? Your carriage is laden, yet you remain proud to the end."*

*Lao Laizi was a man of Chu. "Hunched back" may refer to the head or the back. "Afflictions" denotes troubles. "Deliberation" means unhurried composure.*

Though one proceeds with deliberation to initiate affairs and achieves success, still their traces bring harm for a hundred generations—how much worse when one acts with pride in good conduct and ceaselessly bears its burden?

**Guo’s Annotation:**
This describes superiors hastening subordinates. Yet when one steps back, stoops forward, and peers upward like a marionette, appearing as though managing another’s affairs—this is to say, Confucius could relinquish form and abandon knowledge, thus being deemed a noble person. He bowed and withdrew, receiving instruction.

When he asked, *"Might my work be advanced?"* it was a hypothetical question to prompt Lao Laizi to clarify its impossibility. If one acts for a single generation, the traces become a calamity for ten thousand ages—thus it cannot be taken lightly.

*"Is this not obstinate poverty, or perhaps a lack of broader vision?"* This means that if one simply follows the people’s nature, they will not be impoverished in virtue but will naturally possess vision, with nothing beyond their reach.

*"Kindness that feigns joy"*—without kindness, one incurs disgrace. Yet kindness cannot be prolonged, so a single act of kindness becomes a lifelong disgrace.

*"The conduct of the common people advances thus"*—this means they are easily swayed, so one must not rashly bestow kindness upon them. *"Bound by shared afflictions"* refers to their mutual advancement.

*"Close off"* means to block. *"To act without error"*—following the Way preserves wholeness; stillness ensures correctness.

Affairs do not stray from their root, so success is achieved in every endeavor. Pride cannot be borne, so one abandons it and does not claim possession.

The Lü commentary states: Those who study Confucius in this world cling to his outward traces but fail to grasp his inner heart—hence Zhuangzi’s critique. From the self-cultivating superior man to the inferior who seeks the sage by appearance, all are those who, in their personal conduct, take pride in their own actions. Yet to display knowledge in one’s demeanor is not the abundant virtue of one who feigns foolishness.

Great disorder arose between Yao and Shun. If one cannot bear the harm of a single generation and thus acts to save it, this is to court calamity for ten thousand generations. Is the enterprise of abundance inherently impoverished? Or does it lack the strategy to reach its goal? Neither is the case.

Kindness is not great wisdom, yet to pursue it with joyful zeal courts lifelong disgrace—even this, one should refrain from doing. But when people mutually draw one another by reputation, bind themselves by cliques, and advance together, this is the conduct of the common people. How could a noble person who embodies the Dao be like this?

It is because they cannot utterly abandon sagely knowledge and the dual pursuit of good and evil—both of which court calamity for ten thousand generations. The Dao is non-action, yet to turn away from it is to harm the Dao; to act without non-action is to stray into error. Where is there anything worthy of esteem or praise?

To be as cautious as one crossing a river in winter, as wary as one fearing one’s four neighbors—this is what is meant by hesitation. How can one claim possession of it, believing that without pride it cannot be attained?

Following the root—cultivating the highest brings growth to the body, while hastening to the lowest makes it narrow. This is what is meant by "the waist and below fall short of Yu by three inches." The ends are guarded; the back is slightly hunched. From behind, the ears are visible, but when facing forward, they cannot be seen. To be self-important is to hold oneself with restraint, adorning one’s outward appearance to seek recognition—this is reckless abandon, heedless of consequences. To recklessly court calamity for ten thousand generations is to believe oneself right without regard for the disaster left to posterity.

Or rather, is it that you are truly impoverished and thus act thus? Have you lost your wisdom and foresight, failing to consider this? *Hui* (compliance) is to follow others’ wishes to foster affection, unaware that it courts calamity for ten thousand generations. Thus it is said: "Compliance makes delight its recklessness." Though you take this as recklessness, it remains a lifelong disgrace, no more than the conduct of ordinary people advancing together. They lead one another by reputation, bind themselves by obscurity—this is *hunbi* (obscuration). Confucius often praised Yao and blamed Jie, yet his teaching was: "Rather than praise Yao and blame Jie, it is better to forget both praise and blame." To turn against this principle is nothing but harm; to act without non-action is nothing but error.

The sage acts with hesitation, as if compelled by necessity, and thus always succeeds. How can one claim to possess it, believing that without pride it cannot be attained? Beware lest one persist in such conduct.

**Supplementary Note:**
Is it that your fate is truly meant to be impoverished? Or have you lost your foresight, failing to consider this? The Master’s actions suffice to bring hardship, yet he accepts it without change—is this his destined lot, or does his wisdom fall short of considering this?

---

In the middle of the night, the Lord of Song dreamed of a man with disheveled hair peering through the side gate, who said: "I come from the Zailu Abyss. I was sent by the Clear River as an emissary to the River Lord, but I was caught by the fisherman Yu Qiu." The Lord awoke and had the dream interpreted. The diviner said: "This is the spirit *gui*."

The Lord asked: "Is there a fisherman named Yu Qiu?" His attendants replied: "There is." The Lord said: "Summon Yu Qiu to court tomorrow." The next day, Yu Qiu appeared before the Lord. The Lord asked: "What did you catch?" Yu Qiu replied: "I caught a white *gui* in my net, five feet in circumference." The Lord said: "Present your *gui*." When the *gui* arrived, the Lord wavered between killing it and sparing it. His mind unsettled, he divined: "Killing the *gui* will bring good fortune." He then carved the *gui* seventy-two times, leaving no crack unprobed.

Confucius said: "The spirit *gui* could appear in the Lord’s dream but could not evade Yu Qiu’s net. It knew how to survive seventy-two probings without a single crack but could not escape the disaster of having its entrails carved out. Thus, knowledge has its limitations, and even spirits have their inadequacies. Though one possesses the greatest wisdom and ten thousand men conspire, fish do not fear nets but fear pelicans. Abandon petty knowledge, and great knowledge becomes clear; forsake goodness, and one becomes good of itself."

A newborn babe, without a teacher of stone, can speak—this is because it dwells among those who can speak.

Guo's commentary: "The insufficiency of spiritual knowledge is thus. Only one who abides in stillness, dwelling in what they can do without scheming outwardly, remains whole. Not employing one’s own knowledge but using the schemes of the multitude is like a net without intent—thus it catches fish. Petty knowledge is self-serving; great knowledge accords with things. Forsake goodness, and goodness arises without contrivance—like the newborn babe, who speaks without a teacher of stone, dwelling among those who can speak, not straining to learn from them."

Lü's commentary: "The *gui* possessed knowledge yet could not avoid calamity; it had spirit yet could not evade the net. This is what it means to have limitations and inadequacies. Those who follow the Dao thus abandon sagacity and discard knowledge. Though one possesses the greatest wisdom and ten thousand men conspire, the few cannot overcome the many—this is the nature of things. Fish do not fear nets but fear pelicans; pelicans have knowledge, nets do not. Thus, abandon petty knowledge, and great knowledge becomes clear; forsake goodness, and one becomes good of itself. How then should a ruler govern? The newborn babe, without a teacher of stone, can speak—if one relies on knowledge to dwell among the people, how can one make them unaware? "

Xun's text: "Though one possesses the greatest wisdom, it is not equal to consulting the multitude. Fish do not fear nets but fear pelicans—this is the fish’s ignorance. For the fish know that pelicans can harm them, yet nets emerge from what they do not perceive. How much less do they know that the harm of pelicans is small, while the harm of nets is great! One who can abandon petty knowledge and let great knowledge become clear, who does not flaunt their goodness yet becomes good of itself—like the newborn babe, who has no teacher of stone to instruct them yet can speak of itself, dwelling among those who can speak. Though one possesses knowledge, one should still consult the multitude."

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi: "Your words are useless."
Zhuangzi replied: "Only when one knows the useless can one speak of the useful. The earth is not narrow or small, yet what man uses of it is only enough to stand upon. If one were to dig beneath their feet to the Yellow Springs, would there still be use?"
Hui Shi said: "It would be useless."
Zhuangzi said: "Then the usefulness of the useless is also clear."

Guo's commentary: "The sage responds from within, acting when the occasion arises, expressing outwardly to unfold the circumstances. When circumstances unfold, affairs are resolved; when the outer is clear, the inner is employed—this is the principle of mutual necessity."

Lü's commentary: "The world deems those with knowledge and ability as useful, and those without as useless, yet does not know that the useless is the source of the useful. From the perspective of the Dao, what the world calls knowledge and ability—how small is its use, no more than the space a foot occupies upon the earth!"

Zhuangzi said: "Is there one who can roam yet does not roam? Is there one who cannot roam yet roams? The aspirations of those who flee and the conduct of those who sever ties—alas, are these not the burden of the utmost knowledge and profound virtue? Falling and not turning back, rushing like fire and not looking back—though they may for a time be ruler and minister to each other, with the change of generations, they will have no means to hold each other in contempt. Thus it is said: The perfected person does not linger in their conduct. Those who honor the past and belittle the present are the way of scholars. Yet observing the present age through the lens of the Xi Wei clan—who can remain undisturbed by its waves? Only the perfected person can roam in the world without bias, follow others without losing themselves. They teach without instruction, respond to others’ intentions without opposition."

Guo's commentary: "What one’s nature can do, one cannot but do; what one’s nature cannot do, one cannot force. The sage, without constraint, is thus the same as all things—all attain without knowing how they attain. If one’s virtue is not profoundly thick, one cannot bear their aspirations and trust their unique abilities. Falling and rushing like fire—this speaks of what people desire, not shunning right or wrong, life or death, in pursuit of it. With the change of generations, they have no means to hold each other in contempt—this is how they are equal as people. The perfected person does not linger in their conduct, following whatever they encounter, thus moving in accord with transformation. The past is not inherently honored, the present not inherently belittled, yet scholars honor the past and belittle the present, losing their source. Following the times and adapting to things—this is leveling and blending. The perfected person responds to affairs as they arise, taking what is at hand as the norm. Thus it is said: they roam in the world without bias, for they have no self—what self is there to lose? Thus it is said: they follow others without losing themselves. Teaching arises from their nature, not from learning. Thus it is said: they teach without instruction. They respond to others’ intentions naturally, so the myriad things each attain their self. Thus it is said: they respond to intentions without opposition."

Lü's commentary: "Liezi said: The utmost roaming is not knowing where one goes; the utmost observation is not knowing what one sees—all things roam, all things observe. This is what I call roaming, what I call observing. Zhuangzi’s roaming is like this. The one who has attained the Dao finds nothing that is not the Dao—thus all things roam, all things observe. Though they may wish not to roam, they cannot but do so. One who has not attained the Dao, though they may wish to roam, cannot do so. The aspirations of those who flee follow custom to be humble; the conduct of those who sever ties departs from the world to be lofty—neither is the burden of the utmost knowledge and profound virtue. Blinded by one corner, they fall and do not turn back, rush like fire and do not look back. Though they may for a time be ruler and minister to each other, with the change of generations, they will have no means to hold each other in contempt—their deviation from the Dao is the same. One with utmost knowledge and profound virtue is neither humble in fleeing nor lofty in severing ties, following only the Dao. Thus the perfected person does not linger in their conduct, leaving no traces.
