If one honors the past and belittles the present, observing the present age through the lens of the Xi Wei clan, their heart will be shallow—who can remain level and undisturbed by its waves? Only the perfected person can roam in the world without bias, follow others without losing themselves, teaching in accord with others, not through learning. Understanding their intentions and responding to them—how can there be opposition? This is the perfected person’s roaming."

Jingchuan: "No relationship is stricter than that of ruler and minister; with the change of generations, it alters—how much more so for other principles! This is merely used to illustrate that the perfected person does not linger in their conduct. Not lingering in conduct is like the Buddhist who does not stay three nights under the same mulberry tree—this is the idea."

Fumo: "‘They teach without instruction, respond to intentions without opposition’—what the world calls teaching, though they do not deign to learn it, they still respond to its intentions without opposing it. What is opposed is external words; not opposing means not externalizing them. Why? Worldly and transcendent dharmas are not two things. If one selects and rejects, then one is not roaming in the world without bias or following others without losing oneself. From this perspective, what Zhuangzi calls roaming is certainly not the learning of those who cut themselves off from things and flee the world. There is a way of following and not losing oneself—this is the utmost knowledge and profound virtue."

Fang Sishan: "Those who can roam drown without ceasing; those who cannot roam depart without returning. This ‘roaming’ is roaming in the world, not carefree wandering. Thus, one becomes either dissolute or utterly severed—falling and never returning is the flaw of severance, racing like fire without regard is the flaw of dissolution. When two men become ruler and minister, each values himself and devalues the other. Judged across eras, both are equally unfit for the task of utmost knowledge and profound virtue. Therefore, the perfected person roams skillfully, neither altering with the world nor losing himself, without distinction between past and present, self and other. Why? The past is not necessarily worthy of reverence, nor the present necessarily base. Viewing emperors from the vantage of sovereigns, emperors become base; viewing kings from the vantage of emperors, kings become base in turn. Past and present rise and fall in succession—who can avoid being swept along? This is why the perfected person roams in the world without bias."

Eyes penetrating are clarity; ears penetrating are acuity; nose penetrating is keen scent; mouth penetrating is savor; mind penetrating is knowledge; knowledge penetrating is virtue. The Dao does not desire obstruction—obstruction causes choking, and choking without end leads to stumbling, which gives rise to manifold harms. That sentient beings rely on breath is not Heaven’s fault. Heaven bores through them day and night without cease; it is humans who block their apertures. The womb has layered chambers, the mind has celestial roaming. If a room lacks emptiness, mother and daughter-in-law quarrel; if the mind lacks celestial roaming, the six senses contend. The great forests and towering mountains are good for people—yet the numinous is not as potent as virtue overflowing, fame overflowing.

Fierce scheming arises from cunning; contention emerges from knowledge; firewood is born of guarding office and attending to affairs. When the rains of the multitude’s proper spring arrive in season, grasses and trees burst forth in vigorous growth—hoeing and weeding begin then. Yet more than half of those who tend to the planting of grasses and trees do not understand why this is so.

When passage should be open but is blocked, principles cannot flow freely and trample one another. "Life arises"—all roots that sprout do so without awareness, and this too is called "relying on breath." "Proper" means fitting; breath does not depend on knowledge, for it is through knowledge that one loses fittingness. Losing fittingness leads to obstruction, and obstruction arises from knowledge relying on breath—breath does not rely on knowledge. Yet the use of knowledge and desire is governed by humans, not by an inescapable mandate.

"Heaven bores through without cease"—the circulation of principle has its constant movement. "Humans block their apertures"—without sincerity, they fail to follow Heaven, and their apertures remain closed. "Layered chambers" means spaciousness; "celestial roaming" means wandering without attachment.

Conflict arises where contention dwells; "usurpation" means rebellion. The finest of great forests and mountains follow the natural principle, which finds its expression through things to achieve free flow. Virtue overflows—when reputation is lofty, profit runs deep, so those who cultivate virtue exceed what is fitting. Fame overflows—when one restrains violence, one’s reputation surpasses their virtue.

"Hasty" means urgency; "deliberation" follows haste—only after urgency does one examine their plans. "Wisdom emerges"—when contention is resolved through equanimity, wisdom becomes unnecessary. "Obstruction" means blockage; "official duties" are fulfilled—since what the multitude deems fitting varies, official duties are established. When plants and trees grow, and hoes and sickles are prepared, the arising of all affairs has its cause. "Arriving at growth without awareness"—affairs arise from principle, so one remains unaware of their unfolding.

---

Lü’s Commentary:
When a person’s ears, eyes, nose, and mouth are not obstructed by sounds, sights, scents, and flavors, they become keen of hearing, clear of sight, discerning of taste, and wise in virtue. When virtue is obstructed, it chokes and fails to flow; when obstruction grows severe, things trample one another. Gain and loss wage war in the breast—how long before they lead to ruin? This is the affliction of yin and yang, the source from which all harm arises.

All sentient beings live when breath abides and die when breath departs. The ebb and flow of breath follow the cycles of midnight and noon, moving left and right in accord with yin and yang, ever in communion with primordial qi. Thus, Heaven bores through without cease, its circulation even and unchanging, never waning. Yet humans, by allowing sounds, sights, scents, and flavors to block their apertures, prevent this flow—hence their decline rather than flourishing.

If one can embody tranquility, emptiness, and non-attachment, true qi will follow, the body will align, and harmony with Heaven will arrive. Thus, the womb holds layered chambers, and filth cannot invade; the mind roams freely, and affairs cannot disturb. The room must have emptiness to differ from the mundane. Without proper hierarchy, mother and daughter-in-law will clash in conflict.

The mind must have celestial roaming to rise above the dust—otherwise, the six apertures will trample and rebel against one another. The six apertures are the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, and the mind’s knowing. If one truly understands what is meant by "celestial roaming," though they wander in the human world, the myriad things will not disturb their heart, and their spirit will be sufficient to overcome all. Why seek refuge in great forests and mountains?

Supreme virtue does not claim virtue, so it has no name. When there is a name, virtue overflows; when one acts violently yet conceals nothing, fame overflows. Thus, plans cannot but be examined in haste, and wisdom cannot but emerge from contention.

Those who contend over firewood cannot but give rise to strife—is it by guarding this that one attains fulfillment? The many preferences for sounds, colors, scents, and flavors barricade the outer self, while thoughts, worries, knowledge, and schemes barricade the inner, yet they fail to communicate with one another.

For those who practice the Dao, governing the heart means tending to it before disorder arises—no different from how grasses and trees flourish in their natural vigor before the hoe and sickle begin their work.

】Following the root:【
Choking and gasping, trampling and treading—those whose feet are unsteady in walking are as if trodden upon by others. The three yin meridians of the foot all originate in the toes and ascend along the throat; when perverse qi travels through the channels and collaterals, choking becomes unceasing, and foot ailments arise. Once foot ailments manifest, a host of harms follow—not merely choking or trampling. This illustrates how the Dao must not be obstructed; obstruction breeds such afflictions.

Abundance and flourishing—it is also said that sentient beings rely on the free flow of breath to sustain this body. When breath fails to prevail, it is not heaven’s doing; heaven endows humans with perforated orifices through which qi circulates day and night without cease. It is people who block their own apertures.

Descending—within the human body, breath always ascends from below; if it descends without rising, death follows. This analogy of breath serves to illustrate the heart.

*Làng* (阆) sounds like *xiàn* (限): layered thresholds, layered doorways. The womb’s emptiness, its passageways, resemble a chamber’s layered thresholds. Just as the womb has layered thresholds, the heart has celestial roaming. If a chamber lacks emptiness, mother and daughter-in-law will be cramped before one’s eyes. For when a chamber has space, mother and daughter-in-law may dwell in ease; when the heart lacks celestial roaming, the six apertures will vie and seize. But if the heart possesses its natural, unfettered roaming, emotions and desires will not contend. It is like those who admire great forests and mountains—only because their daily minds are narrow and their spirits insufficient to overcome them. If one’s spirit were sufficient to prevail, why would they admire them?

Virtue resides within, yet overflows due to fame; fame, though inherently unmanifest, overflows through ostentatious display. *Overflow* is like water spilling beyond its bounds. Schemes, in their essence, involve no deep calculation, yet the desire to entice others causes them to linger and deepen.

*Chái* (柴) refers to the meaning of "palisade" in the *Heaven and Earth* chapter: the places where officials station and guard, erecting palisades for defense. Palisades are not originally established; they arise from what officials must guard. Matters, in their essence, lack fixity—yet when they align with what the multitude deems fitting, decisions are made and actions taken, all losing their spontaneity. It is like the season of spring rains, when grasses and trees naturally flourish in exuberance; to then wield the hoe and sickle is to harm their growth and violate their nature.

*Dào* (倒) means *to reverse*.

】 *Limited Insight* 【

The ears, eyes, nose, mouth, and heart—capable of unimpeded communication—all arise from thorough knowing as virtue’s accomplishment. If virtue does not thread through them, these five become obstructed, causing much harm. All living things possess breath to circulate the qi of the entire body and harmonize with the concord of Heaven and Earth. To act in ways that obstruct or block this is to depart from the Dao of the primordial qi’s free flow. Primordial qi permeates all things without cease; where decline and decay occur, it is only that humans, through the six senses, reverse and block its apertures.

Animals rely on breath, plants on roots—each depends on what sustains its life. Great forests and towering mountains appear excellent to humans because, accustomed to narrow and cramped views, they suddenly behold vast, open, and luminous expanses, and their hearts necessarily delight in them. Yet this is the spirit failing to overcome things, instead being overcome by them. Mountains, forests, and riverbanks may bring me joy, but before it is complete, sorrow follows. Thus, do things truly benefit humans? Does delight in things truly bring joy? Only because external admiration creates internal deficiency: valuing one thing means slighting another.

Reputation is a public vessel and cannot be taken in excess. Thus, the emergence of reputation marks the loss of virtue. To admire reputation is to lose it again. When both are lost, one hastily devises schemes, and knowing arises in contention—this is the proof of the multitude of harms. Even those who can maintain integrity suffer from rigid obstruction, unable to adapt. As for the earlier saying that grasses and trees, though uprooted, revive with rain—this is their nature, yet people remain unaware.

Human life depends on breath; if it is made to descend without vigor, how could there be no way to support, protect, and replenish it? The key lies only in knowing the right time.

】 *Ink Traces* 【

When the eyes are obscured by forms, they do not see clearly; when the ears are confused by sounds, they do not hear keenly; when the nose is seized by scents, it does not discern; when the mouth is sated with flavors, it does not savor; when the heart is stirred by perception, it does not know. Knowing that involves discrimination is not the knowing of virtue. These six senses and their six dusts must be thoroughly purified to restore their original, inherent numinous awareness. Yet at the gates of the six senses, each is an obstruction. Though one may apply the word "thorough" in a few places, in truth, to understand one is to understand all; where one is thorough, all are thorough.

Thus the Dao does not desire obstruction. If not thorough, one is naturally obstructed by external things. Like a person choking: if the obstruction persists, distress follows, and from distress arise the multitude of harms. The tracks of distress are like feet sinking into mud. When the human spirit’s emptiness is obstructed by things, it becomes mired in desire, unable to extricate itself. Those who preserve it are few indeed.

All living things depend on this principle of generation and breath. Now, those who preserve it are few, so their generation and breath become faint and weak, not flourishing. This lack of flourishing is not Heaven’s fault. Heaven’s piercing of them continues day and night without cease; it is humans who block their own apertures. For this luminous essence constantly shines forth: with ears, one naturally hears; with eyes, one naturally sees—this is what Heaven pierces day and night without pause. It is like a room with apertures: sunlight naturally pierces through, yet humans block their own apertures, causing light to seem diminished or obscured, unseen.

】 *Reflections on Goodness* 【

Humans rely on breath to live, and breath relies on emptiness to reign. Emptiness is where the Dao gathers. Thus, when empty, the six senses serve me; when not empty, the six senses become my thieves. When they serve, the spirit is stored; when they thieve, the spirit is lost. Those who lose within inevitably seek fulfillment without. Thus virtue overflows into reputation, reputation overflows into display, schemes arise from restlessness, knowing arises from contention, palisades arise from defense, and official matters arise from the multitude’s approval. All these occur when things overcome the spirit and thieves assail emptiness.

"Spring rains in their season" refers to timely rain and sunshine. For things that rely on breath, when the time comes, they grow. Hoes and sickles cannot suppress them—why? Because Heaven’s compliance is at work. When Heaven complies, what is reversed can be planted; compared to wandering with Heaven, what is pierced suffers no obstruction. Thus, those who skillfully nurture things guard their roots; those who skillfully nurture life guard their breath. This is why the perfected value wandering with Heaven.

Stillness can mend illness, plucking can rest old age, tranquility can halt haste. Though such are the tasks of the toiling, they are not what the at-ease ever inquire about. What startles the world is what the sage never inquires about; what startles the age is what the spirit-person never inquires about; what startles the state is what the worthy never inquires about; what aligns with the times is what the petty person never inquires about.

】 *Guo’s Commentary* 【

Mending illness does not mean being free from illness; resting old age does not mean being free from aging; halting haste does not mean being free from haste. Such are still matters of toil, so the at-ease transcend and disregard them. The spirit-person is the sage: "sage" speaks of the external, "spirit" of the internal. Their courses and renunciations each have their place; their heights and depths each have their rank, so they do not inquire of one another.

】 *Lü’s Commentary* 【

"Stillness can mend illness" to "tranquility can halt haste"—these are ancient arts of the Dao. Though such exist, movement precedes stillness, complexity precedes plucking, blazing precedes extinction, disturbance precedes tranquility. These are spoken for the toiling to ease their labor. The at-ease have never moved—why would they need stillness? They have never been complex—why would they need plucking? They have never blazed—why would they need extinction? They have never been disturbed—why would they need tranquility? Thus they do not inquire.

Only those with virtue attain ease; the at-ease encompass the spirit and the sage. The spirit-person and the sage differ in their traces; the worthy and the gentleman differ in their talents; the gentleman and the petty person differ in their adherence to righteousness or profit.

**】Brush Notes【**

The old explanation of *zì* (眦) holds it to be an eye ailment. Xu Xi said: "Stillness is no medicine." Yet it may remedy the eye that sees nothing—though afflicted, it can rest and age without knowing *zì*. This is indeed a technique of the life-nurturing school.

According to the *Zhen’gao*: "At times, press the four corners of the eyes with the hands until the light appears clearly—this is the way to examine the spirit of the eyes. Prolonged practice reveals the signs of a hundred spirits and the omens of aged forms emerging at the eye corners. Parting the *zì* and smoothing wrinkles can bathe the countenance of age."

**Extended【Practice】**

At the Yan Gate, when a parent died, one was ennobled as an official teacher for grieving to the point of emaciation. Half of his fellow townsmen grieved themselves to death. Yao offered the world to Xu You, but Xu You fled from it. Tang offered it to Wu Guang, and Wu Guang raged against him. Ji Tuo, hearing of this, led his disciples to crouch by the Kuǎn River. The feudal lords mourned him for three years, whereupon Shentu Di threw himself into the river.

【Yan Gate was the name of a city gate in Song; *bó* means to collapse, to fall prostrate.】

Guo’s commentary: "To revere reward and filial piety is to stray far from the true. This is the excess of esteeming worthiness—its waves unsettle the nature, leading even to drowning in the river."

Lü’s commentary: "The official teacher’s encouragement led his townsmen to grieve themselves to death; Xu You’s flight led his followers to drown in the river. Such are the harms of following traces."

The *quan* is used to catch fish—once the fish is caught, the *quan* is discarded. The snare is used to catch hares—once the hare is caught, the snare is discarded. Words are used to convey meaning—once the meaning is grasped, the words are discarded. How might I find one who has discarded words, that I may speak with them?

【The *quan* is an aromatic herb used to bait fish—alternatively, it refers to a fish trap. The snare is a device for trapping hares by their feet, hence called a "hoof-trap."】

Guo’s commentary: "When it comes to the two sages, they had no intent, and thus nothing to say at all."

Lü’s commentary: "Zhuangzi feared that later generations, grasping his words, would lose sight of what lay behind them. Thus he concluded with the analogy of the *quan* and the snare, urging scholars to forget words and delve into their meaning."

General Observations in My Humble View:
This chapter begins by weighing the relative importance of inner and outer, clarifying the closeness or distance between self and things. What lies outside is bound to external things and cannot be relied upon; what lies within arises from the self, and seeking it yields attainment. Yet most people devote themselves to external pursuits, and when they fail, resentment and blame follow. Thus, he establishes this discourse to dispel their confusion. Even loyalty and filial piety—virtues that define one’s conduct—cannot guarantee the understanding of ruler or kin, for they are external matters sought from within. How much less can one expect to attain what is external by pursuing it externally? From this, we know that within the nature and destiny of the self, there is nothing that is not the Dao. To awaken to it is to preserve one’s nature and destiny; outside of this, nothing is certain, and those who cling to externals lose themselves. Only by embracing effortless non-action and merging obscurely with the Dao can one escape the dual pitfalls of entanglement. When Zhuangzi borrowed grain and used the analogy of the drying cart tracks and stranded fish, he showed that bestowing kindness must be timely. When Master Ren cast his great hook and scorned the petty catch, he made clear that the Dao must be sought in the grand. Scholars who study poetry and ritual may begin with upright intentions, yet once swayed by material desires, they may violate prohibitions and harm moral transformation without compunction—worse than the unlearned, who at least retain some fear and abide by their allotted place. All this stems from...

The ruler who governs the people through sagely wisdom for too long will see cunning leaders among the people usurp that sagely wisdom. Again, Zhuangzi used the parable of Lao Lai and Confucius—when the world’s praise and blame ceased of themselves, this embodied the principle that “through my non-action, the people transform themselves.” The white minnow can perceive the dream but cannot escape the net, showing that the numinous does not make itself numinous; only then does one know there is a numinous beyond the numinous. This illustrates that relying on knowledge to escape calamity is not as free from trouble as forgetting knowledge altogether.

Next, he shows that only when one knows the uselessness of knowledge can one begin to speak of its use, with these ideas mutually illuminating each other. He further states that one who can roam does so by roaming the mind in tranquility—this roaming is internal. The preceding passages are all parables; here, he invokes Zhuangzi directly to clarify the chapter’s fundamental intent: to guide scholars beyond the entanglements of external things and into the realm of emptiness and penetration, where the spirit fuses and the mind is at ease, unbound in any direction—then the Dao is near.

Yet as worldly habits grow baser, people often roam where they should not, rushing headlong into ruin without a thought. Even if a sage were to reappear, what could be done? Some take pleasure in roaming, yet they merely treat rivers and seas as leisure, mountains and forests as refinement, and drift through life in dissipation. Such roaming in the world, though eccentric, remains mired in external pursuits.

Thus, he teaches that when the body is noble and the six senses are unobstructed, the Dao does not become stagnant. When knowledge rests and ceases, one should value the empty chamber, where the uncarved simplicity of the void gives rise to a roaming unbound by place—where the toiling strive for ease, the restless do not inquire, just as the noble person and the sage differ in degree.

As for Yanmen, who gained rank through slander, and Shentu, who fled Tang yet drowned in the river—all arose from the ruler’s esteem for lofty and exceptional conduct, which led subordinates to establish names for purity and cultivation. Though intended to encourage the world and promote teaching, they unwittingly harmed life and corrupted customs.

Thus, these examples serve as a mirror for later generations. To judge words by conduct is also to be bound by externals. Yet without pointing, one cannot see the moon; therefore, the noble person does not shrink from earnest instruction, while the learner must skillfully seek its essence.

*Zhuangzi Yi*, Scroll Six

From the *Zi* section, Daoist category, *Zhuangzi Yi*
*Collected in the Imperial Four Treasuries*
*Zhuangzi Yi*, Scroll Seven
By Jiao Hong of the Ming Dynasty

**Chapter Twenty-Seven: "Parables"**

"Parables" make up nineteen-tenths,
"Weighty Words" seventeen-tenths,
and "Goblet Words" emerge daily, harmonizing with the Heavenly Equilibrium.

"Parables" (nineteen-tenths):
Borrowing the words of outsiders to discuss—
a father does not act as his own son’s matchmaker;
a father’s praise of his son is not as credible as that of one who is not his father.
This is not my fault—it is the fault of others.
When others align with me, I respond;
when they do not align, I oppose.
What aligns with me is deemed right;
what differs from me is deemed wrong.

"Weighty Words" (seventeen-tenths):
These are the words of the aged and venerable.
Though one may be advanced in years,
without the warp and weft of beginnings and ends to mark the seasons,
the aged cannot be said to be truly ahead.
A person without means to surpass others is no person at all.
A person without the Way of humanity is called a "worn-out man."

"Goblet Words" emerge daily, harmonizing with the Heavenly Equilibrium:
They flow and extend, exhausting the years.
To not speak is to be equal;
to speak is to not be equal.
Speech and equality are not equal.
Thus it is said:
"To speak without speaking,
to speak all one’s life without having spoken;
to not speak all one’s life without having not spoken—
there is a source to this.
Yet there *can* be a source,
and yet there *cannot* be a source.
And if there is a source, how can it be so?
If it is so, then what is its *so*-ness?
If it is not so, then what is its *not-so*-ness?
What is permissible has its *permissible*-ness;
what is not permissible has its *not-permissible*-ness.
Things inherently have their *so*-ness;
things inherently have their *permissible*-ness.
No thing is not so;
no thing is not permissible."

"Goblet Words" emerge daily, harmonizing with the Heavenly Equilibrium:
Who attains their enduring essence?
All things are seeds,
each succeeding the other in different forms,
beginning and ending like a ring—
none can grasp their order.
This is called the "Heavenly Equality."
The "Heavenly Equality" is the Heavenly Equilibrium.

[The purpose of such words is to end human disputes.
*A zhī* is a round wine vessel.]

Borrowing causes—】
Guo’s commentary:【
When entrusted to others, ten words gain ninefold credence;
what the world esteems, ten words gain sevenfold credence.
A *zhī* brims and tilts, empties and rights itself—
it holds no constancy.
How much more with words?
They follow things, shift with change,
yielding only to what accords with them.
Thus it is said: "Emerging daily, emerging daily"—
meaning daily renewal.
Renewal exhausts their natural allotment;
natural allotment exhausted, harmony ensues.
Words spoken from oneself are often rejected by the vulgar,
hence the need to borrow from without.
Yan He, Lian Shu, and their like—
all are borrowed.
A father’s praise of his son is mostly disbelieved;
even when believed, it is suspected as habitual bias.
Thus, borrowing from without is necessary.
Yet even when one’s own words are trusted,
those harboring habitual doubt still refuse them.
Entrust them to others, and they are believed.
Such is the burden of human hearing.

Alike, they respond; different, they oppose,
mutually rejecting one another.
Three share sameness, two dispute their choice—
only where none dispute, all differing,
does one alone affirm right and wrong.
Why then borrow from without?
Because of their seniority.
The world collectively venerates age.
Even if their words do not borrow from without,
seven out of ten are still believed.
For the aged stand first among things—
yet in all else, root and branch,
they offer nothing to await others.
*Awaiting*—this is expectation.
Here, one merely enumerates the long-lived,
yet the vulgar readily believe them.
Such is the world’s settled habit.

Now, the natural has its allotment,
while right and wrong have no master.
Without a master, they sprawl endlessly—
who can fix them?
Thus, cast aside all attachments,
follow and entrust them to things,
so each may fulfill its Heaven-appointed years.
Consign them to things and employ their words,
then this and that, right and wrong,
naturally align as one.
If one cannot follow them in speech to unify them,
self and things remain unaligned.
Speaking what they speak,
though words exist, I ultimately do not speak.
*Free*—this is freedom.
From the bias of self and others arise approval and disapproval,
each thing naturally so.
Each naturally approves—
summed together, there is no approval, no disapproval.
No approval, no disapproval—
this is perfection.

Only words that follow things and conform to their natural allotment
avoid premature decline.
Though transformations succeed one another,
their *qi* remains one.
Now as beginning, yesterday as end—
all follows principle of itself.
Thus, none grasp their order.
This is called the "Heavenly Equality."
How could the Heavenly Equality be false?
All are the natural allotment.】

Lǚ’s Commentary:
"Of Zhuangzi’s *yuyan* parables, nineteen in ten are not parables; of his *chongyan* reiterations, seventeen in ten are not reiterations. Only the *zhiyan*—daily emerging, harmonizing with the Heavenly Boundary—is neither parable nor non-parable, neither reiteration nor non-reiteration.

What are the *yuyan* in nineteen cases? The Dao lies near in our hearts; if we discourse from our hearts, others may doubt and disbelieve—just as a father does not act as his son’s matchmaker, one must rely on external discourse. It is not that I do not wish to speak directly, but that people cannot be addressed directly.

What are the *chongyan* in seventeen cases? When others align with us, they respond and affirm; when they differ, they oppose and negate. What I speak to others aims to elicit response, not opposition. Thus, I speak to people through what their hearts already esteem, citing those they revere. All references to the ancients in the text are to those revered for their precedence—not for their age, but for their capacity to guide with structure and principle. Those who can lead others are followed; those who cannot are called ‘stale relics.’ How can the stale be esteemed?

Words that emerge have never truly been words—they are like the *zhi* vessel, poured from the wine jar yet ever empty, ever unaccumulated. The Heavenly Boundary is the ultimate of non-action, where the sage rests in harmony, letting right and wrong cease.

The Heavenly Equality means that action and stillness, speech and silence, are all the Heavenly Equality. Following its unfolding is principle itself, by which one exhausts the years. Only by being without self and without speech can one align; with speech, there is self and things—how can they align? Thus, alignment and speech, speech and alignment, have never been aligned. Without speech, though aligned, it still differs from alignment with speech—this is not yet great alignment. Only when speech is no-speech does great alignment arise: this is *zhiyan*.

Thus, one may speak a lifetime yet never have spoken; remain silent a lifetime yet never have ceased speaking. What is called ‘affirmable’ or ‘negatable,’ ‘so’ or ‘not so,’ all have their source. What is inherently so, inherently affirmable, admits no negation, no opposition—this is evident. The seeds of the ten thousand things emerge no differently; knowing their sameness, one knows their beginning and end as a circle. This is the Heavenly Equality. In this equality, right and wrong harmonize, the ten thousand things align—this is the ultimate of non-action, called the Heavenly Boundary."

Liu’s Summary:
"Water in the *zhi* vessel is like words in virtue: unfilled, they do not issue forth. What comes from without may be added but not increased; what emerges from within, though abundant, is never diminished. Thus it is said: *zhiyan* daily emerge. Things with boundaries must have a beginning; the natural boundary is a circle of beginning and end. Hence, ‘harmonizing with the Heavenly Boundary.’ Like creeping vines or flowing water, it exemplifies the thread of the natural. The Dao is whole, and things are unharmed—thus one may exhaust the years. ‘A lifetime of speech yet never having spoken; a lifetime of silence yet never having ceased speaking’—then the Six Classics are not fragmented, nor is the *Laozi* overly concise."

Zhuangzi said to Huizi:
"Confucius lived sixty years, and in sixty years, he transformed. What he once affirmed, he later negated—who knows whether what he now calls right is not what he called wrong at fifty-nine?"
Huizi replied: "Confucius was diligent in purpose, devoted to knowledge."
Zhuangzi said: "Confucius has transcended that. He never spoke of it. Confucius said: ‘One receives talent from the great root, returning to spirit to live. To sound in accord with pitch, to speak in accord with law, to set forth profit and righteousness before others—this merely subdues their mouths. To make people submit in heart and dare not oppose, to establish the world’s stability—is this enough? Enough? I cannot even reach him!’

Guo’s Commentary:
"Following the years, following transformation, moving with the times—when the times change, so do customs. One who rides things to roam the mind, how is he different from the common? Change does not cease; it cannot be constant. To call Confucius diligent in purpose and devoted to knowledge is to know he could not entrust himself to spontaneous transformation. This shows Huizi’s inadequacy—his spirit falls far short of the sage’s.

Confucius relinquished the self’s transformations as naturally so, not through knowledge or effort. Thus, he moved with the times, responded to things, and did not contrive words. If one employs talent and knowledge without returning to the root of spirit, life is lost. Sound arises from pitch; words emerge from law—but pitch and law are what the multitude creates. The sage merely employs them. Thus, he is never inappropriate, yet never speaks, never acts. *Fu* means ‘to employ.’"

I do not speak—what I speak is merely employing the mouths of others. The recitation of likes and dislikes, right and wrong, righteousness and profit has never once issued from my own mouth. The mouth serves to express the heart, so if I employ the mouths of the multitude, I employ their hearts. If I align with the hearts of the multitude, their hearts trust me—who would dare oppose or stand apart? I rely on the self-stabilization of all under heaven to stabilize it—what need is there for action? Thus, riding upon it, nothing is beyond reach.

Lü’s commentary:
It is said that Confucius at sixty "listened," and at seventy "followed the heart’s desires without overstepping the mark." This means that whatever the heart conceives, no right or wrong arises; whatever the mouth utters, no benefit or harm ensues. Before the Dao reaches the point of "following the heart," one cannot escape transformation—transformation must begin with "right" and end with "wrong." How can the "right" of sixty be certain that the "wrong" of fifty-nine is not so? Huizi did not understand this. What Confucius shared with others was merely the common—what he shared with heaven, from ancient times to the present, has never undergone transformation. To truly believe that he acted through diligent purpose and devoted knowledge is to misunderstand. To relinquish is to let go of things, allowing them to live—this is what is called "virtue," what is meant by "receiving one’s endowment." The great root returns to spirit to give life. Before birth, there is no qi, no form—how could there be what is called "spirit"? With birth, qi and form arise, and spirit is restored. When sound accords with pitch, there is no need to adjust tones; when words accord with law, there is no need to explain principles. Yet when righteousness and profit are recited before me, I merely follow and employ the mouths of others—likes and dislikes, right and wrong are but the straight path of others’ speech. For what they await is not yet settled, not the spontaneous transformation of non-action. As for making hearts submit so none dare stand apart, and thus stabilizing the stability of all under heaven—this is enabling self-transformation, not merely employing the mouths of others. That which I cannot attain is what he relinquished, never once speaking of it.

Following the root:
Employing knowledge to attend to affairs...

"Knowledge" here is talent, just as Mencius spoke of "Heaven’s bestowed talents." The "great root" is like the "great beginning." "Restoring spirit" means the human heart, empty and numinous, is obscured by material desires, and one restores it to its original state. *Wu* (蘁) means defiance. "Stabilizing the stability of all under heaven" means that all under heaven has its own inherent principle of stability—one merely stabilizes what is already stable.

When Huizi heard Zhuangzi’s words about Confucius transforming at sixty, he thought Confucius had merely toiled in mind and will to attend to affairs. But possessing much knowledge does not constitute transformation. Zhuangzi said: Not so. Confucius himself said: "One receives one’s nature from the beginning and can return to its empty numinosity to live. When one sounds forth, it accords with the pitch-pipes; when one speaks, it accords with the laws. When profit and righteousness are set before one, one knows likes and dislikes, right and wrong—this is the task of the Confucians, but it only submits the mouths of others. As for making hearts submit so none dare defy—this is the Way of the perfected person." He further praised it, saying: "Does the Dao stop here? Does it stop here? Yet I cannot attain that perfected person!"

The following is Confucius’ speech:

Zengzi took office twice, and his heart transformed twice. He said: "When I served to support my parents, three measures of grain made my heart joyful. Later, when I served with three thousand bushels, I could not [reach] my heart’s sorrow." A disciple asked Confucius: "Can one say that Shen (Zengzi) had no entanglement in his faults?" Confucius said: "He was already entangled. How could one without entanglement feel sorrow? To him, three measures or three thousand bushels were like watching cranes, mosquitoes, or gnats pass before him."

Guo’s commentary: *Ji* (洎) means "to reach." *Xian* (县) means "entanglement," referring to Zengzi’s taking office for his parents without fault of entanglement in salary. Yet he was already entangled—bound to salary for sustenance. To nourish parents is to suit them, regardless of means. If one could be without entanglement, one would not weigh noble or base in mind, but remain peaceful and content, fulfilling the proper way of serving with countenance. That is what it means to be without entanglement. One without entanglement regards honor and salary as mosquitoes, gnats, or birds passing before him—how could there be sorrow or joy in between?

Lü’s commentary: Abiding in timeliness and following circumstances, sorrow and joy cannot enter. The ancients called this "the Emperor’s disentanglement." If one has no entanglement, one cannot feel sorrow. Life and death are great matters, yet sorrow and joy cannot enter—thus three measures or three thousand bushels are like watching sparrows, mosquitoes, or gnats pass before one. The insignificance of their size or quantity is self-evident.

Oral explanation: The disciple asked whether Zengzi’s words entailed the fault of entanglement, suspecting that his two transformations involved sorrow and joy. Confucius said: "He was already entangled." This sorrow and joy alone prove entanglement. If one were without entanglement, external things passing before one would be like mosquitoes or gnats—how could they cause sorrow or joy?

Yan Chengzi You said to Dongguo Ziqi: "Since I heard your words, after one year I became rustic; after two years, compliant; after three, penetrating; after four, in accord with things; after five, things came to me; after six, the spirit entered; after seven, Heaven was accomplished; after eight, I knew neither death nor life; after nine, I attained the great mystery. Life is something one does; death is something one is exhorted by. As for life, it has a source—it is yang. As for death, it has no source—it is indeed so. Where does it go? Where does it not go? Heaven has its celestial reckoning; earth has its human demarcations. Where should I seek it? I do not know its end—how could it be without fate? I do not know its beginning—how could it have fate? If there is something to respond to, how could there be no spirit? If there is nothing to respond to, how could there be spirit?"

Liu’s commentary: Those who discuss Heaven have the reckoning of celestial patterns; those who discuss earth have the traces of human demarcations. *Ren ju* (人据) means each person clings to their own boundaries without communication. Guo’s commentary: "Rustic" means relinquishing external advantages. "Compliant" means not acting on one’s own.

The all-pervading is the same in others and myself—things and things are identical. Coming arises from attainment; spirit enters the external form. Heaven completes without further action. Not knowing where death and life reside, one is at ease in all circumstances. Wondrous goodness! Good and evil being the same, there is nowhere one does not guard against. This speaks of one who has long heard the Dao and understood the spontaneity of the heavenly pipes. Suddenly, one forgets oneself, and the defilements daily recede until they are entirely gone.

To live and act is to guard against life’s spontaneity. Because of acting, there is death; because of selfishly cherishing life, there is action. Now, what I urge you with is that death arises from selfishness. The yang of life flourishes, and by leaving no traces and acting without contrivance, it suddenly stands alone—not arising from anything. Yet it is indeed so. Thus, there is nowhere it goes and nowhere it does not go, and only then is it at ease everywhere. When all is at ease, it reaches completion. Heaven and earth are already self-sufficient; principle must naturally end, not depending on knowledge. If it is not fate, how can one not know the reason for its being so? Yet to call it fate seems as if there were intent. Therefore, I discard the name of fate to clarify that it is spontaneously so, and only then is the principle of fate complete.

Principle must have a response, as if there were spirit to bring it about. Yet principle responds of itself, not depending on causes—thus, though it responds, there is no spirit.

---

Lü’s commentary:
The Dao has never yet had things. Once there are things, and one desires to return to the absence of things, then the attainment of emptiness and the preservation of stillness are not the work of a single morning. "Rustic" means forgetting benevolence and righteousness, guests and rituals, music and propriety. "Compliant" means the heart is without opposition. "All-pervading" means the heart thoroughly penetrates things, and when it reaches things, all things roam; all things are observed. "Coming" means the Dao gathers there; "spirit enters" means spirit and divinity come to dwell. "Heaven completes" means uniting virtue with Heaven. Not knowing death, not knowing life, is to know rest in what one does not know. Great wondrousness—then one is spirit! Only after speaking of the wondrousness of the myriad things can one embody spirit.

To live and act without contrivance is not to know there is life, not to know there is death. To live and act is to have death. I urge you to be impartial and without selfishness, and then you will not know there is death. Life and action are the source of death. Thus, the sage puts the body outside and yet preserves it. By being without selfishness, one can perfect one’s selfishness—this is how I urge you. Tracing beginnings and grasping ends, one knows the explanation of life and death. Beginning and end are like a ring—life is yang, and that is all. How could there be a source from which acting arises? It is also spoken from the perspective of the feelings of things—is it indeed so?

Thus, those who embody the Dao and exhaust spirit do not know there is death or life, nor do they know where they go or do not go. If one seeks it in celestial reckoning and human demarcations, they have never been the same—how could one seek it there? Or seek it in the fortunes and misfortunes between human affairs? If one takes it to be without fate, in the end it seems as if there were something controlling it. If one takes it to be with fate, seeking its beginning is impossible. If one takes it to be without spirit, yet there is something to respond to; if one takes it to be with spirit, yet there is nothing to respond to—thus, one rests in what one does not know and has no place for the heart. This is how one attains it.

Two inquiries were posed to the Reflection by the Penumbrae: "Earlier you bowed your head, now you raise it; earlier your hair was bound, now it hangs loose; earlier you sat, now you rise; earlier you walked, now you halt—why is this?" The Reflection replied: "Such trifling matters—why do you ask so persistently? I act, yet I know not why I act. I am like the cicada’s shed husk, the snake’s sloughed skin—resembling them, yet not them. Fire and sunlight are my gathering; darkness and night are my alternation. Is it that I depend on these? How much more so for those who depend on others? When they come, I come with them; when they go, I go with them. When they are vigorous and radiant, I am vigorous and radiant with them. What question is there to ask in this?"*

*[Annotations from the text: The cicada’s husk and snake’s slough are shed skins. "Gathering" (屯) means to assemble. "Trifling" (叟叟) is also written as 搜搜, pronounced *sōu*.]

Guo’s commentary: *[Movement occurs of itself, with no cause for inquiry—it is simply so, hence one knows not why. The reflection resembles form yet is not form. Pushing this to its limit, what is now called "dependence" ultimately reaches the principle of "no-dependence" and "self-transformation," which becomes manifest. It is merely vigorous radiance, movement, mutual following, coming and going—endless and unquestionable.]*

Lü’s commentary: *[The Penumbrae arise from the reflection; beyond the reflection lies subtle darkness, not singular, hence called "trifling." The reflection’s bowing, raising, walking, and halting merely follow the person—how could it know why? That form has a reflection is like the cicada having a husk or the snake a slough, yet it is not the cicada’s husk or the snake’s slough. The reflection gathers and becomes visible in fire and sunlight, alternates and vanishes in darkness and night—this is what the reflection depends on to be a reflection, yet it is without awareness. How could it know of dependence? What the reflection depends on—sunlight, fire, darkness, night—cannot be called dependence. How much less so for those who depend on others? Those who depend on others arise from the reflection, which is form. Since the Penumbrae are without dependence, we know the reflection is without dependence; since the reflection is without dependence, we know what gives rise to the reflection is also without dependence—thus it is not burdened by form. When they come and go, I come and go with them; when they are vigorous and radiant, I am vigorous and radiant with them—yet none of this is me. What question is there to ask?]*

Xun’s edition: *[括 means "bound hair." 叟 is an address for an elder. 稍 means "slight." 彼 refers to form.]*

Moreover, when one employs it to instruct others, forcing the yang—this unbalanced yang qi—then Penumbrae and reflections become like two elders meeting. How long can two elders remain in the world? The moments they might question one another are but fleeting. Why must you ask even briefly?

I speak of my own reflection. Though I possess this shadow, I know not the reason for its existence. Some say the shadow arises from form, like the cicada’s shell or the snake’s slough—this seems plausible, yet it is not so. The shell still belongs to the cicada, the slough still belongs to the snake. But when the shadow encounters fire or sunlight, it gathers and appears; when it meets darkness or night, it departs and vanishes. Without fire or sunlight, even with form present, it cannot become my shadow. Thus, while that form may produce my shadow, it must depend on something else. How much more so for the Penumbrae, which rely on the shadow’s dependence?

When that form comes and goes, I necessarily come and go with it; when that form is vigorous and radiant, I too am vigorous and radiant with it. Yet this vigorous radiance is not the true qi of blood and breath, and the shadow merely follows it to manifest. Neither form nor shadow is real—why then ask about this false doubling, which only repeats itself while the meaning grows ever more transcendent?

---

Yang Ziju traveled south to Pei, while Lao Dan journeyed west to Qin. Invited to the outskirts, they met at Liang, where Laozi looked up to the heavens and sighed: “At first, I thought you could be taught—now, you cannot.”

Yang Ziju made no reply. Upon reaching his lodging, he washed his face, rinsed his mouth, combed his hair, removed his shoes outside the door, then crawled forward on his knees and said: “Earlier, your disciple wished to ask you a question, but you were walking without pause, so I dared not speak. Now there is a pause—may I ask the reason?”

Laozi said: “Your gaze is haughty and overbearing—with whom do you dwell? Utter purity appears defiled; abundant virtue seems insufficient.”

Yang Ziju’s expression changed abruptly, and he said: “I respectfully receive your instruction.”

When he had left, the innkeeper welcomed him, leading him home; the master of the house held the mat, his wife held the comb and towel, the guests rose from their seats, and the cook left the stove. When he returned, the innkeeper and guests contended with him for the seat.

---

[Yang’s given name was Rong, styled Ziju; the *Liezi* writes it as Yang Zhu. *Sui* means to raise the eyes; *xu* means to widen the eyes—both describe an upward gaze on the face, verging on arrogance. *Yang* refers to cooking.]

Guo’s commentary: [*Sui sui xu xu* describes a domineering manner; others will find it difficult to approach and will distance themselves. He exalted his form and set himself apart, so they feared and avoided him. Once he shed his pride, they contended with him for the seat.]

Lü’s commentary: [His haughty gaze set him apart, so the innkeeper welcomed and led him in—this was the summons of shoes filling the doorway. Laozi’s sigh over Ziju’s formed brilliance, and Bohun’s departure from Yu Kou, share the same principle.]

Jiang Yu: [Confucius said: “Without refinement, one cannot attain truth.” Washing his face, rinsing his mouth, combing his hair, removing his shoes, and crawling forward on his knees—all were to seek truth. Among human faculties, none is finer than the pupils, for they are where the spirit resides. When those who have attained the Dao meet, a glance conveys the Way; those who know others often discern them in the brows and lashes. Thus, Yangzi’s haughty, overbearing gaze led Laozi to deem him unteachable.

“Clear in all four directions” is called utter purity; “ever more humble when descending” is called appearing defiled. Empty yet inexhaustible, abundant virtue seems insufficient. Such a one regards the world with equanimity—what place is there for haughty gazes? Avoiding the seat was not merely about non-contention; contending for the seat was not merely about non-avoidance. Upon receiving instruction and returning, those who once avoided him now vied with him. The distance between Qin and Liang is not great; the innkeeper today is the same as yesterday, and Yang Zhu is not two different people. Yet their encounter changed so abruptly—this reveals how the subtlest Dao, though ever-present, alters form and shifts thought, eluding common understanding.

When he traveled south to Pei, he followed external things; upon returning, he reverted to the root of destiny. Whether avoiding or contending, it lay in the difference between going and coming.]

A humble opinion in summary: [This chapter uses allegory as its title, conveying the Immortal of Nanhua’s meaning of “crossing water without wetting the feet.” Reflecting on my own words, I fear later generations might cling to traces and become ensnared, so I erase the traces step by step. The allegories and reiterations are unavoidable borrowings from external discussions.

The *zhi*-vessel’s water, though bounded, does not spill—its outflow comes from within, thus it “flows without ceasing.” Right and wrong, same and different, each finds its proper place. Words arise from wordlessness, just as silence is also a form of speech. Whether affirmed or negated, it is merely the world’s preferences.]

Alas! How can one know whether this is inherently so or inherently permissible? Thus, only by reaching wordlessness does equality arise.

Ah! As the world declines and the Dao withers, none believe in oneself, and one cannot fulfill one’s aspirations in the present age. Yet still, one hopes to leave teachings for future generations, fearing there will be no way to ensure posterity’s understanding. Therefore, one guards what is most essential to gain their trust.

Let them enter through allegory to preserve their authenticity, following subtle signs to ascend to the marvelous—its achievement is one and the same.

As for the ultimate discourse, the Master’s traces shift with the years: what was right at first may end in wrong, and what is right in one’s own time cannot endure forever. How much less, then, can one expect to be unquestionably believed by later ages?

Zengzi took office twice and changed twice, his heart not free from entanglement; sorrow and joy took shape. Was it not asked whether it was for his parents or for emolument?

Yet those who hear words and awaken—like Ziyou, who in a single year went from rustic to attaining the great marvel—find their hearts growing ever more empty and the Dao ever more gathered.

Next, the discussion of whether fate and spirits have form, and the causes of shadows and echoes, all reveal the marvels of creation that cannot be fathomed. If one can fulfill what creation bestows and not obstruct the heavenly within, then the heaven and earth of one’s own body—this unfathomable spiritual thing—are likewise so.

Concluding with haughty arrogance: who would dwell with such a person? Yet those who hear the command and return to their homes, contending for mats, do so in the instant of listening with the heart and awakening. Who would say that those who carry the Dao to instruct later generations are like those who catch fish and forget the trap?

**Chapter Twenty-Eight: Yielding the Throne**

Yao offered the empire to Xu You, but Xu You declined. He then offered it to Zizhou Zhipu, who said: *"That you would make me Son of Heaven is acceptable—yet I happen to suffer from a deep-seated melancholy, and am presently occupied with curing it. I have no leisure to govern the empire. The empire is the weightiest of burdens, yet I would not let it harm my life—how much less would I do so for other things? Only one who takes no account of the empire can be entrusted with it."*

Shun offered the empire to Zizhou Zhibo, who said: *"I, too, suffer from a deep-seated melancholy and am presently occupied with curing it. I have no leisure to govern the empire. Thus, the empire is a great vessel, yet one must not exchange life for it—this is how those who embody the Way differ from the vulgar."*

Shun then offered the empire to Shan Juan, who replied: *"I stand amid the cosmos: in winter, I wear furs and pelts; in summer, coarse or fine kudzu cloth. In spring, I plow and sow, toiling enough to labor my body; in autumn, I reap and gather, resting enough to nourish myself. I rise with the sun and rest with its setting, wandering carefree between heaven and earth, my heart and mind content. Why would I take the empire? Alas, how little you know me!"* He refused and departed, entering the deep mountains where none knew his whereabouts.

Shun offered the empire to his friend, the farmer of Shihu. The farmer said: *"How earnest you are! Here is one who preserves his strength—a man of true vigor. Yet even Shun’s virtue has not reached its perfection."*

Then the man shouldered his burdens, his wife carried their belongings on her head, and together they led their child into the sea, never to return.

King Tai of the Zhou dwelt in Bin, but the Di tribes attacked him. He offered them furs and silks, yet they refused; he offered them dogs and horses, yet they refused; he offered them pearls and jade, yet they refused. What the Di sought was land.

King Tai said: *"To dwell with a man’s elder brother and kill his younger brother, to dwell with a man’s father and kill his son—how could I bear it? Go, all of you, and dwell as you will. What difference is there between serving as my subjects and serving the Di?"* Moreover, he had heard it said: *"Do not let what nourishes harm what is nourished."* So he leaned on his staff and departed. The people followed in such numbers that they formed a line, and together they established a state beneath Mount Qi. This King Tai may be said to have known how to honor life.

One who knows how to honor life, though noble and wealthy, does not let prosperity harm his body; though poor and lowly, does not let profit burden his form. Yet men of this age who occupy high office and exalted rank all cling fiercely to what they might lose, and for the sake of gain lightly risk their lives—are they not deluded?

The people of Yue murdered their ruler for three generations. Prince Sou, troubled by this, fled into the Cinnabar Caves, and Yue was left without a king. When they could not find Prince Sou, they pursued him into the Cinnabar Caves. The prince refused to emerge, so the people of Yue fumigated the cave with mugwort. They brought the royal carriage, and Prince Sou, grasping the reins, mounted it. Looking up to heaven, he cried: *"A ruler! A ruler! Could you not spare me alone?"*

Prince Sou did not despise being a ruler—he despised the calamities that come with being one. One such as Prince Sou may be said not to let the state harm his life. This is precisely what the people of Yue desired in a ruler.

Duke Lu’s note: *"You"* (幽) means hidden, as in the *Book of Songs*: *"as if harboring hidden sorrow."* *"Juanjuan"* (卷卷) describes strenuous effort—what is used to nourish the land, while what is nourished is the people. *"Not letting prosperity harm the body"* and *"not letting profit burden the form"* mean that in wealth and nobility, one possesses nourishment yet does not blindly let it harm the body, while in poverty and lowliness, one lacks profit yet does not let the pursuit of it weigh down the form. *"Sou"* is the prince’s name; the *Huainanzi* writes it as *"Yi."* The *Erya* states: *"Where the sun shines from the south is called the Cinnabar Caves."*

Lü’s commentary: In the late eras of the Three Dynasties, fathers and sons, brothers, all contended for the realm, slaughtering one another. The so-called scholars of the age risked their lives and treated existence lightly to seek favor—this is why the *"Yielding the Throne"* chapter was composed. Perhaps it was inspired by men like Zhi Fu, who would not exchange their lives for all under heaven. Yang Xiong believed that the ancient sages, in the weightiness of Yao’s abdication to Shun, did not take Yu lightly. What is meant by *"weightiness"* if not that one must test a successor thoroughly before entrusting the realm to him? Yet they did not realize that what made Yao able to obtain Shun lay not in such trials—for trials are common to all men, as in the saying *"exposing him to the people."* Had Yu not possessed the intent to avoid Yao’s favor, how could they have known his trials would not surpass Shun’s?

Yi Du’s note: To have a body is to require nourishment; to have life is to bear burdens. The wealthy and noble delight in nourishment, but excess harms the body. The poor and lowly are pressed by profit, but loss entangles the form. Only by avoiding these two perils can one truly honor life. Yet this is but the remnant of the sage’s way, not its essence. The sage’s true essence lies in forgetting life so that life is perfectly preserved, forgetting nourishment so that nourishment is fully realized. Though entrusted with the realm and its affairs, it is merely a matter of circumstance—what cause is there for reluctance?

Xun Ben’s note: In present-day Wuling County, south of Changde Prefecture, stands the Altar of Shanjuan. During the Zhenghe era of the Song, it was bestowed the title *"Master of Reclusive Loftiness."* The prefect Li Fang composed an inscription for the altar, near which his tomb still lies.

The states of Han and Wei contended over border lands. Zihua Zi met with Marquis Zhao of Han, who wore a troubled expression. Zihua Zi said: *"Suppose the world inscribed a maxim before you, which read: ‘If you seize it with your left hand, your right hand will be severed; if you seize it with your right hand, your left hand will be severed. Yet whoever seizes it shall possess all under heaven.’ Would you seize it?"* Marquis Zhao replied: *"I would not."* Zihua Zi said: *"Excellent. From this, we see that your two arms are weightier than all under heaven, and your body weightier still than your arms. How much lighter, then, is Han’s claim compared to the realm? And how much lighter still is what you now contend over? You grieve, harming your life with sorrow—all for naught."* Marquis Zhao said: *"Well said! Many have instructed me, yet never have I heard such words. Zihua Zi truly understands the weight of things."* (Zihua Zi was a man of Wei. *"Jue"* means to seize; *"fei"* means to sever and discard.)

Lü’s commentary: Marquis Zhao, by heeding Zihua Zi’s words and dismissing what he contested, ranks next to those who would not exchange their lives for all under heaven.

Bi Xu’s note: Which is dearer—name or body? Which is greater—body or wealth? Why exhaust oneself over barren battlefields? The *Honglie* explains: *"To slaughter warhorses in pursuit of foxes, to clutch two turtles while losing a sacred tortoise, to sever one’s right arm for a single hair, to break a Mo Ye blade for a mere awl—these are truly those who know not the weight of things."*

When the Lord of Lu heard that Yan He was a man who had attained the Dao, he sent an envoy bearing gifts to precede him.

Yan He dwelt in a humble lane, clad in coarse cloth of hemp and ramie, tending his own cattle. When the envoy of the Lord of Lu arrived, Yan He himself received him. The envoy asked, “Is this the home of Yan He?” Yan He replied, “This is He’s home.” The envoy presented the gifts, but Yan He said, “I fear the messenger may have erred in his instructions and thus bring blame upon himself. It would be better to verify.” The envoy returned and confirmed the matter, then came again to seek him, but Yan He could no longer be found. Thus it was clear that one such as Yan He truly despised wealth and honor.

Therefore it is said: The true essence of the Dao is for the cultivation of the self; its remnants and leavings may be used for the state. Its dregs and chaff may be applied to govern the world. From this perspective, the achievements of emperors and kings are but the surplus affairs of sages—never the means to perfect the self or nurture life. Yet today, the gentlemen of the俗世 often endanger their bodies and abandon their lives to pursue external things. Is this not lamentable?

In all the actions of sages, they must examine their purpose and their means. Suppose there were a man here who used the pearl of the Marquis of Sui to shoot a sparrow a thousand *ren* high—surely the world would laugh at him. Why? Because what he employed was weighty, while what he sought was trivial. How much more so is life itself, which far surpasses the pearl of the Marquis of Sui!

The Lord of Lu (or the Marquis of Lu) had a son named Ma, whose status was as low as weeds or dung. Yet even such humble origins may offer glimpses of insight—difficult to advance, easy to retreat, this is the constant cultivation of the noble person, growing deeper with time until it stands beyond all debate. Moreover, among all the achievements under heaven, none surpass those of emperors and kings, yet even these are deemed mere surplus affairs of the sage. If this is so, how could the true essence of the sage be fathomed by common minds? The "purpose" and "means" (or "path" and "resting place") refer to the *suoyou* and *suoan*. I fear that listeners may misconstrue the character *zhe* (者) as redundant. The phrase "to perfect the self" (*zhi shen*) should be understood as "to preserve." In all the actions of the sage, the character *sheng* (圣) is superfluous. The "weight of the Marquis of Sui" should read "pearl of the Marquis of Sui," as confirmed by the *Lüshi Chunqiu*. Lü Buwei lived not long after Zhuangzi and must have preserved the authentic meaning.

Liezi appeared impoverished, his countenance bearing the hue of hunger. A guest mentioned this to Ziyang of Zheng, saying, "Lie Yukou is a man of the Dao. That he dwells in your state yet suffers hardship—does this not suggest you do not favor scholars?" Ziyang of Zheng immediately ordered an official to send grain to Liezi. Liezi met the messenger, bowed twice, and declined. The messenger departed. Liezi entered his home, where his wife, clutching her heart, reproached him: "I have heard that the wife and children of a man of the Dao all enjoy ease and joy. Now you bear the look of hunger, yet the lord, recognizing his error, sent you food, and you refused it. Is this not fate?" Liezi laughed and replied, "The lord does not know me personally. He sent me grain based on another’s words, and he could just as easily condemn me based on another’s words. This is why I did not accept it." Later, the people indeed rose in rebellion and killed Ziyang. (Ziyang, the chief minister of Zheng, was severe and merciless; none who offended him were spared. His retainer broke a bow, fearing Ziyang’s wrath, and the people, likening him to a rabid dog, killed him.)

Bi Xu comments: Would a true scholar willingly sink into obscurity, bending his will to accept undeserved emolument? Could one who indulges the sentiments of wife and children thus entangle himself in the snares of disaster?

When King Zhao of Chu lost his state, a butcher named Yue followed him into exile. When the king returned to his state, he sought to reward those who had followed him, including the butcher. The butcher said, "When the great king lost his state, I lost my butcher’s stall. Now that the great king has returned, I have regained my butcher’s stall. My rank and emoluments are restored—what reward is there to speak of?" The king insisted, saying, "Compel him to accept." The butcher replied, "The great king lost his state not through any fault of mine, so I dared not submit to punishment. The great king’s return is not through any merit of mine, so I dare not claim reward." The king said, "Let me see him." The butcher replied, "According to the laws of Chu, only those who render great service are granted audience. My wisdom was insufficient to preserve the state, and my courage was insufficient to die in battle. When the Wu army entered Ying, I fled in fear of disaster—not out of any special devotion to the great king. Now the great king wishes to set aside the law and break the covenant to see me. This is not what I have heard of the ways of the world." The king said to Sima Ziqi, "The butcher’s station is lowly, yet his exposition of principle is lofty. You must secure for me a position of the Three Standards for him." The butcher said, "I know that a position of the Three Standards is nobler than a butcher’s stall, and an emolument of ten thousand *zhong* is richer than a butcher’s profit. Yet how could I greedily accept rank and emolument and thereby cause my lord to bear a reputation for reckless bestowal? I dare not accept. I wish only to return to my butcher’s stall." Thus he declined the offer. (The Three Standards: The *Shiji* reads "Three Jade Tablets," as the three ministers of the feudal lords all held jade tablets.)

Bi Xu comments: Those who recite the Odes and Documents yet act with integrity in a butcher’s stall—such men exist in every age. Those who seize power as their own merit or barter influence for great reward, upon hearing this, should feel shame.

Kou Yi notes: When the great king returned to his state, the butcher returned to his stall—each regained his proper place. The Three Standards refer to the Three Dukes, whose carriages and robes each bore distinct insignia, hence "Three Standards."

Yuan Xian lived in Lu in a dwelling of barely twenty paces square, its roof thatched with growing grass, its door incomplete, its hinge made of mulberry wood, its windows of earthen jars. Two rooms were partitioned with coarse cloth, the roof leaked above, the floor was damp below, yet he sat upright and sang. Zigong arrived in a grand carriage, his inner robe dark blue, his outer robe white, his carriage too wide for the lane, and went to see Yuan Xian. Yuan Xian, wearing a hat of thorns, shoes of hemp, leaning on a staff, answered the door. Zigong said, "Alas! Master, what ails you?" Yuan Xian replied, "I have heard that to lack wealth is called poverty, and to study yet be unable to practice is called affliction. I am poor, not afflicted." Zigong retreated, his face flushed with shame. Yuan Xian laughed and said, "To act for the sake of the world, to befriend for mutual advantage, to study for others, to teach for oneself, to conceal one’s virtue with benevolence and righteousness, to adorn oneself with carriages and horses—these are things I cannot bear to do."

Zengzi lived in Wei, wearing a quilted robe without lining, his complexion swollen, his hands and feet calloused. For three days he did not light a fire, for ten years he did not make new clothes. When he straightened his cap, its tassel broke; when he grasped his lapel, his elbow showed; when he put on his shoes, his heels split. Yet as he dragged his hempen shoes, singing the *Odes of Shang*, his voice filled heaven and earth, as if issuing from metal or stone. The Son of Heaven could not make him a subject, the feudal lords could not befriend him. Thus, he who cultivates his will forgets his form; he who cultivates his form forgets profit; he who attains the Dao forgets his heart.

Confucius said to Yan Hui, "Come, Hui. Your family is poor, your station low—why do you not serve in office?" Yan Hui replied, "I do not wish to serve. Outside the city walls, I have fifty *mu* of fields, enough to provide gruel and porridge. Within the city walls, I have ten *mu* of fields, enough to supply silk and hemp. Playing the zither is enough for my amusement; studying the Master’s Dao is enough for my joy. I do not wish to serve." Confucius’s expression changed, and he said, "Excellent, Hui’s intent! I have heard that he who is content does not burden himself with profit, that he who truly possesses himself is not dismayed by loss, and that he who cultivates virtue within is not ashamed by lack of position. I have recited this for a long time, but only now do I see it in you. This is my gain." (The character *kuang* 匡 means "to correct." *Xi* 縰 refers to dragging one’s shoes.)

The term *yingmen* 应门 refers to answering at one’s own gate; *xishi* 希世 means to disregard worldly reputation. *Zhongkuai* 肿哙 describes rough, chapped skin, while *bocuo* 剥错 signifies tattered and worn. Another interpretation holds that it describes the inconstant nature of fullness and emptiness.

---

The newly transmitted teaching states:
Wealth and honor are what all people desire; poverty and lowliness are what all people detest. Both desire and aversion arise from the heart. If one can be without heart, then desire and aversion are thereby forgotten. When desire and aversion are forgotten, one abides in wealth and honor yet remains unaware of their presence, dwells in poverty and lowliness yet remains unaware of their weight. Serene and self-content, one roams freely between Heaven and Earth.

Men like Yuan Xian, Zengzi, and Yan Hui may be called those without heart. Yuan Xian lived in a wattle hut with a door of woven thorns and a window of broken jars. Zengzi’s complexion was rough and chapped, his robes and cap torn and frayed. Yan Hui, poor and of low station, had only gruel and porridge, silk and hemp to sustain him. Yet none of the three ever resented poverty or forgot the Dao. Sometimes singing, sometimes humming, they forgot their forms and attained self-contentment. How could they have striven to chase external things and harm their lives? This is what sets them apart from the common world.

Thus it is said: he who attains the Dao forgets the heart.

---

The Prince of Zhongshan, Gongzi Mou, said to Zhanzi, “Though my body dwells by rivers and seas, my heart resides beneath the towers of Wei—what is to be done?”
Zhanzi replied, “Value life, and profit will naturally grow light.”
The Prince of Zhongshan said, “Though I know this, I have not yet overcome myself.”
Zhanzi said, “If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow your spirit—what harm is there in that? If you cannot overcome yourself yet forcibly resist, this is called double injury. A doubly injured person cannot long endure.”

Though Wei Mou was a prince of ten thousand chariots, his retreat to mountain caves and caverns would have been difficult even for a commoner. Though he had not yet fully attained the Dao, he may be said to have grasped its intent.

The *Xiang Wei* observes the gates of a lord’s state—*Huainanzi* renders it as *guī què*; Xu Shen explains it as the two watchtowers of the Son of Heaven.

To doubt alone:
The Lord of Wei, Gongzi Mou, was enfeoffed in Zhongshan; Zhanzi was a worthy man of Wei. The human heart is most difficult to overcome, and though his body dwelt by rivers and seas, his heart resided beneath the towers of Wei, confessing that he had not yet freed himself from thoughts of wealth and rank. To value life is to make profit light; when profit is light, one no longer longs for the towers of Wei. Though Mou knew that life should be valued and things made light, his heart could not overcome itself. If one cannot overcome oneself, it is better to follow one’s spirit rather than forcibly suppress it—suppression wounds the inner spirit, and the spirit abhors it. Inability to overcome oneself is one injury; forcing suppression is a second. Thus it is called double injury, which is no way to nurture oneself. Hence it is said: “A doubly injured person cannot long endure.”

What Zhanzi spoke of cannot serve as a model for those who study the Dao. It is like a skilled physician treating illness: he must examine the patient before prescribing a remedy, aiming only to cure the ailment.

Confucius was beset between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food, his gruel of wild greens lacking even a grain of rice. His complexion was utterly worn, yet he sang in his chamber. Yan Hui picked vegetables while Zilu and Zigong spoke to one another: “The Master was twice driven from Lu, his traces erased in Wei, his tree felled in Song, and now he is trapped between Chen and Cai. Those who would kill the Master bear no guilt; those who would lend him aid face no prohibition. Yet he sings and plays the zither without ceasing—can a gentleman be so shameless?”

Yan Hui had no reply. He entered and told Confucius, who pushed aside his zither and sighed deeply: “You and Ci are small-minded. Call them in; I will speak to them.” Zilu and Zigong entered. Zilu said, “In such straits, one may truly be called destitute.” Confucius said, “What words are these? A gentleman who is at one with the Dao is called ‘at one’; one who is cut off from the Dao is called ‘cut off.’ Now I embrace the Dao of benevolence and righteousness yet suffer the calamities of a disordered age—how can this be called destitution? Thus, when I look within, I am not cut off from the Dao; when I face adversity, I do not lose my virtue. When bitter cold arrives and frost and snow descend, I thereby know the flourishing of the pine and cypress. The straits of Chen and Cai may yet prove fortunate for me.”

Confucius then calmly returned to his zither and sang, while Zilu, inspired, took up his shield and danced. Zigong said, “I did not know the height of heaven or the depth of earth!” The ancients who attained the Dao found joy in poverty and joy in prosperity—their joy was not in poverty or prosperity. When virtue and power reside here, then poverty and prosperity become as the sequence of cold and heat, wind and rain. Thus Xu You delighted in Yingyang, and Gong Bo found contentment on Mount Gong’s summit.

Lu’s commentary:
From Yan He driving bandits to Confucius, none recklessly accepted rank or emolument, bestowing gifts even in poverty and want, enduring cold and hunger without altering their joy. Next to them, Gongzi Mou, though not yet having attained the Dao, may be said to have grasped its intent. As for the common run of men, steeped in worldly falsity, when they hear of the ways of Xu You and Shan Juan, they deem them mad and do not believe. Thus, recounting the sagely and worthy—none who forgot life found it easy—makes clear that to not let the world and its states harm one’s life is no small matter.

Sima Biao:
Gong Bo’s name was He; he cultivated his conduct and loved worthy men. During King Li of Zhou’s troubles, when the Son of Heaven’s line was severed, the feudal lords all requested that he become the new ruler. He reigned for fourteen years, but a great drought came, houses burned, and divination at Taiyang revealed an omen: King Li was the cause. The Duke of Shao then enthroned King Xuan, and Gong Bo returned to his ancestral line, wandering carefree at the summit of Mount Gong.

Shun yielded the world to his friend, the Northerner Wu Ze. The Northerner Wu Ze said, “How strange! What sort of man is this latter-day ruler?”

Dwelling amid the furrowed fields and wandering at Yao’s gate were not enough—he sought still to sully me with his shameful conduct. Ashamed to face him, I cast myself into the limpid, icy abyss.

When Tang was about to strike down Jie, he consulted Bian Sui. Bian Sui said, “This is not my affair.” Tang asked, “Who, then, is suitable?” He replied, “I do not know.” Tang then consulted Mao Guang.
