Mao Guang said, “This is not my affair.” Tang asked, “Who, then, is suitable?” He replied, “I do not know.” Tang said, “What of Yi Yin?” Mao Guang answered, “A man of strength and endurance, who tolerates disgrace—I know nothing beyond that.” Thereupon Tang took counsel with Yi Yin, overthrew Jie, and offered the throne to Bian Sui. Bian Sui declined, saying, “When the sovereign attacked Jie, he sought my counsel—he must have regarded me as a traitor. Having vanquished Jie, he offers me the throne—he must regard me as greedy. I was born into a disordered age, and now this man of no Dao twice comes to sully me with his shameful conduct. I cannot bear to hear of it again.” He cast himself into the Zhou River and died.

Tang then offered the throne to Mao Guang, saying, “The wise devise the plan, the martial carry it out, and the humane dwell in its fruits—this is the Way of antiquity. Why do you not ascend?” Mao Guang declined, saying, “To depose a sovereign is not righteous; to kill the people is not humane. Others endure hardship while I enjoy the profit—this is not integrity. I have heard it said: one who does not act righteously does not accept its emoluments; in an age without the Dao, one does not tread its soil—how much less accept its honors? I cannot bear to witness this long.” He carried a stone and drowned himself in the Lu River.

In the rise of the Zhou, there were two knights dwelling in Guzhu named Boyi and Shuqi. The two conferred, saying, “We have heard there is one in the west who seems to possess the Dao. Let us go and observe.” When they reached Qiyang, King Wu heard of them and sent Shu Dan to meet them. He made a covenant with them, saying, “I will raise your rank two grades and appoint you to the first rank of office,” and sealed it with the blood of a sacrificial victim, burying it. The two looked at each other and laughed, saying, “Alas! How strange! This is not what we call the Dao.” In ancient times, when Shennong ruled the world...

At that time, sacrifices were performed with utmost reverence yet without prayers for blessings. In their dealings with others, they were loyal and trustworthy, administering affairs thoroughly yet without seeking anything in return. Joy accompanied governance when governance was joyful; joy accompanied order when order was joyful. They did not achieve self-fulfillment through others’ ruin, nor exalt themselves through others’ lowliness, nor profit from the times they encountered. Now, the Zhou, seeing the disorder of the Yin, hastily seized governance—scheming above and bribing below, relying on military force to maintain power, slaughtering sacrificial victims to swear oaths as tokens of trust, employing flattery to please the masses, and resorting to killing and warfare to seize advantage. This is but replacing chaos with violence.

We have heard that the knights of old, when encountering an age of order, did not shirk their duties; when facing an age of chaos, they did not seek mere survival. Now, the world is benighted, the Zhou’s virtue has declined, and it has become one with the Yin. For the Zhou to employ us would be to stain our persons. It is better to avoid them to preserve the purity of our conduct.

The two men traveled north to Mount Shouyang and there starved to death.

As for Boyi and Shuqi, when it came to wealth and honor, if they could be avoided, they would certainly not rely on them. With lofty integrity and unyielding conduct, they rejoiced in their own aspirations and did not serve the world. Such was the integrity of these two knights.

*(The State of Guzhu lay within the borders of present-day Lingzhi County in Liaoxi. "Blood of a sacrificial victim" in some versions reads "slaughter of a sacrificial victim.")*

*(Guo’s commentary: The *Analects* states that Boyi and Shuqi starved beneath Mount Shouyang without mentioning their deaths. This text speaks of their deaths, but only to clarify that they endured starvation to the end—not necessarily that they died of starvation. Lu’s commentary: Those like Wuze, Suiguang, and Boyi and Shuqi not only refused the world and its ranks and emoluments but also regarded hearing its words or dwelling in its age as defilement, even to the point of drowning or starving to death. This makes their joy in the Dao and forgetfulness of life all the more difficult—something the common world cannot believe. These several worthies were all sages and worthies, thus they were fundamentally enlightened regarding the meaning of life and death. Death may be weightier than Mount Tai or lighter than a goose feather, yet the abdications of Shun and Yu later degenerated into the usurpations of Zihuai and King Wu of Yin. The deeds of Wuze, Suiguang, Boyi, and Shuqi, when their influence reached later ages, were no small benefit to the world. Thus, death was not what they loved. Yet Han Fei claimed that Tang, fearing the world would deem him greedy, feigned refusal to Wu Guang, and that Wu Guang, fearing acceptance, had Tang’s flatterers drown him so that Tang might shift ill repute onto Wu Guang. Sima Qian also did not believe in the existence of one called Suiguang. Han Fei, in knowing how to sacrifice his life, would measure Tang and Wu Guang by such standards. Yet Xu You, Zhi Fu, and Zhi Bo would not exchange their lives for the world, thereby teaching later ages to honor life and disdain profit. Wuze, Suiguang, Boyi, and Shuqi, on the other hand, abandoned life to benefit the world, teaching later ages to forget life and esteem righteousness. Their benevolence was one and the same.

Zhuangzi, when discussing the supreme Dao to relinquish fame and profit, placed Boyi, Shuqi, and Suiguang among those to be rejected. Yet when discussing abdication to awaken the world from the folly of endangering oneself for external things, he placed them among those to be esteemed. The reader who understands this will grasp the meaning without needing the words.)*

*(Guo’s general commentary: The overarching intent of this chapter is to inspire a spirit of lofty refusal and distant retreat. Thus, those touched by this spirit, even if they were greedy and reckless men riding the celestial thoroughfare or entering the imperial court, would still sigh in lament midway. How much more so for ordinary men? Therefore, the likes of Boyi and Xu You are worthy counterparts to Yi and Lü. Those who dwell in mountain valleys yet ennoble the world, though not all become sagely ministers, are still loftier than those mired in dust and grime. Their deeds may be difficult to emulate, but their influence is less prone to corruption and thus can be transmitted. Where lies the flaw in Boyi and Xu You? Xu You’s flaw was that it led men to feign refusal in order to seek advancement, culminating in the likes of Zihuai. Boyi’s influence allowed tyrannical rulers to wield their poison without anyone daring to resist. The flaw of Yi and Lü was that it emboldened the world’s greedy and reckless heroes to dare usurpation and rebellion. Only the sage leaves no trace, and thus no flaw. If Yi and Lü are considered the sage’s traces, then Boyi and Shuqi are also the sage’s traces. If Boyi and Shuqi are not the sage’s traces, then the deeds of Yi and Lü are also not sagely. The sage follows the spontaneous course of things, thus leaving no trace. Therefore, what is called sagely is fundamentally traceless, and when traces are obtained, the term "sage" is forcibly applied. Thus, the sage is but a name for the traceless.)*

*(Lu Deming’s note: Some ask, "The chapter 'Abdicating the Throne' contains many passages valuing life, yet two or three worthies drowned themselves—why?" The answer: The rise of Zhuangzi’s book lies in returning to the root. The means of returning to the root takes precedence in relinquishing glory. Thus, the chapter "Abdicating the Throne" establishes the lofty aspirations of transcending the world, preventing surrender to prevent the corruption of custom, and not exalting oneself to preserve life. The occasional passages valuing life ultimately convey the intent to abandon glory. This deeply dispels the flaw of worldly affairs. Those of lesser degree wear coarse cloth and sip congee to preserve themselves, yet even this self-preservation is lofty and transcends the common. How much more so to cast oneself into the clear and cold, never yielding to the world’s entanglements?)*

】 Liu Gai’s Commentary [
To act only when unavoidable is to reject nothing; to persist when avoidable is to seize everything. Those who reject nothing verge on restraint; those who seize everything verge on recklessness. The sage, attaining the central Dao and aligning with it, deems both extremes fit for abandonment. Yet without attaining the central Dao, both fall within the realm of measured judgment.

Recklessness and restraint are indeed the corruptions of the central Dao, but later ages’ reckless ones do not merely advance and seize. They plunge into greed for life and love of profit, sinking into the abyss of desire. The restrained do not merely refrain from action; they wash their ears and cast themselves into the depths to spurn the names of Yao and Shun—this, too, is the corruption of restraint and recklessness.

Zhuangzi called abdication a name that, in the space between offering and receiving, should not be misapplied. For one who rules as a king within the realm, what matter could there be in yielding? Thus, the sage, acting only when unavoidable in governing the world, is exemplified by Wangzi Sou. When the sage reaches the point of having nothing external to trouble him, who would weary himself? Taking the world as his concern, when he attains inner selflessness, the world naturally turns to him—how could he refuse? In this light, Yao’s abdication to Shun, Tang and Wu’s conquests, Yi Yin’s service to Tang, and Boyi’s avoidance of Zhou differ not at all from those who dwell in fields and furrows.

】 A General Overview [
This chapter records the lofty integrity of those who abdicate rulership, from Yao and Shun to Xu You, Shan Juan, and Wangzi Sou—all esteemed the Dao and honored life, refusing to burden their hearts with wealth and honor, regarding the world as a worn-out sandal. Figures like Zihua, Yan He, Zeng and Yan, and Gongzi Mou preserved their authenticity and upheld simplicity, valuing wealth and honor no more than floating clouds. Among them, Wei Mou, though comparing himself to the sages as if inadequate, as a prince of a state, relinquished the exalted position of kingship to embrace the seclusion of mountain caves—this was no small feat.

Thus, the far-reaching influence of their noble winds inspired rulers to esteem the Dao and honor life, establishing the teachings of purity and non-action, and manifesting the legacy of the profound and unsullied king. Those who forget themselves and pursue external things, even when facing the slightest gain or loss, will contend over a single hair. Yet to yield a throne while occupying it is the grandest deed in the world.

Those who embrace the Dao and hold fast to virtue, entrusted by others, may not desire rulership and retreat to mountains and seas—such cases exist. Why, then, do followers like Wuze and Suiguang hastily drown themselves, forsaking their priceless bodies? It is because scholars who fail to attain the central Dao and stand alone in restraint cannot avoid corruption. The excessively greedy, insatiable in their pursuit, inevitably descend into usurpation; the excessively yielding, fleeing without refuge, inevitably drown themselves. Both stem from an excess of admiration for reputation. Only the sage, embodying the mean without corruption, yields and receives appropriately, retreats or advances with the times, and moves with ease in the central Dao—Yao and Shun’s deeds exemplify this.

Boyi and Shuqi yielded their kingdom and fled to Shouyang, subsisting on ferns and bracken until their end—this was not a deliberate display of defiance or pursuit of posthumous fame. For one who yields while already a ruler, the act is conspicuous; for one who avoids rulership before ascending, the act is concealed. The intent to withdraw is the same; only the timing differs.

】 "Robber Zhi" Chapter Twenty-Nine

Confucius and Liuxia Ji were friends. Liuxia Ji’s younger brother was named Robber Zhi. Robber Zhi led a band of nine thousand men, rampaging across the world, assaulting the feudal lords, breaking into chambers and smashing doors, driving off people’s oxen and horses, seizing their wives and daughters. Greedy for gain, he forgot his kin, disregarded his parents and brothers, and neglected to sacrifice to his ancestors. Wherever he passed, the great states fortified their cities, the small states took refuge in their strongholds, and the common people suffered greatly.

Confucius said to Liuxia Ji, “As a father, one must be able to instruct his son; as an elder brother, one must be able to teach his younger brother. If a father cannot instruct his son, or an elder brother cannot teach his younger brother, then the bond of father and son, elder and younger brother, is of no worth. Now, sir, you are a man of talent in this age, yet your younger brother is Robber Zhi, a scourge to the world, and you cannot teach him. I am secretly ashamed for you. Allow me to go and admonish him on your behalf.”

Liuxia Ji replied, “You say that a father must instruct his son, and an elder brother must teach his younger brother. But if a son does not heed his father’s instruction, or a younger brother does not accept his elder brother’s teaching, what can even your eloquence do? Moreover, Zhi’s nature is such that his mind surges like a spring, his will sweeps like the wind. His strength is sufficient to resist enemies, his eloquence sufficient to gloss over wrongs. When his heart is pleased, he is joyful; when it is crossed, he rages. He is quick to insult others with words. You must not go.”

Confucius did not listen. With Yan Hui driving the carriage and Zigong at his right, he went to see Robber Zhi. Robber Zhi was then resting with his followers on the southern slope of Mount Tai, mincing human livers for his meal. Confucius alighted from the carriage and approached, saying to the attendant, “I, Kong Qiu of Lu, have heard of the general’s lofty virtue and respectfully bow twice in greeting.” The attendant went in to announce him.

When Robber Zhi heard this, he flew into a great rage, his eyes blazing like stars, his hair bristling beneath his cap. “Is this not that crafty, deceitful man Kong Qiu of Lu?” he said. “Tell him for me: you fabricate words, concoct phrases, falsely invoking the names of Kings Wen and Wu. You wear a cap like a tree’s branches and a belt of dead oxhide. You prattle endlessly, weaving lies, neither plowing to eat nor weaving to clothe yourself. You flap your lips and wag your tongue, creating right and wrong to delude the rulers of the world, causing the scholars of the world to abandon their roots and recklessly fabricate filial piety and brotherly respect, hoping to gain enfeoffment and riches. Your crimes are great and grave. Flee at once, or I will add your liver to my midday meal.”

Confucius again sent word, saying, “I am fortunate to be acquainted with Ji and wish to gaze upon the hem of your robe.” The attendant went in again to announce him.

Robber Zhi said, “Bring him forward.” Confucius hastened forward, avoided the mat, stepped back, and bowed twice. Robber Zhi, greatly enraged, stretched out his legs, rested his hand on his sword, glared like a nursing tiger, and roared, “Qiu, come forward! If your words please me, you will live; if they oppose me, you will die.”

Confucius said, “I have heard that there are three virtues in the world. To be born tall and large, handsome and peerless, so that young and old, noble and base all delight in seeing you—this is the highest virtue. To comprehend heaven and earth and to distinguish all things—this is the middle virtue. To be brave, resolute, and daring, gathering followers and leading troops—this is the lowest virtue.”

“Any man possessing even one of these virtues is fit to face south and style himself a lord. Now, General, you combine all three: your body stands eight feet and two inches, your face and eyes radiant, your lips bright as cinnabar, your teeth even as strung cowries, your voice attuned to the Yellow Bell—yet you are called Robber Zhi. I, for one, feel shame on your behalf. If you are willing to heed me, I shall journey south to Wu and Yue, north to Qi and Lu, east to Song and Wei, west to Jin and Chu, to build for you a great city of several hundred *li*, establish a metropolis of several hundred thousand households, and honor you as a feudal lord. Together we shall renew the world, disband your troops, rest your soldiers, gather and nurture your brothers, and jointly sacrifice to your ancestors. This is the conduct of a sage and a man of talent, and the desire of all under heaven.”

Robber Zhi flew into a rage and said, “Qiu, come forward! Those who can be swayed by profit and admonished by words are but the foolish, common folk. Now, my great stature and beauty, which all who see delight in—are these not the legacy of my parents’ virtue? Though you do not praise me, do I not know myself? Moreover, I have heard that those who love to flatter others to their face also love to slander them behind their back. Now you tell me of great cities and teeming subjects—this is to lure me with profit and treat me as livestock. How can such things last? Of all great cities, none is greater than...”

“The world is vast indeed! Yao and Shun possessed all under heaven, yet their descendants had not even a pin’s land to stand on. Tang and Wu established themselves as Sons of Heaven, yet their posterity was cut off—was this not because the profit was too great? Moreover, I have heard that in ancient times, beasts were many and people few, so all dwelt in nests to avoid them: by day they gathered acorns and chestnuts, by night they roosted in trees, and thus they were called the people of the Nest Builder. In those days, people knew not clothing; in summer they piled up firewood, in winter they burned it for warmth, and thus they were called the people who knew how to live. In the age of Shennong, they lay at ease and rose without care; they knew their mothers but not their fathers, and lived among the deer and elk. They plowed to eat and wove to clothe themselves, with no thought of harming one another—this was the height of perfect virtue. Yet even the Yellow Emperor could not fully realize virtue: he fought Chiyou on the plains of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred li. Yao and Shun arose and appointed ministers; Tang exiled his lord, and King Wu killed Zhou. From that time onward, the strong oppressed the weak, and the many bullied the few. From Tang and Wu down, all have been the kind who bring chaos.

Now you cultivate the Way of Wen and Wu, grasp the world’s debates, and teach posterity. You wear fine robes and narrow sashes, speak with artful words and feign virtuous conduct to delude the lords of the world, all to seek wealth and honor. There is no greater thief than you! Why does the world call me Robber Zhi and not call you Robber Qiu? You sweet-talked Zilu into following you, making him cast off his warrior’s cap and lay down his long sword to receive your teachings. The world says Confucius can stop violence and forbid wrongdoing—yet in the end, it was not so. Zilu wanted to kill the lord of Wei, but the plan failed, and his body was pickled above the eastern gate of Wei. This was the result of your inadequate teaching!

Do you call yourself a man of talent and a sage? Then why were you twice driven from Lu, your traces erased in Wei, impoverished in Qi, besieged in Chen and Cai, and left with no place in the world? You taught Zilu to meet such a fate—above, you brought no benefit to yourself; below, you brought none to others. Is your Way truly worthy of esteem? Of those the world exalts, none surpasses the Yellow Emperor, yet even he could not preserve his virtue intact: he fought on the plains of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred li. Yao was not kind, Shun was not filial, Yu was paralyzed on one side, Tang exiled his lord, King Wu attacked Zhou, and King Wen was imprisoned in Youli. These six men are those the world exalts—yet upon examination, all were deluded by profit, forcing their true nature into false paths. Their conduct is truly shameful!

The world calls Boyi and Shuqi worthy men: they renounced the lordship of Gubuzhu and starved to death on Mount Shouyang, their flesh and bones left unburied. Baofu adorned his conduct to criticize the age and died clinging to a tree. Shentu Di admonished his lord and, when unheeded, carried a stone into the river to be eaten by fish and turtles. Jie Zitui was the very model of loyalty: he cut flesh from his own thigh to feed Duke Wen, yet later the duke betrayed him. Enraged, Zitui left and burned to death holding a tree. Weisheng made a tryst with a woman beneath a bridge; when she did not come and the waters rose, he would not leave but held fast to the bridge pillar and drowned. These four were no different from dismembered dogs or drifting pigs; like beggars clutching gourd ladles, they courted fame, scorned life, and forgot the root of nurturing their allotted span.

The world calls none more loyal than Prince Bigan and Wu Zixu. Zixu was drowned in the river, and Bigan had his heart cut out—these two are called loyal ministers, yet in the end they were laughed at by all under heaven. From a higher perspective, even Zixu and Bigan are not worthy of esteem. As for what you praise to me: if you speak of spirits and ghosts, I cannot know it; if you speak of human affairs, it is no more than this—all of which I have heard and understood. Now let me tell you of human nature: the eye desires to see beauty, the ear...”

The ear desires to hear sounds, the mouth to taste flavors, and the will and qi seek fulfillment. The long-lived reach a hundred years, the middling eighty, the short-lived sixty—yet within this span, discounting illness, emaciation, death, mourning, and sorrow, the days one opens their mouth to laugh number no more than four or five in a month.

Heaven and earth are without end, but human death comes at its appointed time. Grasping the implements of this fleeting span and entrusting oneself to the boundless, one vanishes in an instant—no different from a swift steed galloping past a crack in the wall. Those who cannot fulfill their aspirations and nurture their allotted years are not masters of the Dao.

All that you, Qiu, have spoken of is what I reject. Leave quickly, return home, and speak no more of it. Your Way is but a frenzied, grasping, deceitful, and hollow affair—it cannot preserve the genuine. What is there to discuss?

Confucius bowed twice, hurried out the door, mounted his carriage, and took up the reins. Three times he fumbled them, his eyes dazed and sightless, his complexion ashen like dead embers. Leaning against the crossbar, he lowered his head and could scarcely breathe. Upon returning to the eastern gate of Lu, he encountered Liuxia Ji.

Liuxia Ji said, "For days now, you have been absent, and your carriage bears the marks of travel. Might you have gone to see Zhi?"

Confucius looked to the heavens and sighed. "Indeed."

Liuxia Ji said, "Did Zhi not offend you as before?"

Confucius said, "Yes. What I did was like needlessly cauterizing oneself—racing to measure a tiger’s head, weaving through its whiskers, nearly escaping not from its jaws!"

---

Zizhang asked Mangoude, "Why not act? Without action, one is not trusted; without trust, one is not employed; without employment, one gains no benefit. Thus, when one observes fame and calculates profit, righteousness is truly in them. If one abandons fame and profit and turns inward, then how can a scholar’s conduct be absent for even a day?"

Mangoude said, "The shameless grow rich, and the trusted become eminent. The greatest of fame and profit lie in shamelessness and trust. Thus, when one observes fame and calculates profit, trust is truly in them. If one abandons fame and profit and turns inward, then a scholar’s conduct embraces their Heaven-given nature."

Zizhang said, "In ancient times, Jie and Zhou were honored as Sons of Heaven and possessed all under heaven. Yet if one told a slave or servant, ‘Your conduct resembles Jie or Zhou,’ they would flush with shame and bristle with indignation—such is the disdain of petty men. Confucius and Mo Di were impoverished commoners, yet if one told a minister, ‘Your conduct resembles Confucius or Mo Di,’ they would change countenance and protest their inadequacy—such is the esteem of true scholars. Thus, to be a Son of Heaven is not necessarily noble, nor is poverty as a commoner necessarily base. Noble or base lies in the beauty or ugliness of one’s conduct."

Mangoude said, "Petty thieves are imprisoned, while great thieves become lords. At the gates of lords, righteous scholars reside. In the past, Duke Huan of Qi killed his brother and took his sister-in-law, yet Guan Zhong served as his minister. Tian Chengzi murdered his lord and usurped the state, yet Confucius accepted his gifts. In speech, they condemned such acts; in conduct, they deferred to them—is this not a clash of principles in their hearts? Is it not perverse?

Thus, the *Book* says: ‘Who is evil? Who is good? The successful are heads; the failed are tails.’"

Zizhang said, "If you do not act, then kinship will lack order, noble and base will lack distinction, and seniority and precedence will lack sequence. How then can the Five Constants and Six Positions be differentiated?"

Mangoude said, "Yao killed his eldest son, and Shun exiled his younger brother—where is the order in kinship? Tang exiled Jie, and King Wu killed Zhou—where is the distinction in noble and base? King Ji was made heir, yet the Duke of Zhou killed his elder brother—where is the sequence in seniority? The Confucians preach hypocritical words, and the Mohists advocate universal love—how can the Five Constants and Six Positions be differentiated?

Moreover, you rectify for fame, and I rectify for profit. In substance, fame and profit do not accord with principle or reflect the Dao. Daily, I dispute with you before Wu Yue, saying: ‘The petty man pursues wealth; the gentleman pursues fame.’ Though their motives differ and their natures change, when it comes to abandoning what they do and dying for what they do not, they are the same.

Thus it is said: ‘Do not act as a petty man; instead, die for what you do not, and Heaven will be without action. Act as a gentleman, following Heaven’s principle.’ Whether crooked or straight, they serve as Heaven’s limit. Observe the four directions, and move with the times. Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism, and your intent will wander with the Dao. Without turning, act; without achieving, embody righteousness. Lose what you do, and you will not hasten to wealth; do not pursue, and you will not achieve. Abandon these, and you will align with Heaven.

Bigan had his heart cut out, and Wu Zixu had his eyes gouged—these were the calamities of loyalty. Zhigong testified against his father, and Weisheng drowned—these were the perils of trust. Bao Jiao stood as a pole and starved, and Shenzi refused to defend himself—these were the harms of integrity. Confucius did not see his mother, and Kuangzi did not see his father—these were the failures of righteousness. These are what the ancients lamented and later ages recount as lessons for scholars. Rectify your words and align your conduct, and you will suffer their misfortunes and encounter their woes."

The Guo commentary states: "This chapter speaks of exalting conduct, yet conduct becomes artificial; honoring scholars, yet scholars become false. Thus, one must despise conduct and belittle scholars to preserve one’s inner integrity—only then will conduct be lofty and scholars esteemed."

The Lü commentary states: "Good and evil stand opposed, so Confucius could not transform Robber Zhi. Fame and profit stand opposed, so Zizhang could not subdue the man of base gain. The man of base gain is one who litigates with Wu Yue—Zizhang studied to seek office, thus knowing fame; the man of base gain knows profit. Wu Yue embodied the Dao and was trustworthy. Those who do evil and pursue profit, the world calls petty men; those who do good and seek fame, the world calls noble men—this is speaking in terms of the human Dao. In terms of the Heavenly Dao, the noble man of men is the petty man of Heaven. If one follows Heaven and adheres to its principle, then noble and petty men cannot be distinguished. Crooked and straight are seen in Heaven’s center; observing the four directions and moving with the seasons, even the center is not held as fixed—this is why the Dao pervades all six directions and opens the four gates, existing everywhere without absence. Right and wrong are one; clinging to nothing, the round mechanism responds to all. Standing alone, the mind wanders with the Dao, then hesitation arises in affairs, and success is achieved in every instance. All such things are how one reaches Heaven without turning, acts without achieving, and aligns with Heaven by abandoning. This is what it means to preserve one’s Heavenly nature without letting men obstruct Heaven’s principle.

Loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and righteousness—what the world calls fame and goodness—yet all suffer calamity. People know only that profit and evil are burdens but do not realize that fame and goodness are also not the Dao. Thus, Wu Yue’s argument weighs heavily upon them."

The humble opinion states: "The two commentators’ views remain unresolved, so the man of base gain once debated with Wu Yue. Petty men pursue wealth to the end of the chapter, where Wu Yue’s words appear—both men clung to one side and did not accord with the Dao. Better to forget good and evil entirely, cling to nothing, and follow nature. Without divisions of noble and petty men, each attains the correctness of their nature and disposition. What need is there for distinctions of crooked and straight, inner and outer, right and wrong? Standing alone without being entangled by things, one wanders with the Dao without loss. If one alters natural conduct to seek the fame of righteousness or pursues wealth and profit hoping for achievement, one abandons and extinguishes Heavenly principle, drowning in the desires of things."

Wu Zu asked Zhi He: "Among men, none do not strive for fame and pursue profit. The wealthy attract followers; followers become subordinates; subordinates are honored. Those who see subordinates honored possess the way of long life, bodily ease, and joyful contentment. Why do you alone have no such intention? Is your knowledge insufficient? Do you know but lack the strength to act? Or do you deliberately uphold correctness without forgetting?"

Zhi He said: "Now, such men regard those born in the same era and dwelling in the same village as themselves, believing them to be those who transcend custom and surpass the world. They lack a fixed standard, thus surveying the times of past and present and the divisions of right and wrong. They adapt to custom and transform with the age, abandoning what is most weighty and discarding what is most honorable to pursue their own ends. How can their discussion of the way of long life, bodily ease, and joyful contentment not be far off? The pain of sorrowful illness and the peace of serene joy are not reflected in the body; the fear of alarm and the delight of happiness are not mirrored in the heart. Knowing to act but not knowing why one acts—this is why one may be honored as Son of Heaven and possess all under Heaven yet still not escape suffering."

Wu Zu said: "Wealth brings every advantage to men, exhausting beauty and perfecting power—what men cannot attain, what even sages cannot reach. Harnessing others’ courage and strength to create might, wielding others’ wisdom and plans to achieve clarity, relying on others’ virtue to become worthy—without enjoying a state’s rule, one is revered as sternly as a lord and father. Moreover, the allure of sounds, sights, flavors, and power over men’s hearts brings joy without need of learning, and the body finds comfort without need of imitation. Desires and aversions, avoidance and pursuit—these are inherent in human nature. Though all under Heaven oppose me, who can reject them?"

Zhi He said: "The wise act for a reason, moving with the people without violating their measure. Thus, they are content and do not contend; having no purpose, they do not seek. Not being content, they seek and contend, occupying all four quarters yet not considering themselves greedy. Having surplus, they decline it, abandoning all under Heaven yet not considering themselves incorrupt. The reality of incorruptibility and greed does not come from external pressure but from reflecting within and observing the measure. As Son of Heaven, one does not use nobility to arrogantly overbear others; possessing all under Heaven, one does not use wealth to toy with others. Calculating their troubles and considering the consequences, they see these as harmful to their nature, thus declining and not accepting—not to seek fame and reputation. Yao and Shun ruled as emperors yet were not harmonious, for benevolence does not benefit all under Heaven. They did not allow beauty to harm life. Shan Juan and Xu You declined the throne, not with empty words of yielding but to avoid letting affairs harm themselves. Both accepted benefit and declined harm, and all under Heaven called them worthy—yet they did not do so to seek fame and reputation."

Wu Zu said: "If one must endure hardship in name, torment the body, reject sweetness, and restrict nourishment to preserve life, one will long suffer illness and hardship without dying."

Zhi He said: "Levelness brings fortune; excess brings harm—nothing does not follow this principle, and wealth is the most extreme case. Now, the rich man’s ears are filled with the sounds of bells, drums, pipes, and flutes; his mouth savors the taste of fine meats and fine wines, disturbing his mind and causing him to neglect his affairs—this can be called chaos. Obstructed and drowned in pent-up qi, he bears a heavy burden climbing upward—this can be called suffering. Greedy for wealth, he seeks comfort; greedy for power, he seeks exhaustion. At rest, he drowns in bodily ease; in comfort, he is obstructed—this can be called illness. Pursuing wealth and profit, his ears are filled like a wall, yet he does not know to avoid obstruction and does not cease—this can be called disgrace. Wealth accumulates without use; it burdens the heart and does not leave. The mind is anxious and distressed, seeking more without end—this can be called worry. Within, he fears the threats of robbers and extortion; without, he dreads the harm of bandits and thieves. Inside, he fortifies towers and bars gates; outside, he does not dare walk alone—this can be called fear. These six are the greatest harms under Heaven. All are forgotten and unexamined, and when calamity strikes, one seeks to exhaust one’s nature and deplete one’s wealth, returning to a single day’s freedom from trouble—but it cannot be obtained. Thus, observing fame, one sees nothing; seeking profit, one gains nothing. Entangling the mind and severing the body to contend for these—is this not delusion?"

[The note on "knowledge insufficient" asks: "Is it because knowledge and strength are insufficient that one does not act? Or is it simply that one pursues the correct Dao without forgetting, thus not acting? *Feng qi* refers to pent-up, obstructed qi."]

Those who "fortify towers within and bar gates without" speak of encircling inner towers with layered defenses and opening outer pavilions for communication—this is called establishing defenses.

Guo’s annotation: *This chapter speaks of those who know contentment as ever-content.*

Lü’s annotation: *To take insufficiency as wealth is to be seen as base and esteemed as noble—this is the Way of securing the body and delighting the mind. Those who know harmony as wealth dwell together in the same life and same village, yet the world invariably esteems the base and noble. From this, it is clear that their minds lack mastery. To abandon what is most weighty and most honorable, following the ways of the world, and losing the true nature of life and destiny—this is called securing the body and delighting the mind, yet it is far off the mark. Grief and joy do not reflect in the body; fear and delight do not reflect in the mind. Then one knows acting for the sake of acting but not knowing why one acts—this is what was meant by "shooting a thousand-yard sparrow with the Marquis of Sui’s pearl." Even those of utmost wealth and nobility cannot escape suffering; how much less can those content with mere possessions, who take insufficiency as wealth? This is the nature of all people—who can refuse it? Those who know harmony yet remain discontent cannot yield their boundaries, thus contending in all directions without considering it greed. Those who know contentment take nothing in the world as their own, thus abandoning the world without considering it integrity. The reality of integrity and greed merely reflects the measure of one’s capacity—yet capacity, like vessels of varying sizes, differs among people. To claim this as the nature of all is incorrect.*

*Drowning in pent-up qi* speaks of relying on abundant resources, where one’s qi becomes arrogant and the body overflows with moisture—this is called *feng*, where the body is glossy yet one does not know how to preserve life. To such an extreme does wealth bring harm, and thus it ends.

Observing fame, one sees nothing; seeking profit, one gains nothing. Yet people entangle their minds and sever their bodies to contend for these—this is what was meant by "knowing to act for the sake of acting but not knowing why one acts." Confucius could not transform Robber Zhi; Zizhang could not tame Longfu. "Seeking gain, seeking gain"—to take what is right without restraint, to be humbled by knowing harmony—shows that good and evil, fame and profit, are insufficient to overcome one another. Only virtue and the Dao are sufficient to overcome them.

Nothing is more weighty than the body, yet nothing is more weighty than life. Now, people conform to世俗 conventions, drifting away from what is truly weighty, discarding reverence to pursue their own ends—how then can they discuss the Dao of preserving the body and delighting the mind? How could they draw near to it? In poverty and lowliness, they tremble with fear; in wealth and nobility, they rejoice with elation—this is to obscure the root and boast of mere traces.

Those who act for the sake of acting strive for fame and pursue profit, yet do not know that wealth and nobility arise of themselves. To abandon what arises of itself and desire to strive for them is to know that one cannot escape [the consequences]. The ants in a mound of dirt gather only around rank odors; scholars who cover their faces in shame scorn even the offer of food. Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; people forget one another in the Dao and its arts—what need is there to rely on external things? Why cling to them?

Those who indulge without restraint delight in music and beauty; those who are arrogant and extravagant find comfort in power and influence—this is human nature. Who does not desire these? Yet when the common people act, it is not for themselves. Not transgressing their measure, reducing selfishness, and diminishing desires—those who contend on all sides speak of campaigning in the four directions, their aim being to pacify the people, not to profit from treasures. Thus, they are not deemed greedy. When their achievements are complete and their fame established, they abdicate in favor of the worthy—neither do they consider themselves paragons of integrity.

Prince Sou fled into the cinnabar caves; Yan He fed oxen and declined official appointments—did they seek fame and reputation? Shun offered the world to Shan Juan, yet Shan Juan plowed on without a glance—did he strive for fame and reputation?

The greedy and rapacious regard tranquility and simplicity as affliction, solitude as distress, unaware that ease is fortune and excess is harm. Wealth brings swift disaster, more grievous than other things, yet the世俗 world does not awaken to this. From the perspective of those who embody tranquility and solitude, bells and drums, fine wine and rich food lead to the ruin of the Dao and its works. Those who seek comfort in power and influence drown in bodily illness; those who snatch gold without regard suffer more than execution or humiliation. Hoarding without satiety, their anxieties and fears never cease—once disaster strikes and their bodies are overthrown, they wish only for their accumulated wealth to be quickly exhausted.

At such a time, their true nature is already exhausted, their goods and wealth already depleted. They long to release hawks on the plains of Cai or hear the cries of cranes in Huating—how could these ever be regained?

---

Yang Yongxiu’s commentary:
*Chén nì yú féng qì* (侅溺于冯气): The old annotation reads, "From eating and drinking to swallowing is *chén*; *féng* means fullness, as in 'swollen with arrogance.'" However, *féng* should be pronounced as in *féng hé* (冯河, "crossing the river"), for the wealthy accumulate resources as if bearing a heavy burden—already difficult, yet they proceed further, making it even more arduous. Thus, it is said, "This can truly be called suffering." Below, "In stillness, one drowns; in glossiness, one is full" further explains *chén nì yú féng qì*. In stillness, one drowns—indulgence is like poison, deluded by music and beauty, sinking without water. Thus, it is said, "Drowning." *Tǐ zé zé féng* (体泽则冯) means bustling about like one crossing a river on foot, only to sink into the nine depths. Thus, it is said, *féng*—why must it be read as "arrogance"?

---

Liu Gai’s general discussion:
In the world, there is no inherent right or wrong—right and wrong arise from human emotions. Yet in the world, there *is* right and wrong, and right and wrong dissolve in human nature. The virtue of affirming is auspicious; the virtue of negating is inauspicious. The *Yi* says, "Auspicious and inauspicious are the triumph of correctness." Those who cannot guard correctness and equalize forgetfulness, yet entangle themselves in the realm of action—each thing values itself and devalues others. Who can settle this? Thus, even the distinction between Confucius and Robber Zhi becomes a matter of calling one another thieves.

Zhuangzi was not ignorant of the need to honor Confucius and despise Robber Zhi. Yet because世俗 people do not awaken to the principle of equalizing forgetfulness, they contend with knowledge, boast of ability, and if one further indulges emotions to honor them, right and wrong become even more pronounced, and the true nature of life and destiny grows ever more chaotic. Therefore, he borrowed what the world universally condemns to describe its self-righteous emotions—even a sage could not prevail in debate. Thus, the final chapter deems Zizhang’s words inappropriate and concludes with the discourse on "knowing harmony."

**Records of Cinnabar and Lead**

Shao Yaofu remarked: "In the *Robber Zhi* chapter of the *Zhuangzi*, matters of utter helplessness—even a sage can do nothing about them. Though the cook does not prepare the feast, the invocator does not presume to take his place beyond the wine vessels and sacrificial stands. This speaks to the gentleman’s thought never straying beyond his station."

Yang Zhongli observed: "The *Free and Easy Wandering* chapter embodies what Zisi called ‘the gentleman finds fulfillment in every circumstance.’ The *Preserving Life’s Integrity* chapter reflects what Mencius meant by ‘acting without contrivance.’ If one reads the *Zhuangzi* with this understanding, one may discuss the Nine Schools with those of perfect discernment. Those who fault the *Zhuangzi* simply do not read it well."

---

**Chapter Thirty: The Sword Banquet**

Long ago, King Wen of Zhao delighted in swords. Over three thousand swordsmen lodged as guests at his gates, clashing before him day and night. Each year, more than a hundred died or were wounded, yet his passion never waned. After three years of this, the state declined, and the feudal lords plotted against him. The crown prince, Kui, grew anxious and offered a reward to his attendants: "Whoever can please the king and put an end to the swordsmen will receive a thousand gold pieces."

His attendants said, "Zhuangzi is the one for this."

The crown prince sent envoys bearing a thousand gold pieces to present to Zhuangzi, but he refused. Accompanying the envoys back, he asked the crown prince, "What instruction do you have for me, that you bestow a thousand gold pieces upon me?"

The crown prince replied, "I have heard that you are enlightened and sagely. I humbly offer this thousand gold as a gift for your attendants. Since you refuse it, how dare I speak further?"

Zhuangzi said, "I have heard that you wish to employ me to dissuade the king from his obsession. If I were to admonish the king and offend him, failing to meet your expectations, I would face execution. How then could I make use of the gold? But if I satisfy the king above and meet your wishes below, what in Zhao could I not obtain?"

The crown prince said, "Indeed. Yet my father sees only swordsmen."

Zhuangzi replied, "Very well. I am skilled in the sword."

The crown prince said, "But the swordsmen my father sees all have unkempt hair, bristling sideburns, slouching caps with coarse tassels, short jackets, glaring eyes, and speak with difficulty. The king delights in them. If you, sir, appear before him in Confucian robes, the matter will surely go awry."

Zhuangzi said, "Allow me to prepare my sword attire."

After three days, he completed his sword attire and met the crown prince, who then accompanied him to see the king. The king, bare blade in hand, awaited him.

Zhuangzi entered the palace hall without haste and did not bow to the king. The king asked, "What would you teach me, that you have the crown prince precede you?"

Zhuangzi replied, "I have heard that Your Majesty delights in the sword, so I have come to present my swordsmanship."

The king asked, "What can your sword do?"

Zhuangzi said, "My sword can cut down one man every ten paces and travel a thousand *li* without hindrance."

The king, greatly pleased, exclaimed, "You would be invincible in the world!"

Zhuangzi said, "The way of the sword is to show emptiness, offer advantage, strike after the opponent moves, and arrive before he does. I would like to demonstrate."

The king said, "Sir, rest at your lodging and await my command. I will arrange a contest and summon you."

The king then tested his swordsmen for seven days, during which over sixty died or were wounded. He selected five or six and had them stand with their swords in the palace courtyard, then summoned Zhuangzi.

"Today, let us see these gentlemen engage in swordplay," the king said.

Zhuangzi replied, "I have longed for this."

The king asked, "Sir, what length of weapon do you wield?"

Zhuangzi said, "Any length will do, but I have three swords, and Your Majesty may choose which to use. Allow me to describe them before demonstrating."

The king said, "I wish to hear of the three swords."

Zhuangzi said, "There is the Son of Heaven’s sword, the feudal lord’s sword, and the commoner’s sword."

The king asked, "What is the Son of Heaven’s sword like?"

Zhuangzi said, "The Son of Heaven’s sword has Yanxi and Shicheng as its point, Mount Tai of Qi as its edge, Jin and Wei as its spine, Zhou and Song as its hilt, and Han and Wei as its guard. It is wrapped in the Four Barbarians, bound by the Four Seasons, encircled by the Bohai Sea, and girded by Mount Chang. It is governed by the Five Phases, judged by punishment and virtue, opened by yin and yang, sustained by spring and summer, and wielded in autumn and winter. When thrust forward, nothing stands before it; when raised, nothing is above it; when pressed down, nothing is beneath it; when swung, nothing lies beside it. Above, it cleaves the floating clouds; below, it severs the earth’s foundations. When this sword is used once, it rectifies the feudal lords, and the world submits. This is the Son of Heaven’s sword."

King Wen, lost in thought, asked, "What is the feudal lord’s sword like?"

Zhuangzi said, "The feudal lord’s sword has the wise and brave as its point, the pure and incorrupt as its edge, the worthy and good as its spine, the loyal and sagely as its hilt, and the heroic and outstanding as its guard. When thrust forward, nothing stands before it; when raised, nothing is above it; when pressed down, nothing is beneath it; when swung, nothing lies beside it. Above, it models the round heavens, following the Three Luminaries; below, it models the square earth, following the Four Seasons. Within, it harmonizes the people’s will and brings peace to the four directions. When this sword is used once, it is like the shock of thunder. Within the four borders, none dare resist; all obey the ruler’s command. This is the feudal lord’s sword."

The king asked, "What is the commoner’s sword like?"

Zhuangzi said, "The commoner’s sword is wielded by those with unkempt hair, bristling sideburns, slouching caps with coarse tassels, short jackets, glaring eyes, and harsh speech. They clash before you, striking above at necks and throats, below at livers and lungs. This is no different from fighting cocks—one morning, their lives are cut short, and they are of no use to the state. Now, Your Majesty occupies the position of Son of Heaven yet delights in the commoner’s sword. I humbly deem this unworthy of you."

The king then led Zhuangzi up to the hall, where the royal chef served the feast. The king circled the table three times.

Zhuangzi said, "Your Majesty, sit calmly and compose yourself. The matter of the sword is concluded."

Thereafter, King Wen did not leave his palace for three months, and the swordsmen all died by their own hands in their lodgings.

The mouth of the sword is called the *tan*; the hilt is called the *jia*. One account says: the *tan* follows the ridge toward the spine, while the *jia* follows the ridge toward the blade. The "three circuits" refer to King Wen’s shame upon hearing Zhuangzi’s words—he circled the feast twice but could not sit to eat. "Serving and perishing" means that, enraged at not being shown courtesy, the swordsmen all took their own lives.

Lu’s Commentary:
Zhuangzi’s conduct and aspirations were to drag his tail through the mud rather than become a sacrificial beast in the grand ancestral temple. To awaken the world from its perilous custom of risking life for mere objects, the art of the sword was perhaps unheard of—yet he borrowed it to illustrate that the Dao’s application knows no bounds. If one can curb a ruler’s obsessions and secure a state’s stability, the blessings bestowed are no small matter.

The Son of Heaven’s sword takes all under Heaven as its blade. This is to say: the divine instrument of all under Heaven cannot be wielded lightly. He demonstrates its emptiness, opens with advantage, follows with what comes after, and initiates with what precedes—thus employing the way of the divine instrument. Though it "cannot be wielded," one wields it nonetheless. To know its root and branches, its weight and measure, the method of its governance, and the moment of its application is to wield it so that all under Heaven submits.

From Yanxi and Mount Tai to the Bohai Sea and Mount Heng—this illustrates the Son of Heaven’s sword, which takes all under Heaven as its blade. From the Five Phases and the balance of punishment and virtue to the severing of earth’s ties—this illustrates the timeless, boundless nature of the divine. Only a spirit-like person can master the divine instrument, thus rectifying the feudal lords and bringing all under Heaven to submission. Such was Zhuangzi’s way of the sword. King Wen, upon hearing this, was struck dumb with realization, knowing his own fondness was not for the true sword.

The feudal lords’ sword takes a single state as its blade, hence it is spoken of in terms of the *shi* (knight). The *shi* is the people’s hope. Courage and valor lead the way, thus forming the tip. Integrity and uprightness follow, thus forming the edge. Worthiness and excellence lean upon it, thus forming the spine. Loyalty and sagacity are planted within, thus forming the *tan*. The heroic and outstanding are what one grasps and employs, thus forming the *jia*. For those who govern a state, observing what serves as tip, edge, spine, *tan*, and *jia*—whether they align or not—reveals whether the weapon is sharp or dull, and whether the state is secure or imperiled.

Though the scale of all under Heaven and a single state differs, the spirit in which they are wielded is one and the same. When asked about the commoner’s sword, Zhuangzi directly pointed to the king’s own predilection to correct his error.

Liu’s Summary:
In the nature of all things under Heaven, none do not disparage the different while revering the same, discard the small while admiring the great—even to the point of shunning harm and pursuing profit, which is often the case. If something does not align with oneself, though advantageous, it is not followed; though the benefit be great, it is not admired.

Zhuangzi’s discourse on the Dao in this chapter, extending even to the words of swordsmen and wandering persuaders, conceals profound principles in subtle allusions, necessarily employing such language to achieve his aim. The nature of things inherently values the self and devalues others, naturally affirms the self and negates others. To seek unity with others despite such differences—even the sagacity of Confucius would bow before the brutality of Robber Zhi.

Yet by leveraging what is shared to overcome others, Zhuangzi’s single remark severed King Zhao’s lifelong obsession—this was indeed the principle at work. The bristling sideburns, slouching caps, coarse tassels, short jackets, glaring eyes, and harsh speech were the king’s preferences, not Zhuangzi’s. Now, by altering his usual demeanor and changing his usual attire, the king would come to respect what he had once disdained.

First discussing the Son of Heaven, then the feudal lords, and finally the commoner, the king would come to admire what was grand. Grandness commands all under Heaven; next, it welcomes the four borders; below, it severs necks and throats—he would thus pursue what was advantageous. The nature of things does not extend beyond this. The sage harmonizes and responds, nurturing things as one rears creatures. Thus, the multitude of monkeys submitted to the morning-four, evening-three trick—was there not a method to this?

As for bending oneself without ever straightening another—Zhuangzi’s persuasion through the sword seems to seek alignment. Yet even Robber Zhi and the Fisherman were not his true concerns. The grand intent of his words was mutual critique, though the principle was subtle. To press for traces and seek meaning is to misunderstand the speaker.

The Fisherman, Chapter Thirty-One

Confucius wandered in the forest of black curtains and rested, seated upon the Apricot Platform. His disciples read aloud while Confucius hummed a tune, plucking the zither. Halfway through the melody, a fisherman descended from his boat and approached. His beard and brows were snowy white, his hair unbound, and his sleeves swaying as he strode across the plain until he reached the shore. There he halted, his left hand resting on his knee, his right hand cradling his chin, listening to the music. When the piece ended, he beckoned to Zilu and Zigong. Both stepped forward to face the stranger, who pointed at Confucius and asked, “What manner of man is he?”

Zilu replied, “A gentleman of Lu.”

The stranger inquired about his lineage, and Zilu answered, “The Kong clan.”

“And what does the Kong clan govern?”

Zilu did not respond, but Zigong answered, “The Kong clan cultivates loyalty and trust in their nature, embodies benevolence and righteousness in their conduct, refines ritual and music, and selects proper human relations. Above, they serve the lords of the age with loyalty; below, they transform the common people. They seek to benefit all under Heaven—this is what the Kong clan governs.”

The stranger asked again, “Is he a lord with lands?”

Zigong said, “No.”

“Is he an advisor to kings and princes?”

Zigong said, “No.”

The stranger laughed and turned to leave, saying as he walked, “Benevolent, indeed, he is—but I fear he will not escape suffering. His heart toils, his form labors, endangering his true nature. Alas, how far removed he is from the Dao!”

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius. Confucius pushed aside his zither and rose, saying, “Was he a sage?” He then descended to seek him, reaching the marsh’s edge, where the stranger was poised to pole his boat away. Turning, he saw Confucius and stood facing his homeland. Confucius retreated, bowed twice, and approached, saying, “What do you seek, Master?”

The stranger replied, “A moment ago, you left with words unfinished. I, unworthy as I am, did not grasp their meaning. I have waited humbly below, hoping to hear the sound of your cough or whisper, that I might fully assist you.”

The stranger said, “Ah! How earnest is your love of learning!”

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, “From my youth, I have cultivated learning, and now, at sixty-nine, I have yet to hear the ultimate teaching. How dare I not empty my heart?”

The stranger said, “Like seeks like, and sounds resonate in harmony—this is the principle of Heaven. I shall set aside what I possess and expound for you the Way of your endeavor. Your endeavor is human affairs. The Son of Heaven, the feudal lords, the great officers, and the common people—these four ranks, when properly ordered, bring the finest governance. When these four depart from their stations, no greater disorder arises. When offices fulfill their duties and people attend to their tasks, none encroach upon another. Thus, fields are tilled, homes stand firm, clothing and food suffice, taxes are not levied unjustly, wives and concubines live in harmony, and elders and youth observe proper order—these are the concerns of the common people. Inability to bear office, failure to govern, impure conduct, subordinates’ negligence, unrecognized merit, and unheld ranks and emoluments—these are the concerns of the great officers. The court lacking loyal ministers, the state in chaos, craftsmen’s work unskillful, tribute unworthy, the seasons out of sequence, and the Son of Heaven and feudal lords disobeying Heaven’s order—these are the concerns of the Son of Heaven and the feudal lords. Yin and yang out of harmony, cold and heat untimely, harming the myriad things, feudal lords violent and usurping, waging war to devastate the people, ritual and music unrestrained, resources exhausted, human relations disordered, and the hundred clans licentious—these are the concerns of the Son of Heaven’s ministers.

Now, you possess neither the authority of a lord or minister above nor the office of a great officer below, yet you presume to regulate ritual and music, select human relations, and transform the common people. Is this not excessive meddling? Moreover, people have eight flaws, and affairs have four perils—these must not go unexamined.

To engage in affairs not one’s own is called *zong*; to advance without regard is called *ning*; to speak to curry favor is called *chan*; to speak without discerning right or wrong is called *yu*; to delight in others’ faults is called *chan*; to sever bonds and estrange kin is called *zei*; to praise falsely and corrupt others is called *te*; to fail to choose good or ill, to accommodate both sides, and to stealthily seize what one desires is called *xian*. These eight flaws externally disorder others and internally harm oneself. The noble person does not befriend such, and the enlightened lord does not employ them.

The four perils are: to love managing great affairs, altering constants to claim merit, is called *tao*; to monopolize knowledge, arrogate affairs, encroach upon others, and act self-righteously is called *tan*; to see faults yet not change, to hear admonitions yet grow worse, is called *hen*; to approve of what aligns with oneself yet disapprove of what does not, even if good, is called *jin*. These are the four perils. Only when one has removed the eight flaws and refrained from the four perils can one be taught.”

Confucius sighed deeply, bowed twice, and rose, saying, “I was twice driven from Lu, my traces erased in Wei, my tree felled in Song, and I was besieged between Chen and Cai. I do not know what I have lost to incur these four slanders—what is it?”

The stranger’s expression turned somber as he said, “How difficult it is for you to awaken!”

A man feared his shadow and loathed his footprints, so he fled from them. The more he lifted his feet, the more footprints appeared; the faster he ran, the more his shadow clung to him. Believing himself still too slow, he ran without rest, exhausted his strength, and died—never realizing that if he had stood in shade, his shadow would have vanished, or if he had remained still, his footprints would have ceased. How utterly foolish!

You scrutinize the boundaries between benevolence and righteousness, examine the distinctions between sameness and difference, observe the shifts between movement and stillness, measure the degrees of giving and receiving, weigh the inclinations of likes and dislikes, and harmonize the moderation of joy and anger—yet you still nearly fail to escape. If you diligently cultivate yourself, guard your true nature with care, and return things to others, you will have no encumbrances.

Now, if you do not cultivate yourself but seek it from others, is this not misplaced?

Confucius, with a solemn expression, said, “May I ask what is meant by *true*?”

The stranger replied, “*True* is the utmost of essence and sincerity. Without essence and sincerity, one cannot move others. Thus, forced weeping, though sorrowful, is not mournful; forced anger, though stern, is not awe-inspiring; forced affection, though smiling, is not harmonious. True sorrow is mournful without sound; true anger is awe-inspiring before it erupts; true affection is harmonious before it smiles. When truth resides within, the spirit moves without—this is why truth is prized.

When applied to human affairs: serving parents with filial devotion, serving rulers with loyal integrity, drinking with joyful abandon, mourning with profound grief—loyal integrity takes merit as its aim, drinking takes joy as its aim, mourning takes grief as its aim, and serving parents takes comfort as its aim. The beauty of merit’s completion leaves no trace.

Serving parents with comfort does not debate the means; drinking with joy does not select the vessels; mourning with grief does not inquire after rites. Rites are what the common customs devise; truth is what one receives from Heaven. It is natural and cannot be altered. Thus, the sage models Heaven, values truth, and does not adhere to convention. The foolish do the opposite: they cannot model Heaven but fret over others, do not value truth, and meekly submit to the whims of custom. How pitiful! You have long been steeped in artifice and only now hear of the great Dao.”

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, “Today, I have had the good fortune to meet you. If Heaven has favored me, and you do not disdain to treat me as a servant, instructing me in person—may I ask where you dwell? I would follow to receive your teachings and complete my study of the great Dao.”

The stranger said, “I have heard: one who can be led may be guided to the subtle Dao; one who cannot be led does not understand the Way. Be careful not to accompany such a person, lest you bring misfortune upon yourself. Strive on—I leave you now.” He poled his boat away, gliding along the reeds.

Yan Yuan turned the carriage, and Zilu handed the reins. Confucius did not look back, waiting until the water’s ripples stilled and the sound of the oar vanished before daring to board. Zilu stepped aside from the carriage and asked, “I have served you for a long time, yet never have I seen you meet another with such reverence. Even the lords of ten thousand chariots or the rulers of a thousand have never failed to receive you with equal courtesy, yet you still bore a haughty demeanor. Now, this old fisherman stands before you with his staff, and you bow deeply, bending at the waist, responding with words of deference. Have you not gone too far? Your disciples all find this strange—how has this fisherman earned such treatment?”

Confucius leaned on the crossbar and sighed, “How difficult it is to transform you, You! You have been steeped in ritual and righteousness for some time, yet your coarse and vulgar heart remains. Let me tell you: to meet one’s elders without respect is discourteous; to meet the worthy without reverence is unkind. If he were not perfectly kind, he could not humble himself before others. If one does not humble oneself with utmost sincerity, one cannot attain truth. Thus, to lack kindness harms oneself—what greater misfortune is there? Yet you alone indulge in this. Moreover, the Dao is the source of all things. Those who lose it die; those who attain it live. To act against it is to fail; to follow it is to succeed. Thus, wherever the Dao resides, the sage honors it. This old fisherman possesses the Dao—how dare I not revere him?”

The term "common folk" (齊民) refers to the ordinary people; after the Spring and Autumn period, they were excluded from the ranks of those attending court audiences. "Both cheeks in harmony" (兩容頰適) describes a countenance that accommodates both good and evil, its appearance composed and balanced.

Guo’s commentary:
This chapter speaks of one who, though not of rivers and seas, can humble himself before those of rivers and seas. Was what Confucius taught and undertook limited to the fisherman alone? He would circulate through the six directions, penetrating all without boundary, so that even the crawling creatures could fully express what they harbored, exhausting principle and reaching destiny—this is precisely the Way of the perfected person.

Lü’s commentary:
If Confucius embodied his nature, embraced the spirit, and wandered through the world, how could he have suffered the fisherman’s reproach? The reason for speaking thus is that those in later ages who study Confucius grasp only his traces. Thus, he employed the fisherman as a metaphor to clarify that what Confucius valued was beyond the understanding of the vulgar. What Zigong reported to the fisherman was merely what the worldly Confucians knew of Confucius. Though the world is vast, it is but a thing. What made Confucius Confucius—who would willingly take things as his affairs? The true essence of the Dao is for governing the self; its remnants and dregs are for governing the state and the world. If things were truly as Zigong described, then to undertake tasks beyond one’s capacity would be to stray far from the Dao. How could he not incur the eight flaws and four maladies? Observing those in later ages who grasped only Confucius’s traces and examining their conduct, one sees that Zhuangzi’s words, even a thousand years later, remain as if witnessed firsthand. Can this not be called a spirit-like person?

*Zhuangzi Yi*, Scroll Seven
*Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*

*Zhuangzi Yi*, Scroll Eight
By Jiao Hong of the Ming Dynasty

**Lie Yukou, Chapter Thirty-Three**

Lie Yukou was on his way to Qi when he turned back mid-journey. He encountered Bohun Maoren, who asked, "Why have you returned?"

"I was startled," Lie Yukou replied.

"By what?"

"I dined at ten soup stalls, and at five of them, they served me first."

Bohun Maoren said, "If this is so, why were you startled?"

Lie Yukou answered, "When inner sincerity is not dissolved, the outward form radiates light, thereby overawing others’ hearts and causing them to slight their elders and guard against harm. Those soup vendors merely peddle their wares for profit, seeking surplus gain. Their power is meager, and even so, they act thus—how much more so with the lord of ten thousand chariots? His body toils for the state, and his knowledge is exhausted by affairs. He would entrust me with tasks and demand results from me. This is why I was startled."

Bohun Maoren said, "Excellent observation! Now, watch how you conduct yourself—others will safeguard you."

No sooner had he spoken than the shoes outside the door were filled to overflowing.

Bohun Maoren stood facing north, leaning on his staff, his chin nearly touching it. After a moment, without a word, he went out. The attendant informed Liezi, who rushed to the door barefoot, shoes in hand.

"Since you have come, Master," he said, "why have you not offered a remedy?"

"It is already done."

"Indeed, I told you that others would safeguard you, and now they truly do. It is not that you can make others safeguard you, nor that you can prevent them from doing so—why then this emotional response, this display of surprise? There must be some stirring of feeling that shakes your inborn nature, yet this is meaningless. None of those who wander with you would tell you this. Their petty words are all poison to men. None awaken, none comprehend—how could they scrutinize one another? The cunning toil, the wise worry, the incapable seek nothing, eating and wandering freely like an untethered boat, empty and drifting."

[The annotations in the original text are not translated as they constitute interpretive commentary.]

The reverence for elders speaks of how things are stabilized through inner substance—this is why people’s respect for elders is sincere. Guarding against misfortune speaks of how refined appearances move others, yet what they guard against is the chaos of the master. The vendor’s influence is light, their profit meager; they need seek nothing from others. As for those who safeguard you, if you do not abandon your form, you will be protected wherever you go—"protection" means gathering and keeping watch. If you act with impartiality and transform through it, there will be no stirring, no seeking; without stirring or seeking, there is no mutual safeguarding. The first to bestow favors does so without prior intent—this is what makes it extraordinary.

If there must be some stirring, it moves against your original nature. Petty cleverness and subtle words enter people—only the sage is without such ability. From this point downward to the insects, none forget their own abilities to entrust themselves to the multitude.

---

The sage wears coarse cloth yet holds jade within, preserving their form and life, concealing themselves without tiring of depth or obscurity. If inner sincerity is not dissolved, one cannot yet still the heart and manifest its radiance—this can be discerned as if by spies, and is no way to conceal oneself. Eating from ten vendors, half of whom offer first, is to rely on externals to stabilize others’ hearts, causing them to slight elders and esteem oneself—this invites misfortune and brings it upon oneself. Guarding is like bearing gifts; only by responding to stirrings does one embody nature, embracing spirit to wander through the world—only then can one make others cease their safeguarding. To stand out is to fail in concealing one’s use; to stir in advance is to disturb and lose one’s original nature—the great peril of nurturing the heart and preserving spirit. Thus, to speak without revealing and to utter petty words is poison, yet none awaken, none comprehend—how could they scrutinize one another? Their influence permeates like incense, gradually shaping those who study, so they toil and worry. Those who follow the Way daily diminish, shedding knowledge and craft to return to a state of no ability—adrift like an untethered boat, empty and wandering.

---

Nature is like water: frozen, it becomes ice; melted, it returns to water. Frozen, its form does not change; melted, its use is boundless. The mind of the perfected person is as ice about to melt, returning to clarity—where is there any radiance to externally stabilize? As for those who inwardly pride themselves on true wisdom yet cannot dissolve it, when things become knotted, their mannerisms form a sheen—others can secretly observe them, as with vendors whose influence is light and profit meager. They are thus slighted, their reverence for elders guarded against as a source of misfortune—a defense against chaos.

The peril lies in its multitude of arrivals—offering the five brews first as alarm reveals one adept at inward contemplation. In one’s own conduct, one claims to leave no form behind; standing northward, one distinguishes among things. Pressing the staff close, one furrows the brow—cheeks forget the self, words emerge without speech. Yet when Liezi grasps his shoes and runs barefoot, he has not yet silently grasped the teaching of wordlessness.

One may not lose virtue yet not reach the supreme virtue of non-virtue; one may know the Dao that leaves traces yet not attain the constant Dao of no-mind—thus one cannot make others free of reliance on you. To deem the inability to free others from reliance a peril differs from those who make others rely on you. The one who moves first to influence acts preemptively; Liezi never once set forth the extraordinary to move things. Yet when others come to rely on him, it is because something has moved them unawares.

Once moved, they tax your spirit and unsettle your essence, daily debating with those who tread your doorstep—do their words truly hold meaning? Thus it is said: agitation uproots one’s nature, and still there is no meaning. Those who wander with you sink together into the perils of the human way, so none know where to lodge their petty words—how could they deliver the medicine of ultimate speech? Such is the shared plight: lost on the path, things and self achieve nothing.

Thus it is said: none awaken, none realize—what comparison can there be? Following the root, those whose inner sincerity remains unbroken cannot attain the central void. Those who scheme outwardly to craft an aura of radiance cannot dissolve into tracelessness. Outwardly, one may be spied upon and their brilliance fashioned into spectacle for others to scrutinize. Guarding against this is like fermenting brine—what one fears is abandoning one’s natural state to pursue external reverence, thus inviting peril. Those who rely on you are drawn to you as a means of protection, just as in the *Records of the Han*, Xiao and Cao feared crossing the city walls to protect the Gaozu Emperor—here, *dun* (protection) and *fang* (guard) share the same resonance. To furrow one’s brow, leaning on a staff until flesh wrinkles—this is *cu* (constriction). To act preemptively is to respond to what has not yet come to pass; thus, the proof of extraordinary influence must lie in some prior stirring, which then unsettles your fundamental nature. Meaningless, devoid of anyone to speak to—even those who wander with you will offer no counsel. Petty words are the clever, insinuating speech that harms others. *Shu* (who, what) is an interrogative: none can awaken or realize, so what is there to compare?

Among the people of Zheng, there was Huan. In the land of Qiu, he chanted and intoned for three years, becoming a Confucian. His influence seeped like a river moistening nine *li*, nourishing three clans. He sent his younger brother Mo to study Mohism, and the two debated for a decade, until Huan, aiding Di, took his own life. His father appeared to him in a dream, saying: *"If your son were to become a Mohist, it would be I who made him so."* Hu once examined the mulberry—it had already borne the fruit of autumn cypress. The Creator’s retribution does not punish the person but the Heaven within the person. Thus, it caused that man to regard himself as exceptional, distinct from others, and to despise his kin. Among the people of Qi, those who drew water from the well would brawl. Thus it is said: in this age, all are Huan. Even those with virtue do so unknowingly—how much more so those with the Dao? The ancients called this "the punishment of fleeing from Heaven."

Guo’s commentary:
*Shen-yin* refers to chanting and intoning. *Zhi* means "to go." Di was Huan’s younger brother. Huan resented his father for aiding his brother, so in a surge of emotion, he killed himself. In death, he appeared in a dream, saying that since he had already transformed himself into a Confucian and transformed his brother into a Mohist, his brother, though shaped by him, could not follow his lead. He had taken a fine teacher as his enemy and died in resentment—such was the depth of his sincerity that he became the fruit of autumn cypress. From *"The Creator"* onward are the words of Zhuangzi.

The power of accumulated practice is retribution—it repays one’s nature, not one’s actions. Thus, the work of study and habit perfects one’s nature, but is this truly for its own sake? That which possesses its own nature is made to cultivate it. Huan prided himself on his Confucianism, believing it the fruit of his accumulated learning, unaware that it was the natural unfolding of his nature. Those who take merit in despising others do not spare even their kin. Those who forget the self to harmonize their nature do not lose sight of the proper order, whether noble or base. Digging a well is for channeling the spring; chanting and intoning are for channeling one’s nature. Without a spring, there is nothing to dig; without nature, there is nothing to chant. Yet the world forgets the natural spring and nature, fixating only on the superficial work of digging and chanting. Desiring to claim these as their own merit—is this not delusion? Observe Huan’s folly: he believed that studying his father enabled him to act as he did, yet how could he have known that it was effortless, arising from the space between things? Those who take the power of nature as their own achievement are those who flee from Heaven.

Thus, when punishment and execution befall them—Lu’s annotation states: Huan styled himself a Confucian yet compelled his younger brother to become a Mohist, leading them to debate one another. Their father sided with Di, and Huan took his own life—all this was merely the doing of the man. As for Huan’s becoming a Confucian and Di’s becoming a Mohist, that was the Heaven of the man. Judging by the man, father and son, elder and younger brother, were not of one mind; Confucianism and Mohism divided their pursuits. Judging by the Heaven of the man, they were one and the same. What their father dreamed of was Huan’s Heaven; Huan’s Heaven was his younger brother’s Heaven, yet Huan did not act as Huan. To say that Di became a Mohist was truly Heaven’s doing—goodness was received from nature, not something attainable through study—it was simply Heaven. To call his younger brother’s actions his own and claim his own Heaven as goodness was to forget the words of father and son, elder and younger brother.
