To study Confucianism and become a Confucian, to study Mohism and become a Mohist, or for Huan to become a cypress fruit—all were repayment, all were Heaven’s doing. Yet people do not know that what moves them to aid others is never different from themselves. They take themselves as possessing something distinct from others, even to the point of despising their kin, as Huan did—is this not lamentable? This is no different from the man of Qi who claimed a well as his own, leading to mutual brawling. The world, not knowing its Heaven, despises others and exalts itself—all are Huan. Tracing the source of such loss of nature, it lies in possessing knowledge. Those with virtue preserve their Heaven by not knowing. How much more so for those who embody the Dao?

Those with knowledge flee from Heaven; fleeing from Heaven, they betray their true nature and cannot avoid returning to it—thus the ancients called this "the punishment of fleeing from Heaven." Following the root: "Moaning and reciting for three years, only three years, and Confucian learning is complete." The river moistens nine li, a metaphor for beneficence extending to the three clans—speaking of Confucians who receive emoluments and extend grace to their clans. *Hé* means "all," *hé* and *hú* both mean "why." In a dream, he spoke with his father in earnest tones: "I provided for you, yet you studied Mohism—it was I!" But when had his father ever regarded him with favor? "After my death, I will become the fruit of the catalpa on my grave." Zhuangzi cited this and concluded: The Creator’s repayment to man does not stoop to repaying what man has done; it often repays what man cannot do. Huan, however, demanded repayment for what he had done—this was his error. The Creator truly enabled his brother to become a Mohist, yet Huan, relying on himself, despised his kin. This is like the man of Qi who drank from a well and fought over it: the well made no distinction between giving and taking, yet the drinkers fought among themselves—this was ignorance of Heaven. Today, all people are like Huan. From this, we see that those of virtue regard the Creator’s repayment as unknowable—how much more so for those who embody the Dao? Those who embody the Dao entrust everything to nature.

The ancients called those like Huan "fugitives from Heaven’s principle." General meaning: The two sentences *hé hú* lack depth in all interpretations—why did the father not see his younger brother’s goodness, like autumn or the cypress fruit, ripening his talent and unfolding his vitality, yet instead sided with his brother to bring about my death? A decade of old resentment—his Confucianism is evident. Lu Deming: The digger of the well claimed credit for creating the spring, yet those who fought over drinking did not know the spring’s emergence was Heaven’s doing. Huan took credit for making his brother a Mohist and resented his father for not recognizing Zhai’s ability to become a Mohist—this too was Heaven’s doing.

The sage finds peace in what is naturally peaceful and does not seek peace in what is not; the multitude finds peace in what is not naturally peaceful and does not find peace in what is. Guo’s commentary: The sage is neither at peace nor not at peace, following the hearts of the people. What brings peace differs, and thus they are the multitude. Lü’s commentary: What is peaceful is Heaven; what is not peaceful is man. Following the root: These few lines suffice to convey the above meaning—Huan was one who did not find peace.

Zhuangzi said: Knowing the Dao is easy; not speaking of it is difficult. To know and not speak is to follow Heaven; to know and speak is to follow man. The ancients followed Heaven and not man. Guo’s commentary: Though knowledge pervades Heaven and Earth, they never spoke to lead others, merely responding to what was fitting. Lü’s commentary: The distinction between following Heaven and following man—this is the "inaction" referred to. Thus, those like Kuang and Qu, though knowing, never came close to the Yellow Emperor. Zhu Ping studied the art of dragon-slaying under Zhi Liyi, exhausting a thousand gold from his family. After three years, his skill was perfected, yet there was no use for his craft. Guo’s commentary: Affairs lie in appropriateness; distant achievements are not prized. Lü’s commentary: The dragon, as a creature, resembles sagely wisdom in its transformations. To slay it is to reject it. Exhausting a thousand gold from one’s family is to empty one’s possessions. Having no use for his craft is to have no need for rejection—this is the wholeness of Heaven.

The sage treats the inevitable as if it were not, and thus has no need for arms; the multitude treats the inevitable as if it were, and thus has many arms. Those who follow arms act with intent; relying on arms leads to ruin. Guo’s commentary: Though a principle is inevitable, treating it as if it were not is the height of compliance. Though arms may not be inevitable, insisting on them breeds discord. Each follows its nature, and sufficiency leaves no room for desire. When arms must be used, employing them with tranquility ensures no ruin. Lü’s commentary: Nothing is more dangerous than the will; *Mo Ye* and *Yan Yue* are inferior. The sage’s talent establishes itself, and the Dao moves accordingly—this can be inevitable. Yet he never insists, entrusting it to Heaven. Thus, treating the inevitable as if it were not prevents injury from unfulfilled ambitions, and so he has no need for arms. The multitude does the opposite, and thus has many arms. Following arms and acting with intent, relying on them, leads to ruin. Xin Yi: The Dao is the uncarved simplicity of non-action; arms are the instruments of action. The sage embodies the Dao and acts without contrivance, following the nature of things, and thus has no need for arms. The multitude, having lost the Dao and acting with contrivance, opposes the nature of things, and thus has many arms. Having many arms means following arms and seeking externally. Thus, it is said: "Following arms, they act with intent." Yet arms are what the sage uses only when unavoidable—how could he delight in them or rely on them? Relying on them makes survival difficult. Thus, it is said: "Arms—relying on them leads to ruin." *Bisheng*: Arms do not refer to spears and halberds; the battles of joy and anger within the breast are arms. Gengsangzi said: "Resentment not yet expressed is arms." How could it be merely the cruelty of blades and arrows?

The petty man’s knowledge does not extend beyond bribes and letters, wasting his spirit on trivialities, yet he desires to guide all things and unify the Dao. His form is as empty as this—bewildered by the cosmos, burdened by form, he does not know the Great Beginning. The perfected man, however, returns his spirit to the beginningless and delights in the realm of nothingness. Like water flowing without form, like breath dispersing in the Great Purity—alas! Your knowledge clings to the tip of a hair, yet you do not know the Great Peace. Guo’s commentary: Bribes for gifts, bamboo slips for inquiries—these are the tools of petty knowledge, which pursues trivial affairs. Bewildered by small tasks, his gains are shallow, yet he desires to guide all things. Traversing emptiness and vastness, his ambitions are great, his spirit exhausted, his form burdened—thus he is bewildered and loses the essence. Therefore, the perfected man is serene and inactive, entrusting himself to Heaven’s course. The petty man’s knowledge is slight, yet he burdens himself with great peace. Lü’s commentary: The petty man’s knowledge does not extend beyond inquiries and gifts, and thus he wastes his spirit. Clumsy and shallow, he desires to guide all things, unify the Dao, and empty his form—this is beyond his capacity. Thus, he is bewildered by the cosmos, burdened by form, and does not know the Great Beginning. He cannot unify the Dao or empty his form.

Only the sage returns his spirit to the Non-Beginning and delights in obscurity within the realm of Nothing-Whatsoever. When he moves, his actions flow like water, issuing forth formlessly into the Great Purity—thus he guides all things with unified Dao, emptying his form. The heart as a thing knows no bounds, yet its knowledge remains confined to inquiries and gifts. Such knowledge extends no further than a hair’s breadth, ignorant of the Great Tranquility—how lamentable!

**Xun Ben’s Commentary:**
The "unified Dao" and "emptied form" here differ from the common usage of "Great Oneness" or "Great Beginning." The syntax pairs "guiding all things" with "unified Dao," and "emptying form" with "Dao and things." "Guiding all things" corresponds to "Dao," while "unifying" corresponds to "form and emptiness"—implying the utmost balance. "Burdened by form, ignorant of the Great Beginning" means being shackled by form, unaware of the Great Beginning. "Delighting in obscurity" is like deep slumber. "Flowing like water, formless, issuing into the Great Purity" describes the perfected man’s effortless nature. "Knowledge confined to a hair’s breadth" refers to petty knowledge.

There was a man of Song named Cao Shang, sent by the King of Song as an envoy to Qin. On his departure, he received several chariots; the King, pleased, granted him a hundred more. Returning to Song, he met Zhuangzi and said: "To dwell in a cramped alley, impoverished and weaving sandals, with a withered neck and sallow face—this is what I was once incapable of. Yet now, awakening to the favor of a lord of ten thousand chariots and following with a hundred chariots—this is my strength!"

Zhuangzi replied: "When the King of Qin was ill, he summoned physicians. Those who lanced boils or drained abscesses received one chariot; those who licked his hemorrhoids received five. The lower the treatment, the more chariots they gained. Did you, perchance, treat his hemorrhoids? How else could you have received so many chariots? Begone!"

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
Serving the lowly leads to great merit; great merit leads to heavy rewards. Thus, those who value lofty detachment abandon such honors.

**Xun Ben’s Commentary:**
"A withered neck" means a gaunt, fleshless neck. "Sallow face" describes a haggard, emaciated appearance, as if mutilated. *Cuo* (痤) refers to sores or ulcers.

Duke Ai of Lu asked Yan He: "I regard Confucius as the pillar of the state—will this bring recovery?"

Yan He replied: "Perilous indeed! Confucius adorns himself with feathers and embellishments, engaging in ornate affairs, using flowery words as defenses, suppressing his nature to impress the people. He does not know whether what he receives is governed by the heart or the spirit—how can he lead the people? That may suit you, or perhaps Xu Yu, but it is mistaken and untenable. Now, to lead the people away from reality toward falsity is no way to govern them. Considering posterity, it would be better to cease such efforts. To bestow upon others yet never forget it is not the Heavenly Way. Merchants are held in contempt, and even if one treats them as scholars, the spirit disregards them. External punishments are metal and wood; internal punishments are agitation and transgression. The petty man suffers external punishments—metal and wood interrogate him; he suffers internal punishments—yin and yang consume him. Only the true man can escape both internal and external punishments."

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
*Ji* (圾) means peril. The perfected man finds peace in the people’s tranquility. If one becomes a pillar of the state, one leaves behind an exalted legacy for ten thousand generations, inciting competition in benevolence and righteousness, adorning their embellishments. The people are then endangered, and the perfected man has no means of securing peace.

Whenever the text says "engaging in," it refers to later generations’ pursuits of adornment, not genuine action. "Engaging in ornate affairs, using flowery words as defenses" means that later generations’ actions lack substance, their intentions running wild. Later rulers will admire Confucius’ distant path and force themselves to suppress their nature, governing the people through pretense. Superiors and inferiors will grow accustomed to this, unaware of their own falsity.

"Leading the people" means later generations will not merely imitate his outward form but will receive and employ his ways with their hearts and spirits, no longer acting from their own nature. "That" refers to the people; "you" refers to Duke Ai. Each has their proper role. Imitating one another leads to losing authenticity—this is already evident today. "Xu Yu" refers to following him, which is no way to cultivate oneself. To call it correct is impossible.

"Considering posterity" clearly does not refer to the present. Governing leads to falsity, so the sage does not govern. To recognize yet not treat things as straw dogs—merchants are held in contempt, let alone scholar-gentlemen! Only those who bestow favors are acknowledged in affairs, yet because they do not forget, the spirit disregards them—this is the great truth of the people.

"Metal" refers to blades, axes, and halberds; "wood" refers to flogging, cangues, and fetters. When one is calm and appropriate, there are no internal or external punishments. Those who do not follow the bright and level path are called petty men. Acting beyond measure harms the inner nature and qi; metal and wood interrogate externally. Unless one is a true man, none can restrain their transgressions.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
The *Book of Changes* takes *zhen* (贞) as the pillar of affairs. The movement of all under Heaven is steadfast in the One.

Only by forgetting the heart-mind can one attain unity; attaining unity is how one becomes the steadfast pillar and the governing principle for all under Heaven and the state. If those who would govern the realm and the nation do not understand this but merely rely on sagely wisdom to order affairs, their corruption will inevitably reach the state described above.

The Dao and its laws follow nature—just as the swan is white without daily bathing. When sagely wisdom becomes a burden, it is like adorning feathers with paint. Feathers are the natural quality of Heaven; painting is the artifice of man. It is like pursuing ornate words to magnify the small, where names and realities become confused and affairs do not arise from nature. If one forces the self and suppresses the inner nature to observe the people, they will not know trust. If one cannot forget the heart-mind and receive it, the heart-mind cannot embody the spirit and govern it. This is why the spirit exists for the people—how could it be sufficient to govern them?

The reason the Dao cannot be shared with others is that its center lacks a master and is not upright. Then, was Confucius able to make you fitting, or did you nourish yourself? Only by cutting off learning and nurturing the heart-mind can one attain unity. Merely taking the sage as the steadfast pillar is a mistake—this is not how to be upright. Departing from true learning is falsehood; this is not how to observe the people. If one claims to move like clouds and rain like moisture, how can there be forgetting? Merchants are not ranked with scholar-gentlemen—this is ancient ritual. Ranking them by affairs is a change in ritual. The spirit does not rank people by their nature. Valuing righteousness and despising profit is indeed rooted in human nature; those who love profit and forget righteousness have lost their original heart-mind.

Metal and wood punish the body; movement and excess punish the heart-mind. One who is still and unmoving has uprightness of heart; movement without deviation is not perverse. Acting with desire to be appropriate stems from necessity—otherwise, it is all excess. Yang Xiong said: "By day, one’s faults are few; by night, one’s faults are many." "Night" here means the same as "dark"—those who have not fully attained the Dao, though grand and great, cannot escape internal and external punishments and remain petty men. Only the true man, acting in stillness out of necessity, cannot be burdened by internal or external punishments.

**Xun Ben’s Commentary:**
"Those" refers to the people; "she" refers to Duke Ai; "you" refers to Confucius; "I" refers to Yan He, who speaks of nourishing the self. "Error" means mistake. The people should forget you, and you should forget them—merely pointing the way is sufficient. What need is there for government decrees? Even if there are errors, it does no harm, for they are united in reality. Merchants cannot be ranked with scholar-officials—though occasionally ranked by circumstance, the spirit of man is ultimately unwilling, as if not wishing to rank with them. Yan He’s displeasure with Confucius likely stems from this. "Petty men" are the same as "small men"; the ancient characters are interchangeable, as in the *Book of Han*: "Do not draw near petty men." Here, Yan He speaks of the Dao of the true man as vastly different from Confucius.

**New Transmission:**
The sage harmonizes virtue with Heaven and Earth and aligns function with yin and yang. He does not display his spirit to make people contend, nor reveal his traces to entrust things to self-transformation. Profound and effortless, he returns to simplicity—how could he merely assist the times? The Dao of the sage lies in the subtle, wondrous, empty, and still; the sage’s traces lie in the obscure, dark, hidden, and silent. The Dao cannot be known, and traces cannot be seen. If one serves in Lu as an assistant, then the Dao can be known and traces can be seen—all under Heaven will surely adorn the exterior and value rhetoric to imitate him. Thus, the sage cannot but act, and all under Heaven cannot but lose their authenticity. This is not the way to govern.

Therefore, it is said: "One is then adorning feathers with paint, pursuing ornate words to make branches the essence." It is also said: "Difficult to govern." Yan He understood the sage’s "useless use." Confucius said: "Human hearts are more treacherous than mountains and rivers, harder to know than Heaven. Heaven at least has the seasons of spring, autumn, winter, and summer, and the times of dawn and dusk. But humans have deep appearances and hidden emotions. Some appear sincere yet are harmful; some seem long yet are unworthy; some appear compliant yet are restrained; some seem firm yet are slack; some seem slow yet are resolute. Thus, those who rush to righteousness may flee from it as if burned. Therefore, the noble man sends them far to observe their loyalty, brings them near to observe their respect, burdens them to observe their ability, questions them suddenly to observe their wisdom, sets urgent deadlines to observe their trustworthiness, entrusts them with wealth to observe their benevolence, warns them of danger to observe their integrity, intoxicates them with wine to observe their restraint, and mixes them in company to observe their demeanor. Through these nine tests, the unworthy are revealed."

**Guo’s Commentary:**
"More treacherous than mountains and rivers... flee from it as if burned" describes how human emotions and appearances can be so contradictory. The noble man is easy to observe, while the unworthy are hard to discern. Yet by examining their motives, observing their conduct, and scrutinizing their contentment, one can know them through these methods.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
"Sincere" is the opposite of "harmful"; "long" is the opposite of "unworthy"; "compliant" is the opposite of "restrained"; "firm" is the opposite of "slack"; "slow" is the opposite of "resolute." Since these are all opposites, one cannot examine them through a single method.

Zheng Kaofu, upon his first appointment, bowed; upon his second, stooped; upon his third, bent low, creeping along the wall—who would dare not follow the rules? But the common man, upon his first appointment, stands tall; upon his second, dances atop his chariot; upon his third, names his peers "uncle"—who could align with the ways of Yao or Xu? There is no greater thief than virtue with a heart-mind, and the heart-mind has its flaws. When it has flaws, one turns inward; turning inward leads to ruin. There are five inauspicious virtues, with inner virtue as the first. What is inner virtue? Inner virtue is having self-regard and rejecting what one does not do. There are eight extremes of poverty and three of success; there must be form, and there are six repositories. Handsomeness, whiskers, height, size, strength, beauty, bravery, and daring—if all eight surpass others, one may still be impoverished. Following circumstances, slouching, cowardice, and fearing inferiority—if all three are mastered, one may still succeed. Wisdom and intelligence externally communicated, brave action breeding resentment, benevolence and righteousness multiplying demands—these are the conditions of a successful life. Those who succeed through knowledge are flawed; those who succeed in great destiny follow it; those who succeed in small destiny encounter it.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
"Who would dare not follow the rules" means no one would dare insult him with unruly conduct. "The common man" refers to ordinary people. "Yao" refers to the sage-king; "Xu" refers to Xu You. This says: Which of these—ordinary people or Zheng Kaofu—aligns with the ways of Yao and Xu? Having a heart-mind for virtue is not true virtue. True virtue is suddenly and naturally attained without knowing how. Following the heart-mind in virtue may still be acceptable.

To labor the heart-mind between the brows is already extreme artifice—yet to seek to probe and divine the obscure, making profundity one’s business, is to ruin both heart-mind and endeavor. To condemn and criticize: when one deems oneself right and others wrong, those who attack are many, thus becoming the chief culprit. If within there is no self-preferring inclination, and one freely allows all things to be as they are, each without self-loss, then the world will all wish to serve him.

"Exhaustion" refers to exhaustion in being employed; the world is never exhausted by its shortcomings but constantly ensnares itself with its strengths. Those who "cling and follow" rely on things to proceed; those who are "haughty and indolent" cannot stoop to tasks; those who are "distressed and timid" are weak—these three, though unfit for affairs, may still succeed through assistance. "Intelligence externally communicated" means outward communication harms the inner through boundlessness. "Brave action breeds resentment" means timidity and stillness strengthen the self. "Benevolence and righteousness" are what the world expects in love, yet love cannot be all-encompassing—thus multiplying demands.

"Puppet-like" describes the appearance of great awakening and release; "resemblance" means dispersal. "Following" means blending indistinguishably with transformation. "Encountering" means stopping at the proper juncture and awakening.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
From Zheng Kaofu onward, who aligns with Yao and Xu? Such is the measure of one’s capacity—unaware and unknowing, following the emperor’s standard. To slander is to become a thief. Virtue with a heart-mind, and a heart-mind with an eye—knowledge complete yet ruining the standard—no thief is greater than this. Inward vision reveals what is called a thief. The movements of the five senses, deluded and unreturning, are all inauspicious.

"Virtue with a heart-mind" means virtue with intention; with intention, there is a self. Deeming oneself right and others wrong, one thus prefers oneself and condemns what one does not do. The eight qualities all surpassing others lead to self-conceit, hence exhaustion. The three qualities inferior to others lead to self-exertion, hence success. "Intelligence externally communicated" brings things to bear; "brave action breeds resentment"; "benevolence and righteousness multiply demands"—this clarifies that what the world deems fine is not truly fine, and what it deems detestable is not truly detestable. The essential point lies in vigorous conduct, having the will to abandon the form. If one can, in life, attain this, then what is called "Heaven-given" is beyond knowing.

"Puppet-like" means merely attaining knowledge; one knows that one’s knowledge arises from unknowing yet cannot achieve unknowing—only resembling it. "Destiny" is what the Creator makes; I and the Creator are one, thus those who succeed in great destiny follow it without departure. Knowing that success and failure lie with Heaven, not with oneself, those who succeed in small destiny encounter it without refusal.

**Textual Note:**
Zheng Kaofu was the ten-times great-grandfather of Confucius.

"Events are recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*: 'pointing' refers to common people dancing atop their carriages, leaping and swaying as they ride. 'Naming one’s elders' means addressing one’s uncles by their given names. 'Tang Xu'—Xu You of the Tang era—declined the empire when it was offered to him, refusing to accept it. How could he take pride in rank or office? Who could compare to him?

The desires of the ear, eye, mouth, nose, and heart—these five—are all baleful powers, with the heart’s desires chief among them. Whenever one favors oneself and disparages others for not acting as one does, this is baleful power. To be fine-bearded and tall is one kind of majesty; to be brave and daring is another kind of wisdom. When Viscount Xiang admired fine beards and great stature, he deemed archery and charioteering sufficient skill; when he admired strength and vigor, he deemed them sufficient virtue—thus two things became six, and six became eight. By these eight abilities, one surpasses others, and by this, one exhausts the limits of exhaustion—hence the saying, 'Exhaustion has eight extremes.'

'Following along' means aligning with nature; 'reclining freely' means resting at ease; 'constrained and fearful' means being oppressed and timid, placing oneself beneath others. These three do not seek passage yet attain it naturally—hence the saying, 'Attainment has three necessities.' Below, the text appends to the earlier discussion of 'penetrating comprehension': those who attain knowledge outwardly through bold action invite much resentment, while those who act with benevolence and righteousness invite much reproach. Only those who penetrate the natural conditions of life can remain grandly self-reliant. Those who attain knowledge, though not yet reaching this, can still approximate it—this is what it means to 'embody form with likeness.' Those who penetrate the great mandate of Heaven move in accord with it; those who penetrate its lesser mandate, though not fully attaining this, can still accept what befalls them. Is this not what is meant by 'penetrating comprehension'—is it not about what lies beyond?

Fang Sishan notes: 'Exhaustion has eight extremes' means these eight exhaust all limits. 'Attainment has three necessities' means these three are essential to attainment. 'Form has six repositories': 'form' is what is manifest externally; 'repository' is what is stored within. To say there are six stored within is to say that what is stored within cannot avoid being manifest externally. Knowledge, wisdom, bold action, benevolence, and righteousness—these are the six repositories. Thus, only those who attain [the Way] are free of them. Those who attain life do so without intent; those who attain knowledge do so without obstruction; those who attain destiny regard fortune and misfortune, good and evil, without thought or scheming, roaming with Heaven.

The *Brush Notes* records: Master Wenzi said, 'When the Dao has knowledge, virtue is disordered; when virtue has intent, it becomes perilous; when the heart has eyes, it is blinded. Why? Having eyes, one must have sight. Those who study the Dao often suffer from lack of insight yet do not realize that sight is the thief of virtue.' The Buddha spoke of five kinds of eyes: only the heavenly eye and the fleshly eye are in the face; the wisdom eye, the Dharma eye, and the Buddha eye are all in the heart. The heart’s eye is the completion of virtue; this heart’s eye is the ruin of virtue. Knowing how it is ruined, one knows how it is completed—there is no dual principle here. Then how can those who attain knowledge be said to have eyes? Why speak of 'likeness'? Laozi did not say, 'The great Dao seems unlike'? If it were like, it would long since have been reduced to the trivial.

There was a man who saw the King of Song bestow ten chariots upon someone, and with those ten chariots, the recipient grew arrogant and childish. Zhuangzi said: By the river lived a poor family who made their living weaving rushes. Their son dived into the depths and obtained a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. His father said to him, 'Bring a stone and smash it! A pearl worth a thousand gold pieces must lie in the ninefold abyss beneath the chin of a black dragon. That you could obtain it means you must have encountered its sleep. Had the black dragon been awake, what scrap of you would remain?' Now, the depths of the state of Song are not merely a ninefold abyss, and the ferocity of the King of Song is not merely that of a black dragon. That you could obtain the chariots means you must have encountered his sleep. Had the King of Song been awake, you would be ground to powder.

Guo’s commentary: Those who seek wealth and honor must align with the people’s hopes. If one clings to strange doctrines, rides the celestial thoroughfare to ensnare the ruler’s heart, the enlightened lord will not accept it. Thus, if there is praise, there must be testing among the people. If it does not contradict the consensus, then promote it to meet the hopes of all—this is how the Three Dynasties practiced the straight Way.

Lü’s commentary: Those who risk danger and seek fortune, hoping for favor and fame without awakening, are like the diver who sought the pearl. This is what the perfected man deems perilous and pities. That one would use such things to grow arrogant and childish—is this not deluded?

Oral Exegesis: 'Arrogant and childish' means being haughty and treating others as children. 'Weaving rushes' means weaving reeds into mats. 'Obtaining the pearl' and 'encountering the dragon’s sleep' are metaphors for those who seek wealth and honor—all perilous paths. 'What scrap would remain?' means there would be nothing left.

Someone sent an envoy to Zhuangzi. Zhuangzi replied to the messenger: Have you seen the sacrificial ox? It is clothed in embroidered brocade and fed with fine hay and beans. Yet when it is led into the great temple, though it might wish to be a lone calf, can it still be so?

Guo’s commentary: Those who delight in life fear the sacrificial altar and decline appointments; the skull, hearing of life, frowns in dismay. The sentiments of life and death differ, each fitting in its own way.

Lü’s commentary: Zhuangzi entered the realm of neither death nor life, having long regarded death as the joy of a king facing south. Thus, the sacrificial ox in the great temple is not what he fears. Yet the world risks life and harms itself for profit, so his conduct is as it is.

When Zhuangzi was about to die, his disciples wished to give him a lavish burial. Zhuangzi said: I take Heaven and Earth as my inner and outer coffins, the sun and moon as my paired jades, the stars as my pearls and jades, the myriad things as my funeral gifts—is my burial not already complete? What could be added to this? The disciples said: We fear the crows and kites will eat you. Zhuangzi said: Above, I would be eaten by crows and kites; below, by ants and mole crickets. To take from one to give to the other—how partial is that! To make the impartial impartial with partiality, to make the unproven proven with proof—those who are enlightened merely act, while those who are spiritually attuned prove it. That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritually attuned has long been so. Yet the foolish rely on what they see, imposing it upon others. Their merit lies externally—is this not lamentable?

Guo’s commentary: To use one household’s impartiality to balance the myriad things is not as good as allowing the myriad things to balance themselves. 'Proven' means 'to respond.' Not relying on the myriad things’ natural responses but wishing to respond with one’s own views will inevitably lead to discord. Those who cling to their views are often employed, but how can they employ things? Only by following the spirit can one attain perfect compliance, thus responding without fail. What the enlightened can reach does not extend beyond form and bones; perfect compliance has no far or near, no hidden or profound—all things attain themselves. Thus, action arises from them, and merit is stored in things. If one relies on what one sees and clings to one’s own correctness, though one may wish to influence others, one’s merit remains external."

Lü’s Commentary:
To attain the unity of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things and identify with it as one’s body—such is life, wherein all things are prepared to nurture form; such is death, wherein one offers oneself as a gift for the journey. This is no empty saying. Those who fear being devoured by crows, kites, mole crickets, or ants cannot escape the bias of giving and taking. Only by being without intent does one remain free from giving or taking, thus achieving equilibrium. Yet to seek equilibrium through deliberate action is to fail in equilibrium; to seek response through deliberate effort is to fail in response. If intent arises, there can be no absence of preference or rejection, and one loses the constancy of the mind—this is the ultimate failure of response and equilibrium.

To desire equilibrium is to disrupt equilibrium; to desire response is to obstruct response. Stillness is like water: undisturbed, it is level. The great artisan takes the level as his model—thus, to level is to achieve levelness. He takes response as his principle—thus, to respond is to achieve response. All who today claim to know the basis of giving and taking rely on clarity alone; those who do not know it are the ones who embody the spirit. Clarity merely acts as an agent, while the spirit responds—this is why clarity cannot surpass the spirit. Yet the foolish, knowing nothing of the spirit, cling to their own views in attempting to influence others, expending effort externally. How can they return to the true nature of life and destiny?

Personal Reflections in Summary:
The text begins with the cautionary tale of offering libations, warning against deviant influences that attract crowds before one is prepared, yet fail to ensure others’ security. Next, it recounts the bitter dispute between Huan and Di, whose rage led to death and transformation into autumn cypresses, evading the punishments of nature—yet the Creator preserves the innate nature of beings. To know the Dao and remain silent is like the movement of Heaven; to know and speak of it is to reveal its mechanism too shallowly.

Thus, the skill of dragon-slaying, though perfected, finds no use; cleverness in cleverness cannot match the skill of dragon-slaying. Those who lick boils to gain carriages find their rewards multiply, for abundance alone cannot honor such service—both serve as warnings to disciples and remedies for the ills of the age. Relying on steadfast pillars to uphold a state is not as effective as ceasing to provoke the punishments of excessive action. The heart must recognize caution: the worthy are employed through ninefold response, while the unworthy meet their fate through threefold destiny. Reverence and negligence divide the eight directions; the three certainties and the nine perils are not constant. A single pearl’s loss in nine disasters serves as a metaphor for the complexities of navigating the world and the calamities invited by the pursuit of fame and profit.

If one can reflect upon the formed to guard against the formless, the burdens of the human realm may be avoided. To abandon the sacrificial ox for the orphaned calf depends on one’s sincerity and dedication. The text concludes with Zhuangzi’s death, illustrating the illusory nature of form and its impermanence—all things must end. His disciples, fearing the birds and beasts, viewed him with worldly eyes, yet the perfected person forgets form and follows transformation, free from the bias of giving or taking. By embodying the spirit and manifesting clarity, the principles of equilibrium and response remain unerring—this is how one departs from the human and enters the Heavenly, ascending to the Dao. Ah!

The Thirty-Third of the World

Those who govern the world through methods and arts are many, each claiming their achievements cannot be surpassed. Yet where, truly, does the so-called *Dao*-art lie? It is said: not in "having," but in the spirit—how else could illumination descend, how else could sagacity emerge? That from which sages are born and kings are made all originates from the One, never departing from the Source. This is called the Heavenly Person. Never departing from essence is called the Spirit Person. Never departing from the real is called the Perfected Person. Taking Heaven as their source, virtue as their root, and the Dao as their gate, they presage transformation—this is the sage.

Taking benevolence as grace, righteousness as principle, ritual as conduct, and music as harmony, they are imbued with compassion and kindness—this is the noble person. Taking law as distinction, names as outward signs, alignment as verification, and investigation as judgment, their reckoning follows one, two, three, four, and so on. The hundred officials rank themselves accordingly, taking affairs as their constant, clothing and food as their primary concern, and the flourishing, storing, aging, weak, orphaned, and widowed as their care—all possess the means to nurture the people. The ancients were truly complete!

They matched the spirit-light, purified Heaven and Earth, nourished the myriad things, harmonized the world, and extended blessings to the hundred clans. They were clear about fundamental reckoning and bound to its branches, their measures penetrating the six directions and opening the four gates. Whether great or small, refined or coarse, their movement was without limit—yet not in their brilliance, but in their reckoning and measures. The old laws and worldly records preserved by historians still abound; those found in the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music* are often elucidated by the scholars and gentry of Zou and Lu.

The *Odes* convey the will, the *Documents* convey affairs, the *Rites* convey conduct, the *Music* conveys harmony, the *Changes* convey yin and yang, and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* convey names and distinctions. Their reckoning spreads throughout the world, and the teachings established in the Central States give rise to the hundred schools. At times, these are praised and followed, yet the world falls into great disorder, the worthy and sagely are obscured, the Dao and virtue are not unified, and the world grasps at partial insights to esteem itself—like the ear, eye, nose, and mouth, each possessing its own clarity yet unable to communicate. Such is the case with the hundred schools and their many arts.

All possess their strengths and serve their uses at times, yet none is comprehensive or all-encompassing—each is but a partial scholar. They dissect the beauty of Heaven and Earth, analyze the principles of the myriad things, and examine the wholeness of the ancients, yet few can fully embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of the spiritually enlightened. Thus, the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingliness grows dim and fails to flourish. The people of the world each follow their own desires, acting as they see fit. Alas! The hundred schools have gone forth and do not return; they will never reunite.

Later scholars, unfortunate in their inability to witness the purity of Heaven and Earth or the great essence of the ancients, will see the Dao and its arts torn asunder by the world.

---

Guo’s Annotation:
*To act according to what one possesses is true action; to act truly is to be without falsity—what more could be added? The spiritually enlightened descend only after being moved by affairs, then depart, causing each thing to return to its root and embrace the One, without adornment on the outside. This is how the sage-kings give life and bring completion. The heavenly spirit, the utmost sage, the ordinary sage, and the noble person—these four names belong to one and the same person, differing only in how they are expressed.*

*Humaneness, rightness, ritual, and music are but coarse traces of these four names, yet they are what the worthy, the gentlemen, and the noble follow. Their names and laws are examined to govern the people’s principles. Once the people’s principles are settled, the sages and worthies do not oppose the ancients—these are the four names mentioned earlier. When the root is numerically clear, the branches do not stray. There is no place where this is not so, and thus nothing is lacking. What can be made clear through reckoning and measures, though numerous, is already distant and external. The scholars and gentry of Zou and Lu can only clarify their traces—how could they grasp the essence behind them?*

*The Six Classics, once scattered, became the hundred schools’ teachings, all of which merely expound the ancients’ old traces. Even so, they cannot consistently uphold them, and the world falls into great disorder because they employ these traces without unity. The sages and worthies are obscured, and their traces are not easily understood. The Dao and virtue are not unified, and the hundred schools force interpretations. The world grasps at partial insights, each believing in their own biased views and unable to embrace the whole.*

*The sage unifies the great passions of the people and establishes systems accordingly. Thus, the people entrust their emotions to what is unified and forget their own likes and dislikes, harmonizing with the age in tranquil indifference. In times of chaos, the opposite occurs: people indulge their immediate preferences, families apply their own classical laws, states adopt different policies, and households follow distinct customs. Their strengths differ and cannot be consistently applied; they are neither comprehensive nor all-encompassing and thus insufficient for full responsibility. Each employs but a fragment, so they dissect and judge the principles of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. The complete person is rarely encountered, and so the Way of the sage-kings grows dim. The great essence lies in each returning to the root and embracing the One—this is the purity of Heaven and Earth. Division and separation arise when the Dao and its arts degenerate, each school striving in its own direction. Some take things as their master, causing things to depart from their nature and follow external impositions, thus losing their inherent nature and destiny.*

---

Lü’s Annotation:
*None among the hundred schools’ teachings fail to apply their methods and arts to action, believing their ways cannot be surpassed. Yet if their arts differ, where then lies the ancient Dao and its arts? It is not absent—only that its wholeness is not attained. If its wholeness is not attained, how can the spiritually enlightened descend? When the spirit descends, it gives rise to the sage; when clarity emerges, it brings about the king. The One is the master of the spiritually enlightened—what we call the heavenly person, the spiritually realized person, the utmost person, the sage, and the noble person share the same great essence, differing only in how they are expressed.*

*To speak of the Dao, one must first clarify Heaven, for Heaven is what is revered. Thus, one who does not stray from the source is called a heavenly person. Essence enters the spirit only when it is true; if not true, it does not reach the sage. The sage fully embodies Heaven, and the utmost spirit resides within, unifying virtue and power to initiate transformations—this is the spirit descending to become the sage. When manifested in humaneness, rightness, ritual, and music, suffused with compassion and kindness, it is called the noble person—this is clarity emerging to become the king. Above the sage, one merges with Heaven; below the sage, one merges with humanity.*

*Laws serve as divisions that must not be violated; names serve as standards that must not be confused; conduct serves as verification that must not be deceived; and examination serves as judgment that must not be doubted. All these have their reckoning. Those with many reckonings hold high positions and wield great influence; those with few occupy lower ranks and govern lesser matters. The hundred officials are ordered accordingly. Above, this gives rise to the sage; below, it brings about the king. None is lacking, and thus they match the spiritually enlightened, harmonize Heaven and Earth, nurture the myriad things, and bring peace to the world. They clarify the root’s reckoning without doubt, adhere to the branches’ measures without losing the Way, and are not constrained by the Six Directions. Their movement is boundless. The great essence of the ancient Dao and its arts is like this. As for the spirit, reckoning cannot fathom it, measures cannot gauge it, and it cannot be expressed in written words.*

*What is made clear through reckoning and measures is the domain of officials, who enact their states’ laws and record their traces. As for what lies in the* Odes, Documents, Rites, *and* Music, *the scholars and gentry of Zou and Lu can largely clarify them. From the* Odes *expressing the will to the* Spring and Autumn Annals *expressing names and distinctions, all are manifestations of the ancient Dao and its arts, made clear through reckoning and measures. The former kings applied these reckonings to governance and disseminated them throughout the world, so the hundred schools, when they praised and followed them, did not stray beyond the ancient Dao and its arts.*

*When the world possessed the Dao, the sages and worthies were clear, and the Dao and virtue were unified. Scholars could witness its wholeness and were not misled by strange arts or divergent methods. In times of chaos, the world grasps at partial insights, each prizing their own biased views. Though each possesses strengths, none is comprehensive or all-encompassing—each is but a partial scholar. Heaven and Earth possess great beauty, yet they dissect it; the myriad things have complete principles, yet they analyze them; they examine the ancients’ wholeness, yet the hundred schools rarely embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of the spiritually enlightened. Thus, the Way of the sage-kings grows dim, and people each follow their own desires. The Dao and its arts are torn asunder.*

---

Following the Root:
*Taking Heaven as the source, virtue as the root, and the Dao as the gate—this summarizes the heavenly person, the spiritually realized person, and the utmost person. Taking humaneness as kindness, rightness as principle, ritual as conduct, and music as harmony—this describes the sage. Their reckoning is one, two, three, four—each clarified step by step. They are ordered accordingly. Taking affairs as constants, each attends to their duties; taking clothing and food as priorities, they focus on agriculture and sericulture; for propagation, they raise chickens, pigs, dogs, and swine; for storage, they accumulate in granaries and treasuries; for the elderly, weak, orphaned, and widowed, they show concern. These are the principles of governing the people.*

*The above, from the heavenly person to the noble person, encompasses the entirety of the ancient Dao and its arts. The following laments the differences between past and present. "Praised and followed" refers to the ancient Dao and its arts, including Fuxi, Shennong, the Yellow Emperor, Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Kings Wen and Wu, the Zhou, and Confucius. "The world falls into great disorder" describes the arts of later ages. "Partial insight" means seeing only one side. The people of the world mostly cling to biased views, delighting in their own preferences—like the ear, eye, nose, and mouth, each with its own clarity yet unable to communicate.*

The ear, eye, nose, and mouth each possess their own knowledge yet cannot communicate with one another; the hundred schools and myriad arts each have their strengths and occasional uses, but those who cling to one side are just like this. Examining the completeness of the ancients—few could embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the bearing of the divine. Observing the ancients’ wholeness, those of partial insight rarely attain the beauty of Heaven and Earth or the demeanor of the divine. To praise and follow the ancients’ universal application is to recognize such beauty.

To act as one’s own method, to make one’s own way—this is the art of self-made schools. Alas! The following laments these differences, each describing the divergences of the various schools.

They do not indulge in later ages, do not waste upon the myriad things, do not dazzle with calculations and measures, but straighten themselves with the carpenter’s line to meet the world’s urgencies. Among the ancient arts of the Dao, some resided in this: Mo Di and Qin Guli heard of its influence and delighted in it, practicing it to excess—calling their own excess "great compliance." They composed *Fei Le* ("Against Music"), decreed "moderation in use," forbade singing in life, and banned mourning garments in death. Mozi advocated universal love and mutual benefit while opposing strife; his Way did not permit anger. He was fond of learning and broad in knowledge, yet did not differ from others nor align with the former kings, instead condemning the rites and music of antiquity. The Yellow Emperor had *Xianchi*, Yao had *Dazhang*, Shun had *Dashao*, Yu had *Daxia*, Tang had *Dahu*, King Wen had the music of *Biyong*, and King Wu and the Duke of Zhou composed *Wu*. In the ancient mourning rites, noble and base had their forms, high and low their distinctions: the Son of Heaven had seven layers of inner and outer coffins, the feudal lords five, great officers three, and scholars two. Yet Mozi alone forbade singing in life and mourning garments in death, using a paulownia coffin of three inches without an outer coffin as his model, teaching others by this. If one fears not loving others through this, then practicing it oneself surely does not love the self. Though Mozi’s Way has not yet failed, to sing yet oppose singing, to weep yet oppose weeping, to rejoice yet oppose joy—is this truly compliance? In life, they toil; in death...

The Way of Mozi is meager and harsh, causing people sorrow and grief—his conduct is difficult to follow. One fears it cannot serve as the Way of the sage, for it turns the hearts of the world against it. The world cannot endure it. Though Mozi alone could bear it, what can he do against all under heaven? Separated from the world, he drifts ever farther from kingship.

Mozi extolled the Dao, saying: "In ancient times, Yu stemmed the floodwaters, dredged the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, and opened the way to the four barbarians and the nine provinces. He named three hundred great mountains, three thousand tributary streams, and countless smaller ones. Yu personally wielded the basket and spade, dredging the rivers of the world. His calves bore no flesh, his shins no hair; his hair was whipped by fierce winds, his body drenched by driving rain. He established the myriad states—Yu was a great sage, yet his form toiled for all under heaven." If later Mohists take wearing coarse hemp and straw sandals as their garb, laboring day and night without rest, and tormenting themselves to the utmost as their ideal, saying, "If one cannot do this, it is not the Way of Yu, and one is unworthy to be a Mohist," then consider: Xiangli Qin’s disciples, the followers of Wu Hou, the southern Mohists Ku Huo, Ji Chi, Deng Lingzi, and their like—all recite the *Mo Jing* yet diverge in their interpretations, calling one another "separate Mohists." They engage in debates over "hard and white" and "same and different," exchanging criticisms with odd and even arguments that never align. They regard the *Juzi* as a sage and all wish to serve as his representative, hoping to become his successors. To this day, their disputes remain unresolved.

Mo Di and Qin Guli’s intentions may have been sound, but their conduct was misguided. They would have later Mohists necessarily wear themselves out, their calves fleshless and shins hairless, advancing one another in this alone. This is the height of disorder and the nadir of governance. Yet even so, Mozi was truly one who loved the world. One might seek his like in vain, for though he withered away, he never abandoned his cause. He was a man of talent.

*(Annotations within the original text: "Great Compliance" is also written as "Great Accord," the title of the *Fei Le* and *Jie Yong* chapters of the *Mozi*. "Basket and spade" are also written as "plow and spade"; "nine" refers to gathering, for what he governed was not one, hence "mixed." Straw sandals are made of wood, hemp sandals of fiber. The *Juzi* is one who has mastered the Mohist Way, akin to a great Confucian.)*

*(Guo’s commentary: "Diligent frugality leads to exhaustion, hence no radiance. It is forced and severe. Diligent frugality leaves wealth in surplus and urgency prepared, but excessive compliance exceeds the measure of what the multitude can bear. When goods are insufficient, strife arises. Mohists urge the people to diligence and frugality to ensure surplus, thus deeming strife wrong—not in anger, but in self-denial. Having deemed themselves correct, they wish all things to conform to them, hence their broad yet undiscriminating stance. They do not align with the former kings, for the former kings indulged their many differences before unifying them, allowing all to attain without knowing how. They condemn ancient rites and music for their extravagance, claiming all things should be governed by effort and emotion as expressions of love. Yet by taking diligence and frugality as their law and overdoing it, they seek to enrich the world but instead undermine the very love they profess. The Mohist Way has not failed, but it opposes the Dao and virtue. Though Mozi alone achieved Mohism, he did not harmonize with the nature of the myriad things, hence the question: is this truly compliance? *Hu* means without luster. To say it cannot be the Way of the sage is to say the sage’s Way delights in enabling the people, allowing them to find joy in their nature. When joyful, the world faces no difficulty. The king must unite the world’s hearts and move with things, so one separated from the world is far from kingship. Mozi saw only Yu’s physical toil and not the ease of his nature. Taking self-torment as the ultimate principle, they deem self-denial the perfect method. Yet adhering to a Way out of season, each Mohist clings to his own views, leaving no room for common ground. Hence, within Mohism, they further divide. The *Juzi* is one who can debate his correctness to perfect his conduct. *Shi* means representative; they wish to continue the *Juzi*’s legacy. Their intent lies in avoiding extravagance and preparing for the world’s emergencies, but their excessive conduct is misguided. No disorder is greater than opposing things and harming nature, hence this is the height of disorder. Yet Mohism inverts this, making it the lowest form of governance. Because they truly love, sages and worthies do not oppose them. But it cannot be taught to others, for one seeks their like in vain. Their withering yet unrelenting devotion proves their true love. They are men of talent, though not of virtue.)*

Lü’s Annotation:
When the governance of the former kings reached its height in fame, culture, and the fullness of ritual and music, they did not indulge later generations, nor were they extravagant in material things, nor did they dazzle with measures and standards—this was not their constant way. Using the carpenter’s line to correct themselves was how they prepared for the world’s emergencies. The arts of the Dao in antiquity indeed included this. The Dao embodies constancy while exhausting change, but Mozi saw only the preparation for emergencies and took it as the constant norm. This is what is meant by "grasping one aspect and examining it"—a self-regard that cannot be shared with others.

From his creation of *Fei Le* (Condemnation of Music) to his indiscriminate opposition to all differences, he committed the greatest of excesses. The great compliance he sought was already lost. The former sages established moderation in rites and music and propriety in mourning and sacrifices; now, he would have the living not sing and the dead not be mourned. Unlike the former kings, he destroyed ancient rites and music, practicing such frugality and austerity that he not only failed to love others but also failed to love himself.

Mozi’s original intent was universal love and mutual benefit, yet he did not consider whether people could endure it. He imposed hardship and called it sweet, and few who adopted his austerity avoided failure—yet Mozi’s Dao had not yet collapsed. Joy and sorrow are unavoidable for people; the former sages gave them form and measure, but Mozi would have them sing when they should not sing and weep when they should not weep. Is this truly human nature?

To toil in life and be meager in death, causing people grief and sorrow—though the arts of the Dao in antiquity included this, Mozi carried it to excess. It cannot be called the Dao of the sages. Even if he could endure it himself, how could the world bear it? How far he strayed from the kingly way!

In ancient times, Yu faced the great flood and labored to such an extent—this was what is meant by preparing for the world’s emergencies. Yet Mozi took it as the constant norm, which is incorrect. The intent to labor and prepare for emergencies is right, but to carry it to excess so that the world cannot endure it is wrong. Will this not lead later scholars to compete in self-inflicted suffering?

Diligence and frugality are indeed difficult to practice, yet Mozi excelled in them. Truly, one who loves such things is rare in the world—he may be called a man of talent.

Xun’s Annotation:
"Not indulging later generations" means not opening the way for later generations to extravagance. "Not extravagant in material things" means not treating external things as luxurious. "Not dazzling with measures and standards" means not using rites, music, and regulations for ostentation. "Using the carpenter’s line to correct themselves" means adhering to strict standards to correct their own deviations. "Preparing for the world’s emergencies" means addressing urgent matters without pursuing irrelevant affairs. The arts of the Dao in antiquity indeed included this, yet Mo Di and his followers alone delighted in such teachings and carried them to excess. Thus, their use of the carpenter’s line to correct themselves was taken to the extreme.

"Their great compliance" refers to the restraint from extravagance, luxury, and ostentation, which was their utmost conformity. "Creating *Fei Le*" means that all their actions were things that could not bring joy. "Indiscriminate opposition" means not aligning with the former kings and differing from the common people while also diverging from the former kings’ Dao. Teaching people austerity is hardly a way to love them, yet he practiced austerity himself, never truly loving himself. Thus, no one could fault him, and Mo’s Dao did not collapse.

The following is Zhuangzi’s critique: To not sing when one should sing, to not weep when one should weep, to not rejoice when one should rejoice—does this accord with human nature? Austerity and simplicity indeed stray far from the kingly way.

"Far from this, they did not align with the former kings. The *tuoluo* was a vessel for storing clothes and garments. 'Nine' in 'Jiu Ru Duke Huan' (who nine times convened the feudal lords) is read as *jiu* (to gather). The interweaving and convergence of the world’s rivers form a network of channels that flow into the sea. *Jiaoqiao* refers to service. Xiangli Qin was a man from a place called Xiangli. The followers of the Five Lords were the five ranks of feudal lords—what the *Zuozhuan* calls the 'Five Lords and Nine Earls.' 'Not acting' means not violating; not violating means mutual resonance. The *Juzi* (Great Master) refers to selecting the most eminent among their faction to serve as the embodiment of the sage. All wished to take him as their master, hoping to become the lineage of Dao for later generations. Yet some believed, others did not, and to this day their doctrines remain unsettled—disorder above, order below, with chaos prevailing over harmony. Truly, they were those of the world who ardently sought governance.

Not burdened by custom, not adorned by things, not careless with others, not hostile to the multitude, they wished for the world’s peace to preserve the lives of the people. Their nurturance of self and others was sufficient and then stopped. With this, they purified their minds. Among the arts of the Dao of antiquity, there were those who embodied this. Song Jian and Yin Wen heard of their teachings and delighted in them. They fashioned the *Huashan* cap as a mark of distinction, engaging with all things by beginning with 'distinguishing constraints.' They spoke of the capacity of the mind, calling it 'the conduct of the mind,' seeking harmony and joy to harmonize the world. They proposed establishing a ruler, enduring insult without shame, rescuing the people from strife, forbidding aggression, and ending warfare to save the world from conflict. With this, they traveled throughout the world, persuading rulers above and teaching the people below. Though the world did not accept them, they persistently and loudly advocated without ceasing. Thus, it is said: 'Above and below grew weary of them, yet they forcibly imposed themselves.'

Nevertheless, they did much for others and little for themselves. They said: 'We humbly propose that five *sheng* of rice are sufficient.'"

The master feared he might not have enough to eat, yet his disciples, though hungry, never forgot the world, laboring day and night without rest. They declared: "We must surely bring life to all! How proud and lofty are those who would save the world!"

They said: "The noble person does not engage in petty scrutiny, nor does he lend himself to things that bring no benefit to the world. To make such things clear is no better than abandoning them. Externally, they forbade aggression and ended warfare; internally, they cultivated few desires and shallow passions. Whether in great or small matters, refined or coarse, their conduct was precisely sufficient to reach this point and no further."

Guo's commentary:
*This refers to opposition and defiance. To be content with sufficiency and dare not hope for excess. The Hua Mountain is level above and below, distinguishing constraints to prevent all things from encroaching upon one another. Insistently applying their Dao to harmonize and unite, they sought to establish these two as rulers of all things. To endure insult without shame was to make saving the people their urgent task. Ending strife and warfare—this was their way of harmonizing and regulating. Though the world did not accept them, they persistently and loudly advocated the principle of harmonization without ceasing. To be weary of them yet forcibly impose themselves—this was their way of enduring insult. If one does not rely on their natural transformation but forcibly comforts them, the burden of merit becomes too heavy. To insist on setting aside five *sheng* of rice—this clearly shows they did too little for themselves. 'We must surely bring life to all!'—this meant the people should also repay them."*

Those who embody arrogance and disdain display a lofty and towering demeanor, yet they do not engage in nitpicking but instead practice forbearance and forgiveness. They do not lend themselves to external things but rely solely on their own strength. What brings no benefit to the world is precisely what defines them as saviors of the age. Their conduct reaches this point and no further—they have not yet traversed the empty and boundless.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Unburdened by worldly conventions, they seek no adornment in things but extend sincerity to others. In ugliness, they do not contend; they wish others to be at peace and seek no excess for themselves. If their hearts harbor discontent, they treat it as filth to be washed away—thus they purify the heart. The chaos of things arises from mutual encroachment and harshness; to distinguish and pardon is the way to quell strife and foster tranquility. The heart, as a thing, admits all without exception—thus it should contend with nothing. These two masters described its capacity and enacted it through harmonizing and uniting, regulating the world. This is called the conduct of the heart, desiring to establish it as the ruler, revering and honoring it. To endure insult without shame, to persistently and loudly advocate without ceasing—this is the Dao of harmonizing and regulating. The ancient arts of the Dao, though present in this, demanded too much of others and too little of themselves. Thus these two masters did not align with it, saying, "Day and night I do not rest in saving the world—surely people will not remain arrogant?" Yet if saviors of the world ignore me, I must still preserve life, unconcerned with dying of hunger. Their conduct reaches this point and no further; beyond this lies what these two masters did not know, for they had not heard the Dao.

**Xun’s Exegesis:**
"Purifying the heart" means laying bare one’s heart. The Hua Mountain’s upper and lower slopes are level—hence the cap symbolizing it is called the "Hua Mountain’s cap." To "distinguish and pardon" is to separate good from evil and forgive what does not reach. Describing the heart’s capacity speaks of its form; "commanding" it is like naming its conduct and function. *Ér* (harmonizing) means to cook thoroughly. An old text mistakenly writes *rì páng* (日傍). The heart’s function is like cooking for others to unite them in joy, making them drink and delight, thus harmonizing the world. They wished to establish this heart as the ruler. They themselves said five *sheng* of rice were enough, yet the master feared hunger, and disciples followed in starvation, walking day and night without rest, saying, "I must surely save the people’s lives!" How could saviors of the world not give their all? Their learning differed in refinement and coarseness, but their conduct reached this point and no further—no distinction of great or small, profound or shallow.

**Gong yet impartial, they formed no factions; though differing, they were without bias. Decisive and without fixed direction, they followed things without duality, unburdened by deliberation, unplanned by knowledge. Toward things, they made no distinctions but moved with them as one. Among the ancient arts of the Dao, some resided in this. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao heard its influence and delighted in it, taking the equality of all things as their foundation. They said: "Heaven can cover but not bear; earth can bear but not cover; the great Dao can encompass but not distinguish. Knowing all things have what they can and cannot do, thus: *gōu* (partiality) is not universal, teaching does not reach all, and the Dao leaves nothing behind."

Thus Shen Dao discarded knowledge, abandoned the self, and followed inevitability. He drifted with things, taking this as the principle of the Dao, saying: "To know is not to know—pursuing knowledge only brings harm." He mocked those who bore burdens and ridiculed the world’s esteem for worthies. Unrestrained and without conduct, he rejected the world’s great sages. Blunt and decisive, he adapted to things, relinquishing right and wrong. To avoid trouble, he did not rely on knowledge or foresight, unaware of past or future, perilous yet unconcerned. He pushed before acting, dragged his steps in moving—like the whirling of a gust, the spinning of a feather, the grinding of a millstone. Whole and without fault, in motion or stillness without error, never guilty—why? The thing without knowledge has no peril of self-assertion, no burden of using knowledge. In movement or stillness, it does not depart from principle—thus it ends life without praise. Therefore, he said: "Reach the state of the thing without knowledge, and you need not employ worthies or sages. The clod of earth does not lose the Dao, yet heroes laugh together, saying: 'Shen Dao’s Dao is not the conduct of the living but the principle of the dead—how strange!'"

Tian Pian was likewise. He studied under Peng Meng and received his teaching without instruction. Peng Meng’s master said: "The Daoist of old reached the point of neither affirming nor denying." His influence was swift and indescribable, always contrary to others. He did not gather crowds to observe yet could not escape arbitrariness. What he called the Dao was not the Dao, and what he spoke as right unavoidably fell into wrong. Though Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not know the Dao, in general, they had once heard of it.

Guo's commentary:
["Decisively without a master—each follows its own course. Things attain their inclinations, thus unified and not dual; then there is no partiality, and all is employed universally. Teaching does not reach it; only by entrusting to nature does it attain. *Lingtai* means to listen freely, to let go. Their knowledge and power were shallow, not knowing to entrust to spontaneity, thus they belittled it and drew near to harm. *Xikua* means without task—speaking of not bearing one’s task but entrusting to the multitude. If the multitude each relies on their own abilities, then there is no need for arbitrary imposition or esteeming worthies. Not being a great sage, they sought to destroy their traces so that things would not be ensnared. Though the Legalists were subtle, they still relied on hammer and anvil, thus not yet dissolved into harmony. They could not discern right from wrong, before from after, merely guarding their eyes and indulging their nature to avoid immediate calamity. *Weiran* means entrusting to nature and standing alone. *Tuiye* means to be drawn along, compelled by necessity. Calamity arises from praise; praise arises from establishing oneself. Only the sage can then discard knowledge and artifice, following Heaven’s principle. Thus, the foolish and the wise each occupy their proper place, the noble and the base each hold their fitting position. Worthies and the unworthy follow their nature, yet they speak of ‘no use for worthies and sages’—this is why they did not know the Dao. ‘The clod does not lose the Dao’—it means to discard knowledge like a lump of earth. Only by discarding knowledge and entrusting to nature does spirit and illumination thoroughly shine. This is why they were worthies and sages, yet spoke of the clod not losing the Dao. If a person is like a clod of earth, is that not death? This is why the heroes laughed. Not yet uniting with the ultimate Dao, they became strange and uncanny. ‘Received without instruction’ means attaining the Dao of self-reliance. ‘Neither affirming nor denying’ refers to equalizing the myriad things as foremost. *Wuran* is the sound of wind blowing against; ‘not gathering crowds to observe’ means not conforming to popular expectations. *Yuanduan* means without sharp edges. *Wei* means ‘right.’ The Dao is nowhere absent, yet they spoke of ‘the clod not losing the Dao’—this is why they did not know. ‘In general, they had once heard of it’ means their understanding did not reach it."]

Lü's commentary:
["Not partisan, without self-interest, thus inwardly empty and without a master, therefore uniting with things, neither looking back nor scheming, advancing together with them. The arts of the Dao in antiquity—those that were still and unmoving were what these three delighted in. Responding and thereby penetrating the causes of the world was what these three did not know. Heaven is great, Earth is great, the Dao is great, yet there are things they cannot do. Thus, knowing that the myriad things have what they can and cannot do, if one is partial, then teaching does not reach; only by equalizing with the Dao is nothing left out. Therefore, Shen Dao discarded knowledge, abandoned the self, and followed necessity. *Ling* means to purify its turbidity; *tai* means to remove its disturbance. The ancients entered the Dao through this, not taking this as the Dao. The two masters took the Dao as stopping here, for they did not know that knowledge and the self had never yet possessed things. The myriad things all arise, yet this is why they return; their flourishing is why they revert to the root. This is not enough to disturb my heart. Shen Dao’s principle of the Dao was to know as not knowing; belittling it only then drew near to harm. Only non-knowing is what preserves it. Shen Dao merely knew that knowledge was not knowing but did not know that not knowing was true knowing. *Xikua* means unsettled, unrestrained, without conduct, and not the worthies and sages of the world—this is why he discarded knowledge and abandoned the self. *Chuipai* and *yuanduan*—the next three phrases refer to *lingtai* applied to things: *chuipai* means to forge and refine, *yuanduan* means to break and sever. Flexible, they advanced together with things, thus forgetting knowledge, deliberation, before and after. *Weiran* means to stand alone by entrusting to nature. *Tuiye* means to move only after being drawn along, like a feather in the wind or a groove in a millstone—then the movement is not mine. ‘Reach the state of the thing without knowledge’—thus, without establishing the self, there is the calamity of employing knowledge. In movement and stillness, not departing from principle, thus there is no praise, no fault. Shen Dao took this as the principle of the Dao. Only ‘the clod does not lose the Dao’—knowing the theory of cutting off sageliness and discarding knowledge, yet those who cut off and discard it are precisely the sagely and wise. How then is this different from the principle of the dead? This is why the heroes laughed at it and found it strange in the world. Tian Pian studied under Peng Meng and received without instruction. If one relies on his teaching, it does not reach. It is said that the ancients reached the point of neither affirming nor denying. Their influence was *wuran*—how could it be spoken? It was also guarded. Never having had right or wrong, yet the theory of the knowing not speaking reached the point where their conduct was contrary to others, and desiring not to gather crowds to observe, they could not escape *yuanduan*. The Dao never yet possessed things, thus taking emptiness and non-destruction of the myriad things as reality. Why then oppose others and take *chuipai* and *yuanduan* as their way? What they called the Dao was not the Dao, and what they affirmed was unavoidably wrong, for they were mired in the realm of non-knowing. Though these three did not know the Dao, in general, they had once heard of it. Mo Di and Guli, Song Xing and Yin Wen not only did not know the Dao but had never even heard of it. The Dao originally emerges from the nature and destiny of the emotions, and its truth is for governing the self. Now, Mo Di and Guli’s regulated conduct departed from the world, even to the point of not loving self and others—thus losing the root and truth to an extreme. Therefore, in discussing the arts of the Dao as divided in the world, they first addressed these, then Zhuangzi and Yin Wen, for they knew the Dao. Tian Pian and Shen Dao knew and drew near to it, progressing from the coarse to the refined."]

Xun's edition:
["*Yi* means level and smooth. ‘Decisively without a master’ means encountering matters and acting decisively without first establishing an intention. ‘Following things without duality’ means pursuing matters without generating dual intentions. For example, doing one thing while also generating another intention is to have a mind. Having something to choose is not universal; using it as teaching results in incompleteness. Only by returning to the Dao is nothing lost. *Ling* means the sense of clarity; *tai* means the sense of washing. *Lingtai* applied to things means encountering matters with ease. ‘Knowing as not knowing’—though knowing, one acts as if not knowing. *Bo* and *lin* both mean slight. If one has slight knowledge, then the mind is slightly harmed. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, Shen Dao, Hui Shi, and Deng Xi were all contemporaries of King Xuan of Qi, residing at Jixia. Their learning was rooted in the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. See the *Yin Wenzi* and *Xunzi*—*xi* means to endure shame; *kua* means to act alone. *Wu ren* means without anything to employ."]

Releasing restraint and abandoning conduct, indulgent and unrestrained, careless and unconcerned with disciplined action—striking it with a mallet or severing it with a blade, all contend with it in vain. "Wind returns, feathers whirl" suggests a spiraling motion; "grinding through a tunnel" likewise emerges in graceful turns. That which is inert and without knowledge does not lose the Dao.

Yet the heroic and eminent mocked Shen Dao’s teachings, deeming them conduct unfit for the living and principles befitting only the dead, merely strange and astonishing. Tian Pian was no different—he, too, followed Shen Dao’s way.

Peng Meng was Tian Pian’s teacher. Tian Pian studied under Peng Meng and received the teaching of "non-speech." Peng Meng’s own master had once declared: "The Daoist of antiquity reached the point where none could affirm or deny them." Their manner was so utterly still and inscrutable that none could glimpse it—how then could it be expressed in words? Thus Peng Meng, too, spoke nothing. Yet when Tian Pian would return from Peng Meng’s home after long stays, people no longer gathered to observe him. Only two or three would come intermittently, like fish breaking the surface in scattered schools. Though his words no longer startled, some still recognized him.

"Taking the root as essence, the external as coarse; regarding accumulation as insufficiency; dwelling in tranquil solitude with the spirit luminous"—such were the ancient arts of the Dao. Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard of this teaching and delighted in it. They established it upon the constancy of "non-being" and "being," governed it by the Great Unity, took gentleness, humility, and yielding as its outward form, and emptiness, non-destruction of the myriad things as its substance.

Guan Yin said:
*"Within oneself, nothing abides—yet forms and things manifest of themselves.
In movement, it is like water;
in stillness, like a mirror;
in response, like an echo.
Fleeting—
as if vanished;
silent—
as if purified.
All is the same."*

Those who attain harmony find it; those who lose it never precede others but always follow them. Lao Dan said: *"Know the masculine, yet guard the feminine—become the world’s valley stream. Know the white, yet guard the black—become the world’s deep gorge.
