All men seek to lead; he alone follows, saying: ‘Accept the world’s filth.’ All men seek fullness; he alone takes emptiness, for he has no hoard. Thus, though seemingly deficient, he abides in surplus."*

In his conduct, he moves slowly yet expends nothing, for he acts without striving. While others laugh at the clever, he alone bends to preserve wholeness, saying: *"If only I may escape blame."* He takes depth as his root and restraint as his guiding principle, declaring: *"What is rigid will break; what is sharp will dull."* Ever tolerant toward things, never carving away at others—this may be called the ultimate attainment. Ah, Guan Yin and Lao Dan! They were the vast and true persons of antiquity.

Guo’s Commentary:
*"To regard accumulation as insufficiency is to entrust it to the world, and thus one has surplus. How can ‘non-being’ and ‘being’ establish anything? To build upon the constancy of ‘non-being’ and ‘being’ is to clarify how things establish themselves. From heaven and earth down to the myriad things, each attains its own nature without borrowing from others—is this not to govern by the Great Unity?*
*‘Within oneself, nothing abides’—when things come, one responds without hoarding, so merit departs with the thing.*
*‘Forms and things manifest of themselves’—not asserting oneself but yielding to the myriad things, so each form naturally becomes distinct.*
*‘In response, like an echo’—this is the constancy of non-emotion.*
*‘Those who attain harmony find it; those who lose it’—to speak of constant wholeness is to know nothing of attainment, for things each guard their own portion and remain silent, without masculine or white.*
*Masculine and white are not prized for victory or self-display. To prize victory and self-display is to chase knowledge beyond one’s portion and endanger one’s life. Thus, the ancients did not follow boundless knowledge but guarded what was within their portion. Only when their nature was whole could they extend to the world; only when they could extend to the world could they return to it like a valley stream. Not contending with the myriad things for supremacy, the world willingly submits without tiring—thus he places himself last.*
*Feminine, black, last, and low—these are what the world calls filth. Those who seek fullness know only ‘being’ as useful, unaware that ‘non-being’ is its function. Those who take emptiness abide in tranquility, awaiting the fullness of things. ‘No hoard, yet surplus’—he entrusts the myriad things to guard themselves, so he need not fear scarcity.*
*‘Abiding in surplus’ means standing alone in self-sufficiency. ‘Moving slowly yet expending nothing’—he acts according to what benefits the people, following the four seasons to completion, ever in accord with the Dao and its patterns, thus free from strain or waste.*
*The clever harm their spirit through striving, but the self-completing vessel arises from non-action. To act without striving is to follow the self-arising, allowing each thing to achieve its own nature. Even spiders can spin webs—every person has their own abilities, so why value the craft of Gongshu?*
*Yielding to the utmost principle preserves wholeness, so without seeking, fortune is sufficient. Following things, they cannot incur blame. The root of principle is the ultimate of the Great Beginning—it cannot be called shallow. ‘Taking restraint as the guiding principle’ is to avoid excess.*
*In utmost compliance, even metal and stone are not rigid; in opposition, even water and vapor are not soft. Compliance preserves; opposition destroys—this is the proper principle. Advancing with haste and boundlessness is sharpness; each guarding its portion naturally has surplus and does not carve away at others, preserving its nature."*

Lü’s Commentary:
*"Taking the Dao as essence makes things coarse; taking things as coarse makes ‘non-being’ essence. The Dao never begins with things, so to regard accumulation as insufficiency is to reach the extreme of emptiness, where only non-accumulation remains. Dwelling in tranquil solitude with the spirit luminous—this is the ancient arts of the Dao, where root and branch, essence and coarse, are all present.*
*Yet if the Dao is fundamentally without things, and at times there are horses, this is still not firmly established. Building upon the constancy of ‘non-being’ and ‘being,’ nothing can uproot it. To speak of ‘one’ is already two; what is called ‘one’ is not the Great Unity. In the Great Unity, even ‘one’ cannot be attained, so the myriad things return to it.*
*The Dao is formless, so it does not contend—thus gentleness, humility, and yielding are its outward form. Observing its form, the substance within can be known. Things each return to their root, and the body is naturally empty. Taking emptiness and non-destruction of the myriad things as its substance differs from those who take hammering and chopping as the Dao.*
*Guan Yin’s eleven phrases all describe the merit of ‘within oneself, nothing abides’ and ‘forms and things manifest of themselves.’ Laozi said: ‘Know the masculine, guard the feminine’—the feminine is still and does not initiate; ‘know the white, guard the black’—the black withdraws and returns to the root. Valleys and streams do not accumulate; gorges respond without hoarding—yet from them flow the sources of rivers and seas. This is what it means to build upon the constancy of ‘non-being’ and ‘being,’ to govern by the Great Unity.*
*Placing oneself last and accepting filth is to take gentleness, humility, and yielding as outward form. Abiding in emptiness without hoarding, thus not destroying things but allowing them to be used—this is why he has surplus, does not precede others but follows them, moves slowly yet expends nothing, differing from those who labor their bodies and exhaust themselves in pursuit of the Dao.*
*Allowing things to be empty of themselves without destroying them differs from inanimate objects. ‘Bending to preserve wholeness and escape blame’—this is what is called fortune. ‘Taking depth as the root’—there is no need for rigidity; ‘taking restraint as the guiding principle’—there is no need for sharpness. Utterly empty and vast, he ever tolerates things and does not carve away at others. Taking the root as essence and dwelling in tranquil solitude with the spirit luminous, what he embodies is the true Dao—this may be called the ultimate attainment. Thus he sighs: ‘Ah, the vast and true persons of antiquity!’"*

Xu’s Commentary:
*"‘Black’ means darkness. Valleys and streams are empty and receptive, so they serve as metaphors—this is what is called the ‘mysterious female.’ ‘Laughing at the clever’ is to laugh at those who strive. ‘Not carving away at others’ is not to encroach upon them."*

Vast and formless, ever-changing and constant, death and life, heaven and earth, the spirit luminous—where does it go? Fleeting, whither does it tend? The myriad things all encompassed, none can return to it. The ancient arts of the Dao were present in this. Zhuang Zhou heard of this teaching and delighted in it. With absurd and boundless words, wild and unconstrained speech, endless and unbounded phrases, he gave free rein without eccentricity, never showing partiality. Taking the world as turbid and unfit for solemn discourse, he used goblet words to ramble, weighty words as truth, and parables to broaden. Alone, he roamed with the spirit of heaven and earth, yet did not disdain the myriad things, nor did he dispute right and wrong to dwell among the common. Though his writings were strange and marvelous, they flowed without harm. Though his words were uneven, they were striking and worth observing. What filled him could not be exhausted. Above, he wandered with the Creator; below, he befriended those beyond life and death, without beginning or end. In his grasp of the root...

Vast and expansive, profound and abstruse, grand and unbridled—his grasp of the root may be called harmoniously attuned and ascending to the utmost. Yet in his response to transformation and resolution of things, his principles remain inexhaustible, his arrival unchanging. How radiant! How obscure! That which remains unexhausted—like one who forgets the reality of emotions in boundless absurdity, in wild and unbounded speech—knows no borders.

Zhuang was upright and proper; his writings, strange and marvelous, flowed and turned in accord with things without resistance. Guo’s commentary: *"Without form, without constancy, he followed things as they were. Death and life alike—he entrusted himself to transformation. Where to go? What to seek? Without intent or inclination. Nothing to which things might return, all entrusted to their own placement. At times, he gave free rein without eccentricity, not urgently desiring to make his intent known to things. The turbid world, burdened by form and name, would deem solemn discourse mad and disbelieve it—thus he did not speak. Goblet words, weighty words, parables—all conveyed the utmost principle, perfectly aligning with the nature and destiny of the myriad things. Without disputing right and wrong, he had no right or wrong, thus letting things proceed as they would. His form mingled with things, so he dwelt among the common; returning to accord with things, he remained unharmed. Not merely responding to the affairs of the age, his unevenness was filled with inexhaustible abundance. Zhuangzi spoke with the same equanimity whether explaining himself or others. Examining his words, how vast and boundless they are—like Yu bowing to forthright speech, what fault could there be in this?"*

】Lü’s Annotation【
Without form, thus invisible; without constancy, thus unmeasurable. To regard it as death is to assume it never had life; to regard it as life is to assume it never had death. To regard it as coextant with Heaven and Earth is to assume there was never past or present; to regard it as the coming and going of spirit and light is to assume there was never self or other. Thus it is boundless, non-active, still, and unmoving—yet the myriad things are all encompassed within it, none left unrestrained. Where, then, could they return if not to the workings of the spirit?

With words of absurd vastness and boundless emptiness, untraceable and inexhaustible, he indulged freely yet not carelessly. All had their counterparts, and if not presented as oddities, even if devoid of substance or unconventional, they did no harm to their truthfulness. Solemn discourse still departs from words; goblet words illustrate the endless daily use of the Dao; weighty words and parables serve to engage the times.

People do not believe my words, so I invoke antiquity to lend them weight. When weighty words fail to illustrate, then parables arise. What Zhuangzi embodied was communion with the spirit of Heaven and Earth alone, never condescending to the myriad things—thus his words were likewise. "Condescension" here means estrangement or intimacy.

Not disputing right and wrong, he mingled with the common world. Though his writings were extraordinary and unbroken in their strangeness, they did no harm. "Unbroken" means without gaps; "strangeness" implies a fixed essence yet one unattainable by seeking—nothing the common world could value. His marvelous and uncanny words were unlike anything the common world could despise.

Only because his inner being was full and inexhaustible could he roam above with the Creator and befriend below those beyond death and life, without beginning or end—thus entering the realm of the spirit. His foundation was vast and great, taking Heaven as its宗; one might call this attunement to the highest fulfillment, never departing from the source.

Thus he responded to transformations. His principle was inexhaustible in untying the knots of things. His coming left no trace—meaning form does not wait for molting to dissolve. Vast and obscure, without end, this is the unknowable nature of the spirit.

】 Hui Shi was versatile in many arts; his writings filled five carts; his Dao was contradictory and discordant; his words...

Hui Shi’s teachings on the principles of things declared: "What is supremely great has no exterior—this is called the Great Unity. What is supremely small has no interior—this is called the Small Unity. That which has no thickness cannot be accumulated, yet it extends a thousand *li*. Heaven and earth are low; mountains and marshes are level. The sun is just now at its zenith, yet it is already slanting. Things are just now born, yet they are already dying. Great sameness differs from small sameness—this is called the small difference. The myriad things are entirely the same and entirely different—this is called the great difference. The south is boundless, yet it has bounds. Today I go to Yue, yet I arrived yesterday. Linked rings can be unlinked. I know the center of the world lies north of Yan and south of Yue. Embracing all things with universal love, Heaven and earth are one body."

Hui Shi took this as his grand vision of the world and enlightened debaters; the debaters of the world delighted in it together. Eggs have feathers; a chicken has three feet; Ying possesses all under heaven; a dog can be a sheep; a horse lays eggs; a *ding*-insect has a tail; fire is not hot; mountains have mouths; wheels do not touch the ground; eyes do not see; fingers do not reach, yet what they reach is unbroken; a turtle is longer than a snake; a square is not square; a compass cannot draw a circle; a chisel does not fit its handle; the shadow of a flying bird never moves; the speed of an arrow has a moment of neither motion nor stillness. A dog is not a hound; a yellow horse and a black ox make three; a white dog with black fur is black; a colt has never had a mother. Take half of a one-*chi* staff each day, and it will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations.

Debaters used these arguments to engage with Hui Shi, and they never ceased throughout their lives. Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long, among other debaters, adorned men’s minds and altered their intentions. They could overcome others in speech but could not subdue their hearts—such was the confine of debaters. Hui Shi daily employed his knowledge to contend with others, especially delighting in the world’s debaters with his strange doctrines. This was his root.

Yet Hui Shi’s eloquence led him to consider himself the most worthy, saying, "Are not Heaven and earth magnificent?" He possessed boldness but no method. In the south there was an eccentric man named Huang Liao who asked why Heaven and earth do not collapse or sink, and the causes of wind, rain, thunder, and lightning. Hui Shi did not decline to answer, nor did he ponder before responding. He discoursed on the myriad things without pause, ceaselessly, yet still considered his words too few. He added the bizarre, taking contraries as truth, seeking to prevail over others in reputation. Thus he was ill-suited to the multitude.

Weak in virtue but strong in things, his path was obstructed. Viewed from the Dao of Heaven and earth, Hui Shi’s abilities were like the labor of a single mosquito or ant. What use was he to things? Even if one were wholly devoted, one might still say he was closer to the Dao—but how much more so when he guarded against it!

Hui Shi could not find peace in this; he scattered himself among the myriad things without weariness, ultimately gaining fame for his eloquence. Alas for Hui Shi’s talent—unrestrained yet unable to follow, he exhausted echoes with sound, racing his form against shadows. How lamentable!

[Laozi says: "Much speech hastens exhaustion," and again, "Sparse speech is natural"—thus those who speak do so out of necessity. Yet Hui Shi’s eloquence led him to consider himself worthy, unaware of the vast emptiness of Heaven and earth and his own excessive self-regard. He could not abide in the feminine. It is fitting that he took Heaven and earth as magnificent, possessed boldness, yet had no method.

The sage takes wordlessness as speech, thereby embodying virtue. Now Hui Shi relied on his eloquence, taking contraries as truth and prevailing over others in reputation—thus he knew not the wordless. Enslaved by speech, unable to overcome himself, he was weak in virtue. Seeking to prevail over others in reputation, he was strong in things. His path was obstructed—was this not far from the six penetrations and four openings of the Dao?

The Dao of Heaven and earth is great because of its non-action. Hui Shi’s abilities could not escape self-regard. Viewed from the Dao of Heaven and earth, though vast and eloquent, he was but the labor of a single mosquito or ant. What use was he to things? Unity and multiplicity are both the Dao. Unity is the root; multiplicity is the branch. Though unity alone is insufficient to complete the root and branches, compared to those who forget the root and pursue the branches, one may still say it is closer to the Dao—yet how much more so when guarded against!

Hui Shi did not return to the root to find peace; he scattered himself among the myriad things without weariness, ultimately gaining fame for his eloquence, pursuing branches without return. Without sound, echoes cease; in darkness, shadows vanish; without self, nothing in the world contends with one. Though Hui Shi had talent, he did not emerge from this. Merely engaging in the trivialities of speech to compete with things—how was this different from exhausting echoes with sound, racing form against shadows? His loss of nature was profound. This is why he is deeply lamented and pitied.]

The Perils of Doubtful Singularity

Hui Shi’s sophistry could invert human understanding. At times, he debated the world on numerical absurdities—such as his claim that a chicken has three feet. At others, he disputed names—insisting a dog is not a hound. Or he contested forms—arguing a carpenter’s square is not square. Or colors—declaring a white dog black. Or hierarchy—asserting heaven is lower than earth. Or length—maintaining a millipede is longer than a snake. His arguments largely held that the myriad things possess no inherent distinctions of high or low, long or short; no true differences in form, name, square or round; no genuine separation of green, yellow, black, or white. He made equalizing all things his foremost principle, claiming the great Dao, once dispersed, gives rise to forms and names—all mere fabrications of human bias, nothing more than artificial distinctions.

Hui Shi clung to this doctrine to debate the world, ultimately gaining fame for his eloquence. Yet this was not the way of the ancients, and thus it is not called an ancient art of the Dao. One laments that, though gifted, he ended by chasing things and losing his original truth.

Following the Root

The preceding passages spoke of the arts of the Dao; here, we address the many schools—what are called the "arts of the methods." Their words do not align with principle. They proceed by conjecturing the intentions behind each thing, speaking without depth, so that nothing substantial can accumulate. Yet even what spans a thousand *li* has no depth that cannot be accumulated. Guard against this, and by accumulation, one may reach a thousand *li*. The slanting glance of the sun at its decline can be observed with a sidelong look.

Heaven and earth, mountains and marshes, the sun at its zenith or decline, the life and death of things—all are united as one. If the great is the same while the small differs, this is called "minor sameness and difference." If all is entirely the same or entirely different, this is called "great sameness and difference." Those who dwell in the north, ignorant of the south’s geography, assume it is boundless—yet it is ultimately finite. Though one may say, "I am now traveling to Yue," upon arrival, one knows Yue. It may be said that Yue has already come. The center of the world is unknown, yet the people of Yan and Yue each take their own place as the center—thus the north of Yan and the south of Yue may also be considered the center.

Embracing all things with boundless love, heaven and earth become one body with the self.

The following discusses the kinds of arguments prevalent among the debaters of that time:

Feathers grow within eggs—thus eggs have feathers. Chickens inherently have two feet, yet the act of walking is attributed to intent—hence three feet. Ying was originally a marquisate yet was called a kingdom—thus bearing the title of "possessor of all under heaven." The names "dog" and "sheep" are human designations; if one first names a dog as a sheep, people will call it a sheep. Horses are certainly born from the womb, yet since foals are born with hair, how do they differ from those hatched from eggs? Why limit this to the tails of birds and beasts? Observe the character for "hook" (丁): the character for "child" (子) clearly depicts a tail. Xunzi also said, "Hooks have whiskers; eggs have feathers." This argument is difficult to sustain—yet Deng Xi and Hui Shi mastered it.

The commentary notes: "Hooks have whiskers" refers to the tail of the character 丁. The curve of 丁 forms a hook; "whiskers" and "tail" are akin to fire and heat. In winter, fire is not hot; mountains are still. An echo in an empty valley can emerge from the mouth. The most perfectly round wheel does not tread the ground—*The Artificers’ Record* states, "When advancing, observe the wheel; it should touch only slightly." Nothing is taken from it; it is taken from the circle.

The eye, when obstructed, fails to see; the finger, when overlooked, fails to reach. Even when it reaches, it may not fully grasp. A snake is long, yet a millipede is longer. A tortoise knows good and ill fortune—thus it is longer than a snake. A carpenter’s square is the tool for making squares, yet the square’s body is not inherently square. A compass is the tool for making circles, yet the compass’s body cannot itself be a circle. A chisel is not round, yet the tenon fits into it. The shadow of a flying bird moves, yet the shadow only adheres to the form and does not separate from it—thus it has never truly moved. An arrow may be swift, yet if not loosed, it does not fly; once loosed, it cannot be stopped. Its swiftness lies in the person, not the arrow.

Dogs and hounds are one and the same. Yet if a dog has a suspended hoof, it is called a hound; without it, it is merely called a dog and cannot be called a hound. Horses are one, yet there is also the so-called "yellow"—thus two. The eye may be yellow, yet it is people who call it so.

Is it not three? The black cattle of Li are likewise so. A black dog cannot be turned white, yet a white one can be turned black—thus a white dog may be called a black colt, and an orphaned colt may be said never to have had a mother. A one-foot staff is not long; if today one uses half of it, and tomorrow half of the remainder, turning and using it thus, it will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations. At the time, debaters used this to engage with Hui Shi, responding and harmonizing with him, yet throughout their lives they never reached an end. "Heaven and Earth are mighty indeed! To say that my strength is like that of Heaven and Earth—how deluded and absurd! How could man ever surpass Heaven and Earth?" Though Hui Shi possessed a heart of heroic dominance, he lacked the means to surpass others. He began with many methods but ended with none, so that even his methods and techniques were lost.

Weakness in virtue is insufficiency in virtue. Strength over things is adornment through debate. The path is a road; *yu* is winding and crooked. This speaks of the path Hui Shi followed—winding and not straight. Unable to find peace in this, he scattered among the ten thousand things without satiety. Hui Shi could not settle into unity but sought to encompass the ten thousand things, taking this as his ability.

Zhuangzi’s extreme disparagement of Hui Shi reveals his disdain for the strategists of the Warring States. At the end of the compilation, the *Dao* and its techniques are arranged: first the Way of Heaven and Man, the spiritual person, and the perfected person; next the sage, the gentleman; and in later ages, the Way and its techniques fragmented, giving rise to the divergences of the various schools. Hui Shi’s methods and techniques rank lowest of all.

Zhuangzi placed himself after Lao Dan, never daring to eclipse the Six Classics. Having read this far, could there be any remaining chapters?

】

Hong Mai: *Zhuangzi* records Hui Shi’s words: “Take half of a one-foot staff each day, and it will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations.” Though this is a parable, the principle it embodies is indeed complete. For even as one takes half, crushing it into motes of dust, the remaining half still exists—so it may continue without end.

*Brush Jottings*: From “Hui Shi’s Many Methods” onward, the text aligns closely with *Liezi*’s account of Gongsun Long deceiving the King of Wei, yet interpreters often impose their own conjectures. Fan Wuyin and his disciples once discussed this, saying: “The vast, the strange, the deceptive, and the uncanny—let these be united as one and left unexamined. Why? These are not the words of *Nanhua*; they are the very heterodox and discordant speech he repudiated. What need is there to explain them? Nevertheless, among all that Zhuangzi described, not only Mo Di and Qin Guli’s teachings approach the *Dao*—even Hui Shi’s words contain semblances of it. As Liu Chenweng said: ‘Only because he loved them did he criticize them without realizing it, taking illness for malice. To destroy others to preserve oneself—this is not Zhuangzi.’”

Lu Deming: Master Xiang’s commentary broadly captures the essence of Zhuangzi’s intent. Guo Xiang, in his earlier years, lamented the decadent paths of the elite, and I, too, have belatedly witnessed the vain discourse of the privileged. This is what is meant by “different ages, same customs”—what more can be said? Some ask: “Zhuangzi and Huizi shared the bond of Hao Liang, the model of the Ying craftsman. Yet why are their *Dao* discordant and their words off the mark?” Is their bond like that of the Ying craftsman, who praised the sleeping carpenter’s snore while disparaging his adze? I say: One who seeks to exhaust the divine clarity of teaching through the marketplace of doctrines—how could he not refine his words and exhaust his analogies? Zhuangzi sounded his resonant tones in the Seven Inner Chapters, arranging these writings for posterity. *Chongyan* traverses the paths of the mysterious, while *Congshi* unfolds the sequence of eloquent discourse. Though his words eschew vain debate and his teachings avoid empty chanting, his text is easy to read but his purport difficult to fathom. Those who grasp at meaning without attaining it risk the charge of overreaching. To dispel the flaws in these writings, he thus broadly condemns Huizi’s grand disputations.

Liu Gai’s General Discussion: The body of the *Dao* is vast and all-embracing, leaving nothing outside its scope. Form and number begin with the One, and from there odd and even generate one another. Beyond this point, even the most skillful reckoning cannot calculate it. The ancients followed the order of the great *Dao* and complied with the principles of spirit and clarity, thus establishing the *Dao* of inner sageliness and outer kingship. In matters of measurement and regulation, complexity abounds, yet the root and branches, the One and the myriad, though scattered, remain interconnected. Therefore, one may emerge or withdraw, move or rest, shorten or lengthen, to correct the crookedness of the world and adapt to the unevenness of change. Fu Xi did not lack methods, yet they were perfected under Yao. The Two Emperors did not lack governance, yet it was completed under the Zhou. They did not rush ahead to favor the new, nor lag behind to indulge in the old—this is what sages in high position could not fully exhaust. Yi Yin bore the burden, while Bo Yi corrected it with purity, though purity verged on narrowness. Liuxia Hui tempered it with harmony, neither defying the world to uphold integrity nor following custom to fabricate fame—this is what sages in low position could not fully perfect. The *Dao* reached Confucius and then achieved its grand synthesis, for he appeared once in a thousand or ten thousand years. Above Confucius, sages adapted to their times out of necessity. Below Confucius, the various masters established their schools, each affirming their own rightness. By Zhuangzi’s time, the sages were already distant. *Dao* and *virtue*, benevolence and righteousness were sundered by Yang and Mo; non-action and purity were lost to Tian and Peng. Thus, Song Jian, Yin Wen, and their followers, hearing the wind, gave free rein to their teachings. Zhuangzi sought to restore the *Dao* of Confucius, but it was no longer Confucius’s era. He therefore exalted the supreme *Dao* to correct the world’s baseness, revived non-action and simplicity to sever the world’s floridity, and embraced clarity, emptiness, and stillness to rescue the world’s turbidity. He deemed concise speech insufficient to remedy corruption, so he expounded at length without fixed abode. He deemed solemn words insufficient to enlighten the vulgar, so he spoke wildly without bounds. He favored exalting Lao Dan while placing Confucius below him. In discussing the learning of the hundred schools, he excluded Confucius altogether. For he believed that when the *Dao* had not yet achieved its grand synthesis, even the most expansive true person remained partial. Lao Dan’s book grasped the root of his *Dao*, thus attaining harmony and ascent. Huizi’s book grasped only its branches, inevitably remaining partial. Alas! Which of the masters’ books did not revere Confucius? Yet none understood the basis of his reverence like Zhuangzi. Scholars should seek understanding beyond his words.

**Zhuangzi Yi Appendix**
**Zhuangzi Liepi**

**Sima Biao**
Zhuangzi was a man of Song, named Zhou. He once served as the warden of Meng’s Lacquer Garden and was a contemporary of King Hui of Liang and King Xuan of Qi. His learning spanned all fields, yet its essence ultimately returned to the words of Laozi. Thus, his writings—over one hundred thousand characters in length—were largely parables. He composed the "Fisherman," "Robber Zhi," and "Opening the Box" to censure Confucius’ disciples and illuminate Laozi’s teachings. Figures like "Wei-Lei Xu" and "Kang Sangzi" were mere empty words without factual basis. Yet, his skill in composition, his mastery of rhetoric, and his vivid portrayal of affairs so incisively critiqued the Confucians and Mohists that even the most learned scholars of his time could not defend themselves. His words surged freely, following his own inclinations, and thus even kings and nobles could not esteem him.

King Wei of Chu, hearing of Zhuang Zhou’s worth, sent envoys with generous gifts to invite him, offering the position of minister. Zhuang Zhou laughed and said to the Chu envoys: "A thousand gold pieces are a weighty profit; the post of minister is a lofty position. Have you alone not seen the sacrificial ox of the suburban rites? Fed and fattened for years, adorned with embroidered robes, it is led into the great temple. At such a time, though it might wish to be a solitary piglet, how could it be possible? Go quickly, do not defile me. I would rather disport myself in the mire and filth, finding my own joy, than be fettered by a ruler. I will never take office, that my will may remain unburdened."

**Zhuang Lun**
**Ruan Ji**

On the day of *Yi Shan* in the *Ren Xu* year, at the season when the myriad things begin, in the distant night of late autumn, the Master wandered and soared, riding the wind in his travels. He went along the banks of the Red Water and came to ascend the Hidden Mound, overlooking...

Along the winding path of the axle’s curve, he turned to gaze upon the vast and boundless isle—suddenly he halted, abruptly he rested, unaware why he had journeyed before or why he now remained. Disconsolate and joyless, he turned back in sorrow. In pure white simplicity, at the quiet of midday, he sat at ease, leaning upon his armrest and plucking the zither.

Thereupon, the gentry and the inquisitive, having heard of this, gathered to deliberate, composing phrases and joining lines to address what had long perplexed them. They peered and scrutinized, adjusting their robes, grinding their teeth in anticipation. First one stepped forward, then another followed, treading close behind, advancing together. With measured steps and guarded gaze, they approached, pacing as if in flight, treading the stairs and circling to alight. Shoulder to shoulder they sat, sleeves drawn in reverence, hesitant and clustered—none dared speak first.

Then one among them, the boldest and most commanding, glared fiercely, striking his posture, and declared in a thunderous voice: “Was I not born after the age of Yao and Shun? Reared in the lineage of Wen and Wu? Did I not wander in the flourishing prosperity of Cheng and Kang? In this present age, do I not recite the teachings of the Six Classics? Have I not practiced the traces of our Confucians? My layered robes and soaring cap, my trailing skirts and paired crane emblems—have I not worn them for years? Yet never have I heard of the essentials of the supreme Dao, nor of how they differ from what we have here!”

Then the lesser men echoed the great man’s words, deferring to him, and said, “We wish to hear the supreme teaching to resolve our doubts.” The Master replied, “What then are your doubts?”

The guest said: “The Way of Heaven values life; the Way of Earth values constancy. The sage cultivates these to establish his name. Fortune and misfortune have their divisions; right and wrong have their norms. Pursuing profit and exalted position, loathing death and prizing life—thus the world is at peace and great works are accomplished. Yet Zhuang Zhou levels fortune and misfortune, unites life and death, treats Heaven and Earth as one thing, and the myriad beings as a single finger. Is this not perverse confusion, a loss of constancy, though he takes it for sincerity?”

Thereupon the Master stroked his zither, composed and leisurely, sighed deeply, lowered his head and smiled faintly, then raised his gaze and surveyed all around. Exhaling his spirit, he spoke of what he saw:

“There are those who wish to gaze upon the heights of Mount Langfeng, and so they don their finest caps and robes, mount fine steeds, and ride to the foot of Kunlun—only to perish and never return. Yet caps and robes are but common attire, and fine steeds but ordinary mounts. They are not meant for soaring above the ramparts of Zengcheng or roaming the gardens of Xuanpu.

Moreover, the light of the Torch Dragon does not illuminate a single hall; the mouth of Mount Zhong does not speak within a secluded chamber. Now I shall cast aside the towering heights of Cuiwei and cease the deceptive chatter of Du Yan. By what path may you awaken and return?

Heaven and Earth arise from the natural; the myriad things arise from Heaven and Earth. The natural is without bounds, hence it is called Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth have their bounds, hence the myriad things are born within them. When there are no bounds, who can call them different? When there are bounds, who can call them distinct?

The Earth flows with its dryness; Heaven rises with its dampness. The moon emerges in the east; the sun sets in the west, following one another in turn. When they separate, they are apart; when they unite, they are one. Rising is called yang; descending is called yin. On Earth, it is called principle; in Heaven, it is called pattern. Steaming is called rain; dispersing is called wind. Blazing is called fire; congealing is called ice. Taking form is called stone; taking image is called star. Dawn is called morning; dusk is called darkness. Flowing is called river; circling is called abyss. Level is called earth; piled is called mountain. Male and female share the same position; mountains and marshes share the same qi. Thunder and wind do not oppose each other; water and fire do not repel one another. Heaven and Earth unite their virtue; the sun and moon follow their light. As one body, the myriad things follow their constancy. Entering is called the hidden; emerging is called the manifest. The one qi waxes and wanes, transforms and does not harm.

Thus, deep yin and thunder are not separate emanations; Heaven and Earth, sun and moon are not distinct things. Therefore, it is said: ‘From the perspective of difference, even liver and gall are as distant as Chu and Yue. From the perspective of sameness, the myriad things are one body.’

Man is born within Heaven and Earth, embodying the form of the natural. The body is the essence of yin and yang; nature is the true disposition of the Five Phases. Emotion is the wandering soul’s mutable desire; spirit is what Heaven and Earth use to govern.

In terms of life, no thing is not long-lived; in terms of death, no thing is not short-lived. From a small perspective, nothing is not small; from a great perspective, nothing is not great. The child who dies young is long-lived; Peng Zu who lived long is short-lived. A autumn hair is great; Mount Tai is small. Thus, life and death are one strand; right and wrong are one thread.

Spoken of separately, eyebrows and eyelashes have different names; discussed together, they are but one hair of the body. The words of the Six Classics are teachings of division and distinction; Zhuang Zhou’s sayings are expressions of intent. Viewed from above, the supreme reaches the limitless; examined in detail, things have their measures.

To hold to the numbers of the decimal system, to scrutinize the names of left and right—this is a partial doctrine. To follow the natural and the nature of Heaven and Earth—this is a discourse of vastness.

Now, the offices of the ears and eyes, the duties of names and distinctions—these are fixed roles. To serve one’s body is not to sever hands and feet or tear apart limbs. Yet later generations, fond of the strange, disregard the root and each claims, ‘I am right.’ Why wait for them to harm life, injure nature, turn back as enemies, sever limbs without feeling pain, see colors without regard to what the eyes perceive, hear sounds without awaiting the mind’s thought, let the mind rush after desires without restraint by what the nature finds peaceful?

Thus, when illness and sores sprout, life is not fulfilled; when calamity and chaos arise, the myriad things are destroyed.

The perfected person is serene in life and tranquil in death. Serene in life, emotions are not confused; tranquil in death, spirit does not depart. Thus, they transform with yin and yang without change, follow the alterations of Heaven and Earth without deviation. In life, they fulfill their years; in death, they follow what is fitting. With heart and qi in harmony, ebb and flow are not diminished.

Therefore, Guangchengzi dwelled on Mount Kongtong to enter the gate of the boundless; the Yellow Emperor ascended the heights of Kunlun to leave behind the root of the dark pearl. Thus, those who conceal themselves find life easy; those who abandon the root find it hard to endure.

Feng Yi, without meeting Hai Ruo, would not have known himself as small. Yun Jiang, without questioning Hong Meng, would not have known himself as young. From this, it is clear: those who assert themselves do not shine; those who establish themselves do not stand. Those who hold to being find support; those who grasp at non-being find nothing to hold. The moon wanes after it is full; the sun sets after it reaches Xianyang. It does not linger at the summit of Yanggu or after the hanging chariot’s descent—it is about to enter.

Thus, those who seek to gain lose; those who contend for clarity are blinded. Those without desire are self-sufficient; the empty and void receive fulfillment.

The mountain is still and the valley deep—this is the Way of the natural. To attain the Way and be upright is the substance of the noble person.

Therefore, those who devise cleverness and craft harm things; those who make right and wrong clear endanger themselves. Those who adorn themselves to appear pure are deluded in life; those who fear death and honor life lose their constancy.

Thus, when the principle of the natural is not followed, Heaven and Earth are not at peace; when the sun and moon vie to follow, morning and evening lose their order; when day and night are not distinct, and all compete and rush for profit, moving recklessly and crossing paths—then father and son are not united, ruler and minister are estranged.

Therefore, to speak again to seek trust is the sincerity of the inferior; to restrain oneself for others is the benevolence of the expansive. Those who steal the pheasant’s classic are the ruined sons of families; those who cut open their bellies and slice their flesh are the rebellious ministers of states. Those who adorn themselves with bright flowers and drink the morning dew are the benighted scholars of a confused age. Those who tread frost and dew, covered in dust, are the greedy and covetous people. Those who purify themselves to blame the world, cultivate their persons to expose filth, are the slanderous sort. Those who multiply citations of right and wrong, abandon substance for ornament, are the deluded class.

Those who are not sincere in pleasing and flattering to seek trust, but don fine pearls and jade to rush into water and fire—these are the ends of Jie and Zhou.”

Those who eat beans and gather ferns, starving side by side to death—such was the extremity of Yan Yuan. Thus, when the paths of fame and profit open wide, the sincerity of loyalty and trust grows thin; when the words of right and wrong stand forth, the purity of deep feeling melts away.

Therefore, the utmost extreme of the Dao is undivided unity, all things as one body, gain and loss unheard of. Fu Xi wove barriers, and Shennong taught plowing: those who defied them died, those who followed them lived—how could they have known that greed and filth were punishments, while integrity and purity were but names? If the essentials of utmost virtue required nothing beyond the self, the great balance would be naturally pure and unchanging in its principle, clear and still, empty and vast, awaiting all things. Good and evil would not be divided, right and wrong would have no contention, and the myriad things would return to their places and find their true nature.

After the rise of the Confucians and Mohists, the debates of "hard and white" arose together, fortune and misfortune linked to things, gain and loss lodged in the heart. Disciples gathered in factions, and arguments clashed. Once, the heroes of Great Qi and the knights of the Three Jin states confronted one another, eyes wide and chests bared, distinguishing this from that. All believed that the life of a hundred years was hard to attain, while the passing of days and months was fleeting and uncertain. Thus, they adorned their carriages and horses, refined their clothing, polished their pearls and jade, decorated their curtains and screens, going forth to flatter their lords and superiors, entering to deceive their fathers and elder brothers. They forced their talents and wits, vying and contending, scheming and maneuvering. Families were ruined by clever sons, states were lost by talented ministers. Thus, they did not live out their natural years but instead brought great harm upon themselves—how excessive their conformity to worldly customs!

Therefore, the trees in the mountains, vast in their roots, remain unharmed, their myriad hollows harmonizing in an instant. The wild geese are gone, their substance lost, their patterns muddied; life and death bring no change, yet the tortoise is treasured for knowing fortune and misfortune. Thus, the perfected person purifies their substance and muddies their patterns; life and death bring no change, and they have never begun to speak of distinctions. Those who fracture words engage in discourse that harms the Dao; those who split hairs initiate the destruction of virtue. The division of qi is an illness of the body; a divided heart is the affliction of the myriad things.

Thus, those who adorn themselves and lean on their chariots’ rails, whose conduct is riddled with entanglements and whose thoughts dwell on success and failure, sit and seek adversaries; those who cross barriers and assault perilous heights are the people of the Zhao state. Those who would lift mountains to fill the sea are the people of Yan and Chu. Zhuang Zhou saw them as such, and so he expounded the wonders of the Dao and the roots of non-action, using parables to broaden his meaning and borrowing things to extend it, merely to amuse his heart in non-action and wander freely in the world. How could he have sought the gates of Xianyang or contended in debate at Jixia?

Those who are skilled in receiving others guide them and nothing more, offering no resistance. Thus, when Gong Meng Ji Zi wore embroidered robes to see Mozi, Mozi did not attack him. When Zhongshan Zi Mu’s heart was in Wei but Jianzi did not reject him, he followed the reason for their coming, employed the means of their arrival, complied with and reassured them, allowing them to settle themselves, opening and unfolding them so they might express themselves. Moreover, what is there to say of Zhuang Zhou’s book? Have you not yet heard the discourse on the Great Beginning, the subtle words of high antiquity? Simply be without harm to things, and form will arise; do nothing to destroy, and spirit will be clear. Form and spirit are within me, and the Dao and virtue are complete. Loyalty and trust do not depart, and above and below are at peace. Now, this guest’s talk aligns with the ancients in speech but diverges in intent—his heart can guard its root, but his mouth does not wait upon it.

Thus, these two or three followers, swayed by the wind and tossed by the waves, looked at one another, their pulses disordered, their order lost, stumbling and losing their way, following and gazing after him. In the end, they knew it was without substance, their qi spent, and they were ashamed and disheartened in their decline and seclusion.
