Wang Anshi’s *On Zhuangzi*:

Those who discuss Zhuangzi in the world do not agree. Scholars of the Confucian tradition say: Zhuangzi’s book is devoted to slandering Confucius to validate its heterodox doctrines. It must be burned, its followers abolished, and only then will matters be settled. Its right and wrong are certainly not worth discussing. Such are the words of Confucian scholars.

Yet those who favor Zhuangzi’s Dao say: Zhuangzi’s virtue does not allow the myriad things to disturb his thoughts, and he is able to trust his Dao. He is not ignorant of benevolence and righteousness but considers them too small to practice. He is not ignorant of ritual and music but considers them too shallow to transform the world. Thus, Laozi said: “When the Dao is lost, then virtue; when virtue is lost, then benevolence; when benevolence is lost, then righteousness; when righteousness is lost, then ritual.” This shows that Zhuangzi was not unaware of the meaning of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music. He considered them the branches of the Dao and thus belittled them.

The words of the Confucians are good, yet they have never sought Zhuangzi’s intent. Those who favor Zhuangzi’s words certainly know how to read his book, yet they too have never sought Zhuangzi’s intent. By the time of Zhuangzi, the transforming influence of the former kings had been exhausted. The customs of the world were steeped in deceit and cunning, and simplicity and honesty had scattered and vanished. Even the scholars and great men of the age did not know the Dao of valuing the self and demeaning things. Thus, they cast aside the threads of ritual and righteousness, seized and plundered at the junctures of profit and harm, pursued gain without shame, and sacrificed themselves without resentment. Gradually, they sank and drowned until they could not be saved.

Zhuangzi lamented this and devised his teachings to correct the world’s ills and return it to uprightness. His heart was overly concerned, for he believed that benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music were insufficient to set things right. Thus, he equalized right and wrong, unified self and other, and made profit and harm one—this was enough for his heart. This was how he corrected the world’s ills. Yet having corrected the ills with his teachings, he feared that later generations would take his words as reality and fail to see the purity of heaven and earth or the greatness of the ancients. Thus, in the final chapters, he grieved in his heart and explained himself.

Therefore, his chapters say: “The *Odes* express the will, the *Documents* express affairs, ritual expresses conduct, music expresses harmony, the *Changes* express yin and yang, and the *Spring and Autumn Annals* express names and divisions.” From this, we see that Zhuangzi was not ignorant of the sages. He also said: “For example, the ear, eye, nose, and mouth each have their clarity but cannot communicate with one another, just as the hundred schools and various arts each have their strengths and are useful at times.” Thus, he made clear that the complete Dao of the sages lies in that and not in this, yet he also listed his book among those of Song Jian, Shen Dao, Mo Di, Lao Dan, and others, all partial and one-sided scholars of a single corner. This was to make clear that his words were composed for a purpose, not the complete Dao in its entirety.

Thus, was Zhuangzi not concerned with the world’s ills and preserving the sages’ Dao?

The purity of Boyi and the harmony of Liuxia Hui were both deliberate corrections of the world’s ways—Zhuangzi applied his mind in the manner of these two sages. Yet Zhuangzi’s words could not but be reckoned heterodox, for his corrections overreached. When one corrects a crooked thing, one seeks to make it straight; but if the correction overreaches, it returns to crookedness. Zhuangzi himself said of Mozi: “His mind was right, but his conduct was wrong.” Yet if we extend Zhuangzi’s own mind to examine his conduct, how was he different from Mozi? Later readers of Zhuangzi who approve the intention behind his book rather than its doctrines may be called true readers. This, too, is what Zhuangzi would have wished of those who read his work in later ages.

Today’s readers wield Zhuangzi to disparage the Confucians, saying: “The Dao of Zhuangzi is vast—beyond what the Confucians can comprehend!” They do not seek his intent but prize only what differs from the Confucians. How lamentable! Zhuangzi’s critique of the world below, his disparagement of the Zhou, his rejection of Yao, Shun, and Confucius—when I examine his book, I see that his words were merely allegorical. Mencius said: “In interpreting the *Odes*, one must not be hindered by the text nor by the phrasing; one must meet the intent with one’s own intent—this is the way to grasp it.” To read the text without tracing it to its intent is why those who defend the Zhou find cause to dispute.

Zhou [i.e., Zhuangzi] said: “Above, one must act without purpose to employ the world; below, one must act with purpose to be employed by the world.” He also claimed to dwell amid benighted rulers and chaotic ministers, thus impoverished and unable to display his talents. Yet who could accept that all of Zhou’s words were unfit for the relations between ruler and minister, father and son, or that he met his age and master in such a way that he could never act? When he cited the sacrificial ox of the grand ancestral temple to decline Chu’s invitation, he was merely using shocking words to frighten the mediocrities of a declining age. With Zhou’s talents, how could he have been confused about the proper course of action or so fixated on fearing the ox? He was likely the sort of man Confucius described as “dwelling in seclusion and speaking freely.” Yet Zhou’s doctrines, in reversing the Dao, naturally offended the followers of the sages.

What the average person can attain, the sage explains in detail and practices with care. If the explanation is not detailed or the practice not careful, the world suffers. What the average person cannot attain, the sage conceals in his heart and speaks of only briefly. If what should be brief is made detailed, the world is confused. Those who must be instructed repeatedly before they understand, who must be badgered before they submit—how could they be the ones “with whom one can discuss higher things”? Alas! Zhou was eloquent but did not grasp this.

**Record of the Zhuangzi Shrine**

Su Shi

Zhuangzi was a native of Meng. He once served as the keeper of the Lacquer Garden in Meng. Though over a thousand years have passed since his death, Meng had never established a shrine in his honor. County Magistrate and Secretariat Drafter Wang Jin first built this shrine and sought an inscription for its record.

According to the *Records of the Historian*, Zhuangzi was a contemporary of King Hui of Liang and King Xuan of Qi. His learning was vast, yet its essence ultimately returned to the words of Laozi. Thus, the over one hundred thousand characters he wrote were largely parables. He composed *The Fisherman*, *Robber Zhi*, and *Opening the Box* to criticize Confucius’ disciples and illuminate Laozi’s teachings—this is what those who only superficially understand Zhuangzi know.

I, however, believe Zhuangzi was in fact aiding Confucius, though his methods were not to be taken as a model. Consider the Prince of Chu, who fled in disguise and was blocked by a gatekeeper. His servant twisted his staff and cursed, saying, “A mere gatekeeper dares not let the prince pass!” The servant’s actions were perverse, yet if one judged him for not loving the prince, he could not serve as a model for serving the prince. Likewise, Zhuangzi’s words often appear to oppose Confucius on the surface but covertly assist him. His straightforward teachings are few, and even in his criticisms of Confucius, his true intent is subtly revealed.

In his discussion of the *Dao* and its arts across the world, he grouped together Mohists like Mo Di and Qin Guli, as well as Peng Meng, Shen Dao, Tian Pian, Guan Yin, and Lao Dan, all the way to himself, treating them as one school—excluding only Confucius. This is the height of reverence! Yet I have long doubted whether *Robber Zhi* and *The Fisherman* truly criticize Confucius, for *Yielding the Throne* and *Discourse on Swords* are shallow and far from the *Dao*.

But when we examine the conclusion of his parables, we find: Yang Ziju traveled west to Qin and encountered Laozi. Laozi said, “With your haughty gaze and arrogant bearing, who would wish to dwell with you?” Yang Ziju’s expression changed. When he departed, the innkeeper’s family welcomed him, the master offering a mat and his wife a towel and comb, while the servants cleared the seats and the cook left the stove. When he returned, the innkeeper’s family vied with him for the best seat.

Discard the four chapters—*Yielding the Throne*, *Discourse on Swords*, *The Fisherman*, and *Robber Zhi*—and Zhuangzi’s work aligns with the chapter on Lie Yukou, which states: “Lie Yukou was traveling to Qi when he turned back midway, saying, ‘I am astonished! I ate at ten inns, and at five of them, they served me first.’ He then understood and laughed, saying, ‘This is indeed a single lesson.’”

Zhuangzi’s words are not yet complete when the ignorant pluck them to suit their own ends. I cannot but clarify: the division of chapters and naming of sections all stem from世俗俗 conventions, not Zhuangzi’s original intent.

Recorded on the nineteenth day of the eleventh month, the first year of the Yuanfeng era.

---

**Parting Gift**

Pan You

Zhuangzi said: “Gain comes with timing, and loss follows compliance. Abiding in timing and complying with change, sorrow and joy cannot enter.”

I have always cherished these words. “Gain” refers to life itself—from one year to two, up to a hundred, from youth to maturity, from maturity to old age. The passage of years cannot be refused. Is this not gain coming with timing? “Loss” is likewise—from one year to two, up to a hundred, as dusk loses dawn and today loses yesterday, from maturity losing youth, from old age losing maturity. The departure of years cannot be detained. Is this not loss following compliance?

All things under heaven are thus: coming cannot be avoided, and going cannot be detained. Therefore, abiding in timing and complying with change, sorrow and joy cannot enter. The enlightened know that I cannot control things, nor can things control me. The two do not interfere, so one drifts freely, expands boundlessly, and follows nature.

Thus, acting without knowing why it is so, one views the affairs of the world as a speeding chariot passing over an anthill—encountering them is not gain, and departing them is not loss. How then could one distinguish gain and loss within them or entangle sorrow and joy in their convergence?

Take a person from one year to two, up to a hundred: amid these years, gain and loss, sorrow and joy intermingle in profusion, burdensome and vexing. In their moment, sorrow brings unshakable gloom, and joy brings unalterable delight. Yet when the moment passes and one reflects, one awakens—this awakening, too, is but a dream. Then the former delight and gloom appear as mere delusion. Thus, those who come after will view the present as the present views the past.

Why should today’s losses trouble one like the sting of a scorpion? South of Yan and north of Yue, where the sun and moon arise, is called the Central Kingdom. Where the sun and moon rise and set is called day and night. Within these bounds, those who bear teeth, grow hair, eat grain, and wear silk are called humans. The stirring of a single nature is called the Great Change—speaking of nature’s mutability, its instability. Some become human, some become other creatures; it depends on what nature favors. Hard and soft, moving and still, endlessly varied—these are called things. Calling to one another by sound is called naming. Multiplying things gather for advantage—this is called profit. Heads gathering in throngs—this is called affairs. Affairs pass, and one records them in the heart, now as joy, now as sorrow, now as resentment. Though their names are many, all are transformations of a single mind.

In the beginning, there was nothing; in the end, what will remain? Here, one divides self and other: the other calls me "other," and I call the other "other." The other calls itself "I," and I, too, call myself "I." If we point at one another, all are "other"; if we point at ourselves, all are "I." Yet in the end, none knows who is "other" and who is "I." Even the sage cannot determine this—yet still, one forcibly imposes order upon it.

Thus, some name them Shang and Zhou, others name them Qin and Han. They strip the skin from bamboo and silk, cut it into slips, and call it *jian* and *jian*; they bind the tips of brushes, dip them in cinnabar and ink, and let them move across the surface—this is called "writing." Gathering such matters and recording them is called "classics and records." Later generations regard them as "studying antiquity," emulating one another age after age without cease. Some attain the Dao through them, while others drown in the mind—this is called "learning." Yet from ancient times to the present, all who bustle about within it share but a single stroke.

Within that single stroke, they scheme for ten thousand generations of affairs—how is this different from one who, waking, frets over dreams, and dreaming, frets over waking? The sun, moon, and stars, the hills and mounds, rivers and marshes remain as they were. Those with teeth and hair, the hard and soft, the moving and still—all continue endlessly. As for the so-called Shang, Zhou, Qin, and Han, some fought to gain them, others fought to lose them—what remains of them now?

When I regard them now, it is as one awake regards a dream. How much better to embody the Dao, settle the nature, and take clarity and emptiness as one’s task! The affairs of the world, before they arrive, have no form. In the present moment, they do not abide. Once past, they are as though they never were.

Here now, what more do I seek in my restless striving? Yet those bound by greed and love of profit, their hearts shackled to gain and loss, are as cramped as colts beneath the yoke. How might they attain the untrammeled freedom of Liezi, whose words resounded like thunder, or Zhuang Zhou, whose speech roared like wind scorching the world’s yokes and releasing its colts—vast and unbounded, returning to the realm of no-thing, even to the point of no words?

What I have said before is thus: it is your conduct, sir. I record these words as a parting gift. You, who are so severely cramped—your heart is already sick. Might you hear these words and find your illness cured?

**Miscellaneous Sayings**

Wang Pang:
The sage has *lunyì* (discourse and deliberation) but no *biàn* (disputation). The various masters have *biàn* but no *lunyì*. Those who *lunshuō* (discuss and expound) stop at exposition; those who *yìpíng* (deliberate and evaluate) stop at evaluation. Those who *biàn* (dispute) merely argue the right and wrong of affairs—nothing more.

Beyond the six directions, the sage preserves but does not discuss. Within the six directions, the sage deliberates but does not evaluate. The *Chunqiu* evaluates but does not dispute—its traces of ordering the world consist in evaluation alone. The sage has deliberation.

The sage’s deliberation is not by choice—how could it compare to the common people, who exhaust themselves in disputation to impress one another?

In Zhuangzi’s book, the question of *wangliang* (shadowy reflections) and the shadow is posed: the shadow’s being a shadow seems to depend on form, yet in truth, it does not. The ignorant take rising, sitting, bowing, and lifting to be bound to form, yet how could the shadow truly depend on form? To insist that the shadow must depend on form, and form must depend on the Creator, is to fail to fathom *duhua* (solitary transformation). One who fathoms solitary transformation knows the shadow does not depend on form, nor form on the Creator—it culminates in nothingness. Thus it is said: how could one know the *suoyiran* (reason for being so) or *buran* (not being so)?

Zhuangzi speaks of dreaming he was a butterfly to express his self-contentment; he speaks of the joy of fish to express his self-delight. The butterfly, though small, flits and soars without limit. The fish, dwelling in the depths, preserves its life. Thus he lodges his meaning of self-contentment and self-preservation in these two creatures, aligning them with the harmony of all things.

*Zhiyan* (goblet words) are words that do not adhere to one form. Words that do not adhere multiply endlessly when set in motion—hence it is said: “Daily they emerge, never one.” Yet their emergence must have a root—hence it is said: “Harmonized with the *tianni* (natural celestial boundary).” *Tianni* is the wondrous root of spontaneity. Words with such a root respond to change without end—hence it is said: “Following it, they unfold boundlessly.” Words that respond to change without end transcend the limits of past and present, yet my own words know no such limit—hence it is said: “Thus they exhaust the years.” Though Zhuangzi’s words may seem unbounded and varied, they never depart from the root of the Dao. Thus Guo Xiang called him one who “knew the root”—this is what it means to understand Zhuangzi deeply.

What all things follow is the Dao. The Dao is what things follow, yet it is not confined to them. In greatness, it never exceeds; in minuteness, it never omits. Thus the natures and capacities of the ten thousand things each have their proper measure, and this is why Zhuang Zhou’s book speaks of the *kun* and *peng*, the cicada and fledgling dove, the quail and wren, the ant and sheep, the fish and butterfly, the horse and ox, the mountains and trees. The root of the Dao lies before the *Taiji* (Supreme Ultimate) yet is not lofty; it lies beneath the six poles yet is not deep. Before heaven and earth existed, it was not ancient; from antiquity it has endured, older than the oldest ages yet not long-lived. The ten thousand things differ—this is called *fu* (wealth); the harmonizing of differences is called *dafu* (great wealth); possessing them is called *daye* (great enterprise)—this is the sage.

Only after form exists does name arise; only after name exists does division arise; only after division exists does *shou* (guardianship) arise. Zhuangzi said: “Once form and name are clear, division and guardianship follow.”

Zhuangzi’s meaning in saying “not breaking the *moye* sword” or “not resenting the flying tile,” and his meaning in “not raging at the empty boat,” are the same. Heaven and earth possess great beauty yet do not speak; the four seasons have bright patterns yet do not deliberate; the ten thousand things have accomplished principles yet do not explain. Thus Confucius wished to be wordless, saying: “What does Heaven say? The four seasons proceed, the hundred things are born.” Who but one who embodies the Dao could attain this?

Following one’s nature is spontaneity; cultivating the Dao is making it so. Spontaneity is Heaven; making it so is man. Within spontaneity, there is being; beyond making it so, there is nothingness. How can man take away what he has or add to what he lacks? Thus what one has is one’s nature; what one lacks is what Zhuangzi called *chi* (excess). Virtue is what one already possesses. To add to what one already possesses is excess—hence it is said: “The conjoined toes and extra fingers arise from nature yet are excessive in virtue; the dangling growths and hanging wens arise from form yet are excessive in nature.”

The gentleman’s path has its limits of success and failure, but the sage’s Dao knows no dullness or sharpness. What people see is the “so.” The gentleman’s path has its limits, but his heart knows no difference between success and failure—hence it is said: “In failure, he delights; in success, he delights.” He takes success and failure as the sequence of cold and heat, wind and rain.

Zhuangzi said: “Do not let *gu* (habit) destroy *ming* (destiny).” Human ways are called *gu*; Heaven’s ways are called *ming*.

The Dao is like the year; the sage is like the seasons. Thus Zhuang Zhou wrote *Autumn Floods* to speak of *shizhi* (timeliness)—being timely is simply being of one’s time. Yet how fitting that petty scholars point to this and criticize it! No wonder he raged that one cannot speak of ice to a summer insect or of the sea to a well frog.

Zhuangzi said: “Yan Hui has forgotten benevolence and righteousness.” Yet he had not yet forgotten ritual and music. Benevolence and righteousness are forgotten first, ritual and music later—does this mean benevolence and righteousness are inferior to ritual and music? Zhuangzi first speaks of forgetting the inner, then the outer: benevolence and righteousness are inner; ritual and music are outer. Only when inner and outer are forgotten can one attain *zuowang* (sitting in forgetfulness). This is why his words differ.

The sage takes the necessary as unnecessary; the common people take the unnecessary as necessary. What does this mean? The great man’s words need not be trusted, his actions need not be decisive—he takes the necessary as unnecessary. Words must be trusted, actions must be decisive—this is taking the unnecessary as necessary. Zhuangzi’s words sometimes resemble those of sages and worthies; one cannot wholly dismiss them.

The sage does not establish intentions, yet intentions always remain; he does not possess a self, yet the self always exists. He moves only when pressed; he rises only when compelled. He does not move with intention, nor rise with a self—it is merely response. Zhuangzi said: “One who objectifies things is not objectified by things.” This aligns with Xunzi’s words: “One who is refined in the Dao objectifies things.” Stillness is the root; movement is the branch. Stillness in harmony with things is constant; movement in response to things is the sage. Stillness in separation from things, movement in conflict with things—this is the common people. The sage objectifies things; the common people are objectified by things—thus it is.

Confucius said: “The noble person studies to attain the Dao.” Zhuang Zhou said: “The Dao cannot be attained.” Confucius said: “As virtue, the *Doctrine of the Mean* is supreme.” Zhuangzi said: “Virtue cannot be reached.” Why is this? Confucius speaks of it as residing in man; Zhuang Zhou speaks of it as residing in Heaven. If it resides in Heaven, it is the Dao of spontaneity—how can it be attained? If virtue is self-attained, how can it be reached? If it resides in man, then without profound cultivation of the Dao, how can one attain the Dao? Without daily renewal of virtue, how can one attain virtue? Only one who can attain it may then not attain it; only one who can reach it may then not reach it.

Zhuang Zhou’s writings delve into the mysteries of nature and destiny, unraveling the scattered threads of Dao and virtue. They aim to dispel obscurity and replace it with clarity—this is the discourse of returning to the root and recovering destiny, the words that shatter measuring cups and break scales, from which such teachings arise. Yet though the Dao resides in the heart and converges in the mind, if one questions the Dao and receives no response, what need is there for words? For while wordlessness may suffice to exhaust the subtleties of the Dao, silence alone cannot make them manifest. Thus, one rises only when compelled, moves only when pressed, responds only when stirred—then mounts one’s discourse and carries it forward, enabling learners to grasp the meaning beyond images, and the images beyond words. This, too, is Zhuang Zhou’s intent in hoping to influence the world.

Zhuangzi spoke of the marsh pheasant confined in a cage, having lost its true nature. The utmost person of antiquity could forget their cunning mind, still their external concerns, align their heart with the great void, harmonize the Dao with yin and yang, and unite Heaven and Earth as one. For them, morning and eternity were a single storehouse; no person was strange, no thing too near or too distant. This transcends all bounds, unlike the marsh pheasant trapped in a cage.

Zhuangzi said: “The true person of antiquity made mistakes without regret; when rightness was unattainable, they did not force it.” Thus, even the sage is not without error. To err without self-reproach is to align with Heaven. If one aligns with others, there is correction without reluctance—this is why all look up to them. Yet winter’s warmth and summer’s chill are Heaven’s errors; if even Heaven errs, how much more the sage? Great fear is called dread; small fear is called anxiety. Zhuangzi said: “Great dread is boundless; small anxiety is restless.”

Zhuangzi’s writings penetrate the division of nature and destiny without being swayed by life and death, fortune and misfortune—they approach the sage. Without luminous wisdom, one cannot attain this. Even studying the words of the sages suffices to reach it; those who fail to do so and sink into Zhuangzi’s teachings create great disorder.

When the qi of night prevails, the myriad thoughts are stilled; if one cannot stabilize it, this is called “not attaining morning clarity.” To attain morning clarity is to recover the root of virtue.

There is that which surpasses the sage in stirring and animating the myriad things—this is spirit. That which shares the sorrows of the myriad things is the sage. If spirit is not sagely, it cannot act; if the sage does not act, they do not withdraw. Zhuang Zhou’s words exalt spirit and demean the sage—this is an overcorrection.

Zhuangzi said: “From its root, from its origin—the root is one.” In trees, the root lies below; the root of a tree ends at *gen* (the trigram of stillness). The root emerges from the origin, and the origin clings to the root—they depend on each other to live. Thus, the origin is destiny; the root is nature. Laozi said: “Return to the root” and “stillness”—this speaks of nature. “Stillness is called recovering destiny”—this speaks of the origin. In Zhuangzi’s writings, there are the “true person” and the “utmost person”: “true” speaks of their nature; “utmost” is the pinnacle of the human Dao.

Clarity is the dispersion of spirit; spirit is the storehouse of clarity. Thus, clarity arises from where spirit is directed. Therefore, it is said: “Clarity cannot surpass spirit.”

Laozi said: “The gate of Heaven opens and closes.” Zhuangzi said: “The gate of Heaven has no existence.” Because the myriad things emerge from it, it is called “opening and closing”; because the myriad things are stored within it, it is called “no existence.”

Zhuangzi’s words on the “primordial vastness” refer to the boundless expanse—endless, yet also without end. The myriad things flourish and take form within it—this is what is meant by “its limit unseen.”

The myriad things are complete within Heaven and Earth, yet Heaven and Earth have no intention toward them. Thus, it is said: “Great completeness is like Heaven and Earth—what need is there to seek it?” The myriad things are also complete within my body, yet I do not externally labor for things. Thus, it is said: “One who knows great completeness has no seeking.” In this way, one attains the Dao without loss. How can one abandon the self to chase things? Therefore, it is said: “No loss, no abandonment; do not let things alter the self.”

Zhuangzi said: “There are names and realities—these are the dwellings of things.” This means: in substance, it is substance; in function, it is function—this is how the myriad things arise. “Without name or reality—this is the emptiness within things.” This means: unseen, unheard, yet it must gather in emptiness. What can be spoken or conceived grows more distant; wordlessness and thoughtlessness bring the Dao closer.

Zhuang Zhou’s writings convey the subtleties of the Dao. Their words save nature and destiny before they scatter, awakening the world’s customs—how could they not be rooted in the Dao? The Dao is the sea; the sage is the hundred rivers. The Dao is the year; the sage is the seasons. Though the hundred rivers differ, what they share is the sea; though the four seasons differ, what they share is the year. Though the Daos of Confucius, Mencius, Laozi, and Zhuangzi adapt to different times, in essence, do they depart from this? To read Zhuangzi’s writings, seek their meaning and forget their words—this is the way of the good reader.

---

**Li Shibiao’s *Dream of the Butterfly*:**

The myriad things share a single root; right and wrong are one qi. What is Zhou? What is the butterfly? To take Zhou as not the butterfly is to fail to forget the self; to take the butterfly as not Zhou is to fail to forget things. Self and things oppose each other, giving rise to a thousand tangled forms—this is called “uneven,” but it is merely delusion. Do not know that things are inherently without things? Even the butterfly is not the self. Do not know that the self is inherently without self? Even Zhou is an illusion. How could there be division?

Flitting about in a dream as a butterfly—then the butterfly is Zhou. Startled awake as Zhou—then Zhou is without the butterfly. This is what is seen alone, yet what is equal in things.

To regard one’s body as private, to cling to the myriad things, to take waking as the opening of form and affairs as real, to take dreaming as the mingling of souls and illusions as empty—this is not knowing that a single night’s waking and dreaming are the opening and closing of one form.

A single form’s opening and closing, a single nature’s coming and going—such is the Way. To transform into a thing brings sorrow; to return to being human brings joy. Yet why should things be worthy of sorrow? Why should being human be worthy of joy? This is merely the ceaseless flux of the ten thousand transformations, without beginning or end.

To cling to one’s form, secretly cherishing it as private—this is delusion. Only with great awakening does one know the great dream; only with the true person does true knowledge arise. The dreamer does not know the awakened, so does not take the dream as delusion. The awakened does not know the dream, so does not take awakening as real. Zhou does not know the butterfly, so does not take the butterfly as non-butterfly. The butterfly does not know Zhou, so does not take Zhou as correct. The numinous source is profound and still—wherever it touches, all is known. Transformations arise in succession, yet it meets each without choosing, and the mind has never once possessed knowledge.

Thus, this chapter establishes Ziqí’s "mourning the self" to open the gateway of "equalizing things," and lodges Zhuang Zhou’s "dreaming of the butterfly" to complete the meaning of "equalizing things." Alas! The whole world is asleep, and the world is but one dream. The oak of the sacred grove warned a man in a dream; the turtle of the Yuan Lord sought escape in a dream; the laborer of the Yin family found joy in a dream; the man of Zheng who caught a deer sued over it in a dream; and Huaxu wandered the emperor’s realm in a dream. Those who attain the Dao meet each circumstance and rest in it, knowing it as illusion and not real. Why should this case alone be different?

Those who embody the Dao loosen what obstructs to open its blockages, still themselves to gather emptiness, cultivate sincerity to quicken the spirit, and settle into tranquility to return to illumination. They regard the world’s gains and losses, right and wrong, honor and disgrace, success and failure, life and death as mere dreams and illusions. Why doubt only Zhou and the butterfly?

The true person of old slept without dreaming and awoke without care. I have long pondered this and know that Zhou’s words are not mere allegory. The "Butcher" who "dissolves the ox" is one who embodies the self-emptiness of things. Treading the ten thousand transformations, he remains ever unobstructed. Those who cling to things as real respond to every path and become mired. Things are inherently without things, their substance naturally detached. The Dao is nowhere unpervading—where is there need for "dissolving," and what is this "dissolving of the ox"?

To wield the knife for nineteen years—through the cycles of yin and yang—is no short span. To dissolve thousands of oxen—responding to the world’s changes—is no small number. One might suspect the blade worn out, yet its edge is as if newly sharpened. This is because clinging to traces, each moment is already past; grasping the root, it endures unchanged through the ages. The wondrously still substance moves yet does not waver; the luminously empty function enters the dust yet is not defiled.

Consider: the body is already illusion—what knife could perform the carving? The ten thousand things are all delusion—what ox could be dissolved? With the knife, there is that by which it endures; with the ox, there is that by which things are established. Self and other merge, ability and object dissolve. Roaming freely in the ancestor of the ten thousand things, its emptiness is unobstructed.

Thus, it never strikes yet the great gaps naturally part; never guides yet the great cavities naturally release; never contends yet those of like kind naturally cohere; never acts yet the sinews and joints naturally align—how much more the great void! With this, the knife resounds *huo* yet bears no labor of response; its movement is subtle, without the mind that competes with things. Releasing the knife, it faces the ox without the burden of lingering; raising the knife, it stands without the pursuit of fleeing things. When its use is complete, it will again care for the blade and return it to non-use. This is why the knife has never been harmed.

Though the utmost Dao is nowhere present, in its wondrous function it responds without responding. In the hand, it responds to touch yet does not know the hand is there; on the shoulder, it responds to leaning yet does not know the shoulder is there; in the foot, it responds to stepping yet does not know the foot is there; at the knee, it responds to propping yet does not know the knee is there. The heavenly mechanism unfolds of itself, and none knows it. The great function makes no choices, yet all is as it should be. This is why the knife’s capacity is vast, with room to spare.

Once the mind perceives the ox, there is the burden of dissolving it, and the principle of preserving life is already harmed. This is why the skilled butcher replaces his knife yearly due to cutting, and the mediocre butcher replaces his monthly due to breaking. This knife—neither ancient nor modern, time cannot grasp it; neither long nor short, number cannot confine it; neither new nor old, transformation cannot alter it; neither thick nor thin, substance cannot fix it. Its inherent hardness is not forged yet remains firm; its profound function is not tempered yet remains bright. Butcher Ding uses it as if casting earth to the ground, while the mediocre butcher sees only difficulty.

From the Dao’s obscurity, in dissolution there is no dissolution; without obstruction, dissolution is also unknown. In obstruction there is no obstruction; without dissolution, obstruction also does not arise. From Butcher Ding’s perspective, the mediocre butcher dissolves his obstructions. From the mediocre butcher’s perspective, Butcher Ding is obstructed by his dissolution. When both dissolution and obstruction are cast aside, emptiness alone remains.

Zhuang Zhou’s intent in lodging the butcher’s parable is to place the cultivation of life after the "equalizing of things" and "free and easy wandering." Why? Those who are confined by the burdens of form cannot wander freely; those who are bound by distinctions of great and small cannot equalize things. Thus, they toil amidst the dust, their blades dulled in the mire of entanglement, and their lives are seldom unharmed. Only those inwardly without self can wander freely in the realm of self-attainment; only those outwardly without things can equalize things in the domain of ultimate unity. Thus embodying the Dao, they roam among the ten thousand things—where could they be obstructed?

Therefore, Zhuang Zhou begins with the analogy of dissolving the ox, and Lord Wenhui thereby attains the cultivation of life.

Viewed from the nothingness of things, the true and constant is profoundly still, enduring unchanged through the ages. Viewed from the existence of things, the great transformation shifts in the blink of an arm’s turn. Those who grasp this see even the flowing realm as the unchanging source. Thus, floating dust may merge with the great void, and autumn hairs may bind heaven and earth. Entrusting the ten thousand transformations to the unchanging—how could one carry it away and flee? Where would one go?

Those who fail to grasp this regard their finite lives as lodged in a place of certain escape. Yet the lamp’s flame is not the same from moment to moment; the body’s form is not the same from past to present. Even if one clings to it and tries to retain it, it departs in obscurity. This is why Zhuang Zhou spoke of hiding the boat in the ravine and the mountain in the marsh—the ravine and marsh, with their empty and luminous function, serve to illustrate the Creator’s lack of intent; the boat and mountain, with their movement and stillness, serve to illustrate the existence of form. The Dao is one—this oneness is inherently without direction. The ravine and marsh, however, are directional.

The One is inherently without form; the boat and mountain possess form. The One follows movement and stillness, wandering within the directional; when the One is deluded by emptiness and luminosity and confined by form, then the One becomes paired from this point onward. There is flourishing and decay as its pair, new and old as its pair, life and death as its pair. The One, being without duality, moves alone and comes alone, without past or present. In pairing, there is coupling, thus things take shape and vie against one another, arising and perishing in succession. Therefore, to conceal fire within fire is the One; to conceal it in water extinguishes it. To conceal water within water is the One; to conceal it in earth buries it. How much more so with the boat and mountain, which already possess form, and the ravine and marsh, which already possess direction—if one grasps and conceals them, there is already intent. Yet the Creator, who has never begun to have things, can carry them away in the dead of night.

Nevertheless, only that which is not a thing can give rise to things; only that which does not transform can transform all transformations. Swift as a gallop, fleeting as a breath, the days pass in an instant without pause—transformation is thus impermanent. I have realized this: it is precisely because the Creator deludes the myriad movements into having intent that they falsely perceive existence and annihilation. When this intent exists, things exist; when this intent perishes, things perish. When one conceals them in ravine and marsh, the intent sees them as secure—unaware that not even the slightest trace has ever stood firm, and in an instant, they are lost. At midnight, the intent sees them as gone—unaware that not even the slightest trace has ever moved. Only by knowing the great constancy that sustains them can one wander where things cannot escape, and all that things cannot escape abides. This is where the myriad things are bound, where the single transformation awaits.

The ancients concealed the world within the world by this means. The world is the unity of the myriad things, and humanity is but one of those myriad things. If one truly attains the wholeness of the One, then one knows that the transformations of the ten thousand things have never had an end. In movement, there is nothing that is not the self—thus, whether heaven ages or time begins and ends, all is desired without aversion. Compared to those who, upon assuming human form, rejoice in it, how can their joy be measured? The ancients spoke of this: "All things are complete within me; turn inward and be sincere—no joy is greater." This joy, though the deluded use it all day, remains unknown to them. You dwell in it, you array it, you wander with things in the inn of creation—how could you attain Zhuang Zhou’s concealing of the world within the world and discuss it? *Sitting in forgetfulness*—the mind is not yours; who else possesses it?

These are but provisional names arising from the accumulation of conditioned habits. The body is not yours—who else possesses it? It is but an illusory arising from the harmonious union of a hundred bones. Know that the mind is no-mind and the ten thousand things are all my mind—what need is there to discard wisdom and clarity? Know that the body is no-body and the myriad forms are all my body—what need is there to cast off limbs and faculties? How much less, then, for benevolence and righteousness? How much less for rites and music? If this is so, then in movement and stillness, speech and silence, there is nothing that is not the wondrous locus. In freedom and constraint, reversal and compliance, there is nothing that is not celestial wandering. Who would recognize this as forgetting?

Otherwise, if one flees disturbance to seek quiescence, fears having to delight in nothingness—this is called forgetting—then even clods of earth and heaps of dust could be said to have forgotten. Yan Hui approached the sage yet did not fully attain it; he surpassed the multitude yet retained something. Following the spontaneous emptiness of the One transformation, he understood: the one who is without thing-ness is the sage; the one who is bound to phenomena and swept away with them is the common person. Understanding no-thing-ness, there is nowhere one does not forget; bound to thing-ness, there is no time one can forget. This is why Yan Hui practiced *sitting in forgetfulness*.

Reversing the flow of the ten thousand things’ turning realm, he dimly merged with the unchanging source of the One nature. In tranquil contemplation of the world, benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music were all seen as empty names. In the silent illumination of the numinous source, limbs, faculties, wisdom, and clarity were all recognized as illusory perceptions. Forgetting things, there are no things—empty names naturally fall away. Forgetting the self, there is no self—illusory perceptions naturally cease. Yet benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music do not name themselves; the deluded cling to them as names. Limbs and faculties, wisdom and clarity do not perceive themselves; the deluded take them as perceptions.

Know that the body arises from non-being—then limbs and faculties will naturally fall away. Yet one who insists on casting them off has not departed from the view of the body. Know that the mind arises from non-arising—then wisdom and clarity will naturally be discarded. Yet one who insists on discarding them has not departed from the view of the mind. Moreover, if even limbs and faculties are not, how can benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music exist? In the past, one cultivated virtue in the liver and diaphragm, and every thing knew; now, there is no knowing. In the past, one employed the mind between the brows and lashes, and every thing was seen; now, there is no seeing. Is this not *sitting in forgetfulness*?

Yet once it is called forgetting, Confucius could not tolerate questions, and Yan Hui could not tolerate responses. How could one know the slightest gain? How could one know the slightest loss? How could one know that the forgetting of benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music is not yet complete? How could one know that the casting off of limbs, faculties, wisdom, and clarity is the ultimate attainment?

Viewed from the wondrous: the one who falls forgets the chariot; the one who drowns forgets the water; the person forgets the Dao and its arts; the fish forgets the rivers and lakes—this, too, is forgetting. Viewed from the coarse: the one who gains forgets form; the one who profits forgets truth; the one who waves an arm forgets the chariot ruts; the one who seizes gold forgets the marketplace—this, too, is forgetting. Shall we say that one is right and the other wrong? The Dao has no right or wrong. Shall we say that one is real and the other false? The Dao has no real or false.

Yan Hui turned his back on the dust and returned to the wondrous, diminished the substantial and gathered the empty—this is what I know of his forgetting, yet it was not yet forgetting. If he had advanced further on this Way, not forgetting would also be forgetting. This is why Confucius, at sixty, transformed sixty times—what value, then, is there in forgetting? Master Huzhi.

The wondrous workings of the spirit have never revealed their marvels, nor have those who receive its marvels ever known them—this is what we call the spirit. Those shamans, however, deceive with words of spirits, proclaiming life and death, survival and ruin, fortune and misfortune, long life and early demise to others. Though their verifications may seem as timely as months, days, or even hours—appearing marvelous yet not truly so—they are but semblances of the spirit. Having called them spirits, we then speak of Ji Xian, for he embodies the marvel of things that respond to stimuli.

Moreover, Ji Xian possesses responsiveness, and with responsiveness comes a heart. When one uses one’s own heart to sense another’s heart, one’s own perceptions to see another’s perceptions, then the false names of life and death, survival and ruin, fortune and misfortune arise. Once names are false, perceptions become false as well; once perceptions are false, words become false. Those in the world who cling to appearances and cannot dispel delusion further accept these falsehoods as truth, fleeing in haste. Even Liezi, upon witnessing this, became intoxicated in heart, for he had not yet hollowed out his heart. He had not yet severed learning. Thus, others could still read your fortune, Master Hu.

The essence of the Hu-vessel lies in emptiness and imperishability; its function, in profound clarity and unfathomable depth. You, however, possess the Way of emerging from the mother to engage the world, thus able to lodge the formless within the realm of forms. Ji Xian, by contrast, responds with a heart, so each time he enters, he claims to see. But when one responds without a heart, as you do, each time he arrives, he can only say you have shown him something. Without a heart, you tread beyond form; how could he read your fortune? Transcending numbers, you stand before the unnumbered; how could he know you?

Ji Xian remains shackled to form and number, never free from perception. Where perception dwells, he takes life and death as fixed, inescapable truths. Thus, at first, you showed him the pattern of earth, and he sighed at your death. Next, you showed him the expanse of heaven and earth, and he rejoiced at your life. Unaware that death originally had no death—only the extinction of the heart—nor that life originally had no life—only the arising of the heart—he saw the arising and extinction of the heart as the presence and absence of form.

The perfected one has never possessed a heart. At rest, they share virtue with yin; in motion, they flow with yang. Sharing virtue with yin, they cannot be seen. Thus, you had to show him the pattern of earth, for patterns are where things intermingle. Flowing with yang, they cannot be seen. Thus, you had to show him the expanse of heaven and earth, for earth is where things arise. When you showed him the Great Thoroughfare, he deemed it unequal—for in the pattern of earth, yin prevails over yang; in the expanse of heaven and earth, yang prevails over yin; but in the Great Thoroughfare, neither yin nor yang prevails, and heaven and earth stand in perfect balance. The myriad dharmas are one, originally without high or low. Seeing inequality, he failed to grasp this.

Yet all three are called "mechanisms," for they reveal the subtlest stirrings before they manifest. Thus, he could perceive them. When you showed him "never yet having departed from our origin," you showed him departure from all that could be shown. He cast reality upon you, but you responded with emptiness; he approached with being, but you received him with non-being. His arising heart and labored perceptions were finite, while your detachment from others and concealment of heaven were infinite. When the finite confronts the infinite, it is undone—this is why Ji Xian fled at the sight of you, vanishing upon pursuit.

Though Master Hu told Liezi, "This is seeing my mechanism of blocking virtue," and "This is nearly seeing my mechanism of goodness," and "This is seeing my mechanism of balancing qi"—all referring to "me"—when I empty myself and follow along, neither knowing who acts nor who is acted upon, even I lose myself. Who, then, is showing? Who is being read? Thus, he fled.

Master Hu’s heart is the Great Void. The essence of the Great Void is empty clarity, wondrous stillness, embracing and upholding the ten thousand things. Adorn it with splendor, and it does not linger; strike it with blades, and it is unharmed; drench it with water, and it is not soaked; scorch it with fire, and it is not burned. This is its nature.

Master Hu’s heart: confronted with death, he receives it without aversion; greeted with life, he receives it without delight. Named as unequal, he receives it without contention. In the end, Ji Xian lost himself and vanished—yet this was not because he had attained anything, but simply because of this emptiness.

Zhuang Zhou discusses the response of emperors and kings in this way: the emperor-king responds to the world by abiding in stillness, unmoving, thus able to resonate and fully communicate. Retreating to concealment, they share weal and woe with the people. But if one emerges from this origin, fretting over the world as one’s own burden, enslaved by the ten thousand things rather than mastering them, can others then read your fortune? This is why the emperors and kings of old were vast and boundless, beyond all naming.

The Dark Pearl lies north of the Red Water’s source, containing yang yet not flowing. The Kunlun peaks stand serene, unyielding—thus mirroring the self-originating nature of one’s inherent essence. Gazing southward, one encounters things and stirs; returning inward, one traverses movement yet circles back—thus mirroring the nature that reverts to its origin. Once the celestial nature unfolds, dusty realms arise in tandem, and human artifice drifts ever farther from the great Dao. Is not the Dark Pearl its remnant?

Yet nature cannot be known through human effort—who then can impose knowledge upon it? Nature cannot be grasped through intentional seeking—who then can claim to find it? To impose knowledge is not to gather emptiness; to seek it is not to silently align. Do these three masters exhaust their wisdom in what they wish to know? Do their eyes fail in what they wish to see, their mouths weary in what they wish to speak? Why is it that the Dao, though subtle, abides equally in drifting dust and clods of earth, while the utterly real dwells near, undivided from the space between one’s brows, never distant from the primal image? It flows forth from the realm of the square inch, sprawling across the expanse of daily use. Yet to pursue it is like facing a dark mountain—ever more distant; to inquire of it is like questioning the vast earth—utterly lost. This is because seeking yields no attainment.

Moreover, nature is originally without knowledge, yet what is called "knowledge" is not true knowledge. Nature is originally without sight, yet what is called "seeing" is not true seeing. Nature is originally without speech, yet what is called "speech" is not true speech. To take knowledge as nature and seek knowledge through knowledge is to become deluded by knowledge. To take sight as nature and seek sight through sight is to become obstructed by sight. To take speech as nature and seek speech through speech is to become bound by speech. What is called "image" seems to exist yet does not; what is called "net" seems absent yet is not. To discard knowledge is to awaken from delusion; to discard sight is to attain clarity; to discard speech is to loosen bonds. Only through this "image-net" can one alone attain it.

When one delves into the root of the Dao, even a sage like the Yellow Emperor, with all his aspirations, loses it, while the foolish Xiangwang, with no intent, gains it. Yet when one obscures the great Dao, whether nature is present or absent, whether one attains or loses, whether sagely or ordinary—all is reversed. In the past, the Yellow Emperor lost it yet suffered no slightest lack; now, Xiangwang gains it yet acquires no slightest gain. Through ancient and present time alike, the true and constant alone is revealed. Profoundly deluded, profoundly awakened—all become the enlightened nature. Who is to say that the three masters’ failure is not true attainment, or that Xiangwang’s success is not the right way? Thus, even the Yellow Emperor stands apart—yet at the Hao-Liang, he too...

The myriad things share commonality—do they share in the One? The One shares commonality—does it share in the Dao? The Dao’s attainment comes from nowhere. That which is born arises of itself, yet birth itself is unborn; that which takes form shapes itself, yet form itself is formless. All that spreads forth amid appearances, images, sounds, and colors—none lacks this Dao. What then should I choose among things?

The allotment of the One Nature is complete, with nothing left over; the wandering of the One Heaven is unbound, with no encumbrance. Both things and I possess it. Only those who harmonize with the knowledge of things and self may, without intending to know, know its wonder; without seeking union, unite with its principle; without striving to meet, merge with its spirit—first receiving what cannot be escaped, roaming where none precede. This is how Zhuangzi knew the fish’s joy above the Hao-Liang.

Now, to emerge and glide, to swim without the dryness of foam, without the peril of nets—leisurely in the midst of the One Water—is this what constitutes the fish’s joy? Taking this as joy, *Qi Xie* already knew it. Why wait for Zhou to know? For the fish’s joy lies in the Dao, not in the water; Zhou’s knowledge lies in joy, not in the fish. Only when the fish forgets the water is its joy whole; only when Zhou forgets the fish does his knowledge become absolute.

Supreme joy is without joy; true knowledge is without knowledge. Zhou did not intend to know, yet knew. Thus Zhuang Zhou harmonized with it beyond all things—perhaps without words. Huizi once shared with him a bond of perfect accord—perhaps without questions. Zhuangzi was not incapable of silence; Huizi was not incapable of awakening. Yet if there were no question, Zhou’s words would have no ground; if there were no words, the Dao’s wonder would have no manifestation. The aim was simply to dispel the later world’s delusion of separating self and things into two.

If things inherently possess their own thingness, then Zhou is certainly not the fish—how could he know that I know the fish’s joy? Or if I inherently possess my own selfhood, then the fish is certainly not Zhou—how could I know that I do not know the fish’s joy? Knowing and not knowing are both branches of the Dao. This is why Zhou asked to return to the root.

The root has never been unknown. Yan He once spoke of it: the eye is like the ear, the ear...

The nose is like the mouth, the mouth like the nose—none differ. What is within me is thus: seeing death as life, wealth as poverty, Zhou as the fish, others as swine, myself as others. What is within things is thus: thus, every thing arrives, roaming without place that is not wondrous—why only above the Hao River? Thus, every thing is truly joyful, without harmony that is not heavenly—why only the joy of the minnows? I know that Zhou and the fish were never divided. Yet in composing the "Autumn Floods," he began with the River Lord and North Sea If vaunting their smallness and greatness, then with the creatures Kui and Feng pitying their presence and absence—how could he know that things are one and joy is complete? Thus, Zhou entrusted the joy of the minnows to convey his intent, and the discourse on utmost joy arose therefrom.

The ancients, enlightened to utmost joy’s absence, often expressed it in their words: "What joy? What aversion?" One who falls from a cart, clinging to things as if seeing something, truly sees the cart; taking the self as real and known, truly falls. With knowledge and perception established, cart and fall divide—how could there be no harm? Yet the drunken man’s wholeness in wine dissolves knowledge and obscures perception; he knows not the cart’s fall, knows not the earth, knows not his body’s touch, knows not touch’s wound—serene, without division.

Even one who temporarily entrusts wholeness to wine can transcend life and death, forgetting fear—how much more one whose nature’s wholeness has never departed? The world is but a cart; those who ride it, inwardly vexed by knowledge and perception, outwardly pursued by illusory disturbances, will soon overturn in the realm of delusions—not merely suffering bodily harm or the intrusion of fear. Once the receptacle opens, myriad forms enter, like the sober witnessing a cart’s overturn—how could there be no harm?

Yet at the inception of form, heaven and earth were born with me; at the origin of numbers, the myriad things were one with me. What thing is the cart? What thing is the person? What thing is the fall? What thing is the wound? When mind and things oppose, heaven is sundered and the human arises; when mind and things merge, the human departs and heaven’s mechanism remains. Machinery gone, what follows is heaven’s principle; fittingly fused, what is embodied is heaven’s harmony. Moving without trace is called "heavenly roaming"; acting without bounds is called "heavenly mechanism." Nothing is sufficient to trouble it—this is "heavenly joy"; nothing is sufficient to beautify it—this is "heavenly harmony." Therewith, serving heaven requires no toil; therewith, assisting heaven requires no aid. This is called "wholeness in heaven."

Those who view gain and loss, sorrow and joy, life and death, poverty and success as the drunken man’s cart-fall—when Zhou expounded this in the "Attaining Life" chapter, he meant that the living must perish, and the perishing must live. Knowing that life is fundamentally non-life, he said: "Inwardly observe without mind, outwardly observe without body, broadly observe without things"—only then can one unify one’s nature without duality, nourish one’s qi without dissipation, harmonize one’s virtue without departure, and penetrate what things create without being ensnared. Where could one go that is not heaven?

Form whole in heaven, and forms have never existed; sound whole in heaven, and sounds have never arisen; sight whole in heaven, and colors have never appeared; taste whole in heaven, and flavors have never presented themselves—this is called "wholeness in heaven." This chapter first entrusted this to the drunken man’s cart-fall, then followed with the avenger who does not break the sword Moye, and then with the resentful man who does not blame the flying tile—why? Things are inherently non-things—what mind for existence? The self is inherently non-self—what mind for things? Things and self were never divided. Thus, the fallen are not harmed, the avenger does not break, the resentful does not blame—all is heaven’s natural emptiness.

Yet because it opposes the human, it is called "heaven"; because one’s nature is non-nature, how could there be heaven? Because it opposes division, it is called "concealment"; because heaven is non-heaven, how could there be concealment? Realizing this, one accords with the wondrous purport of "Attaining Life."

The *Daoshu* says: Those who speak of the Dao ask, "Where is the Dao?" If one says it is nowhere, does one expect it to be in being? The ancients have spoken of it: in antiquity, it is not antiquity; in the present, it is not the present; in yin, it is not yin; in yang, it is not yang; in the distant, it does not leave the eyebrows; in the near, it alone transcends images. In gathering, it flows forth into the myriad existents; in scattering, it withdraws into a single hair. Is the Dao truly in being?

If one expects it to be in non-being, the ancients have spoken of it: in heaven, it is heaven; on earth, it is earth; filling valleys, it fills valleys; filling pits, it fills pits; existing in ants, existing in tiles and pebbles—is the Dao truly in non-being? Non-being is not absent; it is called "non-being," yet true non-being is not non-existent. Being is not present; it is called "being," yet true being is not existent. That which is present in all is beyond the names of being and non-being.

The ancients, enlightened to the wondrous presence of this "all-present" in the world, dared not liken it to forms or numbers, dared not glance at it through boundaries or domains. They forcibly named that which spans antiquity and the present, self-completing in dispersal and unity, as "the ancients’ great body"—like myriad waters reflecting the moon’s embrace, myriad apertures roaring with a single wind’s impulse, myriad images arrayed by a single qi’s accumulation, myriad things entangled at a single Dao’s source.

Spiritual beings attain it and descend as emperors; kings attain it and give birth to success; heaven and humans attain it without departing from the origin; divine humans attain it without departing from essence; perfected humans attain it without departing from truth. The sage transforms thereby; the noble person practices kindness and benevolence thereby; it is the model for names and calculations, the pattern for the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music. The ancients approached it as the *Dao* and *shu*—not burdening the mind, thus it cannot be called "mind-shu"; not chiseling with wisdom, thus it cannot be called "wisdom-shu"; not a mechanism, thus it cannot be called "mechanism-shu"; not a technique, thus it cannot be called "technique-shu." This *shu* is called the Dao—its comprehensiveness is all-pervading.

Alas! The great whole shattered into the fragments of "morality," and the hundred schools of thought, following their partial visions, became mired, believing the *Dao* and *shu* resided therein. Unmoved by life, unmoved by death, Mo Di and Qin Guli heard its wind and delighted in it, becoming people who did too much for others and too little for themselves. Song Jian and Yin Wen heard its wind and delighted in it, mocking the exalted and unrestrained, lacking conduct yet condemning the great sages. Peng Heng and Shen Dao heard its wind and delighted in it, taking humility as their exterior and emptiness as their core. Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard its wind and delighted in it. These several masters either became mired in the Dao through solitary burdens they could not bear, or through ceaseless clamor, or through theories of life and death, or through vast domains. Calculating their *shu* within the Dao, it is like a speck in a great marsh.

As a grain of millet in the Grand Granary, as a pebble beside Mount Tai, as a hair’s tip upon a horse’s body—from what each has seen, they differ, yet from the Dao they have attained, one cannot tell their difference. Why is this? A single stone’s insignificance and Mount Tai alike complete the form; a single grain’s fineness and the Grand Granary alike fulfill the count; a speck of dust and the great marsh share in emptiness; a single hair and the horse’s body alike are fully equipped. Though the Hundred Schools rend the Dao in myriad directions, in great substance they have never departed from it.

Alas! Without the Hundred Schools, there is no Great Completeness; without the Great Completeness, there are no Hundred Schools. Without the Hundred Schools, the Great Completeness cannot be seen; without the Great Completeness, the Hundred Schools cannot stand—their origin is one. Those who all day possess the Great Completeness yet do not know it are the common people; those who aspire to the Great Completeness yet have not reached it are the worthy; those who have exhausted the Great Completeness and effaced its traces are the sages.

This is what Yao and Shun passed on to each other; what Yu and Tang received and transmitted; what the Duke of Zhou gazed up and pondered; what Confucius immersed his heart and immersed in; what Mencius cultivated and nourished; what Yi Yin first awakened and awakened to. Zhuang Zhou’s book concludes with this chapter, profoundly embracing the root of the great Dao, vigorously sweeping away the Hundred Schools’ flaws—yet in the end, with absurd and boundless words, he ranks himself among those several masters, deeply exposing the traces of his writing to enlighten later ages and the world to come. Who would say Zhou was obscured by Heaven and became a one-sided scholar?

*Zhuangzi: Supplementary Wings, Appendix*
